Gettysburg announces Cosby Scholarship

Noted educator and entertainer Bill
Cosby was the speaker for Gettysburg's
162nd Commencement exercises held this
past May 1. At that time, the College an
nounced its establishment of a scholarship
in the name of Ennis Cosby, the speaker's
late son, who was killed earlier this year.
According to the announcement, be
ginning in 1998 funds donated by Gettys
burg College trustees will be used to annu
ally provide a partial scholarship to a stu
dent attending Gettysburg College. Approxi
mately 40 current and past College trustees
have made initial donations of almost
$50,000 to the fund.
The Ennis Cosby Scholarship will be
awarded with preference to students who

Award established in memory of entertainer's late son

from Staff Repor ts

have particular interest in becoming teach
ers. Preference will also be given to stu
dents from the greater Philadelphia area.
"When one considers the lifetime of
caring and giving that Bill Cosby has un
selfishly lived, the tragic death of Ennis,
his only son, virtually begged for a com
passionate, yet dignified response," said
Bruce Stefany, the Gettysburg trustee who
coordinated the scholarship fund-raising
among the trustees. "We were looking for
an effort that would carry forward the good
works of Bill cosby and those that were done
by Ennis. We know we cannot replace the
person, but Gettysburg College is commit
ted, through the scholarship, to helping oth
ers complete Ennis' unfulfilled pursuits in
education and teaching," added Stefany.
Cosby indicated an interest in address
ing the Gettysburg graduates in 1996, as part

Bill Cosby congratulates graduating senior Eric Chalek at Commencement last May

photo by Mark Astrom

of his effort to speak at all the colleges he
competed against as a football and track ath
lete at Temple University.
In his conferring the honorary degree
upon Cosby, College president, Gordon
Haaland called Cosby's past achievements

"classics of American comedy." Haaland
also told the entertainer that "You have dis
mantled barriers of race and color and set
aside stereotypes, gently but firmly, by be
ing yourself. You have helped make us com
fortable with difference and diversity; you

have somehow taught us to value both our
racial and cultural identity, and our com
mon humanity. In triumph and in tragedy,
you've shown us how it's done. We are
proud to claim you as a native Pennsylva
nian."

Special Orientation Issue


Gettysburg: a beginner's guide to campus life

"I'll meet you in fifteen
minutes at Stine Lake and we can
head over to Servo. Or maybe
we can just go to LD's, but first I
have to swing over to the CUB
and hit the MAC."
Your friend just called
and left this message on you an
swering machine. You've been
here for less than a week, so natu
rally you think, "what is he talk
ing about?" Have no fear, new
student, because this handy litle
glossary of Gettysburg-speak is

sure to get you through these so
cial straits unscathed and sound
ing like an old 'Burg pro.
First things first. "Where
am I now?" and "You want me to
go where?"
Servo: a.k.a. the Dining
Hall. Probably nicknamed back
when the college's dining service
was contracted out to a company
called Servomation (eons ago).
Anyhow, you eat here. Tip: Get
here early on Premium Entree
Night. The Cordon Bleu rules.

CUB: a.k.a. The Col
lege Union Building. Here you
will find the mailroom, school
store, ballroom, first-year student
laundry room and the campus al
ternative to Servo, Cafe 101.
The Junction (for -
meriy known as _tlieEtive): This
is a place that studetn organiza
tions can hold meetings, the Stu
dent Activities Council has live
performances and movies, and
where students can just hang out.
Cafe 101: a.k.a. the
Bullet Hole. Looking for a quick

snack while you're on the run?
Travel beyond the Junction, past
the mailroom, and you're in The
Hole. You have $3.75 on you
meal card that's good for break
fast, lunch and dinner. Remem
ber, only two prepackaged items
per meal. The catch to Cafe 101
is that you can only use your meal
cards at specific hours: 8:00 -
10:15 am for breakfast, 1:30 -
4:00 pm for lunch, and 4:30- 9:00
pm for dinner. However, it stays
open until midnight in case
you're in the mood for a late night
snack.

Mailroom: Every week
day, between 11:30 am and 1 pm,
the mailroom transforms from a
drab series of metal boxes into the
very epicenter of social activity at
Gettysburg College. Here the
evening's plans are made, adn flirt
ing is perfected, check your mail,
two, three, four times a day!
MAC: a.k.a. Money Ac
cess Center, this is an automated
teller machine outside the CUB. It's
the same as MOST, Cirrus, or what
ever you're used to. This innocent
looking machine cna be both a Fri
day night life-saver and a Sunday
morning nightmare. Beware of the
lure of fast cash.
MusseknanLibrar y: It's
Tuesday night and nothing's going
on. where can I go to hang out and
meet new people? The Library is
the answer. On any given evening,
the first floors are filled with stu
dents pretending to study while

picking up the lastest gossip on
campus. Plus, when you get home
and find that your parents have
called, you can honestly say that
you were at the library. But being
there and studying are two entriely
different issues. If you really need
to do some work, the third adn
fourth fllors are your best bet. Night
owls will be happy to see that the
library is opne 24 hours a day. And
for those slaves to the almighty
bean, librarians brew coffee and
provide hot water for tea adn cocoa
for those students pulling all
nighters. Also, the library has three
day/three movie video rentals. They
may not have all the newest re
leases, but they do have some of the
best movies ever made. The library
is one of the three "Mussleman"
locations on campus, the others be
ing Mussleman stadium, and
Mussleman Hall, located in the
_Upperclass Quad.

Bream Wright Hauser:
This is the campus gym adn field
house. It's located beyond the CUB
adn across hte street from the Apple
apartments. Be sure you don't con
fuse Bream with the...
Plank Gym: This older
_eym is found between the CUB and

Masters Hall. There s a games 334-0505: Advanced sys
room adn fitness room in the base- tem run by the local newspaper,
ment. WZBT, the college radio sta- The Gettysburg Time. This one
tion at 91.1 FM is located in the gives you options. D j ai i131 fora

basement. Make some requests
and bug the DJ by dialing x6313.
Many studetn organizations also
call Plank home, including the Stu
dent Activites office, GECO
(enviornmental concerns organiza
tion), the Black Student Union,
Student Senate, the Gettysburgian,
the Spectrum (yearbook), and the
IFC (Interfraternity Council), the
Center for Public Service is also in
Plank, but on the first floor.
Stine Lake: Not really a
lake at all, Stine Lake is actually
the open area between Plank Gym
and the library. One theory for the
origin of its odd name may be that
the field is known to flood during
heavy stroms. Almost knee-deep
water is not unusual on the "lake."
After a nastystorm, put on old
clothes, go out, slide around and
have your own little Woodstock.

Brua Hall, Kline The
ater,andStevens Theater: These
are all the same place and for that
reason, it can get rather confusing.
Schmucker Hall: This is
the colege's art and music build
ing. Stop in and check out the art
gallery which is filled with the
work of your fellow
gettysburgians. Frequent recitals
and concerts there, too. and they're
free! Other Important Stuff
OneRing/_T woRings: If
the phone rings once, it's an on
campus cal, and you can risk an
swering it with a more creative
greeting. If it has a double ring,
it's most likely Mom and shoudl be
anwered accordingly.

The Weather Guy(s):

to get time adn hte local weather.

Lincoln Diner: a.k.a

aconscious amigo and hit the

rules. Pizza, pizza, pizza:
Each with its own pros adn cons,

Ernie s Texas Lunch:
Located across Chambersburg
Street from K&K Records, Ernie's
has been catering to the lunch adn

vegetarians out there, Ernies of
fers "The Dummy" - a hot dog

ter than rolling out of bed on a

ing like a set from "American

Blizzard fands will love the
Distlewhip.

Of course, there s much

its enviorns, but with all this new
insider knowledge, you'll be ready
for anything the school can throw
at you. Have a great year!

College receives grant for Civil war Studies program

gcpr Gettysburg College has been
awarded a grant of more than
$500,000 from the Henry Luce
Foundation to support the estab
lishment of a professorship in Civil
War studies. The Henry R. Luce
Professor of the Civil War Era will
lead an undergraduate program in
Civil War studies and will develop
and direct "The Gettysburg Semes
ter," a program selecting students
from across the country to partici
pate in a semester of intensive in
terdisciplinary study of the Civil
War era. Funds from the grant,
which covers an initial period of
six years, will be used primarily
to provide salary and benefits for

a faculty member chosen to fill the
Luce Professorship. The grant was
announced by the Foundation's
Chairman Henry Luce III. The
Luce Professor will be selected by
a committee at the College after
completion of a national search.
The recipient's appoint
ment will be made in 1998, and the
Luce Professor will begin teach
ing at Gettysburg by the fall of
1999. Gettysburg is one of only
tow higher education institutions
to receive a professorship from the
Luce Foundation during this year.
The other was Johns Hopkins Uni
versity. "Gettysburg College is
very grateful for the support of the

Luce Foundation which will allow
us an opportunity to develop great
strength in Civil War studies, we
sincerely believe that we can de
velop a program unmatched at any
other site in the country," said
Gordon Haaland, president of Get
tysburg College. "Our aim is to
use of existing relationships with
the community of Civil War schol
ars and our natural geographic con
nection with the pivotal battle of
that War to establish an integrated
first-rate undergraduate program
that allows not only our students
but also visiting students access to
a unique combination of scholar
ship and original research materi
als." "Many of the basic issues

of contemporary American society
came into focus during the Civil
War era, among those being the
relevance of race in a democracy,
the proper balance of federal and
state government, the principles
that bind Americans, the meaning
of a union. We think that a
multidisciplinary examination of
the Civil War era is a wonderful,
rich, and sound way to examine
our social fabric," said Dr. Daniel
DeNicola, the college's chief aca
demic officer.
"The professorship will
provide scholarly leadership for an

intensive program in this era, ad
dressing not only the causes and
events of the Civil War and its af
termath, but its cultural and intel
lectual milieu. The program will
draw on not only miliary and po
litical history, but, among many,
the fields of economics, sociology,
philosophy, African-american
studies, women's studies, rhetoric,
religion, literature, the visual arts,
and music. Such a study helps us
understand what was changed and
what was preserved by the war,
what was lost arid gained," added
DeNicola.

The Henry R. Luce Pro
fessorship Program wa established
in 1969 by the New York-based
foundation to encourage academic

innovation and creativity through
integrative and interdisciplinary
approaches to teaching and re
search in American private higher
education.
The first recipient of the
Luce Professorship in Civil War
Studies will be responsible for fur
ther developing existing College
curricular programs into an aca
demic concentration or minor pro
gram, with direct responsibility for
teaching the introductory and
capstone courses in that program.
By the third year of the grant, the
Luce Professor will develop and
the direct "The Gettysburg Semes
ter," for which up to 25 under
graduate students will be selected
from applicants across the coun
try for a one-semester, integrated
program of Civil War studies.

We will continue to sup
port the Luce Professor, the estab
lished Gettysburg program, and
the Gettysburg Semester upon the
completion of the six-year Luce
grant period," said DeNicola.
"The college has the option of ap
plying to the Luce Foundation for
three additional years of support,
and we are confident that our pro
grams will show sufficient
progress and strength to warrant
serious consideration."

College offers
off campus guide

There is lots to do at Gettys
burg, but sometimes students like
to get off the campus to explore
what is available in the surround
ing area. Dean of First Year Stu
dents, Robert Nordvall, has put
together a resource that sets out
opportunities for fun and recre
ation on campus and beyond. In
cluded in is information about
what to do and about things to do
in Harrisburg, Lancaster, Balti
more, Washington, and other
nearby cities.
The guide includes infor¬

mation about shopping (where are
the big malls?), parks, theaters,
movies, clubs, concerts, museums,
sports teams, and miscellaneous
attractions within an 80 mile radius
of the College. Driving instruc
tions are included so students can
find out how to get to these attrac
tions. The address for this
Guide on the Web is http://
www.gettysburg.edu/
-1 stonesi/book.html. It can
also be accessed through the Get
tysburg College Home page by
clicking on Student Life, then Stu
dent Activities_, the The Book.

Beware the dangers of binge drinking

College Press Service
Jennifer, a Northwestern
University Junior, doesn't recall
how she ended up at Evanston
Hospital one early morning during
Spring Quarter last year. The last
thing she remembered was doing
tequila shots with a guy she met at
a fraternity party, and then her
world turned black.
Jennifer had a blood alcohol
level of about .21, more than twice
the legal limit in Illinois, and was
unconscious when friends took her
to Evanston Hospital's emergency
room. Her breathing was irregu
lar, and her friends told her that she
looked like a ghost.
"I was so scared," Jennifer
says as she shakes her head and
looks at the floor. "It was one of
the worst moments of my life. I
thought I was having such a good

Adelman writes devilish book

time, and then I wake up in the
hospital with a needle in my arm."
Doctors had to hook Jenni
fer up to an IV to dilute her blood
quickly and lower her blood alco
hol content. Jennifer, who doesn't
want her last name used, says the
experience changed her life be
cause she is one of the lucky ones.
She is still alive.
At least 800 high school and
college students died from alcohol
poisoning in 1994, but researchers
think the number might be higher
than 4,000 because many deaths
related to alcohol may be attributed
to other causes like cardiac arrest,
according to Students Against
Drunk Driving.
Annann Hong, an alcohol
substance abuse educator at NU's
Searle Student Health Service,

photo by Mark Aslrom
Park. Our goal in writing this book
was to bring to Devil's Den the
attention it deserves as a promi
nent, but often overlooked, part of
the three-day battle," said
Adelman.
The book details the history
and folklore surrounding the site,
covers in-depth the events during
the battle, and concludes with a
detailed guide for visitors.
Adelman joined Gettysburg
College in 199S as part of the
College's dining services opera
tion.

ULFK A Gettysburg College ad
ministrator has co-written the first
book dedicated to examining the
history and significance of Devil's
Den in the Civil War Battle of Get
tysburg.
Garry E. Adelman, a life
long students of Civil War history,
has co-written "Devil's Den: A
History and Guide" with Timothy
H. Smith. The book was published
in June by Gettysburg-based Tho
mas publications. Both Adelman
and Smith are licensed guides for
the Gettysburg National Military

isn't surprised to learn about
Jennifer's experience. She often
hears of drunk students who are
found in odd places on campus,
then shipped into Evanston Hos
pital for care.
A recent survey conducted
by the American Medical Associa
tion showed that 40 percent of 800
eighteen to thirty-year olds drink
to levels that impair judgment and
physical performance.
The results demonstrate a
sad, unconscionable waste of tal
ent and potential by our country's
young people," says Nancy
Dickey, chair ofAMA's board of
trustees.
Although many people mis
take alcohol for a stimulant be
cause it can make people more

lively than their usual selves, al
cohol is actually a depressant. If a
person drinks enough alcohol it
can shut the body's immune sys
tem down and affect the circula
tory and respiratory systems.
Hong points out that many
people don't know that alcohol
alone can kill you, and you don't
have to be into the driver's seat to
die from it.
"People are afraid of taking
someone into the hospital because
of the possible consequences, or
they think that the person is passed
out and will be OK in the morn
ing," Hong says. "But this is seri
ous and instead of worrying about
the person getting in trouble, I
think it's more important that you
could be saving that person's life."

A SADD brochure lists sev
eral cases in which young adults
have died from alcohol poisoning,
including a story about Marie
Brinkmeyer. She was 18 and a
first-year student at Texas A&M
University when she bought a
bottle of tequila and took it to a
dormitor party. After drinking
heavily, Brinkmeyer collapsed adn
was carried to her bed to sleep it
off. She never woke up.
"I don't think people are
aware 1 of all the damage alcohol
can do," says Dr. David Barthwell,
medical director for the drug and
alcohol program at Northwestern
Memorial Hospital in Chicago.
"Alcohol companies make alcohol
look so appealing, but the truth is,
if you aren't careful, it can kill
you."

Dean of First Year Students urges new arrivals to get involved

GCPR When students first come
to college, the number of pos
sible activities to join is over
whelming. In addition, there is
the academic challenge of col
lege courses, dean of First Year
Students, Robert Nordvall, rec
ommends that students take their
time reviewing the options avail
able and deciding the activities
in which they want to participate
at Gettysburg, but he notes that
first year students should become
involved in the life of the Col
lege. A leading scholar on
the affect that college has upon
students is Dr. Alexander W.
Austin of the Cooperative Insti
tutional Research Program at

UCLA. Dr. Astin os an alumnus of
Gettysburg College. His work indi
cates that the quality of the educa
tional experience that students get in
college is directly related to how
much they are involved both inside
and outside the classroom in their
college experience. Not surpris
ingly, students who put more effort
into college, receive much greater
benefits from their four years of
higher education.
Dean Nordvall empha
sizes, however, that although almost
all activities provided benefits, not
all co-curricular activities are equal
in what they provide to students.
Students should look for activities
that provided to them strong oppor
tunities for personal growth. A small
group of activities that have proved
particularly powerful in fostering the

growth and development of stu
dents are the service learning pro
grams and community service pro
grams, and opportunities for inde
pendent study and research with
professors. There are activities
that students name as particularly
impor tant as they reflect upon their
four years at Gettysburg. There
four are not the only activities that
play such a role, and students can,
of course, take part in a number of
very beneficial activities at the
College. The Gettysburg Is Volun
teering (GIV) Day activities on the
Monday afternoon of Orientation
from 6:30 pm - 8:00 pm there will
be an Open House at the Center
for Public Service at which stu
dents can find out more about com
munity service and service learn¬

ing programs. Study abroad op
portunities will be discussed in the
rotating discussion sessions on
Monday morning of Orientation.
First year students do not ordi
narily work on research and inde
pendent study projects with pro
fessors, but during their first year
students should be sampling the
various academic programs at the
College in order to find out which
programs offer the academic chal
lenges and opportunities that are
most attractive to them.
Service learning pro
grams, community service pro
grams, study abroad, and indepen
dent study and research are pow
erful experiencesbecause they
stretch students. They force stu
dents to do and see new things.

They force students to look at the
world differently. Students can
graduate from Gettysburg College
without participating in any of
these programs, but students who
want to experience the full range
of a Gettysburg College education
should select the best opportuni
ties that the College has to offer,
both inside and outside of the class
. room.

Birgitte Ginge, assistant provost at Gettysburg College, recently
attended the Summer Institute for Women in Higher Education Admin
istration at Bryn Mawr College.
Sponsored jointly by Bryn Mawr and Higher Education Re
source Services (HERS), Mid-America, the Summer Institute was at
tended by participants from the United States, Canada, Nigeria, and
South AFrica. The program provides participants with skills and infor
mation pertinent to the management and governance of colleges and
universities and with timely information and perspectives on teaching,
research, and service. The Summer Institute also seeks to build a net
work of women administrators and to expend opportunities for women
in higher education.

Taylor named new assistant director
_OCpp Wide Web computer training semi-

Patricia Taylor, a 1994
graduate of Gettysburg College,
has been appointed assistant direc
tor of alumni relations at the Col
lege. In her new position, Tay
lor will share in the responsibility
of planning, implementing, and
evaluation programs, services, and
events for Gettysburg graduates.
She will also advise the Students
Alumni Association, a group com
prised of current Gettysburg stu
dents. Taylor previously served
as a consultant to the College de
veloping and conduction World

nars. She has also developed vari
ous sections of the College's World
Wide Web site on the Internet.
Taylor earned a
bachelor's degree in history and a
minor in social studies secondary
education at Gettysburg and is a
certified secondary social studies
teacher in Pennsylvania. Since her
graduation, Taylor has been a sub
stitute teacher in the Gettysburg
and Littlestown school districts
and a special projects assistant for
"The Gettysburg Times."
Taylor is also a member
of the Gettysburg Jaycees.

Theater to hold auditions

Theatre Professor George Muschamp will hold auditions Wednesday and Thursday, August 27, 28 for Milta
Sanchez-Scott's Rooster the Owl & Nightingale mainstage Fall production. Auditions will be held both days from
3:30 - 6:00 p.m. in the Green Room and Room 100 of Brua Hall.
Needed for Roosters are four females and six males; no advance preparation required. Along with male and
female actors for dramatic roles, students with athletic and dancing ability are urged totry out.

Students interested in helping with costumes, sets or lighting, please call Professor Jerry Hanson.
This explosive, prize winning drama, Roosters, which will be preformed on Kline Stage, October 2-7

(parents weekend) tells the story of love, power, and dreams in a contemporary Latino family m the American
Southwest. It is a colorful tale told in an unexpected blend of robust humor and gripping intrigue.
Legendary breeder of fighting cocks, Gallo Morales, returns home after seven years in jail for man slaughter
On the day of his return his 20year old son, Hector, decides to pit a prize bird inherited from his Grandfather and
then either eat it sell itfor h to out of the The centers the battle for

"or " enougmoney get valley. play on supremacy
between Father and son. Drawn into the dispute are Hector's sister Angela; his lusty aunt Chata, and his martyred
Mother Juna, who only wants her family to live in peace.
This explosive drama, with it's deft blend of fanciful imagery and reality is considered a superb example of
the theatrical style known as "magical realism."

Individualism 101

Hi, hello and welcome to
the orange and blue branch on
your tree of education: Gettysburg
College. While the world spins
wildly out of control, and empires
rise and fall around us, here
strands your academic oasis ~ and
here stands you.
In case you were won
dering, this is the student news
paper ~ your source for all kinds
fo stuff, including campus news
and opinion, but more about that
later. Here's something you
can do: leave your newly arranged
room, step out of your dorm, and
take a good look around. Notice
the green grass, the majestic build
ings. Wander around the param
eter of the campus, look at the fra
ternity houses. Sit on the steps of
Mussleman Library or the base of
the fountain and let your eyes feast
upon your new home.

Now go back to your
room and look at the mirror. Look
at yourself, remeber yourself.

And realize that all you have seen
means nothing if you do not remain
true to the person in the mirror.
Yes, this sounds like petty
advice, but consider it a moment.
At Gettysburg College you will
face your greatest academic chal
lenges and will have to pass your
most demanding tests of character.
Pressures will rise that might in
timidate you into becoming some
one you never met before. TheAll
American Scholar. The Generation
X'er. The Product of a Liberal Arts
Education. These are all nice
people, but you must question, are
they me? Oddly enough, some cli
ches do apply, including "Get In
volved" and "Be Yourself." This
campus truly offers some great
things, but some of the greatest
things are yet to appear. That's
where you come in. The college
has its weaknessess — for one, it's
just too darn expensive. Another
is its lack . of cohesiveness: for a
school of less than 2000, it is a

common thing to graduate with a
class of virtual strangers. If any
one is going to make a difference,
it will be with unique and bold
ideas and action, ones that focus
on what is best for the students (it
seems that sometimes people for
get about that sector of the "cam
pus community.")
The Gettysburgian ex
tends a hand to individuals will
ing to express their views candidly
and with fervor. We look forward
to earning your respect as your
Voice, but just in case we don't,
let us know about.
Do get involved, because
you can make the difference. Put
your prejudices aside and help
bring soem real energy to this
place. There's more here to learn
than what's in the classrooms, and
there's more to do here than spend
tuition money.
Reprinted with permis
sion of William A. Siss '95

Gettysburg's
address for
the best new
music is
UJZBT 91.1 FM


by Colleen DeBaise
College Pr ess Service
IOWACITY-For 18-year
old freshman Sharon Monaghan,
the adjustment to campus life at
the University of Iowa has been
close to trouble-free.
Except, "I forgot my robe,"
she said. "I'd really like that."
Also, she'd like a laundry bag.
The toughest part for her,
she says, is getting used to the aca
demic demands of college.
"It's a lot more work than
high school," said Monaghan, who
plans to major in biochemistry. "I
feel like a dork. I come home, do
work and then I go to bed by nine.
I'm just kind of waiting for the
homework to pile on."
So far, she gets along well
with her roommate, and they've
lofted their beds to squeeze a
couch into their tiny dorm room.
And she's not too homesick.
"You think about going
home, but all your stuff is here,"
she explains.

Being away from home.
Coping with studies. Dealing with
roommates.
Those are just some of the
concerns that nearly every incom¬

ing freshman has during the first
few weeks on campus.
A number of publication
many written by recent grads— of
fer helpful tips on surviving cam
pus life. They list tips on how to
manage with the "roommate from
hell," how not to gain the "fresh
man 15," and how to keep in touch
with Mom and Dad.
For instance, Joe Tur ton, a
1994 graduate of Denison Univer
sity in Granville, Ohio, recently
finished writing "My Freshman
Manual: The Official College
Handbook."
At Denison, Turton was a
psychology major and an athlete,
and he describes himself as
"someone who recently has been
in the trenches and is willing to
share these lessons with others."
"If I had known all the

things I included in the book be
forehand," Turton said, "I would
have avoided many problems my
self." His advice for college fresh
man: Get a phone card for calling
home. It will save you a lot of
money, and you won't have an

excuse for not calling the parents.
When you fill out your
maintenance room report at the
beginning of the year, mark every
single detail, as well as a few ex
tra. School fines can be outra
geous for very small damages to
your room.
Buy an alarm clock that has
a battery back-up. The power al
ways seems to go out in the middle
of the night.
Get to know the professors
in your major department. Letters
of recommendation are very use
ful when you are looking for a job.
Following those "rules of
thumb" will help alleviate the
stress of freshman year, Turton
said. Melanie Sponholz, a 1993
graduate of Drew University in
Madison, N.J., and her husband
Joseph Sponholz, a 1994 grad of
New York University, offer their
advice to freshman in "College
Companion: Attaining Academic
and Social Nirvana."

The book, recently pub
lished by the Princeton Review,
was written because "facing life
in a pantry-sized dorm room with

a total stranger might not be the
easiest of situations," according to
the 25-year-old authors.
They lace the book with real
students' stories gleaned from in
terviews they conducted with cur
rent college students, and com
mentary drawn from the Princeton
Review's surveys of more than
56,000 college students.
First off, the Sponholzes of
fer these tips for incoming fresh¬

man: Take care of money matters.
Open a savings and checking ac
count with a local bank, but shop
around for the best fees. Some
banks require students maintain a
minimum balance; others tack on
charges for using automatic-teller
machine cards at machines not
owned by the bank.
Have a "ground rules" chat
with your roommate. You'll each
be glad you took the time to work
out a plan to accommodate each
other's study, sleeping, eating, and
CD-blasting habits.
But, "don't be a dork about
this," the Sponholzes warn. In
stead of handing your roommate
a typed list of suggestions, have

lunch together and talk about how
you both like to live.
Once a freshman has settled
into classes and dormlife, a whole
new set of problems can arise, ac
cording to the authors.
Melanie Sponholz bases her
advice on her two years as a resi
dent advisor at a Drew dormitory.
Joseph Sponholz's perspective
comes from his years as an NYU
"frat guy" and intramural athlete.
Their tips are:
If you have the "roommate
from hell" give it some time. Dur
ing orientation week, you and your
roommate might spend 24 hours
a day with each other. But once
the school year starts, you'll most
likely have separate classes and
activities to give you some space.
Soon, you'll meet other people
and you can hang out in their
rooms.

"It's also important that you
and your roommate talk about ev
ery problem as it occurs," the
Sponholzes advise. "This way
you'll avoid a bunch of little ar
guments creating a huge blowout
between you and your roommate."

Looking for Part-Time Work?

Information Resources and Computing will be hiring in the fall!
We are looking for motivated, creative, reliable and energetic students to work for us

during the 1997-1998 academic year. We have openings in multiple student computer
support programs throughout the department. Jobs range from Lab Assistant positions to
troubleshooting computer problems in the residence halls to training students on our
various supported software packages. We promise on-the-job learning, a resume-worthy
opportunity and a comfortable, if slightly crazed, working environment.
If you are interested in becoming part of our staff, or want more information about job
opportunities, be sure to stop by the Information Resources and Computing Help Desk on
the Ground floor of Musselman Library when you arrive on campus. We will have job
descriptions and applications waiting for you.
We look forward to hearing from you.

CAMPUS PLANNING CALENDAR
The staff of the Office of Student Activities/College Union is very
excited to be a part of CNAV and what it is offering the College
community.
CNAV offers a calendar of events that is similar to the Planning
Calendar that has been published by our office.
To be environmentally sensitive and in response to the budget,
our office decided to eliminate the calendar.
You will be able to access a longer version of the Campus Calen
dar from Gopher. You will find the information by using the
following directions once you are in Gopher:
1. Campus Calendars and Directories
2. Schedule of Campus Reservations and Events
3. Select the format to search by (Location, Month, Sponsor).
If there are any questions concerning the scheduling of an
event(s) please contact Diann Cooper, Ext. 6302, email dkcooper
or stop by the office in Room 250 of the . Coljej»e Union,.

The Student Activities Council presents

K.J. James

Wednesday, August 27
Noon
The Junction
Standing on the shoulders of the rural male blues
singers before him, K. J. James is to the 90s what
Blind Lemon Jefferson was to the '20s. Since
launching his recording career with the "Salt
Lake City Blues" project on Blue Wave Records,
K.J. has become one of the nation's most
requested blues performers. Unlike other
musicians on the contemporary blues scene,
K.J. James has stayed true to the music.

Tips to guide you through the labarinth of College

Dear Casey.

by Casey Dunn
staffwriter Hello, and welcome to your
college experience! Please keep
your arms and legs inside the ride
at all times and do not exit until
the ride has come to a complete
stop. Oops, wrong introduction, I
guess summer is still not out of my
system, yet. Well, if you are still
reading, let me introduce myself,
I am Casey Dunn, the advice col
umnist, a new addition to the stu
dent news paper.
Although, in order for
this to work, I am going to need
your help. I need to have things to
give advice on, so send concerns,
questions, comments, ect to Box
#618 orBurgian @ gettysburg.edu,
and check the paper for the re
sponse from the oracle of advice,
myself.

As for this first issue I am
offering my Top Ten list of advice
I have compiled after my first year
here as a student and member of
the community. It is meant to be
both humorous and serious, so take
some time and peruse it. And be
sure to send in letters. Enjoy.
#10) Welcome to reality
well, not quite. College is a new,
independent experience, and at
first you may feel that this IS real
ity, but if you take time to think
about it, you might not be too anx
ious to cash in that reality check.
For example, in reality you have
to push more than one button to
get your laundry clean, unlike

those nifty machines that the col
lege offers. Also, reality does not
seem to accept those swell student
ID cards in exchange for food and
access to neccessary facilities, like
the fitness and weight room.
While we are on the topic of ID
cards, be sure to keep in mind that
MAC machines do not accept
them, and that you actually have
to have money in an account, BE
FORE you can access it. It is
sometimes nice to wish that real
ity was as sweet as collge. Keep
dreaming, folks, before you know
it, you will have to wake up. />
#9) Play hard, buj_^ork
harder. Even though we mdy ' pride
ourselves with bcing_^ jfiature, re
sponsible adults, capable of mak¬

ing independent decisions, we
have to be able to let our hair down
and live the life our parents could
only dream of having. This privi
lege of independence does carry
with it a cumbersome, yet fully
color coordinated, set of baggage.
As it is a privilege to be indepen
dent, we must show that we are
responsible, and able to handle that
privilege. The key here is balance,
folks. If your playful side puts on
too many extra pounds, from a
little too much beer, it is going to
throw you skinny responsible side
off the seesawand into the great
sand box of displaced college stu
dents. #8) Reputation, a blem¬

ish even Cover Girl can not fix.
This college is small and can be
come even smaller when everyone
knows where you have been sleep
ing. Bottom line is this, you might
think it is really cool to be able to
chug a bottle of Boon's wine in the
time span of the song Roxanne, but
even your ever so sexy alcohol tol
erance will not gain you the right
respect. The respect that everyone
deserves, but so many people
make the point of loosing. Do not
succumb to belittling your talents
and abilities, trust me, when the
party is over and the laughter is
faded, YOU and you alone are left
with only a hangover and porce
lain bowl to cry to.

#7) Respect, respect, re
spect. Everyone knows the 3 R's
of education, well these are the
three R's of life. Basically, if we
as a whole showed common re
spect to people this world would'"'
be a much more pleasant place to
live, starting with this campus.
Think of all the people,that help
make this place operate, the main
tenance crew, the/dinning center
and bullet hole _^ staff, the office ad
ministrator_^ 'and a myriad more.
_Sometimes; sadly, it seems that
college _^ students will look down
uno ' n these people, sorry folks, but
/tifese unique and talented people
were not put on this campus to put
the plush carpet under your "su
perior" feet. Give them respect.
Take time to appreciate their tal
ents.

#6) Have you hugged
your friend today? There is so
much written, sung, and praised
about friends. They are the ones
that sit on the highway with you
for three hours in 100 degree tem
peratures after your car overheats
and the engine seizes. They hu
mor you and participate in your
inane quests to see the sun rise
multiple days in a row. They en
able us to face each day with a
smile and give us no good excuse
for beating ourselves with our own
backbones on not so kosher days.
Yes, and the best part folks, is they

are absolutely, one hundred per
cent free. True friends, which of
ten take a while to find, and come
with no strings attached. First, re
spect yourself enough not to be
used and mistreated by people who
use you as a stepping stone to gain
their ultimate goal of a reputation.
Trust me, their reputation of being
a manipulative back slabber will
get you no where in the long run.
Second, appreciate your friends. A
good friend of mine once sent me
a poem, entitled "A Friend is
Someone Who Stays After Every
one Else Leaves", this touched me

»»rw»r arn
deeper than anymaterial apprecia
tion could have possibly done, but
it also made me realize that- this
was a true friend. She appreciated
me, and I'll tell you,. I was eu
phoric. /
#5) Parents. Wouldn't it
be nice to really, honestly believe
that we no longer have any con
nections with them, besides the 28
g's_, they are shelling out for our
education. Sorry, Sam, it is impos
sible. Yes, I know, independence,
responsibility, maturity, yadayada,
yada...but let's take a minute and

reflect on who helped you get to
where you are now. Who would
sit in the freezing November rain
to watch the everlasting soccer
matches? Who brought flowers to
your first stage performance, as
Dorothy, "In the Wizard of Oz"?
Who drove you, incessantly, to
every Laser Tag match in the state,
because you truly believed you
could conquer your arch enemies
with one swift blow from your la
ser beam. To our parents, we are
the super heroes. I say let's make
our parents the super heroes, and

us be the trainee sidekicks. The
future is a tough place, and who
better to prepare us than Mom and
Dad, defenders of the universe,
well, maybe just the car.
#4) Appreciate some
one important. Yourself. This is
tough advice to follow, especially
when your world is whizzing
around at the speed of light and
you are so deeply buried in your
new and exciting life, you often to
forget about important things.
Sleep, food, and rest, just to name
a few. Take care of you first. This
may sound self centered and self
ish, but honestly how can you ex
pect to do anything productive if
you are a walking around in a half
spent state, so stressed you are at
tempting to light a cigarette with
the filter side out. Not very. In or
der to enjoy the tremendous feast
of opportunities that is placed on
the plate of the future, you must
first learn how to chew, not gobble.
Careful folks, you might choke.

#3) The only thing that
is permanent in life is change. This
is a simple concept that most
people find a difficult time remem
bering. You know how it goes, you
stay up all night and cram for a test
that in the morning you are so sure
you have in the bag because you
can regurgitate all of Darwin's
theory's, you've memorized
Boyle's Law, you can label all
the parts of a semi-permeable
membrane of a eukariotic cell and
of course know all the enzymes of
the digestive system, and does the
Prof, ask anyof this on the test?
No, of course not. You flunk, and

are bummed. But, wait. Think of
how many tests you will take in
your future. Think about how in
ten years you will in no possible
remember you ever took this class,
and how you can not even remem
ber who Darwin was. My friend
once shared with me her mountain
and mole hill theory. You see, you
are looking at your situation up
close. You see it as a huge moun
tain that must be surpassed. Take
some steps back, let change occur,
and look at it now. It is now a mole
hill. Not as big as it seemed, and
laughable that you even thought so
much about it. Bottom line, there
is no problem that time can not fix.

It is all in how you deal with
change. #2) Get involved. You
have probably heard this a bizillion
times by now, but you need to hear
it some more. So you are at are at
Gettysburg College. With the as
sistance of many people you have
arrived on campus and now it is
up to you to make a splash with
your four year tenure here. At this
point of your life you are swim
ming in a sea of options. You can
either lay back and let the tide take
you in, or grab your boogie board
and take the ride of your life. My
advice: Hang ten, baby.
#1) Go to class. This is
by far my best piece of advice. The
main reason you are here is to re¬

ceive a quality education that will
take you places in life. Alright,
folks, we are the future. Scary,
isn't it? In ten years we will be
holding Government positions,
heading FBI operations, making
and breaking the stock market,
making more g's than Bill Gates,
and raising the new future. Times
are changing rapidly, and we need
to be able to keep pace. The per
fect training; a well rounded, fine
tuned education. GO TO CLASS.
If not for yourself, for others who
have to deal with you in the future,
for your parents who want the best
for you, and above all, for the Pro
fessors, who care enough to offer
you one of life's most precious
gifts, an education.

So that is it. Some are of
these are harder to follow than oth
ers. Some you might not agree
with. Some you may think are stu
pid. But I hope they make you
think. Reflect on exactly why you
are here, what you want to gain
from this experience, and what you
hope to offer others. I wish you
the best of luck in the upcoming
years and hopeful after this year
you will have some of your own
Do you have a question to
ask Casey? Write to her at box
434. Letters must be signed, bul
will be kept confidential.


Women s tennis ends season second in conference

From Staff Reports
Junior Kate Goodall
and sophomore Bev Jack
son emerged as the leading
players on Gettysburg
College's 1997 women's
tennis team.
Gettysburg completed
the regular season with a
14-2 record and was 8-2 in
the Centennial Conference,
good for second place. The
Bullets were the defending
conference champs.
Goodall, playing out
of the number six singles
post most of the season,
recorded a 14-1 record.
Jackson, who handled the
number five spot through
out the season, was 14-2
for the year.

Goodall and Jackson
formed Gettysburg's top
number three doubles team
and were also the team
leaders in that area. They
posted a 13-1 record, the
second best in the Centen
nial Conference.
However, the season's
top honor went to the
Bullets' number two
singles player, senior
Cynthia Hoenes. Hoenes
not only made the All
Centennial Conference first

team, but was named co
player of the year, along
with Johns Hopkins' Zeena
Abdi. Hoenes posted a 13
3 record.
Hoenes, one of only
two seniors on this year's
team, completes her colle
giate career with a stunning
54-13 singles record and a
48-10 doubles mark for an
overall 102-23 record.
Hoenes was joined by
junior Tara Schmitt to form
Gettysburg's number one
doubles team. They were
14-2 on the season and
were named to the all
conference first team.
They won their first seven
matches to end the season
with 14 wins.

Hoenes not only
proved to be a strong
competitor on the court, but
in the classroom as well.
She and senior Mary Joy •
Troxel were named to the
Centennial Conference's
academic honor roll for
carrying a 3.40 GPA or
better.
Gettysburg completed
its sixth season under head
coach Bill Pfitzinger this
Spring. The Bullets are 66
21 under his guidance.

Photo by Mark Astrom
Doubles partners Cynthia Hoenes and Tara Schmitt celebrate after winning a set last spring.
The pair ended their Senior season with A 14-2 record


Men's golf team racks up records
Forbes sets ihiee during championship

From Staff Reports
Senior Jeff Forbes
carried off the bulk of the
honors on the Gettysburg
College varsity golf team
which completed its
season in the spring.
Forbes was named to
the All-District II team.
Forbes captured his second
straight Centennial Confer
ence championship and
completed the season with
935 strikes for 12 rounds

and a team low average of
77.9. During the confer
ence championships, he set
three records: low total per
round, 72; low first two
rounds, 151; and low gross
224. Forbes' closest com
petitor was sophomore
Matt Beckert, who carded
an 80.1 average on 801
strokes for ten rounds. He
was team medalist once
during the season.

Rounding out
Gettysburg's top five golfers
on the ten-player roster, were
Senior Ryan Coffey, with an
85.2 average for 11 rounds;
freshman Rick Deutsch, 89.1
for eight rounds; and sopho
more Matt Doorley, 87.6
average for eight rounds.
Gettysburg completed
the season with a 39-27
record and placed fourth in
the conference champion
ship.

Strong starting lineup, Streeter s 20th make for promising season

From Staf f Reports
Not only will
Gettysburg College be
launching its 105th football
season this year, but Head
Coach Barry Streeter will
begin his 20th year at the
Bullet helm. It all began
Monday when 93
candidates reported for the
first day of pre-season
drills. Streeter is currently
the college's all-time
coaching leader with 108
victories, 80 losses and five
draws. His best season was
1985 when he guided the
Bullets through their only
undefeated regular season

and eventually completed
the year with a 11-1-1 slate
following a semi-final
placing in the NCAA
Division III playoffs.
Streeter added three
new coaches to his staff of
eight. Steve Reider, a 1995
Dickinson graduate, and
Tom Waranavage, a 1993
Muhlenberg grad, have
been assigned to the wide
receivers and tight ends
respectively. The new
outside linebacker coach is
Marty Ogle, a 1974
graduate of Sheperd.
Among the 93
candidates Streeter will
greeted on Sunday were 49

freshmen and 44
upperclassmen, including
31 letter winners. Heading
the list is sophomore Paul
Smith. Smith, a first team
all-centennial conference
fullback as a freshman,
rushed 888 yards and
scored nine touchdowns in
1996. He has been named
on of USA III Football's
top sophomores to watch in
1997. Leading the Bullets
in 1997 will be elected
captains Joe Hodakowski
and Rob Sena.
Hodakowski is a senior
linebakcer while Sena is a
senior defensive back.

The one nice thing
facing Streeter is the fact
that he has a solid starting
veteran at every position
except offensive left guard.
With an offensive line
intact, backed by an
experienced backfield, the
Bullets could unleash a
potent offense. Veterans
Chris Fugaro and Wes
Wells are back at
quarterback while veterans
Matt Helwig and Donny
McNellis will be at the
halfback slots. Joining
Smith at the fullback slot
will be another veteran,
Henry Unger, as well as the
return of Dan Sheats.

Sheats took a year off last
season for personal
reasons, after rushing for
273 yards and one
touchdown in five games as
a freshman in 1995.
The Bullets spent
the first two days going
through physicals,
equipmentadjustments,
testing and meetings. It has
been down to business ever
since with tow-a-day
sessions.
Gettysburg will
open its season on
Saturday, Sept. 13 at
Hampden-Sydney.

Football kicks off 105th season

Bullets sixth in Conference

LANCASTER, Pa.
-Can the dream continue in
Collegeville? Apparently
the coaches and SIDs in the
Conference think so.
Ursinus, which won
its first-ever Conference
football championship in
1996, is the favorite to
repeat as Centennial
Conference football
champion in a poll of the
Conference's head coaches
and media. Each head

coach and Sports
Information Director from
each Conference locale
participated in the poll.
The Bears received
eight of a possible 15 first
place votes (voters were
not permitted to vote for
their own team) for 81
points to outdistance
Franklin & Marshall, which
was second with 66 points.
Ursinus returns 15 starters
and 59 lettermen from last
season's 9-2 team which

I¦s
3

was ousted in the NCAA
playoffs by Lycoming, 31
24. The Diplomats,
which finished second to
the Bears in the '96
standings, barely
outpointed Johns Hopkins
(64), Dickinson (63), and
Western Maryland (60), in
one of the closest preseason
ballotings in the
Conference's 15 year
history. F&M received
three first place votes,
while Western Maryland
picked up two. Johns
Hopkins and Dickinson
were on the top line in one
ballot apiece.

Gettysburg was
sixth with 49 points, while
Muhlenberg (22) and
Swathmore (15) rounded
out the field.
The Centennial
openers are set for Sept. 19
-20, when Gettysburg will
host Western Maryland.



Men s LaX struggles to put season behind them
Bullets fall to Washington after less than perfect sea son

From Staf fRepor ts
When the Gettys
burg College men's
lacrosse team lost three
consecutive games to
Salisbury State, Western
Maryland, and Washing
ton midway through the
season to fall to 5-4,- the
possibility that the
Bullets might miss the
NCAA Division III

tournament for the first
time since 1990 looked
very real.
Head Coach Hank
Janczyk's squad re
sponded by wining the
final five games of the
regular season, earning a
bid to the Division III
playoffs. In the first
round, Gettysburg
knocked off Salisbury
State in double overtime,

10-9. The Bullets' season
came to a close when
they fell to Washington
in the semifinals, 10-9.
"Every once in a
while I guess you have a
season that demonstrates
how certain cliches get
started," said Janczyk,
who has now logged 10
seasons as the head
coach at Gettysburg. "I
probably used phrases
like 'keep believing' and
'never give up' more
than I ever have before
as a coach. It must have
had some impact though,
because by the time our
season ended, we had
worked our way into
being one of the top four
Division III teams in the
country."

_^ ¥MMM_._^"MA ~^

The Bullets had
four seniors in their
starting lineup for the
two playoff games, three
of them at the midfield.
Brett Strait closed
out his four years at

Gettysburg by scoring 26
goals and dishing out 20
assists during the Bullets'
1997 campaign.
Joe Feldman was
runner-up on the team in
goals scored. He furnished

photo by Mark Astrom
the Bullets with 31
goals and 10 assists.
Strait and
Feldman both made the
first unit of the 1997
All-Centennial Confer
ence Men's Lacrosse

Team.
Andrew Nesbitt had
16 goals to go along with
13 assists.
The fourth senior in
the starting lineup was
defenseman James
Gohng. A three year
starter for the Bullets, he
also made the all-confer
ence firstteam.
Junior attackman
Jamie Bateman secured
the scoring title for 1997
with a five-goal perfor
mance against Washing
ton in the Division III
semifinals. He con
cluded the season with
37 goals and seven
assists, and made the all
conference squad as an
honorable mention.

Scott Lowery joined
Strait in the "20-20" club
as the junior attackman
tallied 26 goals and was
credited with 23 assists.
Lowery and sopho
more defenseman Brian
Abbott were first-team
all-conference selections.
A freshman started
in goal for the Bullets in
all 16 games this season.
Andrew Barter made 191

108 goals to finish with a
.639 save percentage.
The 191 saves is the
sixth-highest single
season total in school
history.

Orientation Issue

in
trouble

by Rebecca Babbitt
The Tau Kappa Epsilon house was set for renovations
this summer, but a few brothers decided to start early by caus
ing up to $50,000 worth of damage to the house on the last
two days of exams last May.
Now the house is closed and the brothers who dam
aged the house are being sued by TKE nationals.
The Psi chapter of TKE, founded at Gettysburg in 1926,
is "still operating as a fraternity, just with out housing," said
Jason Gareis, President of the Interfraternity Council.
It was rumored that the TKE brothers were being
housed at the Gettysburg Seminary. "Not true," said Gareis,

Editor's Note This Is part one of a continuing story Mora next week ¦

all photos by Rebecca Babbitt
"Most of them are living off campus."
The decision to close the house was made by the
TKE alumni and national corporation. After the damage
had been assessed, the TKE housing corporation decided
to close the house for a semester.
"The house is not livable," said Gareis.
Renovations are planned for spring semester, and
brothers should be living in the house again by the fall of
1998. Current brothers will have to undergo a re-admit
tance process which includes interviews conducted by
alumni.
"This adds pressure from sources that had negative
ideas about the greek system," said Gareis. "It's fuel for
the fire."
"We're going to have to work hard to get more posi
tive publicity," said Gareis.

College awards distinguished faculty members
Professors Rowland, Schmidt, Delesalle recognized for outstanding teaching

Professors Alex Rowland
(left)and Emile Schmidt (right)

byDanLarkin
News Editor
At the close of the 1996
1997 academic year, Gettysburg
College chose to recognize mem
bers of the College's faculty with
awards for distinguished teaching.
Presented annually at the
College's commencement exer
cises, the Gettysburg College
award for Distinguished Teaching
was shared by two faculty mem
bers. The 1997 co-recipients of the
award were Professor of Chemis
try, Alex Rowland, and Professor
of English and Director of Theater
Arts, Emile Schmidt.
In recognizing Professor
Rowland, Gettysburg College Pro
vost Dan DeNicola said "Profes
sor Rowland has always been com
mitted to quality in undergraduate
science teaching, helping develop
the Organic Chemistry Test Form
for the Examination Committee of
the American Chemistry Society
and publishing several papers in
the Journal of Chemical Educa-

He continued, "By his ex
ample, Alex Rowland has shown
his students and younger col
leagues that one can do important
research of scientific significance
at a small liberal arts college."
DeNicola went on to say that
"Alex's name is synonymous with
Chemistry at Gettysburg College."
The Provost also recog
nized professor Schmidt, saying
"Emile's gift for making the world
of theater come to life in a practi
cal and imaginative fashion has
had a powerful and long-lasting
impact on the lives of his stu¬

dents." He stated that "Time and
again, individuals would rise to
make enthusiastic testimony to
Emile's teaching and his ability to
challenge them in pursuing their
life's goals."
Dr. Rowland earned his doc
torate from Brown University. He
began teaching at Gettysburg in
1958. In 1982, he was named
OCkershausen Professor of Chem
istry. Professor Schmidt earned his
Master's degree from Columbia
University. He began teaching at
Gettysburg in 1962. Along weith
his wife, Partricia Martell, he
founded the Gettysburg Summer
Theater, which ran for twenty-five

years. In addition to Professors
Rowland and Schmidt, Assistant
Professor of Biology, Veronique
Delesalle, received the Luther
W.and Bernice L. Thompson dis
tinguished Teaching award at the
Spring Honors Day program on
May 17. The award is given an
nually to a faculty member who
has come to Gettysburg College
within the past seven years and
whose teaching is recognized as
outstanding by faculty Colleagues.
Dr. Delesalle earned both
her bachelor's adn master's degrees
from McGill University. She lives
in Fairfield.





Beware the dangers of binge drinking

College Press Service
Jennifer, a Northwestern
University Junior, doesn't recall
how she ended up at Evanston
Hospital one early morning during
Spring Quarter last year. The last
thing she remembered was doing
tequila shots with a guy she met at
a fraternity party, and then her
world turned black.
Jennifer had a blood alcohol

At least 800 high school and
college students died from alcohol
poisoning in 1994, but researchers
think the number might be higher
than 4,000 because many deaths
related to alcohol may be attributed
to other causes like cardiac arrest,
according to Students Against
Drunk Driving.
Annann Hong, an alcohol
substance abuse educator at NU's
Searle Student Health Service.

isn't surprised to learn about
Jennifer's experience. She often
hears of drunk students who are
found in odd places on campus,
then shipped into Evanston Hos
pital for care.
A recent survey conducted
by the American Medical Associa
tion showed that 40 percent of 800
eighteen to thirty-year olds drink
to levels that impair judgment and
physical performance.
The results demonstrate a
sad, unconscionable waste of tal
ent and potential by our country's
young people," says Nancy
Dickey, chair ofAMA's board of
trustees.
Although many people mis
take alcohol for a stimulant be
cause it can make people more

lively than their usual selves, al
cohol is actually a depressant. If a
person drinks enough alcohol it
can shut the body's immune sys
tem down and affect the circula
tory and respiratory systems.
Hong points out that many
people don't know that alcohol
alone can kill you, and you don't
have to be into the driver's seat to
die from it.
"People are afraid of taking
someone into the hospital because
of the possible consequences, or
they think that the person is passed
out and will be OK in the morn
ing," Hong says. "But this is seri
ous and instead of worrying about
the person getting in trouble, I
think it's more important that you
could be saving that person's life."

A SADD brochure lists sev
eral cases in which young adults
have died from alcohol poisoning,
including a story about Marie
Brinkmeyer. She was 18 and a
first-year student at Texas A&M
University when she bought a
bottle of tequila and took it to a
dormitor party. After drinking
heavily, Brinkmeyer collapsed adn
was carried to her bed to sleep it
off. She never woke up.
"I don't think people are
aware of all the damage alcohol
can do," says Dr. David Barthwell,
medical director for the drug and
alcohol program at Northwestern
Memorial Hospital in Chicago.
"Alcohol companies make alcohol
look so appealing, but the truth is,
if you aren't careful, it can kill
you."

Involvement, participation required for success, says Nordvall
Dean of First Year Students urges new arrivals to get involved

GCPR When students first come
to college, the number of pos
sible activities to join is over
whelming. In addition, there is
the academic challenge of col
lege courses, dean of First Year
Students, Robert Nordvall, rec
ommends that students take their
time reviewing the options avail
able and deciding the activities
in which they want to participate
at Gettysburg, but he notes that
first year students should become
involved in the life of the Col
lege. A leading scholar on
the affect that college has upon
students is Dr. Alexander W.
Austin of the Cooperative Insti
tutional Research Program at

UCLA. Dr. Astin os an alumnus of
Gettysburg College. His work indi
cates that the quality of the educa
tional experience that students get in
college is directly related to how
much they are involved both inside
and outside the classroom in their
college experience. Not surpris
ingly, students who put more effort
into college, receive much greater
benefits from their four years of
higher education.
Dean Nordvall empha
sizes, however, that although almost
all activities provided benefits, not
all co-curricular activities are equal
in what they provide to students.
Students should look for activities
that provided to them strong oppor
tunities for personal growth. A small
group of activities that have proved
particularly powerful in fostering the

growth and development of stu
dents are the service learning pro
grams and community service pro
grams, and opportunities for inde
pendent study and research with
professors. There are activities
that students name as particularly
important as they reflect upon their
four years at Gettysburg. There
four are not the only activities that
play such a role, and students can,
of course, take part in a number of
very beneficial activities at the
College. The Gettysburg Is Volun
teering (GIV) Day activities on the
Monday afternoon of Orientation
from 6:30 pm - 8:00 pm there will
be an Open House at the Center
for Public Service at which stu
dents can find out more about com
munity service and service learn¬

ing programs. Study abroad op
portunities will be discussed in the
rotating discussion sessions on
Monday morning of Orientation.
First year students do not ordi
narily work on research and inde
pendent study projects with pro
fessors, but during their first year
students should be sampling the
various academic programs at the
College in order to find out which
programs offer the academic chal
lenges and opportunities that are
most attractive to them.
Service learning pro
grams, community service pro
grams, study abroad, and indepen
dent study and research are pow
erful experiencesbecause they
stretch students. They force stu
dents to do and see new things.

They force students to look at the
world differently. Students can
graduate from Gettysburg College
without participating in any of
these programs, but students who
want to experience the full range
of a Gettysburg College education
should select the best opportuni
ties that the College has to offer,
both inside and outside of the class
room.

Gardner garners safety award
College recognizes staff member's contribution

Terry R. Gardner, a car
penter in the facilities services
department at Gettysburg Col
lege, was recently presented the
Quarterly Safety Suggestion
Award by the College's Residen
tial and Workplace Safety Com
mittee. A resident of Gettys
burg, Gardner was cited for sub
mitting the best safety suggestion
for the first three months of 1997.
Gardner's suggestion, that the
steps for entering and exiting the
bucket on a bucket truck be re
designed to provide safer access,
was judged to be the best of the
16 suggestions submitted for the
quarter. Gardner received a $50
cash award, letter and certificate
of appreciation from College
President Gordon Haaland and
safety coffee mug. He will also
have his name placed on the
Safety Suggestion Award plaque
located in Pennsylvania Hall.

Gettysburg: A Beginner s Guide

"I'll meet you in fif
teen minutes at Stine Lake and
we can head over to Servo. Or
maybe we can just go to LD's,
but first I have to swing over to
the CUB and hit the MAC."
Your friend just called
and left this message on you
answering machine. You've
been here for less than a week,
so naturally you think, "what is
he talking about?" Have no fear,
new student, because this handy
litle glossary of Gettysburg
speak is sure to get you through
these social straits unscathed
and sounding like an old 'Burg
pro. First things first. "Where
am I now?" and "You want me
to go where?"

Servo: a.k.a. the Din
ing Hall. Probably nicknamed
back when the college's dining
service was contracted out to a
company called Servomation
(eons ago). Anyhow, you eat
here. Tip: Get here early on
Premium Entree Night. The
Cordon Bleu rules.
CUB: a.k.a. The Col
lege Union Building. Here you
will find the mailroom, school
store, ballroom, first-year stu
dent laundry room and the cam
pus alternative to Servo, Cafe

101. The Junction (for -
merly known as the Dive):
This is a place that studetn or
ganizations can hold meetings,
the Student Activities Council
has live performances and mov
ies, and where students can just
hang out. Cafe 101: a.k.a. the
Bullet Hole. Looking for a
quick snack while you're on the
run? Travel beyond the Junc
tion, past the mailroom, and
you're in The Hole. You have
$3.75 on you meal card that's
good for breakfast, lunch and
dinner. Remember, only two
prepackaged items per meal.
The catch to Cafe 101 is that
you can only use your meal

cards at specific hours: 8:00 -
10:15 am for breakfast, 1:30 -
4:00 pm for lunch, and 4:30 -
9:00 pm for dinner. However,
it stays open until midnight in
case you're in the mood for a
late night snack.
Mailroom: Every
weekday, between 11:30 am and
1 pm, the mailroom transforms
from a drab series of metal
boxes into the very epicenter of
social activity at Gettysburg
College. Here the evening's
plans are made, adn flirting is
perfected, check your mail,
two, three, four times a day!
MAC: a.k.a. Money
Access Center, this is an auto
mated teller machine outside the
CUB. It's the same as MOST,
Cirrus, or whatever you're used
to. This innocent-looking ma
chine cna be both a Friday night
life-saver and a Sunday morn
ing nightmare. Beware of the
lure of fast cash.

Mussdman Library:
It's Tuesday night and nothing's
going on. where can I go to
hang out and meet new people?
The Library is the answer. On
any given evening, the first
floors are filled with students
pretending to study while pick
ing up the lastest gossip on cam
pus. Plus, when you get home
and find that your parents have
called, you can honestly say that
you were at the library. But be
ing there and studying are two
entriely different issues. If you
really need to do some work, the

third adn fourth fllors are your
best bet. Night owls will be
happy to see that the library is
opne 24 hours a day. And for
those slaves to the almighty
bean, librarians brew coffee and
provide hot water for tea adn
cocoa for those students pulling
all-nighters. Also, the library
has three day/three movie video
rentals. They may not have all
the newest releases, but they do
have some of the best movies
ever made. The library is one
of the three "Mussleman" loca
tions on campus, the others be¬

ing Mussleman stadium, and If the phone rings once > it > s an
Mussleman Hall, located in the on.campus cal, and you can risk

Upperclass Quad.
Bream Wright
Hauser: This is the campus gym
adn field house. It's located be
yond the CUB adn across hte
street from the Apple apartments.
Be sure you don't confuse Bream
with the...
PlankGym: This older
gym is found between the CUB
and Masters Hall. There's a
games room adn fitness room in
the basement. WZBT, the col¬

lege radio station at 91.1 FM is
located in the basement. Make
some requests and bug the DJ by
dialing x6313. Many studetn or
ganizations also call Plank home,
including the Student Activites
office, GECO (enviornmental
concerns organization), the Black
Student Union, Student Senate,
the Gettysburgian, the Spectrum
(yearbook), and the IFC (Inter
fraternity Council), the Center
for Public Service is also in
Plank, but on the first floor.

Stine Lake: Not really
a lake at all, Stine Lake is actu
ally the open area between Plank
Gym and the library. One theory
for the origin of its odd name may
be that the field is known to flood
during heavy stroms. Almost
knee-deep water is not unusual
on the "lake." Afteranastystorm,
put on old clothes, go out, slide
around and have your own little
Woodstock.

BruaHalLKIine The
ater, and Stevens Theater:
These are all the same place and
for that reason, it can get rather
confusing.
Schmucker Hall: This
is the colege's art and music
building. Stop in and check out
the art gallery which is filled with
the work of your fellow
gettysburgians. Frequent recitals
and concerts there, too. and
they're free!
Other Important Stuff

answering it with a more creative
greeting. If it has a double ring, it's
most likely Mom and shoudl be
anwered accordingly.
The Weather Guy(s):
There are two numbers you can cal to
get time adn hte local weather. These
numbers are helpful, but they can
becoem serious habits. You'll soon
find yourself calling them before you
walk across the hall. Anyway, here's
the spiel: 337-1234: Your basic com
puter guy with time and weather.
334-0505: Advanced system
run by the local newspaper, The Get
tysburg Time. This one gives you
options. Dial 1131 for a three day
forecast. You can also get daily horo
scopes, sports scores and dirt on the
day's soaps.

line is busy, you can access their web
site at http://

is fast asleep. Grab aconsciousamigo
and hit the diner. A plethora of tasty

burgers, sinful desserts and colorful
late night patrons are sure to be on
hand to keep you entertained. Try the

with its own pros adn cons, the

toppings, but no hot dog. Ernie's is
the perfect place for thoese looking to

spend under $5 and not go awaty
feeling hungry.

the perfect place to satisfy any of

personal vice is nicotine, caffeine,
slurpies_, scratch tickets., or those
delicious hot dogs, 7-11 is there for
you, 24 hours a day.
TheBlueParr otBistr o:
Serving up pasta and seafood
dishes, the Parrot is the perfect
place for a pre-movie dinner. It's
on Chambersburg Street, just up
from K&K.
Chinatown Expr ess: If
you're looking for something be
sides pizza adn subs, Chinatown
Express offers a wide variety of
Chinese food for take out only.

Kilwin' s: The best ice
cream in the world. Period, and

a biology lab report.

ant: For all your grocery needs,

ing like a set from "American

this 50's ice-cream drive-in is
