College receives grant for Civil War Studies program
Luce Professorship to begin in 1999

GCPR Gettysburg College has
been awarded a grant of more than
$500,000 from the Henry Luce
Foundation to support the estab
lishment of a professorship in
Civil War studies. The Henry R.
Luce Professor of the Civil War
Era will lead an undergraduate
program in Civil War studies and
will develop and direct "The Get
tysburg Semester," a program se
lecting students from across the
country to participate in a semes
ter of intensive interdisciplinary
study of the Civil War era.
Funds from the grant,
which covers an initial period of
six years, will be used primarily
to provide salary and benefits for
a faculty member chosen to fill the
Luce Professorship. The grant
was announced by the
Foundation's Chairman Henry
Luce III. The Luce Professor will
be selected by a committee at the
College after completion of a na¬

tional search.
The recipient's appoint
ment will be made in 1998, and the
Luce Professor will begin teaching
at Gettysburg by the fall of 1999.
Gettysburg is one of only
tow higher education institutions to
receive a professorship from the
Luce Foundation during this year.
The other was Johns Hopkins Uni
versity. "Gettysburg College is
very grateful for the support of the
Luce Foundation which will allow
us an opportunity to develop great
strength in Civil War studies, we
sincerely believe that we can de
velop a program unmatched at any
other site in the country," said Gor
don Haaland, president of Gettys
burg College. "Our aim is to use
of existing relationships with the
community of Civil War scholars
and our natural geographic connec
tion with the pivotal battle of that
War to establish an integrated first-

rate undergraduate program that
allows not only our students but
also visiting students access to a
unique combination of scholarship
and original research materials."
"Many of the basic issues
of contemporary American society
came into focus during the Civil
War era, among those being the
relevance of race in a democracy,
the proper balance of federal and
state government, the principles
that bind Americans, the meaning
of a union. We think that a
multidisciplinary examination of
the Civil War era is a wonderful,
rich, and sound way to examine
our social fabric," said Dr. Daniel
DeNicola, the college's chief aca
demic officer.
"The professorship will
provide scholarly leadership for an
intensive program in this era, ad
dressing not only the causes and
events of the Civil War and its af
termath, but its cultural and intel¬

lectual milieu. The program will
draw on not only miliary and po
litical history, but, among many,
the fields of economics, sociology,
philosophy, African-american
studies, women's studies, rhetoric,
religion, literature, the visual arts,
and music. Such a study helps us
understand what was changed and
what was preserved by the war,
what was lost and gained," added
DeNicola.
The Henry R. Luce Pro
fessorship Program wa established
in 1969 by the New York-based
foundation to encourage academic
innovation and creativity through
integrative and interdisciplinary
approaches to teaching and re
search in American private higher
education.
The first recipient of the
Luce Professorship in Civil War
Studies will be responsible for fur
ther developing existing College
curricular programs into an aca¬

demic concentration or minor pro
gram, with direct responsibility for
teaching the introductory and
capstone courses in that program.
By the third year of the grant, the
Luce Professor will develop and
the direct "The Gettysburg Semes
ter," for which up to 25 under
graduate students will be selected
from applicants across the coun
try for a one-semester, integrated
program of Civil War studies.
"We will continue to sup
port the Luce Professor, the estab
lished Gettysburg program, and
the Gettysburg Semester upon the
completion of the six-year Luce
grant period," said DeNicola.
"The college has the option of ap
plying to the Luce Foundation for
three additional years of support,
and we are confident that our pro
grams will show sufficient
progress and strength to warrant
serious consideration."

College receives Kline Grant

$200,000 awarded for renovation of Carlisle House

GCPR Gettysburg College has re
ceived a grant of $200,000 from
the Josiah W. and Bessie H. Kline
Foundation, Inc., which will be
used to partially fund renovations
to a residence facility for students
dedicated to addressing issues re
lating to wellness and healthy
lifestyles.
The grant will be paid in
equal installments during a five
year period by the Harrisburg
based charitable foundatio. The
renovation project, which will in
clude interior and exterior im
provements, along with a overhaul
of the mechanical and electrical
systems of the building, will be
gin this summer and will be com
pleted next summer.
"The continuing generous
support of the Kline Foundation
will enable Gettysburg College to
accelerate the completion of a sig¬

nificant renovation.," said Gordon
A. Haaland, president of Gettys
burg. "The concept of specialty
housing, in general, and this
wellness house, in particular, em
body a critical aspect of a Gettys
burg education, that of combining
classroom learning with students'
cocurricular activities and social
activism."
The studen t housing unit to
be renovated, the Carlisle House,
is one of IS specialty housing units
established by the College to allow
students with shared interests an
opportunity to pursue their goals in
a common residence.
The Carlisle House was es
tablished in 1990 as a result of stu
dent requests. Students choosing
to reside in the building commit to
planning three programs each se
mester which focus the attention of
the campus community on

wellness, including issues of sub
stance abuse.
The Kline Foundation was
established in 1952 exclusively for
charitable, scientific, literary and
educational purposes.
Both Josiah and Bessie
Kline served at one time as trust
ees of Gettysgburg College. The
foundation has supported previous
projects at the College involving
the construction of the Mussleman
Library and new athletic complex,
and the renovation of facilities for
the theater program and one of the
College's original buildings. A
scholarship fund named in honor
of Joseph Simpson, a former presi
dent of the foundation and College
trustee, has also been established
at Gettysburg.

Plagiarism or
Inspiration?

By Elizabeth Peny
College Press Service

college guidance counselors have
scorned IvyEssays for providing
"cheat-sheets." But Kaufman says
because IvyEssays
(www.ivyessays.com) is available
to millions over the Internet, the
service, "levels the playing field
for college applicants, making in
formation more accessible and af
fordable to everyone."
In return, college appli
cants can buy customized pack
ages through the mail, e-mail, or
fax, of five to 10 essays costing as
little as $10 for undergraduate es
says, $20 for law schools, and up
to $60 for business schools. Stu
dents can choose packages tailored
to their wishes, by requesting es
says from a particular school, for
example, or essays relevant to cer
tain events and backgrounds.
Kaufman says his site has acquired
more than 1,00 essays since his site
was conceived last fall.

The deadline for law
school is just a few weeks away,
but your application still sits blank
on the kitchen table. You think you
have the grades, but you don't
want to blow your chances by not
getting the application exactly
right — including the personal es
say that's required.
So, what do you do? If
you're like a growing number of
prospective students, you might be
tempted to turn to,the Internet.
IvyEssays, an Internet site headed
by 28-year-old Williams College
graduate Daniel Kaufman, offers
to buy and sell college essays writ
ten by applicants who already got
into top-notch law schools. For a
small fee, you, too, could own an
admissions essay that was good
enough to get another student into
Yale Law.

Eddie Plank's birthday bash sure to hit a home run Sunday

by Paul Hutchinson
Contributing Writer
This Sunday, August 31,
Gettysburg College will be cel
ebrating the birthday of one of its
own: Baseball Hall of Famer
Eddie Plank. The organizations
housed in Plank Gymnasium,
named for the old southpaw (in

Features -
"Cotton" the act

Student band rocks Junction to packed house

byBarbDickson FeatuKS Editor
The Junction pumped with
music Sunday night, as many up
perclassmen spent their first nights
back on campus dancing the night
away. Cotton Roberts performed to
a large crowd for two hours, intro
ducing the first year students to the
Junction and getting upperclass
men back into the swing of things.
Cotton Roberts is a five per
son band, three of whom have at
tended Gettysburg College. The
band began this summer when Jon
Pistey, who graduated in May, and
Nate Bowen, '98, got together and
decided to form a band.
According to Bowen, Pistey
asked if he wanted to be in a band,
and Bowen gave a noncommittal
answer. Eventually, though, it be
came less of a "whatever" answer
and more of a definite plan.

They were joined by current
senior Chris Paumi and Chris Fos
ter, a friend of Pistey's from
Greece. It was only recently that
Jen Knight, the lead singer, joined
the group.
"We wanna rock," says

Pistey of the group. Cotton Rob
erts, he explained, was a character
in a Willie Nelson movie called
Honeysuckle Rose. The character
was a "total cheeseball" and
mocked by the other characters in
the film. The band liked the idea
and chose that for the name.
The band started at 10 to a
packed house, which fluctuated
throughout the evening. There
was, however, always a number of
people in the front, dancing to the
loud, pounding music.
"It was a lot of fun to dance
to," commented sophomore Krissi
Fisher. "A great way to meet out
going first-years." There were
some of these brave first year stu
dents in the front, dancing away
with the upperclassmen.
Cotton Roberts is the first
band to play the Junction this
school year. They were quickly
followed by blues artist K. J. James
on Wednesday afternoon, and this
Saturday night with the first Cof
feehouse of the year.

The band's music consisted
of both original music and classics
such as "Bad Moon on the Rise"
and "Old Time Rock V Roll."

which ended the evening. "Don't
ask for an encore," said Pistey, "be
cause you're not going to get one."
Pistey made comments
throughout the night As a recent
graduate, he remarked, "I'm
amused to be up here...Four years
ago I was down there," gesturing
to where the audience sat. Pistey
now works in the basement of the
library.
Everyone at the Junction
seemed to be enjoying the band.
"The vocalist was excellent," com
mented sophomore Christine
Sedlacko. "[She had a] great
voice." To make this even more
impressive is the fact that Knight,
the lead singer, only joined the
group a few weeks ago.
Cotton Roberts is a band in
transition, however. Both the
drummer, Foster, and Bowen are
not able to be in the band any
longer, so Pistey is again looking
for the musically inclined to join
his band.

.The fate of the band is yet
to be sealed, but they did their job
Sunday night: the Junction rocked.
And that's just what Pistey wanted.



Previews mislead, but this "Theory" is worth the proof

by Jon Fr oehhch
StaffWriter "I don't know what I know,
but I know it's big." - Jerry
Fletcher Though the television pre
views for "Conspiracy Theory,"
starring two of Hollywood's best
looking and well known faces Mel
Gibson (Lethal Weapon, Mad
Max) and Julia Robers (Pretty
Woman, The Pelican Brief), give
viewers the stereotypical appear
ance of an action movie, this illu
sion is forgotten not long into the
movie.
The previews show scenes
that, though indeed from the
movie, seem to be taken totally out
of context. Perhaps these scenes
of car chases andSWAT team
sieges are what draw many audi
ences to the theater, but it is easy
to forget what one expected to see

because of the way this clever, ex
citing, and only semi-action movie
is presented.
Although a misrepresenta
tion of a movie in its previews is
usually a sign that it has something
to hide, audiences will most likely
be pleasantly surprised by this new
film from director Richard Donner
(Superman, The Goonies).
Jerry Fletcher, played by
Gibson, is a New York taxi driver
whoisabitofaheadcase. Though
some might insist that New York
cabbies are nuts by definition,
Fletcher is definitely a special case.
This character seems to
bring out the best in Gibson be
cause he both gives him a chance
to do some real acting and because
Gibson's natural charm and humor
gives the fictional Jerry Fletcher
the human touch that audiences
crave.

By the time the movie starts,
Fletcher is already in the midst of
a rather one-sided relationship that
borders on stalking with govern
ment worker Alice Sutton, played
with heart by Julia Roberts.
In accordance with the title,
Jerry is convinced that everything
is a government cover-up and is
trying to alert the public through
his newsletter: Conspiracy Theory.
He is the kind of guy who doesn't
trust anyone - except Alice Sutton.
Sutton understandably
doesn't believe Fletcher and is a
little annoyed with his ravings
about such things as sperm
samples from the fathers of Nobel
Prize winners being stored under
the ice at Rockefeller Center. How
ever, her internal kindness won't
permit her to watch Jerry get
locked up or to stop Jerry from
growing on her.

The plot of Conspiracy
Theory really gets moving when
what the viewer suspected all
along is revealed to be true: Jerry
is paranoid for goodreason. This
reason is personified by the su
premely evil Doctor Jonas, played
perfectly by Patrick Stewart (Star
Trek - the Next Generation, Robin
Hood: Men in Tights). Though
Jerry is convinced that he is being
chased because his newsletter has
hit a nerve with the government,
Jonas is in pursuit of Jerry for a
reason left unknown to audiences
until the end of the movie.
Conspiracy Theory marks
another success in the vast collec
tion belonging to acclaimed direc
tor Richard Donner. Donner, hav
ing previously worked with
Gibson on both the Western com
edy Maverick and all three install
ments of the police action trilogy

Lethal Weapon, seems to have ac
quired both the skill of utilizing
Gibson to his fullest potential as
well as that of making an exciting
movie with a balanced combina
tion of action, drama, and humor;
all three are abundant in Con
spiracy Theory.
The only gripe one could
possibly have with this movie is
that the ending is, for the lack of a
more descriptive word, cheesy.
But the fact remains that many
people, though they won't be quick
to admit it, like cheesy stuff. We
see plenty of reality every day.
Part of the reason we go to the
movies is for a change - and that's
OK. Conspiracy Theory wasn't
afraid to give audiences what they
want. This fact plus great casting
and a gripping plot make Con
spiracy Theory one of the few truly
good movies to come out this
summer.

See the world and
serve it. too

by Beck)'Card
Contributing Writer
Concerned with Native
American issues? Want to learn
more about poverty in the United
States? Interested in the plight of
the Nicaraguan coffee picker?
Concerned about the AIDS epi
demic? Then you may be inter
ested in being part of a Service
Learning Project.
For those students interested
in learning more about the world
around them, the Center for Pub
lic Service offers Service-Learn
ing Projects over the reading days
in October, winter break, spring
break, and at the end of the aca
demic year.
Emily Yardley '00 com
mented, "My Service-Learning
experience in Alabama helped to
bring about an awareness of who I
was and what I truly wanted to do
with my life."

Yardley, who participated in
a project last year, continued, "It
helped me to see in which direc
tion I wanted to grow."
Other participants have had
similar reactions. Jessica White,
who graduated in May, remarked,
"The New York City Service-

While under the influence of the hypnotist the Astonishing Neal, this
student believed the microphone stand to be the most beutiful woman
in the world. Photo by MarkAstrom

Learning Project opened my eyes
to the realities of the many faces
of AIDS in a way that no textbook
ever could. I will not forget the
individuals I met during these few
days." The first information session
about these trips is Tuesday, Sep
tember 9 at 9 pm in the CUB
lounge. The Service-Learning
Program Coordinators will be
there to provide you with food and
information and to answer all your
questions.
For more information, con
tact Becky Card, Kristin Notte, or
Andrew Mude at the Center for
Puhlic Service at x6490.

Suspense movie will
make you Scream

byBarbDickson Features Editor
The movie Scream opened
last winter to critical acclaim and
high popularity. The latest movie
from Wes Craven, the director of
the horror classic Nightmare on
Elm Street, was an almost instant
hit. The story is that of a small
town in California, Santa Rosa. It
focuses on the lives of a group of
five students who attend
Woodsboro High School. The
main character is Sidney (Neve
Campbell), whose mother was
murdered almost a year before the
action in the movie takes place.

Her life is once
again disrupted
as two of her
classmates are
brutally mur
dered one night,
and the killer
then focuses on
Sidney. She
doesn't know

who to trust and who not to trust.
And the body count just keeps ris
ing. The plot sounds like that of
a typical horror movie. There is a
wonderful twist, though. It's a
horror movie about teens who
grew up watching horror movies.
They know all of the cliches, and
Sidney's friend Randy (Jamie
Kennedy) tells us "the rules": how
to survive a horror movie. At a
party, as the group watches a hor
ror movie, Randy lists them for us:

-Don t answer the phone
-Don't open the door
-Don't have sex
-Don't drink or do drugs
-Don't go back in the house
-Don't hide in the closet
-Don't just stand there
-Don't trip

-Don't say "I'll be right
back," because you won't be
The list goes on. There are
also numerous references to other
movies, and a comment is made
at one point about a horror movie
director named Wes Carpenter
(combining Craven's name with
that of John Carpenter, another
horror director).
The movie is highly enter
taining and keeps you guessing
throughout. It isn't until the very
end that you have any idea who
the killer could be. The ending

was done wonderfully, with shock
and suspense mixed powerfully to
gether.
The cast was perfect, though
Skeet Ulrich (Last Dance, The
Craft) as Billy, Sidney's boy
friend, was a little too reminiscent
of Johnny Depp's character in A
Nightmare on Elm Street.
Campbell was perfect as the al
most perfect Sidney. While there
was an element of the audience
wanting to protect her, there was
also a feeling that she could take
care of herself.
That is part of what makes
Scream such a great movie. In
many horror movies, you almost
want the charac
ters to be killed
because they are
viivmiw

CY\ 1
"Do you
like scary
movies?"-

uvvuuuv r
sostupid. In this
movie the char
acters are not
dumb; after all,
they grew up on
this stuff. In
stead of con
stantly saying to

yourself, "What an idiot!", you'll
be saying, "Great idea!" These

characters know how to think for
themselves.
Cameos are made by Drew
Barrymore as Casey, the killer's
first victim, and Henry Winkler as
Mr. Himbry, the school principal.
It is the killing of Casey that brings
us into the story and gives us a hint
of what is to come: as the killer
talks to her on the phone, he quiz
zes her on such movies as Friday
the 13th and Halloween.
Courtney Cox is also in the
cast as Gale, a local television
news reporter always trying to get

the story first. You love to hate
her, though you might just change
your mind later on.
There is a sequel already in
the works, though it makes you
wonder whether Scream will turn
into another Friday the 13th with
a string of horrible sequels.
This is a movie that keeps
you on your toes the whole way
through. The script was brilliantly
(as much as you can use that word
to describe a horror movie) writ
ten by Kevin Williamson. The
conclusion of it comes as a shock.

If you like horror movies, this is a
definite must-see.
Note: Scream will be play
ing tonight outside of Plank Gym
or inside the Junction if it rains.

Dear Casey...

Dear Casey:
I have a pr oblem. Befor e
Ileftfor school,mypar entswer e
nice enough to give me a cr edit
card and unlimited access to my
chargeaccountatthebookstor &
While I know that its ther efor
emergency purposes, I am
scar ed that I will star t to go
crazywithit Whatsuggestions
do you have so that I don't
charge too much?

Sincerely,
Charged Up
Dear Charged Up,
First, you must realize
that having a charge account is a
right, not a privledge. In essence,
it is a step towards that ingima
many refer to as reality. Being
afraid of going charge crazy is
probaly not uncommon among
college students because of the
ease in which that piece of plastic
makes buying all those
"neccessary items." Here are some
tips that might keep you from go
ing overboard and into the ocean
of debt. First, never charge
anyhting that you could easily pay
for with the good old green. Sec
ond, never charge anything that
you know that you, nor your par
ents can easliy pay off. For ex
ample, the book store can be
tempting because of it's enticing
array of clothing. It would probaly

be kosher to charge an occasional
item, but do not plan to do your
entire winter wardrobe shopping in
the bookstore's clothing depart
ment. Lastly, always think to your
self, "is this absolutley, and
complely neccessary?". If your
answer is a maybe, go home, think
about it, even discuss it with your
parents, and if you decide you still
want the item, come back the next
day. I can almost guarentee it will
still be there. Utilizing these tips
will definitly help to keep your
charge account down, and you and
your parents happy campers.
Dear Casey,
I'masophmor e, and
last year my best friend and I
decidedtolivetogether . We've
been her efor a week and she' s
driving me up a wall. I don't
want to lose her as a friend, but
Ican'tKvewhhher ,whatshould
Ido? Thanks,
New Roomate Needed

Pear New Roomate Needed,
This seems to be one of
those curve balls life tends to throw
at us. You think to yourself, "what
could b better than living with my
best friend?" Well, often a lot. In
being best friends you know a lot
about each others tendencies, and
some may even urk you, but be
fore this year you could retreat to

your room and she to hers if things
got sticky. Now this is no longer
the case. Most likely you and your
best friend do a lot of things
togehter, eat breakfast, go to some
of the same classes, eat lunch, go
to the same activities, eat dinner
together, ect. And then, after a long
period of togetherness, you go
home, well, together. This is a time
bomb just waiting to explode. Too
much togehterness cna lead to a lot
of aggravation and sometimes
heartache. You and your best
friend need to sit down and have a
heart to heart NOW. If the prob
lem persists, it will only get worse,
and could cause a serious hiatus in

the relationship.
You are concerned about
loosing her as a friend. Listen up.
Tell it to her straight, but not cru
elly. Say, "look roomie, I love you
dearly but your stepping on my
toes and it is starting to hurt." Lay
all the cards on the table and get
her feedback. You might be sur
prised by her reaction, YOU might
actually be driving her up a wall
as well. A true friend will be pa
tient, listen and respond in a way
that will probaly bring you two
closer. Lastly, have faith in your
friendship. Good friends are few
and far between, and sometimes in
order to get close to someone you
might actually have to move apart.

Women's tennis ends season second in conference

From Staff Reports
Junior Kate Goodall
and sophomore Bev Jack
son emerged as the leading
players on Gettysburg
College's 1997 women's
tennis team.
Gettysburg completed
the regular season with a
14-2 record and was 8-2 in
the Centennial Conference,
good for second place. The
Bullets were the defending
conference champs.
Goodall, playing out
of the number six singles
post most of the season,
recorded a 14-1 record.
Jackson, who handled the
number five spot through
out the season, was 14-2
for the year.

Goodall and Jackson
formed Gettysburg's top
number three doubles team
and were also the team
leaders in that area. They
posted a 13-1 record, the
second best in the Centen
nial Conference.
However, the season's
top honor went to the
Bullets' number two
singles player, senior
Cynthia Hoenes. Hoenes
not only made the All
Centennial Conference first

team, but was named
co-player of the year, along
with Johns Hopkins' Zeena
Abdi. Hoenes posted a 13
3 record.
Hoenes, one of only
two seniors on this year's
team, completes her colle
giate career with a stunning
54-13 singles record and a
48-10 doubles mark for an
overall 102-23 record.
Hoenes was joined by
junior Tara Schmitt to form
Gettysburg's number one
doubles team. They were
14-2 on the season and
were named to the all
conference first team.
They won their first seven
matches to end the season
with 14 wins.

Hoenes not only
proved to be a strong
competitor on the court, but
in the classroom as well.
She and senior Mary Joy
Troxel were named to the
Centennial Conference's
academic honor roll for
carrying a 3.40 GPA or
better.
Gettysburg completed

its sixth season under head
coach Bill Pfitzinger this
Spring. The Bullets are 66
21 under his guidance.

Photo by Mark Aslrom
Doubles partners Cynthia Hoenes and Tara Schmitt celebrate after winning a set last spring.
The pair ended their Senio r season with a 14-2 record


Men's golf team racks up records
Forbes sets thiee during championship

FromStaf fRepor ts
Senior Jeff Forbes
carried off the bulk of the
honors on the Gettysburg
College varsity golf team
which completed its
season in the spring.
Forbes was named to
the All-District JJ team.
Forbes captured his second
straight Centennial Confer
ence championship and
completed the season with
935 strikes for 12 rounds

and a team low aver
age of 77.9. During the
conference championships
he set three records: low
total per round, 72; low
first two rounds, 151; and
low gross, 224.
Forbes' closest com
petitor was sophomore
Matt Beckert, who carded
an 80.1 average on 801
strokes for ten rounds. He
was team medalist once
during the season.

Rounding out
Gettysburg's top five golfers
on the ten-player roster, were
Senior Ryan Coffey, with an
85.2 average for 11 rounds;
freshman Rick Deutsch, 89.1
for eight rounds; and sopho
more Matt Doorley, 87.6
average for eight rounds.
Gettysburg completed
the season with a 39-27
record and placed fourth in
the conference champion
ship.

Strong starting lineup, Streeter's 20th make for promising season

FromStaf f Repor ts
Not only will
Gettysburg College be
launching its 105th football
season this year, but Head
Coach Barry Streeter will
begin his 20th year at the
Bullet helm. It all began
Monday when 93
candidates reported for the
first day of pre-season
drills. Streeter is currently
the college's all-time
coaching leader with 108
victories, 80 losses and five
draws. His best season was
1985 when he guided the
Bullets through their only
undefeated regular season

and eventually completed
the year with a 11-1-1 slate
following a semi-final
placing in the NCAA
Division III playoffs.
Streeter added three
new coaches to his staff of
eight. Steve Reider, a 1995
Dickinson graduate, and
Tom Waranavage, a 1993
Muhlenberg grad, have
been assigned to the wide
receivers and tight ends
respectively. The new
outside linebacker coach is
Marty Ogle, a 1974
graduate of Sheperd.
Among the 93
candidates Streeter will
greeted on Sunday were 49

freshmen and 44
upperclassmen, including
31 letter winners. Heading
the list is sophomore Paul
Smith. Smith, a first team
all-centennial conference
fullback as a freshman,
rushed 888 yards and
scored nine touchdowns in
1996. He has been named
on of USA III Football's
top sophomores to watch ii
1997. Leading the Bullets
in 1997 will be elected
captains Joe Hodakowski
and Rob Sena.
Hodakowski is a senior
linebakcer while Sena is a
senior defensive back.

The one nice thing
facing Streeter is the fact
that he has a solid starting
veteran at every position
except offensive left guard.
With an offensive line
intact, backed by an
experienced backfield, the
Bullets could unleash a
potent offense. Veterans
Chris Fugaro and Wes
Wells are back at
quarterback while veterans
Matt Helwig and Donny
McNellis will be at the
halfback slots. Joining
Smith at the fullback slot
will be another veteran,
Henry Unger, as well as the
return of Dan Sheats.

Sheats took a year off last
season for personal
reasons, after rushing for
273 yards and one
touchdown in five games as
a freshman in 1995.
The Bullets spent
the first two days going
through physicals,
equipmentadjustments,
testing and meetings. It has
been down to business ever
since with tow-a-day
sessions.
Gettysburg will
open its season on
Saturday, Sept. 13 at
Hampden-Sydney.

Football kicks off 105th season

Bullets sixth in Conference

LANCASTER, Pa.
-Can the dream continue in
Collegeville? Apparently
the coaches and SIDs in the
Conference think so.
Ursinus, which won
its first-ever Conference
football championship in
1996, is the favorite to
repeat as Centennial
Conference football
champion in a poll of the
Conference's head coaches
and media. Each head
coach and Sports
Information Director from
each Conference locale
participated in the poll.

The Bears received
eight of a possible 15 first
place votes (voters were
not permitted to vote for
their own team) for 81
points to outdistance
Franklin & Marshall, which
was second with 66 points.
Ursinus returns 15 starters
and 59 lettermen from last
season's 9-2 team which

was ousted in the NCAA
playoffs by Lycoming, 31
24. The Diplomats,
which finished second to
the Bears in the '96
standings, barely
outpointed Johns Hopkins
(64), Dickinson (63), and
Western Maryland (60), in
one of the closest preseason
ballotings in the
Conference's 15 year
history. F&M received
three first place votes,
while Western Maryland
picked up two. Johns
Hopkins and Dickinson
were on the top line in one
ballot apiece.
Gettysburg was
sixth with 49 points, while
Muhlenberg (22) and
Swathmore (15) rounded
out the field.
The Centennial
openers are set for Sept. 19
-20, when Gettysburg will
host Western Maryland.

10-9. The Bullets' season

probably used phrases
like 'keep believing' and
'never give up' more ¦
than I ever have before
as a coach. It must have

had some impact though_,
because by the time our

worked our way into
being one of the top four
Division III teams in the
country."

four seniors in their

the Bullets with 31 goals Gettysburg by scoring 26

and 10 assists.

TKE_'s troubles
trivial ?
House closed, but not for long

by Rebecca Babbit
The Tau Kappa Epsilon house, which
planned to undergo a $500,000 renovation
this year, sustained $30,000 in damage when
an unknown number of TKE brothers
"kicked in walls and windows," said TKE
president, Danny Smith.
The incident occurred during final
exam week last semester on May 8 and 9.
"There were 10 to 15 people in the house,"
said Smith. "There was really nobody
around."
Legal action is being taken against the
brothers accused of vandalizing the prop
erty. All disciplinary action against the
brothers accused of causing the damage has
been initiated by the TKE Board of Advi
sors, a group of alumni who act as a hous
ing corporation. Neither the college nor
TKE nationals have taken action against any
of the brothers regarding this incident.

TKE's renovations were set to begin
this summer, however, "'because of the
amount of damage, the project has been
pushed back a year," said Smith.
TKE alumni were able to raise
$550,000 to pay for renovations-the most
of any house on campus.

The College was considering loaning
up to $300,000 to TKE as part of a program

to renovate fraternity houses on campus, but
is now reconsidering the offer.
"We are not prepared to give them
money, until we are convinced they are
moving in the right direction," said Dennis
Murphy, Dean of Greek Organizations.
Most of the brothers are living off
campus, according to Smith.
"The house is not livable," said Jason
Gareis, President of the Interfraternity coun
cil. "We basically told them, 'you're on
your own'" said Murphy. "This is an un
usual situation. We're not in the position to
house 25 more students."
TKE is "running the same," said
Smith. "We are not in trouble."
"This adds pressure from sources that
had negative ideas about the greek system,"
said Gareis. "It's fuel for the fire."

"We're going to have to work hard to
get more positive publicity," said Gareis.
The Psi chapter of TKE was founded
at Gettysburg in 1926 and currently has 33
active brothers.

Student Senate highlights: 9/1/97

byDanLarkin
News Editor The Gettysburg College
Student Senate held its first meet
ing of the 1997-1998 academic
year Monday evening.
President Abbey Rodgers
opened the meeting by welcom
ing back the returning senators.
Rodgers stated that Senate's main
goal for the year would be "alter
native social programming," and
the majority of senate business
should focus on this goal. She
also stated a desire to reduce the
time of senate meetings, with an
emphasis placed on "quality, not
quantity."
It was announced that elec
tions for first year senators and

class officers will be held on
Wednesday Sept. 10 and Thursday
11. All first-year students who are
interested are encouraged to attend
information sessions held in the sen
ate offices.
The formation of a commit
tee was announced to submit a pro
posal to the College for the creation
of a dance club in currently vacant
warehouse space beneath the Ma
jestic complex. Ideas for this club
include a disco and a bar for stu
dents over 21. Ideas for this project
were said to be "very vague right
now." Senate treasurer _.Sara
Zalewski announced that Senate's
budget currently stands at around $

16,000. According to Zalewski, the
budget was cut about 5% from last
year. Due to the budget cut and the
cost of outstanding bills, all senate
sponsored student organizations
were cut 20% of their previous bud
gets. She said that money was re
moved from Senate's budget to
help fund the _organisations. She
urged organizations to spend their
money wisely, and to co-sponsor
events with other organizations.
She also announced that Sen
ate will begin implementing fines
this year for poor attendance and
failure to meet other responsibili
ties. All senators, officers, and or
ganizations will be subject to these
fines.

College Store committee makes decision

byDanLarkin
News Editor

A committee formed to re
view and redefine the mission of
the Gettysburg College Store has
reached a conclusion concerning
the direction of the bookstore. The
store has begun to implement these
changes this semester.

The College Store Re
view Advisory Committee com
prised of faculty, administrators,
staff, and a student was appointed
in the fall of 1996 by Vice Presi
dent Jennie Mingoielli to set a vi
sion for the College Store and to
identify key initiatives and direc
tions for (he future.

Much speculation and
rumor concerning the College's
plans for the store created contro
versy on campus last semester.
Concerns were raised about the
possible outsourcing of the store
to a large corporation, such as
Barnes and Noble, and the poten
tial budget and personnel problems

that would bring with it.
As part of the review pro
cess, the committee solicited sug
gestions from members of all sec
tors of the community; visited
bookstores on other college cam
puses; interviewed and heard pre
sentations from the Gettysburg
College Store staff; and met with
an architect to review design op
tions. The committee resolu
tion states that "two major themes
emerged from our review of the
current situation: first we recom
mend that the College improve the
selection and offering of trade
books in the College Store and sec
ond, we recommend that the Col
lege Store be oriented more toward
supporting an intellectual atmo
sphere on campus."
With regard to the
Store's location, the resolution
states: "The issue of location of the
store/bookstore is absolutely criti
cal to the success of the store. We
believe the store must be in a high
traffic location."

It continues to state that
"We lack consensus within the
Committee on whether to separate
the college store physically from
a new bookstore, or whether the
bookstore can encompass the Col
lege Store and share a location."
The Committee recom
mended two phases to resolve the
location issue: "Phase 1 — an ex
pansion in or around the present

We need
writers
x6449

phtoto by Mark Astrom

location, with emphasis on short
term, low cost options; Phase 2 -
a new space renovated, built or
acquired to design specifications."
The Committee also rec
ommended to move immediately
into Phase 1, and "hold off on any
major expenditures until we have
two to three years of experience to
evaluate the success of Phase 1."
In conclusion, the Advisory
Committee stated: "The store must
house a stronger selection of trade
books and that the store must play
a more significant role in foster
ing an intellectual climate on cam
pus. The store can become far
more fully engaged in promoting
a lively conversation about books
among students and faculty. The
store can serve as a natural venue
for intellectual book-centered pro
gramming and casual interaction.

We seek a bookstore with a
bookstore ambiance. We aim for
a program which not only sells
books, but which celebrates the en
joyment of books as both a soli
tary and communal activity. By
implementing the recommenda
tions proposed above, we believe
the College Store can better
achieve this very important aspect
of its mission."

Paparazzi to face probe for
role in Princess' death
PARIS
A French Judge tuesday de
clared seven paparazzi to be sus
pects in the death of Princess Diana
early Sunday morning in a car
crash. The Princess' armored
Mercedes-Benz sedan crashed af
ter a high speed chase by celebrity
hunting photographers on motor
cycles through a tunnel.
Newly disclosed informa
tion, however, has pointed at a com
bination of deadly factors leading
to the Princess' death.
A police analysis found
that chauffeur Henr i Paul's blood
alcohol level may have been almost
four times the legal limit at the time
nf the crash.

The photographers had
been in custody since being ar
rested at the crash scene Sunday
morning. Judge Herve Stephan
placed them under formal investi
gation for "involuntary homicide,"
the French equivalent of man
slaughter. They will not necessar
ily be formally charged with any
cr ime. The paparazzi will also be
investigated for failing to aid people
in danger, under French "good sa
maritan" law. If they are charged
and found guilty, the paparzzi face
potential punishment of up to five
years in jail and $100,000 in fines.
Huge crowds engulfed St.
James Palace earlier this week
where Diana' s body lay in state
until Saturday's funeral.
The White House an
nounced that First Lady Hillary
Rodham Clinton will attend the fu
neral on behalf of the United States.

Giant Panda gives birth to
twins Beijing One of China's endangered
pandas has given birth to health
twins after a rare pregnancy in cap
tivity where notoriously sex-shy
pandas are usually even less will
ing to mate.

The twins were born over
the weekend at the Giant Panda
Protection and Research Center in
the Woolong Reserve in the South
western Sichuan province and
weighed 5.25 ounces and 4.55
ounces the official Xinhua news
agency said.
Mother and cubs were in
excellent condition, it said.

pregnant in artificial environments,
with morethan 90 percent of male

pandas in zoos or breeding centers
unable to mate.

A postal worker opened fire yesterday in a crowded post office,
critically wounding his ex-wife and a friend before shooting himself to
death as terrified customers fled, authorities said.
The man left his station at the counter when he saw the two
women enter the post office about 1 p.m., said a police spokesman.
Each victim was shot once, and then the gunman walked away
casually, police and witnesses said.
"Exited the post office, went to a tree, looked up in the air and
shot himself in the face," the spokesman said.
Police identified the gunman as Jesus Antonio Tamayo, 65. A
co-worker said Mr. Tamayo was a counter clerk with 41 years of experi
ence.

Catholic school teachers begin year on picket lines
Lay teachers at the 22 Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese
of Philadelphia went on strike yesterday, two days before some 23,000
students were scheduled to start the new academic year.
Archdiocese officials said high schools in Philadelphia, Mont
gomery, Bucks, Delaware, and Chester counties would open tomorrow
despite the strike with the help of some 200 religious faculty members.
After a unanimous vote yesterday morning, teachers picked up
signs, then headed to the archdiocese's downtown headquarters to form
a picket line for their first strike since 1976.
The old contract expired at midnight Sunday; the archdiocese
refused to negotiate past last thursday but indicated it would resume
talks this week.
Greenleaf bill aims at sex offenders
Sen. Stewart Greenleaf, R- Montgomery, appeared in a news
conference to discuss his legislation to have certain sexually violent of
fenders committed after their prison terms have ended.
The bill is in reaction to a U.S. Supreme Court decision this
year that dealt with a violent sex offender in Kansas. The court essen
tially said the state had the right to commit the convicted man.

tions.

New policies reduce diversity

College Press Service
Laura Rothstein, a Univer
sity of Houston law professor,
says she's gotten a taste of what
a classroom is like with fewer
minority students.
Speaking to a civil rights
advisory group in Austin,
Rothstein recounted how a recent
class discussions on housing dis
crimination was far less heated
than in past years, when more
minority students were in the
class. This year, only two black
students are enrolled in her pov
erty laws class.
"All of the students in my
class were harmed because of
that loss. Affirmative action
doesn't just benefit minorities, it
benefits all students."

plications from Hispanic students
fell 22 percent.
Applications from white stu
dents dropped too, by 14 percent, bul
overall more white and Asian stu
dents received offers of admissions
this year than last. That reverses a
trend toward increased college en
rollment of minority students over
the last decade, recently outlined in
report by the College Board.
In Texas, university officials
say one reason for the decline is a
new essay requirement that deters
less ambitious applicants. But
some blame "the Hopwood effect,"
a reference to the federal court case
that blocked most college sin Texas,
Louisiana and Mississippi from us
ing racial preferences in undergradu
ate admissions and scholarships.
In 1992, Cheryl Hopwood and
three other white students sued UT's
law school, saying they had been
denied admission so that less quali
fied minority students could be ad
mitted. A federal appeals court
agreed that the UT's policies were
discriminatory.
The Texas system adopted
a "race-neutral" policy and now
gives more consideration to an
applicant's experience overcoming
adversity or other special circum
stances. Still, fewer minorities have
been accepted.
Experts predict that many
minority students will accept offers
form private universities that still
offer race-based scholarships.

Even as national surveys
show solid gains in college en
rollment for minority students,
several campuses say the end re
sult of bitter affirmative action
battles is a sharp decrease in mi
nority applicants.
Following decisions to dis
mantle their race-preferential
programs, public universities in
Texas and California report that
applications form black and His
panic students for next year's
freshman class have plummeted.
The University of Texas at
Austin announced that applica
tions from black students fell 24
percent from last year, and ap-

This 19-ycar old singer has

is no right and wrong, only true and

Jane pleases without
being obnoxious

byJonFr oehlich
Staff Writer
"G.I. Jane", starring Demi
Moore ("A Few Good Men,"
"Ghost") as Lt. O'Neil, and di
rected by Ridley Scott, is a movie
that attempts to comment on how
men and women arc constantly
being treated differently, both in
the US military and in society at
large. This movie not only tries to
tackle the above gender issues, but
also offers a fairly entertaining
story. After a shady political deal
between a female Senator and the
newly elected Secretary of the
Navy goes down, Lt. O'Neil be
comes a test subject in an experi
ment regarding the complete and
total integration of women into the
US Navy. But this proposal, along
with Lt. O'Neil's opportunity, are
simply for political show.
As part of this experiment,
O'Neil becomes the first woman

ever to be admitted to what is most
often considered the toughest mili
tary division in the world - the
Navy SEALS.
From this point on, "G.I.
Jane" takes on two distinct mis
sions. One is to tell the story of
Lt. O'Neil and attempt to give au
diences an accurate picture of
the Navy SEALS. The other, done
on a more subconscious level, is
to shed some light on attitudes to
wards gender in politics and the
military. "G.I. Jane's" message
about equality is an unavoidable
one simply because of the plot.
The more entertaining of
"G.I. Jane's" two missions, and
most likely the one that will draw

people to the theater, is the first
one. Because O'Neil is the only
woman in her class, she is natu
rally treated as the "new kid" and
scorned by many of her male crew
members. In the SEALS, O'Neil
finds only unequal treatment. Not
only is O'Neil frustrated by her
crew trying to make things more
difficult, she is also upset at how
the Navy tries to make things
easier on her relative to the men.
With these two forces work
ing against her, O'Neil seems
blocked at every turn by a defense
mechanism on the part of the Navy
to avoid embarrassment should
their plan back-fire. It doesn't take
long for her to realize that no one

expects, or wants, her to succeed.
But instead of giving up as every
one expects, O'Neil's determina
tion is immeasurably increased.
This turning point can be symbol
ized by what is perhaps the most
well known scene in which O'Neil
ceremonially shaves her head like
the rest of her crew.
From then on, "G.I. Jane"
progresses into what audiences
might predict - a proud story of a
woman finding the inner strength
and determination to overcome
both political and social obstacles
to infiltrate what was traditionally
a man's world. Where she once
found only closed minds and harsh
attitudes, she eventually uncovers
the kind of camaraderie that we all

crave. Though it may be difficult
for audiences to shake the cliche
"This is not a drill!," perhaps the
actual combat that the director
throws in at the end of this movie
is necessary to prove something.
In this movie, which involves a
woman who is constantly having
to prove herself, some actual per
formance in combat may be re
quired to put many of the issues
approached to rest.
"G.I. Jane" fits right in with
many of director Scott's other
films. Having directed films such
as "Alien" (starring Sigourney
Weaver) and "Thelma and Louise"
(starring Geena Davis and Susan
Sarandon), Scott seems partial to
using strong, and sometimes quite

masculine, heroines in leading
roles. Though "G.I. Jane" may not
have the heart stopping action of
"Alien" or the emotional suspense
of "Thelma and Louise," it does
avoid negative feminist stereo
types, and harbors a story line that,
while fairly predictable, will most
likely be satisfying to audiences.
With especially good perfor
mances by Morris Chestnut
("Boyz N the Hood," "The Last
Boy Scout") as a fellow crew
member and Viggo Mortenson
("Crimson Tide," "Witness") as the
ominous Master Chief in charge of
the recruits, "G.I. Jane" is a decent
movie that, while it may not make
you want to join the SEALS, will
make you respect all those who
have stood up against injustice to
defend their beliefs.

The Curtain Call
Exciting year planned for theater

The O&N, as many in the
theater like to call it, is formally
known as the Owl and Nightingale
Players. This is a student group
that, in conjunction with the the
ater department, is committed to
enhancing live art on campus.
The O&N performs fall,
winter, and spring productions
each year. The shows frequently
represent various styles and peri
ods. Shows have included dramas
such as Tennessee Williams' Cat
on a Hot Tin Roof (4/97), post
restoration comedies like Richard
Brinsley Sheridan's The Rivals (2/
97), classical Shakespeare such as
Macbeth (2/96), modern comedies
like Lee Blessing's Fortinbras (4/
96), musicals of the same ilk as
Kander and Ebb's Chicago (2/93)
and many others.

byGlenBeck
Staff Writer

department

In addition, the O&N pro
vides opportunities for students to
be involved in student-directed
"lunchtimes" (fifteen minutes
scenes usually performed over the
lunch hour) and one-act plays.
The lunchtimes are directed
by the students in the Advanced
Directing class: Phil Anderson,
Glen Beck, Alec Beekmans,
Samantha Gregg, Brian Hershfeld,
Tim Johnsen, Jeremy Katz,
Duncan Niederer, Dan Novall,
Erica Strang, and Alexa Warren.
The lunchtimes beginning

on September 15 include such
scenes as, "The Jest of Hahalaba,"
"Street Scene," "Here We Are,"
"No Problem," "Graceland," "Me
Ow," "The Hat," and "Business
man." A student executive board
encourages and fosters involve
ment to promote the theater on
campus. This year's board is al
ready in the process of enacting
several changes that will give stu
dents who are interested in theater
more opportunities to become in
volved. Such changes include the
revival of the Theater Honor Soci
ety.

The student board lor this
year is Glen Beck (president), Tim
Johnsen, Alec Beekmans,

Students find ways to add spice and life to their rooms

Looking for ideas to liven up your room? Bored with your

byMelodieFoster
StaffWriter Do you ever walk down the
hall of your dorm, look at the other
rooms, and think "Gosh, why can't
my room look like that?" Well, fret
no more. You too can have a room
that will attract visitors, entertain
friends, and be comfortable to sit
around and do nothing in...oops..I
mean to study in.
What makes a room great?
Well, there are many factors: fur
niture, posters, rugs, and accesso
ries such as a TV, stereo, plants,
pictures, curtains, and art work.
How these things are used depends
entirely on the person, but a few
generalizations can be made. For
example, when you walk into a
room, you can immediately tell if
the occupants are male, female,
first-year, or upperclassmen.
There are huge differences
between girls' rooms and guys'

rooms. Girls rooms are cute,
comfy, homey. They are more
likely to put up curtains, match,
and hang aesthetically pleasing
posters; says one junior, "I'm not
afraid to hang up pictures of cute
animals."
Girls' beds have lots of pil
lows-the body pillow is popular
and stuffed animals. Their post
ers differ greatly from many in
guys' rooms. Posters that girls have
hanging often include sunsets,
little kids, animals, people kissing,
collages of photographs of friends.
In a guy's room, especially
if he has an apartment, one finds a
common theme: beer. Posters of
beer bottles, of beer cans, and
scantily clad women holding beer
are all over the walls. Lighted beer
signs, pyramids of cans, and win
dow displays of empty alcohol
bottles also add to the overall ef
fect.

Perhaps the most important
two items to have in a room are a
rug and a couch. Not only does a
rug protect bare feet from the cold
tile in the middle of winter, but a
rug can make a room look bigger
and more inviting.
A couch is a very good thing
if you have the space. Sophomore
Andrew Lee purchased a five-sec
tion white couch this summer from
a furniture barn for $ 139 because
"it was necessary for the sanctity
of the room." The mammoth
couch covers an entire corner, and
this makes Lee happy: "Now I
have my refrigerator, my TV, and
my couch all in one place; I'm
never going to move again."
A TV, though a big distrac
tion and excuse to procrastinate
("But Paity of Five is on—I'll start
my paper at ten, really"), brings a
little of the outside world into a
room. It can also be the focal point

stuff? Sick of your posters ? Look her el

of your room.
Junior Jay Henniger ar
ranged his room in Patrick last year
around his entertainment
centerwhich consisted of a big TV,
stereo, and big speakers. His room
was the home of hall football par
ties and viewings of movies such
as Independence Day that need a
big screen and big speakers with
lots of bass to do them justice.
The best things to have in a
room are interesting conversation
pieces that will draw people in
from the hallway, such a a big
couch, a crazy poster, a life size
cardboard cutout of Elvis (just ask
Marybeth Misluk), an odd chair,
or strange pieces of art.
Lisa Wingenroth, a sopho
more, brought with her this year a
plaster of Paris sculpture of a
dancer from a play put on in her
hometown. She commented laugh
ingly "it's a dancer; I couldn't let

them throw it out." The residents
of her floor hope to make the statue
a hall mascot, and plan to deco
rate him for holidays.
Where can you get all this
cool stuff? The Poster and Plant
sale sponsored by the College is a
good place to start. This year's sale
will be held next week. Yard sales,
attics, basements, and Wal-Mart
are all good places to find inexpen
sive, and often original decorations
and pieces of furniture. So get
motivated, get imaginative, and get
out there and start looking. There's
lots of great stuff to be found.

Dear Casey...

Dear Casey,
I need advice. I'm con
cerned about my friend. She
won't tell a guy who she's friends
with that she doesn't want to date
him. Meanwhile, she's interested
in a couple of other guys and is
thinking about asking one of
them out without telling Guy #1
that she "just wants to be
friends." I really don't care who
she dates, but I just don't want
her to get hurt. Please help.
A Confused Reader.
Dear Confused Reader,
This problem does not re
volve around whom your friend
likes, but whom she might not like:
herself. Everyone likes attention
and attraction, and of course it is
always an ego pat when someone
thinks you are special. It seems as
if your friend is enjoying this atten
tion too much to give it up. Hon
estly, though, who would want to
give it up?

men to dote on her.
Don't be fierce, but be hon
est and firm. Humans are not toys,
but they can be broken easily.
Dear Casey,
There's this guy I was re
ally good friends with last year
When I got here this semester, I
realized I liked him as moe than
a friend. I am really shy and
could never just tell him how I
feel. What do you think?
A Shy Heart
Dear Shy Heart,
One of the best things about
solid and healthy relationships is
that they re always changing and
taking different directions. And of
ten, good friendships with the op
posite sex have the possibility of be
coming strong "more than friends"
relationships. This will often take
time. It happened to me once, but
it took 12 years, and just happened
naturally.

I admire your concern about
her getting hurt in this situation,
but I personally would be more
concerned about the guy she is
leading on. People and emotions
should not be manipulated as ex
periments or as ego pats, and I
think you and your friend should
have a heart to heart about a few
issues—mainly respect. Respect for
this young man who has serious
feelings for her, and respect for
human emotions in general. But,
more than both of these, she should
have some respect for herself, and
not need to have an entourage of

I understand that you may
have qualms about losing him as a
friend by being direct, so take your
time, enjoy your friendship and let
things evolve naturally. All things
happen in due course. Who knows,
maybe you will find yourselves dis
cussing relationships over a cup of
coffee, and both of you will realize
that you would make a great pair.
But if that never comes to pass, en
joy having a friend of the opposite
sex. They are great for advice. Good
luck. If you have a question for
Casey, please write to Box 434.

Pachyderm's Pulpit

The summer is now over,
students are heading back to
school, family vacations are com
plete, the time to work has re
turned. According to most eco
nomic indicators as well as the
feeling in country there is plenty
of work out there. Unemployment
is down, the stock market, while
recently taking a slight plunge is
soaring, inflation and interest rates
are virtually non-existent. Not
only is the economy doing well,
but the budget is being balanced,
people are fleeing from the wel
fare rolls, and crime is falling, par
ticularly in our major cities. At the
most recent G-8 Summit of indus¬

trialized nations held in Denver,
Colorado President Clinton stood
atop his pedestal to explain how
his American model is so success
ful. The world must hope that the
President's fellow summiters do
not take his advice. Iftheydothen
they will have higher taxes, a bud
get in deficit, and a national pro
gram of socialized medicine. A
key reason that the United States
is doing so well is that Bill
Clinton's agenda was rejected.
Rejected by the Congress over
health-care and rejected by the
American people in 1994 when the
elected the first Republican Con
gress in 50 years.

Following that historic
rejection the President wisely
rolled over to the popular Repub
lican agenda of lower taxes, a bal-

by John Dunlap
anced budget, and welfare reform.
Rather than being the national
leader he rolled over and became
a "Me-too" President. The Repub
lican agenda worked during the
Reagan era, largest peacetime eco
nomic growth in our history, lower
crime, and yes we happened to win
the Cold War when some liberals
wanted us to retreat from the Com
munist threat. The Republican
Congress passed welfare reform
and after vetoing it twice, the
President finally signed it with the
1996 election approaching, when
the Republican Congress and the
Republican Presidential ticket of
Bob Dole and Jack Kemp called
for tax cuts, there was Bill Clinton
saying me-too. This summer af
ter fighting them for months de
spite taking credit for what the
Congress was doing, President
Clinton signed the first balanced
budget in a generation.

The most interesting as
pect of the balanced budget bill
was the Medicare provision. The
same medicare plan that Bob Dole
supported and Bill Clinton trashed.
Along with organized labor and
foreign campaigning cash, Bill
Clinton, said over and over that
Dole-Gingrich are cutting Medi
care. Well, Mr. President, Bob
Dole and Newt Gingrich were
right and you admitted that by
agreeing to their demands. It is a
shame that day and day out the
media is not pointing out the

President's hypocrisy, that only
shows their left-wing bias.
If President Clinton re
ally wants to know what makes our
nation so successful then he had
better sit down with Governor John
Engler ofMichigan who cut taxes
and balanced the budget, which
brought his state back from eco
nomic ruin. Or Governor Tommy
Thompson of Wisconsin who re
formed welfare in his state and
found that people do not starve, the
find work. He should also sit down
with Mayor Guilianni of New York
who showed leadership, took on
criminals and won. They are all
Republicans and they are carrying
out the Reagan agenda.
Now even devout liberals
are caving, while the rest of the
nation is growing, Maryland for
instance, with its liberal leadership
is staying behind.

President Clinton has be
come the Mikhail Gorbachev of
America. Like Gorbachev, the
President is watching his ideology,
liberalism, die. Die at the polls, in
the states, and in Congress. No one
can run on a liberal platform in
mainstream America. Mr. Clinton
had to move to the center and he
still only received 49% of the vote.
Just as Gorbachev made conces
sions to save Communism, our
making concessions to save big
government, but election by elec
tion the President is failing. That
is the American miracle.

Consider this . . .

A lot of attention has been
paid to this little paper over the past
two semesters. And with good rea-*
son. On the eve of our 100th an
niversary, we became the first
newspaper to print the tragic story
of our classmate Brian Peterson.
Our historic anniversary was
marked by parties and receptions.
We traveled up and down the East
Coast attending conferences where
we were recognized nationally.
We are currently contenders in the
"pulitzer prize of student journal
ism" --the Pacemaker Award.
Most importantly, the con
tent and coverage of the
Gettysburgian changed. Our staff
increased in size and we were able
to cover more campus events and
do so in a more complete fashion.
The design and layout be
came more reader-friendly and
modern.

But all these changes came
with growing pains.

We quickly outgrew the
computer system we had been us
ing for many years and after many
tribulations, we were able to pur
chase over $15,000 of the latest
newspaper computer technology.
New machines should make
everything new and improved,
right? Not so at the Gettysburgian.
Through a series of circumstance
beyond our control, including but
certainly not limited to the UPS/
Teamsters strike, we have been

unable to get everything up and
running as we had originally
hoped.
This sometimes disastrous
situation has led to obvious flaws
in recent issues that are far below
our normal standards.
We at the Gettysburgian sin
cerely apologize for the lax report
ing and poor design of our beloved
newspaper.
Please bear with us as we
work out the many problems that
have been plaguing our transition.
We will continue to bring
you the latest news, the most in
triguing commentary, the best Bul
lets sports coverage, and the best
coverage of campus entertainment
and features.
We will supplement our
usual coverage with a technology
section, themed features, and by
making our publication available
on our web site.

We have changed our adver
tising policy to increase revenue

ana _oe using -or--an
photography, layout, and informa
tion gathering techniques to bring
you increasing coverage of the
campus community.
In the coming weeks you
will no doubt notice substantial
improvements in the newspaper,
including a few surprises.
We look forward to a pro
ductive year filled with many more
adventures.
Thank you for your continu
ing support and patience.

Conflict and Consensus

Dear Editor:
on August 26, police found a dozen students passed out in a fraternity on the LSU campus. One, 20
year old Benjamin Wyyne, was already dead as the result of acute alcohol poisoning, three other students
were hospitalized.
Unfortunately, the behavior which led to Benjamin Wynne's death is far too common on our own
campus. Our March 1997 CORE Survey revealed that 67% of our students "binge drank" in the two weeks
before the survey. There is no reason, other than luck, which accounts for our not having experienced an on
campus alcohol related death in recent years, colleges around us (F&M, Dickinson, York) have not been as
fortunate.
Most of us know what alcohol does at high levels in our bloodstream. But it's not just the alcohol that
killed Benjamin Wynne. To protect ourselves, we often assume that bad things happen only to "bad" people.
But the fact is that tragedy can occur to any of us, "good" or "bad". Other factors in Benjamin's death were
the campus drinking culture, the way group dynamics influence individual choices and behavior, and inaccu
rate assumptions we make about "normal" college drinking.
I often hear students say that Gettysburg is a "safe" place to drink because drinking doesn't usually
involve driving. Bloomsburg University has lost seven students to alcohol-related deaths in the past five
years... none of these deaths involved cars. Gettysburg is not safer than Bloomsburg, F&M, Dickinson or
LSU. Let's all keep in mind that bad things do happen to good people and that we want to rely on more than
just luck to get us all through the year safely.

Sincerely,
Hariet Marritz

Telephone Statements:
Students will not be receiving a
separate phone statement for the
month of August. We will be
combining the August and Septem
ber phone charges into one state
ment. You will receive this state
ment the first week in October.
There will NOT be a $7.50 dial
tone charge for the month of
August. September will be the first
month you will be charged for dial
tone. You will only receive the dial
tone charge for the following
months: September, October,
November, December, January,
February, March and April. Any
one who resides in campus housing
or fraternities, provided with a

college phone line, receives the
$7.50 dial tone charge. The dial
tone charge is not connected to the
use of your College long distance
authorization code. Payment is
due within thirty days of statement
date. Failure to pay outstanding
charges will result in your College
long distance authorization code
being deactivated until payment in
full is received by the Financial
Services Office. Financial Services
will contact the Telecommunica
tions Department after
the payment in full has been
received and your College long
distance authorization code will be
reactivated. Florence Heuer,

in 32 games. She pounded out 34

cluding five doubles, a team high
five triples, and a team-high two
home runs. She also led the Bul
lets with 24 runs batted in.

was also a team high. Defensively,
the left fielder had only two errors
in 51 chances for a .961 fielding
percent.

bunts. Gravclme joined Bullock

ond team.
