Women s Lax
makes EC AC bid

from Gettysburg Sports Release
A junior-dominated scoring
punch, aggressive defenders and
a stingy goalie added up to a suc
cessful 1997 campaign for the
Gettysburg College women's la
crosse team.
Head Coach Carol Daly's
squad concluded the season with
a 12-5 record. The Bullets fin
ished second behind Johns
Hopkins in the Centennial Con
ference and advanced to the East
ern Colleges Athletic Conference
(ECAC) Mid-Atlantic Champion
ships. A trio of juniors—Kim
Fritz, Leslie Marotz, and Chrissy
Nordhoff—accounted for more
than half of the Bullets' 193 goals
in 1997.

Fritz was the team leader in
both goals (47) and assists (13).
Marotz was a close runner-up in
the scoring department with 41
goals and nine assists. Nordhoff
furnished the Bullets with 32
goals and 11 assists.
With one season of eligibil
ity remaining, Marotz ranks
fourth in school history in career
goals with 125. Fritz and Marotz
are two of only six players in
school history to surpass 100
goals during their careers.
Another junior, Kris
Sullivan, was the Bullets' fourth
leading scorer in 1997. She had
21 goals and five assists to go
along with her team-leading 85
ground balls.
The only three seniors on

the Bullets' 1997 roster were key
contributors to the program's suc
cess. Goalie Carolyn Holmes
made 211 saves and allowed only
134 goals while playing every
minute of every game. She departs
Gettysburg as the career leader in
saves with 728.
Fritz and Marotz made the
all-region squad's first team at at
tack, while Sullivan was placed on
the first team's defensive unit.
Holmes was Gettysburg's fourth
all-region player.
Kate Mason was a solid per
former at both ends of the field and
was in the Bullets' starting lineup
37 times during her career.
Holmes and Mason were in
vited to play in the third annual
North/South All-Star women's la
crosse game on June 7 in Balti
more. Thirty-six of the sport's top
seniors, representing 30 different
Division III schools, were selected
to participate in the contest.

Four players were placed on
the 1997 Brine/Intercollegiate
Women's Lacrosse Coaches Asso
ciation Division III All-Central
Region team.
Fritz and Marotz made the
all-region squad's first team attack,
while Sullivan was placed on the
first team's defensive unit. Holmes
was the fourth all-region player.
Randi Ball had the best year
of her career as a senior, scoring
10 times and dishing out nine as
sists. Three freshmen—Kelli
Brennan, Sharon Coghan, and
BethFallon—started all 17 games

Men's Tennis Update

from Gettysburg Sports Release
Junior Brandon Cutter and
senior Justin Milne were the lead
ing players on the Gettysburg Col
lege men's tennis team.
Gettysburg posted a 10-4
overall record and was 5-3 in the
Centennial Conference, good for
fourth place.
Cutter, playing out of the
number one singles spot all year,
was 10-4 and was named to the
All-Centennial Conference first
team. He and Milne formed
Gettysburg's number one doubles
team, completing the year with a
10-4 record.

Milne was Gettysburg's
leading singles player with an 11 -
3 mark, going 9-2 at third singles
and 2-1 at second singles
Senior Justin Horn, playing
out of the number three singles
spot, posted a 10-4 record. He
matched that mark as a number
two doubles player, but he had
three different partners. His most
successful partner was sophomore
Chris Rippey. The tandem was
undefeated in six matches.
Rippey was 5-6 at number two
singles.
Gettysburg completed its
ninth season under Head Coach
Dave Wright. The Bullets are 84
30 under Wright's leadership.




Beyond the
Bullets

Football is Life...
bySteveJenkins
Sports Editor
As the aromas of pork rinds,
charcoal grilled sides of beef, and
hot wings fill the air, America
knows that is is once again time
for another season of NFL and
College football. This Sund
marks the beginning of twenty
solid weeks of cheers, jeers and
testosterone levels that go through
the roof_.
Hey, what other sport can
you purchase tickets to see fat,
middle-aged, tattoo emblazoned,
and blatantly drunk fans root thier
team on to victory? (Okay, besides
WWF Monday night raw). Yes,
now that football is here all Ameri
cans will rejoice with remotes and
popcorn in hand as "The Pack,"
"The Birds," and "Americas
Team," all make their runs at a
Super Bowl Title. Is,
id :a
le id ly
ty id _;h
in it,
d,
er es s,
•i-
id 's
a

As a consummate fan of
football, I myself have constructed
a beginners approach to watching
and understanding the game.
Football is a game of execu
tion, speed, mental toughness, and
heart. Okay, I know what you are
thinking: "How smart do you have
to be? It is just a bunch of guys
smashing heads together. When
one team smashes more heads than
the other they win the game. How
hard can it be?"
Ah, there is much more be
hind the game than smashing and
punching. You sec each time the
big guys line up to block for the
smaller, faster guys, the coaches on
one team are trying to trick the
coaches on the other team. What
they do is called a "play."
Evcrytime the offense runs a play,
all the guys with one color shirt
have a specific assignment to block
the guys in the other colored shirts.
One player messes up, and the play
goes right down the tubes.

You see, the players who
have the ball arc trying to get past
the players without the ball in or
der to accumulate points. When
you see guys dancing, jumping
into the stands, and back-flipping
in Iront of the cameras, this usu-

Nothing else Matters
ally means the team with the ball
has gotten to the endline and has
augmented their scoie.
Aftei about thirty minutes,
the well conditioned athletes need
a break, so they head back to the
locker room for a rest. During this
intermission, the coaches are
calmly explaining to their players
why the opposing team is pound
ing them into oblivion, or
conversly, how to keep pounding
the opposing team.
If you arc watching at home,
you usually do not see this part of
the game. What you usually see
at halftime is four or five balding,
ex-NFL players trying to re-live
their usually ill-fated careers by
showing and analyzing highlights
from games shown all around the
country. All in all, watching these
guys is pretty fun, but the second
half is the part of the game that any
fan lives for.

Bullet Soccer players scurry for a ball as it
goes out of bounds. The Bullets lost the game
to Mary Washington 1-0. photo by Mark
Astrom

When the second half be
gins, both teams have made the
appropriate changes and are ready
for another half of the elegant bal
let of dives, counters, receptions,
sacks, and pass-rushing. The fi
nal quarters tick away as every fan
sits on the edge of his or her seat,
waiting patiently for their team to
make its move.
If you are unfamiliar with
the game, do not be startled by the
empty beer bottles flying by your
head, or nachos protruding from
the mouth of the angry fan next to
you. Just know that this is the pin
nacle of dedication to a team. All

fans strive to reach this plateau, but
many often lall short in their quest.
When you sit down to take
in a game this Saturday or Sunday,
enjoy all that is going on around
you. Whether you are sitting in
you living room, or you actually
go to a game, it is important to un
derstand that football is not easy.
The game is played by hard-work
ing, focused athletes who deserve
some loyal fan support. So as you
stuff your face with pork rinds and
smear barbeque sauce all over your
face, just know that it is all for the
good of the game we know as loot
ball.


Women's Soccer looks to shoot down
Centennial Conference competition

bySteveJenkins
Sports Editor

Lady Bullet sophomores and
freshmen into a tight and cohesive
unit. The sophomore contingent
of Lady Bullets include Lauren
Scott, Maureen McBnen, Lauren
Frankford, Emily Brown, Laura
Zinck, Lauren Morrell, Traci
Bcigen, Stacey Elwood, Patsy
Cors, and Annie Pryor to name just
a few. The real test will be for this
particular group of girls. If these
ladies can work together and help
each other with the experiences
that each of them gained last year,
there is no telling what this squad
can accomplish.
During last year 's women's
soccer campaign, lack of confi
dence, experience, and injuries
riddled a season lilled with many
challenges. This season, with the
experienced team and 7 returning
starters, the team seems poised for

Leadership, heart, and ma
turity are the three qualities that
the Gettysburg women's soccer
team aie relying on this season.
With the loss of only four start
ers and many freshman seeing
time last season, the Lady Bul
lets are experienced and ready to
lead the charge to the Centennial
Conference Title.
Captain Beth O'Boylc
leads a group of women who had
somewhat of a lackluster season
last year, but are ready to pound
out the competition this season.
O'Boyle, along with fellow Se
niors Paula Connard, Robin
Kn/.a_, Knssy Doyle and Juniors
Sabnna Luciano and Shannon
Blair, are going to help mold the

greatness.
After a large turnout for pre
season camp, the roster has been
refined in order to establish a pow
erful lineup for this weekend's up
coming tournament. With games
scheduled for two regionally
ranked opponents, it is necessary
for the Bullets to "bring the noise"
in this weekend's games to find ou
what their squad can really accom
plish. "We have a great chance to
do well," said veteran Lauren
Frankford, "With the players that
we have back, and a talented fresh
man class, the whole team is very
optimistic."
This weekend's tournament
has the Lady Bullets playing host
to regionally ranked Cortland and
Mary Washington. Along with
Moravian, the Bullets will round
out the four team tourney.




SportsWeekly
Bullets ready to rock the house in 1997

byJoshEyler
Assisstant Sports Editor
As the leaves begin their
change, and Autumn shows signs
that he will soon be "bringin' in da
noise," the competitive football
season is just about to get under
way. Fresh off their annual Orange
and Blue game, the Bullet's grid
iron squad are looking forward to
a scrimmage this Friday night
when they travel to Reading, PA,
to take on Albright College, ranked
second in the nation in Division III.
The Orange and Blue game
was played this past Saturday and
was very successful, even includ¬

ing the fact that several key play
ers were sidelined due to injuries.
Sophomore defensive back Chris
"Sweet Lou" Lunardi said about
the game: "The defense was very
successful, but both sides of the
ball still need to improve. The of
fense showed that it has big play
potential, and hopefully can be
come more consistent. Overall, it
was a lot of fun to finally play in a
game situation and the whole team
is looking forward to scrimmaging
the number two team in the na
tion." This enthusiasm, undoubt
edly shared by all of Lunardi's
teammates, seems to be a trade
mark of the 1997 Bullets.

Predictions for this year's
finish in the Centennial Confer
ence range from sixth in national
publications to third in some local
newspapers.
A veteran packed defense
led by Kevin Gurski, Rob Sena,
Tom Olchon, and Chad Mire in the
backfield_, linebackers Joe
Hodakowski, Jason Osborn, Chris
Felton, and Brian Murphy, and a
stellar line anchored by Justin

"Killer" Domingos and Pete "Wild
Man" Scaffidi, both tackles, and
Scott Grabus and Gene Kraus
playing defensive end should
pound the opposing offenses into
submission this season.
Two questions still remain
ing in Bullet camp concern the of
fense. The first question revolves
around who will lead the offense
at quarterback. Will it be veteran
Chris Fugaro or sophomore
Weston Wells? The second ques
tion concerns who will fill the
empty spot at left guard. Vying

lor this position are Mike Lorge,
Steve Jenkins, and Kevin Cache.
Whoever wins this spot will
be surrounded by an experienced
offensive line that includes Bill
"The Animal" Beining, Bryan
Willard_, Kurt Ritter, and Justin
Ogorek. Junior Mike Holm and
freshman Nate Dahloff will com
plete the line as tight ends. In the
backfield, Paul "Schwarzenegger"
Smith, Matt Helwig, Don
McNellis, and Dan Sheats will all
see significant playing time. Se
nior Wayne Rumsey will return to
handle the kicking duties.

Sophomore Sensation Paul Smith (37) rumbles for yet another touchdown. Paul leads a tough
contingent of starters returning for the Bullets.

Already, in this early part of
the season, one can see that the
Bullets are hitting harder and are
lit with intensity. In the words of
senior linebacker and Bullet cap
tain Joe Hodakowski: "We have a
lot of experience back on both
sides of the ball. Little improve
ments in certain areas will turn
mistakes of last season into wins.
When you look at our schedule,
there is no team that we can't beat.
We had a great off season and ev
eryone is very optimistic." You get
the feeling that the guy is probably
right.

Cordova era comes to a close, but
Bullets stock up with young talent

from Gettysburg Sports Release

another school mark.
Gettysburg's team numbers
attest to the potency of the hitting
attack. The team produced 69
doubles, 29 triples, and 23 home
runs as well as a team slugging
percent of .494, all new school
records.
Freshman first baseman
John Woods had a great impact.
Not only did he bat .404, but he
tied the school record for triples in
a game (2), home runs in a season
(6), and put outs in a season (245).
Another yearling, outfielder
Chris Lunardi joined Woods in hit
ting two triples in a single game.
Senior third baseman Mike Man/.o
tied the school record with his two
home runs in a single game against
Johns Hopkins.

It was a record breaking sea
son for the Gettysburg College
baseball team and, right in the
middle of the action was senior
outfielder Joe Cordova.
Gettysburg completed the
season with a 15-21 record and 10
8 Centennial Conference mark.
However, no less than nine school
records were either tied or broken.
Cordova batted a hefty .433 as he
belted 55 hits in 127 plate appear
ances. The 55 safeties breaks the
old mark of 53 for a single season.
Cordova led the team with 37 runs
scored, 32 runs batted in, 13
doubles, and 13 stolen bases. He
completes his collegiate career
with a .406 batting average, setting

Besides Woods' put outs,
there was one other defensive
record broken. Sophomore second
baseman Mike Wallo accounted
for 81 assists, breaking the old
mark of 69.
Five Gettysburg players
were named to the All-Centennial
Conference team. Cordova was
joined on the first team by senior
designated hitter Joe Trani.
Named to the second team were
Woods and Manzo and receiving
honorable mention was senior
pitcher Chris Volpe. Trani batted
.340 and drove in 20 runs. Volpe
was Gettysburg's leading pitcher
with a 4-3 record, completing four
of the eight games he started. He
had 53 strike-outs and gave up 34
walks.

What to do, what to do ?

Senate proposes dance club,
pushes alternative social activities

photo by Mark Aslrom
The Pat McGee Band played to a crowded ballroom last Saturday following the
Shrimpfest

Is the current status of Gettysburg's
social scene providing a safe and fun envi
ronment for students? The recent breaking
up of two large, unregistered parties in Apple
and Ice House seem to indicate that some
thing is lacking in the social oppurtunities
on campus.
In an attempt to deal with this is
sue, last week at the Student Senate's first
meeting of the year, emphasis was placed
on "alternative social programming" as the
organization's main goal for the year. As
past of this objective, a vague description
of a dance club under the Majestic Com
plex was proposed.
Senator Valerie Katzmar was
picked to chair the committee to propose the
project. According to Katzmar, the proposal
is in the "preliminary stages, but is a definite
goal of the Senate." She also emphasized
that other organization were interested in
supporting the project, including SAC, the
Black Student Union, and WZBT. The or
ganization are seeking student input and
opinions concerning the project.

byMkhdleFidds contributing writer

Katzmar believes that the space
under the Majestic Complex will be ideal
for this type of occupancy. The main goal
of the proposal is to establish a place with a
club-like atmosphere with a bar. Only stu
dents ages twenty-one and above would be
allowed to drink, but all Gettyburg College
students will he admitted.

parties, giving students an environment to
safely and legally enjoy themselves.
Katzmar noted that "other schools of this
caliber have something like it, and this
would make us more competitive."
In a related effort to provide alter
native social activities, Senate sponsored a
BYOB "shrimpfest" and a concert by the
Pat McGee Band last Saturday evening.
Senators Emily Robertson ('00)
and Matt Eisenberg ('98) coordinated the
event. Eisenberg, who gives most of the
credit for the success of the shrimpfest to
Robertson, called the event "a step in the
right direction."
Eisenberg also stated that "SAC
did great stuff with Welcome Week," and

commented that he felt the campus as a
whole is moving towards finding alterna
tives to "just frat parties."
Eisenberg also said that ideas are
in the planning stages for more all-campus
social events, "it's in the works to set some
thing up with SAC and Senate, and some of
the individual fraternities." He noted that any
plans are vague at this time, but he stated an
interest in "Getting _theGreek system more
involved with the campus." The Senior sena
tor said that "we need to make the Greek
community part of the campus community."
He also credited the Commission
on the Future for their input, and said that
he felt that the campus has responded fa
vorably. "There's a lot more involvement
a very diverse involvement" he said.
Parts of this story were contributed _ftvm
Staff Reports

is to provide an alternative to other campus

GCPR An exhibition by H.I. Gates,
a sculptor and George Washington
University professor, will open the
1997-98 schedule at the
Schmucker Hall Gallery.
"Knights of the Rising Sun;
Japanese Armor as an Art Form"
will begin with a reception for the
artist at 7 p.m., Thursday, Septem
ber 18, in the Gallery, and will con
tinue through Sunday, October 12.
The exhibit and reception are open
to the public free of charge.
Gates has been using found
and fabricated objects to create as
semblage sculptures for 25 years.
Working with painted fiberglass
resin to form swirling fabrics and
realistic faces, with woven cloths
to authenticate armor, and metal
rods or wood to represent bodily
limbs, he captures the spirit of the
samurai warrior in his sculptures.
The Washington Post critic
Hank Burchard, writing about
Gates' 1996 exhibition at the Ja-

tures of the samurai that "one
Japanese visitor to the opening re
fused to believe they had been
done by a non-Japanese, even af
ter he was introduced to Gates."
Schmucker Hall Gallery is
open from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Mon
day through Friday, and from 10
a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday and Sun
day. For more information on this
exhibit or the Schmucker Hall
Gallery schedule, please contact
the Department of Visual Arts at
337-6121.

mandated that their houses be

Although some brothers

is still "a good size," said Gareis.

Dr. Kerry Walters, Professor
of Philosophy, will be the speaker
at the first Common Hour lecture
of the 1997-1998 academic year.
Professor Walters will con
tinue the Common Hour tradition
of the "Last Lecture." The "Last
Lecture" offers the speaker the
chance to speak to colleagues and
students as if it were his or her fi
nal opportunity to do so.
The Common Hour Commit
tee calls the Last Lecture "an op
portunity to showcase the personal
development of a scholar. The per
son who delivers the lecture and the
choices her or she has made are the
focal points of the program."

from Staff reports

The Last Lecture attempts
to offer insight into the lives and
philosophies of Gettysburg's fac
ulty members. The Common
Hour will be held today at 11:30
a.m. in the College Union Ball
room. A complimentary lunch
will be served following the lec
ture. Walters is the Edwin T.
Johnson and Cynthia Shearer
Johnson Distinguished Teaching
Professor in the Humanities. He
earned his Bachelor of Arts degree
from the University of North
Carolina at Charlotte, his M.A.
from Marquette University, and
his Ph.D. from the University of
Cincinatti.

I heard it through the grapevine: Rumors, rumors, rumors

bySteveSpicer Contributing Writer
"Hey Kate, did you hear
about Sarah's sore chin?" That's
usually how it starts, nice and in
nocent (not that there aren't excep
tions). But by the time a rumor
hits the mainstream of campus
gossip, it's almost always ugly.
Let's face it: we live on a
small campus. There are only
2100 people here, so it doesn't
take long for news to spread. As
an example, think of that old long
distance commercial; you tell two
friends something, and they tell
two friends, and they tell two
friends, etc. It turns out, using that
logic, that a rumor would only
have to go through 11 generations
of being told before everyone on
campus knows it! And as things
go through multiple generations
they get mutated.

Simply because everyone
has heard a rumor doesn't mean
that it resembles the original story
in any way. Remember that game
Telephone? It's the game where a
silly sentence, "My cat is named
Barberella," for instance, is whis
pered from person to person
around the room, and usually
winds up sounding something like
"Your orange gorilla ate my cat."
If that happens to a simple
phrase, try to imagine what the
ninth or tenth person to hear the
news about you is learning. Be
fore you even know it, you may
be engaged to be married, have

some incurable disease, be con
sidering joining a cult, or just
be a slut.
These rumors are danger
ous things, so why do we even
bother with them? Because
they're fun--duh!!! I can't think

of one person I know who
would willingly dismiss any
gossip at all (at least, not the
good stuff).
Some rumors, though, are
famous. Not the kind that
evolve into an exciting and tor¬

rid tale, but the type that start out
that way.
One story that springs to
mind is the myth that if your
roommate is killed or commits
suicide, then you automatically
get a 4.0 GPA. Don't get your

hopes up too fast; there's appar
ently an exception if you are the
one who killed your roommate.
Sorry. Another, rather morbid,
tale is about a student who was
so frustrated during a test that he

authorized aid.
Gettysburg College has a whole
set of its own rumors and supersti
tions. So far this year I've already
been warned about the "Ghost of
Glatfelter,"which is a popular one on
many campuses. The story, as I heard

The important thing to keep
in mind is that rumors are just that
rumors. The definition of rumor,
according to the American Heritage
Dictionary, is "unverified informa
tion of uncertain origin usually
spread by word of mouth; hearsay."
So if you want the absolute
truth, don't put much faith in the
rumors. But if you want to know
what's really going on, you'd bet
ter pay close attention. Who
knows? This week's topic may be
you, or someone living in your
dorm, or even someone "unliving"
in your dorm.

shoved his official No. 2 pencils up
his nose and smashed his face into the
desk; he, supposedly, died instantly.
Could that be an Honor Code viola
tion? Probably not, since it's not likely
that he could've asked the students
who finished before him for any un¬

it, is that there is a female ghost in
Glatfelter Hall who lures young
men to the top of the bell tower and
then throws them off to their deaths.
Not a nice chick. Is it true? I don't
know, but I can guarantee that you
won't see me hanging around
Glatfelter at night to find out.
Another such story involves
the "Blue Boy" of Stevens Hall.
Apparently many, many, (oh, what
the heck) many years ago a small
boy was forced out into a cold
winter's night. He was forgotten
about, and then froze to death. It's
rumored that sometimes when it's
really cold outside, a young boy's
face can be glimpsed through the
windows. I suppose there could
actually be a spectral image, or
maybe it's just the face print on the
glass from the last person who
looked out the window trying to see
the ghost.

Alicia clueless in Baggage

byJonFr oehlich
Staff Writer "There was only one thing I
never could have anticipated,"
Emily Hope.
"Excess Baggage" is a
movie produced by twenty year
old actress Alicia Silverstone - and
it shows. This movie, directed by
Marco Brambilla, tells the story of
how its two main characters, Emily
and Vincent, are thrown together
under a set of circumstances more
ridiculous than those of your aver
age "Bugs Bunny" cartoon.

Emily Hope, played by Ali
cia Silverstone, ("The Crush,"
"Batman and Robin") is a rich,
annoying brat who chooses kid
napping herself as a way to get
daddy's attention.
Though the role of a rich
eighteen year- old princess should
be fairly natural to Silverstone by
now, she seems to have lost her
edge in this latest showing. The
innocent and fresh qualities that
made her so likeable in "Clueless,"
perhaps Silverstone's most popu
lar movie to date and the one that

pushed her into Hollywood's
mainstream, are largely unappar
ent in "Excess Baggage."
It is fairly clear that audi
ences are supposed to sympathize
with Emily on some level because
of her dead mother and emotion
ally distant father, but audiences
will most likely be repelled by
Emily's frustrated character rather
than drawn in by it.
The story of "Excess Bag
gage" really begins when Emily's
plan goes wrong as Vincent, a pro
fessional car thief, played likeably
by Benicio Del Toro ("The Usual
Suspects," "Big Top Pee Wee"),
steals her BMW with her hiding
in the trunk. At first, Vincent feels
just like the audience: that he has
just stumbled into the wrong place
at the wrong time.

From there on in, Excess
Baggage" inevitably turns into a
love story. Vincent forms an at
tachment to Emily, and soon finds
out that the feeling is quite mutual.
While this romance, perhaps, had
the potential to be entertaining, this
movie doesn't bother to explore it
very deeply, thus causing it to fall
into the common grave of unde
fined relationships and shallow
characters that is "Excess Bag
gage." Added, haphazardly, to the
premise for "drama" are cops,
guns, car chases and a few random

gangsters.
One of the many problems
with "Excess Baggage" is that it
tries too hard to be something that
it simply is not - a funny, bright,
fresh movie that explores the lives
of young people through a set of
comical circumstances. Though
this movie did have a few cute
parts and mildly funny lines, this
goal goes largely unfulfilled, mak
ing "Excess Baggage" about as
fresh as Nebraska seafood. While,
if done successfully, this mission
might have made an entertaining
movie showcasing the qualities
that we see in movies such as "The
Breakfast Club" and "Dazed and
Confused," "Excess Baggage"
simply doesn't do a very good job
of taking an idea and going some
where meaningful with it.

If this movie was indeed
supposed to be about being young
in today's world, perhaps the di
rector should have taken a look to
see how many of young people out
there are actually pro car thieves
and rich little girls who kidnap
themselves to get attention.
Judging from the director's
past credits and fromthe producer
of this movie, Alicia Silverstone,
the extreme incompetence of "Ex
cess Baggage" should come as no
surprise to viewers. With this
project, director Brambilla adds
another flop to his collection in
cluding "Demolition Man." At
least with this movie, Brambilla
simply keeps piling on one con
trived event after another for the
express purpose of trying to make
up for the movie's lack of direc
tion and focus.

Though Silverstone herself
tests and surpasses the limit of how
far a pretty face can get you in her
portrayal of Emily, the supporting
characters in "Excess Baggage"
were, actually, fairly decent, con
sidering the constraints of the ri
diculous story line.
Perhaps the best of these was
Emily's Uncle Ray, played by the
eternally cool Christopher Walken
("Pulp Fiction," "Last Man Stand
ing") whose shady and intelligent
personality helps him to play this
role rather well. Other decent per
formances come from Nicholas
Turturro ("NYPD Blue") and
Harry Connick Jr.("Independence
Day").
Sadly though, these perfor
mances were incapable of saving
"Excess Baggage" from being a
border-line disaster.

Sewage kills 3600 fish

byStephBusch Contributing Writer
On September 2, 1997,
Glatfelter Paper Mill experienced
a power outage which caused an
industrial waste spill into the
Codorus Creek, killing approxi
mately 3,600 fish.
The waste consisted of two
types of latex and clay from the
coater process, as well as paper fi
ber and residual fibers such as ti
tanium dioxide and calcium car
bonate. These containments were
released directly into the creek for

15-20 minutes.
The spill turned the creek
"milk white from bank to bank,"
according to Joe Roth, a Depart
ment of Environmental Protection
(DEP) official.
It is quite possible that these
fish died from oxygen depletion.
When the sewage was released into
the creek, the bacteria in the water
and waste began to break down the
organic material. Bob Schott, a
DEP biologist, said that this, in
turn, "speeds up the bacteria's me
tabolism and depletes the oxygen
in the stream."

The fish may have also died
from an abrupt change in the PH
levels, creating too alkaline an en
vironment for the fish to live in.
Fortunately, this spill will
not effect the drinking water be
cause there are no intakes down
stream from the mill, reported
Sandy Roderick, the spokes
woman for Pennsylvania's Depart
ment of Environmental Protection
(DEP).
Company spokesman Pat
Sweeney said, "We're just as up
set and concerned about this as
everyone else is. So we're look
ing at ways to...prevent this from
occurring again in the future."
Even so, in July of this year
there was a spill from the mill due
to a back-up and overflow in a
man-hole caused by heavy storms.
There were also fish kills in 1993
and 1978 due to Glatfelter pollu
tion. These spills were also both
investigated by Roth, who is look
ing into this spill.

It could be several weeks be
fore the DEP has lab results on the
water samples collected. A notice
of violation was sent to the paper
maker a week ago, giving the com
pany five days to respond.
Glatfelter must provide informa
tion on why the accident happened
and how the company will prevent

it from happening again.
Glatfelter normally dis
charges approximately 12 million
gallons of treated wastewater a day
into Codorus Creek, according to
Sweeney.
The paper mill is currently
operating on a discharge permit
that expired eight years ago, but
has been extended while work con
tinues on a new permit.
Glatfelter has been in busi
ness is 1864, and is a leading pro
ducer of book publishing papers
and technical specialty products
such as the paper used in making
postage stamps, playing cards, and
hospital gowns. The company em
ploys about 1,200 people.
Glatfelter Paper Mill is
ranked by the Environmental Pro
tection Agency (EPA) as the third
largest polluter in Pennsylvania.
This column will be alternat
ing weeks with the Theater column
by Glen Beck.

Prof shows women are
the same everywhere

by Casey L Dunn
Staff Writer

tecture.' Through these courses,
and the symposium, the college
community will have the opportu
nity to learn more about the cul
ture and history of South Asia.
From the very beginning,
Aftab has been interested in
women's history and women's
studies. At the University of
Karachi, she was involved with the
women's studies program as well.
Aftab does not view the culture of
women in Pakistan to be entirely
different from the women in the
States. She says that the "prob
lems, issues, and concerns are the
same.". She relates that discrimi
nation is the same and that "if it is
happening here, it is happening
there." There are many obvious dif
ferences between'our culture and
that of Pakistan's. Aftab views the
United States as the "country of
options," and Pakistan as a place
of "limited options" and that "a
vast majority have no choices" in
cluding the area of marriage and
children.

Professor Tahera Aftab
quotes her mother saying, "as an
educated woman, you owe some
thing to all women...do something
for all of them." These instructions
from her mother have inspired her
to work in the field of education,
and more specially in women's
studies and history.
Professor Aftab of the Uni
versity of Karachi in Pakistan will
be a visiting professor and scholar
at Gettysburg this year. Her pres
ence here on campus works'well
with this year's symposium, for
which the theme is "South Asia:

The Next 50 Years."
Aftab, saw some "excellent
opportunities to share something of
her culture" here in Gettysburg, and
making this opportunity even
greater is that this year celebrates
the fiftieth anniversary of indepen
dence for South Asia. She also saw
teaching in the United States as a
gateway to being able to do more
research in the women's studies
field. Coming as a visiting profes
sor to Gettysburg also offered Aftab
the opportunity to be reunited with
her son, Faris Khan, who is a se
nior here at Gettysburg.

Here at Gettysburg, Aftab is
teaching three courses in conjunc
tion with the South Asian Studies
program this year. Her classes in
clude "History of the Indian Sub
continent", "Women in South
Asia", and "Islamic Art and Archi-

After only being in
Gettysburg for a little less than two
weeks, Aftab has liked what she
has seen. She comments that ev
eryone is "willing to help me."
However, she is a bit worried that
she may seem a little "rigid" to the
younger professors here on cam
pus. Overall, she has been im
pressed with the students and feels
that, as a whole, we should "ap
preciate the youth - they work
hard."

Dear Casey...

Dear Casey ,
I'mafr eshman. During
orientation I hung out mainly
with this girl. Since then, I've
made a lot of friends. I've dis
cover ed that my "orientation
fr iend" and I r eally don't have
much in common. I feel I need
to move away fr om her, but I
don'twanttohurtherfeelings.
She' sanicegirLjustnotmetype
I'dbefriendswith. Any advice?
-Stuck in Orientation
Dear Stuck In Orientation,
You met this girl in a time
of tremendous change in both of
your lives. At the time the two of

you met, you were so caught up in
college life that you really did not
know what you were looking for
in a friend. Perhaps you just
needed someone to pal around
with until you got yourself settled
and acquainted with those whose
interests compliment yours better.
Sometimes, these "transi
tional friendships" are hard to
break away from because of fear
of hurting another person's feel
ings. But you should realize that
moving away from someone is not
the end of the world. It happens
every day; people move apart, and
in the same way, people move
closer.

It is advisable to not com
pletely ignore this girl. Given
time, most likely the two of you
will naturally move apart if your
interests are as diverse as you
claim. If you let it happen natu
rally, then hard feelings should not
be a problem.
Dear Casey,
I dated a guy for several

months befor el decided to end
the relationship. Hedidnottake
_iteasily ,butlwasabletomove
on and have a r elarionshipwith
another guy for several months
after guy#l. Whenguy#2and
I broke up, guy #1 was dating
someonenew . Thenewgirlwas

afnendofmineJr ealizedlstill
hadfedingsfor guy#l,andnow
cannot take being ar oundthem
when they ar e together .Can you
help? -Leftover Feelings.
Dear Leftover Feelings,

Well, it seems that you have
made your bed and now you have
to sleep in it, regardless of how
crowded it is. What you thought
was the right thing to do at the time
now seems like the wrong thing.
This is tough advice. I strongly
advise that you, as one of my
friends often says, "suck it up and
deal." You say you can not stand
to see them together. If you still
had feelings for this boy, would it
not make you happy to see him
happy? The only small detail is

that he is happy with her and not
YOU. Try and be happy for him.
This situation is probably
also putting a strain on your rela
tionship with your friend. My ad
vice is to not let their relationship
cause a rift in your friendship. In
these upcoming years, you are
bound to date many men, but of
ten your girl friends stay with you
for a while. You can either try to
put a smile on your face and ac
cept what these events have
brought about, or sit around in your
room and sulk.The choice is yours.

Conflict and Consensus
Looking toward 2000: Too many candidates?

by John Dunlap
Staff Writer
With the election of Bill
Clinton to the Presidency
of the United States in
1992, the Democratic
Party controlled the
White House and the
Congress, as well as
most of the nation's
governors and state
legislatures. Today, over

four years later, Bill
Clinton is still President
of the United States, but
Republicans have picked
up 13 Senate seats, 41
House seats, 12 gover
nors, and over 500 state
legislative seats. The
Republican Party now
has control of virtually
every elected office, it
seems, on the national
level except the Presi¬

dency. In 1998 the GOP The GOP is notorious to

will most likely pick up
congressional seats
because in midterm
elections the party out of
power usually does
better. Without the
Executive branch of
government, you can not
get all of your agenda
through. The President
has his bully pulpit, his
veto power, now line
item veto power, and the
power of appointment.
No matter who is Presi
dent, he or she will be
the center of national
attention in the govern
ment.
This is why in the year

2000, it is essential for
Republicans to win the
White House back.
Republican nominees in
the last two elections,
President George Bush
and former Senate
Majority Leader Bob
Dole, only received 38%
and 41%, respectively, in
the popular vote. While
the Democrats look to
have Vice President Al

Gore as
their
front
runner,
the
Republi cans
have no
clear favorite
This is

Today there is a fresh crop
of Republican govenors
who are keeping their
promises and making
waves in their states.

very
unusual, though not
necessarily a bad thing

giving out its Presiden
tial nomination to the
most established or
already well-known
figure. Republicans have
nominated Thomas
Dewey, twice Governor
of New York, World War
II hero Dwight
Eisenhower twice, Vice
President Richard Nixon
three times, and Senator
Barry Goldwater. Actor
Ronald Reagan, Gover
nor of California, and
Goldwater's successor in
the conservative move
ment twice would stand
atop the Republican
Convention. Reagan's

Vice President, George
Bush, would be a two
time nominee. Many of
these men were success
ful, though in 1996,
when Republicans
wanted to portray them
selves as the "party of
the people" and of
reform, it was hard for
Bob Dole, one of
Washington's most
established figures, to

run on that platform. No
longer did the face of a
strong leader work
without the Cold War.
With the taint of scandal,
divided government, and
fierce partisanship in
Washington, the Repub
licans may be wise to
move out of the beltway
for their next party
leader. There are a host
of party insiders who
may seek the Presidency,
but each has his own
weaknesses. Consider
ing the lackluster presi
dential campaign a
Senate Leader ran in '96.

it is hard to imagine that
the party would nomi
nate Senate Majority
Leader Trent Lott of

Mississippi. Despite
that, many party conser
vatives are angry with
him over numerous
issues. Speaker of the
House Newt Gingrich is
said to be considering a
run in 2000, however
with his scandal, his low
poll numbers, and some
of his own House depu
ties against him, it is
hard to imagine how he
could even run. Other

Washmg
tonians
who are
said to be
consider
ing the
Presi
dency are
Senator
Fred
Thomp
son of

Tennessee. Thompson
draws comparisons to
President Reagan be
cause of his acting career
and his ability to com
municate. While he has
only been a senator for
two and a half years, he
now is chairing the
Committee investigating
White House scandals
and while that may
surely give him national
attention, he can expect
the wrath of the White
House, which may hold
him back.
Today, there are a fresh
crop of Republican
Governors who are

keeping their promises
and making waves in
their states. Some are

better known than others
like the Governor of
Texas, George W. Bush,
who looms large in the
upcoming race. The
former President's son is
popular in Texas and is
already doing very well
in polls.
Besides Phil Gramm, other
'96 candidates are
looking to hop in like
former Tennessee Gover
nor Lamar Alexander
and publisher Steve
Forbes, whose flat tax is
growing in popularity.
The wife of '96 nominee
Bob Dole, Elisabeth
Dole, who serves as
President of the Ameri¬

can Red Cross, is being
tossed around. Mrs.
Dole showed great
campaigning skills last
year as she toured the
nation for her husband.
Having so many potential
candidates is not neces
sarily bad because while
a civil war is possible in
the GOP, it is sometimes
healthy to have a good
debate. Out of the list
that I have mentioned,
many if not most, will
not run, but with such a
strong farm team in the
works, then the Party of
Lincoln may be wise to
take a chance and give an
outsider the ball.

Welcome back...most of vou

I think I speak for most
Gettysburg residents
when I say that we're
delighted each fall when
you students return. It's
a pleasure to see you on
campus, and on our
streets. We've missed
your youth and vitality,
and your promise for the
future. Most of you, that

is.
Sad to say, there are always
a few bad apples among
you. A few, however, is
all it takes to leave a sour
taste. Each fall, you
announce your arrival by
tossing your cups and
beer cans into our gar
dens. This is an ongoing
ritual—as is the use of
our property as urinals.
Throughout the school
year, you keep us awake
with your parties, and
with the drunken mating
calls that follow-usually
in the middle of the
street.

At Christmas time, we can
count on you to cut our
trees, rip off our wreaths,
and hack our holly
bushes. Of course you
need to deface our
property, don't you, so
you can decorate your
rooms for a few days
before you go home
(where you can enjoy
your families' holiday
decorations).
And when spring comes,
you really get frisky.
That's when you rip our
our tulips and daffodils
out of the ground and
toss them on the side
walks. (You're so cute
when you're soused.)
When you've had your final
round of noisy parties
and Commencement has
come and gone, are we
glad to see you go? In
fact, do we wish you'd
leave right now? What
do you think? (As a
matter of fact, one or two

of you will probably
have to leave, after some
truly disgusting behav
ior.)
Wouldn't it be nice if this
year were different?
Wouldn't it be great if
you made some sort of
connection between your
own towns and homes
and families and ours?
Just like your families,
we take pride in our

homes, work hard, need
our sleep, send our own
kids to college, if we
can—and hope that
they'll take our values
with them when they go
Give it a thought, the
next time you feel like
tossing your beer cans
into our yards.
Maybe this year, we'll be
glad all of you came
back.
A Gettysburg Resident.

¦. .1
Consider this ....

The Gettysburgian is a
newspaper.
As a newspaper, it is
our duty to inform the
campus community. The
Gettysburgian staff proudly
fulfills the role of the fourth
estate, challenging authority
and searching for the truth.
Gettysburg College is
very lucky. We are fortu
nate to have a student
newspaper that functions
separately from student
government tne admin

ana -
istration. Numerous ac
counts tell of student news
papers shut down after
printing mildly controver
sial stories about adminis
trators or student govern
ment officials.
We at the
Gettysburgian are not
subject to such arbitrary
disregard of First Amend
ment rights.
We are protectors of
freedom—a charge we take
very seriously.
We determine the
content and coverage in the
newspaper. We are truly a
STUDENT newspaper.

We work closely with
attorneys at the Student
Press Law Center to protect
everyone's freedom of
speech.
Some readers have
been upset by our recent
coverage of some campus
events.
We have a responsibil
ity to report the news, no
matter how it may hurt a
certain fraternity's rush or
bruise someone's inflated
ego. When unpleasant
things happen, don't kill
the messenger; The
Gettysburgian reports the
news—we don't make it.

T _* *
Likewise, the
Gettysburgian does not, nor
will it, serve as a public
relations machine for any
given organization or office
on campus or off.
But our most impor
tant job remains to be
defenders of the public's
right to know. We are
indeed protectors of the
First Amendment.
The Gettysburgian is a
student newspaper.

Conflict and Consensus
Plagiarism or Inspiration?

To the Gettysburgian:
An article from College
Press Service in your
August 28 issue asks in
its title "Plagiarism or
Inspiration?" This item
concerns a service on the
Internet that provides
canned admissions
essays for students to
submit with their appli
cations to undergraduate_,
law, or business schools.
The answer to the ques
tion in the title is easy
plagiarism. We would
like to think that this
article was printed in the

Gettysburgian simply to
inform Gettysburg
students of a new kind of
unethical business that
they would, of course,
never personally patron
ize because the values of
the Honor Code (which
Gettysburg students
endorse) deplore plagia
rism in any context. To
make this point more
clear, we would have
appreciated comment by
your staff appended to
this article (which was
perilously close to an
advertisement for the
service) or in a separate

editorial that expressed
the moral distaste we all
should feel for such a
venture.
Sincerely,
Robert C. Nordvall

Anne Bucher Lane
Associate Dean of Aca
demic Advising

demic Advising

This Side of _Cyrnsim
Sex before liquor ..

by I. A.
Isherwood
Contributing Writer
For some terribly odd
reason when I came back
to Gettysburg this semes
ter, I imagined change,
something different, or a
more enlightened out
look upon the overall
nature of college life.
Without much percep
tion, the reader can now
imagine my deep regrets
that nothing was differ
ent except for a few new
posters and flyers in the

CUB. Still though, I
vowed for a positive
outlook upon my return
so that I could get the
best out of my
"Gettysburg experience."
When I saw my first
group of freshmen, or
first-year students to the
educated, my heart
dropped and sank into a
pool of tar (in which it is
still stuck), and my
optimism was shattered
into tiny bits throughout
the rest of my body. It is
not that I have a bitter

unbinding hatred for
first-year students, it is
just that I fear for them
and the humbling experi

ence called the Freshman
year. It seems as though
first-year students are
regarded as some of the
most open-minded
people who are on our
campus just because they
are naive to college life
and, most especially, the
seclusion of Gettysburg.
What I resent is the
molding process, the loss
of individualism, which

accompa
nies this
sort of
environ
ment and
possible emotional
effects of
such adaption.
Now, before
any of you
put away
this paper

I guess I'm just a bit old
fashined, or not quite up to
date with the latest dating
ritual or alcohol-indued
sexual entertainment.

or
this column as garbage,
at least listen to a few
remarks and helpful
criticism I have to offer.
First and foremost, the
most revolting situation
is the "Red Zone" for
which we see so many of
those striking posters
plastered across all our
halls. The situation of
freshmen girls is much
different from the situa
tion of men on campus,
in that we are not people

Respond to this or any item in the Gettysburgian! Write a letter to the
Editor and send it to Box 434 or email us at burgian @ gettysburg.edu

easily identified at
parties or other gather
ings for the drooling
lusts of others. Fresh
men women, mainly for
reasons of insecurity in
their new environment,
become not only targets
but victims of a very
cruel and sexually
deviant tradition on
college campuses. The
equation is quite simple

combine an insecure
young woman with a
lusting older male and
throw in some alcohol,
you have a dangerous
situation. I suppose
lusting is too open a
term, so we'll just refer
to Red Zone predators as
character-challenged
young men.
Maybe I'm foolish, but I
can't understand how a
situation so obvious, and
so terribly stupid, can

still exist ma civilized
society. I guess I'm just
a bit old fashioned, or
not quite up to date with
the modern dating ritual
of alcohol-induced
sexual entertainment. It
is a sordid catch and
release policy of corrup
tion. I am not speaking
out against dating,
norrelationships, but just
against using other
people for

temporary
pleasure.
Such
pleasure
can have a
lasting
emotional effect on
people and
we all need
to take that
into con
sideration.
We also

live in a world where
sexual promiscuity is not
the safest option out
there for young folks
and, the more such a
situation exists, the more
work those wonderful
people at the Health
Center will have with
unwanted pregnancy,
strange horrific STDs,
and even possibly the
AIDS epidemic. Such is
the dangerous nature of
the world we live in.
I would like it if people

would just open their
eyes a little to the nature
of the Red Zone, and
whatever other zones
they might think of next
for other problems. (By
the way, who thinks of
these flyers?) I was quite
alarmed by the poster; in
fact, I was frightened
until I realized it was not
meant for me or any of
my friends. The sad
thing is that the problem
is not overlooked nor
under-advertised, but it is
purposefully ignored by
those to whom it is
directed. Such is the way
of the world, for which

our campus is a minute
speck of dust upon.
Regardless of the comic
potential of such a
poster, it is a serious
situation that cannot be
understood because it is
so common. The Red
Zone factor is just one of
those little bits of college
"initiation" which we
can all live without, for

our safety and the rem
nants of dignity in our
culture. It seems to me
that problems are evalu
ated when the situation
becomes a problem, or
someone is seriously
injured. We should not
wait, not with this issue
and let us try to make
Month Two of this
period a little bit better
for all of us.

This Week at Gettysburg

The Civil War Institute (C.W.I.) of
Gettysburg College is proud to announce
its involvement with the
Adopt-A-Position program in cooperation
with the Gettysburg National Military
Park The Adopt-A-Position Program is a
new volunteer program for groups and
organizations that help care for Civil War
monuments, cannons, fences, stone walls
and other features on the battlefield This
program is modeled after the popular
"Adopt a Highway" program. The
National Park Service asks that interested
Civil War enthusiasts make a commitment
to help tackle historic preservation
projects which cannot be funded through
their shrinking park budget Our petition
was filed and approved over the summer,
and we have officially become the proud
"parents" of the 1 Ith Corps Line north of
the college Our first "assault" on the
1 Ith Corps Line is set for 900 a m on
Saturday, September 13, 1997. Those
interested in helping with this project
should contact the C.W.I, at extension
6590 or by email to
ldmarsha.@gettysburg edu. by
September 8th.

>Found: After the meetings for
Work-Study and Stafford Loan on
Saturday evening, Aug. 23, some things
were found in the auditorium. NO ONE
HAS CLAIMED THEM. If you left
something behind at those meetings,

open with a reception for the artist at 7
p m , Thursday, September 18 in the
Schmucker Hall Gallery Gates, a
sculptor and George Washington Univer
sity professor, has been using found an
fabricated objects to create assemblage
sculptures for 25 years Working with
painted fiberglass resin to form swirling
fabrics and realistic faces, with woven
cloths to authenticate armor, and metal
rods or wood to represent bodily limbs,
Gates ' sculptures capture the spirit of the
samurai warrior Washington Post critic,
Hank Burchard, writing about the artists'
1996 exhibition at the Japan Information
and Cultural Center, describes Gates of
having been so penetrating in his carica
tures of the samurai that "one Japanese
visitor to the opening refused to believe
they had been done by a non-Japanese,
even after he was introduced to Gates.
"These figures, " Burchard goes on to say,
"range from ferocious and fearsome to
funny and funky " "Knights of the Rising
Sun; Japanese Armor as an Art Form, "
which is open and free to the public, will
continue through Sunday, October 12

Recording only two first
places, the Gettysburg College
women's track team captured the
1997 Centennial Conference title,
Sunday, May 4 at Franklin &
Marshall College in Lancaster.
The victory was the second in four
years for the Lady Bullets.
Senior Mak Green success
fully defended her high jump
crown as she cleared 5' 1 3/4".
Freshman Cathy Spangler
grabbed the other first place with
her winning discus throw of
116'11". Spangler was second in

the shotput with a school record
toss of 38'2".
Gettysburg's depth played a
key role in the success of the team
and no less than five players
placed in three or more events.
Freshman Anne Schenck was the
leader as she was fifth in the 100
(13.29), fifth in the 200 (27.13),
fifth in the high jump (4'9 3/4")
and was the lead leg on the sec
ond place 4x100 relay (51.27)
which set a school and meet
record. Other members of that
team were junior Jackie Klug,
freshman Emily Brown, and fresh
man Andi Therit.

Besides her anchor on the
relay, Therit was second in the 100
in the 100 in 12.74 and second in
the 200 in 26.21. Brown captured
a fourth place in the 400 in 63.30
seconds and a third in the 400
hurdles in 68.72. Klug had a ban
ner weekend as she posted a
school record and national quali
fying time for the 100-hurdles
with a third place time of 15.19,
and she was third in the long jump
with a 15'8 3/4".
Junior Wendy Johnston was
the leader among the distance run
ners. She nailed down a second
place in the 3,000-meter run in
10:45.62, was fourth in the 1,500
in 4:56.84, and was fourth in the
5,000 in 19:23.64.

"Driving" through the
Conference

by Franc Candido
Staff Writer In the two weeks since the
season opener, the Gettysburg
field hockey team has played
games against Juniata, Rochester,
and William Smith colleges. De
spite how the win and loss column
looks, the Bullets are ready for a
season filled with drives, stops,
and plenty of highlights.
Right now the team has a
record of 1 -3, but dramatic perfor
mances, including a last minute
game winning goal by co-captain

Becky Griffith shows that there is
considerable potential for success.
For 1996, the team finished with
a 14-7 record in the regular sea
son. In Centennial Confrence play,
the team achieved an 8-1 record.
Presently, there are 34 play
ers on the team's roster. This
Bullet's squad is laced with talent
and returns 9 letterwinners from
last season. These players in
clude: Carolyn Anzalone, Tara
Chipko, Shanley Cooke, Laura
DeSario, Heather Donaldson,
Steph Fisher, Kim Fritz, Becky
Griffith, and Anna Spognardi.

Photo by Mark Aslrom
"/ got nuttin but love fo' ya," says this Lady Bullet to her
opponent as she smashes the ball down field.
i i

Donaldson, Fritz, and
Griffith plan to lead this Bullet
team to high heights as they ac
cept the responsibilities as team
captians. Last season, Donaldson
started 20 games and made the
All-Centennial Conference Team.
Fritz spent all of the 1996 season
abroad. Remarkably, she has kept
all of her dope skills intact be
cause she has started in all of the
Bullets games this season.
Griffith must know how
to handle the rock because pres
ently she holds three Gettysburg
records for assists. Last season
she was featured on the first-team
all-conference, and second -team
Division III All-America teams.
Bullets Head Coach Carol Daly
is returning as well. Daly is a 1983
graduate of Gettysburg. In 1980,
she played on the team that cap
tured the Division III national
championship.

This rough start for the
Lady Bullets will definitely not
last long. This bunch of dedicated
women will settle for nothing less
than a Centennial Conference
Title this year, and they are aimed
and ready to shoot at the ever al
lusive crown..

GOODBYE "WHITEY"-

Longtime Phillies standout and color announcer passes away at age 70

On Wednesday September
10, a great era came to an abrupt
end. Richie Ashburn, beloved
baseball player and announcer for
the Philadelphia Phillies, died
Wednesday in a New York hotel
room. Traveling with the team as
their color announcer, Ashburn
was a trademark of the Phillies
broadcasting network, and along
with Harry Kalas, he created many
vivid memories for all Phillies
fans. Richie Ashburn played the
game in 50's along with some of
the most prolific center fielders
ever. Names like names Willie
Mays, Mickey Mantle, and Duke
Snider often headlined the news
paper, while the more low key cen
ter fielder from "Philly," quietly
put up numbers that would get
anyone into the Hall of Fame.

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor

As a player, Ashburn was a
two-time NL batting champ and
the center fielder on the 1950
Whiz Kids, Rookie of the Year in
1948, five-time all star (the only
Phillies Rookie ever to start and
All-Star game.) Ashburn batted
over .300 nine times and until
1995 was passed up in the voting
for the Hall of Fame.

Ashburn was a classic
ballplayer. He epitomized the
word hustle and laid down bunts
like they were going out of style.
As a lead-off hitter, Richie's job
was to get on base~and get on
base he did.
Ashburn was the bomb as he
led the league in walks four times,
in hits four times, and in triples
twice, and his career on base per
centage was close to .400. For all
you fans who do not understand
this stat, Richie reached base 40%
of the time he batted. Dare I say....
"EnFuego."
The thing that many people
know today about the great Richie
Ashburn was his voice and his
character. Along with Harry
Kalas, Ashburn joyously an
nounced 35 years of Philadelphia
Phillies baseball.

Richie was most commonly
known for his announcement of
the birthdays of Phillies fans.
"Gladys Westinghouse of
Newtown Square, Pa turns 102
years old today...She has been a
Phillies fan for all 102 of those I
bet.." Then of course Harry would
agree, and the two would go on
announcing the game, as if they
were blessed under some great
star. For so many years Ashburn
was passed over in the voting, and

A young Ashburn poses for a
picture as a member of the
1950 "Whiz Kids"

Phillies fans felt all of his pain.
After playing in an era where cen
ter fielders were dominating,
homerun hitting, base clearing
legends, Richie was denied the re
spect of many of those great play
ers even though he had compiled
some wonderful numbers.
Finally in 1995, Richie
Ashburn was voted in to the Ma
jor League Baseball Hall of Fame
in Cooperstown, New York.
Richie was enshired to
gether with Michael Jack Schmidt,
a Philadelphia Phillie that he saw
hit 544 career homeruns. The two
Phillies from two different genera¬

tions of baseball drew the biggest
crowd ever in Cooperstown,
28,000 fans strong, including 200
buses from Philadelphia. "We
have lost a cherished friend," said
Mike Schmidt, "you didn't have
to know him personally to con
sider him a friend."
If you were to ask someone,
"What do you think of when I say
Philadelphia Phillies?", undoubt
edly, one of the most prevalent an
swers would be "Richie Ashburn,
of course." Not only was Richie a
great man, but he was everything
that the game of baseball was sup
posed to be.

In an era when no player
complained about contract rene
gotiations, management disputes
or salary arbitration, Ashburn was
sliding in cleats first. He was an
artist of the bunt, and a consum
mate worker who never left a
single thing on the field except his
heart and soul.
Richie, we will never forget
you, in us you have instilled your
ideas, your knowledge, and a little
piece of your spirit. We will never
forget the "Right down the middle
for a ball," or the many "Long,
drive deep to left-center," calls.
You will always remain in
the upper echelons of baseball,
and you knew exactly what it
meant to be a true ballplayer and
a true Philadelphia Phillie.

As Chris Felton picked up the extra point that
junior Tom "smooth as silk" Olchon had just
knocked and ran it back ninety yards for a two point
conversion, he was probably thinking, "You know,
I bet I could make a damn good halfback."
Then, as if God were saying: "Felton, you
animal, just stick to defense," the lights went out
at Albright Stadium. Honestly. Expert football
analyst and sophomore defensive back Chris
"Sweet Lou" Lunardi reported: "It was one of the
most amazing things I've ever seen in a football
game...if I were Albright, after Felton made that
run, I would have turned the lights out too."
The Bullets did have an impressive showing
last Friday night in Reading, Pennsylvania. Al
though the unofficial score was 31-16 in favor of
Albright, Gettysburg played the number two team
in the nation for Divison III quite tough.
Leading the offense were full back Paul "You
can't stop me you can only hope to contain me"
Smith, who ran for 210 all purpose yards, of which
140 were rushing, and halfback Matt Helwig, who
scored two touchdowns for three and six yards re
spectively.

Full house

College adjusts to housing situation

photo by Mark Astrom

by Rebecca M. Schantzenbach
contributing writer
Housing always ranks high
among the concerns of Gettysburg
College students, but this year hous
ing has become an even more prized
commodity.
According to the Office of
Residence Life, (he current housing
situation is not a housing crisis, as all
the students have beds to sleep in.
However, all of the accom
modations traditionally offered on
campus have been filled. The Col
lege has had to make some other op
tions available.
Gettysburg is currently leas
ing the Criterion Motel on Carlisle
Street. It is housing twenty-one first
year students as well as one Residence
Assistant.

There are also twelve spaces
reserved at the Gettysburg Lutheran
Seminary. The Seminary housing is
set aside for upperclassmen. There
are currently eight rooms in use, in
cluding one by the Residence Assis
tant. All of the rooms at the semi
nary are singles with carpets and air
conditioning. Although these hous
ing options are quite appealing to
some students, the question remains,
what has brought on this sudden on
slaught of students?
There are numbers of factors
that have influenced the current hous
ing situation. The most obvious rea
son for the lack of traditional campus
housing is the large number of stu
dents. The current class of first
year students, the class of 2001, is
larger than any other class on cam
pus. The College only planned on ap
proximately 620 First-Year students

The annual Cupola Society Celebration will be held Saturday
see related story—p 3

coming to Gettysburg this fall. Six
hundred forty-four, however, are now
on campus.
According to the department
of Admissions, the First-Year students
are not the only influencing factor.
There was a higher retention of
upperclass students as well. The origi
nal number projected by the College
for returning students was too low.
While these factors are both
potentially positive situations for the
College, it does create some problems,
housing being one of them.
Yet another reason for the
surplus of students requiring housing
is influenced by the fraternities. Many
of the houses are not filled to their full
est capacity. The displacement of fra
ternities from campus also played a
major role in the current housing situ
ation. When their housing was lost,
the College suddenly had to find beds
for many of the brothers of Tau Kappa
Epsilon and Phi Delta Theta.
Two final influencing factors
are more students who had withdrawn

returning to Gettysburg, and a decreas
ing number of students living off-cam
pus. Tim Rupe, Director of Resi
dence Life, believes that this is "a good
problem; it means there are more
qualified people here." Rupe believes
that the increase in the number of stu
dents, both new and returning, has not
only increased in quantity but in qual
ity as well.
Delwin Gustafson, Dean of
Admissions, does not believe that this_,
housing situation will affect the accep
tance rates for upcoming years.
The current housing situation
is an ongoing process, interlinking
many departments on campus. It re
mains to be seen what will happen next
year. Will there be enough beds for
all the bodies?

The Student Newspaper of Gettysburg College Since 1897


by AnneMarieBielii
contributing writer
Is death an appropriate form
of punishment for those who have
committed a murder? This ques
tion has long been a topic of great
debate.
In 1983 there were a total of
five executions performed in the
United States; by 1990 that num
ber rose to twenty-three and this
year, the number has increased to
fifty executions. Many believe the
death penalty should be abolished
altogether. Others believe that ex
ecutions are an appropriate and
necessary punishment for anyone
who commits a murder. Lisa
Bartle, assistant director of the
Death Penalty Information Center
will be addressing Gettysbuig Col
lege on these issues during the sec
ond Common Hour of the year, to
be held next Thursday, September

Dean Nordval is head of the Gettysburg Coalition to end the death penalty

Jennifer Brown ('96) has joined the NCADP diephoio

Courtesy of Church of the
Brethren

Jennifer Brown of
Upperco, Maryland, has recently
undertaken a one year Church of
the Brethren Volunteer Service
(BVS) assignment with National
Coalition to Abolish the Death
Penalty in Washington, DC.
The National Coalition to
Abolish the Death Penalty
(NCADP) was founded in 1976,
the year the U.S. Supreme Court
opened the way for resumption of
executions in the United States.
NCADP works with more than
one hundred affiliated offices
throughout the U.S. and serves as
a resource and coordination cen
ter for the movement to abolish
the death penalty. Jennifer's re
sponsibilities include sending out
requested materials, organization
the educational materials in the
office, and editing newsletters.

Jenn is a 1996 graduate of
Gettysburg College with degrees

in Political Science and Classics.
She was a member of Eta Sigma Phi
(National Classics Honor Society).
She has been involved in a number
of activities: Among others she vol
unteered at Hanover Hospital, was
part of Vision quest Youth Group
and worked with children in the
Sunday school of her church. She
enjoys drawing, playing the piano,
reading, arts and crafts, cooking and
baking. Jenn is member of Mt. Zion
United Methodist Church in
Upperco, Maryland.
Jenn's new assignment to
National Coalition to Abolish the
Death Penalty followed an orienta
tion in New Windsor, MD where a
group of 15 volunteers came to
gether from all over the U.S. and
Germany. For three weeks they
lived together as a community and
studied such topics as the death pen
alty, conflict resolution, welcoming
diversity and cross-cultural aware
ness. They also spent days work
see ALUM page 4

Common Hour to focus on capital punishment

Alum works to end death penalty

25. Lisa Bartle works with The
Death Penalty Information Center
to provide information and critical
analysis on issues concerning the
death penalty to the media and the
general public. The Death Penalty
Information Center does take a spe
cific stand on capital punishment:
they believe it is wrong. However,
Bartle will present both the pro and
con sides of the argument in her
discussion on Thursday.
Bartle will also focus her talk
on four prominent issues concern
ing the death penalty and society
today. These issues include racial
disparity, the execution of the men
tally retarded, the costs of the death
penalty, and the restrictions on ap
peals of persons given the death
penalty.

The issue of race has been a
major factor in determining the use
of the death penalty in murder

cases. Surprisingly, the biggest
predictor of whether or not the
murderer is sentenced to death
does not have to do with the race
of the murderer. The biggest pre
dictor is the race of the victim.
The Death Penalty Information
Center has found that those who
murdered whites were more likely
to be sentenced to death than those
who murdered blacks. This fact
reveals a whole new aspect under
the controversy of the death pen
alty, that of racism.
The mentally disabled are

another group of people who have
been singled out when discussing
the issues of the death penalty.
Many believe that executions of
the mentally retarded should not
be permitted because these indi
viduals are not always capable of
making morally correct decisions,
and therefore they should not be
as severely punished for their ac
tions. However, others believe
that the mentally retarded should
be responsible if they take some
one else's life and that they are
capable of knowing the difference
between right and wrong.

The issue on the restrictions
of appeals is also a great concern
for many in today's society. Re
cently the court system has been
discussing implementing restric
tions on how many appeals an in
mate on death row may have.
Many believe that such re
strictions will lead to the execu
tion of innocent people. If the
number of appeals are cut, it is
possible that new evidence could
arise on the murderer's favor that
would not be allowed to be heard
in court. The Death Penalty In
formation Center has stated in
their web site that since 1970, 71
people have been released from
death row with evidence of their

innocence. If in 1970 appeals had
been restricted to these death row
inmates, they probably would have
been killed.
The financing of an execu
tion is also a topic of great debate
today. The cost of the execution
of a prisoner is very expensive. For
example, Florida spent an esti
mated $57 million on the death
penalty from 1973-1988 to per
form eighteen executions, which is
an average of $3.2 million dollars
per execution.
Following Bartle's lecture
on the death penalty there will be
a fifteen minute discussion session
where students will be able to ask
questions and voice their opinions.
There will also be a complimen
tary lunch served after the lecture
which will allow students to con-

hie photo

tinue talking about this much
heated debate. Dean Nordvall is
hoping to have local attorneys at
tend the lunch to interact with the
students and to discuss any ques
tions or concerns they may have.
The issue of the death pen
alty is one of great controversy and
debate. Whether or not the court
system should be given the right
to kill someone raises many ques
tions about morality and ethics.
Unfortunately the majority of these
questions can only be answered
with various conflicting responses.
There is currently a group on
campus dedicated to the opposition
of capital punishment - The
Gettysburg Coalition To Abolish
the Death Penalty. Any students
interested in the group can contact
Dean of First-Year Students Bob
Nordvall.

Next Thursday s forum will
provide members of the College
community with an opportunity to
arrive at an informed decision re
garding this controversial topic.

College receives $250,000 challenge

Gettysburg College Press Release
Tom and Joan Norris, York
residents and 1960 graduates of
Gettysburg College, have an
nounced a challenge gift to their
alma matter of up to $250,000.
The amount of the final gift will
depend on fellow alumni match
ing their donation through new or
increased gifts to the College's
Annual Fund.
"The Norris Alumni Chal
lenge" will be in effect during the
College's current fund year, which
began on July 1 and ends on June
30, 1998. The Norris gift will
match dollar for dollar up to
$200,000 all new or increased gifts
by donors who qualify for mem
bership in the College's Cupola
society or Cupola Society Associ
ates.

The Norrises will also con
tribute $50,000 to the College if 40
percent of Gettysburg alumni
make a gift to the College's An
nual Fund by the end of the fund

year. During the most recent fund
year, 36 percent of Gettysburg
alumni made such a gift.
"Colleges such as
Gettysburg rely heavily on annual
gifts from alumni and friends to
help guarantee educational oppor
tunities for present and future stu
dents," the Norrises said. "We
hope our challenge will encourage
annual contributors to give a little
more and non-contributors to start
what will hopefully become an
annual tradition."
Tom Norris is the chairman,
president, and chief executive of
ficer of PH Glatfelter, Co., Spring
Grove, and a former Gettysburg
College trustee. Joan is a home
maker and daughter of R.M.
Wachob, a member of the Class of
1927. Tom and Joan are the par
ents of Cathy, a member of the
Class of 1990. In addition to their
past Gettysburg activities, both
continue in active volunteer work

for the College.
The Norris Challenge will

be announced on Saturday, Sep
tember 20, at the annual Cupola
Society Celebration held on cam
pus. Cupola Society membership
is granted to alumni who contrib
ute $ 1250 or more to the College's
Annual Fund. The recently estab
lished Cupola Associates program
grants Cupola membership to
younger alumni who have contrib
uted $ 100 for each year since their
graduation.
"The Norrises have always
set the example for service to
Gettysburg College in their many
gifts of time, talent, and financial
resources," said Gordon A.
Haaland, president of Gettysburg.
"The Norris Alumni Challenge
will serve as a wonderful catalyst
to boost our alumni participation
and increase the number of lead
ership donors to the Annual Fund."
The Norris gift will be used
by the College for a capital im
provement to be determined after
completion of the current fund
year.

Internet provides new tool for grad school search

Josiah Ulysses Young III, professor of systematic theology at Wesley Theological Seminary since
1993, will present "Dogged Strength Behind the Veil: African American Spirituality as a Literary Tradi
tion" at Gettysburg College at 7 p.m., Thursday, Sept. 25, in the Lyceum of Pennsylvania Hall. His lecture,
sponsored by the College's African American Studies Program, is open to the public and free of charge.
Young holds bachelor's and doctorate degrees from Morehouse University and Union theological
Seminary in New York. From 1988 to 1993, he served at Wesley Theological Seminary as an associate
professor of systematic theology. Previously, he was an assistant professor of philosophy and religion at
Colgate University.
Young is an ordained minister in the United Methodist Church and has served as a pastor and
chaplain in New York. He is also a member of the Society for the Study of Black religion. In 1982 he
participated in a fact-finding visit to South Africa, and in 1989, he returned to South Africa, and in 1989, he
returned to South Africa and Zimbabwe as a participant in Wesley Seminary's globalization Project Im
mersion trip. In 1994, Young taught at African University in Zimbabwe as a visiting professor.
Young is the author of "Black and African Theologies: Siblings or Distant Cousins and African
Theology," "Pan-African Theology: Providence and the Legacies of the Ancestors," and "African Theol
ogy: A Critical Analysis with Annotated Bibliography."

Young to lecture on African American Spirituality

Gettysburg College Piess Release

_Piess Release

Students researching their Graduate School options have a new resource to look to this year.
Gradschools.com (http://www.gradschools.com) is now on-line and fully functional. To add to the excite
ment, Gradschools.com is offering a sweepstakes where one lucky student will win free textbooks for one
semester. Users can enter the sweepstakes on-line.

Gradschools.com has quickly become one of the most popular and

programs. The resource currently consists of more than 24,200 listings and even during the summer recess,
more than 3500 prospective students per week have been visiting the website to research their graduate
education options.
Gradschools.com, an advertiser supported website, is free to users and always contains the most cur
rent information available. While printed directors are generally updated once a year, with long lead times
for publication, Gradschools.com is updated daily with the most current information available, including the
latest e-mail addresses and telephone numbers and links to program pages.
Students can search through directories of grad school programs from around the world by choosing
from more than 200 academic areas. Subjects are then subdivided by geographic region. A keyword search
is also available, making it easy to perform searches for even very specialized topics.
