meaningful perfor
mance.

Chata, the prostitute/aunt,
played by Megan Manthey, was
not nearly as sassy and snappy as
she should have been. As a result,
much of the humor that was writ
ten into this character was lost.
Alec Beekmans and Phil
Anderson, who danced the parts
of the actual roosters, were a ben
eficial addition to the production,
however, their dance was silly and
unrealistic, more the fault of bad

choreography by Paula

Get a Clue

byGlenBeck StaffWriter "It's a matter of life
after death; now that he's
dead, I have have life."
This is only one of the
many hilarious lines from
the 1985 movie based on
the Parker Brothers board
game, Clue. Directed by
Jonathan Lynn, the film
provides joke after joke
and gag after gag, that will
keep you laughing until the
credits.
The gala of stars in
clude Eileen Brennan
(Mrs. Peacock), Tim Curry
(Wadsworth), Madeline
Kahn (Mrs. White), Chris
topher Lloyd (Prof. Plum),
Michael McKean (Mr.
Green), Martin Mull (Col.
Mustard), and Lesley Ann
Warren (Miss Scarlett).

The talented comic
actors maneuver well
through the dialogue. The
quick pacing allows for

rolling laughs. An example of this
comes as Miss Scarlett and Prof.
Plum drive up to the scary Hill
House. "Why is the car stopped?"
asks Miss Scarlett. "It's fright
ened," replied Prof. Plum.
Besides very witty dialogue,
there is also a large amount of
physical humor in the movie.
Something very original
about the film is the three endings
that are included on the video.
Originally, different endings were
shown in different theaters, but on
the video, all three are included.
Wayne's World spoofs the
idea at the end of the film with their
own endings such as the "Scooby
Doo ending" and the "incredibly
happy ending."
Although there are a couple
of plot holes, the movie is a sure
laugh fest. The more times you
watch it, the more you'll pick up.
But you should be warned:
if a friend asks to borrow Clue,
she's probably asking for the
movie, not the board game.

El Nino predicts future weather

byStephBusch GECO Columnist
El Nino, a change in wind
direction which in turn changes the
weather conditions throughout the
entire world, occurs every three to
seven years. It is believed by many
scientists that this year's El Nino
may be one of the strongest ever.
What does this mean
for students here at
Gettysburg? Well, most
likely this year's winter will
be more mild than previous
years, and instead of a great
deal of snow, we will see
rain.

The effects of El Nino
vary for different parts of the
world. When the westward
blowing trade winds
weaken, it allows a mass of
warm water, which is nor
mally located off Australia,
to move eastward to western
South America.
The unusually warm
water acts on the jet stream
patterns which in turn alter

weather worldwide.
Most likely El Nino will
cause droughts in Australia and
Southeast Asia, as well as flood
ing in the Southern portion of the
United States.
Along the mideast and
northeast portions of the United
States, there will most likely be
mild winters and rain instead of
snow. It is difficult to pinpoint the
exact effects of El Nino because

of the many factors that can con
tribute to weather change.
The change in weather will
not only effect our everyday
lives, but will also have an effect
on animals.
For example, along the
coast of California, some marine
species are seen in greater abun
dance because of the warmer

ocean water, which is beneficial
for the fisheries.
However, there are some
species that depend on the sea
son changes and the cooler wa
ter temperatures. These species
may suffer from the mild winter
Fortunately, because El
Nino is a natural occurrence,
many animals are able to adjust
or adapt to the weather changes
without too many natural distur
bances.
Some scientists believe

that El Nino will have a great ef
fect on weather world-wide, while
other scientists acknowledge El
Nino, but feel it is difficult to pre
dict what is exactly going to oc
cur. Many effects have been seen
already throughout the world. In
fact, Indonesia is currently plagued
with severe droughts. These
droughts can effect crop

yield and production,
leading to economic tur
moil and distress.
It is therefore un
derstandable why El
Nino has become such a
controversial and talked
about issue, due to its
effects on not only the
environment but the
economy as well.
The El Nino that
is currently affecting the
world's weather condi
tions is one and a half
times the size of the
United States, and is still

growing.
However, knowing that El
Nino could have a severe effect on
certain areas, it allows govern
ments and individuals to plan far
the weather changes. Having this
information can save millions of
dollars in repairs for certain geo
graphical areas.
G.E.C.O. Meets every
Thursday at 7 p.m. in the base

Dear Casey...

Dear Casey,
A few weekends ago, I
was at a party and ended up
getting pretty drunk. I had
come with a bunch of friends,
but in the morning, I woke up
on the floor of this strange
place instead of in my own
bed. My friends had ditched
me there after I had passed
out. I was lucky that nothing
happened, but I can't believe
that my friends totally ditched
me, leaving me in a potentially
dangerous situation. They

don't seem to think that this
is a big deal, but I feel betrayed
and angry. I think that is only
fair. What do you think?
Thanks,
Upset
Dear Upset,
Well, did your friends force
you to drink or get completely
wasted? Probably not. When you
drink you should realize that YOU
are putting yourself in a potentially
dangerous situation to begin with,
especially if all the friends with you
are getting drunk as well.

Now, the fact that your
friends ditched you is rather disturb
ing. They should have seen what
you are doing, and stuck around to
make sure you got out okay.
It seems that we often depend
upon our friends to take care of us
when we are drinking; we put an
awful lot of responsibility on their
shoulders.
This leads me to surmise that
the problem does not lie solely in
the hands of your friends. I sup pose
that if they were sober they would
not have left you. But, when alco
hol is involved, fears, worries, and
concerns are usually left behind in
an empty bottle.
No, I would not completely
blame your friends, or yourself.
Instead, I would blame the lack of
education on alcohol awareness.
People either do not know, or do not
care. Efforts are being made to in
crease awareness, and I would sug
gest that you get involved and help
to spread the word.

Dear Casey,
I have a problem. One oi
my friends has been skipping
a lot of classes. He seems to
do his work, but he just never
seems to make it to class. I
am beginning to worry, but I
do not want to be his mother
and nag him. I have to do
something, but what?
Thanks,
Worried
Dear Worried,
I think that often people do
not tend to realize how important it
is to go to class. When someone
gets into the habit of not going to
class, it is like the potato chip syn
drome-you know, you can never
have just one. The same pertains to
class attendance, or lack thereof.
After all, is there nothing sweeter
than sleeping in until one or two
o'clock on a weekday? Yes, a high
GPA.

I do understand your fear of
the "mother syndrome," which
seems to be a popular trend in col
lege. This can be good and bad. It
is good because it lets people know
that someone cares, but it is bad
because isn't the reason we came to
college to get away from our moth
ers? The last thing we want is to
be nagged. Something you can do
for your friend is encourage him to
go to class, and whatever you do,
don't enable him.
Be a friend and mention your
concern without being pushy. Just
say, "Look buddy, I am concerned
about you, but in the long run, you
are the only one that is going to be
hurt." And it is true, he is.
However, some people are
stubborn, and he might just not lis
ten to you. If this happens, don't
be offended.

You are right: you can't be his
mother, and you can't ground him,
send him to his room, or more im
portantly, send him to class.

Send questions to Box 434

Conflict and Consensus —
From The Donkey's Mouth
On Being A Democrat

byLibbyMain
Contributing Writer
The other contributors to this
column and the writer of its Re
publican antithesis have chosen to
discuss issues of national political
importance. They have avoided
discussion that is first person in na
ture, but I really wasn't comfort
able scanning the papers for the
newest political scandal or trying
to understand the difference be
tween the latest Republican and
Democratic plans for campaign fi
nance reform. Belonging to a po
litical party isn't just about identi
fying with party leaders or issues
on a national or abstract level. I
feel that it is beneficial to think
about political issues on a more
personal basis and I hope that some
people will be able to identify with

me. I, for example, could not
visit the extremely impoverished

area of Sandtown-Winchester in
Baltimore without developing the
belief that the government needs
to do something about economic
and psychological poverty. Could
you walk through the abandoned
houses filled with garbage that in
cludes dirty needles, filthy play
pens and moth eaten clothing
crawling with bugs and feel that
public housing was adequate? If
you were given a tour of the com
munity center and were able to
meet people who benefitted from
improvements provided by Federal
Empowerment Zone status would
you think they didn't deserve wel
fare? If you knew that there was
a decrease in the high school drop
out rate as a result of a tutoring
program, a decrease in the teen
pregnancy rate as a result of coun
seling efforts, and increased com
munity involvement and civic
pride in the neighborhood as a re
sult of the comprehensiveness of

the services provided could you be
indifferent. Would you want Con
gress to take money away from
them? In addition, would you per
sonally want to witness the execu
tion by lethal injection of a person
who vehemently professed their
innocence through countless ap
peals and interrogations?
What would you do if a
member of your family was in a
devastating car accident which left
them in a vegetative, brain dead
state for more than four months?
If the doctors prognosis was for no
recovery _, your family was grow
ing increasingly upset and drained
from seeing the relative hooked
up to respirators and heart moni
tors day after day, and the finan
cial cost of the care was becoming
unbearable would you still respect
the Supreme Courts ruling against
active voluntary euthanasia?
How would you feel if you

were completely qualified and able
to do a job but you could not be
hired because you are wheelchair
bound and the company's office
building has not conformed to fed
eral accessibility standards leaving
you unable even to enter the build
ing? Would you appreciate the
current right to procure an abor
tion if one of your good friends
from High School was violently
raped? In response to Republicans
who would say that these are
highly emotional examples of the
individual effects political issues,
these cases do exist whether or not
they are in the minority. We must
realize that every government de
cision no matter how minor its
seems has moral, social, economic,
and personal repercussions. In
addition, Republicans would argue
that people should take care of
themselves and one another and

leave the government out of these
issues. However, the government
has a responsibility to protect the
liberties of all citizens and is able
to provide more funding and uni
versal enforcement for implement
ing policies.
A final note-don't be de
pressed or upset about the situa
tions I have described! Act on
them! Go to Sandtown-Winches
ter with the Center for Public Ser
vice, protest the death pena 'lty,
write a living will, make sure the
buildings in your town are handi
capped accessible, or join the Na
tional Organization of Women here
on campus! Democrats tend to
take a more optimistic approach
towards change and political ac
tion than their Republican coun
terparts but I realize you don't have
to be a Democrat to have a social
conscience; you just have more
sympathetic company within your
party if you are.

The Pachyderm's Pulpit
Race and the Republican Party

byJohnDunlap
StaffWriter Not Since before the New
Deal have Republicans been able
to maintain control of the Con
gress for more than one term.
Just by holding on to power on
Capitol Hill, republicans showed
that 1994 was not a fluke, that
there was and is some type of re
alignment occurring on the
American political map. Repub
licans however, hold a tentative
control of the House of Represen
tatives as they did lose seats in
last year's election. Speaker of
the House Gingrich's majority is
very thin, as some moderate Re
publicans got the boot last No
vember.
Republicans controlling
the Congress is no easy thing,
considering the GOP can not even
compete in virtually every minor
ity district in America. African-

Americans vote Democratic in
overwhelming numbers, and while
GOP support grows in many sec
tors, Hispanics who were divided
over President Ronald Reagan in
1984 voted solidly against the Re
publican Nominee for President
last year, former Senate Majority
Leader Bob Dole. While the Re
publican stance on immigration
and affirmative action played well
in GOP constituencies it hurt the
Republican ticket from President
on down when it came to expand
ing the party.
President Clinton's slogans
on issues like affirmative action,
such as "Mend it but do not bend
it," were able to attract white sub
urban voters while holding on to
the Democrats base of minorities.
I am not saying that the Republi
can stance on race related issues
is wrong or that Republicans
should ride the fence like our yo¬

yo President, all I am saying is that
Republicans should go into minor
ity neighborhoods and begin a con
versation.
Republicans from the Civil
War to the New Deal were known
as the party who liberated African
Americans from the shackles of
slavery. Reconstruction created a
new type of slavery and fear of
Democrats kept Blacks voting Re
publican. In 1924, the Democratic
National Convention lasted over
two weeks because Democrats
were fighting over criticisms of the
Klu Klux Klan. No matter what
Republicans did they had voters of
color in their pocket.
President Franklin
Roosevelt changed that and he cre
ated a Democrat majority in
America made up of a great coali
tion of labor unions, southern
whites, the poor, and minorities.
Liberals bravely led the charge for

the Civil Rights movements in the
sixties and by 1968 Republicans
could not even compete for minori
ties. The Reagan Revolution
passed over black communities
despite rising standards of living
among African-Americans. Presi
dent George Bush tried to reach
out but things like Willie Horton
kept him from sounding sincere.
President Clinton, on the
other side of the political aisle has
remained popular among a broad
range of minorities, but not be
cause of things which he has done.
For instance, under his administra
tion affirmative action is dying, he
signed the Republican Welfare re
form Bill, which was bitterly op
posed by minority Democrats in
the Congress, and he has moved
the Democratic party rightward. In
doing all of this, he has run con
trary to the wishes of top Black
Democrats like Reverend Jesse

Jackson, who has not had a warm
relationship with the President.
This gives Republicans an
excellent opportunity to talk to
Black voters about their issues and
concerns. Jack Kemp tried to do
that as Bob Dole's running mate
last year but he received little help.
Republicans must talk about how
affirmative action hurts minorities.
In the business I worked at over the
summer my boss was a young
black woman, at first, I wondered
is she had gotten her position be
cause of race or gender prefer
ences. You know what, I came to
soon discover that she was an in
telligent, highly competent leader
who could get things done. She
earned the respect of everyone
working beneath her, white, black
and Asian. I know I was not alone
see PACHYDERM, pg. 11


Racism Does Exist...

in my thinking, and it cheapened
what she had accomplished be
cause of government programs that
are supposed to help.
Racial quotas pit people
against one another and
demagogue's excuses for why
white people lose jobs. When quo
tas were enacted under the Nixon
Administration by the National
Civil Rights Commission they
were a noble idea but they have
failed, they are in my opinion, un
constitutional and unfair. They
have lost their, under our current
system racial preferences would
benefit Eddie Murphy above a
poor white man in Adams County.
That is not right. Today everyone
fits into a quota except white males
and when you single one group out
like that it only encourages hate
and racism. Reverend Martin
Luther King, Jr. and Vice President
Hubert Humprey did not fight for
quotas, they battled for a color
blind society and that should be our
goal as a nation.

There should exist scholar
ships to help all poor people to re
ceive a decent education and Re

Continued from page 10
publicans must talk about how they
are for school choice and vouch
ers, which help the poor, and in
ner-city children. No child should
be should be stuck in a bad school
and the GOP attempt to give
vouchers to District of Columbia
residents does not help country
club Republicans from suburban
New Jersey, it helps the poor black
child who is afraid to go to school
in urban D.C.
Republican candidates for
office must go into the cities and
talk about how Mayor Guilliani's

way of fighting crime, not the lib
eral way used by his failed prede
cessor David Dinkins has worked.
The Republican way should be
tried all across America. In Wash
ington, Mayor Marion Barry has
hopped onto the Republican band
wagon endorsing voluntary school
prayer and the death penalty. The
old way of government checks
does not work in today's society.
Racism does exist; the Los
Angeles riots and the Simpson
Trial showed that. Resentment and
hate are out there and a true con
servative should stand up for all

individuals, minorities, women,
and homosexuals all included.
Not for preferential treatment but
for equal right. It has only been
thirty years since African-Ameri
cans were given by law their true
equal rights with the Civil Rights
Act and the Voting Rights Act.
Hate and discrimination will al
ways exist, but a true two-party
debate among minorities can
open a lot of minds on all sides.
In 1994, Ellen Sauerbrey
was defeated for Governor of
Maryland by about two-tenths of

one percent. She ignored 25% of
the state, the African-Americans
because she felt there was no way
of winning them over and she
only received 7% of their support.
Mrs. Sauerbrey is campaigning
again for Maryland's top office,
and this time she is talking to
black voters, and while most are
not joining her on her campaign,
they are listening. When you look
around urban Baltimore, Phila
delphia, or Washington then it is
obvious that the old liberal way
of governing America's cities just
does not work.

Consider this

This week Gettysburg
College's sidewalks were covered
with the names of various histori
cal, literary, and pop-culture fig
ures. These names were written in
preparation for National Coming
Out Day this week.
Many questions are raised
by the presence of these names.
Are all of these figures homo- or
bisexual? Or did they only sup
port the right to an alternative
lifestyle?
Should the names of former
first ladies, great authors, and tal
ented artists be labeled in such an
ambiguous manner?
While many of the names
chalked on sidewalks throughout
campus represent openly homo
sexual or bisexual figures, the
sexual orientation of many is only
based upon speculation, conjec
ture, and rumor.
But while the homosexual¬

ity or bisexuahty of these iconic
figures of our past and present may
be questionable, the motivation
behind the chalkings is not.
The objective behind the
sidewalk writings was to show the
campus community that alternative
sexual lifestyles are neither a new
phenomenon nor the life choice of
an isolated minority.
Far too often, homosexuals
and bisexuals are portrayed in our
culture as people who do not fit in
or do not have a place within main¬

stream society.
But as the names chalked on
the walks tiiis week attest, gays,
lesbians, and bisexuals number
among the greatest that human so
ciety has had to offer throughout
the history ofthe world.
Try to imagine American lit
erature without the contributions of
Walt Whitman or Herman
Melville. Or American political
history without Alexander
Hamilton or Elanor Roosevelt. Or
the renaissance without Leonardo
DiVinci.
Together, the people repre
sented by the names chalked
throughout campus form a piece of
human history so substantial that
history is unfathomable and inco
herent without them.
Those who wrote the names
of these figures across the campus
have provided an invaluable ser
vice to the Gettysburg College
community.

The students, faculty, and
administration of the College are
frequently in need cf a wake-up
call. In this seemingly homoge
neous campus, it is far too easy to
assume that homosexuals and bi
sexuals are an insignificant and
negligible part ofthe community.
The names on the sidewalks
make us question our assumptions
and realize that sexual minorities
are a valuable part of our cultural
history and important people in our
own lives.

An Open Letter to the Campus

Thank you to all the volunteers who helped make the
Fiesta a tiemendous success again this year Your lifting
cooking, serving, playing, patrolling and celebrating
contributed to joy for literally thousands of others.
Without your hard work an essential part of our
relationship with the community that surrounds us could
not have taken place. We hope the hard work and its

significance was rewarding for you
Gratefully,
Marcello Ardon & Dan Crowell

by Erin Patterson and Kevin
Howard
Public Relations Chair Panhel and
IFC If you missed any of the ac
tion this past week, here is a recap
of all of the events from Greek
Week, and the winners of each

event. On Saturday, the entire
Greek system pulled together and
participated in the annual Greek
GIV day. There were over 120
men and women present represent
ing the Gettysburg's Greek system
participating in community service
all over town. On Sunday the
Scavenger Hunt made its official
return to Greek Week with a huge
success. There were Greeks all
over campus searching frantically
for objects as random as an Illinois
drivers license to #97 at Pizza
House. For the women, Chi
Omega finished first, Alpha Delta
Pi finished second and Delta
Gamma came in third. As for the
men, Sigma Nu came in first, Al
pha Chi Rho finished second and
Sigma Alpha Epsilon came in
third.

Bed races was the next event
on the agenda and it was as comi
cal as was expected. Some beds
made it, while most others had
some minor flaws, like falling
apart. Theta Chi won this event
easily with in our opinion the best
bed we have ever seen raced, while
Sigma Nu and Fiji came in second
and third respectively. As for the
women, Delta Gamma came in
first with Chi Omega and Alpha
Delta Pie finishing behind them.
On Tuesday, we enjoyed the
rain shortened Greek Carnival
while it lasted. Booths were set up
by most organizations with themes
like: A-D-Pie in your face, a fiesta
theme, dart game, bobbing for
apples, or a goldfish toss. Sigma
Nu and Gamma Phi Beta came
away with most creative booths
and earned extra points.

Wednesday was the Greek
Olympics competition with four
events comprising the days activi
ties. The dizzy bat race led off the
festivities with the usual laughs,
but Alpha Tau Omega wasn't
laughing as they led the way to first
place, while Sigma Alpha Epsilon
and Fiji followed. For the women,

Chi Omega came in first with
Gamma Phi and Delta Gamma fin
ishing behind them. The egg race
followed and created a little mess
in Stine Lake. The object of this
race was to run across Stine Lake
with an egg balanced on a spoon.
Phi Sigma Kappa managed to win
this event with Alpha Tau Omega
and Theta Chi finishing second and
third. Alpha Delta Pi finished first
while Gamma Phi and Delta
Gamma followed.
Following the egg race, the
three-legged race began. Aside
from a few broken ropes, the race
went well. Fiji came in first with

Crow and Phi Psi following. As
for the women, Delta Gamma won
the race with Chi Omega and
Gamma Phi right behind them.
Finally, the grand finale for the day
was the much anticipated tug-of
war. To say that Alpha Tau Omega
was pumped up for this years com
petition is an understatement.
They ran away with the competi
tion and with the rope, literally.
Phi Psi finished second and Crow
finished third. As for the women,
Alpha Delta Pi pulled their way
into first while Gamma Phi and
Delta Gamma finished in second
and third.

Mud Volleyball was another
awesome day in Greek Week.
Aside from random dives in the
quarry, the event was great. For
the men, Crow came in first, Phi
Sigma Kappa finished second, and
Theta Chi finished in third. Alpha
Delta Pie won the women's tour
nament while Chi Omega and
Gamma Phi followed.
In the week's finale, there
was no surprise that Airbands was
as good as all of the hype that sur
rounded it. Some of the acts per
formed by the fraternities included

a remake of Paul Simon's "You
Can Call Me Al," "Thriller," the
Bosstones and a couple of rap
medleys. The women performed
a couple of American acts, Aqua's
"Barbie Girl," The Little
Mermaid's "Under the Sea," the
Brady Bunch theme song, "Men in
Black" and Bon Jovi's "Shot
Through the Heart." To say that
all of the acts were well rehearsed
may not be completely accurate,
but to say that all of the acts were
extremely entertaining would be
very true.

photo by Mark Astrom
The Bed Races of Greek Week proved to be fun for all, though the bed races showed little for
the engineering skills at Gettysburg College.

Fiji s performance of "You
Can Call Me Al" easily won first
place, while Crow's rap medley of
Wyclef Jean's "Stayin Alive" and
The Notorious B.I.G.'s "Mo
Money, Mo Problems" finished in
second. Right behind them was
Sigma Nu's rendition of the
Mighty Mighty Bosstones' "The
Impression That I Get."
As for the women, we think
that it is safe to say that Alpha
Delta Pi is always the team to beat,
this year proved to be no different.
Their sophomore sisters finished in
first while their senior sisters ended

up in third with two different acts
concerning an American theme.
Finishing in second place were the
Chi Omega seniors with a great
rendition of the Brady Bunch
theme, and other classic tunes from
the seventies.
The final standings were as
follows. For the men, finishing in
third was Fiji, while Sigma Nu fin
ished in second. For the women,
Delta Gamma came in third and
Chi Omega finished in second.
This years Greek Week champions
were... Alpha Chi Rho and Alpha
Delta Pie. Congratulations on a job

well done.
To all sorority women, the
deadline for scholar of the month
has been extended to next Monday.
This means there is still time to
nominate your worthy sisters. The
winner will receive a gift certifi
cate to K&K Records. Send your
nominations to Liz Hickock at Box
1087 or give them to your
Panhellenic delegate before the
Panhel meeting next Monday.
This Friday, October 10, is
Breast Cancer Awareness Day.
Don't forget to wear denim in
honor of this occasion.

Math Colloquium 212 Gla
Dr. William Dunham, Truman
Koehler Professor of Mathematics,
Muhienberg College "The
Euclid-Euler Theorem". As his last
number theoretic proposition in the
Elements, Euclid proved that, if is
prime, then is perfect (that is, equal
to the sum of its proper divisors).
Twenty centuries (!) later, Euler
established the partial converse: that
any even perfect number must have
this form. Using original sources, we
shall see how Euclid and Euler joined
forces to provide necessary and
sufficient conditions for this peculiar
type of number. All students and
faculty are invited.

NAVAJO VISIT: TIE WITH STUDENT ORGANIZATIONS. THE CO-CURRICULUM AND ACADEMICS

Dear Campus:
As the Gettysburg College Center for Public Service liaison to the Navajo Nation for service learning, I'm fortunate to
have an exciting opportunity to offer Gettysburg College. Three visiting guests will present on Navajo Culture, and
cross-cultural approaches as they relate to many disciplines. James and Mae Peshlakai and Derek Price (bio below)
will be visiting Gettysburg in November. Mae will be here from Nov. 17 - Nov. 21 and James will split this time between
Gettysburg College and Bucknell. He will be here from Nov. 19-21. Also professor of psychology, Derek Price, from
Wheaton College (MA) will be accompanying James during class visits and campus-wide presentations.
Review the following information for a possible tie with your area and interests - things are still in the preliminary
stages. I am looking for your interest in arranging a class or student organization visit with our guests and a
commitment of nrovidine an audience at events.

1) "How to Think about Culture, and Why It Mattes to Higher Education" (Thursday, Nov. 20,11:30 a.m. CUB
Ballroom). «- -
2) "Cross-Cultural Approaches to Cognitive Development: Contrasts between Navajo and Mainstream American
Culture" (could arrange for noon program on Wednesday, Nov. 19 and/or class visit/s).
3) Class visits in psychology, anthropology, religion, art, theater, economics, wellness are possible based on your
interest (James, Mae, Derek will be available to tailor presentations). I will schedule visits on first-come
first-served basis and ability to coordinate with the overall schedule of their visit.
4) Demonstration in silversmithing & weaving (CUB Lobby, would like to coordinate class visits or other groups to
meet with Mae).
5) Demonstration and instruction in Butterfly, Swan, Buffalo, and Eagle dance (location not yet confirmed, but time
Wednesday, November 19. Could repeat at a class.

61 . Nov. -.
6) Exhibit and goods for sale in CUB, Nov. 17-20.
7) Informal meetings to discuss cross-cultural issues (schedule upon request). Example already scheduled
Sophomore Leadership Series Dinner, Thursday, November 20, 7-8:30 p.m.

Please send me an e-mail of your interest to either participate or arrange a class visit or special program. Be specific
with your request (especially with times). I will be in Utah from' Oct. 8-20 so I will review messages and respond to
questions by Oct. 22. I plan to pull a comprehensive schedule together by Oct. 28. Thanks for your interest.
Lynn White Cloud lwhitecl@gettysburg.edu
Brief Biographical Information on the Speakers:
James Peshlakai is a traditional teacher, artist, and medicine man who also successfully bridges the cultural gap to the
non-Native American world. James was born in the western part of the Navajo reservation. His father, uncles, and
grandfathers were all medicine men and his paternal grandfather was a respected leader of the Western Navajo and
twice spoke with President Theodore Roosevelt on behalf of the Navajo. James has continued this tradition, dedicating
his life to the preservation of Navajo culture. He has spoken on the Navajo Way at institutions across the country, runs
cultural immersion programs for visitors on the Navajo reservation and is currently a Cultural Instructor at Greyhills
High School in Tuba City, AZ, and in the Navajo Community College system. James has also worked with many
Tribal, State, and Federal agencies, and for the past 18 years, James has served as an Officer of the Cameron Chapter
of the Navajo Nation. James has worked to settle boundary and land disputes with the U.S. Forest Service and Grand
Canyon National Park. He organized the Navajo Nation Summer Day Camp; started a food cooperative in Arizona;
was a Caseworker for the Arizona State Welfare program and teacher.
Mae Peshlakai is the co-owner of Peshlakai Consulting Service, lecturer, demonstrator, silversmith, weaver, Indian
Arts and Crafts Creator and. dances.

Derek Price, Ph.D., is Associate Professor of Psychology and Dorothy Reed Williams Professor of social Sciences at
Wheaton College (MA). Derek is a developmental psychologist interested in preschoolers' cognition and cross-cultural
issues in the development of mind. Over the past decade, he has made many trips to the Navajo reservation in Arizona
and New Mexico, first to help him develop courses on culture and child development and more recently to pursue
research opportunities.


Beyond the Bullets
Making the "Moss" of a second chance

BySteveJenJdns
Sports Editor
Phenom. That was the only
word to describe Randy Moss as
a high school athlete. He lettered
eight times, and in his senior year
was named West Virginia's high
school football player of the year
As a junior and senior, he was
named the states' basketball player
of the year. Randy Moss was be
ing recruited by Notre Dame and
many other colleges until an event
that changed his life occured.
Spurned by racial slurs and
other demeaning conduct, Moss
took part in a brawl that saw many
people injured and cost Moss his
shot to play at the "mother of all
football programs" Notre Dame.
Moss was then recruited by
Bobby Bowden and the Seminoles
of Florida State. "He was the most
amazing football player I have
ever seen," said the Seminoles
Bowden. "I gauge everything off
of Deion [Sanders], and this guy
reminds me so much of him."

In 199S, Moss was a red
shirt freshman at FSU. He was not
playing very often, and more
trouble made its way into Moss'
life. After Moss had been hang
ing out with some friends, they de
cided to try some marijuana.
Moss was already on probation
after charges stemming from the
fight at his high school, and when
he was caught for marijuana use,
he was arrested and a hearing was
scheduled.
Randy Moss pleaded guilty
to the charges involving the mari
juana and received 30 days in jail
and a mandatory probation term.
"He suffered a huge disappoint
ment," his lawyer said, "there is
no one to blame but himself. He
knows it. He knows it better than
anybody."

After being kicked off the
Florida State football team, Randy
Moss returned home to West Vir
ginia. He transfered to in-state
Marshall University, and Moss
and Marshall have been like "peas
and carrots" ever since.
The first time that Moss, a
wide receiver, ever caught a pass
for Marshall, he ran 26 yards for
a touchdown. This was only a in¬

kling of what was to come for the
Marshall Thundering Herd and all
of their fans.
In 1996, Randy Moss
caught more regular season touch
down passes than any other fresh
man in NCAA History with 19.
(This was the same number of
touchdowns that Desmond
Howard of Michigan scored when
he was awarded the Heisman Tro
phy.) Moss scored, at least, one
touchdown in every game and
scored a touchdown in the first
quarter of the first nine games of
1996. Moss twice tied the

Marshall single game touchdown
record with four touchdowns
against The Citadel and Montana.
In the first round of the 1996
NCAA playoffs, Moss caught
eight passes for 288 yards versus
the University of Delaware - set
ting a Marshall university, South
ern Conference, and NCAA 1-AA
playoff records for receiving yard
age in a single game. Also against
Delaware, Moss showed that he
was "faster than the speed of light"
as he scored two touchdowns in
less than 70 seconds. Impressive,
to say the least.

At the end of the 1996 sea
son, Moss was named a first team
All-American by all five award
ing organizations: Walter Camp,
Football Gazette, The Sports Net
work, Associated Press, and
American Football Quarterly.
During the 1996 campaign,
he caught 78 passes for 1,709
yards and 28 touchdowns. Moss'
28 touchdown receptions tied the
record for most touchdowns ever
in a single season of NCAA foot
ball. (Some guy named Jerry Rice
had 28 in 1984. Anybody ever
heard of him?)
Here are a few quotes from
some semi-famous organizations
regarding Randy Moss:
"Moss has sport's trump
card: talent. Better, he has the kind
of breath taking athletic gifts seen
once in a generation." -Sports Il
lustrated

"You may never have heard
of Marshall's Randy Moss, but as
the best player in College football,
he will not be a secret for long." -
Los Angeles Times
"The most gifted wide

reciever college football has seen
since Jerry Rice." - Boston Globe.
This season Marshall Uni
versity has moved up to compete
with the big boys in Division 1
football. As a tremendous athlete,
and Marshall's first ever Heisman
trophy candidate, Moss was also
named to a few preseason All
America teams by: Playboy, The
Sporting News, Street and Smith
Football, and Football News. He
was selected by Street and Smith's
as the number one reason to watch
college football, and was rated the
number one reciever in college

football by The Sporting News.
Through only the first few
weeks of this college football sea
son, Randy Moss has already es
tablished himself as a Division 1
player and has put himself in the
running for the most prized award
in Division 1 football: The
Heisman Trophy.
Moss has compiled some
impressive numbers in his sopho
more season. He currently has 38
receptions for 789 yards and 14
touchdowns. No, that is not a ty
pographical error, he hasl4 touch
downs. He has scored 84 points

and is looking to smash all kinds
of records with his 4.2 speed (40
yard dash) and his awesome ath
letic talent.
Randy Moss is an athlete of
a different breed. He has talent,
size, and ability, but one of the
most important things that he has
is luck. Because of a few incidents
Randy Moss almost amounted to
nothing; all that talent was almost
washed away forever. Randy
Moss is receiving a second chance
at Marshall University, and he is
making the most of it.

Rugby Women make debut

ByMattEisenberg
StaffWriter

As the sun rose over the
majestic landscape of the Gettys
burg Battlefields, new faces ap
peared, those of the Gettysburg
College Women's Rugby Club.
The newest edition to the athlet
ics at Gettysburg took on
Susquehanna University.
The game was intense. The
Bullets defense was tough with

help from flanker Kelly Graham,
who later suffered her first concus
sion (congrats Kelly welcome to
rugby). The Bullets remained
tough throughout the first half de
spite two quick trys by
Susquehanna.
The second half the Bullets
settled down and with good con
ditioning started to take advantage
of the S.U. backs. Jeannie
Albrecht, now of legendary status,
ran wild through the S.U.
backfield. She was slowed by her

pony tail twice as the S.U.
women's team could not seem to
find anything else to grab.
Sarah Calhoun shout down
pack play with her aggressive play
and fullback Courtney Young was
fierce on the attack (see photo be
low). The team played well over
all. They are young and new to
this foreign sport. They have the
athleticism to go far with help
from their coach. Captain Deb



Women's soccer keeps streak alive

for the •
latest
scores: j
call j
xPORT j

by Frankie Dauphin
contributing writer
The Bullets soccer team
continued their rampage this past
week with three more victories,
extending their winning streak to
12 games and their overall record
to 12-1. The Lady Bullets now
have the school record of 14 con
secutive wins in their sights. If
they continue at this pace, there
will be no stopping them.
The Bullets opened up Fam
ily Weekend on the road at Ursinus
in another Centennial Conference
match up. The Bullets buried the
Bears, 5-0, to preserve their un
defeated conference record. A
balanced scoring effort was high
lighted by freshman Jill
Piekarski's first career goal.

Also scoring for the Bullets

SPORT SPOTLIGHT
Mr. Gurski's Neighborhood

Kevin Gurski lives life with
a huge smile on his face. The se
nior football player likes to have
fun, and this is evident in all as
pects of his life. All through el
ementary school and the pee-wee
football leagues Kevin begged his
parents to let him play football.
But the answer kept coming back
the same, "No!"
Instead Gurski spent his
younger years playing soccer, a
game which he got pretty good at
and enjoyed playing. In the eighth
grade his parents finally allowed
him to play football and even con
vinced him to go out for the team.
Kevin immediately fell in love
with football.
He played for his junior
high school in Harrisburg during
his eighth and ninth grade years
before graduating onto the high
school. As a sophomore, Kevin
was afraid that he was too small
and too short to play high school
football.

ByCheshaMffler StaffWriter

After much harassing from
the high school coach who had
heard of Gurski's talent, Kevin
made a decision which has af
fected the course of his life since.
Two weeks into the season Gurski
finally hustled out to the football
field for the junior varsity team.
"I was way behind and had
a lot to learn," said Gurski, "but it
was great. I'm really glad that I
did it." Gurski began his career
as a defensive back, and aside
from a brief trial as an offensive
receiver, he has continued to play
in that position.
After being actively re
cruited by Head Coach Barry
Streeter and "falling in love" with
everything about Gettysburg,
Gurski found himself playing
football for the Bullets. "I was
really impressed with Coach
Streeter," explained Kevin, "I have
a lot of respect for the whole
coaching staff. It has been a great
program to be a part of."

As a four year starter at free-safety, Senior Kevin Gurski has been the Bullets main hitman

Gurski has had a very suc
cessful football career at Gettys
burg thus far. Aside from some
time out due to a bout with mono
nucleosis during his freshman
year, Kevin has spent four years
starting for the Bullets. Last year,
as a junior, he was named to the
second team All-Centennial Con
ference, led the team in intercep
tions (five) and had the second
best record for tackles (103).
At the present time Kevin
has made 193 tackles, which he
hopes to improve to 300 tackles
in his career by the end of the sea
son. He is well on his way towards
this, leading the team with 40 tack
les this season.
"I love to compete," said
Kevin, "I get to go one-on-one as
a defensive back and it's great."
Gurski has such a "great time"
playing because he has the right
attitude. It is also really special
for him to be playing with his best
friends.

Since junior high, Kevin
has always found his best friends
to be those that he was playing
football with. "I have the most
respect for the guys I've played
with. It's a lot of fun, especially
with friends," Gurski explained.
"I have really enjoyed playing
with everyone [on the team]," said
Gurski, "I appreciate everyone
playing and having a good time. I
will be really sad to see it all end."
Streeter is very proud of all
that Gurski has accomplished. He
has been a real asset to the Get¬

tysburg football team because of
his leadership qualities, commit
ment, and talent.
"Kevin is a really dedicated
athlete. He's a program kid," said
Streeter, "he does whatever he can
to make it a successful program."
Gurski is really respected by all
of his teammates and coaches for
his dedication and dependability.
"What I like best about Kevin,"
explained Streeter, " is his posi
tive, upbeat attitude. I really en
joy being around him."
Streeter believes that

Off the field Kevin is all smiles, but on the field however, Kevin loves to "bring tf?e lumber"

Gurski's successes have to come
to him because of his work ethic
and positive attitude. "He has the
physical qualities, like good speed
and height, too, but it is his con
stant hard work that makes him the
success that he is," Streeter ex
plains.
Gurski works hard in every
aspect of his life. Kevin spends a
great deal of time, "maybe too
much time," he said, on his school
work. He is always looking to
please himself and his parents.
The management major is
also very involved with his frater¬

nity, Sigma Alpha Epsilon, where
he is the treasurer. Kevin also
works with the Special Olympics
and United Way through SAE. He
hopes to get a job in marketing or
sales after graduation this spring
and would really like to be near a
big city like Washington, DC, Bal
timore, or Philadelphia.
Gurski is a very happy per
son, it is hard to wipe the smile
off of his face, a quality he at
tributes to his mother, Rosemary.
"I really respect both of my par
ents," he said, "My dad taught me
hard work and dedication. My
mom taught me to always turns

bad situations into good. She can
always smile and crack a joke, and
she's a child at heart."
Gurski has gained all of
these excellent qualities from both
of his parents, and he uses them
well. Kevin finds success and hap
piness in his life because he
chooses to look at life in the best
possible light. "I wake up every
morning with a smile on my face,"
he said smiling, of course, "I al
ways try to find the good in any
bad situation-1 just want to have
fun with life!"

Sports Weekly —

Bullets, aimed at Hopkins, miss the mark

ByJoshEyler
Assistant Sports editor
Someone once said that luck
is the meeting of opportunity and
preparation. Well, last Saturday
the Bullets were well prepared to
meet the visiting Blue Jays from
Johns Hopkins, but they seemed to
be missing the opportunities. Per
haps, Lady Luck decided to take a
vacation.
Maybe she just stayed at
home to watch Sports Center. I
don't know. What I do know is that
the Bullets had a very large case
of bad luck. Passes fell short,
passes went long, and, in general,
there were a lot of silly mistakes
that turn the tide on a team that is
playing its heart out.
About luck, guru of football
Chris "Sweet Lou" Lunardi had to
say: "Hey, you win some, you lose
some. I guess somebody didn't
want us to win this one."

The Bullet offense was very
evenly balanced on Saturday, scor
ing six points in the first half and
six in the second. Freshman quar
terback Dennis Flaherty played ex
tremely well in his first collegiate
start. He gained 41 yards on eight
carries and was five for 24 with 50
yards in the passing department.
Sophomore fullback Paul

run. Place kicker Wayne Rumsey
made field goals of 37 and 27
yards, respectively, to keep the
Bullets alive.
Unfortunately, the Blue
Jays' offense was on a roll on Sat
urday. They gained 386 yards on
the ground and scored 17 points
in the first half. However, it is a
tribute to the Bullet defense that
Johns Hopkins only scored a field
goal after halftime. Jason Osborn
was once again named to the Cen
tennial Conference Honor Roll for
a performance in which he made
14 tackles and recovered a fumble.
Behind the mighty Osborn came
the usual tandem of Kevin Gurski,
Chad Mire, and the rest of the Bul
let defense that held tough in the
trenches all day long.

This weekend, the Yellow
Jackets (2-2 in the CC) of
Randolph Macon come to Gettys
burg (1-2 in the CC). About the
upcoming game Derek Reed said,
"They're a good team and we will
have to play up to our capabilities
to beat them." It is only the third
time that the two teams have met
with each team winning on its
home field.
You know what that means.
They're on our turf. Barring a sud
den absence from Lady Luck, Get
tysburg should show Randolph
Macon exactly what a Bullet can
do to a Yellow Jacket.

College sued for
discrimination

pholo by Mark Astrom

by Rebecca Babbitt
Gettysburg College is
being sued by a former profes
sor who was denied tenure.
Kelfala Kallon has filed
a federal discrimination law
suit against the College. The
case is being heard by Judge
Rambo this week at the Fed
eral Court in Harrisburg. An
all white jury will decide the
outcome of the case.
Originally from Sierra
Leon in west Africa, Kallon
was a tenure-track professor
of economics at Gettysburg
from 1987 until the fall semes
ter of 1992 when he was de
nied tenure.
Kallon believes he was
denied tenure because he is
black.

The defence, led by the
college's attorney, Dana
Schadudo, is making a case
that Kallon was denied tenure
because of poor reactions from
students on their end-of-se
mester evaluations—not be
cause of his race.
A number of memos,
emails, and letters has been in
troduced as evidence by the
prosecution. Most of the cur
rent faculty of the economics
department have been called to
testify, including Derrick
Gondwe, Robert Gemmiill,
and Anne Fender.
Fender, Chair of the
Economics department, testi
fied Monday that Kallon
would be a "good addition to
the department and the
school."
In a memo sent by then
Provost, Baird Tipson, he de¬

scribed Kallon s teaching meth
ods as causing "anxiety, insecu
rity and even antagonism" in his
students. Tipson based his re
marks on comments by students
given in their evaluations.
Other memos and letters
stated that Kallon "needs to
soften his image," and the some
students dislike his style."
Despite the reviews made
by students, Kallon was unani
mously recommended for ten
ure by the Economics depart
ment faculty. His tenure fol
lowed the usual path and was
reviewed by the Faculty and
Personnel Committee (FPC).
The FPC also approved Kallon
for tenure. The final stepin ten
ure approval comes from the
President, and Haaland denied
Kallon's tenure.

Charles "Buzz" Myers
was called to the stand Tuesday.
Myers was also up for tenure
review in 1991. Myers filed a
grievance after his tenure was
denied. Shortly after he was
denied a permanent place on the
Religion department faculty,
the publishers of a scholarly
journal, Novmn Testimentum,
agreed to publish one of his ar
ticles. After conferring with
President Gordon Haaland,
Myers withdrew his grievance
and his tenure case was re
viewed by Haaland. Myers was
finally granted tenure in 1992.
Haaland will most likely
testify before the trial is fin
ished. The defense plans to rest
its case on Friday.

99 students killed by Bacchus

byDanLarkin
News Editor ,
This past week, the Gettys
burg College chapter of Bacchus
joined many other organizations
nationwide in observing Alcohol
Awareness Week.
The week's events provided
opportunities for students to hear
presentations, reflect with each
other on the impact of alcohol on
their lives, and promote a commit
ment to responsible drinking.
Bacchus is not a
prohibistionist organization, but
stresses contrloled, responsible
consumption of alcohol.
Perhaps the most visible
sign of Alcohol Awareness week

on the Gettysburg Campus came yes
terday, when Bacchus "killed"
ninety-nine students for "White Face
Day." The White Face Day program
was coordinated by sophomore
Kristen Fisher.
Between 8 am and 6 pm,
about ten students every ten minutes
donned white face paint and black
clothing. These studetnts refrained
from talking to others on campus and
wore signs explaining their "deaths.".
Programs like White Face Day
are put on by SADD and Bacchus
groups across the country to spread
a message about responsible usie of
alcohol.
This was done to symbolize
the death of a person every seven
minutes in alcohol related accidents.

According to Bacchus Pro
gramming Chair Matt Bange, "the
purpose of the white face was to
show what it would be like if these
people really were dead, and not
present on campus."
The "dead" students were
"resurrected" following a candle
light vigil that started in the College
Union Building and continued out
side to Plank Gym.
Aspeach was given on alco
hol awareness, and the "dead" stu
dents returned to the world of the liv
ing. Bange said that the recent al
cohol-related death of a Massachu
setts Institute of Technology student
has increased awareness and dem
onstrated a need for increased aware
ness.

Bange stated that he felt "al
cohol awareness has increased in
the student population [at Gettys
burg]." He said "If any good has
happened, it is because the students
are becoming more aware."
In conjunction with Alcohol
Awareness Week, Jean Kilborne an
internationally recognized spokes
person on the effects of alcohol and
tobacco advertising and a former
advisor to the US Surgeon General,
will speak at the Common Hour
today. Kilbourne's presentation,
titled "Deadly Persuasion," will be
held at 11:30 am in the College
Union Ballroom.

non-member of the school".

Paid advertizement

College offers young alumni chance to participate

from staff reports
The Gettysburg Department
of Annual Giving has created a va
riety of programs to encourage the
participation of Gettysburg's
younger alumni in College events.
At Gettysburg, young
alumni, members of classes gradu
ating within the past decade have
traditionally had the weakest
showing in support of the
College's Annual Fund.
-Two major programs that
the College has created to help in
crease the percentage of younger
alumni in College events after
graduation are the Cupola Society
Associates Program and the Com
mittee for Young Alumni.
The Cupola Society Associ
ates Program was created in 1996
by the Gettysburg College Board
of Trustees "to recognize and pro
mote leadership giving by the
College's most recent graduates."
Previously," membership in
the College's Cupola Society was
offered only to alumni who gave

$1,250 or more to the Annual
Fund each year.
The Associates program
grants Cupola Society Member
ship to graduates of the last ten
year who contribute $ 100 for each
year since their graduation.
According to Cathy Norris
('90), head of the Committee for
Young Alumni, the Cupola Asso
ciates Program "offers recent
graduates the benefit of network
ing with elite members of the
Gettysburg alumni."
Last year's introduction of
the Associates program, brought
more than 50 new members to the
Cupola Society, and 17 percent
increase in Annual Fund support
from that target group.

Gettysburg College Press Release
Dr. Joel M. Reaser, a former

Dream a little dream...

by Melodie Foster
St aff Writer
We all have them, we all
want them, but what do we do with
them? Yes, I'm talking about
dreams, those sometimes pleasant,
sometimes demented, images that
haunt your mind while you sleep.
Studies have shown that every per
son has approximately four
dreams each night, though most
are not remembered in the morn
ing. Why do humans dream?
There are several scientific an
swers to that question which have
developed over the last hundred

years or so, but dreams have been
around much longer than that.
In the very first book of the
Bible, dreams are interpreted as
warnings and hidden messages
from God. In Genesis 40, Joseph
has a dream which tells him to flee
to Egypt, where he is imprisoned.
It is his ability lo interpret dreams
that frees him from prison, and he
discloses the meaning of the
Pharaoh's dream about seven fat
and seven thin cows to be a fore
shadowing of the impending seven
years of feast followed by seven
years of famine, a prophesy which
comes true.

It is also told in Mark 2:13
that Joseph had a dream which
told him to take Mary and the baby
Jesus and (lee to Egypt. It was
through his heeding of the dream,
interpreted as a message from
God, that Jesus survived his child
hood. Charlotte Bronte's famous
book Jane Eyre contains two
scenes in which Jane dreams of an
infant, once a week before she re
ceives news that the aunt who
raised her is dying, and once be
fore she discovers she cannot
marry her true love. The appear
ance of a child in a dream was a
symbol commonly accepted at the
time as a warning against impend
ing doom for oneself or one's kin.
Abraham Lincoln and his
wife, Mary Todd, both experi
enced dreams which foretold his
assassination months ahead of
time. Lincoln, during the open¬

ing weeks of his second term,
dreamt of awakening in the
night and seeing his face in the
mirror reflected once normally
and a second time disfigured, as
though in death. His wife cor
rectly took this as a sign that he
would not finish his second

term. Lincoln also once had a
dream while he was in the
White House. He
wandered ^^ _rf
around the build- _* _^ M
ing, and discov- m
ered it was in\ 3
mourning. He /
entered a certain /
room and saw a / _^^^
casket there. B_^ ^^^
Lincoln then
asked a mourner
standing near him who
had died. The mourner looked
at him and said. "The Presi-

Though the dream
as a warning was, and
still is a popular ex
planation for the im
ages one experiences j_>_a_
during sleep, science has _a|A
come up with a different_^_Mj
answer. In the early half oi_^_B
the twentieth century
Sigmund Freud developed a
philosophy which showed
dream as the manifestations of
the mind.
In sleep, when not held in
check by consciousness, the
mind could wander down roads
it passed during the day, but had
not been permitted to travel.
Thus, he said, the various situ
ations and people in one's
dreams could be traced back to
conversations had, places vis
ited, people discussed in pass
ing during the day.

Freud was also well
known for his theories on
sexual symbolism in dreams
and dreams as outlets for sub
conscious desires.
Modern science has pre
sented the world with an even
more concrete reason .why
people dream. When a person

is sleeping, many of the func
tions performed by their body
and brain are put on a suspended
mode. It has been found that cer
tain neurons in the brain, when
left unused for longperiods of
time, cease to function at all, and
dreams may simply be a sort of
screen saver that allows them to
be suspended 1 but still perform

some sort of function.
Another theory says that
the brain is constantly cycling
through images; in the daytime,
these are found in the form of
thoughts, and we tend to have a
bit of control over them. At
night, however, they are strung
together in the sometimes in
comprehensible form of dreams
due to the fact that we are not
awake to control their direction.
Some think that people are
constantly dreaming. This
would be possible because the
process of dreaming is function
ing in our subconscious mind,
and out of view. They may not
be defined as dreams technically,
but the activity is closely related.
However, during certain
cycles of sleep, we can view
these dreams with our con¬

science mind and record them in our tory, which leads one to question
memory (which is why we sometimes their credibility. , _,
we remember them). , According to one source, the
Confused? Try to imagine this: steps to analyzing your dreams are:

your brain, mind, and spirit, while at
rest, "review" and analyze in their
own way your long-term, short-term,
and spirit memory.
It has in its background the
trends of your life and philosophy ,to
influence, it. Your mind is also pro
cessing spiritual data, your be
liefs, whether or not you have
^^V violated them, your infor
\ mation gained through

psychic intuition
(which we all al
legedly have, to
_^^ a certain de
H| gree), and, of
_^B course, any
_^1 communica
W tion from God.
_^ All of this
data, as well as
your subcon
scious "reading
between the lines"
of what people do
and tell you, is then
processed unsuper
vised by you. All this
data is a form of
chaos, and your mind
puts it all together in a

_*_vr form ol visual screen¬
play: a medley of sight, sound, emo
tion, and imagined interactivity. This
is a dream.
Dreams are easily influenced
by factors in your life and spirit, and
these influences create categories that
are almost infinite. We broadly cat
egorize them in terms like "prophetic,
standard, physical, and nightmare" (to
name a few). And these we study each
on their own, in order to gain benefit
from them.
What do dreams mean? Well,
it all depends on what you believe.
Many people, in spite of the scientific
solution, are convinced that their
dreams are messages from their sub
conscious or from a higher power.
Thousands of books have been
written on the subject, including dic
tionaries of objects found in dreams
and their meanings These .sources
are fun to use, but can be contradic-

1. Identify the main concept
or theme of the dream.
2. Match the concept or
theme to a specific area of your life.
3. Get one _jof those
dictionaires (or one on.the Internet)
and figure out what _everything ba
sically means.
4. Take note of the first thing
that catches your attention.
5. List what everything
means to you.
Even so, dream interpreta
tion has long been a means to'un
derstanding oneself and one's life,
but it requires the memory of a

dream. This can be difficult, as
dreams fade away if they are not
immediately thought about upon
awakening. Many people keep
dream diaries, and find them help
ful not only for dream interpreta
tion, but also interesting in general.
Sophomore Laura Fairbairn
had to keep a journal for two weeks
for a Psychology class, and says,
"it was really interesting. Even
though I thought I didn't dream
very much due to sleep deprivation,
when I would write things down
first thing in the morning, I found
that I did in fact dieam."

Dreams have fascinated
people throughout time, leading to
some beautiful thoughts from some
of the greatest people in history.
"The soul in sleep gives
proof of its divine nature," said
Cicero.
"Why does the eye see a
thing more clearly in dreams than
the imagination when awake?"
asked Leonardo da Vinci.
There are no concrete an
swers to what dreams mean, or
even to the question of why people
dream. The fact that even in this
modern age where science is so
prevalent, many people still follow
such time-honored, firmly estab
lished practices shows that even
with the impact of technology on
our society, histoiical and lcligious
tradition remain strong.



Alpha Lambda Delta welcomes 50 new members

by Josh Eyler
Alpha Lambda Delta Editor
On Saturday, October 4 at
4 p.m., Alpha Lambda Delta, the
national society honoring a
student's academic achievement
in the first year of college, held
its initiation ceremony for new
members in the Luella
Musselman Paul Recital Hall of
Schmucker Memorial Hall.
To qualify for Alpha
Lambda Delta, these students
achieved a GPA of 3.5 or above
on a 4.0 scale. The new initiates
are now part of an organization
that has 217 chapters nationwide,
and in which more than 500,000
students have been initiated.
Alpha Lambda Delta was
founded in 1924 as an honorary
for freshmen women at the Uni¬

versity of Illinois.
The goal of the honor soci
ety are to promote academic ex
cellence and meaningful realiza
tion of the goals of the young men
and women of today.
The three advisors for
Gettysburg's chapter of Alpha
Lambda Delta, Dr. Robert C.
Nordvall, Dean of First Year Stu
dents, Amanda Rupert Strong, Pro
fessor of Religion, and Dr. Carey
Moore, ran the initiation cer
emony, along with outgoing Presi
dent Carrie R. Williams.
The honor society puts on
two events per semester. In the
fall, professors can honor fresh
men who are doing outstanding
work. These students get to have
dessert on the faculty side of the
Dining Hall and are served by

members of the society.
The fall is also when the
new members are inducted.
In the spring, the executive
board serves a dinner for freshmen
was have a GPA of 3.5 or above.
Last year's group did some
thing above and beyond this. They
had a program called "Caught
Studying." Members of the soci
ety would walk through the fresh
men dorms looking for open
doors. If the people in the rooms
were studying, the society would
give them candy.
Fifty members of the class
of 2000 became members of the
honor society.
The 1997 initiates of Alpha
Lambda Delta are Mary-Margaret
A. Ammerman, Ann Marie Bielli,
Sabrina L. Bosse, Christopher T.

Bowman, T. Pemberton Brown,
Matthew B. Brown, Renata F.
Coutinho, Carol A. Dancy,
Courtney B. Davis, Jamie L.
Dawson, Anthony J. DeFail,
Christine M. Doktor, Joshua R.
Eyler, Miranda L. Fegley,
Christyann R. Ferraro, Kristina D.
Fisher, Melodie A. Foster.
Also inducted were Lauren
N. Frankford, Julie C. Friedland,
Timothy W. Funk, Kevin J.
Grimm, Angela L. Hayden,
Samuel H. Herley, Mandi M.
Latronica, Christine E. Laurence,
Cara D. Leone, Amy E.
Lucadamo, Christopher R.
Lunardi, David M. Mahoney, Me
lissa E. Martenis, Holly J.
Massimilla, Rakesh Mathur, Marc
D. McCleary.
Other inductees were

Chesha E. Miller, Linda M.
Moses, Theresa M. Mycek,
Caroline M. Philbert, Mark S.
Pollak, Jennifer L. Reiff, Lori J.
Rhoades, Joanna D. Robertson,
Lavinia M. Rogers, Abigail A.
Scholer, Catherine F. Schott,
Daniel A. Sirpenski, Erica D.
Stocker, John J. Truex, Charles N.
Weber, Kim K. Westermann, and
Jennifer E. Wise.
Officers for the Gettysburg
chapter were also installed on Sat
urday. The new officers are Ann
Marie Bielle, President; Abigial A.
Scholer, Vice-President; Julie C.
Friedland, Secretary; Christopher
R. Lunardi, Treasurer; Sabrina L.

Return to a different Oz

by Glen Beck
Staff Writer Somewhere over the rain
bow there is a sequel to the Wiz
ard ofOz. Actually, it's not over
the rainbow, but at any local video
rental store.
Now I know that that's a
cheesy opener for a review, but I
feel that it is very appropriate for
director Walter Murch's 1985 fol
low-up to the Wizard of Oz, en
titled Return to Oz.
The film starts with Dor
othy back at home in Kansas, not
being able to stop thinking about
Oz. On the farm, she finds a key
which she believes to have been
sent to her by her friends over the
rainbow. Auntie Em, worried for
Dorothy's mental health, takes her
to a doctor famous for working
with electric shock treatment.

In Case You Missed It

Afraid of the therapy, Dor
othy runs away, and she and
Ballina (a farm chicken) mysteri¬

ously find themselves in Oz. There
Dorothy finds the Yellow Brick
Road in pieces and a vacant Em
erald City in ruins. She discovers
that everyone has been trans
formed to stone by the Nome King
and the evil witch, Mombie.
It's now up to Dorothy,
Ballina, and their new friends Tik
Tok, Jack Pumpkinhead, and
Gump to defeat Mombie and the
Nome King, find the missing
Scarecrow, and get Oz back to nor
mal. This journey includes once
again being locked in a room in a
castle and having to choose friends
from a group of decorated boxes.
The film has better special
effects that the original film, but
remember that a lot has changed
in 46 years. In fact, Return to Oz
received an Academy Award nomi
nation for Best Effects (Visual).

As I watched, I just couldn't
get used to the different depictions

of the characters. Fairuza Balk (of
Craft fame) plays Dorothy. Judy
Garland was much older when she
portrayed the lead, so seeing a
younger girl playing the role just
bothered me.
The Scarecrow, the Tinman,
and the Lion are very exaggerated.
Where are Ray Bolger and Bert
Lahr when you want them?
And you're certainly not in
Kansas when you watch this film.
The director incorporates many
more expressionistic elements-

some that even make the film ter
rifying for younger kids (whom
the original film was meant for).
The new characters are all
very entertaining. My favorite is
the naive Jack Pumpkinhead. Ev
ery couple of minutes you'll find
yourself laughing at the this talk
ing pile of sticks with a big jack
o-lantern as a head.
The others, Tik-Tok (a ro
botic man) and Gump (a sofa with
a moosehead on the end), are also
quite amusing.

The screenplay is based on
the next of the books in the Oz se
ries (which is twelve books long)
by L. Frank Baum. These books
focus on Dorothy's many adven
tures in Oz, which are not just a
dream, as the Wizard of Oz im
plies. If you haven't already seen
this sequel, you should rent it. If
you have already, well, let's just
say that I don't think this is a
movie you can watch over and
over.

Side by side

by Cara Masucci
Contributing Writer
We all learned the lesson
when we were young: you have
to share. This is a concept that two
of the new English professors, Fred
Leebron and Kathleen Rhett, have
taken to heart. This husband-and
wife team share almost everything,
from their job to their car. It seems
the only thing they do not share is
their dresser!
This past spring the English
Department was looking to expand
its writing program. A position
opened up that called for one pro
fessor to teach both the fiction and
non-fiction writing courses. To
gether, Professor Leebron and Pro
fessor Rhett applied for the same
position.
Their idea was to split up the
position between themselves in re
gards to their disciplines. Leebron,
the fiction lover, would teach the
fiction courses while Rhett, an avid
non-fiction fan, would handle the
courses in that domain. But this is

not the first time the two profes
sors have decided to work together.
It's an almost story-like
meeting. Twelve years ago on the
first day of orientation at John's
Hopkins Graduate School, Rhett
and Leebron met. They have been
together ever since.
Rhett had already done her
undergraduate work at John's
Hopkins, and decided that after
working with two very well-known
writers, Stanley Fish and David St.
John, that she wanted to continue
her education there. Speaking
about St. John, she said that he was
"a teacher [who] made the differ
ence." Writing and teaching were
things that she had always known
she had wanted to do.

Two English professors mix personal and professional

Leebron,
on the other
hand, was con
vinced he would
have to go to
law school. Af
ter studying in
the Woodrow
Wilson School
at Princeton, he
decided to pur
sue a creative
writing career at
John's Hopkins.
Creative

writing had al
ways been
Leebron's "first
passion," but he
had always
thought it would
be something he
would do on the
side of law, or
medicine.
When the op
portunity came
along to go to
John's Hopkins,
he took it.

After re
ceiving their
Masters at
John's Hopkins,
they each re-

C _d _J_% _^ 4 ¦¦¦ _!------¦— _—
¦¦¦¦¦¦¦¦¦ ¦ -
ceived fellow- I ___________
Photo by Emily Glattel
ships there, as Professors Leebron and Rhett relax at home after a busy day
well as at many of teaching.

other places around the world.
These have allowed them to
travel to places like Thailand,
France, Mexico, Guatemala, not
to mention a half-dozen cities
within the United States. This
has been a great experience for
them, and has allowed them to
become quickly acclimated to

Gettysburg.
When asked what they
thought about Gettysburg, the two
professors were very enthusiastic.
Having each grown up in eastern
Pennsylvania, they like the prox
imity to their relatives, particularly
since they have two small children.
They insist that all their free time

goes to Kate
and Jacob.
They have gone
to the Apple
Festival and
toured the
battlefields with
their two chil
dren. They
both insist that
the Gettysburg
community is
"friendly, cre
ative, and ener
getic." In fact,
one of the major
reasons they de
cided to apply
here was their
respect for The
Gettysburg Re
view. Leebron
continued,
"There is a
good feeling of
dynamism in
Gettysburg."

The stu
dents interest
them, and the
faculty at the
college has
been great. The
only things they
would change
are the lack of
Thai food and

the lack of squash courts in the
area, two of their passions. Other
than that, they are entirely thrilled
with Gettysburg.
The conversation quickly
turned to their courses, and what
their positions entail. When asked
what it is like to share the same
position, they both laughed. "We

disagree," they both blurted.
However, it is a nice balance and
they make each other a better
writer and teacher. It is also a
good idea for them to teach under
different disciplines.
This semester Leebron is
teaching Introduction to Fiction
Writing and English Composition.
Rhett is handling the non_^fiction
domain with Forms of Creative
Non-Fiction. Next semester Rhett
will be teaching two non-fiction
courses while Leebron will teach
one fiction.
This led to the discussion of
what each of them has done in
their discipline so far. Leebron has
edited Post-Modern American
Fiction: ANorton Anthology, and
has written Creative Fiction: A
Writer's Companion, as well as
Out West.
Rhett has written Survival
Stories (Memory of a Crisis), and
Near Breathing (A Memoir of a
Difficult Birth).

In the upcoming months,
they hope to complete a couple
projects they are working on, as
well as spending more time with
their children. One of them is al
ways with the children; Kate, the
older of the two, has just become
obsessed with Grease.
Other than that, they share
responsibilities around the house,
the same car, but not the same
dresser. They have to set limits
somewhere.
The English Department set
out to find someone with energy
to develop the writing program at
the college. What it ended up with
it two unique, but parallel, profes
sors who will certainly bring an
added boost to thedepartment.


Alum to swing in Ballroom Friday night

From Staff Reports
Christopher Jentsch, a 1983
graduate of Gettysburg College,
will perform at the College's Jazz
Ensemble Homecoming Concert
on Friday, October 24, at 9 p.m.,
in the College Union Ballroom.
The concert is open to the public
and free of charge.
The Gettysburg College Jazz
Ensemble (GCJE) performance
will include swing standards and
classic ballads of Duke Ellington

and Count Basie, Latin-flavored
arrangements, and contemporary
fusion, as well as original com
position by Jentsch.
Jentsch is currently a per
forming and recording artist
working primarily in jazz and
contemporary improvisational
forms. After graduating from
Gettysburg College, he com
pleted a Master's degree in jazz
studies and contemporary media
at the Eastman School of Music.

He has composed jazz and
concert pieces, writing for cham
ber groups, big bands, and percus
sion and acoustic/electric en
sembles.
The GCJE is directed by
John "Buzz" Jones, Associate Pro
fessor of Music and director of
bands at Gettysburg College, as
well as the leader of the Buzz Jones
Big Band.
Jones is a composer himself.
His latest work, "Cymru: Hen

Wlad Fy Nhadau" (which means
"Wales: Land of My Fathers"),
premiered here at Gettysburg in
April. In addition to their 1997 Big
Band European Tour, the GCJE
also performed at intercollegiate
jazz festivals throughout Virginia,
Maryland, and Pennsylvania, as
well as for the Central Pennsylva
nia Friends of Jazz. Their new al
bum will be released on October
24.

out normally enough. The clash
between small town and big shot
drives a talented, religious, young

Lomax, played by Keanu Reeves
(Point Break, Bill and Ted's Ex
cellent Adventure ), is | fl|
guided by invisible forces
from the closeness of his
Florida home town to the
man-eating streets of New
York City.
As one might guess
from the title of this
movie, the complications
Kevin encounters in "The
Big Apple" are a bit more J
potent than the usual fruit- _^
less quest for a parking _M
space. In fact, as audi- _^B
ences might predict, they're down
right evil.

The Devil s Advocate is re
ally the story of a lawyer who,
though unknowingly, literally
makes a deal with the devil.
Though Lomax's initial success
may be refreshing, audiences will
most likely have a strange feeling
that things are going a little too
well for him.

and eventual fall can be identified
in the character of Milton, played
by Al Pacino (Donnie Brasco,

Though Reeves seemed bet
ter in this than many other previ

Curtain Call
Roosters rebuttal

by Glen Beck
Staff Writer-
As both O&N President and
a person who enjoys theater, I felt
that I must comment on the Roost
ers review of two weeks ago.
I do not wish to put down
Ms. Greely because several of the
points she made were valid. I do,
however, have several problems
with her method of stating her be
liefs. She gives no reasoning be
hind her statements. For example,
Ms. Greely said that two of the
actors had no stage presence.
Fine, but what specifically about
their performances made her feel
this way? Similarly, why did she

feel the choreography of the hu
man roosters looked silly?
I would also like to com
ment on the statement that this was
the best play performed in Kline
but the worst performance of a
play. Apparently, Ms. Greely did
some research to know that
Abuelo was an added feature by
the director. However, the re
viewer should have dug farther. If
she had, she might have found out
more about the director's interpre
tation. Dr. _Mwschamp was in fre
quent contact with the author,
Milcha Sanchez-Scott, discussing
the addition of the grandfather,
which was actually meant to be a
distraction.

Likewise, Dr. Muschamp
spoke with Ms. Scott about the
Shadows, who were meant to be

seen as a stage presence.
Further, the reviewer should
have researched the concept of
"magic realism." At times, con
ventions such as poses, tableaus,
and _^deliberate movement' were
used to relay character relation
ships and intentions.

one-act plays and casts were an
