-Focus

by Rebecca Babbitt
Editor- in - Chief



Dear Casey..

Dear Casey,
I am having a problem. I
have a roommate I really like,
but I don't care for her boy
friend. It seems he's always in
the room; he's practically
moved in. The room is small for
two people as it is, and to make
matters worse, his friends are al
ways over as well and calling for
him at all hours of the night. I
am really getting annoyed at this
situation. What should I do?
Lost in the Room
Dear Lost in the Room,
This seems to go back to the
old adage: two is company and
three is a crowd, and your room is
seeming to get awful crowded
right now.
Let me emphasize again,
YOUR room. The room is tech
nically half yours, and you have
every right to defend your prop
erty.

One question I have for you
is, does your roommate realize
how annoyed you are getting at
this situation? If she does not, I
think you need to give her a few
quick slaps of reality, or you could
always take her to Wal-Mart and
buy her a clue.
Seriously, you should try to
explain to her how you feel that
your personal space is being vio
lated and that you would like to see
this situation changed.
Suggest that she go and visit
his domicile for a while. Ask if it
is really necessary that he lives
with you two in your ever-so-spa
cious living arrangements.

Howard in Gettysburg by Myles Price

Talk it out with your room
mate. If you have been passively
sitting by twiddling your thumbs,
this might have contributed to this
progressive problem.
As for the boyfriend's
friends, inform them that Mr. Joe
Wonderful does not live in this
room and do not try and reach him
there. You are going to have to
stand up for yourself in a situation
like this.
If all else fails, then it is time
for a demonstration of your an
noyance. Show them how obnox
ious they are. One method I have
found to be almost faultless is
playing Christmas music in Octo
ber at a high volume, while sing
ing along with the wrong words
or a Spanish version.
That may not be your style.
If that's the case, then invite your
friends over and throw a little
party, just as the two lovebirds are
about to go to sleep.

These examples might seem
extreme, but the point is that you
need to have your voice heard and
have your roommate not only re
alize your annoyance but under
stand it.
Dear Casey,
I went home for, Reading
Days, and I was able to see some
old friends. I had gone out of
state for college, and they have
stayed home. It seems that there
is a lot of distance between us
and that they are not the same
people as they were before. I am
upset about this space between
us. Do you have any advice?

Drifted Dear Drifted,
First, you need to realize
that the only thing that is perma
nent in life is change and that
change is truly inevitable. This
being said, change is sometimes
hard to deal with.
Another thing is that you
have probably changed as well,
not just your friends. You should
take that into consideration before
you are so quick to judge your
friends for changing.
There is an old saying: ab¬

sence makes the heart grow
fonder. Unfortunately, that is not
always the case, especially when
one goes away to college.
College is a time for chang
ing and growing, and you can not
let yourself get wrapped up in
what could have been, or what
should have been, and what is not.
Even though you and your
friends have grown apart, that does
not still mean you cannot be
friends. As they say, make new
friends and keep the old, one is
silver and the other, gold.

And be sure to remember
that friendship is a two-way road.
You can not expect your friends
to just sit back and watch you
grow and change while waiting
around for you to come home on
your vacations.
This advice is a bitter pill to
swallow, but it is the truth, and
more often than not, the truth
hurts. Any questions ? Send to Box
434.

Conflict and Consensus

To the Editor

First of all, I would like to
thank and commend Musselman
Hall residents for their diligent and
stupendous efforts during the re
cent fire caused by the careless
burning of candles. Too often we
tend to focus on the negative as
pects of an incident such as this,
and we forget to say thank you to
those who truly deserve it. The
residents of Musselman Hall were
incredible in helping one another
out during this crisis. In addition,
a big THANK YOU goes to the
officers and dispatchers working in

the Safety and Security office.
Their quick thinking and fast work
saved us all from potential disas
ter. Unfortunately sometimes,
when incidents like this occur,
there are often many inaccurate
rumors which somehow get spread
across campus. One such rumor
that has surfaced relates to "ran
dom" room searches. I would like
to put this in perspective, and to
acknowledge any responsibility I
or any other staff member had for
this misinformation. Contrary to

To the Editor:
This letter is in response to
last week's cover article titled,
"Party On." I must first commend
the author for accurately report
ing the story and giving Sigma
Alpha Epsilon its due credit for
handling the touchy situation. We
had a situation in which a student
from another college caused a dis
ruption in a crowded house. As
to not let the commotion spread
further, we promptly escorted the
individual out of our house. We
handled the incident impeccably
and kept the crowd's evacuation

calm and collective.
I must then delve deeper
and berate the editor for placing
this inconsequential story on the
cover of the Gettysburgian. One
would hope that there would be
much more important and press
ing issues to bless the cover of this
paper. Our fraternity, SAE, has
been working frivolously to eradi
cate the marred reputation that our
fraternity has endured. We have
been taking a more responsible
approach to social events and have
successfully had numerous parties
that have not had one bottle, can,

the recent letter to the editor, Secu
rity does not "randomly" search resi
dence hall rooms. Students, as ten
ants, are entitled to reasonable pri
vacy in College residence hall
rooms. However, the College does
make periodic inspections of and
maintenance visits to all college resi
dence hall rooms for reasons of
health, safety or possible policy vio
lations. Typically student staff mem
bers of Residence Life are respon
sible for dealing with related policy
violations. When possible, the stu
dent is present during this type of in
spection.
A search, as distinguished
from an inspection, involves a thor
ough examination of the residence
and personal possessions in relation
to a specific violation. A search is
undertaken only with the authoriza
tion of the Dean of the College, and
would never "randomly" occur.
I hope that this has helped to
clear the confusion.
Sincerely,

Christina N. Bell
Residence Coordinator
Musselman Hall

or cup of alcohol. This is a success
ful advance in social events on this
campus and I believe we should be
recognized for this rather than events
that really have no significance. We
are conscious of our reputation on
campus and are working to change
the erroneous, but prominent, opin
ion of our fraternity. The Sigma Al
pha Epsilon of today is not the devi
ant SAE of years past. We are a
strong brotherhood trying to gain
positive notoriety.
Even though the story was ac
curately reported and relieved of all

responsibility, the mere placement of
the article on the cover of the Get
tysburgian, nonetheless damages our
image. My purpose of writing this
letter is to make the campus com
munity aware of the Sigma Alpha
Epsilon of today. We are a frater
nity trying to establish a positive and
cooperative image that will vanquish
past prejudices toward SAE. The in
cident that took place a couple of
weekends ago was an unforeseen oc
currence that was handled in a fault
less manner, but this story should not
be a cover article.
Derek Reed
Brother, Sigma Alpha Epsilon

Consider this ...

Each semester at the end of
each course, every student is
given the opportunity to evaluate
the course, the teacher, and the
course materials. This exercise
gives each student the unique op
portunity to give unvarnished
opinions and possibly effect some
significant change.
Unfortunately, more often
than not, students either use these
evaluations as revenge against the
professor, or they do not bother
to put any time or effort into them.
Moreover, professors them
selves are often guilty of giving
evaluations, which can improve
their craft as teachers and their
courses, short shrift by handing
them out before the final exam or
waiting until the last ten minutes
of the last class.
Furthermore, there seems to
be a general apathy about the va
lidity and usefulness of these
evaluations both by students and
faculty.

However, Kallon v. Gettys
burg College, which is using these
evaluations as evidence, proves
that evaluations do have useful
ness outside of filling time on the
last day of class.
Yet, although this recent
case is proving that evaluations
can be useful to some end, there
is still the issue of getting the
evaluations to work for the good

of the college community.
How can the college com
munity as a whole reevaluate how
we use course evaluations to im
prove the quality of education here
at Gettysburg College?
For starters, the faculty and
administration of the college
should change how the evaluations
are used.
For one, the evaluations
should be handed out earlier than
the last class, and sufficient time
needs to be given to fill them out.
Further, each department
should revise their respective
evaluations keeping in mind cre
ating questions which give ad
equate opportunities to offer sub
stantive constructive criticisms.
Finally, the professors need
to sit down and consciously read
these evaluations not as assaults
but rather tools which can make
them better teachers.

As for all the students out
there, take the time to give some
meaningful commentary on your
courses and your professors.
So often students are left out
of the decision making process
when it comes to forming the sub
stance of their education, evalua
tions give you the opportunity to
make a change.
Gettysburg College is your
school, don't waste your opportu
nity to change it.

Voice IS an
INSTRUMENT

To the leaders of the new a
cappella group, Doug Walsh and
Jenny Bland... first of all congrats
on your endeavors to form a new
singing group on campus. Hav
ing just read the feature article
about you and your group, I find it
to be most exciting and long time
in coming. However, I found the
headline "Instruments? We don't
need no stinkin' instruments!"
quite offensive and in bad taste.
Don't forget, voice IS an instru
ment and your audience will be
comprised of, hopefully, hundreds
of music enthusiasts who love and
play instruments. The lack of his
torical research by yourselves, the
author of the article and senior,
Jonathon Black about singing
groups on this campus from early
days is disappointing. If you had
gone to the college archives, you
would have been pleased to dis
cover any number of such "a

cappella" groups in the past, and
used for the same purpose as in the
contemporary sense. The Gettys
burg College Choir has its roots in
a cappella singing, but choral lit
erature incorporating instruments
today has broadened and enhanced
that picture for us. As its director,
my first love is performing and lis
tening to a capella music. I was
blessed to have heard the current
famous five from Holland named
the Quinks last Monday night at
Mount Saint Mary's. They were
stupendous. Maybe you were
there? Should your group ever
reach that status, Gettysburg Col
lege will be on the musical map,
in spite of the Music Department.
There is an abundance of raw mu
sical talent on this campus... you
have the potential of success at
your finger... pardon me, vocal
tips! I can hardly wait to be "ser
enaded by (the) new a cappella
group"! Good luck!
Kermit Finstad, Associate
Professor Music
Conductor of the Gettysburg
College Choir

our reporters. Editors should be advised by letter if errors occur.

quest-only basis.

Conflict and Consensus —
From The Pachyderm's Pulpit

Al Gore is no angel

On a sunny July day in 1992
outside the Arkansas Governor's
Mansion, a marriage made in me
dia heaven was made as Governor
Bill Clinton tapped Tennessee
Senator Al Gore to be his running
mate. Clinton and Gore at first
seemed to be very much alike.
Both were southern "New" Demo
crats, reasonably moderate, and
young. The picture that the Demo
crats wanted to portray was youth,
moderation, and a new generation
ready to take command. More
than any of that the Clinton team
put Al Gore on the Democratic
ticket because Senator Gore helped
erase Governor Clinton's nega
tives. While Bill Clinton dodged
the draft, Al Gore served in Viet
nam. Governor Clinton had his
share of sex scandals and Senator
Gore by all accounts had a very
strong marriage. As governor
Clinton's record on the environ¬

ment was very shady, and Al Gore
was loved by the environmental
ists, which has always been his pri
mary issue as shown by his book,
Earth in the Balance.
In 1992, the Clinton-Gore
campaign with their bus caravans
were instantly loved by the liberal
media. A new day had arrived, but
when the two landed in Washing¬

ton after dislodging President
George Bush and Vice President
Dan Quayle, Americans realized
that their new 43% president was
not exactly what they had ex
pected. He had caved in to the left,
lacked the leadership needed for
the Oval Office, and had a staff that
was not prepared for the Presi
dency. In 1994, the American
people punished President Clinton
and put Republicans in control of
Congress for the first time in forty

years. During the time while Bill
and first lady Hillary Clinton
(sorry, I mean Rodham-Clinton)
were being bashed over taxes,
healthcare, and scandals, "Honest"
Al Gore remained popular. The
president and vice president by all
accounts are very close. Vice
President Gore is one of the
president's closest advisors. It was
Al Gore who led the Reinventing
Government plan and it was the
vice president who has always
been there to deflect presidential
criticism. By 1996, there was no
question that Al Gore would once
again be on the Democratic ticket
and at the Chicago Convention he
was able to speak on his own night.
The talk was that the president was
going to work to help the vice
president receive the Democratic

Nomination for president uncon
tested in 2000.
Now the tables have turned
on the vice president, as he now
need the President Clinton's scan
dal cronies, who have been
through perhaps the most presiden
tial scandals in American Presiden
tial history. The latest scandal has
to deal with the selling of the presi
dency to domestic and foreign in
terests. The vice president is ac
cused of making calls for cam
paign cash on federal property
which is against the law.
The other offense being lev
eled at our good vice president is
his appearance at a Buddhist
temple for a fundraiser, an outright
violation of federal campaign laws
created after Watergate. For all the
bashing the Democrats give to the
Christian Coalition over cam¬

paigning in churches, Vice Presi
dent Gore is showing his true col
ors as a liberal hypocrite. While
claiming not to be aware of the fact
that it was a fundraiser where ille
gal foreign money was given, the
Vice President's schedule calls it a
fundraising event. The American
people are not stupid and now that
Attorney General "Stonewall"
Janet Reno has opened up an in
vestigation of Mr. Gore, perhaps
we can get to the truth over pos¬

sible espionage in the 1996 Presi
dential campaign.
The vice president earlier
this year looked foolish while an
swering questions over illegal acts
he may have committed last year.
In China, he was upstaged by
House Speaker Newt Gingrich
who had the courage to criticize
the Chinese over human rights
abuses, while Al Gore toasted the
butchers of Beijing. Just maybe
this was because they helped re
elect him and President Clinton
over a true American war hero,
Boh Dole.

Al Gore is getting his first
taste of negative press and he is
showing that he is not as savvy as
his ultimate politician partner, Bill
Clinton. While Al Gore slammed
big tobacco's support for the Re
publican Party, the Gore family
owns and operates tobacco farms.
If you listen to the Democratic
National Convention in 1992, Al
Gore was a working boy from ru
ral Tennessee. The truth is, Al
Gore was born, raised, and edu
cated in Washington, D.C. His fa
ther was a United States senator,
and since 1977 Al Gore has
worked in the Capitol.

The media blasted Mr.
Gore's predecessor, Dan Quayle,
over stupid things; they refuse to

do the same to Al Gore. When Al
Gore, in front of the cameras at
Montecello, asked who was the
painting of that he was looking at,
the response was George Washing
ton. Imagine if Dan Quayle had
done that. Furthermore, unlike Al
Gore who changed his position on
abortion to cater to the left, Dan
Quayle always stood up for what
he believed despite what liberals
yelled.
If Al Gore thinks the presi
dency is his in 2000, than there are
a few Democrats like House Mi
nority Leader Dick Gephardt,
former United States Senator Bill
Bradley, United States Senator
Bob Kerry, and Reverend Jesse
Jackson may have something to
say about that. They all have been
mistreated by the Clinton-Gore
team at one time or another and
now that Bill Clinton is finished
electorally, then Vice President
Gore will likely be their target.

If the vice president makes
it through the scandals and wins
his party's nod in 2000, then he will
have to face his biggest obstacle, a
Republican Party hungry to regain
the White House. The GOP has
not forgotten that it was President
Clinton's loyal sidekick Al Gore
who broke the tie in the Senate that
gave the largest tax increase in
American history.

Conflict and Consensus —
From The Donkey's Mouth
Campaign finance, a serious issue

By Matt Brown
Contributing Writer
Has anyone noticed how
undemocratic our nation has be
come? Today, our nation's Repub
lican led Congress continues to
blatantly ignore the interests and
desires of the American people.
America wants and needs cam
paign finance reform. America
wants to see money lose influence
and issues gain influence in elec
tions. We want leaders who rep
resent us, not leaders who repre
sent a few political action commit
tees (PAC_'s) and privileged and
wealthy businessmen, doctors and
lawyers who contribute large sums
of money to their campaigns. The
majority of Americans want our
government to put an end to the
pervasive influence of money in
politics. Of course, it is a fantasy
to think that their will be a time
that money will be completely
eliminated from politics, but we

must be able to improve our sys
tem over the current one. Today
our system of campaign finance is
being abused by both the Demo
cratic and Republican parties as
they receive money from foreign
contributors. Today it has become
obvious that money does buy ac
cess to the _president. America
wants reform and Congress has yet
to deliver.
Isn't it funny that while Re
publicans attack and criticize our
current campaign finance system
in the investigation of the fund rais
ing practices of the Clinton/Gore
campaign, that these same Repub
licans are the ones blocking reform
on these very same issues in the
Senate. These hypocrites obvi
ously do not care about campaign
finance reform, all they care about
is furthering their own political
agenda by trying to drag out the
president's unethical fund raising
Dractices to weaken him. The Re¬

publicans continue to preach about
how corrupt the system was, yet
most of them continue to do noth
ing about it. Meanwhile, President
Clinton and Vice-President Gore,
the "guilty"-parties continue to
push for reform. Why do the Re
publicans practice this kind of hy
pocrisy? Because they don't want
to bite the hands that feed them.
The Republicans who consistently
raise more money than Democrats
don't want to damage the system
that has traditionally benefitted
them. In their greed, they continue
to block reform. Republicans are
guilty of the kind of things the
president has done too, it just so
happens that Chairman Fred Th
ompson continues to abuse com
mittee rules surprising the Demo
crats on the committee, led by
Senator John Glenn with subpoe
nas and preventing the Democrats
from issuing the subpoenas they
want. The Republicans gloss over

the fact that they received money
from Hong Kong and are seeking
to cover up the outbreak of a Japa
nese money scandal. The party
leading the charge in the investi
gation is also a coconspirator in
the abuse of the system. Their op
position is based on the opinion
that if you limit the amount of
money a person can contribute you
limit their right to free speech.
Well, if speech is equivalent to
money, then a small and privileged
few are able to talk a whole lot
louder and longer than the major
ity of us nearly mute Americans.
Not all Senate Republicans
are guilty of hypocrisy. In fact,
Republican Senator John McCain
of Arizona has written a bill that
would reform our system. How
ever only a handful of brave Re
publicans and the Democrats in the
Senate support it, not enough to
muster the 60 votes that they would
need to break Senate Majority
Leader Trent Lott's filibuster. Lott

has vowed that campaign finance
reform will not come from this
session of Congress. So what can
we do now, when the Republican
leadership has vowed to never re
lent in its opposition to campaign
finance reform? Well we could all
call ourcongresspersons and sena
tors and let them know that
America demands campaign fi
nance reform. Or next year we
could make history. We could
make history by electing a Demo
cratic controlled House, the first
time ever that the president's party
would gain seats during midterm
elections. That event along with
getting enough Senators Democrat
or Republican that support reform
would finally bring about the
change that we want and need.
Everyone can see that the systems
broken, but we do not have the
leadership in Congress to fix it.
America needs a new Congress, a
Democratic congress to bring
about real change.

To the Editor: Student blasts Burgian

To the editors of The Gettys
burgian,
My name is James
McCusker and I am a second se
mester senior at Gettysburg Col
lege. I was readmitted at the start
of this semester, after being away
from the college for three years,
and in the time that I have been
away I am shocked and saddened
by the deterioration of the Gettys
burg College school newspaper,
The Gettysburgian. I will use the
most recent October 9 issue as an
example. In the Oct 9 issue the
mistakes, omissions and quality of
the articles was pathetic. The back
page sports article reported on the
football team's loss to Johns
Hopkins but never even reported a
final score!!! Instead the reporter
seemed too interested in being the
Chris Berman of print as he tries
to annoyingly give every Bullet

player a nickname. I can under
stand some omissions but lack of
a final score is unforgivable. On
page 17 there was a small article
reporting on the debut of the
women's rugby team, once again
not only was there no final score
reported, but the article was cut off
mid-sentence!!! Then on page 12
there was the article on Greek
Week. Again, the article was un
clear as to which fraternity/soror
ity were the overall winners. The
article listed winners of the indi
vidual events but no overall win
ner. The closest it came was to stat
ing "The final standings were as
follows. For the men, finishing in
third was Fiji, while Sigma Nu fin
ished in second." First, the sen
tence does not clear up whether the
winners mentioned were in regard
to the airbands or for all of Greek
Week and second, it lists the third

and second place fraternities but no
first place winner is listed!!!
At the same time The Get
tysburgian reviews a movie "Clue"
which came out 12 years ago!!!
Hello!!!! The freshman were 6
years old when this movie was on
the big screen!!! It was panned
then as it should have been for be
ing a truly bad movie. Why are
we concerning ourselves with it
now? Meanwhile the school and
the newspaper are concerning
themselves with the same old tired
issue of drinking that they have for
the last 15 years. This is not to
say that drinking is a non-issue, but
there is nothing new about the re
porting or the problem and every
one acts like students drinking is a
new phenomena and problem at
Gettysburg and it is not. The col
lege restricts fraternity parties,
clamps down on drinking in

dorms, provides no school sup
ported or regulated social gather
ings where alcohol is served and
then has the nerve to wonder why
there is an increase in off-campus
parties!!! Wake up for gods sake!!!
Students are going to find a way
to party and blow off steam, the
best thing the school could do is
provide a supervised environment
to reduce underaged drinking and
ensure no one gets hurt. While The
Gettysburgian was pondering the
student drinking "problem" for the
50,000 time, a real story of national
interest was taking place about the
Gettysburg battlefields and the
controversy surrounding the park
service and it's plans for private
investment and development. This
story was covered with a full page
article in USA Today and a 2
minute piece on NBC National
News with Tom Rrokaw. but did

the Gettysburgian cover it?
Shamefully, no.
I understand that Gettysburg
College does not have a journal
ism school and that The Gettys
burgian is going through some for
mat changes but these problems
are inexcusable. In the three years
that I have been away from Get
tysburg, I have been working as an
assistant producer at CBS News,
and I would be ashamed to show
this newspaper to any of my co
workers as a representation of my
alma mater. One of the first things
I learned when working on my
high school newspaper was in your
article always remember to report
"who, what, where, when and
why" perhaps this should be re
minded to the staff of The Gettys
burgian.
Sincerely,
James McCusker






Cross Country teams leave their mark

by Peter Huminski
Staff Writer The Bullet cross country
teams were busy competing the
last two weeks in the Dickinson
Invitational on October 11 and the
Allentown Invitational on October
18. There was a lot for the Bul
let harriers to pleased about this
past weekend. The men's team
finished fourth with 189 points,
behind first place Haverford (34
points).
Running for the second
week in a row without top fresh
man Jon Catlett, the Bullet men
put together an excellent team
race. There were only SO seconds
separating the Bullets' first six
runners.
"It is the best meet the guys
team has had since the beginning
of September," said Bullets coach
Robert Condon.

The Bullets were led by se
nior Jason Smith, who finished
23rd in a time of 27:32. He was
followed by James Smith (28th,
27:40), Kris Weum (39, 27:58),
Brendon Clark (46, 28:11), Dave
Gary (53,28:20), Brian Rusignolo
(55,28:22), and Ken Lodge (109,
29:33).
In the women's race senior
Wendy Johnston paced the Bullets
to a fourteenth place finish out of
33 teams. Bloomsburg won the
team title with 56 points. Johnston
finished fifthteenth overall in a
time of 19:36. She was closely
followed by Martie Calello (31,
20:08), Joyce O'Neil (86, 21:14),
and Karen Helmick (104, 21:39).
Freshman Kim Heimerl, Kristin
Mills, and Junior Krissy Snell
rounded out the Bullets top seven.
"Wendy looked the best she
has in few weeks," said Condon.
"She had a real strong finish, but
was just unable to make up the

ground on the top kids."
"Both teams ran pretty
well," said Condon. "Both teams
have been pretty tired for the lasl
couple of weeks. The importanl
thing is that they have their legs
back underneath them. We have a
ways to go until the Regional
meet." Over Reading Days while
most of us were heading home the
Bullet harriers competed in the
Dickinson Invitational. The Bul
let men finished sixth in the 36
team field, while the women fin
ished eleventh in the 33 team field.
The College of New Jersey won
the men's race and CMU was vic
torious for the women.

lason Smith and James Smith who
finished 24th and 25th respec
tively. Weum, Gary, Rusignolo,
George Torgun, and Clark
rounded out the top seven finish
ers for the Bullets.

Rusignolo has slowly
worked his way back into the top
seven after a slow start to the sea
son. "Brian didn't jump back into
his training too fast," said Condon.
"He finally started to look decent
in his last race. He is solid and
consistent and has a lot of ability."
Johnston once again led the
Bullet women finishing thirteenth
in 19:26. Calello finished
eighteeth overall in 19:47. O'Neil
finished third for the Bullets and
101 overall in 21:42. Mills,
Heimerl, Tracy Swackhammer,
and Helmick rounded out the Bul
lets top seven finishers.
"Joyce has been laid up for
the last week," said Condon. "She
missed a week of training with an
illness and you are seeing the re
sults of that in her time. She has
been a real tough competitor this
year." "We're hoping that as we go
into peaking times will start drop-

Gettysburgian. B.A.S.S. (Bullet
Athletic Support Squad) is a spe
cial interest group hoping to in
crease school spirit here on cam
pus. We are posting sports sched
ules around campus and in our
communities, as well as other vari
ous events that will adhere to our
cause. Continue to support our
athletes and for those who are par
ticipating, good luck!
Name: Amie Ashley
Age: 21
Hometown: Watertown, CT
Sport: training team
Major: HES
Year of Graduation: 1998
Hobbies/Interests: sailing
and rollerblading

Today, marks the date of the
first ever "B.A.S.S. Bulletin." To
start off the season we must first
recognize the most important team
we have: the Gettysburg training
team. Amie Ashley, a member of
the many individuals among the
group explains her part in the

mending process. Amie is cur
rently the President of the Train
ers Club.
In a few words, the Trainers
Club is an organization of student
athletic trainers, used to get the
students better oriented with the
different doctors in the area.
The organization also works
with local schools for the Ameri
can Heart Association. As Presi
dent, Amie organizes all of the on
campus events, i.e. the American
Heart Association, and must also
make the decisions on the fund
raisers in which to partake.
What makes the club so
beneficial is that it gives better ex
posure to her major, and she feels
that hands on experience really
helps. Not to mention that she can
meet others with similar interests
and gain good connections for the
future.

Amie was always certain

enjoyed being around athletes.

pires to go to graduate school at

ways something she can fall back
on.

Bears and bees take bite out of Bullets

by Peter Huminski
Staff Writer The Gettysburg Bullets
dropped their third game in a row
Saturday when the Bullets lost to
Ursinus, 13-2.
The Bullets were held deep
in their own territory for most of
the game only accumulating 230
total yards of offense.
The vaunted Bullets running
game was limited to 124 yards by
the Bears defense.
Gettysburg trailed 7-0 in the
third quarter when the Bullets de
fense came up big. Ursinus quar
terback Craig Messick handed off
to running back Joe Conte who
was met in the end zone by a wait
ing safety Kevin Gurski. Gurski
led the Bullets with ten tackles.
The Bullets now trailed, 7
2, but were forced to punt after
only three plays on the ensuing
free kick.

The Bears then put the game
out of reach by marching 75 yards
on 11 plays and scored on a Joe
Nangle two-yard touchdown run.
The Bears accumulated over 300
yards of offense against the Bul
lets and improved their record to
3-4 overall, and 2-3 in the confer¬

ence. Fullback Paul Smith led the
Bullets rushing offense with 51
yards on 16 carries. Smith was
also Gettysburg's top receiver
catching three passes for 51 yards.
In only his second start
freshman quarterback Dennis
Flaherty completed 8-29 passes
for 106 yards in the air. Flaherty
spread the receiving wealth com
pleting passes to Smith, Jeff Closz,
Mike Holm, Matt Helwig, and
Tighe Burns. The loss drops he
Bullets to 2-4 on the season, and
1-3 in the Centennial Conference.

Hit me with your best "Schott"
Sophomore Cat Schott "kills " Centennial Conference Competition

"The
team is a
great
bunch of
girls."

by Chesha Miller
Staff Writer

There are few people that
would go out of their way for any
one else and who always place
themselves behind others. Sopho
more volleyball player Catherine
Schott is one of those rare people.
Catherine, who is affection
ately called Cat, is one of the nic
est and most caring people you
will ever meet. "I am a good lis
tener," Schott said, "if anyone, a
teammate or friend, needs a shoul
der to lean on, or someone to lis
ten to them, they can always come

Although she has these
qualities, she is still a very com
petitive person who is willing push
herself and those around her to do
their best. Schott began her ath
letic career as a sixth grader, par
ticipating in volleyball, basketball,
and track.
Throughout her years at
Montrose High School in Colo
rado, Catherine was always par
tial to track but that eventually
changed. "Volleyball was just a
sport to play," explained Schott, "I
didn't expect it to be so much fun."
Aside from volleyball being so
enjoyable for Catherine, she also
has immense talent.
During her sophomore year
at Montrose, she was approached
by a recruiting service who helped
convince Schott to play volleyball
in college and to help her find the
right place for her.

The recruiting service sug
gested Gettysburg because of its
combined academic and athletic
strength. "I was really happy to
find a place where academics
come first and then athletics,"
Catherine explained, "there is a
good balance between the two
here." Gettysburg was just as lucky
to find Catherine as she was to find
Gettysburg. In a little less than a
year and a half, Schott has made
quite an impression on campus.
An honor student and consistent
Dean's List honoree, Catherine
finished up her freshman year with
an impressive 3.7 grade point av
erage, placing her very near the
top of her class.

This also enabled Catherine
to join Alpha Lambda Delta, an
honor society for superior aca
demic achievement during the first
year of college. Catherine has had
an equally impressive first two
volleyball seasons at Gettysburg.
As a first year student she
made the first All-Regional and
All-Centennial Conference teams,
was named as Centennial Confer
ence player of the week, and was
also named to the All-Tournament
team at every tournament Gettys
burg played, including both of
Gettysburg's own tournaments.
The middle blocker ended
last season ranked sixth in the na
tion for hitting percentage. She is
presently ranked second in the na
tion for hitting percentage and
17th for kills per game.

When you talk to Schott, she
won't tell you about any of her ac
complishments. In fact, she hardly
talks about herself, and when she
talks about volleyball she simply
speaks about the team. Gettysburg
College volleyball coach Kim
Rain explained, "Cat is not a cocky
person, she is definitely very mod
est and alsovery team oriented.
It is so nice to have some
one like that." Rain describes

coaching Catherine as "a once in
a lifetime experience." Schott is
extremely hard working and she
always goes above and beyond
what is required to be sure she is
getting the most out of her athletic
experience.
She understands that she

still has a lot to learn and is al
ways willing to listen to the ad
vice of her coaches. "Cat is a lis
tener and really takes our advice
into stride." said Rain, "she never

questions our judgments and al
ways goes after what she wants."
On the flip side Schott also
knows how to have fun and enjoy
her sport. "She A "s silly," Coach
Rain said laughing, "she's becom
ing really outgoing and is totally
opening herself up to the team."
Catherine's teammates are really
impressed by the combination of
her great attitude and competitive
edge. Catherine has a lot of respect
and admiration for her teammates
and coaches as well.
"Last year was a transition
year for all of us [as we got new
coaches]," says Schott, "Coach
Rain and Coach Armocost made
the adjustment fun for all of us,
and they are continuing to do so."
Schott_'s attitude towards volley
ball is to take one game at a time.
Though very competitive,
Schott only worries about the task
at hand, instead of concentrating
on future games. "I do stupid
things to make volleyball a fun
sport," says Schott, "It A "s an out
let for me and is not my whole
life." For this season Catherine A "s
goal is to accomplish the team
goals, which were set at the be
ginning of the season, and to con
tinue to have fun playing volley¬

ball. "The team is a great bunch
of girls," said Schott, "we have a
lot of fun together both on and off
the court." Catherine does look
into the future in other aspects of
her life. She is a political science
and Spanish double major, who is
planning to become a lawyer.
At this time she is leaning
towards criminal law and a prac
tice as a trial attorney but that
could change at any time. During
the spring semester of her junior
year Catherine plans to go to
Spain. The study abroad is re
quired by all Spanish majors, but
would also give Schott the long
awaited opportunity to travel to
Europe.
Schott attributes her hard
work and dedication to her parents
Pat and Paul Schott. "I've always
been able to talk to my parents and
to take advice from them. They let
me lead my own life and make my
own decisions, while supporting
me no matter what I do. I've re¬

ally modeled my life after them,
she says. Catherine is also really
close to her brother Justin who is
in the Air Force.
The pair is always there to
check up on each other and offer
constructive criticism. In addition
to playing volleyball and being a
member of Alpha Lambda Delta,
Catherine is a member of ALLIES
and the Spanish club. Last year
she took partin the survivor's train
ing course.
After completing 12 hours
of volunteering at a shelter, in ad
dition to the 48 class hours already
completed, Catherine will be a
certified domestic violence and
rape counselor. "It was a really
good class to take," explains
Catherine, "I gained a lot of im
portant knowledge." This knowl
edge epitomizes Catherine's desire
to place others needs ahead of her
own. "Cat is a great person. She
always goes out of her way to help
fellow teammates and students if
she can," noted Rain. Catherine
Schott is the type of person who
will make a difference in the
world, just as she has at Gettys
burg.



SportsWeekly

This is no "Bull"

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
Before reading the follow
ing article, you may want to brace
yourself for information that may
be unsuitable for dedicated basket
ball fans. If you have trouble with
the graphic content of this article,
please turn your paper lo another
page, and try to refrain from in
tense emotional public outbursts.
Okay, here it is... Michael
Jordan had surgery.
Yes, all the rumors are true.
Michael Jordan, perhaps the great
est basketball player of all time,
is in stable condition after having
two ingrown toenails removed. (If
you didn't catch the sarcasm there,
there was some intended.)
Jordan the NBA's nine time
scoring champ, will miss the last
remaining Chicago Bulls pre
season games against Philadelphia
on Wednsday, Philadelphia again
on Friday, and lastly Saturday
against Sacramento.

Jordan though thoroughly
traumatized by the incident said,
"It was decided that it was better
for me to have the toenails re
moved now and thus be ready for
the opening of the season. I'm
looking forward to being back on
the court next week and starting

the defense of our championship.
"What does Jordan think he
is doing anyway? He is not al
lowed to go and get hurt. He is
the only reason that half the fans
watch professional basketball any
way. When people turn on the TV,
they do not want to see "Thunder"
Bob Thorton shooting a two
handed jumper over Kurt
Nymphius.
They want to see " slam,
bam, I'm gonna shoot, dribble,
dunk, stuff, turn,pass, twist, glide,
and sail right past you and you are
going to like it" Michael Jordan.
As far as alot of professional
basketball fans are concerned
there should be a some kind . of
NBA regulation against Michael
Jordan having surgery. Something
in his contract that would read:
"Michael is not allowed to partici
pate in any surgical procedure or
medical practice no matter the se
verity of injury because frankly he
is too damn important to the

I mean hey, when reading
the contract Michael would be so
distracted by the number three and
the seven zeros that follow it (in
the salary paragraph) that the little
clause about "no surgery" may be
somewhat insignificant.
Many people would pay no

attention to a clause like the one
above, if right next to it, the para
graph read: "We will pay you $30
MILLION dollars for one season."
Would you read over it? Me too.
Have no fear. This time,
luckily, Jordan will be suited up
and ready to play in the season
opener on October 31. It will take
about two weeks for Jordan's "toe
sy, woe-sies to get all better" and
then he will be back to continue
on with the professional basketball
dynasty that has become the Chi
cago Bulls.

If you are a basketball fan,
and you read through the entire
article then you are to be com
mended and congratulated. As
hard as it was to write, it was even
harder to read as the truth.
So, don't let this article get
into the wrong hands or mass
histeria could break out all over
campus. Jordan will be back, and
hopefully the loss of a few extra
pieces of toenail will not throw off
his game. Oh yeah, that is right,
Jordan shoots over guys a foot
taller than him... I don't think he'll
be having any problems.

Home Sweet Gettysburg

By Josh Eyler
Assistant Sports Editor

the high school dances and the se
niors that I knew last year who will
be returning, but most of all I think
about the football game that ev
eryone attended religiously to
cheer on the team. The Home
coming Game was a monument,
an institution, I know that many
people feel the same way.
However, no one embraces
these feelings more deeply than
the football alumni that will return
this weekend to watch their Bul
lets play once again. These men
get to come "home" to visit the
field where they bled, dripped
sweat, won, and lost. At the time
it was everything to them.
Now, it is just a fond
memory. Who, that once put on
the pads and helmets, will return
this weekend? Perhaps those
players who are now famous will
return, such as Pete Draovitch,
who is the personal trainer for the
tremendous golfer Greg Norman
or Scott Dudak, who is getting in-

Yesterday I began to think
about Homecoming and what it
means here at Gettysburg. First, I
pulled out my dusty old Webster's
Dictionary, and one of the defini
tions for the word homecoming
was "an annual celebration for
alumni at a college or university."
In the most basic sense, that is ex
actly what will happen this week
end. More importantly, though,
homecoming is defined as "a re
turn home." For many of the
alumni that will return this week
end, Gettysburg is the home of the
memories that they hold dearest to
their hearts. This is where they
made the friends that have lasted
a lifetime and where they had the
type of good times that can never
be retrieved.
When I personally think
about homecoming, I remember

ducted into Gettysburg's Hall of
Honor this weekend.
Maybe the long list of awe
some captains will be at good old
Musselman Stadium to watch
their team: those such as Rod
Albright, Bryant "The Bulldog"
Meckley, Harry Cooper, and Chris
Notarfrancesco. By chance, even
the unsung heroes may return,
such as Chuck Seidenstricker, who
played in the trenches from '68 to
72, or John Buskirk, who played
all four years despite the fact that
he had two major knee surgeries.
Personally, I hope that they
all come. I hope that they take as
much joy in watching this year's
Bullets pound the Mules from
Muhlenberg as they once had
when they themselves were wear
ing the orange and blue. But most
of all I hope that Homecoming for
these guys, as well as all of the
alumni, is a special one, because
"returning home" should always
be a meaningful experience.

College wins
court battle

Haaland says tenure process
working well
A federal jury ruled in favor of Gettysburg College in
a discrimination lawsuit filed by a former professor who was
denied tenure.
Kelfala Kallon was a tenure-tack professor in
Gettysburg's economics department from 1987 until he was
denied tenure in the fall of 1992.
Kallon, a black man originally from Sierra Leone, was
unable to prove hisxlaims that he was denied tenure from
Gettysburg due to his race and national origin. He sought
back pay and compensatory damages.
Kallon, now a U. S. citizen, is currently a tenured
professor at the University of Northern Colorado.
Gettysburg College evaluates its professors for tenure
based on three separate criteria: teaching, research, and gov
ernance. Professors are evaluated for tenure by their aca
demic departments, the Faculty Personnel Committee, and
the President of the College.
College attorneys argued that Kallon was denied ten
ure because he failed to meet the College's standards for
teaching. He had received unsatisfactory evaluations from
students in his classes, which play a significant role in the
tenure process.

Kallon's attorneys claimed that Kallon had been de
nied tenure while white professors of similar ability were
approved for tenure. It was also suggested that the negative
evaluations given by the students may have been racially
motivated.
Much of the testimony in the week-long trial was cen
tered around the various intricacies of the College's tenure
process. Numerous documents were introduced as evidence
for the cases of both the defense and the prosecution.
Several Gettysburg College faculty members were
called to testify about the tenure process in general, and how
it related to Kallon.
Kallon himself spent nearly four hours on the witness
stand last Wednesday, in a very emotional testimony. Kallon
broke into tears many times while discussing the mental
anguish he suffered from the College's refusal to grant him
tenure. see RULING -- page 4

Olmos to show "We're all in the same gang"

Courtesy of The Fall Convocation
Committee Growing up in the East Los Ange
les barrio, barely escaping the violent vi
cious cycle of gang life, Edward James
Olmos went on to become a role model
to many people. He was able to achieve
this by succeeding on his own terms and
making his own choices. Olmos will be
the featured speaker at Fall Convocation
on November 13 at 11:30 a.m. in the
Chapel. Fall Convocation is a time to
arouse the intellect and challenge us to
reflect on both the realities of the world
as well as our own commitment towards
making a difference. Each year a presti
gious speaker is brought to Gettysburg
College to help raise our consciousness
of existing social issues.
Although he is most well known
for his role as Lt. Castillo on Miami Vice,
that is not his greatest accomplishment.
Olmos has dedicated years of his life try
ing to educate people. He is the ambassa
dor of UNICEF and sits on the board of

"Rebuild Los Angeles. " The unofficial
mayor of L.A., Olmos has worked to re
store the city's grief stricken neighborhoods
following the 1992 riots. He has also been
actively involved in bringing food to
Mexico's impoverished Mayan Indians.
Olmos is considered one of the
United States' most visible spokespersons
for the Hispanic Community. Mr. Olmos
comes to Gettysburg College advocating
education of the public in order to reduce
violence. With every word, he delivers the
message of self-discipline and determina
tion can overcome even the most daunting
obstacles. A number of programs will take
place leading up to Olmos' visit to
Gettysburg College, continuing into the
night of November 13 and in the days

CRIME STATS:
October 21-27

By Jason Hatheway
Crime Statistician

CORRECTION
Last week's article
"College sued for discrimina
tion" incorrectly reported that
the FPC recommended Pro
fessor Kallon for tenure when
in fact the Faculty Personnel
Committee decided against
granting Professor Kallon ten
ure. It was the Grievance
Committee of the Faculty, not
the President, who told Pro
fessor Charles "Buzz" Myers
to withdraw his grievance be
cause he had new information
to be considered in the grant
ing of tenure rather than a
grievance on procedural mat
ters. The Gettysburgian re
grets these unfortunate errors.

RULING — from p

The verdict in the case was
decided by the eight-member all
white jury ofthe U.S. Middle Dis
trict Court, despite the request of
College attorney Elizabeth
Dougherty to have Judge Sylvia
Rambo make the ruling due to lack
of evidence on the part of Kallon
and his attorneys.
The jury ruled in favor ofthe
defense, in apparent agreement with
Dougherty's suggestion that Kallon
was unable to show evidence that
any racial bias existed.
Stacey Schmeidel, Director
of Public Relations for the College
was pleased with the decision. "We
were confident from the beginning
that this had nothing to do with race
or national origin," she told the
Hanover Evening Sun.
Gettysburg College President
Gordon Haaland was also pleased
with the results of the case. He
stated that there was "absolutely no
problem," with the way the College
handles the tenure process. He
called the College's procedures in

evaluating professors for tenure
"clear and strong."
"This [decision] will rein
force, positively, the way we handle
the issue, and strengthen the role of
the Faculty Personnel Committee,"
said Haaiand.
Haaland also stated that he

felt the College's current method of
student evaluation was working,
though he acknowledged that "some
departments do a better job than oth
ers." Kallon still has the opportu
nity to appeal the decision.

Linnaean winners announced
from staff reports
The winners of the 1997-98 Linnaean Awards were announced
this Saturday during half-time at the Homecoming football game.
The Awards, given annually to six members ofthe graduat
ing class, were presented to seniors Erin Attfield, Jill Bailey, Ben
Barnhart, Joe Hodakowski, Abigail Rodgers, and Brian Rusignuolo.
Each year, students are nominated for the awards by faculty,
administrators, and other students for their leadership, academic work,
and community service. Students then vote for their peers among the
nominees.
The history of the Linnaean Awards dates back to one of the
earliest organizations on Gettysburg's campus, the Linnaean Asso
ciation, founded in 1844. The Association was founded for the pur
pose of the advancement of science. The Linnaean Awards attempt to
recapture the spirit of this organization by honoring students whose
actions inspire other students.

College plans
volunteer phonathon

Gettysburg College Press Release
Up to 50 students will have
a chance to win incentive prizes,
earn $50 each for their favorite
charity, get a free meal, and help
the College meet a major chal
lenge gift by participating in a one
night phonathon to be held from 6
p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Sunday No
vember 9, in the ballroom of the
College Union Building.
Individual and group volun
teers are needed to make phone
calls to alumni who are eligible to
participate in the Norris Alumni
Challenge, a gift to the College of
up to $250,000 from the Norris
family. The final amount of the
gift will be determined by the
College's ability to obtain specific
qualifying contribution by June 30,

1998. Up to 50 students are needed
to volunteer to make calls to

alumni who have not made a gift
to the College in the past two years.
Student or student groups
who volunteer and attend for the
entire event will be able to direct
$50 to a charity of their choice. Up
to five callers from each student
group will be eligible for the $50
charity gift. Monies for the char
ity donations were given to the
College by several benefactors
who wish to remain anonymous.
Callers will be given a light
dinner beginning at 6 p.m., fol
lowed by actual calling starting at
approximately? p.m. Callers will
also be eligible for various prizes
and gift certificates to be awarded
during the evening.
The deadline for registering
for the phonathon is 5 p.m. Mon
day, November 3. Potential vol
unteers are asked to contact
Kristen Anderson at the office of
annual giving.


Featu res
zoinksh! G-G-G-GHOSTS!!!

by Cara Masucci
Staff Writer As Halloween approaches
every year, it seems as though
we all want to be scared. We
watch scary movies, tell fright
ening stories, and most of all,
talk about ghosts. Nowhere is
this more apparent than here in
Gettysburg College. Since it is
a very old, historic town,
Gettysburg has a rich tradition
of ghosts; our campus is no dif
ferent. When a tourist comes into
Gettysburg and stops you to ask
where the battlefields are lo
cated, your first instinct might be
to point in the direction of the
Visitor Center. If you were go
ing to be more precise, you'd tell
the tourist that they are standing
on them.

All of Gettysburg was a
battlefield during the Civil War,
so almost every inch of ground
has seen bloodshed or loss of
life. This has led to numerous
haunted buildings on campus.
At the time of the Civil
War, there were three buildings
on the campus of the college
then known as Pennsylvania
College. One of the buildings
was Penn Hall. Since it was a
large building , it was used as a
hospital for injured soldiers.
Many men died inside
Pennsylvania Hall, and there
were never enough doctors. In
fact, a few years ago several col
lege administrators were greeted
with a sight they knew they
would never forget.
Around dusk the adminis
trators decided it was time to go
home. They headed toward the
elevator and pushed the button
to get off on the first floor. They
were greeted with quite a shock
when they passed the first floor
and headed towards the base¬

ment. As the doors opened, leg
end has it that, they saw a Civil
War doctor who tried to get them

involved in the war effort. Quickly
pressing the button for the first
floor, they were beckoned more and
more. Just as the doctor was about
to reach the elevator door, the doors
closed and the administrators were
finally able to leave.
Another famous ghost is the
ghost of Glatfelter Hall. There are

brings lots of fun to many college
students. Who knows? Maybe
you'll come across one of the
ghosts of Gettysburg College.



In Case You Missed It
Mutant plant sings, dances, entertains

by Steve Spicer
Copy Editor Everyone needs a plant or
two in his room, but not one like
the Audrey II.
Being carnivorous, such a
"strange and interesting plant"
could never make it in a dorm
room, but place the overgrown
vegetable in the middle of a re
make of a remake and you've got
a surefire hit.
The story line behind Little
Shop of Horrors is an old one. It
was germinated in 1960 by Roger
Corman. Then it bloomed again
in 1980 and was made into an Off
Broadway musical.
However, the story didn't
come to full fruition until 1986

when Warner Brothers picked
up the script and handed it to
director Frank Oz.
No two versions of Little
Shop are quite the same. This
variant, the big screen transla
tion of a musical, is uproari
ously funny.
The reason this film is so
good is due to the phenomenal
cast that was gathered.
Rick Moranis
(Spaceballs, Honey, I Shrunk
the Kids ) plays Seymour
Krelborn, the poor, orphaned
misfit who lives in the basement
of Mushnik_'s Flower Shop
where he also works.
Ellen Greene reprises her
stage role of Audrey, Seymour's

love interest. Her high, squeaky
voice lends itself perfectly to her
ditziness.
Throughout the film, many
stars such as Bill Murray, John
Candy and James Belushi appear
in hysterical cameo roles.
The true star of Little Shop,
however, is the Audrey II. Levi
Stubbs, one of the original Four
Tops, lends his voice to the plant.
His vocal capacity, coupled with
a talented special effects team,
bring this "mean, green mother"
to life.
Another enjoyable aspect to
this movie is the music. From the
fast tempo of the title song to the
climactic moment of "Suddenly
Seymour," the songs amuse, and

move the audience.
The film opens with the om
nipresent do-wop girls, Crystal,
Chiffon and Ronette, singing a warn
ing to all.
The plot quickly advances to
Seymour and Audrey singing the
woes of life on Skid Row. The same
money troubles that keep Audrey
and Seymour trapped on Skid Row
also threaten to close Mushnik's
Flower Shop.
Seymour spends his time pin
ing away for Audrey as she dreams
of life in a suburbian home, com
plete with a white picket fence.
In an attempt to persuade the
owner, Mr. Mushnik, not to close the
store for good, Seymour places one
of his "strange and interesting"
plants, which he has named the
Audrey II, in the window.
Immediately, the customers
begin pouring in to gawk at the odd
ity.

As Seymour soon discovers,
though, there's a slight catch. His
cute little plant refuses to get big
ger. Seymour accidentally finds the
necessary food for his plant.
In order to grow, the Audrey
II requires an odd type of fertilizer:
blood. The vampire-vegetable's thirst
soon increases to the point where
Seymouris forced to "perform mu
tilations" in order to continue the
growth of both the plant and his
fame. The most memorable victim is
Audrey's boyfriend, Orin Scrivello,

D.D.S., the motorcycle-riding ,
leather-clad, sadistic dentist who
is portrayed perfectly by Steve
Martin {The Jerk, Parenthood).
Every scene containing
Martin is a must-see. As the char
acters in the movie say, he is a "to
tal disgrace to the dental profes
sion," After the Audrey II con
vinces Seymour that "the guy sure
looks like plant food to me,"
Seymour goes to Scrivello's office
expecting to have to kill him, but
instead the dentist overdoses on
nitrous oxide as Seymour looks on.
How convenient!

Apparently the good doctor
has a habit of getting lambasted
before any procedure he performs.
The Audrey II eats the now
defunct dentist but is still hungry.
Eventually, after the overgrown
squash devours a few more char
acters, Audrey II decides to snack
on its namesake, the real Audrey.
Since by this point Seymour
and Audrey (the woman, not the
plant) are planning on getting mar
ried and running off together,
Seymour has to confront the hor
ticultural nightmare to make a
clean escape.

I can't in good faith divulge
the shocking ending. If you want
to know what happens, you'll just
have to get this movie and see for
yourself.
I highly recommend this
flick for one of those goofy nights.

Brusque Brits

It his been an interesting
time to be in Britain. First of
course was the death of the Prin
cess of Wales; this contributed
greatly to the on-going saga of the
royal family. (Personally, I think
the Queen was in a lose-lose situ
ation: had she publicly expressed
grief, she would have been called
a hypocrite; by keeping silent, she
was called cold.)
Then there was the "yes"
votes on devolution; first in Scot
land, then in Wales. For Scotland,
this means a significant measure
of self-government free from
London. Wales will have some
what less freedom of action than
Scotland, but more than it had
before. Some believe this is the
final phase of the end of the Brit
ish Empire.

by Mark Berg
Contribut' ng Writer

And there is the continuing
discussion of whether or not col
leges and universities in England
should remain free for all who at
tend. The Labour government has
proposed charging students and
students across the nation are up
in arms; there will be a demon
stration at the University of Essex
on November 1.
Imagine! The government
wants to charge $ 1,600 per year
to attend!! Some students may
even have to take out loans!! Per
haps you at Gettysburg would like
to stage a protest in support.
But the most striking im
pression I have of England is their
approach to customer service.
Though approach is not exactly
the right word; avoidance may be
a bit more accurate.

For example, we went into
a bakery and coffee shop in
Greenwich to buy some scones.
There were four clerks and two
waitresses behind the bakery
counter. We stood about three feet
away and waited; perhaps they
were resolving some problem.
We waited a little longer;
they continued their discussion.
Finally I said, "Could someone
please sell us some scones?" With
a look of annoyance, one of the
clerks did, without so much as a
"Thank you."
Another example: I went to
the Museum of the City of Lon
don late one afternoon and asked
to see the remnant of a gate and

guard tower from the Roman
walls. The museum building
straddles the site of the walls, so
you have to ask to be taken to a
large basement containing the rem
nant. The attendant told me,
"Sorry, it can only be seen one the
first and last Tuesday of every
month."
When I pointed out that it
was, in fact, the first Tuesday of
the month, he was crestfallen, but
he did summon a guard to take me.
While waiting, I apologized for
coming so late in the day (the Mu
seum was open another hour), and
he replied, "Actually, you can only
see it in the morning."
Too bad he had forgotten
Plan B until it was too late to stop
me.

Last example: We went to a
Victorian lunch room one day in
Dublin (to show that bad service
isn't merely an English trait), went
through the line, and went to the
cashier. At that moment, the cash
ier, second cashier, and what
looked like a manager were hav
ing an animated discussion.
We waited; perhaps they
were resolving some problem or
another. We waited a little longer.
Finally I shrugged my shoulders
and raised my hands palm up as if
to say, "So?" Whcn_^^^^_M
the manager final _ly_^^^^^^
looked over, I com-_^^^^^_f
mented, "We're what_^^^^^_f
is known as" custom-_^^H_^H
ers.'" The cashieil^^|^^
cheerfully said _. _HMIHHB

"Sorry," as the man
ager glared at me.
Now you might
say these could be
isolated examples,
and that you could
just as easily point to
similar experiences in
Gettysburg. I don't
think so. And don't
get me wrong, we're
having a great time.
The Brits are warm,
friendly people—as
long as they don't
have to wait on you.
Mark Berg is
Prof. Temma Berg's
husband. He's ac
companying his
spouse on the study
abroad trip.

Reel Hits & Misses—

Pucker up, Casanova

by Jon Froehlich
Staff Writer

critics might attempt to fit it in.
Much of the movie's suc
cess lies on the shoulders of Alex
Cross, played by Morgan Freeman
{Driving Miss Daisy, The
Shawshank Redemption). His
smooth but sharp manner that of
ten makes him so appealing to au
diences works well for him in this
role.

"He's a real student of the
game . . .And he loves to play."
said Alex Cross.
Forensic psychologist Alex
Cross is the kind of guy that has a
knack for knowing things about
people, almost before they know
it themselves.
The plot of Kiss the Girls
kicks in when that distance is shat
tered after a serial abductor call
ing himself Casanova makes the
game personal for Cross by tak
ing his niece, Naomi, played by
Gina Rivera (Soul Food).
Though audiences may
feel that this basic framework is
like that of a typical cop movie,
this assumption only rings true
to a certain extent.
For one, whether people
are quick to admit it or not,
movies about revenge bent cops/
tough guys out on personal mis
sions to catch the bad guy are usu
ally entertaining and offer plots
that have, and will continue to,
draw in eager viewers.

Movies such as Out for Jus
tice, starring Steven Seagal and
others like it will forever satisfy
many viewers on some level.
Secondly, Kiss the Girls is
a little bigger than the mold that

Tonight only partially
succeeds in being different, Kiss
the Girls must be given credit for
trying to break away from many
of the cliches that aren't so easily
avoided when making a police
mystery movie.
For example, Casanova
took Cross's niece. Director Gary
Fleder (Things To Do in Denver
When You're Dead) could have
just as easily given into tempta
tion and made Cross's daughter
disappear, but he didn't.

Though simply a difference
of one branch on the Cross family
tree, this decision nevertheless
shows a deviation from the nor
mal cop movie blueprint.
As Kiss the Girls takes on
a personal tone for Cross, it soon
becomes as personal as is possible
with its viewers when Casanova
grabs Kate McTeirnan.
Played well by Ashley Judd
(Smoke, A Time to Kill, Sisters),
Kate is one of the only characters
besides Cross that the movie has
allowed audiences to really
"know."
I In the character of Kate,
Judd offers a defiant and on-tar
get performance that audiences
can easily appreciate.
A movie with many of the
same shadowy qualities as Seven
(which also stars Morgan Free
man), Kiss the Girls, though noth
ing strikingly new, offers an ex
citing well-paced plot with char
acters that seem deeply connected
to the story and to each other.

Concluding with a battle
between two men who have made
their lives out of getting into other
people's heads, Kiss the Girls will
not leave viewers disappointed.




Go speed racer... But keep it clean

by Kyle Heulitt
GECO Columnist
The car industry has been
pressured for years to produce
cleaner automobiles. Each com
pany has been working intensely
to be the first to find the perfect
fuel-efficient, pollution-free car of
the future, and the public is just re
cently beginning to see the fruits
of their labor.
The week Honda unveiled its
lower-emission vehicle, which has
a device in the exhaust system that
changes pollutants into less toxic
substances like water and carbon
dioxide.
This car reduces noxious
emissions to one-tenth the level of
the world's toughest emissions
standard set by the California Air
Resources Board. The new engine
could be in production in less than
two years.

Although Honda s new ve
hicles seem to be the most practi
cal and soon to be available right
now, the most promising technolo
gies for the future seem to be the
fuel cell, the electric car, and the
hybrid.
The fuel cell is able to power
electric cars without the need for
bulky batteries. It converts the
chemical energy of fuels into elec
tric and thermal energy, and the

only exhaust it produces is pure
water and a small amount of heat.
This car is able to run on
ethanol, methanol, natural gas,
and recently, a U.S. government
industry team demonstrated one
that can use gasoline.
Each of these fuels could

easily
r e -
place
gaso
line at
t h e
pumps and keep the ex
isting
net
works of gas
sta
tions intact.
I n

May 1996, in Berlin, Germany's
Daimler-Benz AG unveiled the
NECAR 3, and became the first
major international car maker to
unveil a fuel cell powered pas
senger car. This particular car
runs on methanol.
Another type of car that
will be utilized in the future is the

electric car. In the past these cars
were small and inconvenient, but
car makers are finding new ways
to bring them up to the level of
today's gasoline cars.
Toyota's RAV4-EV, an elec
tric sports utility vehicle, will re
tail this fall (exclusively to busi¬

nesses)
for about $42,000.
It has a
range _0 f
about 1 3 0
miles before r e -
charge is nec
essary.
R e -
charg
i n g

takes 8
hours and can be done from a 220
volt electric line. Its maximum
speed is electronically limited to 78
miles per hour.
One more type of promising
technology is the hybrid vehicle,
which has both an electric and
gasoline engine. It has the advan
tages of the gasoline engine with

none of the disadvantages of elec
tric cars.
The hybrid engine has an
automatic power-split device in
the transmission that allows it to
use an electric motor in low speed
driving, and cut to a gas engine for
higher speeds, supplying extra en
ergy and recharging the batteries.
Also, the gas engine never
idles, which is where the most en
ergy is wasted. Instead, the en
gine remains off until extra power
is needed.
Toyota plans to retail its hy
brid, named the Prius, in Japan
starting on December 10, for
about $22,000. GM, Ford,
Chrysler, Volkswagen, and
Renault are also pursuing hybrid
cars. In Kyoto, Japan, on Decem
ber 1, there will be a meeting of
representatives of governments
from around the world to discuss
the threat of global warming.

This meeting will undoubt
edly force the auto industry to be
come environmentally friendly,
and put earth-friendly cars on the
market. Hopefully we will see
these cars for sale in a few years.
GECO meets every Thurs
day at 7 p.m. at the GECO office
in the basement of Plank Gym. All
are welcome!!!


Sour
Apple?

by Casey Dunn
Staff Writer

Fiona Apple is a name that
is becoming more and more
prominent, especially here at
Gettysburg College.
As I began to listen to her
album, I was expecting something
spectacular in her music. What I
found was a talented musician, but
one much like everyone else.
Her debut album, Tidal, was
written by Apple. At age 19,
younger than half the student
population here on campus, she
had become a prominent figure in
the music industry, and I assumed
it was because of earth shattering
music. After listening to her CD I
realized I was wrong.
Her music resembles much
of what is popular today, espe
cially in the female music indus
try. She is similar to many of her
contemporaries in the style of
music she plays and in the image
she portrays: an image of an "or
dinary" girl making a name for
herself in a male dominated world
and industry.

Her faster songs, with a lot
of guitar, are a shade less bitter
than Alanis Morrisette and sound
almost identical to that Joan
Osborne. Other songs reminded
me of Jewel.
My favorite songs on the
CD were the ones accompanied by
piano, sounding almost like Tori
Amos, but with a lot less flare and
emotion. The song
"Shadowboxer" was by far my
favorite, with its piano-in-a-small
bar-on-the-corner type feel. In my
opinion, this particular song was
the most unique and revealed a lot
of her talent.
I found the CD to be one that
was enjoyable to listen to, and
even found myself humming
along to some of the tunes. She
does display a tremendous amount
of talent, but her music did not
seem groundbreaking to me.

I began to wonder what
makes her so popular, and decided
it is the image she portrays as a
young female. Her image gives
hope to those who aspire to "make
it" in the music industry. In es
sence she is the icon of possibil
ity.


Dear Casey...

Dear Casey,
I am rather bummed be
cause my parents took my car
away and are letting my brother
have it at his campus. This has
forced me to give up my off-cam
pus job and limited my mobil
ity. There is no way I can get a
car by myself, and I am rather
bitter about this loss. Is there
anything I can do?
Carless
Dear Carless,
It does seem rather unfair
that you lost your car to your
brother, but it is probable that your
parents had their reasons. I would
not attempt to squander your
money on buying a lemon. Instead
I would attempt to make lemon
ade. Seeing as the campus and
town is not too expansive, it
should be relatively easy for you
to get around without wheels, and
enjoy the scenery as well.

As for your job, try getting
one on campus, it will most likely
save you lots of time and energy
you could be using in other con
structive activities.
In general, I would like you
to know that the loss of a car is
not the end of the world and that
you are just going to have to learn
to get about without it.
There could be many more
terrible things that could happen,

Howard in Gettysburg by Myles Price

and even though the situation is a
real bummer, things could be
worse.
And, if just sitting back and
accepting things is not your style,
try constructively convincing your
parents that you need the car. Do
not try to use guilt trips and the
such, because they usually do not
hold water with parents.
Perhaps, if you can defend
the argument that you need the car
more than your sibling, you might
be able to retrieve it. If not, try

not to hold a grudge, or you might
be carless for a much longer time.
Dear Casey,
Just recently I found out
that people who I thought were
my "friends" were talking about
me behind my back. I acci
dently overheard a conversation
in which they were complaining
about me. They don't know
that I overheard them and still
treat me like a friend. I cannot
believe that my "friends" would
be so two-faced. What should I
do?

Feeling Friendless
Dear Feeling Friendless,
This seems to be a sticky
situation, but my best advice is to
stand up for yourself and do not
let your friends walk over you like
an old throw rug.
The last thing anyone needs

are shallow friends who just keep
you around to complain about you.
It is sad, but true. Perhaps over
hearing their conversation can be
seen as a good thing, because now
you know where you really stand.
You should definitely let
them know that you heard what
they said, and do not let them try
to apologize or explain their way
out of it. Let them know how you
feel and leave it at that.
It is really self-defeating if
you keep friends around who are
two-faced. You can certainly do
better than them. True friends do
not maliciously rag on their
friends to others, even though
sometimes friendship ties can be
strained.
Do not allow yourself to be
treated with anything less than re
spect. This is often hard to do, es
pecially in this age of exploitation
and the such where everyone
thinks they can walk over anyone
they want.

You re at an awkward point
in life. You want to feel popular;
nobody wants to sit in Servo alone.
But this doesn't mean you should
sacrifice your self-respect. Your
"friends" are the jerks here, not
you. You need to remember that.
So I say, stand up and de
fend yourself. After you do, move
on and do not dwell on them any
longer. After all, are they really
worth your time and energy?

Conflict and Consensus

Baseball, motorcycles and the GOP

Random Thoughts by Sara Spren/qe

by John Dunlap
Staff Writer Last Sunday's victory by the
Florida Marlins in the World Se
ries was very representative of the
changes effecting Major League
Baseball today. America's national
pastime is undergoing a process of
historic change. Change, that in
my opinion, is dragging the entire
sport down from the big leagues
to the little leagues.
It could easily be said that
baseball is a business, and as an
ideological conservative I should
allow the sport adapt to the chang
ing times. In other words, the own
ers and the players should be left
to handle matters on their own. For
the most part, they should be al
lowed, however there are some
cases when government should
step in and protect the national in
terest.

In 1981, when Harley
Davidson was near death because
of Japanese competition, President
Ronald Reagan stepped in and
moved away from his devout free
trade positions to support tariffs to
save America's great motorcycle.
This was not exactly a capitalist
position having the government
come in and influence the buying
and selling of goods, but it was the
right thing to do. Certain traditions
are timeless and should never be
allowed to either die or face rapid
demise. Baseball today is under-

There are too many cars here
at Gettysburg. Not only are there
too many cars, but there is always
one in my space.
The parking problem is
worst in the lots in College Apart
ments, Paxton Hall, and Huber/
Patrick/_Musselman/Stevens Halls.
The people who live in these
dormitories and apartments should

going a great deal of demise. What
acting Commissioner Bud Selig,
club owners, and the player's
unions are doing is wrong. Fore
most wrong for fan.

Consider this...

According to President
Haaland, the tenure process here
at Gettysburg works.
He seems to view the
school's victory in the discrimi
nation case earlier this week as a
victory for the system currently
in place.
Many disgruntled students
would disagree as they watch their
favorite professors search for new
jobs at different schools and the
respective departments bring in
candidates to replace what
shouldn't be replaced.
Was Professor Kelfala
Kallon denied tenure because of
his race and national origin, as he
claims?
Or is he, as the College
would suggest, merely a dis
gruntled former faculty member,
blaming Gettysburg for his own
shortcomings?

While the court ruling may
serve as a legal vindication of the
College's point of view, the com
plexities of the tenure process are
such that it is nearly impossible
to resolve the question.
While President Haaland
may be justified in his belief that
the College's actions in the Kallon
case were not racially motivated,
his refusal to acknowledge the
glaring problems in the manner in
which the college handles the ten
ure process is not acceptable.
Stop and think about it: can
you clearly describe the tenure
