Living with HIV

Early treatment the key to living longer with the virus

by Darcy Daniels and
Miranna Smith
Contributing Wuters
You were worried about
HIV. You had a few close en
counters. You got tested and
you found out that you are
HIV positive. All of your
worst fears have been con
firmed. You are afraid, you
fee] alone, and you don't know
where to turn. What do you
do now? This news can be
very shocking, but it is impor
tant to face this crisis and learn
how to live with HIV.
The subject of AIDS and
HIV is a very personal, confi
dential topic. It is also very
scary. There is a large support
network that you can turn to
that can help you sort out your
feelings.
If you don't feel com-

I fortable discussing this with
your family or friends, there
are people on campus that
are available to discuss your
fears with you. Their names
have been printed in this is
I sue of the Gettysburgian.
You can also call your local
HIV/AIDS service organi
zation, because they can re
fer you to a physician or
, clinic experienced in the
[ care of HIV/AIDS patients.
You now have to live
your life differently. Many
people live long lives once
they find out they are HIV
positive, but the key to long
life is early intervention.
You need to find out what
combination of treatment
may be right for you. You
need to go see a doctor to
discuss your options.
Besides seeing a doc¬

tor, there are more personalized
steps that you can take such as
eating a balanced diet. Good nu
trition can help your body fight
infections.
Rest is also essential for the
body to renew strength, resist ill
ness, and relieve stress.
Exercise, good hygiene,
and avoiding drugs and alcohol
are three important steps to help
you lead a healthy lifestyle.
Finding out that your are
HIV-positive is critical to your
relationships with others. HIV is
spread through blood, semen,
breastmilk and vaginal fluid.
This means that it can be
spread to others during sex, by
sharing needles, or during preg
nancy. You can reduce the risk of
transmittal to others by using la¬

tex condoms, every time, if you
decide to have sex. Though they
do not eliminate the risk of infect
ing someone else, it highly re
duces the risk.
Other important prevention
factors include never sharing
needles, razors or toothbrushes,
not donating blood, and telling
your partner and your health care
providers about your infection.
You are not alone in your
crisis. You have a lot of informa
tion, a lot of support, and a lot of
love from your family and
friends. Hopefully, a cure is in
sight, but in the meantime, be re
sponsible for yourself and others.
For more information con
tact The National AIDS Informa
tion Hotline 1800-342-AIDS or
your local Red Cross chapter.

Noted physics
professor to speak
in Masters

Number of minority
Ph. D.'s increasing

Gettysburg College Press
Release An Amherst College phys
ics professor and author of the
prize-winning book "Frozen
Star" will come to Gettysburg
College to discuss "The
Anthropic Principle and the Fun
damental Constants of Nature" at
3 p.m., Friday, Dec. 5, in Room
208 of Masters Hall. Dr. George
Greenstein's presentation is open
to the public free of charge.
Greenstein has been a
member of the Amherst faculty
since 1977 and is currently serv
ing as the Sidney Dillon Profes
sor of Astronomy. He is also se
ries editor of "The Challenge Se
ries" and contributing editor of
"Air and Space/Smithsonian
Magazine."

The Gettysburgian is currently
seeking News Reporters and Copy
Editors for next semester.
Callus x6449

Greenstein is recipient of
both the Phi Beta Kappa Award
in Science and the American In
stitute of Physics/U.S. Steel Sci
ence Writing Award for his 1984
book "Frozen Star." "The Sym
biotic Universe," written in 1988,
is a selection of the quality Pa
perback book Club, the As
tronomy Book Club, and the
MacMillan Book Club.
Greenstein has also written nu
merous articles and essays for a
variety of publications, including
"Nature," "Astrophysical Jour
nal," "the American journal of
Physics," "The American
Scholar," and "Science."
Greenstein earned a
bachelor's degree in physics from
Stanford University and a doctor
ate in physics from Yale Univer
sity.

A record number of minor
ity students earned doctorates at
American universities, according
to a new study by the National
Research Council.
Black, Hispanic, Asian and
American Indian students re
ceived 3,542 Ph.D. _" s in 1996, up
from 3,517 in 1995. The num
ber of doctoral degrees awarded
to American minority students
rose in each ethnic group, except
for Asian Americans.
Black Americans received
1,315 doctorates last year, while
American Indians earned 186.
Puerto Ricans earned 251
Ph.D.'s; Mexican Americans 282;
and other Hispanics_, 417.
White Americans earned
slightly fewer Ph.D.'s in 1996
23,956 down from 23,920 in
1995. The same was true of
Asian Americans, who received
1,091 doctorates last year, com
pared with 1,140 in 1995.

for about 40 percent of the de
grees awarded in 1996, earning
16,945 degrees, up from 16,414
in 1995.
Women earning doctorates
outnumbered men in education
and in the social sciences. In the
humanities, women earned nearly
Ph.D.'s as men: 2,544 women
compared with 2,572 men.
Men dominated in engi
neering, the physical sciences and
life sciences. Men, for example,
earned 5,529 Ph.D.'s in engineer
ing, while women received 776.

The National Research
Council's final report, "Summary
Report 1996: Doctorate Recipi
ents from United States Univer
sities," will be available in late
December or early January. Cop
ies of the report will be available
at no charge from the Doctorate
Records Project, Office of Scien
tific and Engineering Personnel,
National Research Council, 2101
Constitution Avenue, N.W.,
Room TJ 2006, Washington, D.C
20418; or by e-mail at
phdsurvy @ nas.edu.

Features
Celebrating in style

by Cara Masucci
Staff Writer After the last dishes are
cleared from the table on
Thanksgiving, everyone is
looking forward to the upcom
ing holiday season. Whether
it is for Christmas, Hanukkah,
or Kwanza, decorations are
hung from all corners of the
house. Walking down the
street, one is greeted with
bright lights and well-known
symbols of the holidays. Gifts
are exchanged, and families
gather together to give thanks
for their happiness. It becomes
a custom to every person,
young and old.
Christmas is probably the
best known holiday of the year,
due to the fact that a majority
of the country celebrates it. It
is the day that Christians cel¬

ebrate the birth of Jesus Christ,
the Son of God, who was born

into the world to save people
from original sin. It is a day of
great rejoicing across the world
for many Christians. Many
families gather together to cel
ebrate by going to services
and gathering for large
meals on the twenty-fifth _^

Are you sure?

by Alec Beekmans
Contributing Writer
It's a story you probably
don't want to hear, but I'm go
ing to tell you anyway because
you need to hear it. I know, I
know, you're already covered in
it, buried by a deluge of facts,
figures, and bleeding-heart mes
sages all designed to make you
put on a condom, put a con
dom on him, throw out your
needles, and ultimately de
nounce sex. I'm not here to do
any of that.
I'm here to talk about re
alities, to let forth a stream of
consciousness that will either
hit you or not, I don't care
which.
I want to talk about the
constant taste of vomit I've got
in my mouth because my pills
make me sick, and about the
constant nausea I carry with me
right next to the thought, "I am
dying." I want to talk about the

fact that she didn't look sick,
didn't say she was sick, told me
she loved me, then gave it to me
(or me to it?) anyway.
Oh, you don't want to
hear about that, either? How
about the fact that my hope
rises and falls with my T-cells,
and that to me, vitamin C is no
longer "nature's candy" but an
unreliable lifesaver? Avoid cer
tain death by avoiding the com
mon cold.
Every week I have to take
a stool sample to my doctor and
try and ignore the fact that
people are staring at my thin
ning hair and my lesions.
Sometimes, I can't even hold it
when I have to go to the bath
room. Are you still going to tell
me that putting a piece of rub
ber on your penis (his penis,
whoever's penis) is embarrass
ing? It ruins the mood? So will
your funeral, because sex with
a dead body isn't much fun.

If I asked you right now
if you were like me, how sure
would your answer be? Are you
safe? Are you healthy? Are you
dying? Let's face it, any of us
who's fooled around, who's
"done it" with any opening,
who's tasted the "forbidden
fruit" (among other things) is
healthy purely by chance. How
sure are you?
I was sure, but when I
scratched off my lottery ticket,
it said I had it, I won. I played
Russian roulette with my geni
tals and I caught the bullet. All
things considered, I'd rather
have had the consolation prize.
Now I get consolation. Have
you joined my winner's circle?
How sure are you?

In October, I went on a
service learning project to New
York City. I spent some time
laughing, some time shopping
and a wonderful evening at a
Broadway show.
I also spent a great deal

of time with people who don't
do much of any of the above. I
prepared food for an organiza
tion that exists solely to deliver
meals to AIDS patients who can
no longer leave their house,
except for their obligatory
doctor's visits.
I saw what it's like to be
completely dependant on oth
ers. I understood what it's like
to be panic-stricken over ruin
ing a bowl of lettuce by sneez
ing openly in its vicinity (all
food prepared for the clients
must be kept completely germ
free). I learned what it feels like
to brighten an eight year old's
day (who, incidentally, knows
that he's dying) by giving him
an extra helping of dessert.
I have seen the faces of
the dying patients, and no mat
ter how beautiful I have come
to view them as, they are still
tragic. It is in their honor that
I write this, but they are still
dying. Are you? How sure are

you? These days, to say that
someone is "positive" is not to
describe his or her outlook on
life. Positive certainly doesn't
describe the death that the per
son is facing.
Get tested, be safe. Live
life freely, have sex cautiously,
play carefully. And if you know
someone who's got AIDS or
HIV, hug them—hard. Think
of it as giving them an extra
dessert.
The Pa. State Health Cen
ter, located on E. Middle St.,
will continue their practice of
offering, by appointment, free
tests for those concerned about
exposure to the AIDS virus.
Information is available by con
tacting the State Health Center
at 334-2112.

A table will be in the CUB
during lunch today and tomor
row to distribute information
and tor people to write letters
of advocacy and understanding.


Plugging for studying
abroad

by Mark Berg
England Correspondent

THE FOLLOWING IS A
COMMERCIAL ANNOUN
CEMENT:
I was back in Gettysburg
briefly (the fares are low in
November, and my wife had
papers to grade and research to
do) and noticed, on the bulle
tin board, an announcement of
a meeting on December 5 to
explain the College's program
in London and the University
of Essex next Fall.
Since none of the current
students can attend, I thought
that if you are interested in the
program, I'd give you my per
ception of the program and
how the students have benefit
ted. When I attended a simi
lar meeting, I — and I think
some of the other attendees —
came away thinking the previ
ous students had been on one
long vacation. To some extent,
that's true.

A lot of this year's stu
dents have been to Scotland,
Ireland, Holland, Belgium,
France, Germany, all around
England, and elsewhere, singly
or in groups. Clearly, one of the
benefits of being in Britain is
its proximity to the Continent;
and being students, the cost of
travel is about as low as it can
be. There was also much talk
about student life at the Uni
versity of Essex: the drinking
age in Britain is 18, there don't
seem to be as many quizzes and
tests in the classes; and because
they're there for only half a
school year and most courses
are a year long, the professors
were lenient in grading the
Gettysburg students.

That, at first, is definitely
true, but I don't believe the
Gettysburg students in Essex
now feel like they're coasting.
Of course, you can travel to
Europe without being in the
program; I've been told that
some students under 21 at
Gettysburg have been known
to drink beer; and not having
as much school work to do
without worrying about your

grade (if in fact true) may ap
peal to a few students.
But what I have observed
in the students, the change I
have seen in them since we ar
rived, is, well, I guess it could
be called sophistication as de
fined in the dictionary: sophis
ticated character, ideas, tastes,
or ways as the result of educa
tion, worldly experience, etc.
That education, that worldly
experience, is not due to just
traveling in foreign countries,
but day-to-day living and learn¬

ing in another culture, having
formal and informal contacts
with other than waiters or tour
guides.
It's as simple as recogniz
ing that the British don't drive
on the wrong side of the road,
they drive on the other side.
Or, in the case one of the
Gettysburg students, having a
great meal prepared by and in
the company of the visiting
parents of a Greek flatmate. Or
another with a French flatmate
who likes to cook.

What's not as obvious,
and perhaps unexpected, is
that they are learning in their
classes how the rest of the
world views America, and how
its history and actions are in
terpreted by others.
From their classmates and
flatmates, they gained an un
derstanding how others view
their history, and how our
knowledge of other societies
and cultures may are not be
accurate. Given especially the
make-up of the student body of
the University of Essex, drawn
from more than 110 countries,
multi-culturalism is far from
being an abstract idea; here it's
around you all day, every day.
Gettysburg students, meet the
world, so to speak.

So, not matter what you
may hear at the meeting, if you
are open to being "altered by
education, experience, etc., so
as to be worldly-wise; not na
ive," - and have a great time
while doing it - this is the pro
gram for you.
Just remember, there may
not be a Gettysburg teacher's
husband to bring back boxes of
Kraft Macaroni & Cheese.

Reel Hits & Misses
Resurrected Alien a clone

by Jon Froehlich
Staff Writer
"You can't stop it; it's in
evitable" - Ellen Ripley
Though Ellen Ripley,
played, yet again, by Sigourney
Weaver (Alien 7-7/7, Dave) was
referring to the alien force that

she knew would
eventually kill ev
eryone on board
her ship, her state
ment is also ideal
for describing the
movie Alien IV -
Resurrection.
After parts
one through three
of Alien were so
successful at the
box offices, it
should come as no
surprise that a
fourth movie was
made. The discus
sion of this movie
is one of the sim
plest in a long

. are
no deep characters, no com
plex story line and no gut
wrenching emotion. There is
just four times the chases, four
times the flesh ripping, drool
covered aliens and four times
the big guns.
Basically, what it all
comes down to is whether or
not you enjoyed Alien I through
III. If you liked those, you'll,
most likely, not be let down by

Alien TV - Resurrection.
With this being director
Jean Pierre Jeunet's first major
American movie, he had to get
creative to make it work. He
saw what needed to be done
and did it.
In order to get this movie
off the ground, two things

needed to happen - the aliens
had to come back and so did
Ripley. Considering that both
Alien and Ripley met their de
mise in a pit of flaming lava at
the end of Alien III, this task
was not an easy one.
Jeunet continues the
Alien saga two hundred years
later through the use of a shady
military experiment. The op¬

eration, ol course, goes horri
bly wrong, and the action
comes in when Ripley is forced
to stand up and face her old
enemy again.
Though the cloning of
Ripley and of the aliens may
sound incredibly contrived,
and even a bit desperate, we
can let that go because of

what kind of a movie we're
dealing with. Jeunet does,
however, earn a little
more credit for his cre
ative input of a slight
maternal connection
/j\V between Ripley
jnil and the main

the Brits, with no comparable
Thanksgiving, knew when to
start their holiday shopping.
The answer: November 5, Guy
Fawkes Day. Guy Fawkes Day

ready to start counting the days
until we leave.
It's either that, or the fact
that the days are now so short,
with sunset before 4 p.m., mak
ing it a little gloomy. We cer
tainly cannot complain about
the weather; it's been below
freezing only a few nights, and
until this morning, we've had
hardly any rain. And, witness
the students in Paris, there are
still some places we plan to
visit. Though we have been
here for a few months, we
haven't gotten to see all of Eu
rope, and our time is running
out. As one student said, "it's
a bittersweet feeling; we have
seen a lot, we have had experi
ences we will never forget, and
most important, we now have
friends here. Still, we're ready
to go home."

Thanksgiving in Britain
was just another day; no big
football games, no family gath
erings, no traditional holiday
greetings from students ("My
ride is leaving early").
But most of us (a few ac
tually preferred to go to Paris
with their art history class)
wanted to be together and cel
ebrate in the spirit of the holi
day. So, 31 Americans (some
from other schools) and 22
Brits (in the American Studies
program) joined for a Thanks
giving dinner.
We met at the Greyhound
Pub in Wivenhoe. After drinks
in the pub, we went to a pri
vate room on the second floor
for the actual feast. The meal
consisted of turkey (white meat
only) with gravy, stuffing (of a
sort), roasted and mashed po
tatoes (they do like their pota
toes here), peas, carrots, brus-

"This celebra
tion has capped
our experience
here."-

can pecan pie, more like an
apple pie with a layer of
chopped pecans) topped with
either whipped cream or cus
tard. I did note, however, that
some of the American students
(not the Gettysburgians!) and
the Brits used their utensils Eu
ropean style; how unAmerican.
I wondered aloud how

is the anniversary of the day
that Guy Fawkes tried to blow
up the Houses of Parliament.
Though not widely known out
side of England, it's actually
something of a big deal there.
All agreed that it was a
very good meal in excellent
company. But it also seems as
if this celebration has capped
our experience here, and we're

This is the last of the re
ports from Mark Berg in En
gland. The students will be
back in time for our finals.

Fools won't rush to this
movie

by Glen Beck
Staff Writer "You are everything I
knew I always wanted" —
"Whatever you do, don't tell
them I picked you up outside a
restroom." Who ever thought
you would hear those two lines
in the same movie? They can
be heard in director Andy
Tennant_'s 1997 film Fools Rush
In. The film only lasted a short
time in the theater, but if you're
in a sappy, sentimental mood,
I think it is an enjoyable film.

Granted, if you're not
high on life at the time of
watching the movie-you'll find
many a problem with the plot
and the situation itself. Panned
by other reviewers as one of the
forgettable movies of the year,
the film is saved by one thing:
Salma Hayek, who portrays
Isabel Fuentes. She is a breath
of fresh air and gives one of the
most believable performances
I have seen in a long time.
Matthew Perry {Friends) also
stars. He is quite

Chandleresque, which is fine
for this film, but I hope he
learns to play another type of
character. Actually, he provides
the much needed comedy
through the overly long film.
The major problem is the
storyline is rather predictable.
After a chance meeting in Las
Vegas and a night together at
his place, a young American
construction supervisor, Alex
Whitman, leaves Mexican pho
tographer Isabel Fuentes preg
nant. She finds him a few
months later to let him know
what happened. In the rush of
the moment, he follows her and
they decide to get married. Af
ter that, a clash of customs and
ideas develops in their families
and in their relationship be
cause of their different cultural
and national backgrounds.

Now, I don t know if you
believe me or not, but I did
watch the movie twice in two
different mind sets and believe
me, if you're in a good mood
you will enjoy it. Otherwise,
stay away.

ind I have used latex condoms
ind/or latex barriers with sper
nicide for all sexual inter-

:ourse.

;exually active, I have been di
ignosed with at least one sexu
illy transmitted disease.

for HIV infection, based on

Thanks to all!


by Matt Miller
I know you felt you had to go,
that in this world you couldn't stay
But many here still love you,'
and wish you hadn't flown away.
"We'll see a picture, hear a phrase,
and our control will fall apart.
For it brings to mind a memory
that pierces through the heart.
It brings to mind a memory
that shouldn't be done yet.
But from that one day onward,
the nonexistent future's set.
Please let this be a tribute,
to your sorrows, pain and fears,

For Casey

so that we don't forget how your life had
many tears.
But more this is a tribute
to your life we hold within,
to your laughter,
to your joy,
and to your gorgeous grin.
To the way you held your head up,
to the brilliance in your eye,
to the way you helped me perk up

and hold my own head high.
We all know that you loved us
and that you know we loved you too,
and somewhere in the future
I hope to see you once more, too.





Conflict and Consensus

Condoms Lessons from abroad

don't cover it

by Jay Spiese
Contributing Writer
On this past Monday we
all received little red ribbons in
honor of AIDS awareness
week. Included with this was
an envelope containing
condoms. On the way back to
my house, I thought about
what this was saying to people
on campus.
I see students walking
across campus wearing these
little ribbons. They take pride
in wearing them. It shows they
are socially concerned. Besides
it's fashionable. There is some
thing false in these ribbon cam
paigns. We wear them because

we want to raise awareness
about AIDS on our campus. I
tell you that if there is anyone
on this campus who doesn't
know how you get AIDS, then
they have been living in a plas
tic bubble for eighteen years.
Also, I ask you, how does wear
ing a ribbon educate, let alone
prevent the transmission of
HIV? It doesn't. It is just an
other example of a culture
where symbolism is valued over
action. Besides, both you and
I know that the same people
wearing these ribbons all week
have no problems sleeping with
the first person to walk by at a
party.

As for the more difficult
question of condoms. The
Health Center has them avail
able to students free of charge.
It takes at most ten minutes to
go in, pick one up, and head
back to your dorm. Instead
someone decided that this was
not enough. Condoms must be
distributed through the campus
mail. There is nothing naive or
Puritan in my views. I know
that there is a segment on cam
pus that will have sex no mat¬

ter what. Neither do I have a
problem with consenting adults
doing whatever they want.
But, in addressing this I am
going to break one of Gettys
burg College's taboos. Where
in all of AIDS week does absti
nence come in to the discus
sion? There is a significant
number, though not majority,
of students who have chosen to
abstain from sex until marriage.
Let us face it, this is not an en
vironment that supports that
decision.
In our freshmen year, the
Health Center comes around to
the dorms and gives a program
on contraceptives. If they men
tion abstinence at all it is only
in passing. These profession
als treat it as an abnormality or
a joke.

Socially these brave indi
viduals who abstain are pres
sured by their friends. Sex on
this campus is often a way to
social acceptability. We all
know women who start sleep
ing with men to become popu
lar. I know a woman who pa
thetically enough, slept with a
man anytime he wanted to just
so she could say she had a boy
friend. She knew he used her
only for her body. Sometimes
she would be in tears because
of something he said or did.

But come the weekend she
would put out just to have
someone she could say loved
her. Even when he slept with
another woman she didn't
change.
Perhaps I am alone on this
issue. I don't know and I don't
care. Someone needs to say that
abstinence is a legitimate and
honorable choice. Since no one
else will say it this week, this is
for everyone who believes in
abstinence: You made a great
choice.

Student finds questions and answers in Japan

To the Gettysburgian: I
appreciate the copies of the
burgtan sent to me by the Study
Abroad office. I know there are
a number of fellow students
studying all over the world that
appreciate it too. I wanted to
write to you in the hopes of
relaying one of my invaluable
experiences while studying
abroad in Japan. Gettysburg
College offers wonderful op
portunities to spend some time
away from Gettysburg, and I
hope incoming students can
benefit from those that have
already "been there, done it."
It is hard for me to be
lieve that my stay in Japan is
almost over. I came halfway
across the globe hoping to find
some answers to the numerous
questions I had about Japanese
people, their culture, and their
history. I wanted to dispel
myths-draw my own clear im
age about what it is to be Japa
nese. Naive, I know, but the
effort was made.

I looked for it by open
ing an old book to a page long
forgotten. A four-leaf clover,
memento of some exuberant
afternoon in the grass, falls to
the floor and reminds me that
life is both long and short, that
love fades and luck changes.
Somewhere south of Nara, in
a farfetched corner of the
Yamato Plain, is a little six
teenth-century temple town.
Imai-cho, once a rich and pow
erful city surrounded by over a
mile of moat and a 12 ft.-high
wall, is now a quiet backwater
town with a maze of streets too
narrow and people too careful
to accommodate much twenti
eth century nonsense. That this
wooden, tile-roofed town has
stood nearly intact for over 400
years makes it a historical phe
nomenon rarely found in all of

Japan, and one of the Kansai
district's best kept secrets.
The history of Imai-cho
goes back even further. When
the emperor Kammu moved his
court from Nara to Kyoto in
the eighth century,'he refused
to allow the ambitious temple
priests of Nara to accompany
him. As compensation, he
awarded large tracts of land to
these priests, one of which was
in the Yagi area in the center of
the Yamato Plain. The Yagi
tract was strategically located
at the crossroads of two major
highways and was from the
start a village of wealthy land
owners. The powerful
Kofukuji Temple in Nara
wasted no time in imposing a
stifling tax on their smaller
neighbor. A rebellion took
place in 1532 which left the
village in ashes.
Ever since Imai-cho

gained recognition 20 years ago
as an important historic town,
the people of Imai have taken
the future of their formerly
obscure habitat as a matter of
life-and-death importance.
With streets too narrow for cars
(much less buses), they decided
to build parking lots and an
information hall outside the
borders of the town itself. Dis
inclined, however, to have their
town turned into another tour
ist attraction, the people of
Imai require that people seri
ously interested in seeing their
homes apply by telephone will
in advance. This decision has
kept Imai-cho from suffering
the ravages of the mass-tourist
industry that has plagued cit
ies like Kyoto for so long.

Although changes and
additions have been made to
some of the houses that are in
compatible with the traditional
style of the town, many of the

new buildings reflect an in
creasing awareness among lo
cal residents of the significance
of its historical atmosphere. As
long as the people of Imai-cho
continue to value the classic
beauty of the view that awaits
them just outside the doorstep
each morning, this town will
remain a very special place.
Imai-cho is just one of
many places that I have visited
in Japan, but the one that has
had the most profound effect
me. Many Japanese, as do
many Americans, spent their
lives with mysteries. We are
embedded in, and look out on,
a universe that is as mysterious
as it is vast, and if that weren't
mystery enough, we have our
own personal mysteries: Who
am I? Where am I? Why am I?

Our reaction to the mys
teries has been twofold: we cre
ate religions, all of which say
in one way or another, "There
is something bigger than I;"
and, in our quest to find our
selves, we establish and support
programs and institutions such
as Study Abroad and Gettys
burg College, where a new gen
eration is taught what we al
ready know, and equipped with
the tools and inspirations to
continue the grand quest. For
many of us, Gettysburg College
is the place where we begin the
grand quest. To my surprise, I
will leave Japan with even more
questions than I had before I
came. Come see for yourself,
bring a friend. The Study
Abroad office is located in the
College Union building, second
floor. I.E. Fletcher


Consider THIS!

Conflict and Consensus

I can't help it if people
are stupid. My job is sim
ply to inform the campus
community of the actions of
their peers. And I must say
that I have had an excellent
time doing just that.
I have served as Edi
tor-in-Chief of this fine stu
dent newspaper for three
semesters, and adventures
have abounded.
The first issue that I
was in charge of was printed
out of my apartment in
Apple. We had been
flooded out of our office in
Plank Gym and had to move
most of our equipment to
my dining room. That
should have been my first
clue about what I was get
ting myself into.

Less than two months
later, the Gettysburgian was
the first newspaper in the
country to cover the death
of the Brian Peterson baby.
On a hunch, we contacted
the Review at the University
of Delaware and unknow
ingly stumbled upon one of
the biggest news stories of

1996. Through out the year,
the 'Burgian battled college
policies in our Opinions

pages; covered everything
from outsourcing to squirrel
attacks in the news; brought
you the best in Bullets sports
coverage; and entertained with
numerous interesting features.
We changed our style of
layout, increased our coverage,
our subscriptions and our ad
vertising—all while celebrating
our 100th anniversary. We
learned a great deal-and had
even more fun—at national
conferences. We were recently
awarded tops honors in the
world of student journalism
we are finalists for the presti
gious Pacemaker Award.
But enough memories.
As Editor, I have often had to
hide my true opinions in the
interest of the newspaper. The
truth is, the Gettysburgian is
one of the best college news
papers in the country, and any
one who thinks differently is
an ignoramus. We strive for
fairness and have never, never
knowingly gotten a story


wrong.
I am proud to be an
American where the press is
free. Without a scrutinizing,
analytical media, democracy
cannot exist. The first amend
ment is arguably the most im
portant part of our great Con¬

stitution. The fourth estate is
an unofficial check on the bal
ance of all power in this nation
and on this campus.
I am not sorry for any
thing that I have done over the
past year and a half. Sure there
are some things I would change
if I had it all to do over again.
Over all, I am proud of the
Gettysburgian, its history, and
most of all its people. It is com
monly believed that reporters
constitute their own kind of fra
ternity, forming close bonds of
friendship between those who
cherish truth and cynicism. The
reporters, editors, visitors and
staff of the Gettysburgian are
some of the best people I have
met on campus. The love and
respect that I have for these
people can not be measured.
Despite the numerous times
that they have been fired, they
all continue to give every effort
possible-an admirable trait that
weekly inspires me.

I will miss the Gettysburg
ian, but I know that it is time
for someone new to take the
reigns, continue to improve the
paper and make her own mark
on the newspaper and the col
lege. Rebecca K. Babbitt

Conflict and Consensus —
The Pachyderm's Pulpit

In 1988 DanQuaylewas
elected Vice President of the
United States. This should have
been a moment of triumph for
the 41 one year old Vice Presi
dent-elect, however disap
pointment must have befallen
Mr. Quayle. His selection as
then Vice President George
Bush's running-mate was hit
with criticism, his campaign
was a severe disappointment
and in the sole Vice Presiden
tial Debate, the Democratic
Vice Presidential Nominee,
Senator Lloyd Bentson won the
debate with a single line
pointed towards Dan Quayle,
"You are no Jack Kennedy." This
was only the beginning for the
nations 43rd Vice President as
the media was relentless in pub
licly shredding him, he became
the biggest target for comedi
ans looking for a laugh and
gaffe after eaffe befell him.

Oh Danny boy
by John Dunlap
Staff Writer

Four years later President
Bush and Vice President
Quayle were gone the Demo¬

cratic Ticket of then Governor
Bill Clinton and Senator Al
Gore came out on top, but the
outgoing Vice President must
have been happy, happy that he
had begun to repair his reputa
tion. Unlike 1988 when he was
not focused, in 1992 Vice Presi
dent Quayle ran a great cam
paign, one of the few bright
spots in the lackluster Bush
campaign. Unlike 1988 when
Senator Bentson got the best of
him, in 92 the Vice President
went after his opponent Sena
tor Gore and came off well.

With his attack of television
character, "Murphy Brown" for
glamorizing illegitimacy Dan
Quayle started a national de
bate that continues to this day.
His attack of the CBS television
program was mocked and
made fun of at first but by 1994
even President Clinton admit
ted along with most of the lib
eral media that had trashed
Quayle that yes, "Dan Quayle
was right."
His attack of illegitimacy
and his calls for a renewal of
family values won him strong

support among conservative
Republicans. His support of
life and issues that are impor
tant to the family have made
him a favorite among Christian
Conservatives. Today Dan
Quayle is a favorite campaigner
for Republicans running for
public office. The former Vice
President has been on the
stump campaigning with mod
erate Republican Governor
Christine Todd Whitman of
New Jersey to freshman after
freshman in the historic Repub
lican Congressional Class of
1994. He has written two
books and is putting together
a national organization. All
signs are pointing to a run for
the White House himself.
The allegations that Dan
Quayle is not intelligent are stu
pid comments themselves. He
is a great politician who was
able to win a U.S. House Seat

at the age of 29 and four years
after that in 1980, he defeated
longtime Indiana Senator Birch
Bayh, for Senator Bayh's Sen
ate seat. As Vice President his
work with the Competitiveness

Council was viewed positively.
There he fought big govern
ment and the regulations that
punish business. On the Space
Council he was given credit for
helping to restrengthen and
reenergize NASA and his calls
for tort reform and being
headed by the Republican Con
gress. Finally, unlike most poli
ticians, including the current
incumbent President, Dan
Quayle speaks his mind, and
when he does he says what
means and means what he says.
Dan Quayle is a politician
of conviction. In his first race
for Congress two issues that he
campaigned on were term-lim
its and the flat tax, both, espe
cially the latter will big issues
in 2000. Along with his wife,
Marilyn who is his strongest
advisor, and is pretty outspo
ken herself, the Quayles have
been in two national cam¬

paigns, they know what their
like and if they decide to give
2000 a try then Dan Quayle
should go beyond the expecta
tions that the media and the
political pundits will set for

him. If Dan Quayle wants to
remain in politics than he has
to run for President the next go
around. You can stay out of the
political game to long or else
you will be forgotten and the
Quayles know that but they
will strong competition. Some
of the former Vice Presidents
possible competitors include
the 1996 GOP Vice Presiden
tial Nominee, Jack Kemp, the
wife of the man on the top of
the 1996 Republican Ticket,
the President of the American
Red Cross, Elizabeth Dole, and
the son of the man who chose
him to be in the national spot
light and supported him while
he was there, Texas Governor
George W Bush. Beyond those
facing his numerous Republi
can opponents looms Vice
President Al Gore, the Demo
cratic front-runner, and I am
sure that Dan Quayle would
love to get a little revenge for

1992



To the Editor:

Some of our . favorite
things to complain about here
at Gettysburg are the apathetic
students, the uncooperative
administration, and the un
friendly community. AIDS
Awareness Week 1997 has
proven all of us who com
plained wonderfully wrong.
The following community part
ners, administrative and aca
demic departments and student
organizations gave their money,
time, support, and hard work
to make this week of AIDS
Awareness one of the "biggest

things to happen on campus in
a long time," in the words of
one administrator. Those
sponsors include:
The Center for Public
Service, The Office of College
Life, the Chaplain's Office and
the Chapel Council, the Get
tysburg Hospital, the Health
Center, Adams County AIDS
Community Resource Pro
gram, Allies, Student Senate,
Alumni Relations Office, the
Susquehanna Valley Names
Project, the Office of the Dean
of the College, the Office of the

President, Rotoract, ACTUP,
Adams County Family Plan
ning, Alpha Phi Omega, Greek
Organizations, CHEERS, the
Religion Department, the Phi

Math Colloquium 212 Gla
Dr. James P. Fink, Gettysburg
College "The Great Bridge Contro
versy "
Once upon a time long ago, a bridge
collapsed. The date was November
7, 1940, and the bridge was the
Tacoma Narrows Bridge. This
spectacular collapse was captured on
film, and resonance is frequently and
conveniently blamed for the disaster.
But what really happened on that
fateful day? What was the real
culprit? In this talk, we will take a
closer look at the fascinating story of
the Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse
and the ensuing controversy over its
cause. ALL STUDENTS AND
FACULTY ARE INVITED

faculty members will help students
clarify an assignment, plan for an
assignment, organize a paper,

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is '
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the Colleee Union. The Allies

bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more
information, contact any of the
following persons: Students:
Christian King (Allies moderator),
Ext. 8159; T.J. Scott (Allies secre
tary/treasurer), Ext. 7596; Alec
Beekmans, Ext. 7071; Helen
DeVinney, Ext. 7807; Faculty:

Hinrichs_, Ext. 6192; Administra
tors: Anne Bucher Lane, Ext.
6579; Bill Gohl, Ext. 6283.
REGISTRAR'S INFORMATION

HEALTH SERVICES

Hours for Health Services are
Monday through Friday from 8:30
am to 6:00 pm. Please call ext.
6970 or stop by to make an ap
pointment.
The Health Hotline, provides
non-emergency medical advice on
Saturdays from 10 am to 2 pm.
You can page a nurse practitioner
at 338-5283, enter the phone
number where you can be reached
and the nurse practitioner will call
you back. You will be advised on
self care, emergency room care,
physician consultation or health

service follow-up. OF COURSE,
IN AN EMERGENCY CALL
6911 OR 911 IMMEDIATELY!!
F. Kinsella
Needle Disposal - Anyone who
has the need of self- administering
medication by needle injection, we
ask that you collect your used
syringes and needles in a sharps
container. You may bring the full
container to the Health Service for
disposal. Ifyou do not have a
puncture proof sharps container, ,
you may pick one up at Health
Services at no charge. Let's keep
our community safe. F. Kinsella

Procedures for Reporting
Grades:
At the end of the semester we will
mail a grade report to your home
address. No grades will be re
leased to individuals at the
Registrar's Office during the exam
period. All grades are due from
instructors on Saturday, December
20 by 5:00 p.m. We expect to have
the grade reports
completed and in the mail by 5:00
on Tuesday, December 23. We
will send a second copy to an
alternate location ifyou have a
second parental address or to a
holiday address. Students with an
international address may request
that a copy be sent to their post

Men's and Women's swim teams leave
opponents doggie-paddling

by Kelly Brennan
Contributing Writer
The men's and women's
Swim Teams continued their
winning streak, beating Wash
ington College last Saturday.
The final score was 142 to 63
for the women, and 147 to 53
for the men. For the women,
Liz Burzio, Missy West, Kelly
Brennan, and Nicole
Hammerstrom won the 400
yard medley relay.
West also won the 200
yard breaststroke while
Brennan finished first in the
200-yard butterfly. In the 200
yard freestyle, senior co-cap
tain Janel Pfeifer placed first,
while junior Megan Lewis fin
ished first in the 50-yard
freestyle.

Sophomore Leanne
Rebuck won the 200-yard in
dividual medley with a winning
time of 2:22.44. In the 100
yard freestyle, junior Carolyn
Thorpe finished first followed
by a first place in the 200-yard
backstroke by fellow classmate
Keri Kaylor. In the final relay,
Kaylor teamed up with Pfeifer,
Brennan, and Lewis to win the
400-yard freestyle relay.
Junior Mairead
Hartmann also'had a great
meet, finishing second in both
the 1000-yard freestyle and the
500-yard freestyle, and anchor
ing the second place 400-yard
freestyle relay.

Men's Basketball is burning up the hardwood at 4-0

by Paul Redfern
Contributing Writer
The Gettysburg College
Men's Basketball team has
started out with a sizzling 4-0
record. The team is led by se
nior Co-Captains Terry
Schofield and John Bauersfeld.
The Bullets will look to several
returning players to make large
contributions this year includ
ing Junior Matt Rothenberger
and Sophomore Ryan Napp.
Transfers Jon Bowman
and Bill Davidson, a junior and
sophomore, respectively, along
with sophomore Kevin Tonkins
rounds out the starting five.
Off the bench the Bullets will
look to junior Kevin Carrol,
sophomores Riche Pfeil, Brett
Miller and Jason Hummel.
Mike Monroe, Josh San
Martino, and Greg Schneber
are the lone three freshmen to
make the squad.

The Bullets opened up
the season at home with the
Gettysburg College Days Inn
Tournament. The Bullets
hosted the Kueka Warriors in
their first game. The Bullets
moved out to an early first half
lead and won the game 78-48.
JNapp led the Bullets with 17
points and Tonkins added 8
boards.
When the Warriors drew

Men s soccer closes out tremendous season

From Gettysburg Sports Release
Saddled with just a 3-3
record six games into the 1997
campaign, the Gettysburg Col
lege men's soccer team went on
a 15-game unbeaten streak that
not only landed the Bullets in
the NCAA Division HI playoffs
but carried them all the way to
the quarterfinals.
The 15-game unbeaten
streak, which included a pair of
ties , was just one of many
school records established dur
ing the season. The Bullets
broke the team record for goals
in a season by scoring 69 times.
The former mark of 62 was set
in 1995.
The 2-0 loss to New Jer
sey, in .the Division II
quarterfinals also brought an
end to the redord setting career
of Greg Stevcic. Stevcic was the
Bullets second-leading scorer in
1997 with 12 goals and 15 as¬

sists. Stevcic will leave Gettys
burg with the following
records: goals in a career (45),

goals in a season (21 in 1995),
assists in a career (33), assists
in a season (15), points in a
career (123) and points in a
season (49 in 1995). Kind of
impressive.
The Bullets' leading
scorer this season was stellar
sophomore forward Chris
Pryor. He supplied Head
Coach Dave Wright's squad
with 17 goals and seven assists.
Pryor's goal total was the sec
ond highest in school history.
In addition, to this feat, he

matched th,e school record for
assists in a game by assisting
three goals in the 5-0 victory
over Washington.
Senior midfielder Brian
Hill and sophomore forward
Jason Vishio each accounted
for seven of the Bullets 69
scores. Hill had seven assists
to go along with his seven
goals, while Vishio was cred
ited with four assists.
The leading scorer
among freshmen was
midfielder Jeremy Shapiro. In
his first season at Gettysburg,

Photo by Emily Glatfeltei
Sophomore goals leader Chris Pryor tries to toss the ball downfield to one of his teammates.

Shapiro tickled the twine with
four goals and also tallied three
assists.
Junior goalie John
Katerba is on the verge of es
tablishing a new school record

for shutouts. He had seven
shutouts in 1997, boosting his
career total to 17. The record
of 18 is held by both Mike
Battagha and Tom Ashworth.
Katerba benefitted from

the best defense around in
three solid starters. Playing all
22 games for the Bullets were
backs senior Matt Kelly, junior
Josh Rubinich, and junior Jim
Green.

Trustees allot $50,000 for social events

by Daniel Larkin
News Editor
The Gettysburg College Board of
Trustees has alloted $50,000 to fund
social events for the 1998 spring semes
ter. President Haaland and Dean
Ramsey announced this at the January
19 Student Senate meeting.
The new funding was the result
of a meeting the trustees had with a
group of six students at the end of last
semester about social life on campus.
Val Katzmar, one of the six stu
dents, said that the group was "pretty
blunt," in addressing the board.

Katzmar said that the students told the
trustees that social life on campus has
been suffering over the last two years.
Katzmar said that the restrictions the
current BYOB policy places on frater
nity parties has created a lack of social
outlets on campus.
Katzmar, a member of senate's
Social Life Commitee, said the students
asked the trustees for a possible bar or
dance club on campus. According to
Katzmar, President Haaland responded
by asking what the students would do
if they were given money to fund social
events.
The group of six students
(Katzmar, Becca O'Connell, Mark

Astrom, Jen Gillete, Rodwin Lowe, and
Marcelo Ardon) were chosen to be rep
resentative of diverse aspects of
Gettysburg life, including Greeks, Non
Greeks, Student Government, and mi
nority students.
These six students now compr ise
an ADHOC committee formed for the
purpose of administering the $50,000
to student groups interested in putting
on ad-campus social functions.
According to Katzmar money will
be granted to student organizations re
questing to hold all-campus social
events. The adminstration of these
funds will be handled completely by the
student committee.

Katzmar said that only three cri
teria are necessary for receiving these
funds: the event must be an all-campus
event, it must follow the BYOB guide
lines, and the committee will need all
receipts.
Katzmar urged students to "take
advantage of this large amount of
money," noting that another popular
campus event, the Snow Ball costs
about $3000.
Student groups wishing to gain
access to these funds will be able to ap
proach the committee in the coming
weeks. Katzmar said that there are al
ready "lots of good ideas in the works.'

Student vehicles vandalized during Winter Break

by Laura Root
Staff Reporter Eight cars were found vandalized
in the Bream/Wright/Hauser and Sta
dium parking lots on January 6. In each
vehicle, windows were broken. Some
car owners also reported stolen items
to the Borough Police. This makes the
crime not only vandalism but larceny.
Gettysburg College Safety and
Security responded to the situation right
away. The vandalized vehicles were
towed to a compound for safe-keeping,
and their owners were informed of the
situation. Unfortunately, most car
owners were not were not accessible
due to participation in Gettysburg
sports activities.
Gettysburg College has agreed to
pay for the broken windows. Car own
ers with missing items are in contact
with their insurance companies to help
pay for those damages.

Safety and Security does not yet
have any indication of who might have
committed the crime. Because the van
dalism occurred over the Winter Break.
Nor do they also do not know exactly
when the crime took place.
To prevent this from happening
again, Safety and Security is increasing
their patrol of all parking lots. There
is also a possibility of cameras being in
stalled in order to monitor probelm ar
eas more effectively also exists. Sergeant
Witt, a member of the Safety and Secu
rity team, also suggested taking the fol
lowing precautions in the future:
-report all suspicious activities to
Campus Security
-store valuables in the trunk
instead of in plain view
-keep doors locked/ keeping
windows up
-park in a well-lit area

photo by Emily Glaneiter
Vehicles parked in the lots of Gettysburg College are under the surveillance
of Safety & Security.

Professors to lecture
on Nuclear
Weapons

GCPR Professors from
Princeton University and the
Massachusetts Institute of
Technology (MIT) will come
to Gettysburg College for a de
bate on nuclear weapons and
energy in South Asia at 7:30
p.m., Thursday, Jan. 29, in
Room 260 of the College
Union Building. The program
will be moderated by Profes
sor Peter Pella of Gettysburg
College, who worked on the
Nuclear Disarmament treaty.
The public is invited to attend,
free of charge.
Dr. Zia Mian currently
works at the Center for Energy
and Environmental Studies at
Princeton University. She also
taught at Quad-e-Azam Uni
versity, Islamabad, and was a
research fellow at the Sustain
able Development Policy Insti
tute in Islamabad and at the
Union of Concerned Scientists,
Cambridge, Mass.

Mian is editor of
"Pakistan's Atomic Bomb and
The Search for Security" and
has been a columnist with
"The News," and English
newspaper published in Paki
stan. She is also a member of
the Coordinating Committee
of the International Network
of Engineers and Scientists
Against Proliferation and an
advisor to the United Nations
Nongovernment Organization
(NGO) Committee on Disar
mament.

Dr. M.V. Ramana, a
postdoctoral fellow at MIT's
Center for International Stud
ies, completed his undergradu
ate degree at the Indian Insti
tute of Technology in Kanpur
and earned a doctorate degree
from Boston University. He
served as a postdoctoral fellow
at the University of Toronto
before being awarded an
SSRC-MacArthur Postdoctoral
Fellowship on International
Peace and Security in a Chang
ing World in 1996. Ramana
began his work at MIT in Sep
tember 1996.

Recital to
feature tenor

GCPR Tenor Jeffery Fahnestock,
a voice instructor at
Susquehanna University and
Dickinson College, will present
a recital at Gettysburg College
at 3 p.m., Sunday, Jan. 25, in
Schmucker Recital Hall. The
solo voice recital-which will
include music by Beethoven,
Chausson, Turina, and Britten
-will feature accompinment by
pianist Michael Matsinko and
is open to the public free of
charge. A visiting artist at
Gettysburg College,
Fahenstock maintains a busy
performing schedule in addi
tion to his teaching duties. He

has appeared across the United
States, singing with choirs and
orchestras in Boston, Tulsa,
Philadelphia, Washingotn, and
other cities. A specialist in ora
torio and recital literature,
Fahnestock also frequently per
forms the operatic repetoire.
Fahnestock holds de
grees from the Eastman School
of Music at the University of
Rochester and the Peabody In
stitution of the Johns Hopkins
University, which awarded him
its Artist Diploma in 1991.
Fahnestock has held fellow
ships at the Tanglewood,
Ravinia, and Blossom Music
Festivals.

Associate professor of
music Michael Matsinko has
been a member of the
Gettysburg College faculty
since 1975. Former director of
the college's Chapel Choir, his
current responsibilities include
teaching music history and lit
erature , and keyboard studies.
Matsinko is also serving as
chair of the music department
this year.

——Features
Views from the outside

by Cara Masucci
Staff Writer Starting college is an ex
perience many people say they
will never forget. First year stu
dents are constantly bom
barded with advice. Older stu
dents describe what to expect
and the activities taking place
on campus, your parents tell
you that you need to balance
your social plans with studying,
and everyone warns you to es
tablish a good relationship with
your roommate. These are
some standard topics of discus
sion that a typical freshman is
likely to engage in.
However, one issue is of
ten left out: how it feels to go
back to where you came from.

6 months

Going back home is a unique
experience for everyone, and
visiting your old high school
can seem especially odd. Many
first year students return to
their high schools for the first
time over the winter break.
Talking to students, most
everyone seems to agree that
seeing the friends they left be
hind and visiting their favorite
teachers are the main reason
they went back to their old high
school.
For Anne Corrigan, a
freshman from Lancaster, PA,
the experience, was no differ
ent. Having left some of her
closest friends behind, who
were a year younger, she was
happy to return.
People had different reac
tions to her appearance at her
former school. Sometimes she
says she was looked at strangely
as people wondered what she
was doing there, but as soon as

people got over the initial
shock, they were really excited
to see her.
One of Anne's favorite
teachers sat her down and
made her relate every aspect of
her life at college. The teacher
even called her by the nick
name she had given Anne
when she taught her in class.
With the new addition
that had just been added to the
school, Anne felt a little over
whelmed at first. "One of my
friends had to show me
around!" she exclaimed. For
tunately, though, she was able
to see everyone and everything
she had hoped to see.

In Case You Missed It —
Tommy Boy leaves comedic Farley legacy

by Eileen O'Donnell
Contributing Writer
Tommy Boy, released in
1995, is the first of two road
movies Chris Farley made with
Saturday Night Live costar
David Spade (the other movie
is Black Sheep). Previously,
Farley played bit parts in SNL
skits-to screen movies like
Wayne's World and Coneheads.
Farley is at his finest, star
ring Tommy Callahan, a recent
college grad all set to work at
his dad's auto parts plant.
Seven years after starting col
lege, Tommy's life is on the
right track. He has an execu
tive position, his father is re
marrying, and Tommy's going

to have a brother. Holy
Schnikes! Things couldn't be
better. But then everything takes
a turn for the worse. After Big
Tom's sudden death, Tommy
has to take over his dad'b sale
route with only his dad's smug
assistant, Richard (Spade) to
guide him.
Wacky adventures ensue
as Tommy and Richard try to
sell brake pads before the bank
forecloses on Callahan Auto
and his evil stepbrother and
stepmother (Rob Lowe and Bo
Derek) take over what's left of
the family fortune.
Lowe shines as Tommy's
menacing stepbrother, Paul.
Lowe has gone from playing

the heartthrob of such Brat
Pack films as St. Elmo's Fire
andT/;e Outsiders to playing
the villain in Wayne's World
and Tommy Boy. Lowe, how
ever, is a villain subject to con
stant mockery and ridicule
from the movie's heroes.
Another face to look for
is SNL alum Dan Akroyd, who
plays a small role as an auto
parts tycoon interested in buy
ing out Callahan Auto.
Both Farley and Spade
are at their funniest in this film.
These two comedians comple
ment each other with their in
dividual styles. They are polar
opposites: Spade with his dry,
sarcastic humor, and Farley
with his lovable buffoonery and

physical comedy.
Farley and Spade offer a
fresh look at traditional com
edy teams like Abbott and
Costello and Laurel and Hardy
Both Farley and Spade make
the jump to the big screen with
ease. Like Mike Myers, Dana
Carvey, and Adam Sandier,
Farley and Spade have made
several movies with other SNL
stars like Chris Rock, Dan
Akroyd, and Will Ferrell.
Farley will be best re
membered as the bumbling but
well-meaning slob. This is a
role he reprises in Black Sheep
as Mike Donnelly, the brother
of a political candidate. Mike
does more harm than good in
his attempt to help his brother's

campaign, so Spade is sent to
keep him out of the way. The
chemistry between Spade and
Farley makes Black Sheep a hit
as well.
Farley once more plays
the lovable buffoon as "the
great white ninja" in Beverly
Hills Ninja.
Farley followed the foot
steps of his larger-than-life idol
John Belushi. Like Belushi, his
untimely death has been la
mented, for it will be a long
time coming before the world
sees a fresh comedic face like
Farley's.
Other films starring Chris
Farley:
Black Sheep
Beverly Hills _Ntn_/a

Good Will Hunting Is

by Mike Petro and Dan Larkin
Op/Ed and News Editors
Before we begin, our hats
go off to the Majestic theater
for finally installing some de¬

cent seats. Glad to see where
that three dollars I paid for a
soda is going. However, this is
not the only reason to go and
see Good Will Hunting.
The story of Hunting at
first glance is quite simple. Will
Hunting, a troubled youth
from South Boston holding
down a job as a janitor at MIT
divides his time between drink
ing, fighting, and higher math¬

ematics. One thing leads to
another and his genius is soon
discovered, along with his
troubles. What follows is a
wonderfully written story
about relationships, personal
demons, and how we all must
deal with them.
The fact that this is movie
had been billed as a "wonder
fully written story about rela
tionships, personal demons, and

how we all must deal with
them," worried me at first.
But Good Will Hunting really
impressed me. I was expecting
a sappy romantic drama, but
instead found a thoughtfully
directed and intelligently
scripted film. Sure , it's tragic
and romantic. But it's done in
a realistic, non-melodramatic
way. In addition to an excellent
story, the film is set against a
very colorful background . As
a Massachusetts native, my fa
vorite part was the wonderful

Southie accents heard through
out the movie.
This really is a good
movie. Matt Damon {The
Rainmaker, School Ties, Cour
age Under Fire), the newest
Hollywood find, in the title
role, stars with an excellent
supporting cast including Ben
Affleck {ChasingAmy, Mallrats,
Phantoms) as Chuckie, Robin
Williams {Good Morning Viet
nam, Dead Poet's Society,
Awakenings) as Shawn, and
Minnie Driver {Grosse Point
Blank, Circle of Friends).

All actors turn in believ
able and powerful perfor
mances that draw the viewer in
and make them connect with
the characters. Beyond the per
formances, this is a very well
written movie with a believable
and engaging story.
The acting is really amaz
ing in this movie. It's really

good to see Robin Williams do
ing good movies again. He's a
very good actor, but in the past
couple of years he's been floun
dering in ridiculous family
drivel. fFlubber and Father's
Day spring imediately to mind.)
I don't think I 've liked him this
much in a movie since The
Fisher King. I loved Ben Affleck
in Chasing Amy, and he's even
better here. Matt Damon proves
that's he more than just a pretty
face, with an unbelievable per
formance. His character is the
perfect mix of Southie street
punk and mathematical genius.
All three o f these guys should
be, at least, considered at Os
car time. As the only female
member o f the film 's excellent
cast, Minnie Driver, more than
holds her own as Damon's ro
mantic foil.

Overall, I give this movie
a four and a half out of five
stars. Robin Williams deserves
serious consideration for an
Academy Award, acknowledg
ing his true talent as a dramatic
actor, and the screenplay, co
written by Damon and Affleck
is one of the best to hit the
screen in a long time. In short,
go see this movie.
/ don't see why anyone
wouldn't like Good Will Hunt
ing. In short, it's a wicked good
movie. I give it " fouh out of
five stahs."

to deal with the ongoing con
struction, but we never got to
use the new parts of the

school," she says.

for many reasons. Some sim
ply have no desire to return to
a place that holds nothing (or
bad memories) for them, while
others do not want to face the
changes or admit to themselves
that they are growing up.
Gardner estimated that
17 people from his hometown
were attending Gettysburg
when he first arrived and does
not recall any of them return
ing to visit the high school.
"High schools don't do
anything to bring back old stu
dents. Mine was a public
school, so they weren't look
ing for money. They don't
need us after we've graduated,"
he commented.

Though high schools may
not encourage graduates to
visit, many find the relation
ships with old friends and
former teachers a strong
enough incentive to return to
their alma mater.

time, though, once he got over

The first time students
return to high school is often a
very enjoyable experience.
People are excited to see some
one who has gotten out, and
the alum feels the pleasure of
being able to laugh at what was
left behind.
However, the more often
a person returns, the less plea
surable it is. The high schoolers
begin to scorn the alum, won
dering what kind of social life

the cool graduate actually
leads. Alums have been kicked
off campuses for being around
too much.
Some students agreed
that certain changes were not
for the better. Several students
who attended high school in
upstate New York were upset
to learn that the administration
in their high schools had taken
a disappointing step in becom
ing much more strict in rules
and regulations.
One school, better

known for high-test scores than
a drug problem, had a dog
brought in to sniff out the stu
dents' lockers for illegal sub¬

nces.
This shows the lack of
trust the administration feels
for the student body. One stu
dent commented, "I'm glad I
got out when I did!" Other
than the tightened security
measures within the school, the
student was glad to see her old
friends.
For most freshmen at
Gettysburg, the experience of
going back to their alma mater
is a positive one. Initially, see
ing friends for the first time in
over four months feels awk
ward, but as time goes on, the
students begin to feel more
comfortable as old ties are
reawakened.
The sentiment was best
expressed by Anne Corrigan,
who said, "I will never forget
the people or the experiences,
because they made me who I
am."

Consider this

Safety 8c Security's of
fice on the corner of Washing
on and Stevens Streets acts as
)ur own Legion of Justice, but
:hey are much maligned in our
:ommunity.
As one yells for help,
superman is expected to arrive
n a timely fashion. What
)eople don't realize is that
_Juperman also has to go and
escue countless other students
ill over campus—from fire
darms and lockouts to escort
ng the wary home.
Complaints range from
legligence to sluggishness to
gnorance.
The recent vandalism
_ind larceny to cars over Win
:er Break has brought an ad
litional onslaught of criticism
:o Safety & Security.

Safety & Security does a
fine job in dealing with situa
ions such as lockouts and re
sponding to fire alarms, but
ieems to have a harder time ef
fectively responding to more
serious crimes. They are not a
jolice force, nor do we wish
:hem to be; however, it seems
idd that they did not notice
so many vehicles which were
iamaged in such an obvious
;tate. Is the persecution war
ranted, or is the alleged negli
gence the effect of the aug¬

mented responsibilities from an
increased student population
and extended campus grounds?
But over Winter Break,
there were no students.
Superman never made ce
lebrity guest appearances. Yet
Safety & Security is often called
into situations where they aren't
needed. This overuse of these
services is partly to blame on
overly anxious students whose
problems could be solved by an
other agency.
Furthermore, Safety &
Security's usefulness is question
able in some scenarios in which
anything they could do would be
futile. An example of such a situ
ation would be sexual assault.
This type of a situation il
lustrates the limits of the system
as it stands, since the officers
don't have a "legal leg to stand
on." They do have disciplinary
measures at their disposal, but
these actions are rarely taken.

We are not attempting to
bash Safety & Security. They
provide an invaluable service to
our campus community, and on
many occasions respond quickly
and effectively. They cannot be
everywhere at once.
Safety & Security are not
the police; nor are they members
of the Super Friends. And even
without super powers, they serve
the College community well.

The Pachyderm's Pulpit True diversity

by John Dunlap
Staff'Witer For at least the moment
it appears as if the President of
the United States will have to
put down his golf clubs, stop
talking about his legacy, and in
stead, deal with a crisis brew
ing in his Administration. A
crisis dealing not only with al
legations of an extra-marital
affair, but allegations concern
ing the possibility that Presi
dent Clinton, along with his
longtime friend, the Chairman
of his 1992-93 Presidential
Transition Team, Vernon Jor
dan, may have influenced and
urged the 23 year old woman
involved in the affair, former
White House Intern Monica
Lewinsky, to lie under oath to
lawyers for Paula Jones the
woman suing the President for
sexual harassment.

Bill Clinton is said to be
outraged, but the source of this
allegation, Monica Lewinsky,
was tape-recorded by one of
her friends, former White
House Staffer Linda Tripp. On
the tape, Lewinsky speaks
about her year and a half rela
tionship with President
Clinton, and how along with
the President, Mr. Jordan urged
her to lie. According to these
same tapes Vernon Jordan was
arranging a new job for Miss
Lewinsky in New York. Linda
Tripp's allegations go even fur
ther, as she informed
Newsweek magazine that Presi
dent Clinton made sexual ad
vances towards another White
House Staffer, Kathleen Willey
in the Oval Office. All of these
combined help the case of Paula

Jones who alleges that then
Governor Clinton sexually ha
rassed her in 1991. The Su
preme Court has ordered Ms.
Jones's case against the Presi
dent to go forward.
The White House is de
nying the charges, and Miss
Lewinsky is standing behind
her affidavit denying the
charges but her lawyer, William
Ginsburg has blasted the Presi
dent if the charges are possibly
true. Whitewater Special Pros
ecutor Kenneth Starr has been
given approval by both the Jus
tice Department and the courts
to look into the matter of the
President urging a cover-up.
Once again I am sure that
the liberals in the press and on
this campus are going to try to

attack the Special Prosecutor
and try to attack those doing
the investigation like they al
ways do to escape blame. This
time there are tapes, and for
once we can perhaps see what
Bill Clinton is really like and
how his White House is run.
Congress should now step in
and take a look at these tapes
and determine what abuse has
really occurred. To those who
attack Kenneth Starr, who was
able to get a conviction against
Bill Clinton's hand-picked suc
cessor as Governor of Arkan
sas, Jim Guy Tucker, could you
please open your eyes and see
that after this many scandals,
indictments, and convictions,
that our President has a prob
lem telling the truth to the
American people.

Now, more than legal
troubles, President Clinton
faces questions of trust and of

leadership. Just a few weeks
ago, we saw the President danc
ing on the beach with his wife,
our First Lady, Hillary Rodham
Clinton. Now we hear stories
of the President committing
adultery while he is President,
with someone just a few years
older than his daughter, and
possibly in the White House.
Bill Clinton would not be the
first President to have commit
ted adultery in the White
House but with the reporting
of it, he should have known
better. Almost six years ago on
60 Minutes , he admitted that
he and his wife had problems
but said they were in the past.
Miss Lewinsky did not start
working for the White House
until December of 1995. If this

is true, then once again Bill
Clinton has broken faith with
people he was elected to serve.
I am not the most moral
of people, anyone who knows
me will tell you that. In fact,
we all make mistakes but Will
iam Jefferson Clinton is the
President of the United States
and today that office is in dis
grace. After Watergate,
Presidents Ford, Carter, and
Reagan were able to give honor
back to the office, but that is
being destroyed. The moral
leadership of the President is
gone, and no longer can small
children look up to the Com
mander-in-Chief. The investi
gation should continue and if
the President broke the law
than perhaps we have had one
scandal too many.

by Jay Spiese
Staff Writer In the spirit of Martin
Luther King Jr. Day, I shall milk
a new sacred cow on campus:
diversity. We have all heard
people whine about the lack of
diversity. Sometimes we are the
guilty party.
Let's be honest with our
selves and others. When we say
"diversity," we really mean race.
There aren't enough blacks
here. There aren't enough
Asians here. Why don't we

have more Jews? Is there a way
we can recruit more Hispanics?
If this is what we believe makes
a place diverse, then we are far
too centered on images.
Diversity is not a matter
of how we look. If we had ev
ery race equally represented on
this campus, the diversity
would not change. True diver
sity comes from the mind. It is
our thoughts and our beliefs
that make us unique. Diversity
on campus is achievable if we
allow these thoughts and beliefs
to be freely expressed.

So then, how does our
campus stand on diversity? We
have vocal groups like ALLIES
who freely express their opin
ions. (Amazingly they do so
with little open mainstream re
sistance as evidenced by the
universal free zone that is Get
tysburg campus. If you aren't
sure what I mean then try to
find a building or office that
does not have one of those tri
angles). We have a number of
groups who should be contro¬

versial but aren't. GECO
spends five hundred dollars to
bring a speaker up from Wash
ington, but has done nothing to
clean up the Tiber area. Our
resident communists (all three
of them) were praised for their
determination to show diver
sity. I've often wondered if the
same license would be given to
a Neo-Fascist party. Were I
pessimistic in nature I would
ascribe it to a sense of apathy,
the "to- hell-with-the-world
I'd-rather-get-drunk" attitude.
Since I started writing

these articles, I have received
far more support than disagree
ment. But most of this is done
privately in whispered tones.
These individuals often don't
want to stand up and say that a
popular movement is wrong.
Many people feel the college
community does not want
them to disagree with politi
cally correct, feel good groups
like ALLIES. And so they act
in secret against the group.
Murmured discontent, tearing
down the triangle stickers, and
slurs I will not mention here.

If we want true diversity
on this campus then we must
be prepared for what that
means. We will have people
speaking from all points of the
spectrum. If someone says that
blacks should be sent back to
Africa then we can (and indeed
should) disagree, but we must
allow him to express his view
with the same freedom guaran
teed to us all.

The Junction is a versatile community
space combining a comfortable
atmosphere with a high quality
programming area. It is an open
attendance space that is a
welcoming living room designed to be
used for informal gatherings and
scheduled programming. The Junction is
intended for interaction amongst and
between the Gettysburg College
community and at times to extend that
interaction to the greater community
beyond Gettysburg College.

What a tangled
WEBBER we weave

by Stephen Jenkins
Sports Editor

Here is a big surprise.
"NBA player arrested for vio
lations stemmining from a rou
tine traffic stop." Wow. You
don't say.
Yes, once again another
National Basketball Association
star, Chris Webber, goes down
the tubes after being charged
with assault, resisting arrest,
possesion of marijuana, driving
while under the influence of
marijuana and five other traf
fic related violations.
Multiple players have
been arrested in the past year
including Philadelphia Seventy
Sixers guard Allen Iverson,
most for some drug realted of
fense. Reportedly, police had to
exceed the forty mile per hour
speed limit to keep up with
Webber's car. When he was
checked, Webber could not
provide license, registration
nor proof of ownership of his
vehicle.

Apparently, Webber was
slow to answer the policeman's
questions and when the officer
reached to open Webber's door
to remove him from the car,
Webber batted his hand away
and proceeded to assualt the
man. Once he was tamed by
pepper spray, Webber was de
tained, and legally charged.
So, once again, the al
ready unexciting NBA has been
dealt a low blow by one of it's
tremendously overpaid em
ployees. Is it because the play
ers are young and immature?
Do they leave college or high
school early just for the multi
million dollar contracts teams
wave in front of them?
Of course. In case you
did not know, Webber is only a
few years our senior, and he
makes more in one year what
most of our parents will ever
see in a lifetime. He is already
making decisions that men of
his age normally would not be
making for some time.

The NBA has nothing in
their drug policy that forbids
the use of marijuana. Hello,
marijuana is illegal. If it is
against the law in the United
States of America, it should
also be illegal in the NBA.
Wait, that would be infringing
upon the rights of the players
to freely express themselves
with a joint. Yeah, good one.
Frankly the NBA, has to
reform its drug policies and
crack down on the more, irre
sponsible actions of the imma
ture players of the National
Basketball Assiociation. I can
see it now, "Hey, Chris Webber

Casares, Carroll, Lavigne_, Peters and
Quinn head the men's swimming team

From Gettysburg Press
Release Through the Gettysburg
men's swimming team's first
four competitions of the 1997
98 campaign, 10 different
swimmers have turned in first
place performances in indi
vidual events.
Senior Pete Casares, was
a double winner in
Gettysburg's convincing 162
25 victory over Ursinus on
January 17, a meet which saw
the Bullets' record improve to

2-0. Casares won the 100yd
freestyle in 49.95 seconds and
the 1000yd freestyle in
10:44.89, and also anchored
the winning 400yd free relay.
Casares was also a part of
200yd free relay at the Frank
lin & Marshall Invitational that
established a new school
record. Casares, along with
first year swimmer David
Lavigne, and junior Rich
Carroll, and senior Todd Peters,
completed the race in 1:25.55,

2-0, CC & overall

3-0, CC & overall

knocking almost a full second
off of the old school record
which stood for almost five
years. Junior Gavin Quinn also

medley and 200yd breast
(stroke).

vidual events in their other dual

over Washington, but had no
double winners.

SportsWeekly
Men's hoops squad dribbling all over competition

By Paul Redfern
Staff Writer The Gettysburg College
Men's Basketball team beat
conference rival Dickinson 74
72 on Saturday to improve
their overall record to 7-7 and
their Centennial Conference
record to 2-2. After starting
out fast with a 5-0 record the
Bullets hit a skid, losing three
to Muhlenberg, Goucher, and
Navy before leaving for Christ
mas break.
After break the Bullets
opened at home with a tough
84-83 overtime loss to

Elizebethtown. After an im
pressive victory over Mary
Washigton the Bullets dropped
three more to Catholic, Alfred,
and Johns Hopkins.
Dickinson came into
the game unbeaten in the Cen
tennial Conference posting a 3
0 record. They won the Con
ference Championship last year
to earn a berth in the Division
III National Championship
Tournament. The Bullets after
suffering their worse loss of the
season to Johns Hopkins came
into the game very much in
need of a win.

Pfeil led the Bullets scoring
while Junior center Matt
Rothenburger led the rebound
ing efforts with a game high of
12. Gettysburg got going early
with offensive scoring behind
their Co-Captain Senior for
ward Terry Schofield.
