the game with 16 first half
points from their Senior center
Nate Brought.
Brought was a force as
both a scorer and a rebounder
in the first half. With Sopho
more forward Bill Davidson out
with an ankle sprain Freshman
Mike Monroe stepped up for
the Bullets and provided some
depth off the bench. Gettys
burg went into the locker room
down 11, 44-33.

In the second half the
bullets came to play. With a mix
of both man and zone defenses
the Bullets were able to take
control of the tempo of the
game. Junior Kevin Carrol hit
some big 3 point field goals
down the stretch for the Bullets.

Rothenburger and Bowman
played excellent tandem de-

Alpha Xi Delta withdraws from Formal Rush

Right Now

Chapter seeks more effective way to recruit new members

By Laura Root
Staff Reporter The Beta Chi chapter of Alpha Xi
Delta has withdrawn from Formal
Panhellenic Rush this year. Instead, the
chapter will conduct its own informal
rush in February.
The withdrawal was originally
proposed by Alpha Xi Delta National
Headquarters in November.
In past years, Formal Rush has not
been as sucessful as the chapter would
have liked. After the death of Casey
Dunn last semester, the organization
has 18 members.
The Chapter president, Marcie
DePalma stated that "In the past few
years, the numbers have gone down for
every sorority. By doing something dif
ferent, we're trying to rebuild the chap
rer." DePalma also added: "we are not

looking just to increase our numbers;
the quality of women we want to re
cruit is very important."
By withdrawing from rush, Alpha
Xi Delta is infact helping the other four
sororities by allowing them take larger
pledge classes, since they can only draw
from the women registered for rush.
Currently, 117 women are going
through rush. "Panhel and the other
sororities have been very supportive,"
said DePalma.
The chapter participated in last
weekend's first round of Formal Rush,
but will not participate in this
weekend's festivities. Instead, it will
offer informal events, including a Pub
lic Relations Week during the first week
of February, a Mocktail Party before the
February 6 Snow Ball, a visit to the Al
pha Xi Delta philanthropy of the
Children's Hospital on February 7, and
a Coffee House on February 8. An in-

rnoio oy _tmiiy tiianeiier
Alpha Xi DeltaSisters chat with Rushees _durinq the first round of parties last Friday.

formation session will be held on Feb
ruary 13. These events are open to all
non-greek females on campus.
"The entire chapter is working
tirelessly to make this work for every
one," said DePalma. "We are incred
ibly excited and very enthusiastic about
rush this year.
Alpha Xi Delta will deliver bids
on Sunday, February 15. The strategy
that Alpha Xi Delta is planning to fol
low is not new. It has been tried in sev
eral sororities at many different colleges
and has been very successful. Next year,
Alpha Xi Delta plans to return to the
formal rush practice after using this new
opportunity to increase its numbers.
"Doing normal rush hasn't been
helping us," DePalma said. She called
the new process "a more relaxed and
informal way to meet rushees. We want
a chance to really get to know these
women in a way that formal rush

doesn't allow."
"In the past, we've brought in
more new members during informal
rush," she said.
Most members of Alpha Xi Delta
feel that the change in rushing policies
is for the better. Tamara King, an Edu
cational Leadership Consultant for Al
pha Xi Delta National Headquarters,
observed that, "A lot of the women rush
ing sororities today are not interested
in the frills and pressures of Formal
Rush."
DePalma commented that "We
have a lot of support from National
Headquarters," and said that Alpha Xi's
alumni "support any effort to help
strengthen the chapter."
The informal festivities will be a
less stressful method to join the sister
hood of Alpha Xi Delta than the more
structured rushes of past years.

The $50,000 Question
Student Life Committee will allocate money for social activities

by Keith Davis
Staff Reporter
Across most of the cam
pus, arguments about the lack
of social activity available have
left fault with the administra
tion. Now, a new opportunity
aimed at strengthening student
activities lies solely in the hands
of the students.
The Student Life Com
mittee will be responsible for
allocating $50,000 in an at
tempt to strengthen and im
prove the current social situa
tion. The committee will have
its first official meeting today
to establish its operating meth
ods and determine how it will
function in the lives of students.
According to Dean
Ramsey, the SLC is intended to
be an experiment that places
more responsibility on students
so they can make the necessary
initiatives to improve social
activities.

"It is clear that because of
BYOB the social life is chang
ing," Ramsey said.
Ramsey further com
mented that the college could
do a better job in providing
more social outlets, especially
to first year students and
sophomores. But the adminis
tration decided that students
needed to be taking the initia
tives and risks involved also.

Consequently, President
Haaland decided to offer
$50,000 to the now forming
SLC. "The idea of this commit
tee is to put this money directly
in the hands of the students,"
Ramsey said. "I want to leave
maximum flexibility to the
[committee]."

Ramsey _8 et are
discussed « We want to help plan! 1 ;^ 7
the moti- r r e s t a t> -
v b a eh. ° n n d s something fantastic " lshed
the "The
money. -Jen Gillette 1 w °
Accord- groups

ing to Ramsey, the money is not
the most important issue.
Ramsey wants people to get out
of the complaining mode.
"This is the time for the
creativity to come forward,"
she said. "If you don't like the
way it is, here is a chance to
change it."
Although SLC is an ex
periment, the outcome is not
considered as important as the
opportunity.
"The real emphasis is on
trying new things and improv
ing social lives, not whether or
not the project fails," Ramsey
said. Dean Ramsey also said
the committee was designed in
order to be independent of

other organizations to avoid
becoming part of the bureau
cratic system. The committee
will be structured but not
enough to hamper the oppor
tunity. The money was not
given to SAC, the current or
ganization offering alternative
activities to the Greek system,
because their schedule and bud-

will compliment each other. We
will have to becareful not to
step on SAC's shoulders,"
Ramsey said. "SAC is and will
continue to be the main pro
grammer of campus activities."
Ramsey expects that the
experiment will end in one of
two ways. The first is if the
committee is unable to estab
lish itself as a popular resource,
SAC could apply for greater
funds. The second option
would be that if the committee
did establish itself as a popular
resource then the administra
tion would examine the possi
bility of continuing the SLC
program. Ramsey encourages
caution however, because she
says the nature of social activ¬

ity needs to be subject to
change. This change would
need to come from constant

innovation.
The SLC is an experiment
currently contained only to the
spring semester. "[President
Haaland] has made no prom
ise that it would be an ongoing
basis," Ramsey said. In regards
to this opportunity, she said, "I
am pretty optimistic."
The six SLC members
were chosen by the administra
tion to discuss problems of so
cial life with the college's trust
ees. The committee formed
from the discussion. The mem
bers represent a wide range of
social organizations on campus.
Member Jen Gillette is
part of the Greek system and is
an RA in a freshman dorm. She
believes the current social at
mosphere is unfair.

"We want to help plan
something fantastic," she said.
Member Rodwin Lowe, a
representative of Christian Fel
lowship and the Black Student
Union, said the SLC exists to
represent the student body.
"It is not our commit
tee, he said. Lowe is not intimi
dated by the amount of money
he and his colleagues will be
allocating.
"Personally for me it is
not a problem."

Police raid "Crack Alley"

From Staff Reports
Gettysburg Borough Po
lice hope the name "Crack Al
ley" will soon be a misnomer.
Twelve suspected drug
dealers in the Gettysburg area
were targeted by the police in
a Wednesday morning raid.
"We're going to make
every effort to turn the name
back to Zefnng_'s Alley," said
district Attorney Michael A.
George in an interview with
Janet Williams of the Hanover
Evening Sun.

Advertise in the Gettysburgian
Call 337-6449

Almost three dozen offic
ers were involved in the effort
to "curtail drug activity," said
George.
"We're seeing an influx of
people from New York," said
George. According to the
Hanover Evening Sun, police
have gained knowledge of as
many as three New York deal
ers who have set up shop in
Adams County. George is con
cerned with the possible in
crease in violence "as city in
fluences have come to
Gettysburg."

Crime Statistician

First African American professor
completes tenure track

College to hold lecture
on ecofeminism

by Daniel Larkin
News Editor
In December of 1997,
Gettysburg College for the first
time, awarded to tenure to an
African American professor.
Dr. Deborah Barnes of the En
glish department is not only the

first African
American pro
fessor to be
granted tenure,
but the first to be
placed in the
tenure track.
Gettysburg has
in the past
granted tenure
to African pro
fessors, but
Barnes is the first
inter

"I can't teach the way I
want and do research at
the same time."
Deborah Barnes,
Professor of English

Concern
ing this mile
stone, Dr. Barnes stated "I feel
honored, but at the same time,
I am shocked that no one has
ever been on the tenure track."
Barnes noted that this
event is one among several
"firsts" in her lifetime. In the
first grade, she was the first to
integrate the school she at
tended. She was the first to re
ceive a doctorate in English in
only three years from Howard
University. "One expects to be

Speaker to discuss Native
American issues

Gettysburg College Press Release

Echohawk has been actively in
volved in NARF since its incep
tion, serving as executive direc
tor since 1977.
Echohawk currently serves
on the boards of the American
Indian Resources Institute, the
Association on American Indian

John Echohawk, executive
director of the Native American
Rights Fund (NARF), will discuss
Native American issues, includ
ing religious freedom and civil
rights, at 7 p.m., Wednesday

Starhawk will speak in the Junction on February 18

Gettysburg College Press Release
Starhawk, a feminist and
peace activist who is one of the
foremost voices on ecofeminism,
will come to Gettysburg College
on Wednesday, February 18, to
present a lecture and ritual. Her
presentation, which is open to
the public free of charge, will be
gin at 7:30 p.m. in The Junction
of the College Union Building.
Starhawk will present "Sa
cred Roots, Sacred Values," dur
ing which she will draw on her
knowledge of the ancient Euro
pean Goddess tradition and her
recent visits to Israel and
Lithuania to identify core values
that come from a deep spiritual
connection with the earth. She
will also give examples from the
practices of her own community

Tweneedx
writers copy _editors

in th San Francisco Bay area and
will read from her no vel, The
Fifth Sacred Thing. Her talk will
be followed by a brief ritual and
spiral dance.
Starhawk earned a
master's degree in psychology
from Antioch West University
and since 1983 has been a lec
turer at the Institute for Culture
and Creation Spirituality at Holy
Names College in Oakland, Cali
fornia. The author of four
books, she consulted on the films
Goddess Remembered and The
Burning Times, directed by
Donna Reed and produced by
the National Film Board of
Canada. She also co-wrote the
commentary for Full Circle_^z
third film in the same Women's
Spirituality series.

A"
by Cara Masucci and Rebecca
Babbitt
Staff Reporters
At first glance,
Gettysburg College can some
times seem to be a campus of
students who are carbon cop
ies of each other. The J. Crew
look can interfere with a
student's individualism, so
many times students look for
other ways to display their in
dividuality. One way students
express themselves is through
body art. As a somewhat new
trend, body art allows people
to be as discrete or as distinct
as they would like.
When first year student
Eileen Fortune decided to get
tattooed a few months ago, she
and her friends went to Eric
Von Don's Elite Tattooing.
Because of a special affection
for all things Irish and her love
of Celtic art, Fortune decided
to get a Celtic cross on her
ankle. While at the tattoo par
lor, she saw another design that
was of special interest to her: a
water and fire ying-yang, which
she is thinking about getting
tattooed on her shoulder blade.

Fortune said it was a neat
experience because the owner

of the parlor painted the out
side of the building in an intri
cate design himself. She also
said that she was not worried
about infection because every
thing was safe and clean. "You
could actually see them take the
needles out of the package."

For first year student
Mandi Kalbach, the experi
ence was much the same.
Known as an elephant fanatic,
Kalbach decided to have her
passion tattooed "on her leg.
Unlike Fortune, Mandi has had

hers f o r
several
years.
She likes

crete,

viduality nicely.
Many students have
body art done in the beginning
of their first year. Students test
the limits of their indepen
dence from their parents by
getting something pierced or
tattooed.
It is also an interesting
way for the younger first year
students to celebrate their

eighteenth birthdays.
Reactions to piercings
and tattoos vary from parent
to parent. Many students also
use these activities as a form
of rebellion.
The piercing of various
body parts is also quite com¬

mon among college students.
Ear and tongue piercings are the
most popular.
Susannah Kopcho has a
total of 22 piercings, including
a tongue ring. "I knew I wanted
to have one ear covered," said

the first
year stu
dent, a
feat she
achieved by having
17 holes
put in her
right ear.

image for

people like it," she said.
As for her future plans,
Kopcho said she would "like to
have my lip pierced."
Unlike Kopcho, first year
student Casey Martin didn't
plan his tongue piercing. "It
was spur of the moment," he
said. "Ear piercing is too com
mon, nipple piercing is too
painful. Tongue piercing
sounded interesting," he said.
Martin, who had his
tongue pierced last Saturday, is
still suffering from a swollen
tongue. "The actual piercing
didn't hurt, but afterward there
was a sharp pain," he said.

Martin s tongue piercing
is slightly off-center because of

by Kyle Heulitt
GECO Columnist
Last year, a study was
done that found many of our
country's national parks to be
in decline. Many park facili
ties in the U.S. have been forced
to close, parks have had to
shorten their seasons, and
maintenance of historic build
ings have had to be put off un
til funding is available. Visitor
facilities are deteriorating, and
natural and historic park re
sources are being degraded, as
well. Most of these problems

PA Co-Ed Children's
Overnight Camp seeks staff
Contact Mark Glaser for
application or to schedule local
interviews being held on Feb 5th.
16 Gum Tree Lane
Lafayette Hill, PA 19444
(610) 941-0128
mglaser851@aol.com
(internships available)

have been caused by lack of
protection from the prevent
able threats that plague the na
tional parks.
For example, there are
clearcuts right up to the edge
of Yellowstone and Olympia
National Parks, and the bison
population at Yellowstone has
been drastically reduced by
capture and slaughter along the
park border. Real estate devel
opment on the boundaries of
Saguaro National Park puts
human activities right at the
park's edge.
The list goes on and on,
including such problems as traf
fic, mining, hazardous materi
als, and grazing. Whether they
originate inside or outside of a
park, the threats are diverse
and complex, and due to these
threats, natural resources in the
national park system are dete
riorating.

Despite the problems
many parks have been having,
they have been attracting more
visitors each year. Our national

parks receive 40 million more
visitors each year than they did
20 years ago, with numbers
expected to increase to over
300 million visitors per year by
1999. Ironically, some parks
are so popular they have traf
fic jams and more air pollution
than the cities people are try
ing to get away from.
Unfortunately, the parks'
budgets have not kept pace
with their visitations. Funding
for the national parks between
1978 and 1996 has actually
decreased, by over $600 mil
lion, making the total budget
$1.4 billion. This may sound
like a large amount of money
but it has not been enough to
keep many of the parks in good
condition.
Hopefully in the near fu
ture, government officials will
realize that our national parks
deserve more attention than

they are presently receiving.
These parks are part of our
heritage, and if we may lose an
important part of our history.

In Case You Missed It
It's still a Scream, baby

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist
Writer/director Wes Cra
ven has rekindled interest in the
classic slasher movie with his
1996 film Scream. If you
haven't seen it by now, better
hurry up, because the nineties
are about to leave without you.
The cast of Scream is
filled with today's rising stars,
led by Party of Five star Neve
Campbell. You'll also find fa
miliar faces like Friends star
Courtney Cox, Parenthood's
David Arquette, and even
Henry Winkler (a.k.a. The
Fonz), who has a cameo as the
principal of Woodsboro High.
Sadly, after more than a
decade of gory slasher flicks
like Halloween, A Nightmare
on Elm Street, and Friday the
13th, the genre faded from the
theaters.
Lately, however, it has

been making a comeback be
cause of this revolutionary
motion picture. Scream was a
surprise hit that took both crit
ics and the advertising market
by storm. After its initial run
in late 1996, it was re-released
in the spring of 1997 for a sec
ond run. _^^^^M
Scream relies _^^^^H
heavily on the "for- _^^^^H
mula" of slasher _^^^^H
movies like Hal- _^^_BHI
loween. While _^^m
watching this _^H i
movie, you can _^H I
pick out many _^H '
similarities be- _^^_L
tween it and your _^^_HH
favorite old-school _^^^^H
scary movies. The
film has the unique ability to
bring the audience to the brink
of terror, and then have them
falling out of their seats laugh
ing. It's quite an experience.
The movie opens in typi¬

cal horror movie fashion.
Casey (Drew Barrymore) is
home alone waiting for her
boyfriend when she gets a dis
turbing phone call. This phone
call leads to a bad end for Casey
and her boyfriend, Steve.
_Saetn

is not a movie for the faint of
heart: it opens with gore, and
it doesn't let up until its un
usual ending.
Campbell gives a stun
ning performance as Sydney, a

high school student who finds
that she is the next target of the
serial killer who is terrorizing
Woodsboro, the fictional set
ting of the movie. Sydney also
squares off against tabloid re
porter Gail Weathers (Cox),
author of a tell-all
^^^^_ book about the high
^^^^| profile murder of
_^^^^_h Sydney's mother.
_^^^^_B Like every hor
R ^^^_H ror movie heroine,
_^^M Sydney fends off the
_^H killer with the help
_^H of her best friend,
_^H Tatu m. Rose
_^^H McGowan (of the
¦^^^_J newly-released Phan
^^^^_H toms) plays this part
brilliantly, shining as

the fun-loving friend.
SkeetUlrich (As Good As
It Gets ), who was probably
cloned from a strand of Johnny
Depp's DNA, plays Billy,
Sydney's brooding boyfriend.

His innocence and intentions
are called into question on
more than one occasion.
Sydney's and Billy's char
acters contribute to the dark
ness of the film, while Tatum,
her boyfriend, Stu, and their
friend Randy all add to the
lighter side of the movie.
Scream is truly a fun
movie to watch. The screen
play is hip and original, and it
pokes fun at the whole slasher
genre. The subtle tensions and
ambiguities of the plot will
keep you on the edge of your
seat every time you watch it.
This is perhaps one of the most
definitive movies of our gen
eration.
The popularity of the
movie has already led to one
sequel, with a third movie cur
rently in the works. And to
understand these films, a
knowledge of the original is a
must!



Reel Hits and Misses
A wannabe good movie

by Dan "Newsy Spice" Larkin
and Mike "Opinionated Spice"
Petro
Movie columnists

movie also with extremely low
expectations. In fact, I even
tried to avoid writing a review
for this "film" until a certain
fellow reviewer threatened me
bodily harm if I did not endure
it. In spite of myself, I was
rather amused at parts of Spice
World. The self effacing humor
of the band, at times mocking
their own success and absur
dity of it all, was refreshing to
see. Too many musicians take
themselves way too seriously
(Pearl Jam or Oasis anyone?)
and it was fresh to see a group
that knows their star will fall
faster than it rose. Yet, I must
admit, most of the movie was
a cheesy and contrite concoc
tion of music videos and pre
dictable melodrama.

Dan: Spice World presents
the zany misadventures of a Brit
ish pop group with distinctive
personalities who have taken the
world by storm. Sound famil
iar? Well, if you're looking for a
nineties version of A Hard Day's
Night, I'm sorry to disappoint
you. Spice World stars the ever
popular and always frightening
Spice Girls (Mel C. "Scary Spice"
, Mel B. "Sporty Spice", Victoria
"Posh Spice", Emma "Baby
Spice", and Geri "Ginger Spice")
in their first full-length motion
picture.
The "plot" of this gem in
volves the girls' attempts to have
fun while avoiding an evil tab
loid photographer on the week
leading up to their first live con
cert and the wacky fun they have
along the way.

I went into to see Spice
World with very low expecta
tions. Leave it to the Spice Girls
to surpass them. The movie is
basically a bunch of Spice Girls
music videos strung together by
a really weak story.
Mike: I never had the op
portunity to see A Hard Day's
Night, and I guess that I have a
general disdain for movies about
bands. As a result, I went to this

Spice World's lame at
tempts at self-parody serve to
highlight what might have been
a clever and amusing look at a
bizarre cultural phenomenon.
But the movie instead is much
more interested in serving as a
marketing machine for the
quintet and their music.
Yet, I must also add, even
though this movie is blatant
marketing, it does a slick job
in doing so. Cameo appear
ances and bit parts by the likes
of George Wendt (Norm!),
Elton John, Meatloaf, Elvis
Costello, and Roger Moore all

provide a healthy dose of
chuckles.
/ think my favorite part
of Spice World was the eleven
year old girl sitting behind me
who new every line of the
movie and sang all the songs.
I also wonder who the
film's target audience is sup
posed to be. The show I went
to was packed with preteens,
but some of the film's content
is a bit racy. I also wonder at
the value of a group of women
who preach "girl power" while
prominently displaying their

T&A. Plan 9 From Outer Space
has nothing on Spice World.
This is one of the worst movies
I've seen in my entire life. I
honestly think that everyone
who was in the theater with me
is stupider for having seen it.
No stars (out of five).
This movie is pretty bad.
It left me missing the Monkee's
television show. I'll tell you
what I want, what I really re
ally want: I want this whole
Spice Girls phenomenon to
fade faster than Vanilla Ice's
career. However, for effort and
some original laughs, I give this
a one out of five stars. How
ever, I sincerely hope the man
agement of the Majestic will
have the decency to replace this
film with something more
watchable.

Curtain Call
A month of theater

by Glen Beck
Theater Columnist
Here on the Gettysburg
College campus the month of
February will most certainly
lend itself to the theater. Mark
your calendars for three major
events heading your way.
Next Tuesday, February
3, performance artist Paule
Turner will present two short
pieces in Stevens Lab Theater
at 12 p.m. Don't worry, the
show will be short enough so
that students will not miss their
1:10 classes.
The performance consists
of a twenty minute piece called
Porch Monkey, followed by a
ten minute excerpt from a
longer work entitled She's Out
of Her Time." Discussion may
follow.

On Tuesday, February 10,
the National Theatre of the
Deaf (NTD) will present
Henrik Ibsen's play Peer Gynt.
The play is directed by Will
Rhys, and features dances by
Pilobolus Dance Company, one
of the top dance companies in
the country. The performance
will be at 8 p.m. in the College
Union Building Ballroom.
Tickets are free.
The performance will
feature both American Sign
Language and spoken words.
The company is a professional

acting company made up of
deaf and hearing actors.
The NTD has received
critical acclaim throughout its
30-year history for its adapta
tions of classic literature. The
company has adapted works
by such authors as Chekhov,
Voltaire, Homer, Moliere,
Ibsen, and Puccini. The NTD
also performs original works.
The NTD has collabo
rated with such artists as Chita
Rivera, Jason Robards, Arvin
Brown, Bill Irwin and Peter
Sellars. In 1977, the NTD won
a Tony Award for theatrical
excellence.
Then, on Saturday, Feb
ruary 14, don't forget about
the Pow-Wow. It will start at
11 a.m. And run throughout
the day. Check the publica
tions circulating around cam
pus for further information.

Keep looking out for the
O8cN winter production of
Cotton Patch Gospel, set to
open on Thursday, February
26. Rehearsals are currently
underway. This toe-tapping
version of the Gospel accord
ing to Matthew guarantees a
crowd-pleasing evening.
Come watch your fellow stu
dents act, dance, and sing their
way through a musical you'll
be sure not to forget. More in
formation will follow in the
upcoming weeks.

Cafeteria connoisseur complains of crowds

by LA. Isherwood
Staff Writer As a social critic, my
role on this staff is to provide
a different opinion and new
insight on issues pertaining to
the campus community. That
means, for lack of more elo
quent terms, I bitch about
events or institutions on this
campus which tend to aggra
vate me and others with
whom I have had immediate
contact.
As I walked into our
school cafeteria on Monday
afternoon, I was irked and
annoyed at many of the events
that are all too common in our
beloved Servo. I felt as
though I was going to have
some sort of a nervous break
down. I confided in a group
of friends, and they instructed
me not to vent my frustrations

Disgruntled postal workers

The Post Office Staff is obligated, by
the college, to place all mail that we
receive into your boxes. We do not
appreciate mail being pushed back
through the boxes, onto the floor,
where we then have to pick up the
mess.
Have a little respect, you are adults!
The Post Office Staff

on them, but rather to write
them down for my next column.
So here is a short narrative about
my usual post-weekend experi
ence at Servo.
I walked into Servo and
proceeded to push my way
through the crowded corridor of
indecisiveness and socialization
to "Checkpoint Esther" where I
was greeted by some of the hap
piest faces in the world, the caf
eteria employees who swipe my
card almost daily.
They are always very good
to the students and seem to
know almost everyone by name,
something which, in itself, is
comforting. I was then con
fronted by a large crowd of stu
dents, all pushing for glasses and
trays. I am always amazed at hoe
hard it seems to be for people to
take their glasses with two
hands, place them on a tray, grab
the necessary silverware, and

then depart for the getting of
good eats. For some reason,
this simple procedure is beyond
the dexterity of some people,
leading to dropped glasses and
a floor strewn with silverware.
It is really not that difficult to
get your utensils neatly, but I
understand that some are inca
pable. Next came the great task
of retrieving food. The food
area is always packed with
people who are often way too
aggressive. It is almost like run
ning a gauntlet to be fed in the
corridor of death as a pack of
hungry wolves seeks its chicken
nuggets and curly fries. Daily
I am almost run over by some
one who is not watching where
he (or she) is going, but talk
ing to a buddy who is also
clumsily running into people.
Then, as I tried to get a ham
burger, I saw a flock of four

_ITs

women talking about the week
end and hookups and the like
and preventing people like me
and the others behind me en
trance to the soup and salad
bar. Honestly, I didn't really
care about anyone's social life,
and all I wanted was a cup of
soup to nurse my sore throat.
Then, I had to once again cross
the gauntlet to the drink area
where there was a huge line
that for some reason didn't
move at all. I went back to my
table really annoyed and tried
to confide this in my friends all
of whom had the same exasper
ating experience. All of us were
too tired, from fighting and
starvation, to attempt to go
through the same ordeal again
just for some more food.

The moral of the story
comes in three helpful hints to
you, the campus community
First, please try to be a little

more tidy inside of Servo. We
all have to eat there and silver
ware strewn about, broken
glasses, and colliding people
don't speak well for an institu
tion of higher learning. Sec
ond, the middle of the food
court is no place for extended
conversations. In fact, it is a
really annoying practice to
those of us who go to Servo to
eat. Please, try to save the con
versations for you tables. And
finally, the drink lines need to
be more efficient, and they can
be if people would decide what
they wanted ahead of time and
possibly learn to fill two glasses
at a time. With people waiting
behind you, it is a little rude to
stand in front of the drink ma
chines for several minutes.

Anyway, those are just my
little complaints and sugges
tions for a better, brighter Get
tysburg College.





The Pachyderm's Pulpit

Al Gore, President sooner than we think?

by John Dunlap
Staff Writer When President Bill
Clinton gave his State of the
Union Address, he spoke as
though no scandal had hit his
administration. The atmo
sphere of the Chief Executive's
speech to Congress, was how
ever, much different. Ameri
cans tuned in not to hear what
his plans for the economy or
education are, but to see the
President in crisis, in the middle
of a media feeding frenzy.
A little over a week ago,
the President expected his State
of the Union Address to be a
triumphant moment. He was
going to be the first President
in 29 years to be able to an
nounce that the budget is bal
anced. With, the new budget
surplus, Bill Clinton had hoped
to make saving Social Security

the big issue of the day. Now
the issue of the day remains
whether or not he took advan
tage of Presidential aides, in a
sexual nature, committed per
jury and/or suborned perjury,
and to what extent has he lied
to the American people. We
now know that he lied in 1992
when he was campaigning for
the New Hampshire Primary
about his affair with Gennifer
Flowers. The President not
only owes the American people
an apology, he owes Miss Flow
ers an apology.
There seems to be no
doubt now that the President
is dragging the honor of the
office of the President of the
United States down. He is the
President of the United States
and he has a responsibility to
uphold the honor and integrity
of the White House. He is fail
ing in that duty. Bill Clinton

could survive this scandal like
he has numerous others:
Whitewater, Troopergate,
Travelgate, Filegate, and the
campaign fundraising scandal,
but now he is left with the Paula
Jones sexual harassment law
suit and allegations of sex in the
White House, and perjury. This
scandal has breached the inner
circle and the President's moral
authority is under attack.
Even if the most severe
allegations are true, impeach
ment seems unlikely. However,
if Paula Jones's lawsuit contin
ues than 1998 could turn into
another 1974 where the presi
dent lost control of the coun
try. President Richard Nixon
lost the moral authority to lead
and his domestic agenda died,
and his foreign policy was
slowed. Watergate consumed
his time and even after he re
signed the new President,
Gerald Ford, took command of

a much weaker presidency.
Congress was empowered and
the Democrats were able to
make huge gains in the Con
gressional midterm elections.
This is what Bill Clinton must
avoid. Open talk about resigna
tion is dangerous and it is a sign
that the President is in crisis.
If Bill Clinton has lost the
moral authority to be Presi
dent, and if he suborned and
committed perjury, obstructing
justice then he should go. This
country deserves better. "Slick
Willy" may not be slick enough.
First lady Hillary
Rodham Clinton wants us to
believe there is some type of
"right-wing" conspiracy against
the President. What world is
she living in? Give us a break,
Mrs. Clinton. People may hate
Independent Counsel Kenneth
Starr, but Attorney General
Janet Reno, along with the

Third Judicial Circuit of Wash
ington, D.C. agree. This groups
includes a Judge appointed by
President Lyndon Johnson.
Judge Starr has hit a serious is
sue and lets remember his in
vestigation has not gone nearly
as long as Lawrence Walsh's
Iran-Contra investigation
which lasted seven years, five
of them being after Ronald
Reagan was retired from the
Presidency. He hounded Presi
dent George Bush all through
out his 1992 reelection cam
paign but found nothing. Let
Judge Starr complete his inves
tigation and uncover the truth.
No matter what the far-left says
about Judge Starr, it does not
take away from the charges
against the President. These
charges are so serious that they
could very well determine
whether it will be Al Gore or
Bill Clinton giving next year's
State of the Union Address.

High standards for high officials

by Cammie Grant
Contributing Writer
This past week, the
American public has been bom
barded with rumors about
President Clinton and his al
leged affair with Monica
Lewinsky. Lewinsky, a former
White House intern, claimed
that she and the president had
a sexual affair and he encour
aged her to cover it up. Clinton
responded, "I did not have
sexual relations with that
woman, Miss Lewinsky."
Lewinsky started work
in the White House, as an in
tern in the summer of 1995.

White House officials criticized
Lewinsky's work. She was
sloppy and perhaps a bit loud
and giggly. Hillary Rodham
Clinton has accused the "right
wing" of orchestrating this con
spiracy. The first lady is stand
ing by her man, even after her
husband has admitted to hav
ing an affair with Gennifer
Flowers, and now is denying an
affair with a woman half his
age. Commendably, Newt
Gingrich has decided not to
comment on the accusations
and let the White House handle
the situation. If the Republi
can Party is being accused by

Mrs. Clinton of creating a con
spiracy against her husband and
herself, the best thing for the
right wingers to do is stay out
of it. Obviously, the Republi
cans could not "dig up" or con
spire such information, as
many women have come for
ward. Hillary, open your eyes.
Other high-ranking people
have been punished for their
affairs, and Bill Clinton should
be as well. Kelly Flynn was
discharged from the Air Force
recently after having an affair.
Why should we lower our stan
dards for the Commander in
Chief of our country? After all,
The United States is a brilliant,

vivacious nation and the stan
dards we set should be high and
abided by our leaders. It is our
leader's duty to provide the
United States with the best
reputation.
The President of the
United States should make the
best moral and ethical deci
sions. Although it is not in the
Constitution, it is an obligation
of the president to set a good
standard for the public. Im
peachment is not facing the
president at this time, though,
he could be forced to resign
from office if any more hazard
ous information is presented.
Should the American public

trust a man who has been ac
cused more than once of hav
ing affairs? Should we trust a
man who claims that he "didn't
inhale" or break any laws of the
American government? How
much more lenient should the
public be with our president
and his moral and ethical deci
sions? I hope that in the next
presidential election, the
people will opt to vote for the
most _^qualified, morally
equipped, and honest indi
vidual. Voters should not be
worrying about what is going
on in the West Wing of the
White House and in the Oval,
or should I say "oral" office?


Consider this

At the end of this past se
mester, seven out of seven pro
fessors were granted the brass
ring of teaching, tenure. Given
the abysmal one out of three last
year, this was a significant im
provement.
Based on the fervor that
surrounded last year's much
publicized tenure denials, and
the recent court case, the ma
jority of the campus is aware
that tenure is based upon an
evaluation of the candidate's
research, teaching, and gover
nance.
According to procedure,
the most important quality is
teaching, with research and gov
ernance following respectively
Yet, is this really so?
Based on what this year's group
is saying, research may have
moved to the head of the line
in terms of importance.

Beyond this, does the col
lege even uphold any ranking of
these? How does the FPC mea
sure governance? And what
exactly is considered an ad
equate amount of research?
What has become increas
ingly obvious with the past two
years tenure groups is this: the
majority of the campus has no
idea how the tenure progress
works.
This isn't for lack of try
ing either. Last year, a group of
over one hundred students tried
to find out more and only ran

into a repetition or standard
protocol.
Further, based on a belief
that research is now more im
portant than teaching, it seems
that even the candidates them
selves are confused about what
they need to do to become a
permanent member of this col
lege community.
What can be done about
this issue?
It would be nice to see the
college, in its thrust to move
towards the future, take a long
and hard look at its tenure pro
cess. What do we value in our
staff? Are we a research or a
teaching institution? How do
we go about attracting the best
teachers we possibly can while
still generating academic pres
tige through research?

Let's be honest, everyone
on this campus knows of ten
ured professors who are excep
tional researchers but poor
teachers, exceptional teachers
but poor researchers, and those
who are exceptional in all ar¬

eas. This alone shows that
there are some obvious flaws
with our tenure system here at
Gettysburg College; to deny
this is to bury our collective
heads in the sand.
As a whole, the campus
should throw down the gaunt
let to the administration and
demand a tenure process re
view.

Conflict and Consensus -

"What planet was he on
when Regan was president_?

This is in response to
the exceedingly well-in
formed but far more naive
comments consistantly
written by John Dunlap in
the Pachyderm's Pulpit.
Here is my big news-flash:
BOTH . DEMOCRATS
AND REPUBLICANS LIE!
Conservativesare constantly
banging their fists at the
strings of lies told by Demo
crats. Mr. Dunlap discusses

the dignity brought into the
White House by former Presi
dent Reagan. What planet was
he on when Reagan was presi
dent? What concerns me is the
climate being created in Wash
ington, where no future presi
dent, from any political party,
will be able to run the country
without a special prosecuter
hiding in the shadows, scoop
ing up dirt, and believe me, all

politicians have plenty of it. To
be sure, Mr. Clinton has more
to hide than others but I would
rather have a leader with some
skeletons in his closet than one
who would put women back in
the kitchen, more pollution
into the environment, and a
gun in the hand and a cigarette
in the mouth of every teenager.

To the Editor:

This is a response to
Jay Spiese's article 'True Di
versity' (January 22). The
purpose of raising the issue
of diversity is unquestion
able. I agree that it is 'not a
matter of how we look 1 and
'True diversity comes from
the mind.' However, it is un
deniable that if not for all
but for most individuals
their 'minds' are influenced
by their backgrounds, expe
riences and the cultures they
were raised in.
Our thoughts are not
devoid of the various expe
riences we and/or our ances¬

tors have had. It does not mat
ter how we look but in many
instances our physical features
are an indication of where we
come from and how that has
shaped our minds (our intellect
and thinking). Jay raised many
issues all of which have
stemmed from his observation
that we can be diverse when we
show the diversity in our ideas
and actions. These ideas and
actions I feel cannot be taken
in a vacuum and those who ask
for diversity (such as more
people other than Caucasian)
are saying just that. Our ideas
and actions are influenced by

our cultural identities. A differ
ence of appearances in these
matters is unavoidable. Sec
ondly, it would be, if not any
thing, simply a matter of rec
ognition if the word 'Blacks' is
capitalized since we are not
talking about a color. If we
were to use Hispanics, Jews,
Asians it would make sense to
also use Africans or African
Americans.
Thank You,
Kabir Kumar

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,

founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more information,
contact any of the following
persons: Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext. 8159; T.J.
Scott (Allies secretary/treasurer),
Ext. 7596; Alec Beekmans, Ext.
7071; Helen DeVinney, Ext. 7807;

HEALTH SERVICES

Hours for Health Services are
Monday through Friday from 8:30
am to 6:00 pm. Please call ext.
6970 or stop by to make an ap
pointment.
The Health Hotline, provides
non-emergency medical advice on
Saturdays from 10 am to 2 pm.
You can page a nurse practitioner
at 338-5283, enter the phone
number where you can be reached,
and the nurse practitioner will call
you back. You will be advised on
self care, emergency room care,
physician consultation or health

service follow-up. OF COURSE,

John Elway: Hall of Fame resume complete

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
Who says you can't teach
an old dog new tricks? Thirty
seven year old, fifteen year
NFL veteran John Elway, fi
nally reached the pinnacle of a
legendary career with a Super
Bowl victory.
In a courageous effort
Elway passed, handed off,
fought, grabbed, fell, dove and
sprinted his way to a title which
eluded him in his previous
three Super Bowl appearances.
Before Super Bowl
XXXII, John Elway was a good
quaterback, probably the best
to never win the big game.
However, after a tremendous
display of heart and valor, John
Elway will be known as one of
the best.

"It was really incredible,"
said Bronco center Tom Nalen,
"You see your leader, your
franchise guy, giving his all. It
was real motivational for us to
see." Although his stats were
pretty average (12-23, 123

yards, 1 int, 1 rushing TD)
Elway was at the helm for one
of the more exciting Super
Bowls in recent history.
Another amazing thing
about the victory of the Bron
cos was that finally, after what
seemed like hundreds of years
watching the AFC get pum
meled in a weak attempts to
bring home the Super Bowl, the
Broncos finally did it.
Yes, it had been 13 years
since the Al Davis and the Oak
land Raiders last brought home
the Vince Lombardi Trophy.
That means the last time
the AFC won the Super Bowl
JAMS were in style, and The
Bangles rocked the house with
"Walk like an Egyptian."
With the score tied at 17-

facing a third-and-six on the
Packers 12 yard line. A fourth
down would mean a field goal
attempt and most likely a
three point lead, but the
touchdown was the priority.
In a play that typified the
Broncos' win, John Elway
evaded the rush of all-pro
Reggie White, and dove
bravely into the air. After be
ing smashed by Packers safety
Leroy Butler, Elway de
scended towards the early im
planting his fossil-like body to
the ground. One important
fact: he got the first down.
So, as the game ended
the crowd roared for the aged
veteran, and saw that he had
accomplished all he ever
needed.

17, in the fourth quarter the
Broncos were in the midst of a
long drive that started at their
eight yard line. It was the kind
of drive that eats the clock —
something Denver knew it had
to win.
Ten plays into the drive,
Elway had the Denver offense

No matter how many
years he continues to play, no
matter how many touchdowns
he has the rest of his career,
for now John Elway is the best
quaterback in football. And
watch out... he could be the
best ever.

Gettysburg gridiron to see major changes

by Ronnie Beeman
Contributing Writer
The Gettysburg football
team has wasted little time in
making changes for the 1998
football season. The Bullets are
altering the duties of some of
their coaches to dethrone West
ern Maryland as top dog in the
Centennial Conference.
The major move will see
the movement of head coach
Barry Streeter from offensive
coordinator to defensive coor
dinator. This allows for head
baseball coach and the new spe
cial teams/backfields coach
John Campo to devote his full
attention on his baseball duties,
instead of trying to prepare for
the upcoming football season.
Streeter is taking over a
defense that has lost four
starters. These include captains
Joe Hodakowski and Rob Sena,
Kevin Gurski, and Tom
Olchon.

Seniors Chris Felton, Jus
tin Domingos, Chad Mire,
Brain Murphy, Ryan
MacNamee and Jason Osborn
will be looked to for leadership.
Chris Lunardi is the heir appar-

Intramural basketball scores, bores, and eye sores

ent to Kevin "The Warrior"
Gurski's position at free safety.
Transfer Steve Brock,
Mike Graham, Gene Kraus,
Scott Grabus, Matt Ritz, Greg
Gudis, Justin Cheseroni, Brett
Thorpe and Pete Devlin occupy
the remaining spots on the "D."
The duties ot the offen
sive coordinator will be handed
to coach John Schmid. The of
fense seems in good shade with
only two senior starters lost,
second team All-Centennial
Conference selection Brain
Willard and center Kurt Ritter.
These holes will be filled
with senior Chris Nuss, juniors
Steve Jenkins and Tim Peltier,
and sophomores Chris
Matthaei, Mike Lorge, and
Brain Pokorny. They will be
playing along side senior leader
Justin Ogorek, junior Bill
Beining, and sophomore Jack
Starkey.

The tight ends are led by
senior Mike Holm. The rest
of the offensive backfield is
filled with seasoned players,
headlined by Third Team All
American Paul Smith as full
back.

Bullet players excited about changes and look to surge into next season. Photo By Em ' ly Glatfeller

Juniors Dereck Reed and
Matt Helwig are returning
starters with Dan Sheets, Jay
Jablonski, and Brian
_Pojanowski in reserve. The re
ceivers are a veteran group.
Seniors Jeff Closz and Rob
Crowe, and junior Tighe Burns

lead the receiving corp.
The quarterback position
has returning starter Dennis
Flaherty, with contention from
senior Chris Fugaro, junior
Weston Wells, and sophomore
Jeff Boyd.
The Bullets are working

hard for the up coming season.
The most visible change for the
Bullets will be their new or
ange helmets. They are simi
lar to the helmets adorned by
the University of Syracuse.
The Bullets opponents will
soon be aware of the orange
crush. See you in the fall!

Bullets shoot past Alvernia

by Paul Redfern
Staff Writer

The Gettysburg College
Men's Basketball team com
pleted a great week finishing 2
1. They lost at Western Mary
land, 63-74, Wednesday night.
On Saturday, the team traveled
to Washington College and
played in what Coach George
Petrie described as the team's
best effort of the year.
The Bullets came away
with an outstanding 74-63 win.
Washington College was the
leader in the Centennial
Conference's East Division.
The Bullets then played region
ally ranked Alvernia College,
one of last year's Final Four
contenders. The Bullets went
down early but fought back to
win 77-73.
Alvernia got on top in the
game early with field goals
from Lonnie Walker their big
inside player. Alvernia got help
in the first half going 3-4 from
beyond the three-point line.

But the Bullets fought
back, shooting 13-25 or 52%
from the field. Freshman Greg
Schreiber, sophomore Rich
Pfeil, and senior Terry
Schofield all played a key de
fensive role in stopping Walker.

dunked sparking a run for the
Bullets. Down the stretch, jun
ior guard Jon Bowman did a
great job of containing the
Alvernia point guard and lead
ing scorer Damien Hunter.
Bowman, along with great de
fense from the rest of the
squad, was able to force Hunter
into taking off balanced shots.

The Bullets pulled ahead
by two with just under one
minute remaining in the game.
After several missed free throw
attempts, the Bullets were fi
nally able to hit from the line
and go up by the final score of
77-73. With these games Get
tysburg moves to 9-8 overall
and 3-3 in the conference. This
week the Bullets travel to con
ference foe Swarthmore on Sat
urday at 7:30p.m., and then
play rival Franklin & Marshall
at home on Wednesday, Febru
ary 4 with a tip-off time of
8:00p.m.
In team notes, sources
close to the team report that
the Bullets recent success has
been attributed to freshman
forward Mike Monroe's switch
to Polo socks. Very interesting.

Olympic Spotlight

by Matthew Eisenberg
Assistant Sports Editor
On February 7, 1998
Nagano Japan welcomes 3,000
athletes from 83 countries. The
torch has been on its tour of 47
Japanese prefectures that began
on January 6, 1998. The
United States will be bringing
approximately 200 athletes, in
cluding men's and women's
snowboarding and the newest
edition to the Olympics:
women's ice hockey.
The opening ceremonies
will begin at 9 p.m. ET and the
first day of events will be pre
liminary rounds of men's ice
hockey. Italy vs. Kazakhstan, 2
a.m. ET; Germany vs. Japan, 6
a.m. ET; Austria vs. Slovakia, 2
a.m. ET; France vs. Belarus, 6
a.m. ET. These teams will be
vying for two spots to battle the
hockey heavyweights such as
Team USA, Canada, and Swe-

With the addition of
NHL players entering the
Olympic mix the medals race

is clearly undecided. Team USA
is favored with strong competi
tion from Team Canada. How
ever, keep your eyes on the
mighty Czech Republic with
Dominik Hasek and Jaromir
Jagr, as well as Finland, Sweden,
and Russia all boasting all-star
rosters.
Team USA women's ice
hockey also brings an all-star
line-up and should bring home
hardware, probably the gold.
Cammi Granato, sister of Tony
Granato of the Los Angeles
Kings has an incredible resume.
She is a six-time member of U.S.
Women's National Team, one of
three players who have been
with program since inception.
Granato is also the all-time lead
ing scorer for the U.S. Women's
National Team and was named
the 1996 USA Hockey Women's
Player of the Year. •

Other events on CBS will
be: 4-6 p.m. ET Men's down
hill and women's ice hockey pre
views; 8-11 p.m. ET Men's
downhill, freestyle and cross
country skiing.

Bullet Wrestlers continue to "take down" competition

From Staff Reports
A five march winning
streak, all against Centennial
Conference opponents, has
boosted the Gettysburg Col
lege wrestling team's overall
record to 10-6-1.
Since concluding the pre
holiday portion of its 1997-98
campaign at 2-3, Head Coach
Troy Dell's squad has won
eight matches, dropped only
three and tied one. The tie was
against Franklin & Marshall,
which fields a Division I wres
tling program, and it was a 21
12 victory over Ursinus that
jump-started the Bullets on
their current five-match win
ning streak.
The Bullets have five dual
matches remaining prior to the
Centennial Conference Cham
pionships at Swathmore on
Saturday, February 14.

Senior Jamie Binnall has
fashioned a 12-11 record at
118 pounds. Including the six
pins he has had this seasons,
Binnall's career total now
stands at 27, making him one
of only four wrestlers in
Gettysburg's history to reach
that goal.
Although a majority of
Marty Scarpato's matches this
season were at 134 pounds, the
junior has recently begun com
peting at 126. His overall
record is 18-8, including a re
cent 8-4 decision over the de
fending Centennial Conference
champion at 126, Bucky
Johnson of Ursinus. He has a
team-leading 95 takedowns
this season.
Senior Mike Ben'Ary,
who recently moved up to the
134-pound weight class from
126, has won three of his lat
est four matches to up his over
all record to 6-17.

Residence Life changes summer housing policy

By Laura Root
StaffReporter The Office of Residence Life has
changed its summer housing policy.
Due to the maintenance that needs
to be done in all residence halls over the
summer, there will be greater restrictions
placed on the number of students allowed
to stay on campus during the months of
May through August.
In the past, Residence Life has re
ceived complaints about the conditions
of students' rooms that had been utilized
for summer housing.
Although students are cleared out
of the dorms by early August, mainte
nance often has not had the time to get
the rooms in top condition for the fall

semester. Now, the priority is being
placed on getting the dorms in better
shape. This summer, Residence Life plans
to use one dorm for housing instead of
the twelve that have been used in the past
in order try to renovate the rest.
Renovations are especially neces
sary in Special Interest Houses. Because
Gettysburg College does not offer sum
mer classes, Residence Life feels that this
is a reasonable change.
Several groups proposed changing
the summer housing policy. Residence
Life, Maintenance, and members of con
ferences that use Gettysburg's facilities
over the summer all agreed that some
thing needed to be done.
Action was taken in the fall when
the new plan was devised. Usually, be
tween 80 and 100 students stay in

Gettysburg dorms over the summer. In
ternational students, students interning
with academic departments, students do
ing research, students employed by the
college, and students who have no affili
ation with activities on campus during the
summer, but one working in town or at
tending summer school at a nearby col
lege, are all given the opportunity to re
main in Gettysburg.
The only criteria that a student stay
ing the summer has to meet is to have
been enrolled in Gettysburg College for
some part of the previous school year.
Currently, there are 140 spots re
served for summer housing. All students
will be staying in either Musselman or
Patrick Halls. The final decision on which
hall will be harboring students will be
made once it is determined which one

needs less work this summer. If any more
students apply for housing, Residence Life
may be forced to prioritize.
Students who need to stay in dorms
the least may then be denied summer
housing.
Student reactions to the change
have been mixed. Although they are
happy to have a place to stay, some are
disappointed that there is no longer a wide
variety of summer residences to choose
from. Tim Rupe, Director of Residence
Life believes that his staff has imple
mented a change for the better. "Our lack
of readiness in the fall was inexcusable,"
he says, "We need to be prepared."
Dean Julie Ramsey agrees. She be
lieves that, "This is a fair policy that will
cater to the needs of all students."

New beds for new heads

by Kabir Kumar
Staff Reporter Two Hundred Twenty-Five
North Washington St. will be made avail
able as Honors Housing for the academic
year 1998-99, said the College and Resi
dence Life Offices of Gettysburg College.
About 11 students will be housed
in the new campus building next semes
ter, after renovations are made over the
summer. "It should be fully networked,"
said Scott Simonds, Assistant Director of
Residence Life, Apartments and Special
Interest Housing Area. "I am not sure how
many singles or doubles . . . primarily
singles," he added.
The house was purchased after
the owners approached Gettysburg Col
lege with an offer to sell. "It is the kind of
housing that students are attracted to;
close to the campus, much smaller than
typical residence hall," said Julie Ramsey
Dean of College Life. "We got a pretty
good price on it.... Not a good deal but
a reasonable deal."

New property acquired to meet the 'housing crunch'

, 3.25 and Sophomores with a minimum

Honor Commission sees dramatic increase in number of cases

by Henry Fawell
Staff Reporter
The past year at
Gettysburg College has seen a
significant increase in reported
violations of the school's Honor
Code. While the exact number
of the cases could not be deter
mined, one Honor Commission
member approximated the num
ber to be as high as forty.
"This is a tremendous in
crease," said Brian Pumphrey,
who just completed his one-year
term as Chairman of the Honor
Commission, "I have been on the
Commission for three years and
never during that time did we
receive so many reported viola
tions." While the student-run
Honor Commission has been
working hard to deal with the
sudden boost in the number of
hearings, several defendants de
cided to plead guilty before their
respective cases had even

reached that stage.
One of the most notable
Honor Code violations at the
College occurred last spring
within the Computer Science
department, when fourteen stu
dents from three separate
courses were tried and found
guilty of plagiarism. In 1997,
nearly one-third of all reported
violations came from within the
Computer Science Department,
including another five incidents
unrelated to those of last spring.
This sharp rise can be at
tributed the computer's in
creased bearing on classroom
work, as well as the sti dent's
ability to gain a tremendous
amount of information off the
Internet in a short period of time.
With the rise in computer
related violations, plagiarism has

Editors at Virginia Tech's
student newspaper claimed it
was a terrible mistake when a
Virginia Tech administrator
was referred to as the "direc

The student journalists say
dummy type accidently made

She wants at least $850,000 to

sional and personal reputation.
Student editors sent a

from a combination of a com-

nate incident that she has to
move on from and become a
little more thick-skinned
about," said James R.

think a reasonable reader
would think this an assertion
of fact, and if it's not asserted
as correct — a person's repu

it goes the route of subjective
opinion and impression. It be

a butt-licker to one person isn't

someone who shamelessly cur
ries favor for personal and pro
fessional gain, Ciaffone said.
To make matters worse,

pearing with the bold quotes

the university sending students
to a state honors program.
"My client makes
some very positive comments,
and The Collegiate Times essen
tially calls her a brown-nosers,
an apple-polisher and a kiss
ass," Ciaffone said. "If some
one reads that story and they
don't know Sharon Yeagle, they
may not believe a word she
says." "Ms. Yeagle is a pro
fessional woman who is very
good at her job and worked
very hard to get where she is."
That is why it has been
difficult for Yeagle to endure
the snickers and jokes that have
come from co-workers, super

In last week's article titled "First African American
professor completes tenure track," we incorrectly reported
that Deborah Barnes was the first African American pro
fessor in the tenure track. In fact, J udy Gay, a social psy
chologist in the Department of Psychology was the first
African American in Gettysburg's tenure track. Dr. Barnes
remains the first African American professor to complete
the tenure track. The Gettysburgian apologizes for this
oversight.

Service with a smile

by Cara Masucci
Staff Reporter So many aspects of col
lege life exist that sometimes
one can spend four years at
college and never fully take
advantage of all opportunities
available to him or her. Amidst
the academic and social scene,
the sect of service projects can
sometimes get lost in the
shuffle. Fortunately, this is not
the case at Gettysburg College.
Quickly gaining national
attention as a school geared
towards service, Gettysburg has
many opportunities for stu¬

dents who want to get involved
a small amount or on an exten
sive level. From service learn
ing trips to Alpha Phi Omega
t(j> special interest housing, the
community and college are eas
ily accessible to anyone willing
to donate their time and effort.
A major facet of service
on the campus has always been
the Center for Public Service
(CPS). Starting within the
Chapel, the CPS has given the
college a large variety of issues
and opportunities for service.
Largely run by the students, the
administrators are there to as
sist in details and smooth out

the rough edges.
Various students coordi
nate projects with community
members in different area that
range from elderly issues to
hunger and homelessness.
The CPS also maintains a
large variety of yearly activities
and projects that include GIV
(Gettysburg Is Volunteering)
Day during orientation and ser
vice learning trips.
According to administra
tive intern Darcy Daniels, the
CPS runs both GIV Day and
Greek GIV Day, as well as the
Fiesta in the fall for migrant
children of the community,
AIDS Awareness Week, Christ
mas toy drives, and Mission of
Mercy.
Along with their main
projects, the CPS picks up vari
ous other campus and commu
nity projects.

Speaking with Daniels,
she conveyed the CPS aims to
raise campus awareness, not
only of each other and the
community, but also of the
world as a whole.
"There are people out
there that do not have the same
opportunities as we have,"
Daniels commented. "It is our
job to use our education, man
power, and strength to assist
them in their needs."

Daniels's primary fo
cuses this year as an intern

have
been lit
eracy i s -
sues,
AIDS aware
ness,
and a
cur
rent project
with a t -
risk
chil

Junior Megan Mecca went on a service learning trip to the Carolinas. Here
students work hard cleaning up an area of woods.

land. Currently, if people
would like to get involved,
they can contact the CPS at
x6490 or
"serve@gettysburg.edu" If
there is something the person
is especially interested in, they
should specify their likes and
dislikes, and the appropriate
coordinator will contact them.
For those willing to get
involved on a much broader
scale, the center is currently
accepting applications for pro
gram coordinators to go out
and work with community
contacts and provide the cam
pus with an outlet for service.
Anyone wishing to do so can
pick up an application at the
center.

Senior Jaime Foanio
took advantage of an aspect of
the CPS over the fall reading

days when she went on a ser
vice learning project to New
York City. Foanio had always
been interested in going on a
service learning trip, but did not
have the opportunity to do so
until this year. In New York she
helped out an AIDS organiza
tion in delivering meals to those
in the advanced stages of the
disease.
Foanio said she really en
joyed her trip, not only because
of the knowledge she gained in
working with the AIDS patients,

but her opportunity to meet dif
ferent students and faculty
members from the campus.
One of over twenty projects
worldwide, the trip was not
entirely hard work. There was
time to go sightseeing and catch
a Broadway show.
Foanio was able to get a
scholarship that covered 80 per
cent of the trip's cost from the
CPS. Daniels stated that al
though they have limited re
sources, the center gives all it
can to the scholarship fund.
Other organizations are also
available to give out service
learning scholarships. Foanio
stated that the trip was such a
great experience that she would
"definitely recommend it to ev
eryone on campus."
For four sophomores, the
service experience that has im¬

pacted their lives is on campus.
Nick Stefonich, Jamey
Gallagher, Brett Montich, and
project leader Chris Hill have
a special interest apartment
that allows them to work with
the school in advancing recy
cling. The students record how
much water they use within the
apartment, and from these re
sults, they try to find a solution
to cutting down the amount of
water wasted. They also count
and recycle glass, aluminum,

service opportunities and stu

group.

the year.
Service can be rewarding,
not only to those receiving it,
but to the giver as well. Every
person asked about their ser
vice projects said decisively that
the service they had done gave
them a sense of goodness and
accomplishment.



Science for the young

by Allison Zoller
Contributing Reporter
How does someone so
young get placed in charge of
such important research? This
is the first question that popped
into my mind upon meeting
with the creator of Gettysburg
College's Molecular Biology
Department, Dr. Steven James.
In a generation hooked on ER
and Chicago Hope, the word
doctor no longer brings to
mind the image of a sixty-year
old man walking around in
hospital scrubs. George
Clooney and Noah Wyle have
popularized the notion of
young doctors with big respon
sibilities.

Although this typical pre
sentation may no longer be
commonplace, I was not pre
pared for what greeted me
when I first met James. Born
January 17, 1958, in Detroit,
Michigan, James does not look
a day over his 39 years. And
yet he is conducting research
that could lead to major break
throughs in the areas of cancer
treatment and physical rehabili
tation. Age is not important if
you know what you want to do.
While age may not be a
significant factor in success or
failure, education certainly is.
Young Steve James started his
quest for knowledge at our very
own Gettysburg College. It
was "serendipity," since he

wasn t sure how to go about
choosing the right school. In
1980, he graduated with a B.A.,
which would serve as his ticket
into graduate school. James
received his master's degree in
botany from the University of
Minnesota in 1983. After 13
long years of higher education,
James earned himself a new
title; the "Mr." changed to
"Dr." when James earned a
Ph.D. in Cell and Developmen
tal Biology from the University
of Minnesota in 1989.
For his post-doctorate
study, James spent three years
conducting research at the Uni
versity of Medicine and Den
tistry in New Jersey (UMDNJ),
under the care of Dr. N. Ronald
Morris. Morris became a role
model for James, as he was one
of the founders of Cell Cycle
Research, which is the area of
biology James eventually de
cided to pursue through his re
search.

In 1992, James was hired
by Gettysburg College to start
a Molecular Biology program,
bringing him back to the place
he started all those years ago,
thus finishing his formal edu
cation and starting a new stage
of his life: research.
James has spent the past
eight years researching two
genes essential for cellular re
production. The experiments
James and his students are now
performing are timely and

costly because the techniques
and equipment used are not
easy or foolproof. Where does
someone get money for this
kind of research?
Foundations such as the
Howard Hughes Medical Insti
tute in Washington were estab
lished to provide for young re
searchers such as James. The
Hughes Institute gives grants to
colleges and universities, in or
der to "advance the field of sci
ence." In 1991, Gettysburg Col
lege was selected to be the re
cipient of one of these grants.
Gettysburg was given the sum
of $850,000 to be spread over
a period of five years. This
money was to be used to start
departments in Molecular Bi
ology and Biochemistry. As a
result, James was hired.- Most
of his funding comes from the
Hughes Foundation, which will
run out this year.

A major component of
James' job was to begin and
oversee a research program in
which undergraduates can take
part. Part of the Hughes Grant
provides funding for a summer
research program during which
time three students are hired
full time for ten weeks to re
search gene cloning. Student
research in this program has
ranged anywhere from six
months to three years. Imag
ine spending three years trying
to accomplish one thing, in an
area where failure is not an
option. As James says, "You get
used to failure. There are al
ways going to be roadblocks."
In the words of James,
"Part of being a good scientist
is being able to choose between
things to work on - the key is
to have a knack for knowing
which question to-pursue; that
advances science."

What good would re
search-be if you didn't share it
with the world? In addition to
overseeing research, teaching
classes in cell biology and mo
lecular genetics, and finding
time for his family, James has
managed to write seven differ
ent publications. Dr. James has
also presented ten papers to
various professional societies, is
currently working on several
writings, and has received nu
merous awards and fellowships

Actors Darby Jared Leigh (left) is Peer and Debe'Taylor is
his dying mother in Peer Gynt, which will be performed by
the National Theater for the Deaf in the CUB Ballroom on
February 10 at 8 p.m.

Peer to perform

since 1980.
So far, James has just
been described as a series of ac
complishments. Although he
probably doesn't get away
from the lab often enough,
when he does, James has a wife
and two young sons to go
home to. He takes part in the
Cub Scouts and Boy Scouts,
_dnd goes camping with his fam
ily in Maine and Ontario.
James earned money one
summer during his college
years guiding canoe trips in
Quetico Provincial Park, in
Western Ontario. He relives
this summer by taking Boy
Scout troops on 10-day trips
throughthe same park. In ad
dition to spending time out
doors fishing, camping and ca
noeing, James has also taken
up cycling.

With everything else that
he is doing, Dr. James still takes
the time to get to know the stu
dents and answer their ques
tions in person, as opposed to
the impersonal but quick e-

mail approach taken by some
professors.
James is pushing at the
limits of molecular biology,
earning recognition for himself
and for the school, and he is
not even "over-the-hill." My
sentiments are best put by Dr.
James himself, "If you are
clever enough and enjoy what
you're doing enough to persist
you will succeed.!'
Last semester, each stu
dent in Professor _Marshall's
Writing About Science first-year
seminar had the opportunity to
interview and write a profile
about a professor of his/her
choice in one of the science de
partments. In an effort to ex
tend these insights to the entire
campus, several profiles have
been selected to be printed in
the Gettysburgian over the next
few weeks.

For more information on
the Writing About Sciences
seminar, visit the homepage at:
www.gettysburg. edulprojectl
physics/dealfyshome. html

Reel Hits and Misses What the Dickens?!

Kf'JDan Larkin and Mike Petro
_fii_$i/Columnists
_%f.
'' : In many literary circles,
Great Expectations is consid
ered to be Charles Dickens' fin
est work. Granted, I am say
ing this not from experience,
but from something I read on
the Internet. (My sincerest
hope that I will not incur the
wrath of our fine English de
partment here on campus.)
However, I can say this
from experience: the new film
adaptation of the classic tale,
directed by Alphonso Cuaron
and starring Ethan Hawke
(who has lately turned to writ
ing fiction), Gwenyth Paltrow
and Anne Bancroft, is far from
an American classic.

Hollywood seems to have
exhausted the cinematic possi
bilities of William Shakespeare
and Jane Austen, moving on to
Dickens as the author du jour.
Like some of the more recent
Norton Anthology-to-big
screen adventures, Great Ex
pectations has been moved
from its original setting to a
more contemporary backdrop.
In addition; the names of
the novel's central characters
have been changed. Apparently
Dickens' characters' names
seemed out-of place in a mod
ern setting, so the character of
Pip has been given the much
more contemporary "Finn."
But, the change from the novel's

original setting is not the prob
lem with the film. Not to
worry, director Cuaron finds
other ways to disappoint.
For those of you who
don't know the general story,
Finn (Hawke), plays a brilliant
artist who grew up poor in the
Florida panhandle, lusting af
ter his best friend, the rich niece
of Ms. Dinsmoor (Bancroft),
Estella (Paltrow).
Finn's life is traced, in
cluding his upbringing, an en
counter with an escaped mur
derer (Robert DeNiro), and his
eventual rise to prominence in
the New York City art world.
Much like my synopsis of
this movie, the plot is full of
holes, and as a whole, the story
just doesn't flow well at all.
Hawke (Gattaca, Reality
Bites) turns in a good perfor
mance, as does Bancroft (The
Graduate, GI Jane) as the
quirky and partly mad Ms.
Dinsmoor.

As for Paltrow (Emma,
Hook), she turns in an icily
erotic performance that
projects a snobbish and heart
less demeanor, yet hints to the
viewer that there is a softness
within. In fact, one of the few
highlights of this work is see
ing Paltrow maintain the air of
snobbishness broken at time&
by tenderness.
Great Expectations really
doesn't do a very good job hold
ing the story together. The tran¬

sitions made by the film's many
shifts in time are not handled
well ( a problem augmented by
the fact that Hawke and
Paltrow look exactly the same,
whether they're eighteen or
twenty eight.)
This is, however, a really
good looking movie. Both the
scenes set in Florida and New
York are visually spectacular.
The rest of the cast is well
put together. DeNiro (We're
No Angels, Raging Bull) turns
in one of his usual strong per
formances, and one character

worth seeing is Finn's uncle
Joe, played extremely well by
Chris Cooper (A Time to Kill,
Money Train).
The supporting cast of
Great Expectations is probably
the best reason for anyone to
go see it. Cooper does an ad
mirable job, and Bancroft is hi
larious, basically stealing the
show in all of her scenes.
DeNiro is almost incapable of
turning in a bad performance
(hell, I'd have given Spice
World a star or two if he was in
it) and this is no exception.

My main problem with
the movie comes from the two
central characters. Hawke (the
thinking-man's Chris
O'Donnell) and Paltrow (better
known as Brad Pitt's ex) should
hold the film together, but in
stead they turn in fairly lack
luster performances, around
which Great Expectations falls

apart. As a whole, this movie is
a beautifully filmed movie filled
with lush and well designed
scenes. Further, the.well as
sembled cast does a solid job.
However, the plot leaves
too many questions unan
swered, and the fact that so
many changes were made from
the original make this movie
something I would say is best
left alone until video.
I give Great Expecta
tions, for good acting and be
ing technically sound, two out
of five stars.
