In Case You Missed It
Pacino and DeNiro beat up the screen

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist
When you put two film
legends like Al Pacino and Rob
ert DeNiro together on screen,
the result is explosive. Writer/
director Michael Mann pits
these box office giants against
one another in the 1995 movie
Heat. The supporting cast is
dynamic, with actors like Val
Kilmer (The Saint), Jon Voigt
(Mission: Impossible), and
Ashley Judd (Kiss the Girls).
The chemistry of this cast is
incredible, and it makes the
movie extremely enjoyable.
Heat is the story of Neil
McCauley (DeNiro), the leader
of a gang of high profile, tech
nically proficient armed rob
bers. McCauley and his crew
are pursued by the LAPD's
most dedicated cop, Vincent
Hanna (Pacino).

Neil has lined up one last
score, and is planning to leave
his life of crime and settle into

a regular lifestyle with his new
girlfriend, Edie.
His plans are complicated

the hit
list of
shady
business tycoon Roger
Van Z a n t

_L_* 14 1. %J 14 _W_^l
because not only is McCauley
pursued by cops, he is also on

(Will- I
i a m I
Fichtner) I
and his I
hench- I
m a n I
(singer I
Henry I
Rollins). I
Hanna '
is also
trying
to get his

gether. His third marriage is
suffering because of his dedi
cation to his work, and his re
lationship with his wife and

s own life back to-

stepdaughter (Natalie Portman)
is disintegrating.
The plot of the movie
takes many twists and turns,
and all of the characters, no

matter how insignificant they
might seem, come together in
the end. Likewise, the support
ing actors are very important to
the success of the film.

Kilmer gives a stunning
performance as Chris,
McCauley's protege, whose
marriage is falling apart, and
wife Charlene (Judd) is about

t o
leave with their son.
Charlene wants
t o
bring some
sanity
and stabil
i t y
into their lives,
and to
d o
that,

she faces the dilemma of turn
ing Chris in to save the baby
from a foster home.
Each criminal's relation
ship with his family brings a

more human element to the
film. _.
Only once before have
DeNiro and Pacino appeared in
the same film. In The Godfa
ther II, DeNiro portrays a
young Vito Corleone, during
his rise to power in the world
of organized crime. Pacino re
prises his role as Michael
Corleone, the new don of the
Corleone crime family. The
two never met on screen in the
movie, as DeNiro's role existed
solely in flashbacks.
DeNiro's McCauley is
quiet and reserved, yet in the
blink of an eye, he can fly into
a murderous rage. Pacino's
character is emotional and ex
plosive. These two film giants
are what gives the film pa
nache, and the story is substan
tial enough to keep you in sus
pense the whole time.

Heat is by far one of the
best action epics of this decade.
DeNiro and Kilmer have you
cheering for the bad guys until
the end.

Band to rock Huber

by Jared Kaufman
Contributing Reporter
Have you ever wondered
what it would sound like if you
combined the sounds of the
Dave Matthews Band, the
Beatles, and George Clinton?
That's how Joel Streeter, lead
vocalist, guitarist, and
songwriter for Fizgigg, de
scribes his band's unique
sound.
Fizgigg's innovative mu
sic combines the traditional
guitar, bass guitar, drums, and
sax with a cello and sometimes
a congo drum.
Bass guitar is played by
Kyle Gebhart. Of Gebhart's
bass playing, Streeter says,
"Kyle can really play. His tal
ent really comes through on
* Intruder.'"

Drums are handled by
Jeremy Gantz, and Dave
Winjum plays the alto and so
prano saxes. Look for a stel
lar solo by Winjum in the song
"Buck."

The cello is played by
Garon Taylor-Tyree, a cellist
with eight years of classical
training. However, he aban
doned his classical roots to play
provide a lively, upbeat sound
on tracks such as "You Stay"
and "Intruder."
Gantz also plays the
congo drum, which is used in
all of Fizgigg's acoustic perfor¬

mances.
On top of the band's
original material, Fizgigg also
does covers of Paul Simon,
Phish, and the Dave Matthews
Band. Fizgigg has played before
at Gettysburg, at a Coffee
house.
If you think you would
like to hear Fizgigg for your
self, then come to Huber Lobby
this Saturday at 10 p.m. If you
have enjoyed their music up to
this point, be sure to come to
this performance, as the band
has some new material.
And don't forget to re
quest the soon-to-be classic
"Shaft;" he's a bad...you know

Conflict and Consensus
An open letter to the campus community

I want to talk with you
about one of the most impor
tant issues on our campus—stu
dent drinking.
Let me begin by saying
that this is a very difficult topic
for us as a community to dis
cuss. Like many of you, I am
not a teetotaler; I occasionally
enjoy a drink with meals, and
it's hard not to feel either hypo
critical or preachy when talk
ing with others about "appro
priate" behavior surrounding
this issue. Yet as a college presi
dent, not a day goes by when I

am not reminded of the tragic
effects that alcohol can have on
a college campus. Student
drinking is widely perceived to
be the number-one health and
safety issue on college cam
puses today. Over the first part
pf-this academic,.year,,the na
tional media brought us news
of several alcohol-related stu
dent deaths at other colleges
and universities. Here at Get
tysburg, we have seen numer
ous students taken to the hos
pital for over-consumption of
alcohol.

While the issue of student
drinking is of unanimous con
cern, there is no widespread
agreement about how colleges
should respond to this prob
lem. Nationally, the debate
about student drinking tends to
be polarized around two ex
treme stances. First, there are
those who advocate "dry cam
puses" —that is, banning alco
hol anywhere on campus, in
cluding at on-campus parties
and in student residences. On
the other side are those who
argue that "kids will be kids."
These individuals tend to be
lieve that drinking is a normal
and natural part of the college
experience, a "phase" students
go through on the road to re
sponsible adulthood. For col
leges to interfere with this pro
cess, these individuals argue, is
fr> exceed the _hnnndaries nf

appropriate monitoring, step
ping too far into the outdated
notion of in loco parentis.
In fact, both of these po¬

sitions have merit. Yet for
many types of institutions, in
cluding smaller, residential, lib
eral arts colleges like Gettys
burg, neither approach is ideal.
For better or for worse,
drinking is a part of the way
that most college students—
and for that matter, most
Americans— socialize. And if
we accept that most students
are going to drink, we must ask
ourselves, "What in our envi
ronment leads to safe and re
sponsible consumption of alco
hol? And what in our culture
tends to reinforce and perpetu¬

ate abusive, illegal, and exces
sive alcohol consumption?"
The dry campus option can
lead to unmonitored drinking
in off-campus settings that are
difficult to supervise. When
overconsumption occurs,in
such circumstances, the results
can be deadly. On the other
hand, a laissez faire attitude
toward alcohol consumption—
one that allows students to
drink as much as they want to
whenever and wherever they
want to, assuming that they will
quit when they've had
enough—can be equally disas¬

. What, then, are colleges
to do? Each institution must
ask, "What makes sense for us?
What makes sense for our stu
dents?" Clearly, we must obey
the law. And there are certain
types of drinking—drinking
games and binge drinking, for
example—that are especially
dangerous and that should
never be tolerated. But within
this framework there is latitude
and room for debate on which
approach is best suited to indi
vidual institutions.
At Gettysburg, I believe
that we must address this issue
with a three-pronged approach
that provides support for those
who do not wish to drink, per
mits legal and responsible con
sumption for those who wish
to drink (and are legally al
lowed to do so), and provides
for quick and aggressive action
against illegal and abusive con¬

sumption of alcohol.
Make no mistake about
it: Gettysburg College students
are at severe risk for the dan
gers associated with alcohol
consumption. Empirical evi
dence supports our anecdotal
observations: A recent CORE
survey shows that students at
residential, liberal arts colleges
are more likely than students
at large universities to partici
pate in binge drinking. Students
at schools in small towns or
rural settings are more likely to
drink to excess than their coun
terparts at schools in urban set
tings, and students at colleges
in the Northeast demonstrate
higher incidents of binge drink
ing than students at schools in

other parts of the country. Fi
nally, students at schools with
active Greek systems are far
more likely to drink to excess
than students, at schools with
out fraternities and sororities.
It is essential, then, that
Gettysburg—and schools like
Gettysburg—take an active and
aggressive role in helping stu
dents negotiate the issues asso
ciated with alcohol consump
tion. For schools like Gettys
burg, single-issue answers—
like opting for a dry campus,
on the one hand, or arguing for
individual responsibility, on the
other—are not enough. Our
response must be more com
prehensive. Our response must
rely not on a single solution,
but on a combination of tech¬

ques.
First, we must continually
examine our environment, our
policies, practices, and behav
iors to determine what encour
ages responsible alcohol use
and what does not. Such evalu
ation cannot be left to college
administrators alone: students,
student organizations, faculty,
and alumni all need to become
involved in exploring and ad
dressing environmental ques
tions. Second, we must all take
more responsibility for creating
social options that do not re
volve around underage or ex¬

cessive alcohol use. To that end,
I have committed $50,000 this
semester to encourage student
initiated social activities. At a
recent Board of Trustees meet
ing, several students shared
their concerns about what they
believe is a limited range of
social options at Gettysburg.
My hope is that these new
funds will help broaden those
options, and encourage events
that don't center around drink
ing. These funds will be admin
istered by a special subcommit¬

tee of students operating under
the auspices of Student Senate.
Any student who has an idea
for a social event may apply for
funding from this subcommit
tee, which is chaired by Val
Katzmer and also includes
Mark Astrom, Rodwin Lowe,
Jen Gillette, Becca O'Connell,
and Marcello Ardun. In addi
tion, we have freed up the ball
room for several weekend
nights in the spring semester in
order to accommodate events
that might be held in that facil
ity.

Third, we should permit
legal and moderate consump
tion of alcohol in connection
with some College events. His
torically, since fraternities have
dominated the College's .social
scene, "they also' have domi
nated access to alcohol on cam
pus. Our current policies/tend
to discourage alcohol at Col
lege-sponsored events, thereby
driving all drinking (even legal
and moderate drinking) off
campus. This approach does
not allow for the effective mod
eling of responsible drinking by
upperclass students. This se
mester, we will pilot some Col
lege-sponsored events with al
cohol in order to help model
more appropriate drinking be
havior. Alcohol at these events
will be dispensed in accordance
with BYOB policies or with the
assistance of TIPS-trained serv¬

ers. Finally, we must chal
lenge Greek organizations on
this issue. While no one is pre
suming that alcohol abuse is a

"Greek problem," the presence
of Greek organizations is a fac
tor related to higher levels of
binge drinking on college cam
puses. A national study re
leased just before Christmas
indicates that fraternity and
sorority leaders have higher
rates of alcohol abuse than
members or non-members. We
all know how important the
peer group is in influencing stu
dent behavior. Fraternities and
sororities need to develop mea
surable ways to live up to val
ues in their charters stressing
academic achievement
and personal develop
ment. At this time of year, when

Rush and pledging are about to
begin, it is incumbent on all
who participate in the Greek
system to understand the dan
gers inherent in hazing, drink
ing games, and any Rush " event
in which alcohol is present,
whether on campus or off. I
must remind you in the stron
gest words , possible that such
activities will not be tolerated.
The four-year suspension of Phi
Delta Theta last year was due
to the combination of Rush,
alcohol, and drinking games,
which led to the hospitalization
of four students. We cannot—
and will not—^ tolerate such ac
tivities. We will continue to set
and enforce reasonable rules.

We have taken many
good steps and made good
progress in addressing this
problem. We must expand our
support for students who do
not drink, enhancing our com
mitment to substance-free
housing and similar programs.
We need to get serious about
providing alternative beverages
at all campus parties so that
those who don't choose to
drink don't have to. We must
continue our efforts to educate
our students about alcohol—in
wellness classes, in groups like
CHEERS and Bacchus, through
programs like this year's out
standing Alcohol Awareness
Week, and through programs in
- continued on _page 11 -


TT i j Women under covered
Haalana

To the Editor:
I am a weekly reader of
the Gettysburgian and also a
woman athlete on the campus.
Each week I look forward to
reading about how all of the
athletic teams are doing on
campus, not just the mens
teams. Ever since the begin
ning of the year such sports as
Volleyball, Women's Soccer,
and now Women's basketball
have been neglected by your
staff. The school did not even
know that the Women's Volley-

- continued from page 10 -
the residence halls. Finally,
we need to find effective
ways to talk about this issue
on campus. Numerous sur
veys show that the vast ma
jority of our students hold
very responsible opinions
about alcohol and its use. We
need to be more purposeful
about sharing this informa
tion in ways that will help
shape perceptions about
drinking norms.
This is an important is¬

sue, and inevitably there is
more to be done. I invite
your participation in our
ongoing conversation about
how we can best encourage
healthy discussion of this is
sue on campus and develop
appropriate behaviors in our
community. There is no is
sue that is of greater concern
to our alumni, our parents,
and our students. As recent
events have taught us, stu
dent alcohol abuse truly is a
matter of life and death.

ball team won the conference
and played in the NCAA tour
nament.
And now, the Women's
Basketball team is having the
best year in a long time and we
can't even be mentioned in the
NewsPaper. Tell me why two
months after the end of a ter
rible football season there is an
entire page dedicated to their
team? Do you know that the
women's basketball team is
now 11-3 and the men are 9-8,
but somehow that does not

make it in the news. Tell me
how we can get campus sup
port if our very own school
paper can not support us.
Please do not tell me that
you are low on staff members,
because obviously you have a
few too many if you have to
report on the changes being
made for the football team 8
months before they even play.
And why is it the paper can tell
the whole school intramural
scores and not the scores of its
own Women's basketball team.
I am not the only woman
who feels this way about the
neglection of women sports in
the Gettysburgian. I am writ
ing on behalf of my entire team
as well as many other women
athletes on this campus.
I do expect a response to
this message. I will not accept
the sexism to continue any
longer.
Stephanie Dravis '98
Member of the Women's

Conflict and Consensus

In elementary school, we
)iled books high between our
_lesks to hinder any threat of
>eeking. We were taught that
:heating was wrong, and mak
ng prevention a game was fun.
_fhe highest tower of books won
_>eer admiration.
Over 10 years later, we
till know that cheating is
vrong. On the Honor Com
nission in nearly every class
oom, Thomas Jefferson
>reaches, "Nobody can acquire
lonor by doing what is wrong."
Visit a school without an
¦lonor Code and the difference

s obvious. Professors hover
_>ver you while you take a test_,
t_'s more like high school there,
vhere you haven't fully grown
lp, rather than college, where
he assumption is that you can
nake responsible decisions.
That's a huge assumption
:onsidering some of the stu
lents at Gettysburg College. In
he 1990s, does such a thing as
lonor still exist? The fact that
_>ur president is dodging ques
ions of sexual misconduct, one
vonders whether honorable
>eople are still extant.
Hopefully, people con
ider honor an important qual-

ty- The computer science de
>artment has come under fire
or the recent Honor Code vio
ations plague. It is easy to cheat

in the field of computer science
but also easy to be caught.
In a 100-level course,
some students found the only
way to complete projects was to
copy each other's assignments.
Like essays, even at the most
basic level, programs have a dis
tinctive style. Although in
stances are not as clearcut as the
average case of plagiarism, the
telltale signs of wrong doing are
blatant to a computer science
literate person.
The Honor Code is not
equipped to handle these kinds
of cases. The Honor Commis
sion has to confront the diffi
cult task of dealing with the
problems caused by technology

The Honor Commission
also faces the disapproval of the
faculty. The disheartening num
ber of violations each semester
lowers the faith the faculty puts
in the Honor Code. Some of
the major complaints concern
ing the honor system center
around the fact that the process
is slow, relies heavily on the
word of students, is inflexible
in the doling out of punish
ments, and is not reducing the
amount of cheating on campus.
While some would say
that only cheaters need an
Honor Code, others argue that
the honest people should desire
to uphold the Honor Code even
more. Side with the latter.

Conflict and Consensus
From The Donkey's Mouth

Judge not the man, but rather his policy

by Libby Main
Political Columnist
Should it matter if
Monica Lewinsky had a five
year affair with her high school
drama teacher? Should we be
lieve allegations that she had an
obsessive infatuation with the
president and that she told
people her goal was to have a
sexual relationship with him
before she became a White
House intern? Is Lewinsky's
credibility damaged because
she admitted to forging a let
ter from a college administra
tor offering a job to her lover?
Does the women who taped
phone conversations with
Lewinsky, Linda Tnpp, have

questionable motives because
she is connected to a Clinton
defaming publisher? What if
independent Council Kenneth
Star was involved in plans to
secretly wire Lewinsky before
Janet Reno authorized the ex
pansion of his investigation?
Despite the shadiness of
the information which has been
reported about Lewinsky re
cently, I frankly don't think the
answers to any of the above
questions matter. Neither do
the majority of Americans. A
CNN, USA Today, Gallop poll
that was conducted this past
weekend reported that Presi
dent Clinton's approval ratings
are the highest ever—69%,
which is also higher than

Ronald Reagan ever received.
(I say based on this information
let's re-name National Airport
after Bill rather than Ronnie).
In addition, 58% of
Americans feel that Kenneth
Starr should end his investiga
tion and as of last Friday he will
not be able to use Lewinsky's
testimony in the Paula Jones
lawsuit. This is because Judge
Susan Webber ordered all evi
dence related to Lewinsky be
excluded from the Jones pro
ceedings, making Jones case
less likely to hold up.
Despite the fact that these
sexual allegations against the
president have captured con
tinuous media attention, I
doubt that they will ever be re¬

corded as damaging and as dis
turbing as the Whiskey Ring,
Teapot Dome, Watergate and
Iran Contra Scandals in the his
tory books. These scandals in
volved political decisions
rather than the presidents per
sonal life. So while it is nice to
have a U.S. President who is a
moral role model, I think it is
far more important to have one
who is honest in the realm of
public and foreign policy. Be
sides, the British still loved and
respected Churchill despite the
fact that he reportedly held
meetings and greeting foreign
leaders in the nude.
Thus, the fact that these
allegations have taken attention
from President Clinton's State
nf fhe Union Address and an¬

nouncement of his balanced
budget proposal is the biggest
disappointment of the whole
situation. In the State of the
Union, Clinton took a more
moderate stance, claiming that
the era of big government is
over. Using money from to
bacco settlements, the new
budget contains proposals for
new teachers, more child care
money, more health care for
children of the working poor
and more health research dol
lars. Finally, the only questions
which I think are relevant to
this matter are related to how
much it is detracting from, and
effecting the day to day busi
ness of running the United
States.



Morality matters

by Cammie Grant
Political Columnist
President Bill Clinton de
livered his State of the Union
Address last Tuesday night.
Since then approval ratings
have been on a climb. In fact,
he has achieved the highest ap
proval ratings of his presidency,
according to a Time Magazine
poll. In his one hour and
twelve minute speech, Clinton
focussed on his successful ac
complishments and _encouraged
the voters to continue support
ing him. He did not focus on
Monica Lewinsky, but rather

on the future of Americans lives
and the future of our country.
To many Americans, the
approval ratings may come as
a surprise, particularly after his
alleged affair with Monica
Lewinsky. I for one, am
shocked. The public must be
captured by the artificial sincer
ity of Clinton. I will agree that
President Clinton, in times of
hardship, is at his best. In his
State of the Union address, he
came across as sincere and
pure, but is purity a good word
choice when describing our
president? How can we the
people trust and put the future

of our country in the hands of
a man who has been accused
of numerous affairs?
I will leave it to the vot
ers to answer these questions.
In a Time Magazine poll,
Americans believe that
Clinton's alleged affair with
Lewinsky was not conspired by
the conservatives. To the Re
publican party's credit, they
stayed out of the problem and
sat on the side lines watching
Hillary Clinton point her fin
ger in their direction.
Hillary deserves a pat on
the back for sticking up for her
hubby; after all, not every wife

would show such support and
faith in a husband accused
many times of engaging in ex
tra-marital affairs.
Perhaps many Americans
believe that the president's sex
life is personal, and has no rel
evance in assessing Clinton's
performance. Ask yourself,
what does lying under oath
mean, morally and ethically? If
he lied under oath, there
should be no question of resig
nation. In addition to, if he
encouraged Lewinsky to deny
their affair under oath, resig
nation should not be a ques
tion.

I must admit, it is a great
accomplishment for Mr.
Clinton to obtain the highest
ratings in all of his five-year
presidency, especially under the
circumstances. I do commend
our president, if it was from the
heart, for focussing on the fu
ture of America in his address.
If I were in his shoes, I would
be praying on my knees that
whoever else he has been in
volved with, if anyone, stays
quiet, at least through the re
mainder of his presidency.




Conflict and Consensus
The Pachyderm's Pulpit
Happy birthday Mr. President

by J ohn Dunlap
Political Columnist
This week the United
States honors the 87th birthday
of one of its greatest presidents,
Ronald Wilson Reagan. As
President Reagan suffers from
the pain of Alzheimer's Dis
ease, the United States will re
flect upon his life and accom
plishments. We have begun to
honor the work of the 40th
President of the United States
and his Administration. Across
America, bridges, buildings,
and highways are taking on his
name. The Congress will soon
vote on whether to rename
National Airport after Presi
dent Reagan as this great leader
is beginning to take his place
in history.

Despite what some in the
media and academia would
have you believe, Ronald
Reagan was one of the greatest
Presidents in our history. In my
personal opinion President
Reagan stands with George
Washington, Thomas Jefferson,
Andrew Jackson, Abraham Lin
coln, Theodore Roosevelt, and
Franklin Roosevelt as one of
the greatest men who have
served as the Republic's Com
mander in Chief.
When we look at our
most recent presidents, includ
ing our incumbent scandal rid
den Chief Executive, President
Reagan stands out as the

model. A key reason for his
success was that he was not a
career politician, the only eight
years he ever lived in Washing
ton, D.C. were those spent in
the White House. Ronald
Reagan was born into a poor
family in the heartland of
America, Tampico, Illinois.
"Dutch" as the future President
was called was raised in Dixon_,
Illinois and he attended a small
local College called Eureka
where he played football. Af
ter college, Ronald Reagan
would broadcast college foot
ball on a small radio station out
of Des Moines, Iowa. From
there he was able to get a job

with Warner Brothers, and was
off to Hollywood.
During World War II, Mr.
Reagan served in the army and
his acting career moved for
ward. Politically, he was a
Democrat who cast his first
four ballots for president for
F.D.R., and in 1948 cam
paigned for Harry Truman. As
President of the Screen Actors
Guild his concern over the
growing threat of Communism
began to alarm him. His fierce
determination to fight what he
considered an evil system led
him to head Democrats for
Eisenhower in 1952. By the
1960's President Reagan had
moved to the Republican party

and in 1964 he would
address the _^^^_fl

nation on behalf of the Repub
lican Presidential Nominee
Barry Goldwater. Goldwater
was defeated by President
Lyndon Johnson by a landslide
but it launched Ronald Reagan
into the Governorship of Cali
fornia two years later. Gover
nor Reagan cut taxes, balanced
the budget, and fought the pro
test against the Vietnam War.
The Governor was the titular
Conservative leader in the
United States and in 1968 he
received a great deal of support
for the GOP nomination for
President.
Ronald Reagan stood up

for his beliefs before anything
else and his determination
drove him to challenge the Re
publican President of the
United States, Gerald R. Ford.
Reagan took his campaign all
the way to the 1976 Republi
can National Convention.
Four years later he moved the
Republican Party to the right by
winning the party's presidential
nomination. President Jimmy
Carter ran a scare campaign to
defeat the former California
Governor but it failed as the
American people by a large
margin sent an actor to
the White _^^^
House. _^^^^^^^^^^ _m
Af- _^^^^_H_^^^

rw t e r
years
of tur
moil and
crisis, with
the assassina
tion of President
Kennedy, the race
riots and anti-

^^^_H War riots
_^^™ of the 1960's and
1970_'s, the
Watergate Scandal, and Jimmy
Carter's days of malaise, a new
leader known as the "Great
Communicator" gave the
United States hope and turned
the country around.
He gave us the greatest
tax cut in the history of the
United States, an act which re
duced unemployment. Infla
tion and interest rates dropped
and since the Reagan Presi
dency the United States has had
the longest period of economic
growth in our history. With
only a minor decline in the
early nineties our economy has
never stopped growing. Liber¬

als blame President Reagan for
the deficit but in the 1980's rev
enues tripled and the Demo
cratic Congress refused to vote
on his spending cuts. Today
President Clinton and the Re
publican Congress are balanc
ing the budget and cutting taxes
following the Reagan model
and it is working. In 1982
President Reagan along with a
bipartisan coalition saved social
security and in 1986 massive
tax reform was enacted under
his leadership.
The Reagan Administra-

^^^^^^ t l o n
_^^^P_^^^^^ was a
_^r _^ _^^^^_L model

' work and the
J_^_r accomplish¬
ments are end
less. During his
eight years he ran the
country we saw parole at

the federal level abolished.
With the help of First Lady
Nancy Reagan the "Just Say
No" campaign dramatically
dropped drug use in America
and saved the lives of thou
sands of children. President
Reagan fought for free and fair
trade as the United States and
Canadian Free Trade Agree
ment was negotiated but when
Harley Davison was dying, his
leadership saved it with a pro
tective tariff. The president
always did what was right for
the American worker.

Out of all of his accom
plishments, Ronald Reagan's
fierce determination to defeat
what he called the "Evil Em
pire" stands out. He rebuilt our
military, increased defense
spending, and engaged in a se
cret war with the help of our
allies, including British Prime
Minister Margaret Thatcher
and Pope John Paul II, to de
stroy communism. Coming
into office President Reagan
knew communism was dying
but he wanted to speed up its
decline. In 1983, communism

began its retreat with the lib
eration of Grenada, which
freed American students. By
the late eighties the Soviets
were ready to come to the table
and when President Reagan
went to Berlin and declared,
"Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this
wall," the Soviet General Sec
retary did just that. Millions
of people worldwide owe Presi
dent Reagan thier thanks as
nation after nation has been lib
erated from the evils of com
munism. The fact that a piece
of the Berlin Wall can stand
outside the Ronald Reagan
Presidential Library in Simi
Valley, California, is evidence
of President Reagan's place in
history.
More than anything else.

President Reagan gave the
American people hope and they
thanked him for it in 1984 with
a landslide 49 state victory. He
always had a joke, and his hu
mor was a nice change of pace.
His ability to speak to the com
mon person and talk about his
agenda moved the whole coun
try rightward. Today, Bill
Clinton is moving the Demo
cratic Party to the center be
cause under Ronald Reagan the
left was blown out of the wa
ter. In 1988, Ronald Reagan's
Vice President and former op
ponent George Bush won the
Presidency on President
Reagan's coattails and in 1994,
a Republican Congress was
elected for the first time in forty
years carrying the Reagan ban¬

ner. To honor our 40th presi
dent, Ronald Reagan deserves
to be carved into Mount
Rushmore for the American
people always to be able to
honor him. He gave us hope
and restored our faith in our
Republic. He never let the
American people down and
they never let him down. We
owe President Reagan a great
thank you, so thanks to the
Gipper, for all you did for our
country and for my generation.

Math Colloquium Series 212 Gla
Dr. Sandra Fillebrown, St Joseph's
University, "Chaotic Dynamics - Or
When Is Close Good Enough?" A
quadratic function is easy to under
stand, right? Wrong! With the
seemingly innocent idea of iteration
(repeatedly applying function
composition), the quadratic function
goes from being a friendly little
parabola to being a showcase for
chaos. In this talk, we will look at the
dynamics of quadratic iteration and
develop the necessary background to
explain why in chaotic systems, close
is not usually good enough. ALL
STUDENTS AND FACULTY ARE
INVITED.

faculty members will help students
clarify an assignment, plan for an
assignment, organize a paper,
suggest ways to make troublesome

writing difficulties. The staff will

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more information,
contact any of the following
persons: Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext. 8159; T.J. '

"Staying on the right track": catch up with the Bullet track teams

by Nathan Grim and
Bryan Sentz
Contributing Reporters
The Bullets track and
field teams have begun 1998
full of anticipation for a ban
ner season. The women's
team is one of the largest in
recent memory, and returns
many key veterans that will
greatly contribute to its ef
forts to successfully defend
their title as Centennial
Conference champions.
On Sunday, January
18, a skeleton squad of the
men's and women's indoor
track teams competed at
Haverford College. For the
women, Beth Castagno took
first place in the high jump,
clearing 5'6" and tying the
school record.

Sophomore captain
Andi Thent tied for first in
the 55 meter dash (7.5) and
placed second in the 200
meter dash (28.0). Senior
captain Jackie Klug placed
third in the 55 meter high
hurdles (9.0) and Cathy
Spangler captured second
place in the shot put with a
throw of 33'1".
The men's squad also
turned in some solid perfor
mances. Senior captain
Bryan Sentz pole vaulted to
a personal record height of
13'8" that was good enough
for first place.
The men also were

well represented in the shotput
where Mitko Koburov had a
career best throw of 41'1.75"
which earned fifth place. The
shotput was won by Nathan
Grim who threw 5_T1.25" es
tablishing a new school record
and qualifying for nationals.
Last Sunday, February 1
while the rest of campus was
engrossed in preparations for
Groundhog Day, the Bullets
traveled north to Dickinson
College. This was the first meet
for the entire team and many
strong performances were
turned in.
First place finishers for
the women included Beth
Castagno in the high jump and
the 4x400 meter relay team of
Jackie Lumbra, Andi Therit,
Jackie Klug and Keri Hymen.
Emily Cerda placed second and
established a new school record
in the women's pole vault

(7_'0").
The 4x800 meter relay
team ran a strong race to finish
in third place. Other bronze
medalists for the Bullets were
Andi Therit in the 55 meter
dash (7.74), Keri Hymen in the
400 meter dash (65.15) and
Eileen Chazan in the200 meter
dash (27.76).
Molly O' Keefe took
fourth in the 1500 meters,
(5:42.64) as did Tracy
Swackhammer in the 800
meters, (2:34.93). The silver
spike award, given to the Bul
let who has turned in the best

student Ken Hymen for her
stellar performances in the 400

The men's squad was

Brendan captured two second

earned him a share of the menis

Olympic Spotlight

by Matthew Eisenberg
Asst. Sports Editor
With only a day until the
1998 Winter Olympics com
mence in Nagano, Japan, CBS
has come under fire by sports
writers and Olympic fans. The
problem is with the tape delay
and air times of certain events,
such as figure skating and ice
hockey. Since the time differ
ence is 14 hours the winners
will be known by the morning
talk shows. CBS will be airing
women's figure skating, the
main event of the winter
Olympics, at least 14 hours af
ter the fact. Most of America,
if they desire will know the re¬

sults by lunch.
The critics are not asking
CBS to make the Olympics for
North America, but there could
be some concessions made. If
they were to have some events
at 10 a.m. Japan time they would
be on at 8 p.m. here. They are
not asking for all events, they un
derstand that the Japanese work
days and pay upwards of $200
for tickets to the women's figure
skating finals.
The loser with the time dif
ference is the NHL. They have
made several concessions to al
low players to compete for their
nations. The hockey times are
all 12 a.m. or later, the benefits

of this situation for the NHL is
questionable. It seems that the
NHL is using Nagano as a trial
run for the 2002 Olympics in
Salt Lake City, Utah. If CBS
executives were smart, they
would have requested that
some of the hockey games be
played at 10 a.m.
The winners will
definately be men's alpine ski
ing, with all their events being
broadcast live. Tommy Moe
will be the American to watch.
He was the first American to
ever medal in two alpine
events. He won a gold and a
silver at the last Olympics in
Lillehammer, Norway. He has

been recovering from knee sur
gery and hopes to retain glory.
However, CBS will still
give excellent coverage overall
and their ratings will be higher
than the Super Bowl because of

photo courtesy of ESPNet Sportzone
the wider audience appeal of
figure skating. Most sports
writers agree that middle
America will continue to watch
events even if they know the
results.

Bullets men's swimming stays on roll

by Kelli Brennan
Staff Reporter The Men's Swim Team

nior Todd Peters in the 200
yard IM, freshman Matt
Flaherty in the 100 yard But
terfly, sophomore Jamey
Gallagher in the 100 yard Back
stroke, senior Pete Casares in
the 500 yard Freestyle, and
freshman Kris Nessler in the
100 yard Breaststroke.

ters teamed up with junior Rich
Caroll to win the 200 yard
Freestyle Relay. The Men's
Swim Team continues to domi
nate going 4-0 in Centennial

Conference meets.

further dominated the Confer
ence on Saturday, January 31,
defeating Swarthmore College.

had an outstanding meet, win
ning the 50 yard Freestyle, the
400 yard Medley Relay along
with team-mates Chris Hill,
Gavin Quinn and Tim Valen
tine. Winning the 400 yard
Freestyle Relay along with
teammates Pete Casares, Todd

Peters, and Dave Lavigne, se
nior sprint freestyler Todd Pe
ters, also won the 200 and 100
yard Freestyles. Junior breast
stroker Gavin Quinn finished
in first place in the 200 yard
IM and in third place in the 200
yard Breaststroke. Sophomore
Tim Valentine placed first in
the 200 yard Butterfly while
classmate and teammate Chris
Hill placed first in the 200 yard
Backstroke. The final score
was 139-66 and the team has
improved their overall record

Sports as Steve Sees it...

The nation gears up for UNC -DUKE

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
It has finally arrived. No,
it is not time for the return the
footlong hot-dog at servo, nor
have the Spice Girls finally de
cided to kick back and bear it
all. Finally it is time for the
match-up we have been salivat
ing over for weeks. Duke ver
sus North Carolina.
Duke and North Carolina
held the top two spots in The
Associated Press' college bas
ketball poll Monday, setting up
a No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchup this
week. The Blue Devils (20-1),
who stayed in the No. 1 spot
for the third straight week, will
play at North Carolina (22-1)
on Thursday night in the 14th
meeting of the poll's top two
teams since 1980.

The game will be broad
cast live by ESPN2 at 9 p.m.
ET. The last 1-2 matchup was
Kentucky's win over No. 1

Massachusetts in the 1996 Fi
nal Four. The last regular-sea
son matchup was between
Duke and North Carolina on
Feb. 3, 1994, an 89-78 victory
for the second-ranked Tar
Heels. Duke received 54 first
place votes and 1,734 points
from the national media panel,
41 more than North Carolina,
which was No. 1 on 16 ballots.
However, Thursday you
can flush all the ballots and all
the votes right down the
_perverbial toilet. It is going to
be Duke's best five against
UNC's best for forty minutes
and that is all.
Who will win? Will it be
the Duke Blue Devils and the
composure of Coach Mike
Krewjewski, or will it be the
run and gun, in your face style
of coach Bill Guthendge.

If both teams bring their
best games and their best play
tonight, it will be a battle for
the ages. UNC stars Vince

Carter, Antawn Jamison, and
Ed Cota will look to pummel
the Duke standouts; namely,
Steve Wojcieowski, Trajan
Langdon, and Rickey Price.
Duke is like a man smok
ing a cigarette by a gas station;
they are blowing up. They
have lonly lost one game this
year to defending national
champion Arizona, and have
tortured their ACC foes by con
siderable margins.
UNC also only has one
loss, and has what many ex
perts consider two of the most
explosive players in college bas
ketball in Jamison, and Carter.
Both of these players for UNC
have dominated Atlantic Coast
Conference oppponents and
have showed that they have the
skills to shine at the NBA level
as well.

photo courtesy of ESPNet Sportzone
Antawn Jamison looks to lead the Tarheels past conference
rival Duke.

ably say that this basketball
game will be, "SENSA

Beckler & Burzio

The swim teams' "Killer B 's "

by Chistopher Bowman
B.A.S.S/Contributing Writer
Picture this: a blonde
haired little girl diving into the
pool at the country club. This
was how the swimming career
of Liz Burzio began. Liz, at the
age of 20, is a sophomore ma
joring in political science. She
comes to Gettysburg from her
hometown, Potomac, Mary
land. Liz has one younger sis
ter, age 17, who surprisingly
did not follow in the footsteps
of her older sister. The most
enjoyable aspects of swimming
for Liz include the friendships
that she has made over the
years, as well as two trips to
Barbados with the college swim
feam

Liz feels that through
swimming she has really been
able to have a lot of fun, and
meet a lot of people, some of
whom she has grown quite
close to. The country club pool
was just the beginning for Liz.
Soon after she began to com
pete in the summer leagues, her
coach encouraged her to con
tinue swimming throughout
the winter, in order to make her
that much better for the com
mencement of the summer sea¬

son. Throughout her career,
and still to this day, she com
petes in the 200m and 100m

backstroke, 200m individual
medley, and 400m and 200m
medley relay. The fondest
memory for Liz was at the age
of 12, when she maintained an
undefeated record throughout
the County Championship,
where her team finished first
overall, and she obtained the
highest overall point total for
an individual.
Liz also told me that one
of the reasons she is still swim
ming in college is because of
her coach, Mr. Mike Rawleigh.
She says, "He just makes it easy
for me to still want to swim."
Coach Rawleigh helps to cre
ate a fun, and hard working
atmosphere for his athletes,
which has enabled the swim
team to produce such a tremen
dous winning record over the
years. Liz Burzio is obviously
not a stranger to the water, and
neither is her friend, and team
mate, Mark Beckler.

Mark also started at a
young age, in his hometown of
Merchantville, New Jersey,
only he has Liz beat by three
years. Mark also grew up
around the water, spending his
summers at the swim club.
Mark felt that at the age
of four he was perfectly ready
for competitive swimming, and
decided to meet this challenge
the following summer, as he
joined the swim team at the age

Pholo By Emily Giatfelter
This Bullet swimmer has gotten out quick and is lengths past the competition.

of five. He hasn't stopped since
then, and plans to finish his
college career. He competes in
the events of 200m and 100m
breaststroke, 500m freestyle,
and 400m and 200m individual
medley.
Mark said that it defi
nitely isn't easy, but to help
keep swimming interesting, he
also participated in soccer,
starting at age six, and continu
ing through high school.
Though swimming is hard

work, Mark looks forward to
forming new friendships each
season, and loves to travel. He
also likes the fact that it helps
to keep him in good physical
condition.
Mark told me that his
most memorable moment
would have to have been when
he qualified for YMCA Nation
als during his junior year in
high school with a broken arm.
He still to this day feels
that he has never swum faster.

Mark loves to compete, and
accepts the challenges which
swimming present, which to
him has just become a part of
his life.
On top of this, Mark has
declared a major in Biochem
istry and Molecular Biology. As
you can see, if you stop by the
pool every now and then, the
many long years of hard work
and determination have paid
off for both of these talented
young athletes.


Women swimmers on top again

from Centennial Conference
Press Release Gettysburg remains on
top of the conference stand
ings with perfect records as the
women's swimming team
swept two more meets last
week. With the most recent
win over Dickinson, the Bul
lets are 6-0 in the Conference
and 7-0 overall.
Gettysburg easily de
feated Western Maryland, 70-

19, and Swarthmore, 133-72.
Megan Lewis took the
200 free and ied her team to
the finish in both relays.
Karin Olmstead and
Kelly Brennan were both
triple-winners against
Swarthmore.
In all Centennial Confer
ence meets, Gettysburg has at
least one swimmer ranked in
the top five.
In the 50 free,
Gettysburg's Olmsted,

Brennan, and Lewis rank as the
top three.
Gettysburg took second
through fifth overall in the
1650 freestyle with Mairead

$50,000 result of increased enrollment

by Keith Davis
Staff Reporter Many students question
the source behind the funding
of the Student Life Committee.
The $50,000 given to the
SLC by the administration is a
direct result of the increased
enrollment of first year stu
dents in the fall of 1997, ac
cording to President Haaland.
"The money basically
comes from more students en
rolled than we had budgeted
for," Haaland said.
The extra money avail
able is used as a contingency.
Because of the desire to im
prove social outlets for students
by both the student body and
the administration, the possi
bility for improvement became
more tangible. The available
desire and money lead to the
creation of the SLC experi¬

. "It was a spontaneous
decision but was made in con
junction with a lot of thinking
about the College's social life,"
Haaland.

President Haaland spoke
of the dilemma the administra
tion and some students, now
members of the SLC faced in a
forum. This forum met at the
end of last semester to discuss
the problems of social life for
students. According to
Haaland, the dilemmas faced
were rooted in the design of
current social activities. He
states that the are a lot of op
tions currently available such as,
readings, musical performances
and so forth but mentioned the

conflict between these events
and the diversity of students.
"The students are very
diverse and some activities are
just not designed for them," he
said. The SLC is responsible
for allocating the $50,000 to
groups interested in sponsoring
events for the entire campus.
There are a certain criteria the
committee will follow. Because
the committee of students is an
experiment its direction is not
yet known. The administration
has given no guarantee that

funding will continue into fu
ture semesters, however both
President Haaland and Dean
Ramsey are confident that SLC

will be successful.
"If it is successful, we will
do the best to keep it going,"
Haaland said.

-Features
Sabres, rifles, and smiles

by Cara Masucci
Staff Reporter There are many different
activities and clubs on campus
that offer a wide variety of cul
tural experiences. The newly
founded Indoor Color Guard
is one of them. With sabres,
rifles, flags, and intricate dance
moves, the nine members at
tempt to capture beauty and
grace at its finest.
Indoor Color Guard is a
relatively new activity on cam
pus, drawing heavily upon the
initiative of several persistent
young women.
An extension of the Out
door Color Guard in the fall,
cofounders Clair Roberts and
Maureen Miller, Melanie
Milburn, Melodie Foster,
Mandi Latronica, Christina
Dickert, Kristin O'Neill, Laura
Fairbairn, and Katy Roy have
put forth a tremendous effort
to get this activity off the
ground this semester.

Color Guard itself is the
highly skilled performance
group of eight to fifteen mem
bers. It involves choreograph
ing moves and tosses of flags,
sabres, and rifles to a variety of
different types of music.
A performance based
upon interpretation, color
guard allows for a huge expres
sion of individuality and inten
sity by the performers, accord
ing to president Maureen
Miller.
This, the first year for the
Gettysburg College Indoor
Color Guard, has been a build
ing experience. Miller, a jun
ior, and Roberts, a first year
student, both came from very
competitive high school teams.
The rest of the team has

varying levels of experience.
What is really great is how they
are willing to work together,
says Miller.
Speaking to Miller, it be
came very clear how much of
effort has been put into the rou
tine. At the beginning of the
semester, the guard had two

grueling nine hour practice ses
sions where they learned the
basics of the performance.
Since then, they have
been practicing four hours a
week with an optional practice
for those who feel they need
to work on their technique.

The
women are very
con
cerned
with the
precision and ex
ecution of
their

moves.
Both Miller and Rob
erts com
mented
on the im
portance of timing,
and work
ing to
gether.
Ev
erything
has to be
exact for
the show
to be a
hit. That
takes a lot
of effort
on the
part of ev
eryone in
volved.
Ac
cording to
Miller,
the rou-

| _,
¦ Photo by Emily Glatleller
Laura Fairbairn and Kristin O'Neill pause during a rehearsal for
the indoor color guard. Rehearsals last for two hours.

can mes appear
easier than they really are, but
there are things people do not
realize about the motions.
Some technical aspects include
posture and the positioning of
hands for tosses and spins.
Miller was quick to point
out that she was really happy
with how things were develop
ing. "I'm really proud of ev
eryone, and it's a lot of fun
when there are moments that

everything comes together."
For the newly formed In
door Color Guard, individual
ity and expression takes the
theme of Celtic Nights. Com
bining a very Irish selection of
music and a series of intricately
designed dance moves, the

theme burns throughout the
show. The group decided on the
Celtic theme because, according
to Roberts, they wanted to
make it beautiful. "It [color
guard] is an art form." The
music is full of passion, inten
sity, and radiance, much like the
art form itself.
Miller and Roberts wrote
the routine over winter break,
and Milburn (the choreogra¬

pher) helped iron out the rough
edges. The women used their
own experience in high school
color guard as a basis for teach
ing and instructing the other
members.
As Mandi Latronica,
whose mother made the flags

said, "It's amaz
ing that we put
this together as
kids." It has not
been an easy
battle, though.
Between gruel
ing practices
and having to go
out and find
their own equip
ment, the girls
know the real
meaning of hard
work. Over va
cation, and even

through their
season, the team
has devoted
much time to
making and fix
ing old equip
ment for the
routine. The
team also sets up
and takes down
their equipment
during the per
formances, since
they are given
only so much
time to get on
and off the
floor.

The group
is quick to point
out that the

campus community has been
very supportive of their efforts.
Earlier this year, Student Sen
ate allotted $500 to the guard.
Miller was enthusiastic about
the money and recognition the
team will be receiving from
Senate at the beginning of next
year. "Campus support means
so much to us," Miller said.
"We [perform] for the cam
pus."

The Indoor Color Guard
will be performing for the cam
pus on Wednesday, February
18th, at halftime of the men's
varsity basketball game. Gear
ing up for that performance, on
Saturday the women will travel
to Philadelphia for a competi
tion. The team will perform
against at least fifteen other
guards.
They would also like to
perform on campus again dur
ing Get Acquainted Day, and
another as yet unspecified per
formance.
One of the team's main
goals, outside of performing,
has been to boost membership
and interest in the organiza
tion. The women are very ea
ger to point out that the Indoor
Color Guard is something any
one can join.

It is not necessary to have
previous experience, one needs
only dedication and the willing
ness to work hard. The women
would like to expand the color
guard to include men as well.
Anyone interested in join
ing need not wait until next
fall. It is possible, according to
Robert and Miller, to come and
practice with the team.
While it might be too late
to compete, there are advan
tages to having a semester more
of training. That way, the
whole process can become
quite cyclical. If one were in
terested, he or she should con
tact Maureen Miller or Clair
Roberts.
The Indoor Color Guard
members are quite excited
about the future. Prospects for
success look good, and like the
Dance Ensemble, the guard
hopes to become an integral
part of campus life.

The hard work should
pay off, and from the laughs
and smiles at practices, the nine
women have gained a sense of
accomplishment and achieve
ment from laying the founda
tion for the Indoor Color
Guard, not to mention a feel
ing of fun.



Beware the
"Grim Reefer"

Valentine's Day for the lonely

by Kyle Heulitt
GECO Columnist

For years, people have
been awed by the beaury of
coral reefs. Aside from their
aesthetic appeal, coral reefs
give rise to a very complex and
diverse ecosystem, and provide
an ideal habitat for many or
ganisms. Unfortunately,
throughout the world, coral
reefs are being threatened by
human activity.
Reefs occur around the
world in clear, shallow, tropi
cal waters. Over thousands of
years, they are built up by tiny
coral animals called polyps,
which are aided by minute al
gae called zooxanthellae that
live in their tissue. Biologically,
coral reefs are the second most
productive systems in the
world after tropical rainforests.
Although they cover only one
percent of the earth's surface,
they are home to twenty-five
percent of all marine fish.
Reefs are also a potential
source for new medicines.

Chemical compounds from
tropical reef organisms show
promise of being effective
against diseases such as arthri
tis, cancer, and AIDS.
Threats to the reefs have
never been greater than they
are today. Their ecosystems are
disturbed by commercial fish
ing and harvesting of valuable
species, mining of reef lime
stone for building materials,
pollution and sedimentation
caused by deforestation, and
excessive coastal development.
Disease and damage from
pollution has wiped out huge

areas of the Florida Reef Tract,
the third largest coral reef sys
tem in the world, as well as in
parts of the Caribbean and
Asia. An increase in phospho
rous and nitrogen levels due to
human waste and agricultural
run-off has caused life-destroy
ing algal blooms, covering the
coral and killing it. Careless
anchoring and accidental boat
groundings have also de
stroyed years of coral growth
in minutes.
Experts also agree that if
reefs are to be preserved, the
sale, importation, and harvest
ing of corals must end. In third
world countries, thousands of
tons of living corals are being
ripped from the reef by cranes
and sold in foreign markets,
notably the U.S.

Worldwide, approxi
mately ten percent of all reefs
have degraded beyond recov
ery, and if current practices go
unchecked, it is estimated that
twenty to thirty percent of the
resource could be destroyed
within the next ten to twenty
years. Fortunately, many
threats to coral reefs are re
versible and preventable, but
we must act before any more
damage is done. If we do not,
we will have destroyed in mere
decades what it took thousands
of years to create.
For more information on
coral reefs, check out:
www.erols.com/psiegel/
coral.html
www.enn.com/
newswire/09309 7/
09.309706.htm

by Barb Dickson
Features Editor
Saturday is the big day, and the card and candy makers will not let us forget it.
There is a large number of people out there who think that Valentine's Day should be
wiped off the calendar forever. Obviously, we are the people who do not have a "signifi
cant other" (s.o.) this Valentine's Day. Valentine's Day was a happy day until about
fourth grade, when we stopped exchanging valentines with everyone in our class. For us,
it is now a day of pure misery, when our lack of a boyfriend/girlfriend is clearly shown.
Unfortunately for us, this year, the big V-Day falls on a Saturday. So what do we do this
Saturday night, without someone special to share it with? Here's a list that I've come up
with (with the help of my many single friends).
1. Sit in your room with some Ben &C Jerry's and cry.
2. Pretend it's just any other day and conduct business as usual.
3. Hit on every guy/girl/farm animal you see in hopes of getting a s.o. by the end of
the evening.

4. (Over 21) Go to JD's and get wasted
(Under 21) Goto LD's and just be happy
5. Hang out with other people who don't have a s.o.
6. Crash someone else's date
7. Send yourself roses.
8. Listen to sappy music.
9. Read a trashy romance novel.
10. Call the psychic hotline.
11. Write a nasty letter to an ex.
12. Flirt with someone on the Internet.
13. Think up evil sayings for those little candy hearts.
14. Send evil valentines to people.
15. Watch romantic comedies and boo at the end.
16. Watch tragic love stories and cheer at the end.
17. Leave town and spend the night in a cave.
18. One word: Chocolate.
19. Go see Titanic—you're going to have to eventually anyway. If it's not at the
Majestic, I'm sure it's somewhere within driving distance.
20. Make hearts out of red construction paper and burn them with a few close
friends.

One in four women...

by Kerry Reid and Ken
Greenberg
Contributing Reporters
One in four college
women...
• survive rape (15%) or
attempted rape (12%).
• 84% of survivors knew
their attacker.
• 57% of rapes happen
on dates.
• 75% of the men and
55% of the women involved in
acquaintance rapes were drink
ing or taking drugs just before
the attack.
• 41% of college women
who are raped were virgins at
the time.
• 70% of rape survivors
physically resisted the rape in
some manner.

• 92% of the time when
a woman reports a rape, she's
telling the truth.
• 84% of rape survivors
tried unsuccessfully to reason
with the man who raped her.
In the last half of 1995,
432,700 incidents of rape, at
tempted rape, and sexual as
sault, happened to women in
the United States. This
amounts to 99 women every
hour. • 42% of rape survivors
told no one about the rape.
• 42% of rape victims
had sex again with the rapist.
• 41% of women who are
raped expect to be raped again.

• 30% of rape victims
contemplate suicide after the
rape. • 84% of men who com
mitted rape said that what they
did was definitely not rape.
• 55% of gang rapes on
college campuses are done by
fraternities, 40% by sports
teams, 5% by others.
• 35% of men report
some likelihood that they
would rape if they could be as
sured thy would not be caught.
Women who are raped
define their experience as such:
1/4 define it as rape, 1/4 think
it was a crime but did not know
it was rape, 1/4 believed it was
serious sexual abuse but did not
know it was a crime, 1/4 did
not feel victimized by the ex
perience.

Rape is common world
wide, with 19%-28% of col
lege women reporting rape or
attempted rape all over the
world. In many countries,
women are treated far worse
than in the United States.
Statistics were taken from
John D. Foubert's "The Men's
Program: 'How to Help a
Sexual Assault Survivor: What
Men Can Do."
These may be difficult
facts to accept, but they are
facts. Rape can happen to any
one: friend, family member, co
worker, or peer - male or fe
male. However, in 99% of all
rapes or attempted rapes

women are the victims. Yes,
rape occurs on the small cam
pus of Gettysburg College, as
it is a problem on every college
campus.
If someone who is close
to you is a recent survivor, here
are some ways that you can
help: 1. Tend to her needs.
Make sure both her medical
and emotional needs are met.
Be sure that she can feel safe.
2. No More Violence.
Saying that you are going to
beat him up is usually the last
thing she wants to hear. The
best advice is to let her know
you are upset that this hap
pened to her and that you will
do anything to help her re
cover.

3. Comfort her. What
she does need from you is to
be comforted. Let her be in
charge - she may want a hug,
some don't want to be touched.
4. Listen. Don't ask for
details. Don't suggest why it
happened. Listen to what she
wants to say, and don't judge
her. 5. Believe her. The single
most important factor in recov
ery is whether or not she is be
lieved. There is a 92% chance
she's telling the truth.
6. Give her control. Get
her to make small decisions,
whether about a restaurant or
a soda. Accept her decisions
even if you don't agree. Be

patient, it will take her a long
time to decide.
7. Realize limitations.
Victims often remain in acute
trauma for three months. One
year recovery time is common,
even with counseling, and some
take years.
Refer the rape victim to
counseling!
Don't talk to the survivor
about your own feelings, but do
talk to others. If you are over
whelmed, get counseling for
yourself.
We are fortunate at
Gettysburg to have a number
of resources for survivors. En
courage the survivor to get the
medical attention that they
need as well as the crucial coun
seling she needs.
• Health Center (x6972)
• Gettysburg Hospital
(334-2121 or 334-0468)
• Counseling Center
(x6960)
• Crisis Intervention

(334-2121)
• Survivors (334-9777)
If the individual wants to
report the rape, call Security
(x6911) or the Borough Police
(334-1168).
If you are a survivor, you
are not alone. One in four. . .
look around.
All-male peer education
programs are the most effective
means to change men's atti
tudes toward rape. If you are
interested in taking part in such

a group, contact Dennis
Murphy (his office is in the
CUB, in the Office of Student
Activities, or e-mail him at
dmurphy). EARN
$750-$1500/Week
Raise all the money your
student group needs by
sponsoring a VISA Fundraiser
on your campus. No invest
ment and very little time
needed. There's no
obligation, so why not call for
information today.
Call 1-800-323-8454, ext. 95

Blues redux
All the music; few of the laughs

Reel Hits & Misses

by Dan Larkin and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Mike: Jake's dead, and
Elwood is back to bring the
world the blues. That is, Dan
Aykroyd and John Landis have
teamed up to bring the Blues
Brothers back to the big screen.
Dan: To be honest, the
very idea of resurrecting this
classic of American comedy
without John Belushi is some
thing close to blasphemy. De
spite this, I still tried to enter

Blues Brothers 2000 with a
relatively open mind. I'm re
ally not sure why I bothered.
In BB2K, Jake has passed
on to that big gig in the sky,
and Elwood is left to face the
world on his own. So as you
may very well guess, he does
the only thing he knows how
to do: he buys an old police car
from a surplus yard owned by
aspiring musician Malvern
Gasperon (B.B. King), and sets
about "getting the band back
together."

What follows is more in
tune with a remake than a se
quel. Elwood, played by a sig
nificantly slimmer Dan
Aykroyd (Dragnet), teams up
with some new "brothers":

Mighty Mack, the replacement
big guy, played by John
Goodman (Barton Fink), Cabel
"Cab" Chamberlain, played by
Joe Morton (Terminator 2),
and Buster, played by J. Evan
Bonifant (3 Ninjas Kick Back).
As a general rule, Dan
Aykroyd is only funny when he
teams up with someone else
who can carry the comedic
weight (i.e. Belushi in the origi
nal Blues Brothers, Bill Murray
in Ghostbusters, Eddie Murphy
in Trading PlacesJ. In BB2K,
Aykroyd has to carry the entire
movie on his shoulders, and it
just doesn't work.
The only laughs the movie
provides come more from a rec
ognition factor than actual
comedy, as the sequel revisits
the original ad nauseam.
Goodman, who is capable of
excellent comedic perfor
mances, is not an asset here.

As Elwood and his new
found "family" set about to
find the scattered band, they
become the focus of a state to
state police chase, upset the
Russian mafia, and enrage
some right-wing militia mem
bers. Sound familiar?
This is a movie that never
should have been revived. The

biggest indicator of a franchise
showing its age and lack of en
ergy is the addition of an obnox
ious little kid. Buster's addition
to the cast is reminiscent of the
introduction of Oliver to the
Brady Bunch in its last season
after Bobby and Cindy weren't
as cute as they used to be. While
he may not be as annoying as
Oliver, Buster is yet another of
the many strikes against BB2K.
Let me be honest with
everyone. This movie's plot is
terrible. The first Blues Broth
ers became a revered cult hit
because it is genuinely funny
throughout the movie, and it
had an unbelievable cast. This
movie's plot is not funny, and I
found it lacking energy.
Lacking a certain energy
is putting it mildly to say the
least. BB2K goes through the
motions, duplicating the plot of
the original, minus most of the
laughs. The best example of this
can be seen in the car chase

scenes, which attempt to repli
cate some of the fun of the first
movie, but fall so short of their
mark that one wonders why the
film's creators even bothered.
HOWEVER, this movie
flat out blows away the first
when it comes to music. With

the exception of Aretha
Franklin singing "Respect" to
Matt "Guitar" Murphy, all the
songs are different from the
original movie.
Furthermore, the talent
overflows in this movie.
Aykroyd, Goodman, Bonifant,
and Morton are all solid, but
it is the entire band that really
rocks this movie. Even beyond
the Blues Brothers band itself,
we see other music greats such
as James Brown, Wilson
Pickett, Johnny Lang, Blues
Traveller, and much more than

my knowledge of music allows
me to even recognize.
The best scene in this
movie comes at the end when
the Blues Brothers enter a
battle of the bands against the
Louisiana Gator Boys at
Queen Mousette's, a voodoo
club. Queen Mousette
(Erykah Badu) obviously has
an eye for talent because the
Gator Boys consist of Eric
Clapton, B.B. King, Bo
Diddley, Isaac Hayes, Dr.
John, Billy Preston, Lou
Rawls, Travis Tritt, and Steve
Winwood.

I needn't tell you what
kind of performance they put
on. But I will say this, in a year

when Puff Daddy sells millions
of records for stealing-oops
sorry-"sampling" from every
one under the sun, it was a fan
tastic experience to see and
hear master musicians practice
their craft.
In Puff's defense, he
doesn't strictly sample, but re
record and .update classic
grooves for a new audience
(which, I suppose, is what
Aykroyd and Landis are at
tempting to do with this se
quel). But I digress.
Yeah, the music is good.
But I went to see this movie
hoping to be entertained. What
I got instead is a tepid remake
of a movie that should have
been allowed to rest in peace.
People shouldn't waste
their time or money on this tur
key. For the music, I give this
one star (out of five). If you
want to hear the music, I sug
gest you buy the soundtrack.

I was disappointed that
this installment of the Blues
Brothers didn't make me laugh
as much as the first did. How
ever, the music really impressed
me. I give this movie two and
a half stars out of five. The
movie is the music, and the
music makes it worth seeing.

by Libby Musselman
Contributing Reporter
Why did the library stop
sending my fines by mail?
Sending overdue notices
via e-mail is part of our ongo
ing effort to reduce waste and
act in an environmentally re
sponsible way. By sending
overdues via e-mail, we save
paper and ink, reduce wear and
tear on the printers, and use stu
dent workers for more impor
tant tasks than folding and mail
ing paper notices. Hold Pickup
and Recall notices will be
printed and also be delivered
over e-mail. However, we will
continue to send all replace
ment bills in print to your cam
pus box. If you must have your
notices sent on paper, please
contact Linda Isenberger

(lisenber) by day, Jon Lady
(jlady) by night, or call x7024.
/ am clueless about
searching in the library. How
am I supposed to know how to
run all these databases and
search engines? Nobody is
picking up the phone and I need
help! Librarians are at the ref
erence desk 60 hours per week
(Monday-Friday 9-5; Sunday
Thursday 6-10). If you call the
reference desk (x6600) during
those hours and we don't an
swer the phone, that's because
we're helping someone else
who is in the library. If you
come over, you'll have first
priority, too.
My professor told me to
go to the library for an RPC.
What is it?
Research Paper Consul¬

tations are offered by the ref
erence librarians. Make an ap
pointment for a personal con
sultation with a librarian. You
just fill out a form to let the li
brarians know for what course
your paper is, the topic, and
when you're available. They'll
get back to you with an ap
pointment verification. 163
students took advantage of
RPCs last semester.
When you drop in, check
out the posters hanging in the
stairwells. They're vintage
World War I, saved in our col
lege archives. Of particular
note is the "V" flag, or Victory
Liberty Loan Flag. It hangs
between the second and third
floors and would have been
given in recognition of the
college's participation in the
bond drive at that time.


Happy drives
laughter home

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist

Finally, someone has
made golf fun again. Adam
Sandier is hilarious starring in
Happy Gilmore, the best golf
movie since Caddyshack.
Ever since he learned to
skate, Happy Gilmore
(Sandier) has wanted to be a
hockey player. He holds two
junior hockey records: most
minutes spent in the penalty
box, and for being the first
person to take off his skate
and try to stab someone.
Since graduation, Happy has
been working odd jobs be
tween hockey tryouts. After
being passed over again,
Happy's life takes a strange

. Happy's grandmother,
who raised him after his fa
ther was killed by a Terry
O'Reilly slap-shot at a Bruins
hockey game, has had her
home repossessed by the IRS.
After winning a long-drive bet
with the movers, Happy sees
a way to make the $270,000
he needs to buy back the
house his grandfather built.
With his hot temper,
Happy doesn't seem like your
typical placid golfer. With
Chubbs Peterson (Carl Weath
ers) as his coach, Happy wins
a spot on the pro tour. On
the pro tour, Happy battles
Bob Barker and an alligator,

and falls in love with the tour's
PR agent (Julie Bowen). With
her help, Happy will try to beat
the arrogant tour favorite,
Shooter McGavin (Christopher
McDonald).
Sandler's brand of comedy
is one of a kind. In Happy
Gilmore he has the ability to
please all kinds of audiences,
young and old, with his antics
and running commentary about
the "sport" of golf.
Sandler's performance is
bolstered by his supporting cast,
which includes evil nurse Ben
Stiller {Reality Bites), construc
tion foreman Richard Kiel, and

existential golfer Kevin Nealon.
Since leaving Saturday
Night Live, Sandler's career has
skyrocketed. He was a very
popular cast member, playing
such roles as "Opera Man" and
the obsessive host of "The
Denise Show." By the time
Happy Gilmore was released in
1996, Sandier had already re
leased two comedy albums, and
had starred in Billy Madison and
Airheads with Brendan Fraser
(George of the Jungle). Late last
year he released his third album,
What's Your Name?, as well as a
new rendition of the ever-popu
lar "Chanukah Sons."

Sandier currently stars in
The Wedding Singer, which will
be released tomorrow. If it's any
thing like Sandler's other cin
ematic efforts, it will be a defi
nite hif.
