Conflict and Consensus

by Christina Dickert
Columnist Welcome to my first col
umn. My apologies to the fans
of political columns, but this
column is definitely not about
the leaders of our land. Actu
ally, it's not really about any
thing. Before Jerry Seinfeld's
lawyers come after me for roy
alties (What would I give them?
My tuition bill?), I'll admit that
this column will have some sort
of topic every time it appears.
What sort of topic? That, my
friends, will be decided a few
hours before it is written. Now
that you know where I am com
ing from, on with the show.
"Shut up. Just shut up.
You had me at hello. (Sniffle.)

You had me at hello."
Even if you hate Tom
Cruise or haven't seen Jerry
Maguire a hundred times, you
know that these words are ut
tered at the end of the movie's
theme song, "Secret Garden."
I don't think that Tom Cruise
is the best actor in the world
(Sorry all you Tom fans out
there!!), but I admit that I know
ever single spoken word in that
song. Even though it is so
cheesy, that song is sacred to
me. It will forever be in my
memory from my high school
days. Picture this: A group of
high school seniors are driving
around on a Friday or Saturday
night when this song comes on
the radio. They all scream the
words at the top of their lungs
with enough emotion for six

drama departments, like they
were Dorothy Boyd with Jerry
Maguire sitting right next to
them. So, when I hear the new
"remixed" version of Celine
Dion's "The Heart Does Go
On" with the neat little twist
of words added from the
movie, it makes me want to lis
ten to Englebert Humperdink.
"Secret Garden" was an acci
dent, folks. Some DJ thought
that it would be cool if he
added these word into this
song. Surprisingly, it worked.
Once. It does not work with
the Titanic song. First of all,
there is background music from
the movie played over the ac
tual song, _s Secondly, there is
about one catch phrase in all
of Titanic. Sure, the movie is

beautifully written, but all you
really remember walking out of
the movie is, "If you jump, I
jump." Lastly, I don't think that
"ICEBERG, RIGHT
AHEAD!!" is on the same ro
mantic level as "You complete
me." I don't know. Maybe it's
just me. Maybe "Secret Gar
den" just holds some amount of
sentimental value from those

oh-so-long-ago high school
weekends. Maybe deep down
inside, I am really a Tom Cruise
fan. But as much as I love Ti
tanic and know every word
that Celine sings, I refuse to lis
ten to that poor excuse for a
remix. I just wish that people
(especially music executives
with dollar signs in their eyes)
would just leave a beautifully
orchestrated ballad alone.




A Message from
President Haaland

In recent months, there's
been a great deal of public dis
cussion about ethnicity and
quotas as factors in the college
admission process. Since this is
an ongoing issue—not just at
Gettysburg, but at colleges and
universities across the U.S.—I
want to take this opportunity
to articulate Gettysburg
College's stance on this impor
tant topic.
As a private institu
tion, Gettysburg College is not
bound by federal or state legis
lation regarding admissions or
hiring. Racial quotas have been
illegal since the 1978 Bakke
decision, and Gettysburg Col
lege has never used a quota sys
tem in its admissions decisions.
The College's private
status does-not, however, ex
empt usfrom a moral and ethi
cal obligation to reach out to
people of all racial and ethnic
backgrounds, both when we
recruit students and when we

hire faculty, administrators, and
staff. At Gettysburg College, we
believe that increasing the di
versity of our student body and
our faculty will create a more
vibrant learning community,
one which better reflects the
reality of life in America.
While it would be a
disservice to all involved to
admit any student who was in¬

capable of succeeding at Get
tysburg, we are working very
hard to attract students who
bring something special to our
community. The admissions
process allows for consider
ation of many factors, includ
ing academic performance, spe
cial talents, community service,
past family associations with
the College, and so on.
In short, students who
bring different cultural and eth
nic backgrounds with them to
Gettysburg enhance the expe
rience of everyone here at the
College. We all benefit from
efforts to make Gettysburg a
more diverse community.

I hope you all will join
me in further examination of
this issue throughout the se
mester. In particular, I invite
you all to the February 19
Town Meeting, which will fo
cus on "Diversity Matters."
Mari Matsuda, professor of law
at Georgetown University and
a vocal supporter of diversity
in higher education, will be our
guest speaker. After her brief
talk, Professor Matsuda, Abbey
Rogers, and I will lead a ques
tion-and-answer period. The
Town Meeting begins at 11:30
a.m. and will be held in the
CUB Ballroom. I look forward
to seeing you there.


Conflict and Consensus

Scarred and Battered:

A student's assessment of our liberal arts education

by Henry Fawell
Staff Writer In two and a half years
here at Gettysburg College, 1
have been fortunate to learn
from a number of intelligent,
energetic, and insightful profes
sors who have a firm under
standing of the responsibilities
inherent in their profession. I
am in debt to these men and
women for their inspiring
teaching which has encouraged
me to explore my dearest in
terests and beliefs to the best
of my ability and for the even¬

tual betterment of my future.
And through my coming
years I will be equally affected
by a small group of professors
who, in my view, willfully ig
nored the passions of their stu
dents and chose instead to use
their respective courses as ve
hicles to promote their own
prejudicial political and social
viewpoints. These professors
presented to their students
ideas that undermined the tra
ditional classroom foundations
of respect and consideration
and quickly entered the realms
of hate.

On January 14, the first
day of classes, I attended a
course pertaining to western
. literature, mostly American.
After listening to the first five
minutes of the professor's
opening remarks, I was
tempted to leave the classroom.
But I chose, rather, to jot down
so <me of her remarks, which
centered around the literature
of Western civilization.
As most of you surely
know, this literature genre en
compasses the works of Walt
Whitman, Harriet Beecher
Stowe, William Shakespeare
and a number of other works,
including the King James Bible.
Here is a list of my notes:
1. White male authority
is looking to control and domi
nate. 2. The Western Canon
forces upon us what is right and
good in the minds of white
male authority.
3. The Western Canon
pushes people through the
\!' ' _'
\ ;; j )
j'j
_, .

cracks.
4. Is the Western Canon
even necessary?
5. The fact that William
Shakespeare is known as "the
master" in western civilization
is only because it has been po
liticized and institutionalized
by the white male authority.
6. A quote from the pro
fessor, "History people hate
me, but that just means I'm do
ing my job." (My favorite, be
ing a History major).
What left me even more
bewildered was the absence of
Ernest Hemingway, Flannery
O'Conner and other notable
writers of this genre from the
course syllabus.
I later bumped into a peer
from class who, like me,
dropped it as soon as we were
excused. During our conver
sation, I was struck by his com
ment, "I just wanted to read the
things that move me. She won't
let me do that."

For the first time, I sensed
disappointment in a remark
ably easygoing and optimistic
student who, like me, switched
into the section of another pro
fessor whose methods were not
quite so personal. This incident
indicates a problem, not with
the course, but with a specific
section of it.
This semester is not the
first in which I have experi
enced such an instance. Over a
year ago I took a class pertain
ing to the ancient Greeks and
soon discovered the professor

had a far more narrow agenda
than I had anticipated.
To shorten a painfully
complex discussion we had in
class, I remarked that it was
difficult for a civilization to cre
ate a "just" state, but if each
person relied not on others, but
on themselves it would create
a fairly healthy society. The
professor told me, in the pres
ence of over a dozen of my
peers, that I think like a Nazi
and a slave holder. I sincerely
doubt those of you who know
me would subscribe to this no
tion. It is possible that I did not
present my argument clearly

but, nonetheless, the remark
was a shock, and an embarrass
ment, to an 18 year old who
merely wanted to advance his
fledgling knowledge on classi
cal civilization.
Had I dropped the course
at this time, I would not have
heard the professor later praise
the Greek heroine Medea, for
killing her children so that their
father, her former husband,
could no longer see them. I
also would not have been
handed an essay question pro
posing how the Greek epics
The Iliad and The Odyssey had
been written, not by Homer,
but rather by an anonymous

woman.
If the professors in ques
tion are reading this article,
they may be unable to find the
problem at all, since these are
their comments and I imagine
they would stick to them. But
there is a problem that needs
to be addressed, and, fortu
nately, there is a surprisingly
simple solution.
Department chairs
should, before the beginning of
a semester, be well informed of
what curriculum will he used

in a given section and what that
professors' intentions will be.
If the Chair feels the professor
is straying from the structure
of the course, or if the profes
sor refuses to adhere to the de
scription set forth in the Col
lege Catalogue, than a separate
course should be created under
a different title for those stu
dents still interested. This way,
the three sections of a given
course will present the same
general curriculum, thereby
preventing students from being
mislead in the future.
I find the methods prac
ticed by these professors in
complete contradiction to the
liberal arts education, yet I
must support their natural right
to express their ideas. Further
more, I am not concerned with
restricting a professor from his
or her right to teach, but I am
concerned for our right, as stu
- continued on page 13 -
see Battered

Consider this

Overhearing conversa
tions around campus about the
college we attend, it is hard not
to notice the fact that the com
ments made are overwhelm
ingly negative.
Students complain about
everything from tuition and
Gordon Haaland to the food at
Servo. What this college lacks is
school spirit.
Many of us went to high
schools that were overflowing
with school spirit. We got ex
cited about homecoming and
playing our big rivals. We at
tended pep rallies and painted
our faces.
Naturally, there are ex
ceptions to this rule. But there
is nobody out there that does
not know what school spirit is.
Attendance of events on
this campus is pathetic. The
football stadium is practically
empty in the fall, and though
many of our sports teams do
exceedingly well, there is rarely
anybody there to cheer them
on. Sports events are not the
only ones that are neglected.
Theater productions, recitals,
and Common Hours, to name
a few, are incredibly under at
tended.
We attend an outstanding
school. It is not perfect; but
what school is? The problems
that many students find with
Gettysburg would be found at

any similar school. And we too
often forget how lucky we are
to even be attending such an
institution of higher learning.
Maybe nobody notices
those signs that proclaim that
our dining services are among
the best of the nation. Maybe
people spend too much of their
time drunk to notice all the op
portunities available to us.
People complain that
there is nothing to do on this
campus. Check out "This Week
at Gettysburg." The calendar
is full of lectures, social events,
and functions happening
around campus. If a person did
not have to worry about classes
and homework, he or she could
spend all week running from
place to place.
Homecoming weekend
here is geared completely to
wards alumni. Students should
be out at the football game,
rooting on our team and inter
acting with the people that
made Gettysburg what it is.
We should support our
teams, our friends, our peers.
Those people on stage, on the
fields, on the courts are the
same people who we go to
classes with. If you were per
forming, wouldn't you want
someone there to appreciate
you? Gettysburg College is not
perfect, but it is a good place.
We should take the time we're
here to appreciate it.

The Gettysburgian Publication Code
Stories printed in The Gettysburgian are accurate to the knowledge
of our reporters. Editors should be contacted by letter if errors
occur. Signed letters to the Editor will be printed without
name(s) on a request-only basis.


— Conflict and Consensus—
From the Donkey's Mouth

Clinton will come through this

by Matt Brown
Political Columnist
I don't know about the
rest of you, but I am certainly
starting to get sick of all the at
tention that is being paid to the
stories of Monica Lewinsky.
You would think that with a
crisis in the Middle East brew
ing, that the media would pay
a considerable bit more atten
tion to that situation than to all
the rumors being spread about
our nation's president and
some mixed up girl who we are
starting to learn a lot about.
I wonder if Republicans
would still cry that the media
is liberal after all that has been

said about the president. I can
see our friends on the fringe of
right wing politics foaming at
the mouth, hoping that these
allegations of an affair and sub
orning perjury bring down the
president. The opponents of
the president think they can
dupe the American people into
looking at these allegations
more critically then the
president's many successes.
But that is not going to happen.
The American people are
upset that some of the allega
tions could be true, but they
also see how well our country
is doing. The American people
realize that this is not the first

time that a president has been
accused of or actually had an
affair. In fact, our nation's first
president, the great George
Washington, whom we remem
ber fondly this month, has been
accused of having an affair.
Throughout history, our
president's have had or have
rumored to have had affairs,
Franklin Roosevelt,
Eisenhower, Kennedy, LBJ,
Bush all fall into this category.
I know we all like to think that
our president's are perfect
models in every way, but they
are flawed just like us. Despite
these rumors however, our na
tion has continued to have
strong leaders. Bill Clinton is
one such strong leader, the
American people overwhelm¬

ingly approve of the way that
President Bill Clinton is doing
his job. We have the lowest
unemployment rate in 24 years.
America is experiencing the
highest level of home owner
ship ever. Crime rates are fall
ing. Incomes are rising.
America's commitment to im
proving education is growing.
Thanks to President Clinton,
we finally have'a balanced bud
get. No matter what the right
says about his morals, that can
not take away his successes. In
fact after all he's done, I won
der what kind of buildings they
will be naming after him when
his 87th birthday comes
around.
We just have to accept
that we do not yet know what
has happened between the
president and Monica

Lewinsky. It is quite premature
to make blanket attacks against
the president. The fact is that
every time this pawn of the
right, Ken Starr, has tried to get
the president on something he
has failed. I think it only right
and proper that the Justice
Department to begin to inves
tigate this man. So many things
have leaked out of his office,
he has spent so much of
America's tax dollars and all he
has to show for it is the con
victions of a small number of
Clinton associates. I think we
should question if this lawyer

is not out for justice, but ven
geance against the president.
We need to know if Ken Starr
is wasting our money. After all,
we are looking to cut govern
ment spending and I think it
would be better to cut the
spending of a fruitless crusade
then any other worthwhile pro
gram. Who knows how much
more could have been done
with the money that Ken Starr
has wasted on chasing after the
president. Regardless of what
I think, it is high time to see
whether or not Ken Starr is car
rying out his investigation in a
judicious way.
Who is this Monica
Lewinsky anyway? As the story

unfolds we see that she was
surrounded by a sketchy
crowd. Linda Tripp_, the friend
that records her conversations,
a woman bent on bringing
down President Clinton, writ
ing a book to make profit from
her supposed knowledge.
Tripp's publisher, a woman
who believes she will person
ally will be a hero for bringing
down the president. Lewinsky,
herself, has been involved in
numerous affairs. Lewinsky
was supposedly obsessed with

the president. The facts point
to a record of lying and ques
tionable behavior on the part
of Miss Monica Lewinsky. Can
we trust these women?
I am afraid that we may
never know or may never truly
be able to believe what has hap
pened. So many people have
blackened President Clinton's
good name that we may not be
able to sort out the truth of
what happened for quite some
time. It might be pertinent to
remember that the central fig¬

ure of right wing ideology,
Ronald Reagan whom Repub
licans are so eager to name
things after, faced a crisis in his
presidency with the Iran-Con
tra scandal. 'Like Reagan, I be
lieve that President Clinton will
weather the storm (and who
knows perhaps one day there
will be a nonsense rush to name
things after him too). Not only
will Clinton weather the storm,
but I believe he will successfully
continue to tackle the chal
lenges facing America.



Missing morals

by Cammie Grant
Political Columnist

been placed on Colorado Re
publicans by Colorado Demo
crats. All accusations have been
denied by the Republican Party
Why do the Democrats point
their finger to the Republican
Party when private, potentially
harmful information is un
earthed?
Not only in Clinton's al
leged affair, but now the Re
publicans are to blame for
Romer's relationship. It is time
for the Democratic Party to pay
the price, which may be their
reputation, and admit their
wrong doings.

Chairman of the Demo
cratic National Committee and
Colorado Governor, Roy
Romer admitted last week to a
16 year relationship with B.J.
Thornberry. Thornberry
worked on many of Romer's
Colorado gubernatorial cam
paigns and was his assistant at
the Democratic National Com
mittee in Washington D.C.
Governor Romer has been ac
cused of having an affair with
Thornberry for many years and
has repeatedly denied it.
Insight Magazine re¬

leased a cover story early
Thursday morning on the
Internet summarizing the de
tails of Romer's relationship
with Thornberry. The maga
zine stated, "Insight has ob
tained confidential records-in
cluding photographs and video
tapes-purportedly showing that
Romer may have had more
than a platonic relationship." A
Denver private investigator was
hired to track Romer in 1995
and uncover details about his
private life, according to In
sight Magazine. Blame has

Governor Romer told the
Denver Post, "We worked this
out among ourselves. We knew
it would not fit the public per
ception." Roy, of course it does
not fit the public perception;
screwing around on your wife
with another woman is not
morally correct and the public
should shun Roy Romer. When
asked about his denials con
cerning his relationship with
Thronberry he said, "I was
carefully answering about hav
ing a sexual affair. I am not a
very sexual person." Romer's
wife, Bea prepared a public
statement, "B.J. Thornberry is

a close friend of Roy's. He has
been open with me and shared
the facts about the relationship
with me from the beginning. It
has not affected our marriage
or our family. I ask people to
respect our private lives." Mrs.
Romer's statement is tasteful
and brief. She, ' however, will
not openly admit the pain her
husband's relationship has
caused. Even if Governor
Romer is not sleeping with
Thornberry, having an extra
marital relationship is unac
ceptable.
What I find most disturb
ing is the fact the Colorado
Governor and Democratic Na
tional Committee Chairman
has lied repeatedly when ac
cused of a relationship with
Thornberry. How can the
people of Colorado and mem
bers of the Democratic Na
tional Committee trust this
man, not only with the future
of Colorado but, the future of
the Democratic Party?

Maybe extramarital af
fairs are a way of life for high
ranking Democrats. My advice
to Bill and Roy, get some mor
als and values, if not for your
selves, but for the individuals
for whom you are representing.

The Pachyderm's Pulpit

Senate works and works

Battered

by John Dunlap
Political Columnist
Within the next month
another session of Gettysburg
College's Student Senate will
come to an end, as new elec
tions are held. Having served
on Senate since the beginning
of my freshman year I have
come to the conclusion that
Senate can and most of the time
does work. This year has been
a good year for Student Senate.
Under the leadership of Senate
President Abby Rogers and Vice
President Val Katzmar, the Sen¬

ate has moved at more swift
and decisive pace in enacting
change and getting things done.
Today Senate, is at the fore
front of pushing for so
cial change on _^^^^m

t r a -
tion has an important an
nouncement to make or policy
to implement they often come
before Student Senate. Take
for instance, President Gordon
Haaland's announcement just a
few weeks ago that the student
body will have fifty thousand
dollars to spend on all-campus
social events. It was Senate that
started the campus discussion
on the new sexual consent
policy. Dean Julie Ramsey
came to Student Senate to first
discuss the changes.
As a member of Senate
representing the Class of 2000,

I feel as if I have an obligation
to represent the opinion of my
entire class, as well as the Col
lege as a whole. Student Sen
ate is the vehicle for communi
cation between the administra
tion, the faculty, and between
each class as well. The money
we appropriate in Senate is
your money, the money you
pay to go to Gettysburg Col
lege. This is why I was proud
when, after a great debate, Sen
ate decided to fully fund the
Civil War Club. This is Get
tysburg after all, the site of the
greatest battle of the Civil
War.

Senate
this year has
had

_^^^^^^_H many
interest
ing de
bates and
discussions on some of the
prominent issues facing our
campus and how we spend the
money we are given.
There is nothing wrong
with debate; we are a legisla
tive body and as representatives
of the entire campus's views
than debate is only inevitable.
Discussion and debate in Sen
ate is not limited to Senators
and club representatives, but is
open to everyone. More of the
campus should get involved
and come to Senate. This is our
College, and if we feel it is

moving in the wrong direction,
or are dissatisfied with a cer
tain policy than Senate is where
our grievance can be heard.
Change can occur, and I
have seen it. Last year, because
I felt that Senate was at times
overly long and very drawn
out, I along with my colleague
Ted Hartman drafted a contract
with Gettysburg. Its purpose
was to reform the Senate pro
cess. Working with all of Sen
ate and Senate's Executive
Board it was com
posed.

W Wnn
I felt
that
members

^^^^^^ of the stu
^^^_r dent body were
wronged by the
denial of tenure of
Dr. Edward DeClair
of the Political Science
Department, I took my
concern to Student Senate.
What I found out was that I
was not alone, as students in
and outside of the Political Sci
ence Department rallied to Dr.
DeClair's side. While the ad
ministration failed to reverse
their decision concerning Dr.
DeClair we were able to see
how the tenure process worked
and hopefully, we the student
body will get to play a larger
role in the future, when it
comes to deciding who will be
teaching us.

Senate has had a lot of
success. Before I arrived on
campus it was Senate that was
able to keep _iVlusselman Li
brary open 24 hours a day. It
is Senate that funds the
College's clubs and organiza
tions. Much more is left to be
done. Before Senate moves
forward more internal changes
are necessary.

The Residence Hall Sena
tors idea should be done away
with. Today the Vice President
of each hall gets to serve on
Senate. Many times people
elected from these dorms do
not know that they have to go
to Senate and in some dorms
people switch around who will
represent them at Senate. Vice
Presidents of dorms should
have the same position as club
representatives. Currently, it
does not seem that they feel
fully part of Senate and in their
place the number of Senators
per class should be increased to
at least seven, perhaps even
eight. Beyond the change
within Senate itself, the social
life of the campus is dramati¬

cally changing. With B.Y.O.B
and the weakening of Greek
organizations on campus as a
social outlet for students, more
must be done to make Gettys
burg an enjoyable place to live
and work. This is an issue that
Senate and the Student Activi
ties Council are currently
working on. The fifty-thou
sand dollars that has been ap
propriated for social programs
is a good idea. As chairman of
the sub-committee on how the
money shall be spent, Val
Katzmar explained last week at
Senate, this is only to hold us
over. We need a long-term fix
to aid the social environment
of this College and- the next
Senate will be crucial in decid
ing what that fix will be.

Senate should be doing
more to help strengthen the
Greek organizations on cam
pus. Gettysburg College owes
fraternities and sororities a lot.
For years they were the social
outlets for the student body
and now with new rules and
regulations, their roles are
changing. They need help in
making that change. First of
all, we all need to chip in and
help Alpha XI Delta; if its
chapter were to come to an end
that would be a real tragedy.
Lastly, the Senate's new
leadership and members should

remember that while we must
work with administration to
enact change, it's also our re
sponsibility to stand up to the
administration when we think
they are wrong. We can never
forget that this is our campus
and for at least four years of
our life this is home, and we
have responsibility to make it
better.

- continued from page 11-

dents, to study the concepts
that motivate us to open our
minds to education.
Beyond all the social
events and activities that reso
nate through our campus, each
student, at least once, takes a
course not as a requirement,
but because it speaks to the
principles that govern him or
her as an individual. We should
be deeply concerned for the
safety of these issues, which
spark each one of us, though
we may not admit it, to con
tinue reading a book beyond its'
given assignment. If these pre
cious ideas are twisted and dis
torted by even a few willing
professors, then the founda
tions of a liberal arts education
will inevitability crumble with
them.

There is simply no room
on this campus for prejudice
against a culture, gender or
race, nor should statements ba
ed on strident ideologies or po
itics be tolerated by anyone.
Instead, students and profes
sors alike should work to em
brace the virtues of fairness and
impartiality, while living up to
both professional and moral
standards. When we accom
plish this, our classrooms will
flourish with a fundamental
basis of respect for all the cul
tures and ideas that humanity,
in it's great complexity, has to
offer us.

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from

12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more information,
contact any of the following
persons: Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext. 8159; T.J.

HEALTH SERVICES
Hours for Health Services are
Monday through Friday from 8:30
am to 6:00 pm. Please call ext.
6970 or stop by to make an ap
pointment.
The Health Hotline, provides
non-emergency medical advice on
Saturdays from 10 am to 2 pm.
You can page a nurse practitioner
at 338-5283, enter the phone
number where you can be reached,
and the nurse practitioner will call
you back. You will be advised on
self care, emergency room care,
physician consultation or health

service follow-up. OF COURSE,
IN AN EMERGENCY CALL
6911 OR 911 IMMEDIATELY!!
F. Kinsella
Needle Disposal - Anyone who
has the need of self- administering
_medication by needle injection, we
ask that you collect your used
syringes and needles in a sharps
container. You may bring the full
container to the Health Service for
disposal. Ifyoudonothavea
puncture proof sharps container,
you may pick one up at Health
Services at no charge. Let's keep
our community safe. F. Kinsella

scoring six points each dur
ing the opening run. Geor
gian Court was unable to get

first year guard Chris "Meat"
Collins may undergo treatment
for an apparent snoring prob
lem. Sources also report that
many Bullets complain of
Collin's problem on long bus
rides. Officially the Bullets had
no comment on the situation.

The Teacher and the Pupil

Nathan Grim is the savvy veteran who has taken home numerous titles. Cathy Spangler is the
youngster looking to dominate the Centennial Conference for years to come.

By Chesha Miller
Player Profiler
Gettysburg College is
lucky to have two of the Cen
tennial Conference's most tal
ented throwers in their midst
senior Nathan Grim and
sophomore Cathy Spangler.
Ironically, both track and field
athletes are relatively hew to
their successes.
Nathan Grim began his
athletic career playing soccer
when he was 8 years old.
Throughout high school he
continued to play soccer and
began playing basketball as
well. In order to keep in shape
for soccer and basketball,
Nathan _decided to join the
track team in the spring. He
threw the javelin and the shot
put and also ran the quarter
mile.

A true athlete at heart _.
Grim knew his athletic career
would have to continue after
higljschool. Following a failed
attempt to join the soccer team
his first year, Nathan spoke
with his Wellness instructor and
track and field throws coach,
John Schmid. Coach Schmid
encouraged Nathan, who is
fondly known as Nate, to speak
with head coach Bob Condon
and to join the track team.
Nathan laughs, "I went to see
Coach Condon and he sent me
right to the weight room." The
265 pound Grim weighed only
200 pounds at the time, cer
tainly not enough to be a com
petitive thrower.
"I was a scrub as a fresh¬

man and was always getting
kicked around by everyone in
the conference," said Grim.
That soon changed. Grim is
very well versed in his throws.
Indoors he throws the shot put
and 35 lb. weight, outdoors, in
addition to the shot put, Grim
throws the discus and the ham
mer. "I really enjoy the synergy
between all the events and the
technique work in each helps
me in the other," commented
Grim. Nathan won his first col
legiate medal as a sophomore
during the indoor season, plac-

ing third in the shot put at the
Centennial Conference Cham
pionships. He repeated his
third place finish in the out
door season and then again in
the indoor season of his junior
year. Last spring Nathan broke
the Centennial Conference
record in both the shot put and
the discus. In addition he was
the Centennial Conference
Champion of both events.
Nathan also holds both
Gettysburg's indoor and out
door records in the shot put

as well as the hammer record.
A few weekends ago
Nathan qualified provisionally
for the National Champion
ships in the shot put with a
throw of 50' 2". This past
weekend he improved his
throw to 52'1", practically guar
anteeing him a spot at Nation
als- he is presently seeded fifth.
Nathan and his coaches are
hoping he will defend his Con
ference title and qualify for
Nationals in the spring as well.
According to Coach
Schmid, Nathan has great tech
nique. "Nate is a technician,"

photo by Emily _Glatfeller
said Schmid,,"He is practically
the assistant throws coach and
he has madehimself into every
thing he is today." In high
school Nathan struggled with
the shot put and didn't even
enjoy doing it, but since com
ing to college it has become a
huge focus in his life. "I've
learned if you do something
you truly enjoy and are able to
devote yourself to it willingly,
you will be rewarded," ex
plained Nathan, "In high school
I did stuff for my coaches, in

college, I did it for myself- be
cause I love it."
Nathan has had many
good people to push him to
where he is today. His parents,
Bruce and Kathleen, have been
excellent role models and have
constantly given Nathan en
couragement. When he was
growing up, Nathan's father
was very involved in his athlet
ics as a coach of his soccer
team. But more importantly to
Grim, his father has always
been a friend to him. Grim
greatly admires his mother,
who just recently went back to

school for her bachelors and
masters degrees. At Gettys
burg, Nathan is supported by
his fellow throwers who are his
best friends. He commented,
"I'm out there every day hav
ing a great time with my best
friends and no matter how bad
a mood I am in when I get to
practice, I always leave smil
ing." Cathy Spangler is another
thrower who is always smiling.
Like Nathan she has had won
derful people ' supporting her
along the way. Her mom,
Patricia, is a very special per
son who is very loving and sup
portive of both Cathy and her
brother. Talking about her
mother, Cathy commented,
"When you grow up with some
one like that, you know you'll
be okay."

The sophomore thrower
began her track and field career
as a junior in high school. "One
-

of the track coaches asked me
if I'd ever thrown before. I
hadn't, but I'd always wanted
to do something," Cathy ex
plained, "I tried it and I liked
it." Not only did Cathy like it,
but she was good at throwing
too. Cathy, who competes in
the shot put, 20 pound weight,
hammer and discus, is most
taken with the discus. "I love
throwing the discus because I
feel so graceful when I throw
it," she explained. "[The dis
cus] just flies and it makes me
feel good."
In high school, she held
the shot put relay record which
was over 110 feet. Since com
ing to Gettysburg, Cathy has
continued in her successes and
grown through them. In the
indoor season of her first year,
Spangler broke the school
record in the 20 pound weight
throw with a distance of 33'4"
Last spring Spangler won the

Rush brings
changes to

Hail to the chief

sororities

Eighty-eight women go through formal rush

Anthony DeFail of Alpha Chi Rho celebrates his
victory as Mr. Fraternity last Friday.

by Laura Root
Staff Reporter
The Greek System at
Gettysburg College has been un
dergoing a period of change. Dur
ing this year's Formal Rush, all of
the sororities witnessed some new

occurances.
Eighty-eight women went
through Formal Rush this year. All
88 were accepted as pledges to the
four sororities participating in
Rush. (Alpha Xi Delta followed a
different strategy to attract mem
bers this year.) This number was
considerably lower than in previ
ous years, especially considering
the large size of the First Year class.
According to Meaghan
Halpin, the vice president of this
year's rush, this has not occurred
at Gettysburg College in recent
times. Halpin gives credit for this
victory to the Rho Chis, or Rush
Counselors, who encouraged the
women not to "suicide" a sorority
by having a certain sorority be their
only choice. Most women had a
few first choices.

The 88 pledges were distrib
uted fairly evenly between the four
sororities. Alpha Delta Pi has 19
pledges, Chi Omega has 20, Delta
Gamma has 22, and Gamma Phi
Beta has 23.
The withdrawl of Alpha Xi
Delta from Formal Rush had an
effect the amount of women that
each sorority could accept.

Happy 21st Birthday Mark Astrom

Alpha Xi Delta has presently
accepted five new members with
theur new rush policy.
On the last day of Rush, there
is a certain number of members that
each sorority is allowed to take in,
called quota.
Quota is the number of Final
Rushees divided by the number of
sororities. Dividing the number by
four instead of five increased the
number of pledges in each sorority.
This year, the quota was 23
women per each of the four sorori
ties involved in formal rush. Last
year, the quota was larger. A 24
woman quota was given to five so
rorities.
Neither Halpin nor Pan-Hel
President Rebecca O'Connell has an
explanation for the drop in the
number of rushees.
This year was also the first in
history that no Rush Violations were
recorded.

A Rush Violation involves
breaking the Code of Silence be
tween sorority members and rush
ees imposed during the weeks of
Formal Rush. A violator is usually
expelled from Rush.
"I'm especially happy with
this new development," says Claire
Christman, president of Chi Omega.
For the most part, Formal
Rush has pleased everyone. Both
Halpin and O'Connell are excited
about the changes that occurred this
year. "Overall, it went really well,"
sums up O'Connell.

Gettysburg College on Channel Five

by Kabir Kumai
Staff Reporter The Gettysburg College
_Television Station (GCTV)
broadcasted for the first time
in many years, this Saturday,
Valentine's Day from 7 to 9 pm
on Channel Five.
The broadcast included a
basketball game between Johns
Hopkins and Gettysburg Col
lege, Video Valentines, and a
short film by a first year stu
dent titled "297."
"1 would like to have
more student films," said Matt
Bange, Station Director. "I
would like students to get cre
ative," Bange has been

invovled from the start with the
revival of the television station
since the birth of the idea last
October.
"There were revival com
mittee meetings most of last
semester," he said. "We wanted
to organize it in a way we
thought it would make it," he
added.
"We had all the equip
ment we needed to start up,"
said Mike Wooden, Student
Advisor to the station. Wooden
was involved in an earlier at
tempt to revive the station
which failed. "It failed then
because it did not have enough
backing," he said.
" We have a number of

people dedicated to the sta
tion," said Wooden "But we
need to get people involved -
not just the people in the sta
tion." The Station members had
been collecting Video Valen
tines in the main lobby of the
College Union Building last
week. "We didn't get as many
valentines," said Wooden.
"They were under six min
utes," said Bange.
The Station decided to go
ahead with the broadcast on
Valentine's Day. Due to the
lack of programming material
the same program has been
scheduled to be shown from 7
p.m. to 9 p.m. this week.
"It had to have a start,"
said Wooden. "Now that we
are on the air it will attract
more people," said Bange.

The time slot of 7 to 9 pm
coincides with television pro
grams on popular stations. "We
are right now competing with
primetime TV - that is a given,"
said Bange.
Bange hopes that the
channel and station will be no
ticed if viewed more often. "I
think it will take a while," he
added.
The Station plans to build
up its programming by sched
uling with academic depart

Zalewski runs for Senate President

Treasurer feels "very qualified" for position

by Ann Marie Bieli
Staff Reporter Sara Zalewski is a junior
at Gettysburg College and is
double majoring in philosophy
and political science. She is the
treasurer of Student Senate this
year, and is currently running
for the position of president for
next year. Sara believes that
her many activities, her well
roundedness, and her experi
ence in Student Senate over the
last three years make her the
best candidate for the job.
Zalewski has been ex
tremely involved during her
four years here at Gettysburg
College. She has been the
president of the Class of 1999
for the last three years. She
stated, "We have a really suc
cessful, great class govern-

She has been a member of
Gender Benders for two years,
an appointed member of the
student conduct review board
for two years, and a tour guide
for three years.
Zalewski has been also
been indirectly involved with
Gettysburg Students Against
Racism (GSAR). Sara has sat
in on the Commission for
Women, worked in the politi
cal science department, is a
member of the women's rugby
team and is currently the sec
retary of the newly established
pre law society.
Zalewski believes the nu¬

merous activities she has beer
involved with have made her i
very well rounded person anc
have enabled her to make some
important contacts. Most im
portant to this election how
ever, are the positions she has
held in Student Senate and as
an important member of sen
ate committees.
Zalewski has sat in on
many executive senate meet
ings. Sara believes this is per
haps the number one reason
she is more qualified for the
position of president of student
senate than her opponents,
John Dunlap and Earl Redding.
Zalewski stated, "the
other candidates have never sat
in on executive meetings, they
don't know how to run the
meetings or execute the rules,
things which are necessary
when being president."

Zalewski has many con
cerns and goals for the upcom
ing year and Student Senate,
She wants to create initiatives
for campus traditions, old and
new. She also wants to concen
trate on Gettysburg's school
spirit. She stated that she feels
the campus community is be
ginning to lose its school spirit.
She also stated that she plans
to strengthen the ties between
faculty, students, and adminis
tration. Another important
goal for Zalewski is to bring the
Gettysburg campus closer to
the Gettysburg community.
Creating new goals for

senate is not Zalewski's only
objective, she is also con
cerned with continuing and
improving upon current ac
complishments of student sen
ate. She hopes to continue to
worktowards adequate repre
sentation of the student body
in student senate. She also
want to continue the social
programming and the answer
ing and confronting of stu
dents' concerns and issues.
She stated, " I feel very
qualified for the position of
president of Student Senate. I
have always had the best in
tentions to improve campus
and continue the positive
things." .

In the beginning of the
current semester, Zalewski
dropped many of her activi
ties to ensure she could take a
full responsibility if elected
president of Student Senate.
Sara is now solely involved in
Student Senate and class gov
ernment.
Zalewski reiterated sev
eral times that she is not run
ning for this position as a "re
sume builder." She said, "I
have a genuine concern for the
student body and I am not do
ing it just for the name."
Student senate elections
will be held February 23, 24,
and 25 in the College Union
Building.

Donnella to be

The Revered Joseph A.
Donnella, II, will be installed as
the 13th senior chaplain oi
gettysburg College at a public
service to be held at 4 p.m. Sun

on the College's campus.
Pastor Donella, who
pined the College this fall after
serving as Lutheran chaplain at
Howard University, is the first
African American to serve as a
chaplain at Gettysburg. Founded
in 1832, Gettysburg is the old
est college in the country affili
ated with the Evangelical
Lutheran church in america

(ELCA).
The Service of Word anc
Sacrament will be attended b)
many clergy of various faiths
Officiating the Rite of Installa

Edmiston, Jr., of the ELC_^

the Bishop of the Southwesi
Ohio Synod of the ElcA, will
preside at the Liturgy of the
Word. Preaching will be the Rev
Dr. Bernard E. Richardson, dean
of the Howard University
Chapel.
Pastor Donnella was re
cently named to the ELCA Pre
siding Bishop's worship Initiative
team, which was established to
examine, during the next six
years, ways of deepening wor
ship in the lives of congregations
and of the Church at large, par¬

ticularly concerning the histor)
and various styles of worship
which have or still exist withir
the Lutheran Church.
He has also served on tht
ELCa Sacramental Practices Task
Force, the ELCA African Ameri
can Strategy Team, and on the
liturgy committee of the inter
church African American
Lutheran Hymnal Committee.
Donnella earned his un
dergraduate degree from
Duquesne University, and his
master's degree from the
Lutheran School of Theology at
Chicago.
Before arriving at Howard
University in 1987, Donnella
served his clinical pastoral edu
cation at the University of Chi
cago Medical Center, as an as
sociate pastor at St. John's
Lutheran Church, in Marywood_,

_af churches in Cary, Ind., Chi

gelical Lutheran Church of Our

attend the installation, the pre

lowing the service.

Features
Liberating our bodies

by Cara Masucci
Staff Reporter The message is inescap
able: the thinner you are, the
better. The constant bombard
ment with magazine and tele
vision commercials trying to
sell weight loss products has led
many Americans to hold up an
ideal that has never really ex
isted. This in turn leads many
to eating disorders in attempt
to capture what is in vogue. A
great number of people realize
this, but really do not do any
thing about it. In a campus
wide effort to increase aware
ness and further movement to
expel eating disorders from the
Gettysburg College campus,
next week has been deemed
Eating Disorder Awareness
Week.

There are three main
types of eating disorders: an
orexia nervosa, bulimia
nervosa, and compulsive over
eating.
The first, anorexia
nervosa, is a disorder where a
person eats too little in order
to stay thin. This often leads
to the point of emaciation.
Many people suffering from
the disorder have an intense
fear of gaining weight and eat
ing foods with any fat. The
disorder can also lead to over
exercise in order to shed
pounds. Many times those
with the disorder still see them
selves as overweight, even
though everyone else around
them could be telling them they
are too thin.

Unfortunately, being too
thin is not the only problem
anorexics face. Many times de
hydration and kidney problems
can occur. Hair and nail loss
can take place, as well as severe
cardiac problems. Other
symptoms associated with the
disorder are dry skin, insomnia,
stress fractures, constipation,
and, in women, amenorrhea
(loss of menstruation). It is es
timated that between five and
eighteen percent of those suf
fering from anorexia will die.

Bulimia nervosa sufferers
are characterized by severe
binging and purging in order
to keep weight off. Purging
may come by way of vomiting
or through the use of laxatives.
Use of diuretics and excessive
exercise may also be employed.
The behavior may be done
sporadically over the course of
a month or many times a day.
Bulimics often times have pe
t ir" _^j——mmimxm _.g._Mifl_^iB'' *-

riods of rapid weight loss and
gain. Like anorexia, there are
many medical problems asso
ciated with bulimia nervosa.
Digestive disorders, constipa
tion, severe dental problems
and loss of teeth, skin rashes,
hair loss, amenorrhea, and os
teoporosis may occur. Vomit
ing can cause bleeding of the
esophagus, seizures, and severe
cardiac problems as well. In
many cases, bulimia can also
cause death.
The third disorder, com
pulsive overeating, is some
times pushed into the shadow
of the other two disorders.
Compulsive overeaters go on
periods of binging and may
become obese.
People suffering from

this disorder oftentimes suffer
from shortness of breath, high
blood pressure, and joint prob
lems. The problem can become
life threatening in that it can
cause heart disease, heart at
tacks, diabetes, and contribute
to certain forms of cancer.
With all the ill effects of
eating disorders, it becomes
very confusing why many,
sometimes as much as one-fifth

of the population turns to these
options. Eating disorders do
not exclude males, but the ma
jority with the disorders are fe
male. In fact, the victims do not
include only ordinary women.
Famous figures such as Karen
Carpenter (who died from the
medical complications of an
eating disorder) and the late
Princess Diana was suffering
from eating disorders. It is a
problem that affects everyone.
No one is immune.
There are many cultural
and psychological factors that
play a role in causing the disor
der. First, it is no secret that
American culture encourages
people to base self-worth and
esteem on body weight. Ac
cording to Frances Parker of the
counseling center, the fashion

industry is playing a large part
in the problem. The women
in magazines are taped up and
electronically distorted, so
when one is trying to measure
up to that idea!, they are not
able to. The models themselves
are not even able to. For most
women, the genetic makeup is
such that the boylike figure
deemed attractive is not acces
sible.

Photo by Emily Glatfeller
Parker is quick to point
out, though, that it is beautiful
to have that body type in the
same way it should be seen as
beautiful to have a whole
myriad of body types. Parker
states, "All of us have to be ac
cepting of diversity in every
way. People cannot be the same
size in the same way they can
not be the same race or reli
gion." The purpose of next
week is to further the accep
tance of diversity in body types.
Debbie Fielder, Chair of the
President's Commission on
Women: Eating Disorder Task
Force, states that the group
wants to go beyond awareness
and develop serious and coor
dinated efforts on the campus
to expel the problem. Part of

the focus of next week's events,
according to Fielder, will be to
make known to all students at
Gettysburg what services are
available to them if they or
someone they know has an eat
ing disorder. Support at the
college includes individual
therapy, nutrition consultation,
medical testing to check for ill
effects of the disorders, and
numerous other services and
referrals. Fielder also said there
will be a nutritionist coming to
speak to the College next week
to demonstrate "what is normal
and what is a disorder." Fielder
agrees with Parker in some of
the causes for the disorders.
"The body myths are learned
and culturally situated," she
stated.

Both women are quick to
point out, though, that al
though society can be viewed
as having the most profound
affect on the presence of eat
ing disorders, it is not a cut and
dry problem. An eating disor
der can sometimes stem out of
emotional conflict. It can be
come a learned coping skill
used to rechannel anger, sad
ness, anxiety, and even joy. The
destructive behavior can also be
learned from people in the
person's environment who
abuse themselves through other
destructive behaviors such as
alcohol and drug abuse. That
is why it is important for a per
son suffering from an eating
disorder to get therapy to find
a way out of the web of destruc
tion.

According to junior Julie
Wilmer, the campus wide push
to eliminate eating disorders
will be fueled by the commis
sion. "What we are trying to do
is slam the campus with infor
mation," she says. Packets will
be distributed to athletes, resi
dent advisors, and members of
the Greek system. The idea be
hind being so inclusive with
those receiving the packets is
to get everyone involved.
The Women's Center will

see Eating disorders

Do you know what you're sleeping with?

by Leah Bagley and Amanda
Swank Contributing Reporters
One in four people have
a sexually transmitted disease
(STD), which means that as you
look around, at least one per
son near you is infected. The
scariest part of these statistics
is that many people are asymp
tomatic, which means they are
not aware that they have an
STD, and therefore that they
can spread the disease unknow
ingly. STDs can be treated, but
few can be cured.
Human Papillomavirus
(HPV) is one of the most com
mon STDs; approximately 40
million Americans are infected
with it. Sexually active women
under the age of twenty-five are
the most susceptible to contract
this disease. HPV is rarelv dis¬

cussed and therefore the con
sequences are more dangerous.
The symptoms may not show
for months or even years, but
this disease can lead to cervical
cancer and infertility. Symp
toms appear as warts in the
genital area, or internal lesions.
HPV cannot be cured, only
"cleared" from the body with
treatment.
Chlamydia infects three
to four million Americans, in
cluding ten percent of all col
lege students. Eighty percent
of those who have contracted
chlamydia show no symptoms.
Symptoms can include whitish
discharge for males, and itch
ing, burning, and discomfort in
the genital area for women.
Women who are infected have
a high risk of developing pel
vic inflammatory disease,
which ran lead to infertility.

Treatments for chlamydia in
clude antibiotics and erythro
mycin.
Syphilis is categorized
into three levels of seventy de
pending on the symptoms. The
primary stage includes painless
chancre on the external geni
tals. The secondary stage
symptoms are skin lesions and
achiness. The tertiary stage
includes lesions and problems
within the nervous system. The
only treatment for syphilis is
penicillin and the disease may
remain contagious for life.
Each year, more than
600,000 cases of gonorrhea are
reported. Symptoms for men
include milky white discharge
and a burning sensation when
urinating. Females experience
abnormal vaginal discharge and
inflammation of the vagina, but
80 percent of women do not

show any symptoms. Gonor
rhea can also lead to pelvic in
flammatory disease and, when
passed from mother to fetus,
may cause blindness to an in
fant. Penicillin is the only treat
ment. Genital herpes affects
half a million people each year,
and there is no cure, only sup
pression treatments. Symp
toms are lesions, warts, and
blisters which can be either in
the genital area or in the
mouth. If left untreated, a fe
vefmay result which may cause
meningitis and extremely pain
ful sores. Washing with soap
and water twice daily is a
simple at-home treatment;
painting lesions with podophyl
lin must be done under a
physician's care.

AIDS is the most well
known STD because of the epi

demic proportions that it has
reached. Young women who
are sexually active are the most
high risk group for contracting
\IDS. As we all know, there is
no cure for the virus, but there
are treatments to prolong the
life of the infected person.
The most preventative
measure for avoiding the con
traction of an STD is absti
nence, but if you are sexually
active, wearing a condom will
greatly decrease your chances
of becoming infected. Some
STDs are transferred by just
rubbing or touching the in
fected areas. Being aware that
all of us need to take precau
tions against all STDs, not only
AIDS, is our best defense
against the spread of these dis
eases. All STDs have the po
tential to change the direction
of vour life forever.


Curtain Call
The Gospel according to the South

by Glen Beck
Theater Columnist
Cotton Patch Gospel, the
toe-tapping musical by folk
singer Harry Chapin, opens at
Kline Theater on Thursday,
February 26. Produced by the
College's theater arts depart
ment, the musical features the
Owl and Nightingale Players.
Based on the book The
Cotton Patch Version of Mat
thew and John by Clarence Jor
dan, Cotton Patch Gospel is set
in the South and tells the story
of the life of Jesus in very

American terms. Bethlehem
becomes Gainesville, Georgia,
while Jerusalem is represented
by Atlanta. Although the story
adheres closely to the Gospels,
the interpretation, the charac
ters, and the music are very
American.
The music is primarily
bluegrass. The songs range
from the rousing opening
"Somethin' Brewin' in
Gainesville" to Herod's aggres
sive declaration "I Did It." The
neighbors sing that "It Ain't
Easy Growing Up to be Jesus,"
but later state that he is indeed

a "Dangerous Man." Mary and
Joseph offer the plaintive and
beautiful "You are Still My
Boy," while the entire company
joins in for the high-spirited
"Goin' to Atlanta." The play is
brimming with good humor,
and the music is sure to set the

audiences toes a-tapping.
The director of Cotton
Patch Gospel is Professor Emile
O. Schmidt, and the designer
of the production is Professor
Jerome O. Hanson, both mem
bers of the College's theater
arts department. Visiting pro
fessional artists engaged for the
production include musical di
rector Don Bollinger, choreog
rapher Paula Kellinger, and
New York designer Stephen
Quandt.
Seventeen members of
O&N perform more than sixty
roles. First year student Reco
Grisby is featured as Jesus,

Duncan Niederer as Matthew,
Jennifer MacMurtrie and Glen
Beck as Mary and Joseph, Tim
Johnsen and Paul Lapato as the
brothers Rock and Andy, Brad
Cerilli as John the Baptist, Phil
Anderson as Pilate, Alec
Beekmans as Jud, Megan
Manthey as Dr. Caiaphas, Jen
nifer Baumgartner and Hannah
Roth as Satans, Allison
Kennedy and Michael Harp as
TV evangelists Timmy and
Tanya, Justin Arnold as the
Heavenly Messenger,
Samantha Gregg as the Angel,
and Mary Cordero as the Rev
erend Troy.

In addition, each actor
plays several other roles.
The production staff in
cludes Ashley Brown and
Lauren Wells, stage managers;
Jody Robertson, master electri¬

cian; Allison Perry, costumes;
Christa Zuber, properties; Glen
Beck, publicity; and Corinna
Krauskopf and Brian
Hershfeld, shop supervisors.
Cotton Patch Gospel will

open on Thursday, February 26
at 8 p.m. Other performances
will follow on Friday, Feb. 27
at 8 p.m.; Saturday, Feb. 28 at
2 p.m. and 8 p.m.; Monday
March 2 at 4 p.m.; and Tues¬

day, March 3 at 8 p.m. Admis
sion is free. Tickets are re
quired for the Friday, Saturday,
and Monday performances and
may be obtained at the theater
department office.

Marriage of comedy 6c the 80's

by Dan Larkin and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Mike: I must confess, I
was really excited when I saw
that The Wedding Singer had
come to town. Given the fact
that I find Happy Gilmore and
Billy Madison such fun, it-was
a natural reaction for me to get
excited. I figured that Adam
Sandier set to the tune of the
1980's would be an instant
recipe for movie hilarity. '
Dan: I admit that I'm
generally a bit of a snob when
it comes to my taste in movies
But darn it, I'm a sucker for
Adam _handler's low-brow cin
ematic exploits, too. It's a bit
of a guilty pleasure, but Billy
Madison makes me laugh like
few other movies can, no mat
ter how many times I watch it.
So I was looking forward to 1 this

one. Well, I won't keep you in

Library BULLETin

by Libby Musselman
Library Columnist
Q: Dear Libby, I can't
study in ray room—it's too
noisy. And the library is a so
cial center. Where can I get
some quiet?
The second, third and
fourth floors are for quiet
study. I recommend the
fourth floor study carrels and
the third floor study bays. The
first floor can't be a quiet area
because of the circulation
desk, reference desk, and of
fices, and neither can the
ground floor, which has pho
tocopiers, the computer lab,
and media services. We can't
make every floor quiet, but
levels two, three, and four are
designated quiet floors.

Q.: Dear Libby, I've
come to the library in the
morning three times this se
mester to take out a reserve
video, and each time, it hasn't
been returned yet! How can I
find out who has it? Don't
worry, you won't be named as
an accessory.
Unfortunately for you,
PA law - Title 24 P.S. Section
4428 (PA Act 198490, Sec
tion 428) declares all library
circulation and borrower
records are confidential. Fur
thermore, the American Li
brary Association's Code of
Ethics promises to "protect
each library user's right to
privacy and confidentiality

with respect to information
sought or received and resources
consulted, borrowed, acquired,
or transmitted." Of course—if
you were the one in question—
you'd be happy this protection
was in place. The only recourse
you have is to complain to your
professor that the reserves are
unavailable when you've needed
them. One action that your pro
fessor could take would be to
curtail everyone's ability to take
the reserve item from the library
at all—but we don't want that,
do we? The best solution is for
people to be timely in returning
the reserve items they check out.
Libby's tip of the week: If
you need a book that has been
checked out, the library can re
call any book or put a "hold" on
it for you. If it is an emergency
and you are sure that someone
else in your class has it, some
one will call that person and see
if he or she is willing to share.

When you drop in: Check
out the display cases on the first
floor of the library. The four
cases include pictures and art
from students who went on the
winter break service learning
trips and contributed materials
to the displays. The four service
learning sites: Luther Place,
Washington, D.C.; Woodside,
Jamaica; Greene County, Ala
bama; and Cajamarca, Peru.
Please send your com
ments, questions, and/or com
plaints to
lmussel@gettysburg.edu

From the Donkey's Mouth

Al Gore for president

by Libby Main
Political _Columnist
Despite the investigation
of many of President Clinton's
closest confidants and staff
members, one key political
player has escaped connection
to the nasty Lewinsky scandal.
Vice President Al Gore, as
usual, remains unconnected to
allegations of wrongdoing. And
yet Gore is behaving appropri
ately by standing behind the
president without directly ad
dressing the scandal. Along
with a high level of morality,
there are many other positive
aspects of Al Gores intellect
and character which make him
the best candidate for president
in the year 2000.
Americans who think that
Al has escaped charges because
he is an uninvolved vice presi¬

dent are uninformed. Since
taking office in 1993, Gore has
been actively involved in the
formulation of many executive
policies.
Gore conducted a now
famous survey of the efficacy
of the federal government
which produced hundreds of
specific recommendations and
cost savings reforms to improve
the government and save tax
payers money. Gore also
served as chair of the Violent
Crime Control and Law En
forcement Act of 1994's Crime
Prevention Council. In the
realm of foreign policy, Al Gore
is integrally involved as a co
chair of several binational com
missions.
Al Gore's commitment to
and leadership on environmen
tal issues is unparalleled. He
has said that protection and

preservation of the earth is one
of the most important issues
facing this generation. Acting
upon his concerns, Gore estab
lished the GLOBE program to
increase environmental aware
ness among children around
the world.
Gore is also very knowl
edgeable in the areas of science,
space and technology policy.
He was aware of the introduc
tion of the Information Super
Highway almost 17 years ago,
and since then has become a
recognized national leader in
the development of the Na
tional Information
Infostructure. A president who
is familiar with computer tech
nology would help focus na
tional efforts to help America
regain strength in the global
marketplace.
Al Gore is a caring, intel¬

ligent individual. He has the
experience in government,
strength of character, an'd dedi
cation to issues that will affect
this country for the better that
America needs. Yes, Al Gore
appears stiff and uncomfort
able in front of television, cam
eras, but he is at ease when
meeting one on one with gov
ernment leaders.
Gore is the son of former
U.S. Senator Albert Gore, Sr.
and he was raised in both Ten
nessee and Washington as a re
sult of his fathers government
career. Al Jr received a degree
in government with honors
from Harvard University where
he roomed with famous actor
Tommy Lee Jones. After gradu
ation, Gore voluntarily enlisted
in the Army and served in Viet
nam. After his military service,
Gore attended Vanderbilt Uni¬

versity, married Mary Elizabeth
Tipper Aitchenson and eventu
ally ran for the U.S. Congress.
Gore won an election in 1976
and served eight years in the
House. He was then elected to
the U.S. Senate in 1984 and
1990. Al Gore would make
an excellent U.S. President.
On a different topic, I
would like to commend Presi
dent Clinton for considering a
tough policy stand against Iraq.
Persons who criticized
Clinton's lack of military expe
rience have to admit that the
President is taking a hard-line
approach to keep the U.S./U.N
inspection going. A possible
bombing of Baghdad is a much
more decisive move than
former veteran and President,
George Bush decided upon.
Lets not forget that Al Gore is
a veteran! Gore 2000!



nPQ The Greek Word IKN

by Earl Redding
IFC Public Relations
Greek life is back and in
full swing this semester as the
three and a half weeks of
pledging come to a half way
point. In total, about 150 men
and 90 women are pledging
our 11 Fraternities and 5 So
rorities. This year, however,
Alpha Xi Delta hopefully be
came trailblazers as they
dropped out of formal rush
after the first weekend and
decided to rush informally
with many events such as
mocktails before the Snow
Ball. All of the Greek commu
nity wishes Alpha Xi the best.
The sorority pledges
were busy this past weekend
at Chi Omega's annual Mr.
Fraternity where they danced
and sang in commercials. The
Chi Omega pledges ended the
highly eventful evening to
Mase's "Bad Boy" while Delta
Gamma, Gamma Phi Beta, Al¬

pha Delta Pi, and Alpha Xi
Delta also livened up the crowd
with routines. The highlight of
the evening though was the Mr.
Fraternity contest.
Tony DeFail of Alpha Chi
Rho took home the crown with
a stellar and steady perfor
mance that captivated the
crowd with his rendition of
Sublime'a "What I Got," and
was helped out by the guitar
playing of Mike Soltesz. Mike
Ben'ary of Fiji was the runner
up with his performance high
lighted by his singing and pi
ano playing to Ben Folds Five's
"Brick". Gary Lawson of Phi
Sigma Kappa was second run
ner-up also with a steady per
formance. The biggest cheers
however, were given to the
cowboy who was not partici
pating in Mr. Fraternity but
wowed the female audience
with a strip tease.

This weekend will also be
busy among Greeks as Sigma
Alpha Epsilon and Alpha Delta

Pi team up to host a Mardi Gras
dance-a-thon on Friday night
to benefit the Ronald
McDonald House. Everyone
on campus is invited, and the
last person dancing will win a
hundred dollars as well as the
best male and female dancers
will be crowned King and
Queen of Mardi Gras. Please
participate and show your sup
port for a worthwhile cause.
Next weekend, the 27th
of February, Sigma Nu will be
hosting MANDAY HUGE, a
band from Nags Head, North
Carolina from 10-1 pm for
an all campus BYOB party. The
event is helped by the $50,000
Dr. Haaland has given to the
student body. If you would like
to check out more information
on MANDAY HUGE, you can
visit their web-site at http://
www.mandayhuge.com.
Again, good luck to all
the pledges and congratulations
to Tony DeFail, Mr. Fraternity,

Strike down the tyrant

by LA. Isherwood
Columnist

the matter is that everyday the
United States government is
sending hundreds of troops and
supplies to the Middle East in
anticipation of military conflict
with the tyrant, Saddam
Hussein. Why is there now the
possibility of war?
In 1991, the Gulf War
came to a close after the Iraqi
army crumpled under the force
of the allied coalition to free
Kuwait. Most of us undoubt
edly remember watching the
nightly news, anticipating our
victory over such an evil little
man as Saddam Hussein. The
United States was, for the first
time since Vietnam, in favor of
- continued on page 12 •
see Tyrant

Carl von Clausewitz, a
nineteenth-century military
tactician, stated that "the aim
of all action in war is to disarm
the enemy." Such a statement
concerning the ever-prevalent
war with Iraq is quite accurate
concerning United States
policy.
Over the weekend, I was
appalled to discover the
plethora of people across our
campus not remotely aware of
the current crisis in the Gulf. I
know that at college sometimes
it is difficult to keep in touch
with current events, but when
one's nation is on the brink of
war, such negligence becomes
intolerable. The simple fact of


Consider this

Has anyone ever noticed
the long lines at the salad bar
in Servo? You stand, attempt
ing to avoid being swept away
by the pushing crowd, while
skinny girls place skimpy
amounts of greenery onto their
plates.
As with any college cam
pus, eating disorders are a not
so-hidden reality at Gettysburg
College. With National Eating
Disorder Awareness Week
coming up, the campus com
munity needs to make a spe
cial effort not only to acknowl
edge the presence of the prob
lem within its own institutions
and student body, but to search
for causes and propose solu
tions. Are there things on this
campus that promote eating
disorders?'Sources say yes.
Take a look at the wrestling
team...how do you think some
of the lighter athletes maintain
such a low weight level in a
sport that requires a large
amount of muscle?
And what about the
Greek system? Though hazing
is illegal on this campus, cer
tain sororities still seem to 'en
courage' their pledges to as
semble for a review dressed in
only their underwear, during

which the 'problem areas' or
their bodies will be circled with
black magic marker.
Though these are just a
few incidents out of what is
most likely a countless amount,
it is apparent that some activi
ties supported by the college
encourage unhealthy eating
behaviors. Although most
people do not realize the ex
tent to which these forces cre
ate low self-esteem and poor
body image, they indeed have
a serious impact upon the way
that students look at them
selves in the mirror each morn
ing. When a thin woman
looks in the mirror and sees
nothing but fat, and when an
athlete cannot afford to gain
even a pound or two without
the fear that they will be un
able to compete in the next
competition, there is a prob
lem. The college has contrib
uted to this situation by not
doing enough to educate stu
dents about the dangers of
these actions.
The upcoming programs
intended to inform and edu
cate our students will hopefully
be the first step in creating a
healthier campus environment.

Greek problems

by Jay Spiese
Columnist We are now full swing
into the time that organiza
tion leaders fear. Every club
and activity around campus
experiences a drop in mem
bership and participation. It
is tragic that students are
forced to choose between
participating in many activi
ties around campus and be
coming Greek.
The problem we find
with Greek society is two
fold. First we lose members
to what is basically a drink
ing club. My Greek readers
are surely, at this point, go
ing to spout off their tired
refrain, "We do more than
just party." You can point to
perhaps one or two philan¬

thropic events that your group
organizes each year. If you
include participation in events
organized by other groups
then it does appear like you
actually do some good for the
campus. I, however, hold you
to the same standard as other
clubs. I will not accept your
participation in an activity you
did not organize as evidence of
your positive contribution to
this campus. When that is
taken away we are left with
only drinking and partying.
Secondly, Greek society
is not composed of individu
als as much as herds. The T
shirt I used to see sorority
members wearing unintention
ally stated the truth, "No mat
ter what the letter, we are all
Greek together." It is amazing
how soon after rush people

follow their Greek brothers
and sisters like so many cattle.
People who used to think on
their own now resign them
selves to accepting the views of
the group. This is arguably the
gravest harm that Greek soci
ety causes on this campus.
They are a stifling influence on
the individual.
I praise those individuals
who have rebelled against
Greek life by leaving
their Fraternity or Sororit
. I also support all indepen
dents. You are the individual
voices on campus that make the
difference. I also hope that
many of those pledging this
year take a long hard look at
the group they are joining. Do
not surrender your individual
ity to the mob. Be independent
rather than a slave.


by Cammie Grant
Columnist The current hot topic
in the world is Operation
Desert Thunder. American
military forces are lining up
in the Persian Gulf. The
United States, Britain, Aus
tralia, Canada, Poland, Por
tugal, Germany, Sweden,
Norway and Brazil are the
countries who are support
ing the . use of force in the
Persian Gulf. The primary
question facing the countries
is what their main objective
is; is it to eliminate Saddam
Hussein's chemical and bio
logical weapons or is it to
end Saddam Hussein en
tirely? I support the Clinton

administration slogan regard
ing this potentially harmful
situation, "no more pin
pricks." For years now, the
United States has been in
volved with Iraq, and it is time
to take action, once and for all.
Hussein is a dangerous threat
to surrounding countries and
production of weapons of
mass destruction is hazardous
to the world. Saddam had
toyed around with our leaders
for years and it has reached a
point of possible mass destruc
tion. It is time for us and our
allied forces to move in, and
at the very least, make an ef
fort to eliminate all chances for
the further production of
chemical and biological weap
ons and to destroy all existing
weapons of mass destruction.

Many people do not realize the
destructive capability these
weapons possess. Inhaling a
small dust particle of Anthrax
is fatal. It is also thought that
Hussein also has the supplies to
end all life on Earth.
Countries need to unite
and support a common effort
to "disarm" Saddam Hussein.
He is an incredible danger not
only to his neighboring coun
tries, but our entire world.
Within the next couple of
weeks, I expect that there will
be action taken. According to
U.S.A. Today, opinion polls
show support exists for air
strikes.
It is time for Americans
to come together with support
ing countries.

A look at our college

by John Dunlap
Political Columnist
If I may, this week I

my normal tirade on national
politics or the latest scandal hit
ting the country. The politics
that I wish to concentrate on
this week are right here at Get
tysburg College. Next week
are the elections for the Execu
tive Board of Student Senate,
and following those elections,
regular Student Senate and
Class Officer elections will oc¬

cur. This past year has been a
pretty good year for Student
Senate. Just last Monday, a ma
jor victory for fairness was an
nounced during Senate as Dean
Julie Ramsey read a letter
signed by President Haaland
allowing for international stu
dents to receive financial aid to
go abroad, just like any other
student is able to. Senate has
been fighting for fairness on
this issue for longer than I have
been around, and this is a vic
tory for the entire campus.
Student Senate this past
year has made a great deal of
progress in regard to issues

dealing with the social life on
the campus. Two committees
are now working to improve
the social climate. One of these
committees has been given the
power to appropriate fifty
thousand dollars in order to
make Gettysburg a better place
to live and work. The other
committee is looking to solve

now need to push it from' the

System on this campus. That
starts with saving Alpha XI
Delta and keeping the Greek
system independent. By inde
pendent I mean keeping the
Greek Judicial system and not
replacing its duties with
theStudent Conduct Review
Board, as some wish.

at long term planning, the
housing crunch is the immedi
ate concern. Students should
not have to live at the Seminary

reason that fraternities are im
portant now is because they
house students.

ideas being examined for the
future are mixed. The college's
decision not to keep J. Martin

not only will Dr. DeClair be
leaving Gettysburg College, the

for the time being. The Euro

only academic competition and
year after year Gettysburg does
well. This year was no excep
