government of Iraq has led UN
officials on a wild goose chase
which has finally led to an in
ternational conflict due to the
barring of United States inspec
tors from these laboratories.
The United States will not tol
erate such resistance, the vio
lation of United Nation's pre
cedents, and the treaty of
1991.

The simple fact of the
matter is that this third world
terrorist is a threat to our for
eign policy within the region
and has repeatedly tried to hurt
our interests. He is a tyrant who
has killed hundreds of thou
sands of his own people to keep
his regime afloat. He has used
weapons of mass destruction on
other nations as well as on par
tisan groups within his nation.
He is a threat to freedom and
democracy, two of the ideals
which we hold so dear, and is
causing his own people harm.
Our foreign policy is not against
the people of Iraq, but rather

this evil person who calls him
self their leader. He must be
stopped, and if the greatest
army in the world won't do it,
who will?
Carl von Clausewitz also
said that "war is the continua
tion of politics by other
means," and our policy now is
that when diplomacy fails
(which it is rapidly doing), war
must take place. The regime
of Saddam Hussein is irratio
nal and fanatical, and politics
has shown that little progress
can be made with such a per
son. Thus, if diplomacy fails,
we must intervene and disarm

the enemy by force and with
great speed and strength. If we
commit force, then may our
armed forces do everything
necessary to destroy the Iraqi
army, their capability for mak
ing weapons of mass destruc
tion, and the government of
Saddam Hussein. Iraq needs to
be free, the people want to be
free, and a genocidal maniac
prevents such freedom. We
must then free Iraq from
Saddam Hussein, and force is
necessary, we as Americans for
the sanctity of our values
should support such action.

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from

12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more information,
contact any of the following
persons: Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext. 8159; T.J.
Scott (Allies secretary/treasurer),
Ext. 7596; Alec Beekmans, Ext.
7071; Helen DeVinney, Ext. 7807;

Katherine McFate, PhD, "Welfare
and Work " ~ Katherine McFate is
Associate Director of Equal Opportu
nity at'the Rockefeller foundation.
Prior to that time, she directed the -
Social Policy program at the Joint
Center for Political and Economic
Studies, a Washington DC think tank
that specializes in issues of concern to
African Americans. She has pub
lished articles on a variety of issues
related to urban poverty, but for the
past several years, she has been

focusing on welfare reform. She
authored a forthcoming monograph
for the Joint Center, Neglected
Voices: How the Poor View Poverty
and Welfare Reform, and published
another last year entitled, making
Welfare Work: Constructive Prin
ciples of Welfare Reform. She also
edited a volume with William Julius
Wilson, Poverty, Inequality and the
Future of Social Policy: Western
Stales in the New World Order,
published by Russell Sage comparing
social policy in the U.S. with those of
Canada and a number of European
countries. A complimentary lunch
will be served following the program.
Sponsored by the Department of
Sociology and Anthropology. -

Dell and friends take conferences by storm

Muhlenburg's Jason McLain to
augment his already stellar
record.
As a team, the Bullets fin
ished third in the Fifth Annual
Wrestling Championship held
at Swathmore College.
Gettysburg totaled 78
points, good enough to place
them ahead of Muhlenbergj
Swathmore, and Johns
Hopkins, but not enough to
outpace Western Maryland
(overall champions) and
Ursinus.
Gettysburg senior Jamie
Binnall came up short in the
118 lb. class championship,
while Brad McCutcheon, Mike
Ben'Ary, Chris Clifford, Brad
Baker, Sean Greene, and James
Lobsenz all registered victories
in their respected weight classes
before being knocked off by
tough competition.

by John Luiz
Contributing Reporter

Last Saturday Gettysburg
wrestlers senior Jake Dell and
junior Marty Scarpato proved
themselves able to dominate
their respective weight classes.
Jake became only the second
wrestler ever to win four con
secutive Centennial Confer
ence championships.
With a pin, Dell, the top
rated wrestler in Division III,
boosted his incredible season
record to 33-1. It took Dell
four minutes and nineteen sec
onds to pin Ursinus College
Junior Nate McElhaney and
clinch first place in the 167
pound class.

Bullet wrestler to best his
weight class. Marty Scarpato

In case you missed it...
Hodakowski shows off his stuff in Division III Senior Bowl

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
If this article would have
never been published in the
Gettysburgian, you would
never know about the mild
mannered, well groomed Bul
lets football captain named Joe
Hodakowski. Hodokowski has
been smashing the oppostion
into the ground in Mussleman
Stadium for four years and re
cently he reached the pinnacle
of his outstanding career.
On Januai y \_9, in a
snowy Fayetteville North Caro
lina, 78 of the nation's top se
nior Division III football play
ers assembled for the annual for
the USA Division III Martin
Luther King Holiday All-Star
Classic.

Hodakowski, who was
named a third team All-Amen
can for his perfomances on the
field this year, was invited to
the game to play along side
some of the top college players
in the nation.
Joe who you ask? We had
an All-Amencan on our foot
ball team this year? Yes, we did.
He wouldn't tell you if you
asked him though, rather he

would give you and answer
like, "I was part of a team, as
far as I am concerned the team
is responsible for my sucess. I
just go out and do the best I
can for them. That's all."
"Hodo" as his friends
call him, always gave all he
could for the best of the team
and perhaps that was why he
was chosen as team captain this
season. But on January 19, the
little man with the huge heart
ran into Douglas Byrd stadium
as one of the best in the nation.
But he is only five feet,
nine inches tall, and only
wieghs two-hundred pounds;
how did he hold up against the
best players in the nation? He
did more than ]ust "hold up."
Playing beside three other Di
vision III All-Amencans on the
same defensive line,
Hodakowski racked up 7 tack
les one of which was a
quaterback sack.

Hah. So much for the
big, ugly guys always being the
best football players. To rack
up those kind of stats Joe must
have used his strength, quick
ness and desire to win to over
come the sometime 300 hun
dred pound odds.

photo by Mark Aslrom
Number #54 Joe "Hodo" Hodakowski, quietly moves to assault this opposing passer.

"What thrill to play
against the best D-III players in
the country," said a smiling,
mud-splattered Hodakowski
after the game. "Here we come
the North Carolina and it
snows. It is something I will

never forget."
Although his name was
never printed in big letters (ex
cept today) and not everybody
knows his name, Joe
Hodakowski has left a perma
nent mark not only on football
team, but the collge as well. Joe

said that the game was some
thing that he will never forget;
well Joe, none of your coaches,
teammates and friends will ever
be able to forget you. Thank
you for being a part of our lives
for the last four years. It was
special.

Bullets reload for new season with Woods, Lunardi, and Lavenburg

If the young talent can come together, these Bullets are aimed at success

by Ted Hartman
Contributing Reporter
The Bullets baseball team
finished strong in the closing
weeks of the 1997 season, win
ning twelve of their last eigh
teen games. Coach John
Campo is hopeful that this suc
cess will continue into the
Spring of 1998, and considers
this squad a viable contender
for the Cenntenial Conference
championship.
Gettysburg's pitching
staff features proven consis
tency in its returning arms.
Sophomores Dan Sirpinski and
Paul Koether are expected to
step up this Spring and provide
the Bullets with reliable perfor
mances after sizable contribu
tions as freshmen. PJ McElroy,
also a sophomore, shares this
potential and will fill the third
position in the rotation.

Campo is not yet sure
which of his remaining seven
hurlers will be designated the
fourth starter. Juniors Pete
Rittenhouse and Matt
DeVecchi are both in conten
tion, with freshmen Tom Boob
and Drew Chiesa providing
competition as well. Out of the
bullpen the Bullets can look to
a strong group of young talents

for middle relief and late-in
mng closing.
Sophomore Jere Dee, a
first year player, is making a
smooth transition from outfield
to the mound. Ryan Sweeney
and Jeff Ellis, each freshmen,
showed an ability to pitch ef
fectively at the college level in
fall ball.
"Once we go down to
Florida we will be able to de
fine our roles better as far as
who will be middle and short
relief. Our pitching coach Lee
Rentzell is very optimistic
about this group," said Campo.
The Bullets are also en
thusiastic about their position
players. The outfield is stocked
with strong arms and speed in
sophomore Chris Lunardi, se
nior Daryl Clancy, both prob
able starters. Sophomore Greg
Kosc, and freshmen Bill Neston
and Jim Nestasi are all cur
rently vying for the remaining
position. Campo expects his
outfielders to he the table set¬

ters with an aggressive running
assault for the Bullet RBI men.
Sophomores John Woods
and Bill Beining should effec
tively plate the Gettysburg
lead-off hitters. The 1997 sea
son saw Woods tally 30 RBIs
and belt six home runs, to go

along with his .404 batting av
erage. Combined with
Beining_'s power, the tandem
should make it impossible for
opposing pitching staffs to
pitch around the core of the
line-up. Though both are good
defensive first basemen, Woods
will take the field opening day,
while Beining will be slotted
as designated hitter.

"John Woods is an all
conference cabber ball player
and has the potential to be an
ail-American candidate. It is
rare to find a player that can

great power. His six home runs
last season tied a school

Dravis scores 1000

From Staff Reports
Despite a stunning 83-71
loss at the hands of Western
Maryland last week, the Get
tysburg College women's bas
ketball still has a bright post
season playoff picture.
Gettysburg and Western
Maryland are currently tied for
second place in the west divi
sion of the Centennial Confer
ence with 9-4 records. West
ern Maryland traveled to
league leading Johns Hopkins
(12-0 in Centennial) on
Wednesday. Gettysburg is
sporting a 16-6 overall record.
Gettysburg is currently
paced by a set of senior twins,
Jen and Steph Dravis. Steph is
the current scoring leader with
a 12.3 average and leads the

Ziggy Marley to play Springfest concert
Grammy winning group chosen by SAC

Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers will play at the
Springfest concert on April 18. Opening acts Guster
and Ghetto Youth will also perform. Tickets go on sale
April 6. _^^

By Laura Root
Staff Reporter Ziggy Marley and
the Melody Makers will be
coming to Gettysburg on
Saturday, April 18. Open
ing for the Melody Mak
ers will be the bands
Guster and Ghetto Youth.
The Student Activi
ties Council (SAC) decided
that Ziggy Marley and the
Melody Makers were the
best choice after reviewing
the student surveys passed
out earlier this year.
Adam Norton and
Jackie Trottier, co chair
persons of the concert
committee, said that there
was a great demand on
campus for reggae music.
The band has re
ceived widespread praise,
and their new alburn,
Fallen Is Babylon, has been
nominated for a Grammy
Award.

"Ziggy Marley and
the Melody Makers aren't
a flash in the pan," sayi
Norton, "they have re
ceived both good record
and concert reviews."
Other bands being
considered for the Spring
Concert included Rusted
Root, Barenaked Ladies,
Third Rye Blind, Match
box 20, and Toad the Wet
Sprocket. After studying
the bands' schedules,
Norton and Trottier made
their hnal decision.
Opening band
Guster pLiys a unique type
of modern folk. They are
known for their outstand¬

ing live performances. The
Melody Makers are bring
ing an additional opening
band, Ghetto Youth with
them. Ziggy Marley and
the Melody Makers strive
to connect the rich reggae
roots with a variety of
today's popular music
styles. The band has sold
millions of records, toured
the globe, and won two
Grammy Awards.
Melody Makers
Sharon, Stephen, Cedella,
and Ziggy Marley are all
children of the late reggae
great, Bob Marley. More
than 20 other musicians
accompany the Marleys to
make up the band.

According to SAC,
the student response to the
Spring Concert has been
"outstanding." Reggae
record sales at K&K
Records have increased,
and Norton and Trottier
have heard nothing but
good things about their
choices.
"Guster has a strong
following," said Trottier,
"and the Melody Makers
fit the upbeat Springfest
theme."
A large turnout is ex
pected for the event. Tick
ets are set to go on sale
Monday, April 6.
"Everybody is look
ing forward to something
different," concluded
Norton, "They're excited
to come, and we're excited
to have them."

Commission
on Future
to reveal
findings

The Commission on
the Future of Gettysburg Col
lege will complete its year-long
examination of the College's
academic and co-curncular
programs when it presents its
findings to the College's Board
of Trustees on Saturday, Febru
ary 28. Approximately 200
members of the Commission
are expected to attend an af
ternoon working session and
evening dinner celebration.
The members will be briefed on
a number of themes that were
identified by the task forces of
the Commission. During the
evening, the trustees, the gov
erning body of the College and
the group responsible for the
creation of the Commission,
will be presented the final re
port of the Commission.

GCPR

"The Commission has
been successful beyond our
greatest expectations," said Jim
Brenneman, chair of the Com
mission, a Gettysburg graduate,
and College trustee. "The
Commission members have
provided thoughtful and in
sightful perspectives on areas of
vital importance to the future
of the College, and their rec
ommendations will provide sig
nificant impetus to the Board
of Trustees as Gettysburg
moves forward in it's strategic
planning process."
The Commission com
prised task forces studying eco
nomics and management, ex
cellence in the sciences and psy
chology, public affairs and pub
lic service, information tech
nology, collaborative learning
and teamwork supporting stu
dent success, enhancing resi
dential life, culture and the arts,
and student recruitment and

Award winning poet to speak

Run-off election
to be held
by Henry Fawell
Assistant News Editor
- The Student Senate elec
tions saw several new students
voted into office this week, yet
the most important position,
the Presidency, will have to be
decided in a runoff.
In accordance with the
Student Senate Constitution, a
presidential candidate must
obtain a majority vote from the
students to claim the position.
Yet none of the three candi
dates for the position, Sara
Zalewski, Earl Redding nor
John Dunlap could do so.
The run-off election will
be held between Zalewski and
Redding, most likely sometime
next week.

There were, however,
three new positions decided in
the elections. Emily Robertson
won the Vice Presidency, Liz
Walsh will be the new Secre
tary, and Lisa Wingenroth is
the new Treasurer.

more than $30,000 left to al
locate to students for social
events. In order to obtain fund
ing for its events, an organiza

tion to be approved by the Stu
dent Life Committee.
In order to be approved
the event or function must
meet four cirtena established
by the committee. The event

must be approached in a fresh
and inovative way. The pro

unique partnerships between

strategic planning and budget
considerations.

A sporting good time

by Cara Masucci
Staff Reporter Lately it seems as though
there is an increase in the
amount of time people are put
ting into working out and
maintaining a healthy body.
Nowhere is this more apparent
than here at Gettysburg Col
lege. Students at _k_^_kh

Gettysburg have a
wide variety of op
tions open to them in
order to achieve their
goals. This is thanks
to a large effort on the
part of the Campus
Recreation Depart
ment. There is a wide
variety of different
programs that anyone
on campus can join.
They range from
intramurals and club
sports to aerobics, spe
cial events, and finally
the fitness facilities.
A lot of work
goes into these pro
grams, according to
Director of Campus
Recreation Cynthia
Wright. First off, you
have to secure a facil
ity, advertise the event
and sign-ups, and hire
and train officials and

supervisors.
This is not all. It _^
is essential to work _t
with the Office of Col- -s
lege Life and Student

Basketball Is just one of the many Intramural sports offered by the Campus Recreation Department for all
tudents to play. If you have any questions about the programs, contact Cythia Wright or Barbara Streeter,

Senate,
which currently fund club
sports, in order to get every
thing off the ground.
Consequently, there are
hundreds of workers in Cam
pus Recreation. According to
Wright and her Assistant Direc
tor, Barbara Streeter, campus
recreation has always been one
of the most popular jobs on
campus. The workers do ev
erything from manning the fit
ness facilities to refereeing in
tramural events. According to
Wright, "Our programs would
not exist if not for the students

helping to run it."
Currently there are seven
intramural sports that Wright
oversees (Wright handles all
intramurals, club sports, and
fitness facilities, while Streeter
oversees special events and
aerobics). Flag football and
basketball appear to be the
most popular, drawing on

about 350 participants each.
Rounding out the seven
intramural sports available to
the campus are softball, indoor
and outdoor soccer, volleyball,
and floor hockey. All draw
roughly 200 participants each.
The intramurals are not
the only aspect of recreation
drawing high numbers. The
fitness facilities have seen a
jump to 1000 visitors a week,
not including athletic teams
according to Wright. Streeter
also points out that the aero
bics numbers have grown to
about 225 with this time of

year being the most populated.
Special events draw heavy
participation as well.
One improvement in
numbers that both Streeter and
Wright are happy to see is the
increase in women's participa
tion and co-ed participation in
al I aspects of campus recreation.
Wright stated, "The College is

really trying to make an effort
to have students interact in a
healthy environment."
One of the main goals in
cluded in the mission statement
of Campus Recreation is to fos
ter an environment conducive
to studying. If you can relieve
stress, as many students who
participate say they do, then
you are much more able to
study more efficiently and pro
ductively. The recreation gives
the students a chance to blow
off steam.
It might be e.isy to blow
off steam in recreation because,

as several students comment,
they make new friends and cul
tivate existing relationships.
is also easy to laugh when you
see your professor trying to
drive the lane in a game of bas
ketball!
Again, Wright feels this
emphasizes the goal of putting
everyone on the campus at an t,

Reel Hits & Misses
Sphere not much of a ball

by Dan Larkin and Mike Pctro
Movie columnists
Mike: Okay movie fans,
picture this. You are one of the
leading minds in the country in
your field, either mathematics,
astrophysics, biology, or psy
chology. You are called to in
vestigate a crash of a "space
craft" somewhere in the middle
of the Pacific Ocean, inside of
which you discover a perfect
sphere. Somehow you go in
side of this large orb and after
coming out, all of your dreams
and nightmares come true.
If you can picture this,
you might like the new Michael
Crichton movie Sphere.
Dan: I'm still having a
difficult time picturing that.
But I liked Sphere anyway.
Sphere is directed and produced
by Barry Levinson (Wag the

Dog, Sleeper;,), and while it
isn 't as memorable as some of
his other projects, it does have
its moments. I was fairly ap
prehensive about this movieie
membenng that my last expe
rience with a Michael Crichton
vehicle was The Lost World,
which I'm pietty sure is the
worst movie I have ever seen.
But, have no fear, Sphere is
much better than that dinosaur
flick. I went to see this movie
with admittedly low expecta
tions, and I actually came out
of the theater with it exceed
ing my expectations im
mensely. The movie features
an all-star cast with Dustin
Hoffman (Ishtar, Dick Tracy)
as Dr. Norman Goodman,
Samuel L. Jackson (National
Lampoon's Loaded Weapon,
The Great White Hype) as

Harry Adams, and Sharon
Stone (Action Jackson, Police
Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol)
as Beth Halperin.
Beyond these three stars,
who all turn in unique and in
teresting performances is an
excellent supporting cast. Pe
ter Coyote (E.T. The Extra-Ter
restrial, Outrageous Fortune)
plays Harold Barnes, the token
government spook, and Liev
Schreiber of Scream fame plays
Ted Fielding, the hot shot
physicist. Add in Queen
Latifah (Hoodlum, House
Party 2) and you've got your
self a cast!
The cast does a pretty
good job developing these
characters despite a fairly weak
script. The dialogue seems
forced and artificial through
most of the film. It is to the
credit of the actors (especially

Hoffman and Jackson) that
they are able to carry much of
the film with their personalities.
Jackson and Hoffman
have both bad particularly
good winters at the movies,
each following strong perfor
mances in Jackie Brown and
Wag the Dog, respectively, with
good jobs here. Stone's perfor
mance, however, isn't as strong
as her two co-stars. The special
effects of the movie are quite
good. The underwater scenes
are spectacular, and the various
underwater creatures are all
pretty creepy. The effects are
not overpowering, allowing the
film to tell its story unfettered
(unlike the stupid dinosaur
movie, which was all about the
effects.)
This movie bills itself as
a suspense and it delivers the
goods. There are some genu¬

inely scary moments in this film
that will make you jump out
of your seat. Furthermore, the
story, save for a few plot holes,
is well held together and engag
ing for the viewer.
/ liked the story, but I felt
it was condensed in order to fit
into the two hour movie, and
the conclusion seemed a bit
rushed. Overall, it is an inter
esting, suspenseful film. I give
it two and 3/4 stars (out of five).
I thought this movie was
worth the price of the admis
sion and I am going to give it a
three out of five stars. Not ev
ery movie can be a great movie,
so the cinematic landscape has
to be dotted with movies that
are simply good entertainment.
If you are looking for a few
thrills and a good suspense
movie, then I recommend
Sphere to you.

A battler's testimony

by Megan Lewis and Jen
Hamel Contributing Reporters

successful field hockey career.
Throughout high school I had
worked my way to All-State and
Ail-American titles. But a con
tinued career in the sport came
to a sudden halt when I devel
oped a fierce battle with an eat
ing disorder, a struggle which I
have endured for the past three
years. When most college stu
dents wake up in the morning,
their first thoughts are "What
will I wear?" or "What do I
have due in my first class?" Not
me. My first thoughts are "Will
I eat today? If so, how much or
how little? How many times
will I work out then, if I do
eat?" These are all questions I
struggle to answer, not just
when I wake up, but as I go
through my day, until I go to
sleep. And then, many of my
dreams are about food and ex-

Eating disorders. Many
people choose to believe that
they do not exist at Gettysburg
College. All someone has to do
is open their eyes to see that
there are students who are af
fected by bulimia and/or anor
exia. The fight against eating
disorders is a continuous one.
For those who are struggling to
overcome it, the battle is ex
hausting. Each day, the mere
thought of food overpowers a
person's thoughts and actions,
resulting in an obsession that
just doesn't stop.
The following is a per
sonal experience of a student
who has continuously battled
eating disorders over the past
three years. Hopefully this will
give a better understanding of
what it is like to live with an
eating disorder and help us to
realize that it is a common oc¬

currence in our society.
/ came to Gettysburg with
high hopes of a productive and

erase. Contrary to what many
people believe, eating disorders
are not just about being skinny.
My eating disorder is about my
need for control and perfection.

It is related to my desire to
please everyone. It is a reflec
tion of the guilt and worthless
ness that I feel about myself.
Sometimes, I do not believe that
I am worthy of eating.
Over the past three years
my weight has ranged from 90
pounds to 130 pounds. Finally,
this past fall, my weight reached
the lowest ever and I was forced
to go to an eating disorders hos
pital. My three week stay taught
me a lot about myself, both in
relation to food and self-worth
as a person. Although the hos
pital has helped me tremen
dously and I have now gained
about 25 pounds, every day is
a difficult struggle.
What is important is that
people are aware that eating
disorders are very prevalent,
especially on college campuses
like Gettysburg.

The first step to over
coming this battle is to admit
that you have a problem and to
accept help from those who care
the most for you. In doing this,
half the battle is won.

by Farzana Sultan
Contributing Reporter
Alex Rowland, a profes
sor of organic chemistry at
Gettysburg College, is a man
who spends his days working
with his students and doing re
search in the laboratories of the
Chemistry Department. He
has spent his last 40 years in
Gettysburg and is one of the
most senior faculty members in
the Chemistry Department.
Raised in New York,
Rowland is one of seven sib
lings. He spent five years in
high school, which he de
ribed
buiucu

as a:
a great
experi
ence.
"An ex-
tra year

did me a lot of good. I learned
typing, took extra courses and
did a lot of extracurricular ac
tivities," he commented.
He did his undergraduate
studies at Gettysburg College
because his parents wanted him
to study at a Lutheran college.
After graduating from
Gettysburg, he attended Brown
University, where he studied
organic chemistry. Ultimately,
he came back to Gettysburg as
a professor.
As a professor, Rowland
has flourished and is held in
high regard among both his
peers and his students, al
though he has the reputation of
giving difficult pop quizzes. He
was awarded the Distinguished
Teaching Award this year, and
has published articles in many
journals over the years.
Rowland thinks the

Honor Code System was the
best thing to be introduced into
college. He believes that it
makes students more reliable
and fosters a trustworthy rela
tionship between the faculty
and the students.
Over the years, he also
tried to promote a smoke-free
environment in the college.
Even so, he can still be found
smoking on the steps of
Briedenbaugh Hall. The latter
incident expresses the more
human side of Rowland.

In the research field.
Rowland is a prominent figure.
He has been carrying out re
search in both stereochemistry
and fullerenes and is a promi
nent member in that field.
"Because I like it," an
swered Rowland when asked
why he got involved in chem
istry. He has spent three-quar
ters of his life studying chemis
try only because he enjoys it.
"I was good in other subjects,
but chemistry was my favorite.
Curiosity drives me on."
He believes that science is
an important part of one's edu
cation and he was very dis
t u

i r b e d
when a
deci
sion
was
made
_-"
the labs

last year to remove
from some of the science
courses. "How can one do a
science course without con
ducting the practical side of it?"
he wondered.
Besides the resulting lack
of unity among the professors,
he is very satisfied with the
freedom Gettysburg allows its
professors. "Gettysburg never
interfered with my work. It al
lowed me to do research in
whatever interested me.
"I like working with my
students. They make it fun. I
want my students to do their
best and better than I ever did."
Since he is so involved in
his work, Rowland has very
limited outside interests.
"Working is my main pasttime,
but I find the history of World
War II very interesting." He
also sang in a choir during col
lege but quit because of all the
extra work.

At the end of the day,
Rowland likes to go home and
relax, which for him means
"drinking coffee and smoking
a cigar."
"The most important les
son I learned in life is that one
should exert oneself both out
wardly and inwardly." This is
Rowland's motto, and is per
haps what brought Rowland
the success and contentment he
now enjoys.

overpopulation is like a big

cluding clearance for stationary
agriculture, producing fire
wood and charcoal, rotating
cultivation, commercially
driven logging, expanding ur
ban and industrial areas, over
grazing and fodder collection,
are associated with the rapid
growth of population. Energy
consumption also increases
with population, as more
people in developing countries

For 99% of man's history,
there was essentially no popu
lation growth. But now, in the
last 1% of our history (starting
at approximately year 0), hu
man population has exhibited
exponential growth. It took
35,000 years (to 1830) to reach
the first billion people. The
second billion took only 100
years (to 1930) to reach, and
the third, 30 years (by 1960).
The fourth was reached in 15
years (by 1975), and the fifth
only 12 years (by 1987). With
today's rate of growth, our
population will swell from 5.6
billion to about 8.5 billion by
2025. If current predictions of
population growth prove accu
rate and patterns or human ac
tivity on the planet remain
unchanged, science and tech
nology may not be able to pre
vent the irreversible degrada
tion of the environment or
widespread world poverty.

cational program. Family plan
ning and social and economic
incentives may help curb this
population growth.
At any rate, what is done,
or not done, in the next decade
will determine the economic,
social, and political prospects
for much of the world for the
next century.

Monty worth the
show

by Stacy Schmeidel
Contributing Reviewer
Why would anyone
want to see a movie about six
unemployed guys who take
up stripping to make a few
bucks? Well, take it from some
one who's seen The Full
Monty, which was released
last August, not once but
seven times: this is one film
you won't want to miss. Sure,
the plot focuses on a cadre of
average blokes "getting their
kit off." But this is no

Showgirls. It's not even Strip
tease. The Full Monty, di
rected by Peter Cattaneo and
written by Simon Beaufoy, is
a simultaneously poignant, in
sightful, and laugh-'til-you
cry funny look at friendships,
self-esteem, and making the
most of what you've got. Lit
erate and witty, the film also
features one of the most real
istic and richly drawn mar
riages ever portrayed in a
comedy, and some of the most
brilliant physical comedy of
the past year.

Plus, it's got lawn
gnomes. What more could
you ask for?
The man behind the
Monty scheme is Gaz (Robert
Carlyle, virtually unrecogniz
able from the loathsome
Begbie he played in last year's
Trainspotting), who like a lot
of men in Sheffield, England,
is down on his luck after los
ing his job in the bust of
Sheffield's steel industry.
Desperate to'come up
with 700 quid to pay his over
due child support bills, Gaz
notices how the local women
line up when a traveling
Chippendales show comes to
town, and seizes on the no
tion of putting on a local ver
sion of the show in order to
make some quick cash.

Reactions to the scheme
are initially cool ("Who'd
want to see your widgie?")_,
but times in Sheffield are
tough, and almost before Gaz
knows it he's holding audi
tions and putting together a
line-up of dancers.
Over the next few

weeks, through a series of rous
ing rehearsals, soccer games,
and personal crises, the guys
coalesce, both as friends and as
a dancing ensemble; these six
men who initially had nothing
in common are soon sharing
beauty tips and swinging their
hips to Donna Summer tunes.
The problem, as some see
it, is that even after all the re
hearsal time, the ensemble is still
made up of average guys. Gaz
is "too thin," Dave is "too fat,"
Lomper's "pigeon chested," and
while Horse has some good
moves, he's also got gray hair
and a hip that's "a bit dodgy."
Pressed as to why the lo
cal "birds" will turn out to see
this act when they can see "the
real thing" at a Chippendale's
show, Gaz lights upon an idea
that will make his group stand
out. He promises that the
Sheffield men will go "the full
Monty," that is, they'll take their
striptease act all the way, no g
strine required.

As the film winds toward
its inevitable (yet tasteful!) con
clusion, we watch the six main
characters wrestle with the per
sonal insecurities that accom
pany unemployment, divorce,
body image, and intimacy.
Of particular note is Mark
Addy {Frost, in preproduction)
as Gaz' best friend Dave, who's
convinced that his weight is
cooling his wife's love for him
but feels unable to do anything
about it.
The other men in the
group are played by Tom
Wilkinson (The Ghost and the

Darkness), Steve Huison (When
Saturday Comes), Paul Barber
(Priest), and Hugo Speer (Bhaji
on the Beach).
The Full Monty has de
servedly earned Oscar nods for
Best Score, Screenplay, Director,
and Best Picture, and a Golden
Globe nomination for Best Pic
ture, but it's the fully drawn
characters that make the film
worth seeing even more than
once. After spending a couple of
hours with Gaz and the boys,
you'll want to see more of
them—even after they've gone
the full monty!

The Full Monty will be
shown in Bowen Auditorium on
Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m.

Women's history? Duh

by Sara Lindahl
Contributing Reporter

and the month of March has
been designated Women's
History Month to honor
many great women and to cel
ebrate their achievements.
During this month,
Gettysburg College's aca
demic buildings will be deco
rated with colorful posters to
featuring women who have
made outstanding contribu
tions to these academic fields.
The posters were de
signed not just to include trail
blazers who fought against
discrimination to force doors
open for women's higher edu
cation and promotions in the
work place, but also include
women whose efforts have
helped a global community.

Two years ago I overheard
a male to male conversation in
Musselman Library. The boys
were looking at the course cata
logue when one asked the other,
"Why is there a women's stud
ies major, but not a men's stud
ies major?" The response was,
"Duh, what do you think history
is?" The first replied, "Oh yeah,
that's because women haven't
done anything."
It is my hope that at the
end of next month, everyone on
this campus will be able to scoff
at this erroneous statement.
Women have made a sig
nificant contribution to history,

Women's history was
completely neglected in cur
riculums as recently as the
1970's.
In 1978, a California task
force started Women's History
Week, which led to Women's
History Month across the na
tion. In 1987, Congress de
clared March to be Women's
History Month.
Many states now have a
Women's Hall of Fame, and
Women's History Month has
become a focal point of cel
ebration across the nation.
I encourage everyone to
examine the posters and join in
the celebration of women's his
tory throughout the month of
March.

Screenwriter/Novelist to speak
in Junction

Screenwriter and novelist Todd Komarnicki will be reading from his work on Thursday,
February 26th, at 8:00 p.m. in the Junction. The event is sponsored by the Writing House.
Komarnicki's novels include Famine (1997) and Free (1995). Of Famine, Publisher's Weekly
says, "Hints of supernatural forces at work subtly underscore the narrative's theme: the
power of emotional need to create its own reality. A stylistic tour de force."



Library BULLETin

by Libby Musselman
Library Columnist
Q: I'm a big fan of In
terlibrary Loan, but I have a
complaint. If I want two ar
ticles from the same journal,
why can't I write them both
on the same request form?
It saves paper, and then
I don't have to write down my
name and address so many
times-what a pain!
A: We need one request
per card for two reasons. One
is that even though the articles
are from the same journal, the

same may
be filling the request for both
articles.
The second is that we
must comply with copyright
laws. After we've made five
requests in the same year (like
in 1998) tor the current five
years of one journal (like the
Journal of Chemical Educa
tion from 1992 to 1998), then
we (as in Gettysburg College)
must pay a copyright fee for
each subsequent request (af
ter five requests) of that jour
nal (dated from the past five
years).

It is bookkeeping that
drives us crazy and we know
it doesn't make you feel any
better, but we have to com
ply with the law. Capice?
Q: Who decides what
books and videos the library
buys? If a student like me

wants something, who (or is it
whom?) do I tell?
A: Librarians, and the fac
ulty select and purchase materi
als for our collection. Generally
the selections support the cur
riculum.
However, we are happy to
entertain suggestions from stu
dents as well. Please give us your
suggestions at the online sugges
tion box:
h t t p : / /
www.gettysburg.edu/forms/
suggest.html
If you want an answer, give
us your name and email address
so we can you.
Libbv'sTipsof the Week:
1. Tax forms are located
at the circulation desk after the
pass-through. Hurry if you want
one; they're going fast.

2. You can bookmark the
Library's homepage from your
computer at home: http://
www.gettysburg.edu/library/ so
you can conveniently search
Muscat, Periodical Indexes and
Abstracts, or full-text journals,
or many other engines.
. If you have trouble, you
can email a librarian to ask a
question at http://
www,getty sburg.edu/forms/
libref.html or from the
homepage under "Library
Forms" and "Ask a Librarian."
Please send more of your
comments, questions, and/or
complaints to
lmussel@gettysburg.edu

ANSWERS



Conflict and ComEmus-

To the Editor:

In defense of a brotherhood

I am writing in response
to the column "Greek Prob
lems," printed in the Febru
ary 19, 1998 edition of The
Gettysburgian. I will refrain
from making scathing re
marks as I understand this
point of view. 1 will, however,
proceed to show that harsh
generalizations about Greek
life are, at least in one case,
sorely mistaken.
I must start by giving
some background so that one
can better understand where
my point of view is coming

from. Upon coming to Get
tysburg, I too was skeptical
about the values of Greek life.
I came over to Crow often
simply to visit my older
brother and many of his
friends whom I have known
for a number of years. At a
certain point in the second
semester of my freshman year,
I made the decision that I
would join Alpha Chi Rho,
and that has probably been
the most important decision
that I have made in my col
lege career.

The article points to the
shortcomings of fraternities
citing that fraternities are es
sentially nothing more than
drinking clubs. It further goes
on to cover its bases in decry
ing the most basic response
that "we do more than just
party," saying that one or two
philanthropic events a year
and participation in events
organized by other groups
does not really add toward to
good of the community or
campus. I am in complete
agreement on those grounds.
I would simply like to bring
to point out that the standard
view of fraternities, at least in
one case, is very far off base.
Yes, we at Alpha Chi
Rho do party. I won't try to
justify that in saying that we
are providing some great so
cial outlet for the campus, or
any other b.s. line commonly
recited. In regards to parties,
I will simply say that in most
u
_£,
a_;
I
tc
vi _oi
al
c j
a i
r_{
I

cases, they are simply a lot of
fun. I would like to turn the
attention, to the fact that we at
Alpha Chi Rho do, in fact,
more than just party. Since I
have been a brother in this fra
ternity I have seer, the most
dynamic and upward moving
organization I have ever been
a part of. Certainly, we have
our routine philanthropy
events each year, with our char
lty volleyball tournament
(which last spring raised almost
$1500 for a one day event) be
ing the most prominent. We

participate from time to time
in those events organized by
others; helping with toy drives,
spending time with underprivi
leged children and many other
worthwhile ventures. These,
however, are few and far be
tween. What I would most like
to draw attention to is the fact
that this fraternity organizes
and runs one of the biggest
ongoing philanthropy projects
on campus. Every Saturday
(and recently we have begun
going on Friday afternoons as
well) my Brothers and I travel
the 50-or-so miles to

Sandtown, a community in in
ner city Baltimore. Every week,
we spend numerous hours
working on the renovation of
a row house located at 1506
Mount Street, working in con
junction with Habitat for Hu
manity. This is not simply a
chapter project, either. Al
though still struggling some,
our initiative has started a na
tionwide project for all broth
ers of Alpha Chi Rho, combin
ing fundraising efforts with in
dividual participation in order
to help rebuild this once-thnv
mg community. In addition to
just working, we have at
tempted to join ourselves into
the community, making friends
with local youths (especially a
young boy named Marcus) and
spending almost as much time
with them as with our work on
the physical structure of the
house. The generalization
about fraternities being noth¬

ing more than a negative influ
ence and a drinking club are
not at all true. (We often find
ourselves having a much better
time in Sandtown than we do
at a party.)
Now I would like to ad
dress the generalization that
"Greek society is not composed
of individuals as much as herds"
and that "people who used to
think on their own now resign
themselves to accepting the
views of the group." My re
sponse to these statements is
simply that in the experiences
I have had, this couldn't be fur
ther from the truth. Some of
my best friends in the entire
world are here at AXP, and
these are the people that are
polar opposites to my view
point. We never agree on any¬

thing, debate and argue con
stantly, and I love them dearly
for it. On more than one oc
casion, I've found myself
locked in struggles over the
existence of God or the nu
ances of Buddhism, as well as
discussions of every topic from
chemistry to rush. Through it
all, rather than conforming to
any particular viewpoint, I've
found myself strengthened in
my own convictions, and have
been encouraged to do so. Be
ing a member of Alpha Chi Rho
has allowed me to pursue a per
sonal passion for philanthropic
endeavors and shown me the
value of many points of view
that I had previously dismissed,
while all the while allowing me
to cling to my own individual
views and beliefs.

I hope that these ex
amples have opened eyes to the
fact that, whether we here at
AXP are an exception or not,
generalizations about Greek
life do not always hold true.
Thank you very much for tak
ing the time to read my re
sponse.
Sincerely,
Ryan Ridenour

Consider this

On Monday, Tuesday ,
and Wednesday of this week,
students were presented with
the opportunity to help deter
mine the future of student life
on this campus.
Elections for the Student
Senate executive board were
held in the CUB from 11 to 1.
But due to the fact that none of
the three candidates received
more than fifty percent of the
votes, a special election will be
held next week to determine
the office of Student Senate
President.
In the past three days,
only about 400 out of over
2,000 eligible student voters
turned out to support their
choices for the leadership posi
tions. That means only one
fifth of the student population
opted to participate in the se
lection of these powerful.
Who really cares about
apathy anyway? How does
apathy affect me? Does apathy
even matter? Perhaps the issue
of student apathy has been
beaten to death.
Some students might
question the effectiveness of
our student government. This,
however, should not be a rea
son not to vote, but rather, the
primary reason to cast a ballot.
The run-off election held
for the presidency should be
looked upon as a second chance
for the campus, a chance to

show that we care about the fu
ture of social and academic life
at this college.
Students constantly
whine for more social events,
for non-Greek activities, and
for more culture. Well, what
does the Senate do? Does any
body care? By the voter turn
out, guess not.
The elections were widely
advertised. The everyone di
gest has been flooded with
"vote for me" messages for sev
eral days now; bulletin boards,
walls, and doors around cam
pus are flapping with signs.
Could it have been the glut of
political advertisements actu
ally discouraged students from
voting? Was it due to the fact
that people don't happen to be
in the CUB between the hours
of Hand 1?
These are all possible ex
planations for the lack of stu
dent support for the election,
but they are not excuses. Does
this imply that over 1600 of the
students on this campus could
not find time in their days to
go to the CUB and circle four
names on a piece of paper?
How many of these non-voters
can be heard complaining about
something on this campus?
Perhaps it is time for ac
tion. Perhaps if they ignore
them, the problems will go
away. Yeah....and perhaps tu
ition will go down next year.

Editor-in-Chief Sara Sprenkle

Conflict and Coh$eh$us
To the Editor: TotheEditor:

Sisters unite
"Our strength is in know
ing that each one of us could
stand alone, but we choose to
stand together."
On behalf of the Greek
women at Gettysburg, we
wanted to write a letter ex
pressing the benefits of soror
ity life. We are proud of our
affiliation and more than will
ing to tell everyone why we feel
this way.
Not only are sorority
women leaders in our GreeK
organizations, but we hold
many executive offices
throughout other organizations
as well. We are all active par¬

ticipants in shaping the lives of
students at Gettysburg College.
In addition to that, we support
many campus functions both in
numbers and with monetary
contributions. As a community
of Greek women, we agreed
not to sponsor any events that
conflicted with the Snowball
and encouraged our members
to attend. The Panhellenic
Council (which is the unifying
and governing body of all five
sororities on campus) gave
$500 to help support the all
campus event. The 400 plus
women that are part of the
Greek system bring a tremen
dous amount to Gettysburg.

Sororities are social orga
nizations, but we are also much
more. Academic success is held
at a high value. Women can
not rush if they have below a
2.2 GPA. Many organizations
have even higher standards
once you become a sister. Phi
lanthropy is also a valued en
tity. Whether the event is An
chor Splash (Delta Gamma),
Turkey Trot (Chi Omega), a
Softball Tournament (Gamma
Phi Beta), a Dance-a-thon (Al
pha Delta Pi), or a Pancake
Breakfast (Alpha Xi Delta),
women of ALL organizations
work together to raise con
sciousness and financial sup
port for those less fortunate
than we are here at Gettysburg.
We are, however, differ¬

ent from other campus organi
zations. What makes us unique
is our ritual. Every Tuesday
night, we reaffirm the fraternal
values that we were all founded
on. They are the basis and
guidelines for every meeting.
Every sorority and even the
Panheilenic Council has an
open creed that states each
group's purpose and values.
Some creeds are repeated as
part of ritual, while others are
recognized in different ways.
The sorority pins we all wear

each Tuesday are a symbol of
our affiliation and the design
is an extension of our ritual.
Pins are meant to be a daily re
minder of our foundation.
Being Greek has made us
all more self-confident. We are
not afraid to voice our opinions
in a room of 85 people. The
results include teamwork, com
promise, and respect for oth
ers. Running meetings with all
these women has challenged
our leadership skills to a higher
level than

we thought possible. We
value our differences and sup
port each of our sisters not only
within our organization but the
others as well. We collectively
agree that joining a sorority was
one of the best individual deci
sions we have made in college.
We can only hope that our
pride in being Greek will ex
emplify the reasons why we
decided to make the commit
ment to Greek Life, not only
during college, but also for a
lifetime. In Sisterhood and
Panhellenic Spirit,
Becca O'Connell,
Panhellenic President
Claire Christman, Chi
Omega President
Allison Englen, Alpha Xi
Delta President
Michelle Vojtush, Delta
Gamma President
Kristy Anderson, Alpha
Delta Pi President
Shallon Nadeau, Gamma
Phi Beta President

Greeks and independents, equal impact

As a member of a slave
producing, cattle herd forming,
alcoholic inducing, party cen
tralized organization, I obvi
ously would be completely in
clined to agree with the article
entitled "Greek Problems."
Our mind numbing, commu
nistic policies and beer guzzling
impulses have left us stupid and
without independence or indi
viduality. Furthermore, it is
downright unfortunate and
completely horrendous that
organizations like the Greek
system exist. This campus and
the world in general would be
much better off without
Greeks.
Is this really what is be
ing said about over half the
people of our campus? It sure
seems like it. Anyway, let's
examinet arguments.

First, is the argument that
Greek organizations subtract
from participation and mem
bership in other clubs and ex
tracurricular activities. Yes,
pledging does take up a great
deal of time, but the first thing
that one often fails to under
stand is that joining a Greek
organization is a life long com
mitment which effects where
you will be living, who you will
be living with, and in general,
the people who will become
your closest friends for the next
few years. Oh I'm sorry, I for
got, we brainwash our pledges

so that they have absolutely no
free will and no ability to
choose who they associate with
or what activities they choose
to do for the rest of their col
lege career. Come on, please
tell me that e some research
actually went into this. Real
ize that many of us choose to
be Greeks for the same reasons
any other person joins a politi
cal party or a different social
organization. Each of us feels
strongly about the ideals of the
chapter, and we enjoy the com
pany of the people within it.
How horrible is this?

I, and about 50% of this
campus, chose to become
Greeks, and we each deal with

the consequences of that
choice. The article praises those
who rebel against the status
quo? Which would be the
more productive choice? Is it
better to quit a system that you
willingly became a member of
and do nothing but complain
about its existence, or is it bet
ter to remain in the system and
work on improving upon its
faults? Of course I have my
problems with being Greek, I
doubt you can find one Greek
who feels the system is with
out flaw. Some of us though
work to improve upon it in
stead of quitting.
The article holds us (the
Greeks) responsible for the
same standards as other clubs
and states that we can't take
credit for any participation in
any activity we did not orga
nize. Hence, if you take away

everything that a fraternity or
sorority does or is involved in,
all that we have left is drinking
and partying. Think about the
intelligence of that last state
ment. It is analogous to the
statement that if I take away the
skin, muscle and bone from a
human body, all I have left is
the fluids within it and I refer
to this as "human." If you are
going to judge the Greek sys
tem, judge us on everything we
do, not simply that which you
consider in poor taste. Just
because you have seen Animal
House and PCU does not mean
you can judge the Gettysburg

Greek system by those stan
dards. Second, the herd atmo
sphere which the column
claims affects the Greeks so
soon after rush is over is obvi
ously true. You will not get me
to he and say that Greeks don't
travel in packs. Okay now tell
me what's wrong with this?
J ust because I choose to go to
Servo with a group of friends,
or go to the bar with my broth
ers does not mean that some
where along the line I, or any
of them have lost the capacity
for free thought. You see
though, the point of joining an
organization like a fraternity is

to understand the concepts of
cooperation and sacrifice. Each
of us functions for the good of
the whole, but do so without a
loss of morality or belief. To
make a hasty and sweeping
generalization that the herd at
titude robs one of self is com
pletely groundless. It isn't only
the voices of the independents
which "make the difference."
I was raised to believe that any
one can make a difference as
long as they keep an open mind
and give 110% to whatever

their cause might be. The ar
ticle states that the Greeks are
a negative influence. I feel they
are a necessary and useful so
cial outlet and provide a fam
ily environment to those who
choose to open their eyes and
minds to the possibilities for
personal growth. As an indi
vidual, Greek, stubborn, and
hardheaded human being I can
make just as much of a differ
ence as someone with all these
wonderful characteristics, yet is
not Greek.

In closing, please realize
the absurdity of both of our
articles because neither one is
going to make one iota of dif
ference in the lives of our read
ers. You see, maybe half of the
campus community will read
both of the pieces. Maybe a
portion of the faculty and ad
ministration will likewise pick
up a copy. And maybe a few
parents will even take some of
their time to page through, but
what I have said before and will
reiterate is simply act rather
than speak. Words and articles
are a waste of our time. For
example I have just spent the
past hour writing this rebuttal
when I could have been doing
something else which could
have affected me positively. To
change the status quo requires
demonstrable action, not ink
on a page. The pen is not
mightier than the sword and in
reality is perhaps only equal to

it. Respectfully submitted,
With hope for the future,
Joshua D. Hirsch


To the 'burg or not to the 'burg

Conflict and Comensu

by Christina Dickert
Columnist A few days ago, I was re
minded of a conversation I had
when I was home over break.
A senior from my high school
asked me how I had come to
choose Gettysburg as the place
I wanted to be for the four most
important years of my educa
tion. I was speechless. I really
never looked back to my col
lege application process, which
started about two years ago.
(Two years ago!! Geez, I'm
feeling really old.) Sorry to say
but I gave some corny answer
like, "It just grabbed me as the
place I wanted to go." That
was an absolute lie, and it both
ered me for the rest of the day.
Finally, as I laid in bed that
night trying to fight my guilty
conscience, I racked my brains
for the real answer to that ques
tion. I am so embarrassed to

admit this, but the reason why
I had chosen Gettysburg as one
of my top ten choices the spring
of my junior year was because
I really liked the pictures in the
brochure. C'mon, you know
they are nice- fall in central
Pennsylvania, a group of
friends (culturally diverse, of
course) sitting on the steps of
Musselman Library. This, for a
sixteen year old, is appealing.
Hey, it also had a political sci
ence department. I thought
that might come in handy, since
I believed that is what I wanted
my major to be.
So, in the fall, when the
Gettysburg representative came
to visit my quaint Catholic high
school, I was one of two people
interested in coming to Gettys
burg. Or at least 1 thought I
was interested. The meeting
was during seventh period,
which just happened to be the
exact same time that I had

physics. I learned a bit more
about Gettysburg, was per
suaded to come visit the cam
pus, and went to my AP English
class ten minutes late. It was a
good deal.
My interview and visit
were a complete disaster. I
wore black Adidas sneakers to
the Admissions office. My
mom could have killed me, but
Gettysburg was my fourth
choice. American University is
where I belonged- big city, no
cows, famous lawmakers, and,
the best part, five hours away
from home. I really didn't care
if I was accepted here. The tour
was even worse. I had picked
Reading Days for the perfect
weekend to visit. Even more,
it was a Saturday morning. The
campus was completely and
totally empty. Our tour guide
was at least seven feet tall, and,
considering that my mother
and I are five feet tall, we felt

like we were running a mara
thon. Let's just say that Get
tysburg did not make the im
pression on me that I was hop
ing to get.
Things didn't turn out the
way I had planned. I was ac
cepted at American, too, but
Gettysburg offered me more
financial aid. I tried getting
excited about coming here, but
I felt so cheated. Just because
money controlled where I
wanted to go, I was stuck liv
ing in this godforsaken farm
land for the next four years. I
used the same line, over and
over again to my mother, when
1 was trying to convince her to
let me transfer to Lehigh
(which is strategically placed in
my hometown) this fall when I
was homesick. I never wanted
to come here, I'd say. I felt as
though I had made no big de
cision- the financial aid had
made the choice for me.

Almost four months after
that homesick period, I find
myself running into a campus
tour every Monday and
Wednesday as I walk out of
work. As I leave the White
House, I see the perspective
first-year student with his or
her parents, walking with one
of our own peers. Walking
across the grass, I feel their cu
rious eyes follow me across the
empty campus, imagining
where I am going and what
exciting class I am heading for.
I feel like walking up to them
and telling them the answer
that I couldn't give that senior
over break. I want to tell them
that no matter where you end
up in the fall, whether it is your
first choice or your absolute last
choice, you'll end up loving it,
and, like me, who is not look
ing forward to going home
over Spring Break, you will
never want to leave it.

what molecules are like inside, and
how they respond to external distur

Math Colloquium 212 Glatfelter
SPRING COLLOQUIUM SERIES -
Gettysburg College, Department of
Mathematics and Computer Science
Dr. Paul Tymann, Rochester Institute
of Technology, "Java Remote
Method Invocation"
Remote method invocation (RMI)
provides a framework for developing
distributed object systems using Java.
Using RMI, it is possible to create
Java objects whose methods can be
invoked by objects residing on
different hosts. Object serialization,
introduced in the 1.1 release of the
JDK, provides a means by which
objects can be converted to and from
a stream of bytes. Serialization makes
it possible for applications to send
full objects across a network. This
feature is utilized by RMI to provide
support for passing full objects as
parameters or return values. This talk
introduces Java RMI. It begins with
an _overview of RMI and is followed
by a simple example. Additional
examples illustrate how objects can
be passed between programs running
on different hosts.

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office For more information,
contact any of the following
persons Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext 8159, TJ
Scott (Allies secretary/treasurer),
Ext 7596; Alec Beekmans, Ext
7071, Helen DeVinney, Ext. 7807,
Faculty Nancy Cushing-Danieis,
Ext 6858, Debbie Fiedler, Ext
6187, Don Hinrichs, Ext. 6192,
Administrators - Anne Bucher
Lane, Ext 6579; Bill Gohl, Ext.

The Health Hotline, provides
non-emergency medical advice on
Saturdays from 10 am to 2 pm.
You can page a nurse practitioner
at 338-5283, enter the phone
number where you can be reached,
and the nurse practitioner will call
you back. You will be advised on
self care, emergency room care,
physician consultation or health
service follow-up. OF COURSE,
IN AN EMERGENCY CALL
6911 OR 911 IMMEDIATELY! I
F. Kinsella
Needle Disposal - Anyone who
has the need of self- administering
medication by needle injection, we
ask that you collect your used
syringes and needles in a sharps
container You may bring the full
container to the Health Service for
disposal If you do not have a
puncture proof sharps container,
you may pick one up at Health
Services at no charge Let's keep
our community safe. F. Kinsella

Cupid had his turn, now bring on. St. Patrick

by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
So your Valentine's Day
did not pan out. Your girl
bought you all kinds of lovey
dovey crap like candy and
chocolate. All you wanted
was a big fat bowl of chicken
wings, an ice cold beer, and
the remote to the television.
Well, guess what? St. Patty's
Day is here; so if V-day was a
wash out, the next major holi
day is almost here and it is all
about guys.
Yeah, no more stupid
cherubs shooting people with
arrows. Just plain fun. Just
settle into your lazy boy, with
all of your buddies and just,
you know, consume, It's
probably the best holiday of
the year, and to add to it, the
Phillies Spring training camp
will be opening so we can see
all the nobodies and the

never-will-be's that reside on the
"Spring Training" invite list.

Pete Casares and Janel Pfeifer led their respective swim teams to yet another Conference Title

By Chesha Miller
Player Profiler
Seventeen years ago,
when they were both five years
old, seniors Pete Casares and
Janel Pfeifer began their swim
ming careers. The pair, who
were to become future Gettys
burg College swim team cap
tains, started racing during
their summers for country club
swim teams.
When Janel was eight,
she began competing all year
round, while Pete waited until
the " seventh grade for year
round competitions. Pfeifer
and Casares have both left their
mark in Gettysburg's pool.
Pfeifer is an extremely

well versed swimmer. "Janel is
probably the most versatile ath
lete we've ever had," explained
Gettysburg head swim coach
Mike Rawleigh. "She's tough
and a very good competitor
who is willing to swim any
event that will help the team."
Janel has had the oppor
tunity to do just that, swim
ming the 200 yard , 500 yard
and 1000 yard freestyle, 200
yard butterfly, 200 yard back
stroke and the 400 yard Indi
vidual Medley. Pfeifer, who is
considered a distance swimmer,
has also competed in the long

mile. During the Centennial

thebackstrokc.

something 1 was always good
at." One of Pfeifer's fondest

swam the butterfly. Poignantly,
this past weekend at the Cen

Swimmers steal show at conference meet

The women's and men's
swim team continued their
winning streak, beating Wash
ington College last Saturday.
The final score was 142 - 63
for the women, and 147 - 53
for the men.
For the women, Liz
Burzio, Missy West, Kelly
Brennan, and Nicole
Hammerstrom won the 400
yard medley relay. West also
won the 200-yard breaststroke
while Brennan finished first in
the 200-yard butterfly. In the
200-yard freestyle, senior co-

Predicting the future

Commission reveals findings

by Rebecca Babbitt
Staff Reporter The Commission on the Future of Gettysburg College
met Saturday afternoon to present the preliminary findings of
their year-long examination of the College's academic and co
curricular programs. The final presentation will be made on
Monday and reviewed by the Board of Trustees at their next
two meetings in May and September.
The Commission, a group of 367 alumni, parents and
friends of the college, volunteered one year ago to examine
and plan for the future of the College. They formed nine task
forces to study:
Culture and the Arts
Collaborative Learning and Teamwork
Economics and Management
Enhancing Residential Life
Excellence in the Sciences and Psychology
Information Technology
Public Affairs and Public Service
Student Recruitment and Retention
Supporting Student Success
Together they proposed 186 recommendations plus sub
- points to be considered by the Board of Trustees.
*_L The major themes of the recommendations were presented
over the weekend. These themes included active teaching and
learning, creating a vibrant campus climate, working on global
I outreach, recruiting a diverse community, creating distinctive
programs, and improving technology and facilities. More pre
cise goals were presented in a formal report issued on Monday.
I President of the College, Gordon Haaland said the Com
mission presented "a truly impressive effort." Paul Odell,
I Chairman of the Board of Trustees told the 170 assembled
I members of the Commission "you've done a first class job."
I "I had high expectations, but they exceeded them," said
B President of the Commission, Jim Brenemann. "This will have
I a greater impact than anything else I've been involved in with
the College."
H Some of the recommendations included student-designed
_II social activities and establishing a Center for Leadership and
U Public Affairs. Formal recommendations call for 32 new or

Redding wins presidency

Zalewski
by Laura Root
Staff Reporter After two different elec
tions, it has been decided that
Earl Redding will be the Student
Senate president for the 1998
1999 school year.
Last Monday, a runoff
election for the presidency was
held between Redding and Sara
Zalewski.
According to the Student
Senate Constitution, a person
running for an executive office
must capture fifty percent of all
student votes.
None of the three candi
dates for the position, John
Dunlap, Earl Redding, nor Sara
Zalewski could do so. A runoff
election was then held between
the top two vote-getters,
Redding and Zalewski.

Although there has not
been a runoff election in several
years, both Redding and
Zalewski thought that there

defeated in special ru
might be one this year.
"Having three candidates
for president splits the votes,"
said Redding.
Zalewski commented that,
"This year's Vice President, Val
Katzmar, who is in charge of
elections made sure that every
thing followed the Senate Con
stitution."
During the extra days of
campaigning that the candidates
received, both Redding and
Zalewski kept working hard to
_increase the amount of enthusi
asm on campus for elections.
Zalewski replaced signs,
wrote messages on the sidewalks,
and emailed to publicize the
event. Redding spoke up about
the elections and encouraged as
many people as he could to par
ticipate.
The candidates were not
happy with this extra election.
Zalewski thinks that it placed too
much pressure on both candi-

noff election
dates. "It's just four more days
of stress," she said.
One of Redding's goals
while in office is to reform the
Senate constitution. He hopes
to change the election process
and get nd of the runoff policy.
"Congratulations to all
other executive position holders
and thanks to everyone who sup
ported me. We have some big
shoes to fill," he concluded.
Redding replaces sitting
president Abby Rodgers who
graduates this spring.

Wednesday, March 18, at 7:30

College's Japanese Studies pro

of charge and will be followed

"The Only Woman in the
Room" is a personal and vivid
account of Gordon's life in
Europe, prewar Japan, and the

United States. As the daughter
of a renowned Russian pianist
Leo Sirota, Beate Gordon grew
up in the cosmopolitan world
of the concert tour, and settled
in Japan in the 1930's.
During World War II, her
parents remained in Tokyo,
while Gordon lived in the
United States, attending Mills
College and monitoring Tokyo
Radio in five languages for the
government.
Gordon later returned to
Tokyo to work in General
MacArthur's headquarters,
where she singledhandedly for
mulated the clause guarantee
ing equal rights for women in
Japan's new constitution.
On returning to the
United States in 1947, Gordon
became a cultural advocate,
responsible for bringing artists,
writers, musicians, and dancers
from all over Asia to the United
States. In recognition of her
cross-cultural achievement, she

end here," said Brenemann.
The theme of the Com
mission now is, "There can be

Future
Gettysburg College." The Col
lege hopes the Commission
will continue to play an active
role in their strategic Planning
and that others will volunteer.

its recommendations are part

ward in its strategic planning
process," said Brenemann

tions neglected History, Writing
and Civil War Studies.

the issues currently plaguing the
College. Although there has
been some student protest
about the tenure process, and

crimination in tenure last se
mester, the Commission did not
deal with tenure as a separate
issue. They examined the "im
portant roles for faculty in ad¬

ing," said Brenneman and
looked for ways to recognize
and reward professors.

dealt with as a piece of larger
areas, mainly "residential life
and social opportunities," said
Brenemann.
Although the Commis

debate among students for over

Commission.

completion of the Commission
on the Future of Gettysburg
College will help the Board of
Trustees develop a clear action
plan for review and eventual
implementation for the benefit
of our current and future stu
dents, especially in relation to
programs curriculum and fos
tering of an active and dynamic
learning environment," said
Haaland.
