Library BULLETin

by Libby Musseltnan
Library Columnist
Q: If I send for something
on Interlibrary Loan, am I
likely to get in it time to write
my paper?
A: It depends on when
you ask and when your paper
is due. Most book loans and
photocopies come in within a
week of request and can be
kept for three to four weeks
(photocopies, of course, are
yours forever). The catch is
that lending libraries are not
required to fill our requests.
So if your request is un
usual (like a thesis or an ob
scure journal), then we might
have to send off to a number
of schools before someone is
able to provide it, or the re
quest might not be filled at all.
Q: I have 100 things I
need on Interlibrary Loan. The
librarian told me that was too
many to ask for. Why?

When placing an interli
brary loan request, ask yourself
how much time you'll have to
read and analyze 100 articles
or books. When is the paper
due? What is a more reason
able number to read in the time
you have? Can you put your
requests in some priority—for
instance, which articles look
the best, which are longest and

might have the most details, do
they come from reputable
sources, etc.? Have you
checked with one of the refer
ence librarians to see what we
may actually own on your
topic? It is easy to fall into the
trap of taking the first 100
items that come up on a search
and ordering them all.
If you start with some
questions, you might find it is
more fruitful to pare down
your list. I mean, GET REAL
Nobody can read 100 items
and process all that informa
tion in a short time. In addi
tion, the average interlibrary
loan costs $30. We don't pass
those charges on to you, but
that's $30 that we don't spend
on something else in the library
Interlibrary loans are really
meant to supplement materials
we have right on hand.

Libbv's Tip of the Week:
Check the new feature on the
library homepage. Under
"What's New" access "New
Books." It will give a listing of
all the new books (and provide
a link to new videos) that have
come to the library in the last
week. Please send more of your
comments, questions, and/or
complaints to
lmussel @gettysburg. edu



CONFLICT & Consensus

1
I'll say it out
loud, Vma cynic
and proud

by Christina Dickert
Columnist Spring break is a time to
rest and reflect on the begin
ning of the new semester. My
first half turned out pretty
well, but something that a few
of my professors said to me
stuck out in my memory.
They accused me of being
cynical.
That got me to thinking
about that. Am I really all that
cynical? Do I really question
people's sincerity because I
constantly search for an ulte
rior motive behind their
words and actions?
Nah, it couldn't be true.
After seeing As Good As It
Gets, I knew that I wasn't that
neurotic. What do my pro
fessors know? They met me
in the middle of January and
by February, they are making
these assumptions about me.
I don't think so.

Well, I went straight to
the one person I knew would
be able to answer this ques
tion, the one person who has
known me all of my life— my
mother.
After all, she's my mom.
Moms aren't supposed to
have anything bad to say
about their children. I knew
she would give me the truth,
which is exactly what I
wanted to hear.
Well, maybe I shouldn't
have spoken with my mom.
Maybe she wasn't a good
source. I mean, she's just my
mom. She doesn't know what
I am thinking.
And to make matters
worse, she laid a mom-style
guilt trip on me— I don't
know what happened, but
you turned out to be one of

the most cynical people I know.
I didn't raise you that way. Wow
I love you too, Mom.
So, if she didn't raise me
that way, why am I so cynical?
Who made me this way? I
thought back to my childhood.
Did my twelve years of Catholic
education- socialize me to be
cynical of the world I live in? I
didn't remember any hidden
messages in my theology books
or any subliminal messages in the
hymns at Mass.
Then, I started thinking
that cynicism is biological.
Maybe cynics like me have a
chemical imbalance in our
brains that some yet-to-be-dis
covered medicine can cure and
let us lead optimistic, the-glass
ls-half-full lives. Then again,
maybe not.
Maybe it is the world
around me. With all the racism,
sexism, and basic hate in this
world, it is a wonder that every
one isn't a cynic.

It is difficult to recognize
who is sincere and who is not.
It's not me who is crazy; it's the
rest of the world.
People can get killed for
believing in the wrong God, be
ing a different race, or for sim
ply wearing the wrong color T
shirt down the street. Most of
the world's leaders have the abil
ity to end the world with the
press of a button.
So, is there really some
thing wrong with me or is there
something wrong with the world
that makes me question every
thing? After analyzing my deep
soul-searching, I don't think that
there is anything wrong with be
ing cynical. So, until this world
can (and does) change, I am just
going to have to be satisfied be
ing a cynical realist.

From the Donkey's Mouth
Shopping for president

by Libby Main
Political Columnist
Buying a swimsuit is a
chched traumatic experience.
Yanking on at least a dozen suits
in a 3x5 foot cubicle to find one
with the perfect size, cut, pat
tern, color, and label can seem
like the most exasperating of all
experiences. Is there anything
that compares to this frustrat
ing decision-making process?
Selecting the best presidential
candidate for the year 2000 is
going to be similarly over
whelming. Although few poli
ticians have officially declared
themselves in the race, there
are a few names that stand out
like the suits featured on de
partment store mannequins
and wall displays. Let's try few
of them on.

Texas Governor George
W Bush, son of former U.S.
President George H.W. Bush,
was polled as the candidate
most likely to win the Repub
lican nomination at the recent
Southern Republican Leader
ship Conference. Bush has
name recognition, a big state,
and personal connections to
wealthy donors on his side i
His weaknesses are a shoiJ
temper and a sharp tongue. /_J
40 he gave up drinking to try
to mitigate these shortcomings.
In terms of bathing suits, Bush
would be a suit with a quality
name but poor construction, a
DKNY that wears out in the
backside after sitting on the
edge of the pool a few times.

Another man of famous
paternity, Steve Forbes, also
seems eager to grab the Repub
lican nomination. Yet, this flat
tax obsessed millionaire is a
one issue candidate and a com
plete political outsider. Forbes
is like a John Paul Gautier suit
made out of an outlandish fab
ric that isn't functional or prac
tical.

A bathing suit in black
and red plaid flannel fabric
would be the signature of
Lamar Alexander, who often
wore a shirt of that print while
campaigning in 1996. This
former Tennessee Governor
and State Education Secretary
would be a grandmotherly cut
suit with a skirt because he
wants to hide his bulging
tummy—great personal wealth
he amassed through govern
ment connections.
Two rather lightweight
candidates, Jack
Kemp and

Dan Quayle is know for stupid
statements and his inability to
spell potato. Thus, he would be
a suit with a built in bust be
cause what he really needs are
intellectual push-up pads.
The Southern Republican

Leadership Conference en
dorsed Oklahoma Congress
man J.C. Watts as its top Vice
Presidential candidate. Watts,
who was elected in 1994,
preaches regularly and es
pouses family values. A convert
from the Democratic Party in
the early eighties, he is the
only African American
Republican in Con
gress. The Repub
licans would
put Watts . a

on the ticket for the
people who would buy a bikini
just for the sake of buying a bi
kini if you catch my drift.
Across the isle in the
Democratic section of

choices, however the candi

some people want a

on everyone.
House of Representatives
Minority Leader Richard
Gephardt has championed the
issues of healthcare, trade and
tax fairness since his freshman
year in Congress. Know as a
combination of a fiery populist
and a back-room pragmatist,
Gephardt has shifted his views
on abortion and gay rights to

the left in recent years. In light
of this newer, more hip image
a halter top swimsuit with
spandex short bottoms would
fit him well.
Champion of govern
ment-funded health care, en
titlements and Social Security,
Nebraska Senator Bob Kerrey
is considering a second presi

eran and chair of the

thong which exposes more

Just as new swimsuit
styles are sometimes released
late in the season, more candi
dates may prove to be impor
tant contenders in the presiden
tial race of 2000. Reviewing
the candidates early and learn
ing as much as you can about
them helps make sure you
make the best choice. Nobody
wants to take a swimsuit home
and discover that the front gaps
when you sit down. Thus,
bending over and taking a look
at the candidates from every
angle prevents you from regret
ting your decision at the ballot

This article was my at
tempt to write about politics in
a more lighthearted way in the
hopes that it will be read by a
more diverse and larger audi
ence. Becoming politically in
formed is neither painful or
tedious. Internet resources can
be helpful, as can contempo
rary magazines such as George
; useful information is not lim
ited to C-SPAN and The New
York Times. As college stu
dents, we should all try our best
to know what is happening in
Washington—it affects all
Americans.



CONFLICT & Consensus

by Earl Redding and Erin
Patterson Public Relation Chairs oflFC
and Panhel
Congratulations to all
new members of the 11 fra
ternities and five sororities on
campus! Pledging is finally
over and now we can all get
some rest and focus on the
end of the school year. For
now, the Interfraternity
Council (IFC) is very busy.
This Saturday over four
fraternities will be engaged in
a philanthropy at a homeless
shelter on North Stratton
Street. We will be helping to
renovate a house for a fam
ily. This is the first of four
philanthropic events this se
mester for IFC. We hope to
have great participation and
fun. Sigma Alpha Epsilon
and Gamma Phi Beta coop
erated in holding the second
annual Singled Out event this
past Wednesday which, like

last year, was a great time for
all. Get psyched again be
cause Greek Week is coming
this semester. More details will
follow in other editions of the
"Greek Word" detailing the
events planned.
This year's Greek Week
chairs, Thomas Sansone and
Erika Beernik_, would like to
take the opportunity to inform
everyone as to why Greek
Week will be held in the Spring
this year.
"Many of you are prob
ably wondering why Greek
Week is in the Spring or you
might have no idea what is go
ing on. Well, the answer can
be simplified to one word -
participation. In the past,
Greek Week was a thriving
event, one that people looked
forward to."
"However, last semester
it was difficult to get someone
to come to an event as it is get
ting someone to the dentist.
Greek Week is meant to be a

time to show how proud you
are to be a member of the
Greek Community. It gives
everyone a chance to bond with
their fraternity and sorority.
There is even the element of the
good, healthy competition be
tween organizations. The in
creased numbers in all of the
fraternities ad sororities will
hopefully increase participa
tion." "Since the nice weather
usually increases morale on
campus, we hope that more
people will come outside and
have fun at all of the events that
are planned. Without the in
creased support of every orga
nization, Greek Week will not
be as enjoyable and successful
as it has the ability to be."

One final note to the
campus community: the all
sorority GPA was higher than
any other campus
organization's GPA, as well as
higher than the all campus
GPA. Looks like partying is not
the prime object of our organi
zations.


Consider this

Emailing a bomb threat
to get out of class? Is this the
latest method of procrastina
tion, or has there been a no
table shift in the ethical values
of students?
Though it has not been
proven that the threat came
from a student, it cannot be
ignored that there has been a
marked increase in the amount
and nature of the crimes on
campus.
Just look at the crime
stats for this semester...in ad
dition to the inevitable liquor
law violations, there have been
numerous reports of criminal
activities in the form of van
dalism, break-ins, theft, voy
eurism, and suspicious activity.
Though unpleasant for the vic
tims, these incidents have been
somewhat isolated: most stu
dents were probably informed
only by reading about them in
the newspaper.

Wednesday's bomb scare
threatened the entire campus,
but was anyone truly fright
ened? It seemed that students
cared more that class was can
celed than that one of the most
beautiful, historically rich, and
widely used buildings on cam
pus could have been destroyed,
not to mention the fact that
they themselves and other
buildings could have been

damaged.
Maybe it is a natural hu
man response to try to laugh
in the face of danger (there are
what, 800 psychology majors
on campus--any thoughts?
Anyone? Anyone? Bueller?),
but even though it may have
been a joke, it is quite illustra
tive of the "not me" syndrome
that is becoming more and
more prevalent in society to
day, especially on this campus.
We must be pretty lucky
to live in a place where a bomb
threat is not even remotely
frightening. Some people,
even in this country, face the
real threat of danger every day
of their lives.
It is doubtful that many
individuals on campus paused
during their unexpected hours
of freedom to consider the fact
that the lives of numerous
people could have been endan
gered had there actually been
a bomb.

What does it say about
this campus that people care
more about having an extra
hour of spare time than the loss
of an integral part of Gettys
burg College's heritage?
Wednesday was a sad day
for Gettysburg College. The
reaction of the campus was a
poor reflection on the way we
live flnH think.

As the parent of a student

at the College, I am writing to
let you know how much my

reporting of campus events and
for the opinions expressed in
its column and editorials.
We were especially im
pressed with two recent opin
ion columns which addressed
teaching at the College. One
of the columns was by regular
columnist John Dunlap and
appeared in your February 19th
issue. The column contained a
thoughtful tribute to two of
Mr. Dunlap'_s professors who
were denied tenure. The trib
ute was part of a discussion of
student input to important de
cisions on campus. The other

who was denied tenure that the

whether one agrees or disagrees

sues central to the life of the
College.
We will continue to read

Sincerely,

of our reporters. Editors should be contacted b y letter if errors
occur. Sig ned, letters to the Editor will be printed without
name(s) on a request-only basis.

Common Hour Ballroom, CU
Nathan Rutstein, "Healing Racism "
What is racism and how does it
impact us as individuals, in our
communities and in our society? In
his speeches and books, acclaimed
human rights author Nathan Rutstein
not only exposes racism's roots, it's
nature and how it affects us all, he
also offers a workable solution to a
grave social challenge that many
people believe can never be resolved.
More than just a prejudice, Rutstein
suggests that racism is a form of
prejudice that has evolved into an
obsessive psychological disorder that
deeply affects perpetrator and target
alike. Hailed as "a brutally honest
portrayal of racism that offers a
solution and does not leave us with

GENERAL INFORMATION

The Peer Tutoring Center (240
CUB) is open for free, drop-in
tutoring S-R 7-9 pm in biology,
chemistry, French, math, physics,
and Spanish. Tutoring is available
by appointment in art, astronomy,
Greek, HES, history, Japanese,
Latin, political science, study
strategies, and theater. For infor
mation, stop by the Peer Tutoring
Center (240 CUB) or email Anne
Craft at acraH@gettysburg.edu.
Email tutoring! Have a question?
Can' t get to the tutoring center?
Email tutoring may be for you!
Tutors ordinarily can respond in 24
hours. Be sure to flag your ques
tion in the subject line as email
tutoring so that the tutors will be
sure to respond quickly.

REGISTRAR OFFICE

DEADLINE DATE!
The last day to drop a course with
a grade of "W" is Monday, April 6
A student withdrawing from a
course after this date will receive a
grade of "F" regardless of his of
her standing in the course at the
time. This grade counts in the
accumulative average.
ATTENTION SENIORS:

Photo by Emily _Glatfeltei
Geared up and ready, the Bullets Lacrosse team prepares for their game'with top-ranked and perennial powerhouse, Roanoke College, before Spring Break.

Henry Fawell
Staff Writer

In the past ten days the
Gettysburg men's lacrosse team
has learned the true definition
of working overtime, as it took
five extra periods of play to
decide the outcome of the
squad's first two contests.
With their record stand
ing at 1-1, the number eight
ranked Bullets have now gained
crucial overtime experience
that could help them down the
road against high profile oppo
nents. On March 7, Gettysburg
played host to number six
ranked Roanoke College, a
team the Bullets beat in the sea
son opener one year ago.
Like Gettysburg, the Ma
roons are consistently ranked
in the top 10 and can provide
fit competition for any team in
the nation. They did just that
on Saturday by dragging the
Bullets into three overtime pe
riods before succumbing to the
Gettysburg offensive attack.

Throughout the contest,
the Bullets relied on their usual
strongpoints-fast-break open
ings, face-off play, and tough
goaltending. Sophomore Mark

while Milliman tallied three,
including the game-winner in
triple overtime which ended
the contest at 10-9.
This past Sunday the
team travelled to Lexington,
VA_, looking to knock off num
ber 11 Washington 8c Lee, their
second straight nationally
ranked opponent.
The Bullets started off
slow in the first period, but
opened the flood gates the sec
ond quarter by scoring five of
the team's seven goals.

Junior attackman Ross
Garretson spearheaded the bar
rage, weaving through the
W&L defense and dumping in
four goals.
Milliman and senior

Scott Lowery tallied a goal a
piece, as did junior middle Rob
Crowe, who also provided
tough defense and solid face
off work.
Freshman Mike Plantholt
delivered a fine defensive effort
by shutting down W&L's top
scorer throughout the second
half. But the second half
proved to be teh Bullets' down
fall, as the offense lost all mo
mentum and was held scoreless
the rest of the game.
"No one could get it in
the net the second half," said
midfielder Lee Hemming.
"Our defense played well and
we just blew it on the offensive
side." Gettysburg's problems,
however, were just beginning.
While they managed to sneak
into overtime at 7-7, critical
mistakes plagued the Bullets on
both sides of the field.

Clearing opportunities
broke down on defense and the
offense failed to regenerate the
first half's momentum. Finally,
in the second overtime period,
W&L struck one final time,
sending Gettysburg home with
an 8-7 loss.
With a number of top-

ranked teams still left on their
schedule, the Bullets can use
the overtime experience to
their advantage.
Last year, Gettysburg
went into overtime on three
separate occasions, including a
double-overtime victory over
number one ranked Salisbury
Sate. However, as junior

attackman Pat Pendergast said,
"We'd much rather win these
games quickly and decisively.
We don't need any more dra
matics."
The Bullets won deci
sively this Tuesday by pound
ing Wooster 23-2 and will look
to improve to 3-1 this Saturday
as they host Amherst.

Young Bullet batsmen showing that they are the real deal

by Ted Hartman
Staff Reporter The Bullets Baseball
team returned to Gettysburg
last Sunday from a very im
pressive week long stint in
Cocoa, Florida. Beating the
Ikes of defending Mid-Atlan
tic Conference champion
Ehzabethtown, the squad tal
lied eight wins, and lost just
three games. The Bullets _inv
proved to 9-3 on Tuesday
with a victory over Catholic
in the team's home opener.
Head Coach John
Campo credits the Bullets'
pitching for the early suc
cesses. The staff as a whole
pitched seven complete
games, appearing particu
larly prepared for this early
in the season.

SophomorePaul
Koether had two excellent
performances in Florida and
proved to be a huge asset in
relief against Catholic, while
fellow sophomore Dan
Sirpinski threw well in his
second outing. For the un
derclassmen, freshmen Pat

Jordan, Tom Boob, Drew Chiasa,
and Jeff Ellis pitched extremely
well in their first collegiate out
ings, was Jordan hurling a one
hitter. With the stretch of non
conference games coming to a
close Campo is beggining is to
narrow his pitching rotation.
Sirpinski, Boob, Jordan, Chiasa,
Ellis, and Koether are potential
starters on Campo's day-to-day
approach with his staff.
Juniors Matt DeVecchi and
Pete R-ttenhouse will primarily
throw in middle relief and should
be joined by two others once the
four-man rotation is finalized.
Gettysburg's closer is
sophomore P.J. McElroy, who
would currently be vying for a
starting position if not for a ham
pering injury. However, Campo
expects McElroy to effectively
seat opposing batsmen in finish
ing Bullet wins, as he also had
an impressive southern trip.

port from the bat of John
Woods. The Bullets' first
baseman hit an incredible .513,
smacking two home runs and
plating 13 teammates. His hit
ting prowess guaranteed the
sophomore the title of Centen
nial Conference player of the
week. The play in Cocoa al
lowed Campo to solidify his
lineup, clearing up certain
questions about the order.
The Bullets tablesetters

include Daryl Clancy as lead
off hitter and either Bill
Neston or Greg Kosc in the
two slot. While Clancy should
start all season in left, Kosc and
Neston each represent poten
tial right-fielders. As the sea
son progresses, the two play
ers will either platoon the po
sition or one will emerge as the
everyday choice.
As expected, third
baseman Kevin Grimm,
Woods, and designated hitter
Bill Beining constitute the
heart of the Bullets' order.
Second baseman Bret
Thorpe hits sixth, with either
Jack Tanner or Ken

Rittenhouse batting seventh,
depending on who is catching.

and second baseman Brett
Thorpe complete the lineup,
and provide late order speed.

Bob Dole to speak on campus

Former Presidential candidate is the recipient of the Eisenhower Prize

Photo courtesy Office of Public Relations
Bob Dole will speak in the ballroom of the CUB on April 13 at 7:30 p.m.

by Laura Root
Staff Reporter Former US Senator, Senate
Majority Leader, and 1996 presi
dential candidate Bob Dole will
provide a free lecture open to the
public on Monday, April 13, at
7:30 pm in the CUB Ballroom.
Dole is the 1995 recipient
of the Eisenhower Leadership
Prize. The award was presented
to him by Gettysburg College and
its affiliate, the Eisenhower World
Affairs Institute in Washington,

D.C. The Eisenhower Leader
ship Prize is an annual award
which publicly recognizes a leader
who is influential in national and
international affairs and honors
a person whose lifetime accom
plishments reflect Dwight D.
Eisenhower's legacy of integrity
and leadership.
Other recipients include Lt.
Gen. Brent Showcroft, Gen.
Colin Powell, former Secretary of
the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen,
former US president George
Bush, and international human
rights advocate and Nobel Prize
laureate Elie Wiesel.
It is understood that all re
cipients of the award will even
tually come and speak at
Gettysburg.

Born in Russell, Kansas,
Dole has a distinguished carreer
of public service that spans'half a
century. Serving as a platoon
leader in the Tenth Mountain Di
vision in Italy, Dole was wounded
and decorated for his service in
combat in World War II. His
decorations include two Purple
Hearts and a Bronze Star with
Oak Leaf Cluster.

"GRAB" a chance at adventure
see page 6

He has had nearly unparal
leled experience in the American
political arena.
Dole has served as a county
attorney, a state legislator, Chair
man of the Republican Party, a
member of the House of Repre
sentatives, the Republican nomi
nee for Vice President, Chairman
of the Senate Finance Committee,
Senate Majority Leader, and a
candidate for President.
Dole retired from politics in
1996 after being defeated by Bill
Clinton in the Presidential Elec¬

tion. President Ronald Reagan
has said of Dole that "his title of
Leader is not just a job title, it's a
description of the man."
Dole's effectiveness as con
sensus-builder and his commit
ment to deficit reduction and eco
nomic growth have earned him
accolades from his peers — Re
publicans, Independents, and
Democrats alike.
Dole is currently married to
Elizabeth Hanford Dole, Presi
dent of the American Red Cross.
He has one daughter, Robin.
The plans for Dole's visit
were just finalized over Spring
Break. Dole will privately meet
with a group of several hundred
specially invited students on the
afternoon of April 13. Specially
invited students will also attend a
dinner with him. The public ad
dress will be given at 7:30 that
evening.

Dole's lecture is untitled as
of yet. It is expected that he will
speak on the world of federal poli
tics and federal government with
an emphasis on leadership.
Additional information compiled
from staff reports.

Acclaimed short story writer to speak tonight

by Daniel Larkin
News _Editoi
Short story writer and
novelist Judy Bidnitz will read
from her writings tonight at the
Junction in the College Union
Building, at 8:00 p.m.
Bidnitz's debut collection
of short stories, Flying Leap,
met with much critical acclaim
when it debuted in January.
J.D. Biersdorfer, in The
New York Times Book Review,
writes: "Budnitz takes highly
imaginative leaps of faith and
logic in 23 stories about love,
despair, escape and hope. And
she doesn't look down."
Rachel Cusk of the Vil
lage Voice comments "Budnitz's
humorous and original story
ideas and the bold strokes with
which she delineates them are
the indispensable allies of her
lyric intelligence. They are
what makes Flying Leap an in
triguing and mature debut."
Newsweek says "There's

no filler and none of
those pretentious
stories about "real
life" where nothing
happens but we're
all supposed to pre
tend that something
did... Here is a col
lection that makes
good on the hype. .
. I don't know what
planet Budnitz
comes from, but I'm
happy to have her."
Kirkus Re
views calls it "Im
pressing by its au
dacity and original¬

ity ... Budnitz s j ucjy Budnitz will speak in the Junction tonight. f.i8photo
wry, conversational

tone is mcely leavened by pre
cise lyrical passages . . .
mordantl funny."
Compared with Margaret
Atwood, Paul Rudnick and
Shirely Jackson, Bidnintz tells
stories with a wide range of
topics. These include "Dog
Days," a tale of a man in a dog
suit in post-apocalyptic

America, "Got Spirit," about
cheerleaders so caught up in
school spirit that they set them
selves on fire for a football rally,
and "Guilt," a story of a son
convinced to donate his heart
to his dying mother.
Budnitz, 24, grew up in
Atlanta, and graduated magna
cum laude from Harvard. She

is now earning her Masters' de
gree from the NYU Creative
Writing Program.
In addition to her writ
ing, she is currently a cartoon
ist for the Village Voice, and has
drawn and produced an ani
mated film, "Hershel."
Budnitz's reading is spon
sored by the Writing House.



Women in black

by Libby Main
Staff Reporter On Monday, March
23, over two hundred
Gettysburg College Women
dressed in black to emphasize
the involvement of Greek
women in the campus commu
nity. Among the participants
were the former President of
Student Senate and Co-direc
tor of the Women's Center, the
Advertising Manager of the
Gettysburgian, the President of
the Art Society, the Chair of the
Student Alumni Association,
the Concert Mistress of the
College and Community Or
chestra, the Treasurer of the
College Democrats, the Vice
President of the Dance En
semble, the Secretary of Circle
K, the Choreographer and
Founder of the Indoor
Colorguard and the captains of
many sposall teams.
Greek women ac
tively participate in more than
sixty organizations on campus
including Allies, APO, Chapel
Choir, the Common Hour
Committee, the Commission
on the Future, Soccer, Softball,
Ministries at Christ Chapel,
SAC, Skeptical Chymists,
Circle K, College Choir, Col
lege Democrats, Student Ath¬

letic Trainers Club, Senate, the
Women's Center, Honor Com
mission, Field Hockey, The
Gettysburgian, Teaching Assist
ing, Temple Musicians, Tennis,
Swimming , Spanish Club,
Cheerleading, Lacrosse, Fel
lowship of Christian Athletes,
GECO, WZBT, Rugby, Volun
teers for Youth, Tae Kwon Do,
the Management Club, Big
Brothers/Big Sisters, the Volley
ball Team, the Center for Pub
lic Service, Dance Ensemble,
GRAB, Cheers, Band,

BACCHUS, Biosphere, Varsity
Basketball, Owl and Nightin
gale Players, Pet Facilitated
Therapy, Rotaract, Christian
Fellowship, MENC, Classics
Club, College Republicans,
Orchestra, Cycling Club, the
Spectrum, Aerobics Instructing,
Track, Cross Country, Hall
Government, Habitat for Hu
manity, Peer Tutoring, the Mer
cury, the Color
Guard,HandbellChoir ,Intra
mural Sports, Pre-Law Society
and the Pre-Med Society.
For many perspective
and first year students, a Greek
woman is the first Gettysburg
student they meet. This is be
cause this year, twenty-eight
Greek women have served as
Orientation Leaders, twenty
seven sorority women are cam
pus hosts, and twenty are tour

guides.
Last semester, the Greek
women's composite GPA was
3.043 while the non Greek
women's composite GPA was
2.939 and the all women's GPA
was 2.967.
The women dressed in
black to protest what they con¬

sider to be the prevailing atti
tude on campus, which is, that
Greek women are uninterested
in activities outside of their so
rorities. By doing so, Greek
women hoped to show that
they contribute a lot of time,
energy and leadership to many
aspects of Gettysburg College.

Features
Take a GRAB at outdoor opportunities

by Erin Howe
Staff Reporter "You can learn more in
one hour of play than in a
whole day of conversation." -
Plato The Gettysburg Recre
ational Adventure Board
(GRAB) provides experiential
education opportunities to the
Gettysburg College campus
community. The overall mis
sion of GRAB is to provide an
environment which fosters per
sonal development and respect
for individual differences
through adventure-based ac
tivities, such as backpacking,
rock climbing, caving, and
leadership seminars. GRAB
creates an understanding of
safety procedures for trip suc
cess and recognizes that having
fun is still one of the top pri
orities. GRAB has sponsored
more than 25 trips this year.

In the past month alone,
there have been trips to North
Carolina, West Virginia, Vir
ginia, and Maryland. During
spring break, GRAB sponsored
a 63-mile backpacking trip to
the highest peak in Virginia,
Mt. Rogers.
First year student Kate
Welton described her experi
ence on the spring break trip
as "absolutely amazing" be
cause "you have the opportu
nity to do things you would
never think you would be able
to do, and can reach beyond

your own expectations in a re
ally positive atmosphere."
While the trip to Mt.
Rogers was lead by Paul
Hutchinson, Mark Rostafin_,
and Poppy Goforth, the new
GRAB facilitators went to Cold
Mountain, North Carolina,
where they experienced freez
ing temperatures, waist-high
snow, high winds, and torren
tial downpours during the Wil
derness Institute.
The Institute is an inten
sive week-long introduction to
trip and group facilitation.
Through workshops and dis¬

cussions during the training,
staff members get firsthand ex
perience in technical skills and
leadership development. The
staff is challenged on their per
sonal vs. professional facilita
tion styles, such as understand
ing gender and diversity issues.
Additionally, through spending
so much time together in this

Photo provided by Erin Howe
Students pose before heading off on a GRAB trip. Five trips will be taken in April, providing
numerous opportunities for students to participate.

kind of setting, the staff come
to rely on each other, and on
each other's judgement.
The second half of the
week was spent at Stone Moun
tain, North Carolina, where the
staff learned about rock-site
management, anchor and
rappel systems, and vertical
rock rescue techniques. Facili
tators concluded their week
with a 4-pitch, 675 ft. climb
and rappel on the face of the
rock. The week was a great
chance to strengthen leadership
skills and build group unity.
"Through these challenging
adventures and activities, we
benefitted from each other's
strengths and weaknesses as
individuals and as a whole

group," said first year facilita
tor Becca Sargent.
GRAB was developed and
created in the spring of 1996
by John Regentin, with the sup
port of President Haaland and
Dean Ramsey, recognized the
assets of what an experiential
education program could offer
the campus community.

GRAB is composed of 26
student facilitators who have
experience in a variety of out
door areas. All facilitators re
ceive training in backcountry
skills, wilderness medicine, and
expedition ethics by Regentin,
Alan Baker, and Dr. Gary
Nussbaum, Chair of the Leisure
Services Department at
Radford University.
The facilitators are also
dedicated to two central phi
losophies, the Full Value Con
tract and Challenge by Choice,
which emphasize the necessity
to uphold safety standards and
to respect yourself and the
group. Many Gettysburg stu
dents may have been exposed
to these two teachings while
participating in ropes course

activities. Essential to the func
tion of GRAB, these philoso
phies are necessary in that they
provide a framework for the
emotional and physical safety
of all the participants of any
GRAB sponsored activity and
therefore are never subject to
compromise.
The Full Value Contract

is the component of the GRAB
philosophy that allows both
participants and staff to get the
most out of their experience
and to define and achieve their
goals. The contract is an oral
or written statement guarantee
ing individual respect in a
group setting. Its purpose is to
stimulate each member to think
about their own role in the
group and to push themselves
to their own limits, while be
ing safe in the process.
While encouragement
from the Full Value Contract
allows groups to work together
and provide productive feed
back, the Challenge by Choice
element of the GRAB program
encourages participants to "try
potentially difficult and/or

frightening challenges in an at
mosphere of support and car
ing." In other words, anyone
has opportunity to back off and
say "I'm not sure I want to try
this," and their decision will be
supported by the group.
Casey Jaykus, who re
cently went on a caving trip,
appreciated the atmosphere
created by these philosophies.
"The staff was really support
ive and I didn't feel forced to
challenge myself more than I
wanted to."
Many students are intro
duced to GRAB through AS
CENT trips offered to first year
students. According to Welton,
the ASCENT trips "allow in
coming students a chance to get
to know other people even be
fore Orientation." Led by
GRAB facilitators, the trips ad
dress issues and questions
which concern incoming stu
dents about academic and so
cial expectations at Gettysburg
College.

GRAB also offers pro
grams for the communty. They
have a partnership with a Bal
timore high school, and some
of the male staff work with an
agency to start an adolescent
male involvement program.
As for the campus, GRAB
welcomes all students, staff,
and faculty to join them, re
gardless of experience level.
First year student Kate Cosseo
explains, "Outside, you can
learn more about yourself than
you could ever imagine."
Remaining open trip
schedule for spring semester

1998: April 3-5 Women's Back
packing in the Shenandoah
National Forest, VA
April 3-5 Sophomore
camp and climb in Michaux
State Forest, PA
April 9-12 Whitewater
rafting and rock climbing at the
New River Gorge, WV
April 9-12 Caving in
Southwestern VA
April 9-12 Backpacking
to Harper's Ferry, WV



Reel Hits & Misses

Marshals , Marshals , Marshals

by Dan Larkin and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Okay, how many people
out there didn't see The Fugi
tive? Well, those of you who
didn't see that classic summer
movie featuring Tommy Lee
Jones and Harrison Ford, you
are in for a surprise with U.S.
Marshals. For the millions of
you who did see the first install
ment, well, you won't be sur
prised by the premise of this
quasi-sequel.
The Fugitive was one of
the first of the classic TV-to-sil
ver screen films that swamped
the box office in the early nine
ties. It's also one of the best
(though with competition like
The Beverly Hillbillies and A
Very Brady Sequel . . . ). But
just when the glut of television
inspired movies seems to have
passed, we get this oddball.

Spinning the minor char
acters of a successful movie re
make of an old television show
into their own feature presen
tation may even be a first for
Hollywood, an attempt to lure
audiences on recognition ap
peal. "I've seen that before, it
must be good." (What's next,
Alice, the Bradys' maid in her
own feature film? )
Here goes. Picture a
man, Mark Sheridan, a former
CIA operative, framed for mur
der. He is arrested and placed
on a plane bound for a federal
penitentiary. The plane goes

through a spectacular crash
landing and Sheridan goes run
ning. Unfortunately for him,
U.S. Deputy Marshal Samuel
Gerard, a man with blood
hound instincts and the same
weathered looks (just kidding,
Tommy), is on his trail.
Sheridan, with the search
teams in hot pursuit must seek
to clear his name and get his
life back. Wesley Snipes
{Money Train, The Fan), plays
the hunted, Tommy Lee Jones
(Volcano, The Package) re
prises his Academy Award win
ning role, and they are joined
by the same supporting cast
members, the most notable be
ing Cosmo, played by the very
likeable Joe Pantoliano
(Congo, Calendar Girl).
The main appeal of The
Fugitive was the character of
Richard Kimball, played by
Harrison Ford. We believed in

his character, and wanted him
to escape. Snipes' portrayal of
Sheridan doesn't elicit the same
sort of sympathy that Ford did.
This is not due to Snipes' short
comings as an actor as much as
to the amount of screen time
that he is given. Where Ford
and Jones received equitable
amounts of screen time in The
Fugitive, U.S. Marshals is
clearly Jones' movie.
Jones does a respectable
job playing Gerard again, but
without the "Valjean -Javert"
style relationship of the origi
nal, his character is not as ex¬

citing . He won't be winning
any Oscars this time around.
The chemistry between
Jones and his fellow marshals,
however, is nicely portrayed
and probably the best part of
the movie. I'm sure they'll all
be back for another sequel in no
time. Maybe next time they'll
get to chase somebody who ac
tually did something wrong.
The team is joined by an
FBI counter-terrorist specialist,
John Royce, played by Robert
Downey, Jr. (Air America,
Heart and Souls) and proceeds
on a cross country search. You
don't need me to tell you all of
the near misses and deceptions
which twist the plot of this
movie, especially if you saw the
first.

Dustin Hoffman, in a re
cent interview, called Robert
Downey Jr., "the most gifted
actor of his generation." I'd be
more inclined to agree with him
if Downey didn't do stuff like
this. His character is never fully
developed and his performance
is rather uninspired. This is a
real waste of talent.
I was not overly im
pressed with this movie. It was
not as funny, nor engaging, as
its predecessor. However, I did
find myself enjoying the two
hours I spent with it. For the
enjoyability and the feeling of
a decent amusement park ride,
I give U.S. Marshals a three
stars. However, since the
weather is improving, your

money may be better spent go
ing to a real amusement park.
To me, U.S. Marshals was
more like watting in an amuse
ment park line. / mean, the
weather's nice, and at least
you're not at work, but get to
the good stuff already!
I've seen much, much
worse, but U.S. Marshals is
probably not a movie I'll re
member much about in a
month or so. Two and a half
stars (out of five).
And in a quick Oscar
redux, I'd like to say some
thing. Overall I was pleased
with the awards. Helen Hunt,

In Case You Missed AIt movie here to amuse you

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist
Of all the film genres, the
mob movie is one of the most
captivating. Since the birth of
the motion picture, gangsters
have been glorified. The mob
movie has evolved over time,
from the romanticized black
and white to the violent blood
bath of GoodFellas.
One of the most popular
and most quoted mob movies
of all time is GoodFellas. The
film was nominated for six
Academy Awards, including
Best Picture and Best Director
(Martin Scorsese).
The cast of GoodFellas is
a very talented one, starring
Ray Liotta (Eight Men Out;
Corrina, Corrina; Unlawful
Entry), Joe Pesci {Casino, My
Cousin Vinny), Robert DeNiro
(Wag the Dog), Paul Sorvino,
and Lorraine Bracco.
GoodFellas, like Casino
and Donnie Brasco, is based on
a true story. The movie itself

is based on the book Wiseguy
by Nicholas Pileggi.
GoodFellas begins right
in the middle of things. Henry
Hill (Liotta) takes the story
back to his childhood and his
dream of being a gangster. He
starts out as a run¬

ner for mobster
Paulie Cicero
(Sorvino), and
quickly moves up
the ranks. Even as
a kid, Henry be
comes very well re
spected and well
known, but be
cause he is only half
Sicilian, he could
never become a

"made man."
Henry, Tommy DeVito,
and Jimmy "the Gent" Conway
(DeNiro) are involved in rack
eteering, extortion, and hijack
ing. The movie follows
Henry's life in the mob from
errand boy to drug runner. Af
ter living the good life for a
while with wife Karen (Bracco),

lives of his wife and daughters,
Henry tells the feds what he
knows and Paulie and Jimmy
are sent to prison for their mob
crimes.
Joe Pesci's performance
as Tommy DeVito is unforget
tariis

Henry'_s world begins to fall
apart. Bracco, who received an
Academy Award nomination
for her performance, also nar
rates the story of Henry's life
in the mob.
Following the formula of

the mob movie, everything
comes to a climax after surveil
lance by the FBI. Henry faces
a long sentence if convicted on
narcotics charges. He also
stands the chance of being
killed by Paulie's men for his in
volvement with drugs, some
thing which was strictly prohib
ited. To save himself and the

most memorable line from Taxi
Driver. GoodFellas has even
been parodied in Steven
Spielberg's Animaniacs.
"Goodfeathers," a cartoon
sketch about three pigeon
wiseguys, draws largely on
GoodFellas, as well as on other
films in the genre.
Joe Pesci's performance

me, over-me
top character is
volatile and unpre
dictable. Pesci's fa
mous line "Funny
how? I'm a clown,
here to amuse you?"
is etched into film
history and is
quoted almost as
much as Robert
DeNiro's "Are you
talking to me?" the

h this movie is almost comi
cal, as he plays the melodra
matic wiseguy. Pesci received
the Best Supporting Actor Os
car in 1990 for his performance
as Tommy. DeNiro's soft-spo
ken, yet commanding presence
is among one of his greatest
performances. Although
Pesci's role as Nicky Santoro in
Casino, which also starred
DeNiro, is very similar to his
portrayal of Tommy, his role in
this film is much more likeable
and convincing.
GoodFellas is extremely
violent and explicit, but in or
der to tell the story properly,
these elements are necessary.
The use of flashback and sus
pended animation at pivotal
points are very effective tools
in telling the story. The voice
over done by Liotta and
Bracco's characters gives the
film a Wonder Years kind of fla
vor. The difference: Kevin and
Winnie are heavily into co
caine, and are now in the Wit
ness Protection Program.



Paper from here to the Pacific

by Kyle Heulitt
GECO Columnist
By 2005, when it
reaches capacity, the Fresh
Kills Landfill on Staten Island
will be the tallest peak on the
East_/Doast between Maine
and Florida.
The U.S. recycles only
11% of its total waste com
pared to Japan, which recycles
50%. Sixty-five percent of our
trash goes to landfills, half of
which will close within five
years. U.S. businesses buy an
estimated 5 billion cubic feet
of polystyrene foam "pea
nuts" a year. That's enough
to fill the Empire State Build
ing more than 135 times.
! The U.S. produces 70%
of the world's solid waste.
Paper:
¦

It takes 390 gallons of
oil to produce one ton of pa
pier. That ton of paper, when
disposed of, takes up nearly
eight cubic feet of public land
fill space.
That public landfill is
approximately 36% waste
paper products.
Every one million pages
of paper not printed saves 85
pulp trees.
In prehistoric times,
60% of the earth's surface was

covered by forests; today, that
amount has been reduced by
30% and is still shrinking.
Paper and paperboard con
stitute 36% of the total amount
of solid waste produced.
Paper can be recycled
about four times before it loses
its tensile strength.
U.S. businesses
throw away 21 _^jf m
million mffk_^m M
tons _^ _f _d W'

day, we could save up to 1.4' rriil'

lion trees per year.
Making new paper,from
old paper uses up to 55_^K>iess
energy than making paper from
trees and creates much less air
and water pollution.
Every year, Americans
throw away enough office paper
to build a wall 12 feet high
stretching from LA to NYC.

If only 100,000 people
stopped their junk mail, we
could save about 150,000 trees
every year (and think of all the
junk mail we get!)
If we all recycled our
Sunday papers, we could save
over 500,000 trees each week.

Making cans from re
cycled aluminum cuts related
air pollution (for example, sul
fur dioxides which create acid

rain) by 95%.
It takes 19 times as much
energy to manufacture an alu
minum can from raw ore than
from recycled aluminum.
The average aluminum
can goes from the supermarket
shelf to scrap and back to the
shelf in 42 days.
The average American
uses about 42 lbs. of aluminum
each year, while the average
Chinese or Mexican uses less
than 2 lbs.
In 1991, the U.S. recycled
56.8 billion cans.

Library BULLETin

by Libby Musselman
Library Columnist
Q: Is it too late to sign
up for an RPC?
A: Heck, no. It only takes
about 24 hour notice. You
should sign up in the blue book
on the reference desk in the li
brary—just give them 24 hours
between the time you fill out
the request and the time you
want the appointment.
A Research Pa- _M_±_A
per Consul- _^^Sf_^L

tation is
that first
step in
turning
out a
great pa
per. A
student may sign
up for indi
vidual half
hour appo
ments with a 1
re;
to develop

research strat
egies for a paper or project.
Appointments may be
made between 10 a.m. and
noon, Monday-Thursday, and
between 2 p.m. and 4 p.m.
Monday-Friday. If none of
these times are convenient, spe
cial appointments may also be
arranged.
During the consultation,
the librarian will discuss strat¬

egies for finding the most rel
evant resources for your topic
with you. Discussion may in
clude, for example, how to use
subject and word searches in
MUSCAT to find books, how
to find materials in other librar
ies, which journal indexes con
tain appropriate information
and how to use these efficiently,
how to discover if good topi
cal information exists on
the web, and what

her kinds of
sources (e.g.,
special
ized bib
liogra-p
h i e s ,
govern
m e n t
docu
ments)
might be
useful.

the Week:

Check the new feature on
the library homepage. Under
"What's New," access "New
Books." It will give a listing of
all the new books (and provides
a link to new videos) that have
come to the library in the last
week. Please send more of your
comments, questions, and/or
complaints to
lmussel@gettysburg.edu

CONFLICT & Consensus

A plea for sanity

To the Editor:

ing that individual here, divide
the hosting responsibilities, and
share the marketing for the lec
ture. . For example, WSPAC, in
setting up its programming for
1998-99, sent a letter to all
departments and programs ask
ing whether they would be in
terested in cosponsoring speak
ers. Positive responses came
from three departments, and
next year's series (diminished
in size) will include at least two
cosponsored speakers.
3. If voluntary compli
ance is not effective, we might
think about reducing our bud-

As we are in the middle
of scheduling events for the
next year, I hear everyone
complaining about our fren
zied calendar of events. In an
effort to bring some sanity to
the scheduling process, let me
review the facts and then sug
gest some remedies.
The Facts:
1. Scheduling as it now
exists operates on free market
principles: as many events are
scheduled on one night as
space is available, and atten
dance occurs on a demand ha-

S1S. 2. This year, at least four
groups which strive to educate
the entire campus community
about other cultures scheduled
events against each other: the
Senior Scholars' Seminar, the
Intercultural Resource Center,
the International Students, and
the Area Studies Symposium.
Many other major conflicts
occurred as well.,
3. We have chosen not
to exert any control over
scheduling; no advice is of
fered as to possible conflicts
which may occur. This laissez
faire approach is exacerbated
by the use of Gopher for
scheduling purposes. It is now
possible to find out whether a
particular space is available on
a particular evening and to just
ignore what else is going on
that night. It is also possible
to check the campus schedule
by date , but some would per
haps prefer not to know.
_> * r
\\F a i,
tt
_t

have little money available to
bring in lecturers and perform
ing artists.
5. Moreover,-something
like a turf battle seems to have
erupted between certain pro
grams and departments. If a
series already exists in conjunc
tion with one program, then it
seems that each must mount a
spate of lectures or an addi
tional series in an effort to
prove competitive.
6. Despite the fact that a
large portion of tuition money
is expended on speakers and
performances, most students
do not attend these events un
less they are required in con
junction with a class. Many
professors hesitate to require
students to attend events out
side of class, either because
they themselves do not live
nearby and cannot attend, or
because they are reluctant to
require peripheral intellectual
experiences.

7. We may have confused
the student cry "there isn't
enough to do at Gettysburg"
with the need to pour money
into our Lecture and Perform
ing Arts budget ant to sched
ule more and more events. (Ad
mittedly a conjecture rather
than a fact.)
Possible Remedies:
1. Every group which
sponsors a series of lectures or
performing arts might think
about reducing the number of
such events. All of us are
stretched too thin} Next year's
Area Studies Symposium, for
instance, will offer fewer pre
sentations than in past years.
The topics will be provocative
ones, however, dealing with
controversial issues in Latin
America.

4. We have created
Common Hour to bring the
campus community together in
a mutual intellectual experi
ence, but we have not dimin
ished the amount of evening
programs which are being
funded. Very few. programs
are well attended, even Com
mon Hour, which includes that
rarity, a free lunch. The "Com
mon Hour Effect" occurs natu
rally on those _campuses that
,
F s r r r r

2. Co-sponsorship may
be one way to encourage larger
attendance at lectures. Thus,
two _' ciepartments or groups
would mutually agree on a
speaker, share the cost of bring-

gets for such programming in
future years. In their place, we
might set up a Faculty Presen
tation Series in which certain
individual faculty members or
departmental teams did presen
tations on such offbeat topics
as their own research, film criti
cism, or politics and world af
fairs. The Socratic Club is a
great student venue for student
debate and needs to be encour
aged. In other words, we need
to stimulate each other and
model for each other the pro
cess of making sense of the
world in which we find our
seives.

4. Of course, we have no
intention of cutting ourselves
off from that world or of ceas
ing to bring new ideas and per
forming techniques onto our
campus from other places.
However, we might try to cul
tivate an attitude of what the
Buddhists call "mindfulness" in
our- scheduling. Such an atti
tude would require that every
individual, every program, ev
ery department commit them
selves to considering carefully
what else is scheduled and
whether it would be a thought
less gesture program a signifi
cant event against some other
program of similar content. We
- continued on page 13 -
see "Slanitv"

Consider this

Three hundred people
have spoken, and they want a
dance club.
Last Friday night, the So
cial Life Committee sponsored
a BYOB Video Dance Party in
the CUB Ballroom.
Poor attendance has often
plagued such events, and the
party did start out slowly with
only a handful of people mill
ing around the Ballroom, per
haps due to the fact that stu
dents were mesmerized by co
median Alonzo Bodden. After
his show ended around 11 p.m.,
the Ballroom quickly filled up
with dancers.
The video dance party of
fered dancers the opportunity
to request songs, and although
some choices, such as ABBA's
"Dancing Queen," were ques
tionable, even the security
guards could be seen occasion
ally mouthing the words to
songs.

This one-time event was
a success, but does that imply
that a permanent dance club is
a feasible option for Gettysburg
College? Will the novelty of a
dance club wear off? Will atten
dance decline as time goes on,
or during Rush or other special
events?

The success of college
sponsored social events in the
past varies with the event. En
thusiasm is currently high for a
dance club, but many activities
and events look good on paper.
A one-time turnout does not
guarantee success in the future.
The target _audience for
the dance club is likely to be first
year students, possibly as a
means of discouraging them
from attending fraternity par
ties. However, students will be
required to be 18 years of age
in order to enter. Some first
year students have not turned
18 by the time they enter col
lege. Is it fair to bar thern from
campus events?
What to do about this di
lemma?

meant to _teflect the opinions of the College as a whole.

Stories printed in The Gettysburgian are accurate to the _knowledge
of our reporters. Editors should be contacted by letter if errors'

name(s) on a request-only basis.

Before finalizing any
thing, the school should experi
ment with dance parties a few
more times. If attendance con
tinues to be high, then the
school should consider sinking
a lot of money into a dance club.
If attendance drops off
with time (as happens with so
many other activities), give up
the idea. Our tuition money
should not be going towards
something that people won't
use.

The Pachyderm y s Pulpit

Maryland republicans? If spossible.

by John Dunlap
Political Columnist
A few miles to our south,
as we all know, stands the state
of Maryland, one of the most
Democratic states in the coun
try. For 30 years Democrats
have controlled the state's Gov
ernorship and for over 65 years
the state General Assembly. In
1992, with the exception of
Arkansas, Maryland gave then
Governor Clinton his biggest
majority in his election as Presi
dent. In recent history, only
President Ronald Reagan in

1984, and President George
Bush in 1988 were able to
break the Democratic hold 1 on
the state.
Today things are chang
ing in the Old Line State, as the
Republican Party is finally be
ing competitive. For years, the
GOP was a carbon copy of the
Democrats in the state. Repub
lican candidates tended to be
very liberal and many times
from Washington, DC, not
Maryland. Individuals like
Reagan Aide Linda Chaves ran
for office, not native Maryland-

ers. Democratic leaders were
usually firmly based in the
greater Baltimore area. That
too is changing. The state's
largest counties are Montgom
ery and Prince George's Coun
ties. Both sit right outside
Washington. These people do
not read the Baltimore Sun or
watch Baltimore television, but
instead read the Washington
Post and get their news from
the nation's capital.
In 1994 for the first time
in over a hundred years, some
one from the Washington sub
urbs, Prince George's County
executive Parris Glendening
was elected Governor.
Now the GOP has cre
ated a farm team and is creat
ing a statewide network to win
elections. Four of the eight
members of the Maryland del
egation to the United States
House of Representatives are

Republicans and GOP numbers
in the General Assembly are
rising. Republicans hold 41 of
141 state House of Delegates
seats and 15 of 47 State Senate
seats. This means that Repub
licans are building a base and
the party is doing this by mov
ing to the right. No longer are
Maryland Republicans "Want
to be" Democrats, but they
now stand for a conservative

set of principles.
The 1994
midterm election
was

a watershed year for Maryland
Republicans. First, the minor
ity leader of the House of Del
egates, Ellen Sauerbrey of Bal
timore County shocked the
state's political establishment
by defeating the party's pre
sumptive nominee United
States Congresswoman Helen
Bentley. Mrs. Sauerbrey's vic
tory was a win for the Repub
lican right. Sauerbrey is a con
servative Republican who
based her campaign on her pro
posed 24% state income tax cut
as well as holding the line on
future government spending.
Sauerbrey attacked Mrs.
Bentley for being too cozy with
Democrats, such as Governor
William Donald Schaiffer,
whom Sauerbrey had battled in

the legislature. By a margin of beat the Governor and make
52% to 38% Sauerbrey de- major gains in the General
feated the Congresswoman. In Assembly in 1998. Even with
the general election, Mr. the economy growing and
Glendening attacked Sauerbrey crime dropping, Parris
hard for her pro-life stance on Glendening finds himself
abortion, as well as her oppo- extremely vulnerable_,
sition to gun control. First of all, the Maryland
Glendening attacked Sauerbrey economic growth rate is slower
for being out of the mainstream than the rest of the nations and
of Maryland politics, but the fundraising, as well as pensidn
Sauerbrey tax message domi- scandals have
nated _._^M_^^^. marred

V the
cam
paign.
A s
the cam
p a l g n
neared the
end it
looked as if

Republicans for the first time
since Spiro Agnew in 1966
would take the Governor's
Mansion. On election night,
the race was to close to call, and
with the counting of the absen
tee ballots Glendening's four to
one fundraising edge came in
handy as he was elected Gov
ernor by two-tenths of a per
cent. His victory was marred
by accusations of fraud in Bal
timore City. Sauerbrey even
took the election to court but
her case was denied.
Today however, many of
Sauerbrey's accusations of
fraud are being confirmed. In
the past four years the
Maryland GOP has continued
to grow in numbers. Republi
cans feel confidant they can

stadiums have hurt the
governor.
Governor Glendening is
facing trouble within his own
party as he has trouble keep
ing Democrats together. Hart
ford County Executive Eileen
Rehrman is giving the governor
a strong challenge within his

own primary.
Retired Washington
Redskins football player Ray
Schoenke is also taking on the
governor. If the governor can
make it through the primary,
then he must defeat Mrs.
Sauerbrey again. Unlike four
years ago, today Sauerbrey has
high name recognition, a great
deal more cash, and has been
campaigning virtually non-stop
for governor for the last three
years. She has also softened her
image talking more about edu
cation, something she knows a
lot about considering she was
a biology teacher in Baltimore
County.
The issues that Sauerbrey
is concentrating on are the
economy, education and ethics.
She promises to bust up the
"cozy clique" who run Annapo
lis and to stop runaway state
spending. Howard County

Executive Charles Ecker is tak

lican primary, accusing her of
being overly conservative. This
does not appear to be working
as Sauerbrey is far ahead in the
polls and has the state GOP vir
tually united behind her.
National GOP figures are
rushing into Maryland to help
out her campaign like Gover
nors Tommy Thompson of
Wisconsin, John Engler of
Michigan and Terry Branstand
of Iowa. Former Governor
William Weld of Massachusetts
and Governor Christie
Whitman of New Jersey, both
moderates have paid visits.
Former Vice President Dan
Quayle, the 1996 Republican
Nominee for Vice President
Jack Kemp and Congressman
John Kasich all have helped
Sauerbrey raise money.
A recent visit by retired
Marine Lieutenant Colonel and

the 1994 Republican Candi
date for the United States Sen
ate from Virginia, Oliver
North, caused controversy as
both Democrats and Republi
cans attacked Sauerbrey for in
viting the very conservative Mr.
North.
The balancing act that
Ellen Sauerbrey must perform
is difficult. The Maryland Re
publican Party has one of the
most liberal members of Con
gress, Connie Morrella, and
one of the most conservative
members of Congress, Roscoe
Bartlett, in its leadership. It is
up to Sauerbrey to hold them
together and win enough
Democrats in this overwhelm
ingly Democratic state to be
come governor. With Parris
Glendening's unpopularity and
a divided Democratic Party
than this could be the year.

The election of a Repub
lican governor in 1998 can fur
ther strengthen the national Re
publican party by making one
more state competitive; never
again will Republicans have to
concede Maryland just because
it is Maryland.



CONFLICT & Consensus

Passage to
Africa

Their business is
your business

Sanity

reporters be more concerned
with gaining American atten
tion and interest in their coun
try rather than what our presi
dent is doing behind closed
doors? The African country,
Ghana was extremely excited
to host Mr. Clinton. He spoke
before a very large, enthusias
tic crowd. In his speech he
stated, "Democracy requires
human rights for everyone, ev
erywhere. For men and
women, for children and the
elderly, for people of different
cultures and tribes and back
grounds. A good society hon
ors its entire family."
President Clinton is ex
cited about promoting free
markets and democracy and
aiding the African people, who
are in need. However, my con
cern is, why aren't the efforts
being made to make America
better?

by Cammie Grant
Columnist

President Clinton is on a
twelve day tour of Africa. He
is there to assure Africans aid
and attention from the United
States and he is speaking out in
support of democracy and free
markets.
Prior to beginning his
journey, to Africa, some specu
lated that the president was
leaving the country to avoid the
Lewinsky controversy. The trip
to Africa has been planned for
at least a year. It is a coinci
dence that the trip and the in
vestigation are occurring at the
same time. There is no reason,
unless the president was called
to testify in court, that the Af
rica trip should be canceled.
James Bennet, The New
York Times wrote, "This trip
has come at a propitious time
for Mr. Clinton, who is under
pressure at home from the in
dependent counsel investigat
ing his relationship with
Monica S. Lewinsky". But it
was clear that the President

would not escape his troubles
in Africa. The Times stated that
"Ghanaian reporters grilled
their American colleagues
about details of the crisis"
Once again, it is sad to see
that other countries are aware
of President Clinton's lack of
morals. A few weeks ago,
Saddam Hussein was running
clips of Wag the Dog in addi
tion to airing Clinton's Cabi
net members being shouted off
stage in Ohio. Now, the Gha
naians are questioning Ameri
cans about Clinton's alleged
affair. Shouldn't the Ghanaian

Thousands of American
citizens claim their homes on
city streets under bridges; jails
are filled to capacity; the bud
get suffers; when is the execu
tive office going to focus its
undivided attention on our
country's problems, before ad
dressing problems in other
countries and giving aid?
I am proud of the United
States. I take tremendous pride
in our government and its
structure. It is, however, an
embarrassment to read in
magazines and newspapers that
foreign countries are aware of
Clinton's personalcn ' s/s and
even more so, want to report
on it. I do, however give ku
dos to Clinton's foreign policy
efforts.

CONFLICT & Consensus

Random
thoughts

Free floating hostility

by Sara Sprenkle
Random Thinker
It's a small campus.
Duh.
What that means,
though, is that when you speak
loudly of a person, someone
nearby could be his or her
friend/roommate/signif leant
other. On Monday night, I was
at Servo, minding my own busi
ness, when I heard a certain
female speak of one of my
friends and call her a not-so
nice name. She didn't seem to
care who heard her, or maybe
she was ignorant of the fact that
one of her verbal victim's
friends might hear. So, I guess
I was within my right to tell her
that I thought she was out of

ne. I feel bad that I didn't
defend my friend because what
the verbal assaulter said was
totally not true, but I felt out
of line since I didn't know the
girl or anyone she was talking
to. The point is remember
the next time you complain
about (your TA/a classmate/a
person down the hall) someone
nearby may overhear you and
take issue with what you said
about his or her friend.
Now I'm in a bind. I
want to write about another
rude person, but that doesn't
seem very random. Oh, wait, I
thought of something else be
fore I write about that.
The snooze button is ev
ery college student's friend.
Every alarm clock I have had
has an alarm that goes off seven
minutes after the snooze but
ton was hit.

Why seven minutes? Was
there some study done that
found that seven minutes is the
optimal time for someone to
wake up after a first warning
alarm? Just wondering. I'm not
saying there wasn't. If anyone
knows, send a letter to the edi
tor, Box 434.

I like cherry flavored
stuff, but I don't like cherries.
I know other people who like
some flavor, but they don't like
the real thing, so I'm not that
weird.
Anyway, back to the rude
guy... My friends and I went to
Myrtle Beach over Spring
Break, and we went to the
Hard Rock Cafe.
I ordered The Pig sand
wich because the menu says
that I haven't been to the Hard
Rock Cafe until I've had that.
I have been at the Hard Rock
Cafe in New York before, so if
I wanted to tell people I had
been there, I had to get the
sandwich.
The waiter took my order
as an invitation to mock me.

When he brought the
meal, he asked, "Who is the
barbecue chicken?" Then, he
asked, "Who's the pig?" I re
luctantly answered-fodder for
the fire.
After that, the waiter
would stop by and comment on
how quickly I ate my food and
how much of my food I ate. He
did not do this once or twice—
he did this every time he
stopped to check for refills, to
ask how our meals were, to
pick up our plates, to get a
desert order. Every time.
I don't know why the
waiter thought that this was a
good way to score tips. It
seems that my tablemates
found this amusing, but I was
not amused.
The guy ended up with
over a 20% tip, under my pro
test. My tip suggestion was 94
cents. However, it seems that
my tablemates thought other¬

. I understand that some
restaurants have some strange
service philosophy with pur
posely rude waiters, but Hard
Rock isn't one of them. Like
improvisation in rock and roll,
an impromptu waiter is some
times good but not always.

by Michael Petro
Opinionated Editor
Okay Gettyburgian fans,
given the fact that I was aban
doned by a couple of my writ
ers this week, you're all in for
a special treat. As editor, I am
usually consigned to reading
what others write. However,
today I trade in that hat

to become a writer
Actually, I have
traded in nothing,
rather, I am pull
ing double duty
tonight!
As a re
sult, I give to _JF
all the loyal _jdj
readers out 5_^
there a «_2
written _^Cm
contnbu- _^JJ
t i o n .
However, if
you are a
glass is half full
person, I highly
reccomend that
you stop read
ing this
right now.
Tak¬

ing
theme from the
comedic

,
George Carhn, I offer to the
readership something known as
"free floating hostility." Enjoy
Kids and guns. I know
that our violence prone society
has desensitized many of us to
violence, but surely there must
be many out there that share
my abhoration at the shootings
which took place in a small
Arkansas town. How is it that
we have denegrated as a soci
ety so much that two thirteen
and eleven year old kids can
shoot fourteen classmates and
a teacher?
¦ There are apologists out
there that would be inclined to
think that it is just the actions
of mentally unstable and impul
sively immature kids, however,
where the hell did a thirteen

and eleven year old get a veri
table arsenal of weapons?! Not
only should these kids be pros
ecuted to the full extent of the
law, but those who had the
weapons within reach should
be brought up on a few hun
dred charges of endangering
the welfare of a child, one for

each student at that school.
Okay, enough of sound
ing like a real right winger.
Moving on. Turn signals. Vir
tually all of the readers of this
publication are drivers. When
is it that people stopped using
turn signals? There is a reason
that the law requires that ev
ery car has them, so people
know where a car is going! Has
it become so difficult to move
that little lever up and down?
Please, for everyone's benefit,
use your damn turn signals!
' The media. When did we
become' a 'society of scandals?
Ever since Watergate, every
hack with a tape recorder and
a camera crew is trying to be
come the next Woodward-and
Bersteui. Why is it that Bill
Clinton is off in Africa and the

main story CNN runs is that a
reporter asked him about the
allegations? Who the hell
cares? Personally I take an inter
est in our foreign policy, and
making headway in Africa is
much more important than
some contrived scandal. I don't
give a damn who he slept
with! If he co¬

erced people
to lie, im
peach him,
otherwise
leave it
i alone!
i Re
I sponsibil
|_ ity. Why
P_^ 1 is it that
it seems
as if ev
eryone al
ways has
an excuse?
If you make
_t a mistake,
P own up to it.
If you make a
commitment
to someone,
follow through
on it. There
used to be a thing
called honor. A
person word

_^^B s was
_^^_B seen as a bond.
Where did those days go?
I'd be a lot more forgiving if
people would just own up to
their faults.
Finally, let me say a few
things about complacency.
Don't people care anymore.
Why is it that it takes someone
Greek bashing to bring a letter
to the editor to this paper?
What ever happened to people
climbing on a soapbox and tell
ing others what they think.
People, it is okay to get angry,
it is okay to voice your opin
ions! It doesn't take long, and
trust me, it can be rather
therepeutic. So I challenge all
of you opinionated people out
there to sound off at the top of
your lungs. Maybe if more of
us did this, less people would
feel the urge to blow fellow
human beings away.

Fall Convocation 1998 will be held on
Thursday, November 12,1998.
We are seeking your input on suitable
speakers for Fall Convocation — please
include a brief bio and rational with your
suggestions. The Fall Convocation committee
made up mostly of students, but also
including faculty and administrators will
meet in April to discuss your suggestions. It
is important to share with you that one
speaker is currently being sought and we are

awaiting his reply — your input is still very
valuable: Elie Wiesel (brief bio: He has
worked on behalf of oppressed people for
much of his adult life. His personal
experience of the holocaust has led him to use
his talents as an _^ author, teacher, and
storyteller to defend human rights and peace
throughout the world. His efforts have
earned him the Presidential Medal of
Freedom, the United States Congressional
Gold Medal, Medal of Liberty Award, and
the Nobel Peace Prize.)

A sampling of some of the more recent Fall
Convocation speakers at Gettysburg College
include" Edwards James Olmos; Morris
Dees; Dr. M. Joycelyn Elders; Robert Jay
Lifton; Alex Kotlowitz; Li Lu; and Maya
Angelou.
I am interested in names of students, faculty,
and administrators who would like to serve
on the working Fall Convocation committee.
You may recommend yourself or someone
else. This would be an April, Sept.-Nov.
Commitment. In April we would only meet
once or twice and then in the Fall there would
be one standing meeting weekly and a
commitment to serve on one sub-committee.
Types of sub-committees include: marketing,
program development, logistics, and tie with

curriculum & service.
Thanks for your review of this information.
Please respond to lwhitecl@gettysburg.edu b
April 14. — Lynn White Cloud

The
Slackers
The Slackers are a 7 piece band
based in New York City -who play a
music based around the "ska" beat; a
Jamaican predecessor of reggae that
over the years has been mixed with
other forms of pop music. The band
also plays rocksteady, dub, and
reggae rhythms, mixing them 'with
mambo, bossa nova, the boogaloo,
6O's garage rock, and occasional
doses of punk attitude.

IN THE PAINT..

The NCAA Men's
by Steve Jenkins
Sports Editor
It is March again, and
nobody cares about coming in
like a lion or that stupid lamb.
Any sports fan with a heartbeat
knows what has been going on
for the last two weeks. In
jected with passion, feeling,
and the way sports were meant
to be, March marked the be
ginning of the NCAA Division
I Basketball tournament; oth
erwise known as March Mad¬

ness. Why is it called March
Madness you ask? What is so
mad about it? Well, March is
the time of year when the
NCAA brings the 64 best bas
ketball teams in the country
together for one big, rip-roar
ing clash of the most intense
gritty, powerful, and exciting
basketball in the world.
" "But I like the NBA," you
say. "I just go watch the Wash
ington Wizards." Yeah. The
Wizards are a good team to7

the clock. The emotion is the
reason we love sports.
"The Tournament,"
which started with 64 teams
has now been whittled down to
four. Sixty teams are now at

that could have been. With all
the heart in the world, and the

emotions will be running high,

they should be played- not for
