Four
Nations to
host "Barn
Dance"

GCPR Gettysburg College will
host the Four Nations En
semble and Jaybird, a country
consort, as the two groups cel
ebrate Four Nations' tenth an
niversary with a rousing barn
dance at 8 p.m., Tuseday, April
21, in Paul Recital Hall in
Schmucker. The performance is
open to the public, free of
charge. Bringing together the
energy and emotion oi the tra
ditional fiddlers of Jaybird with
one of New York's most imagi
native and vital early music
ensembles, the Four Nations
Ensemble, "Barn Dance" fea
tures a selection of folk music
for violin, plucked strings, and
voice from England, America,
and Quebec along with music
for three violins and the
continuo of Purcell, Rameau,
Marini, and Haydin.


Features
Students attempt to take back the night
Action group formed to combat sexual assault on campus

by Cara Masucci
Staff Reporter The statistics can be
alarming. We've all heard
them. Men and women, no
one is immune. Sexual assault
seems to become more and
more prevalent in society. With
all the horrific facts we hear, it
can seem as though there is no
light at the end of the tunnel.
One group on campus, though,
is trying to change this and
bring about the means to the
end of sexual assault at
Gettysburg College.
The group, loosely re
ferred to as the "action group"
had its start a little over three
months ago when co-directors
cf the Women's Center, Abby
Rodgers and Becky Card,
looked around and decided the
campus needed to come to
gether to curb the growing
number of incidents of sexual

assault on campus. Card
stated, "It was not a single in
cident [that started the group],
but an accumulation of events."
Card pointed out that
when she and Rodgers met at
the end of last semester, they
noticed a lack of cooperative
action on the campus in deal
ing with all forms of sexual as
sault. The two directors de
cided to set a goal for the
present semester, and make it
successful and strong enough to
carry on in the coming years.
• The group is made up of
a large congregation of women
and men from many different
aspects of college life, includ
ing students, support staff, and
faculty. The large amount of
diversity among members of
the action group allows for
many different ideas about pro
gramming and ways to, reach
the campus.

According to a student
member of the group who
joined because of her own ex
perience with sexual assault,
the campus needs to become
more aware that rape and oth¬

ers forms of sexual assault do
happen. The woman became
involved because she wanted
to educate people and prevent
it from happening to others.
The college is not immune.
The statistics hold true on this
campus, even though we can
sometimes assume we live in a
bubble.

Each week on this campus, approximately ten women are sexually assaulted.The newly formed
action group on campus is working to fight this problem. Meetings are every other Wednesday
night; call the Women's Center at x6991 for more information.

One of the main goals of
the group is to make the dis
cussion of sexual assault open
and to educate the campus on
issues of prevention and sup
port for those directly affected
by sexual assault. Another goal
is making the victims aware
that there are people out there
to help them and aid them.
To accomplish the above
goals, the group has plastered
the campus with posters, rib
bons, banners, and survival
stories. Walking across the
campus, one cannot escape
purple ribbons tied around
trees as a symbol for how many
people have been victim to
sexual assault.

There will also be a table
located in the CUB throughout
the week containing informa
tion about campus resources,
books on prevention and cop
ing, as well as a wall where
people have told their own sto
ries of crisis.
According to the action
group, the first day alone pro¬

vided a full wall of stories. Card
stated that although it is unfor
tunate to see the true number
of cases of sexual'assault on
campus, it demonstrates the
need for improvement and pre
vention of it on campus.
The group also held a
Take Back the Night rally last
night on Musselman Library
steps to raise support.
The action group is also
presently working with Cheers
to slam the campus with infor
mation. According to Alec
Beekmans, a senior member of
the action group, "We are work
ing with Cheers to combat and
build a defense against sexual
assault on this campus."

First year student
Miranna Smith likes the idea of
the involvement with Cheers
because it will be geared to
wards first year students who
can be the main targets for rape
and other forms of sexual as
sault. Beekmans's involvement
also points to a significant goal

Photo by Emily _Glatfeltei

of the group. Sometimes all
people see or think about is the
man as the aggressor and the
woman as the victim. The ac
tion group realizes this error
and, as Card puts it, "We are
not out there to ostracize men."
Men, as the group points out,
are victims too, and are affected
by rape just as women are. The
action group wants to see more
people, particularly men, in
volved in the process to elimi
nate assault.
If you think a friend has
been raped, there are signs to
look for. Thirty-one percent of
all victims suffer from Rape
Related Post Traumatic Stress
Disorder (RR-PTSD). The

symptoms of this include fear,
helplessness, shock, disbelief,
guilt, humiliation, embarrass
ment, anger, self-blame, flash
backs of the rape, avoidance of
previously pleasurable activi
ties, avoidance of the place or
circumstance in which the rape
occurred, depression, sexual
dysfunction, insomnia, and
impaired memory.
Based on U.S. Census re
ports on the number of women
in the United States, 1.3 mil
lion women currently have RR
PTSD, 3.8 million women have
previously had RR-PTSD and
roughly 211,000 women will
develop RR-PTSD each year.
Victims often pull away
from intimate relationships or,
alternatively, become regres
sively fearful, clingy, and needy.
Be sure to support your friend,
though, as when compared
with nonvictims, rape victims
have been found to be 8.7 times

more likely to attempt suicide.
If you know that a friend
has been sexually assaulted,
encourage him or her to seek
medical treatment immedi
ately. Most victims don't seek
medical care during the criti
cal 72 hours after the attack,
making gathering evidence of
the attack next to impossible.
Only 16% of rapes are
ever reported to the police.
Most believe that nothing can
be done, with other reasons
being that the victims felt it was
a private matter, they were

afraid of police response, and
others felt it was not important
enough.
If anyone is interested in
joining the action group, they
can sign up in the CUB all this
week, or call the Women's Cen
ter at x6991. The group meets
every other Wednesday night in
the Women's Center at 6:30.
The group hopes to boost in
terest in it and wants to elimi
nate the occurrence of rape and
other sexual assault from the
campus. All are welcome and
encouraged to join.




Fungi at Gettysburg

by Brooke Hutt
Contributing Reporter
"I seem to have been only
a boy playing on the seashore,
and diverting myself in now
and then finding a smoother
pebble or a prettier shell than
ordinary, whilst the great ocean
of truth lay all undiscovered
before me."
-Sir Isaac Newton (1642
1727) If you happen to hear a
peculiar noise echoing in the
Biology Department of
Gettysburg College, it is most
likely Dr. A. Ralph Cavaliere.
You can ask any one of his col
leagues about the dominant
trait of Dr. Cavaliere and the

answer .
"It would have to be that
noise he makes," one col
league says.

"this is so great, Dr. Cavaliere
is going to hyperventilate."
Dr. Cavaliere's love for
both science and teaching shine
through this noise. You will be
able to locate good scientists in
any lab, but scientists who love
their students as much as Dr.
Cavaliere are one in a million.
When Dr. Cavaliere took
an interest in plants, he was
merely a little boy, as was New
ton when his eyes were opened
up to the atom. This childhood
interest swept him all the way
out to sea to his first research
project in Iceland. It was there
that he met up with an erupt
ing volcano that was in the pro
cess of forming an island.
Here, in 1963, he observed
marine organisms, all the while
searching for a "prettier shell
than ordinary."
Although this was very

intriguing research, Dr.
Cavaliere felt that it was time
tor a change. "I remember it
Was very cold in Iceland," said
Cavaliere. "If I ever do a
project like this again, I want it
to be in Bermuda, and lo and
behold, fifteen years later, I was
in Bermuda."
With the help of many
grants, Dr. Cavaliere went on
to an even more productive
project in Bermuda. With the
warm waters of Bermuda be
fore him, Dr. Cavaliere's career
was taken to new heights. With
its unique protected inshore
waters, including extensive
sounds, bays, and marine
ponds,the opportunities for
*—. studying marine

flora and fauna
were infinite.
According to
one of the field
guides he
authored, the
protected in
shore waters
"harbor a rich
and beautiful
variety of
marine life
_^ t hat is
quite dif
ferent from
' the off
shore
_A flora and
fauna associ
ated with the
Many of these

reefs."
organisms can be observed
merely by snorkeling or walk
ing along the shore.
Based upon his extensive
research' on the islands of Ber
muda, Dr. Cavaliere has pub
lished a multitude of books,
field guides, and articles.
Among these publications, are
The Marine Algae of Bermuda
and The Field Guide to the
Conspicuous Flora and Fauna
of Bermuda, both of which are
published by the Bermuda Bio
logical Station for Research.
He has been collaborating with
the Director of the Natural
Museum of Bermuda on a six
year project entitled The
Seaweeds and Seaside Plants of
Bermuda.

Be still my beating heart

by Greg Bellanca and Jen Sabo
Contributing Reporters
Learning how to measure
your heart rate at rest, during
exercise, and after exercise is
easy and practical. Your heart
rate can serve as a useful foun
dation for various exercise pro
grams.
There exist several ana
tomical sights that can be pal
pated to determine heart rate.
The carotid artery in the neck
and the radial artery (thumb
side) in the wrist are the most

resting heart rate than a seden
tary person. Aerobic exercise
performed three times a week
for twenty minutes has been
shown to benefit the resting
heart rate. There are several
other factors that affect heart
rate besides exercise, including
medications, disease, and age.
Measuring the heart rate
during exercise is a good index
of how hard the heart is work
ing and the intensity of the ex
ercise session. Achieving a cer
tain intensity level is the goal

of an exercise session. The
term target heart rate range is
used to denote heart activity
high enough to induce cardio
vascular benefits.
The target heart rate
range of typical college stu
dents is between 120 beats per
minute and 200 beats per
minute. To determine your ap
proximate target heart rate
range, complete the following
formula:
Step 1: 220 - (your age)
= maximum HR
Step 2: (max HR) x .60

common and convenient sights
for measuring heart rate.
In order to determine
your heart rate, place your in
dex and middle fingers over the
carotid or radial arteries. The
throbs you feel correspond ex
actly to the beats of the heart.
The beats can be counted for
ten seconds and then multiplied
by six.
The resting heart rate av
erage is usually between 50-90
beats per minute. A physically
fit individual will have a lower

= lowest HR for exercising
Step 3: (max HR) x .80
= highest HR for exercising
Once you are well into
your aerobic conditioning pro
gram, you will notice that your
exercise heart rate is lower than
it was during the early phases
of training. This decrease in
dicates that the heart is becom
ing more efficient through
training. In other words, your
heart is not working as hard to
accomplish a certain task.
When the exercise bout is
finished, your heart rate does
not instantly return to its rest
ing level. The time it takes for
an elevated heart rate to return
to resting levels is referred to
as the heart rate recovery pe
riod. The heart rate returns to
its resting level more quickly as
a result of endurance training.
A more physically fit person
recovers faster after exercise
than a less fit individual.

Measuring and keeping
track of the heart rate period
is an excellent parameter for
progress evaluation.


Hair Grease and poodle skirts

In Case You Missed It

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist
In 1978, the stage play
Grease hit the big screen. Last
week it was rereleased in movie
theaters and drive-ins across
the country. The film boasts a
big name cast, starring Satur
day Night Fever heartthrob

John Travolta and
Australian pop star
Olivia Newton
John as the lovers.
Danny
(Travolta) and
Sandy (Newton
Jbhn) enjoyed a
summer romance
the summer before
their senior year of
high school. They
said good-bye at the
end of the summer

as Sandy was on her way back
to Australia. But by some twist
of fate, her family wound up
staying, and Sandy faces her
first day of school at Rydell
High. Little does she know
that Danny is also a student
there. Sandy nervously goes
through her first day and be
comes friends with Frenchy
(Didi Conn), one of the Pink
Ladies. At lunch she meets the
rest of the girls and tells them
of her summer love. Mean
while, on the bleachers at the
football field, Danny is regal
ing his fellow T-Birds with sto¬

ries of his summer fling. The
song ends with their images
against a sunset.
After meeting Sandy at a
pep rally, Danny realizes he has
to keep up appearances in front
of his friends. He can't act like
the sweet and innocent boy
Sandy knows from the summer.
His crude, macho behavior

confuses Sandy. Frenchy has an
idea: why not give Sandy a
makeover? So the Pink Ladies
have a sleepover and invite
Sandy, asking her to dye her
hair and pierce her ears. This
brings about the best song in
the whole musical. Rizzo
(Stockard Channing) breaks
out into "Look At Me, I'm
Sandra Dee," while Sandy is
out of the room.
Danny and Sandy try to
make their relationship work,
but they are so different that it
seems impossible. Then each
comes up with a plan to win
the other over for good. Both

Danny and Sandy try to change
to suit the other. The real les
son learned by the end of the
film is to be yourself; you don't
need to change for anyone.
Just about everybody has
seen Grease and can croon
along with the gang. Grease
pays tribute to the way it was,
evoking feelings of nostalgia
_^^_hm_^^_m for bobby \

ii/i ujuu y
soxers and
drive-ins. But
for we Gen
eration Xers,
who don't
know first
hand the sim
plicity of
poodle skirts
and saddle
shoes, Grease
is a window to
the world of

drive-ins and malt shops.
The supporting cast also
has some famous names:
Lorenzo Lamas (from TV's
Renegade), Jeff Conaway (who
was in the original Broadway
cast as well as being on TV's
Taxi), Stockard Channing {Moll
Flanders), Frankie Avalon, Sid
Caesar, and Eve Arden.
The best thing about
Grease is the music. The tunes
are catchy, and the lyrics are
simple and fun. This is a film
that everybody will enjoy. So
if you can't find it in a theater
near you, rent it this weekend
for a rockin' good time.

Fungi

Throughout his numer
ous field guides are scattered
beautiful pen and ink drawings.
Dr. Cavaliere's artwork,
coupled with his detailed de
scriptions, makes learning
about marine algae and other
organisms relatively simple for
the average student.
Dr. Cavaliere was not an
overnight success, however.

Years of laborious study were
necessary to even come close to
the "great ocean of truth" de
scribed by Newton. He re
ceived both his Bachelor of Sci
ence and Master of Science
degrees in Biology from Ari
zona State University. Dr.
Cavaliere then went on to
Duke University, where, in
1965, he received his Ph.D.

- continued from page 6 -
with a major in Botany and a
minor in Zoology. His areas of
specialization included Mycol
ogy, Marine Fungi, and Marine
Algae.
In beginning his studies,
Cavaliere was given "a great big
fungus" to start him on his re
search. Dr. Cavaliere took the
fungus home and sauteed it in
butter, garlic, and oil. The next
day, his professor asked about
what research he had come up
with. Dr. Cavaliere responded,
"I took it home and ate it." His

professor replied, "Boy, a hell
of a biologist you're going to
make." He was right. Dr.
Cavaliere has made a hell of a
biologist after all.
Following his gradutaion,
Dr. Cavaliere taught at Duke as
the Visiting Assistant Professor
of Botany. He then went on to
Gettysburg, where his teaching
was not limited to the standard
school year. He spent his sum
mers as a faculty member at the
Duke University Marine Labo
ratory and at the Bermuda Bio
logical Station for Research.

Someone once said that
"a teacher affects eternity, he
can never tell where his influ
ence stops." With his knowl
edge of both science and art,

Dr. Cavaliere has opened the
eyes of countless students.
With the help of his field
guides, now others can "play
on the seashore" as Newton
once did and Dr. Cavaliere
now does.
Years ago, Dr. Robert
Barnes, then Chairman of the
Biology Department, hired Dr.
Cavaliere to teach an under
graduate course in physiology
Dr. Cavaliere did not believe
he would be capable of teach
ing a course in a field other

than his own, but has proven
himself worthy of the job. To
day he teaches courses in Gen
eral Biology, Electron Micros
copy, and the Physiology of
Plant Adaptations.
A few of Dr. Cavaliere's
students have even gone on to
greatness. Dave Hartman was
the first blind student ever to
be admitted to an American
Medical School. Also, two of
his students, one of whom was
his advisee, received McArthur
fellowships.

Dr. Cavaliere's ability to
enlighten others, as well as his
pleasant personality, are evi
dent in the words of his col
leagues. According to Janice
Diehl, the Biology Department

secretary, "his ability to encour
age students to learn" is his best
quality. "He never forces you
to learn, but he makes it so
much fun, you just want to."
When asked about Dr.
Cavaliere, Dr. Hendrix replied,
"He is a fine person to be with
as a colleague; We enjoy work
ing with him. If you're doing
something wrong, he will tell
you, and if you're doing some
thing right, he will tell you."
Professor Hirazumai feels
the same way. "He is a fun pro
fessor to be around as a col
league, and students are lucky
to have him as a lecturer."
Perhaps the following
words of Professor Hirazumai
sum up Dr. Cavaliere the best.
"His love of and love for sci
ence is genuine, and anyone
who has known him will rec
ognize it."

When asked what his
greatest contribution to science
has been, Dr. Cavaliere re
sponded, "No one has ever
asked me that before." He feels
that his greatest contribution
has been, "to be able to take
concepts of biology and teach
them in a way that science and
nonscience students alike can
understand them."

Reel Hits & Misses
More fun than a barrel of animatronic monkeys

by Dan Larkin and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Dan: 1 never thought I'd
say this, but the monkey was
the worst part of the movie.
But I'm getting ahead of myself
here. Mike: My friend here is
right, the monkey was really
bad. Imagine Roger Rabbit
trying to pass as a real being
and you might get a vague idea
of what this effect is like.
Lost in Space, the cin
ematic update of the frighten
ingly campy sixties space-corn,
is a bit of a mixed bag in this
new adaptation.
All of the basic elements
of the Space Family Robinson
are left more or less intact. The
sci fi geeks out there will be glad
to see that the Robot and Dr.
Smith and Will and Penny and
Judy and Mom and Dad and
that other guy are all still there.

Lost in Space has the ben
efit of strong, if somewhat bi
zarre, casting. Dr. John
Robinson, the family patriarch,
is played by William Hurt
(Dark City, Kiss of the
SpiderWoman). Like most
characters he plays, Hurt's
Robinson is detached and aloof
until something makes him
"come around." This role is a
bit less dramatic than Hurt usu
ally plays, but he does a good
job with a pretty easy part. _r
Gary Oldman (Dracula,
The Scarlet Letter) does an ad
mirable job trying to dupli
cate Jonathan Harris' campy
Dr. Smith. The portrayal of Dr.
Smith in the movie falls short
of its mark, but this is due much
more to the script than to any
shortcomings on Oldman's
part.

Smith is made to be much
too villainous in the movie
Harris' Smith was opportunis¬

tic and cowardly, but he was
never evil.
It took me a couple of
years before I realized that Matt
LeBlanc (Ed) and Matthew
Perry on Friends were two sepa
rate people, so I guess that
LeBlanc was a pretty good
choice to play the everyman pi
lot, Don West. LeBlanc is not
much of an actor, but he doesn't
have to do too much here. He
doesn't hurt the movie.
The casting is really well
done. I like the way that you
can believe that the cast mem
bers are really a family. Hurt
and Rodgers are the believeable
parents, and the kids are midly
disfunctional, a perfect 90's
adaptation. -
Like any TV show from
the sixties, the women on the
original Lost in Space had no
personalities. Director Stephen
Hopkins attempts to remedy
this, making Mom (Mimi

Rodgers) and Judy (Heathet
Graham) into scientists instead
of just girls along for the ride.
There's some tension in the
Robinson marriage. Judy has
problems getting in touch with
her emotions. Penny feels ne
glected and unloved. But the
women still don't do anything,
leaving the all the real action
to the men and the Robot
(original voice of Dick Tufield),
just like the old series. So much
for progress.
Despite a lack of depth,
the movie is pretty fun and a
visual treat. Particularly
memorable is a scene where
Will Robinson commands the
Robot through a kind of V.R
remote control.
The effects are really well
done in this movie. I read that
this movie has more computer
special effects than any other
in history. Watch it and you'll
believe that to be true. I en¬

joyed the lush scenery and the
seamless computer animation.
This movie represents a big
step forward in special effects.
What came really close to
ruining the movie for me was
the inclusion of a cutesy com
puter-animated space monkey
as a friend for Penny. I like
monkeys as much as the next
guy (okay, maybe a little more
than the next guy), but this
thing was really annoying. This
creature fails in comparison to
the time honored legacy of sci
ence fiction monkeys (Dr.
Zaius, Gleek, etc.). But, over
all, Lost in Space is a good time.
Two and three quarter stars (out
of five).
If he likes monkeys as
much as the next guy, well
then, call me the next guy! I
liked this movie, it's a good
time and worth the price of
admission. Two and a half
stars out of five.


Library BULLETin

by Libby Musselman
Library Columnist
Q: The library is open
24 hours from Sunday-Friday,
but what does that really
mean? I mean, the building
is open, but other stuff isn't,
what's the deal?
A: The building being
open means there is access to
library materials, study space,
and the student computer lab.
It also means that one library
staff member is here to over
see the library and to check
out materials to students.
There are also a lot of services
which are not available all
night long because of staffing.

Q: Is it too late to sign up
for an RPC?
Heck, no. It only takes
about 24 hour notice. You
should sign up in the blue book
on the reference desk in the li
brary-just give them 24 hours
between the time you fill out the
request and the time you want
the appointment. A Research
Paper Consultation is that first
invaluable step in turning out a
great paper. Appointments may
be made between 10 a.m. and
noon Monday through Thurs
day, and between 2 p.m. and 4
p.m., Monday through Friday. If
none of these times are conve¬

nient for you, special appoint
ments may also be arranged.
During the consultation, the li
brarian will discuss with you
strategies for finding the most
relevant resources for your topic.
Libbv's tip of the week:
"Freshmen shall at no time wear
white trousers and shall at all
times wear only plain black socks
and black neckties." These and
other words of advice are on dis
play in the Freshman G-books in
the exhibit cases on the main
floor of the library. Stop in and
see the archive's collection of
dinks—and if you don't know
what a dink is, you'll have to
read the G-book!

Here are the hours of the
other services: Evening ref
erence help and media ser
vices are provided until 10
p.m., Sunday through Thurs
day. Special Collections closes
at 4:30 most days but is open
until 9 p.m. on Wednesday
You can drop off an interli
brary loan request anytime
but the staff leaves at 4:30.
The computer help desk
closes at 6 p.m. and the stu
dent computer hotline is
staffed until 10 p.m. You
might be surprised that we are
open 104 hours per week,
which, according to a recent
survey, is more hours than any
other liberal arts college in the
U.S.

Please send more of your
comments, questions, and/or
complaints to
lmussel@gettysburg.edu

WORDS!!! The Dole enchilada

by Christina Dickert
Columnist Did you ever notice how
words surround our lives? I
know that sounds really dense,
but I never did. It was some
thing that I totally took for
granted. But now, with ten
school days left before finals, it
seems as though those words are
everywhere. I feel as though I
am being suffocated and at
tacked by little clauses and let
ters!! HELP!!
Maybe I'm exaggerating
just the tiniest bit. I feel this way
because I have so much reading
to do. (I know I'm not the only
one, so let's relate.) And if it's
not words to read out of my
textbooks, it's words to write for
one of my numerous papers.
Doesn't it ever stop?

I am one of those people
whose mind, after reading about
50 pages in a book, my mind
starts to wander and the words
start to blur. So I raise my weary
head from the oh-so-interesting
book that I was reading to stare
blankly at the shelf above the li
brary desk that I am sitting at.
My dreams of getting to stare
blankly at nothing but wood are
dashed as I begin to read the
curious scribbling of my prede
cessors of this desk. Wow. "I
got baked at SPRING BREAK
"98." Exciting. Thanks for in
forming me. There is an apol
ogy scrawled on my right, and a

religious quote carefully written
beneath it. Fine, free expression
is just great. But no more
words!! Seriously, I don't think
that it makes any sense to
scribble when you are tired of
either reading or writing other
words.
Then, my favorite time of
night comes along. It usually
happens between midnight and
1 a.m. It begins when you start
reading- you know you are read
ing something because your eyes
are moving- but what did you
just read? I usually give up after
reading the same paragraph four
times and I can't remember any
words except "the." This means
that my brain has checked out
for the night, and, if I want to
learn anymore, I'll have to save
it for tomorrow, after I sleep.
Most of the time, I am very
happy when this special signal
:omes along, because it means
that it is time to pack up and go
to bed.

Maybe my brain is filled to
capacity. I mean, what more can
I learn? I know I am only a
freshman, but I feel so burned
out already. Most of the seniors
encounter tell me that I am
lucky. It only gets harder from
where I stand. Great. That's
really what I want to hear. But I
just want to point out one more
time that there are TEN MORE
DAYS OF CLASSES!!!! I think
[ can make it without going to
tally nuts. I hope you can too.

by Cammie Grant
Political Columnist
On Monday, Senator Bob
Dole was on campus. There
was a private question and an
swer session, followed by a din
ner and ending the evening
with a public speech. I at
tended all of the functions held
for Senator Dole. Dole was a
charismatic speaker. In his
talks he emphasized taking re
sponsibility for one's actions,
trust, honesty, and morals. He
was very careful not to attack
Clinton.
Several questions were
directed to him regarding the
Lewinsky scandal and
Clinton's progress in office.
Senator Dole responded to
these questions with humorous
remarks however, and he did
not directly criticize the
President's efforts.

Dole frequently made
references to President
Eisenhower. He labeled him
his hero. He made it clear to
the students that Eisenhower
was an outstanding president
because he kept his word and
took full responsibility for his
actions. As Dole noted, this is
very hard to come by today
Today, everyone tries to find
somebody else to blame when

something goes wrong. Presi
dent Eisenhower was a man
who stuck to his word, that is
why Dole admires him.
Eisenhower was also a very
trustworthy individual.
In his references to Presi
dent Eisenhower, Dole was
smart. Eisenhower has many
ties not only to the Gettysburg
community, but also to the col
lege. Dole spoke of a time
when he was a congressional
freshman and President
Eisenhower gave his class, both
democrats and republicans

alike, a tour of Gettysburg.
Senator Dole was also a recipi
ent of the Eisenhower Leader
ship Prize.
I heard many comments
from students that if Dole had
spoken the way he did Monday
night, he would have won the
presidential election. He was
very straight forward in his
speech, while adding jokes here
and there. He was relaxed, yet
very enthusiastic about the gov
ernment and the United States.
Dole spoke very highly about
the people of America and our
system of government.

Senator Dole is a true pa
triot and takes great pride in
our country. In my opinion, he
would have been an outstand
ing president. My first vote was

cast for Bob Dole, and I have
no regrets about it. He is a war
hero, a public servant, and an
honest man. His credentials for
the job were nothing short of
acceptable.
Currently, Dole is work
ing for a law firm. He is also
in charge of fundraising for a
World War Two Memorial in
Washington D.C. I admire Dole
because his failed bid for Presi
dent has not affected his cha
risma. He did not dwell on his
loss, but did note that the voter

turnout for the election was
very low. He spoke to students
about the importance of voting
and being involved. After all,
we are the next generation and
we must strive to continue
making positive progress in the
United States. The right to vote
is a privilege and it is something
that many U.S. citizens take for
granted. It is time for every
one, especially our generation
to become involved. Our in
volvement can prevent weak
leaders and promote a stronger
government.

Senator Dole did a phe
nomenal job speaking Monday
evening. For those of you who
were unable to attend, you not
only missed an excellent
speech, but you missed a man
speaking from his heart.

CONFLICT & Consensus
Work with positive means to gain your end

by Jay Spiese
Columnist In two weeks we will be
holding Get Acquainted Day.
All the prospective first year
students will be coming onto
campus to see if this really is
where they want to go to col
lege. This is our chance to
make one final sales pitch to
them. As a college we have
many problems that need to be
dealt with. No one can claim
that we are a perfect institution.
Last year some students felt
they had been wronged by an

administrative decision.
Get Acquainted Day last
year was hurt because members
of Phi Delta Theta hung ban
ners from their house windows
telling these high school seniors
to go elsewhere. This is not a
proper way to change the prob
lems on campus. There are
certain channels for us to at
tempt to change policy.
First, you must call atten
tion to the problem. You must
make people understand your
position clearly. Gather them
together as a base of support.
You do this through the radio
as the Communist party has
done. You can write an article

for the newspaper as I do. Use
the emails to spread the word
as was done by a rape victim
last year.
Secondly, work with the
administration, not against
them. They are not the enemy
You can oppose decisions they
make and still work with them
to find an acceptable solution.
All of us want the same thing:
a better college. We must work
together to build it.
The proposal of a fine
arts center is a great example
of this. Students and faculty
in the music and theater de
partments are working with the
administration to construct a

new performing arts building.
Through announcements at all
productions and encouraging
petitions, they have gotten
good initial success.
The third thing to keep in
mind is to always be willing to
compromise. Holding firm to
every goal, regardless of con
sequences will make you seem
valiant and romantic, but lost
causes and last stands often are.
Success comes through com
promise.
Shelby Foote one said that
as Americans, our true genius
is for compromise. It is not a
betrayal of your ideals if you
can gain some success even

when you can not win the
whole thing. Remember noth
ing happens over night. The
way must be paved with these
small successes first.
Only as last resort should
you even consider sinking
down to that kind of public dis
play. You do nothing to aid
your cause and worse still, you
reinforce your opposition's re
solve not to bargain with you.
I do not know of anything that
happened this year that would
cause another such display this
year. Still I wanted to give this
advice to anyone with a griev
ance who was planning some
thing like that.


CONFLICT & Consensus

Our reputation is our responsibility

To the. Editor:

tification (two forms) as a non- ing stupid things. Act like you

I would hereby like to
express my thoughts in re
sponse to the front page ar
ticle last week featured in The
Gettysburgian. The article
described the recent forma
tion of a group called the
Hazel Alley Association. This
association is apparently up
set with college students who
are both loud and often ob
noxious, not to mention dirty
and disrespectful individuals.
While some of the
Association's prejudices may
be unfounded, most are prob
ably at least half true. How
ever, I don't think they really
need an association to deal
with the 'problem' of college
students.
The following is ad
dressed to my fellow college
students:

Have you ever tried to
get a job in Gettysburg? If so,
and you write on the appli
cation that you are a Gettys
burg College student, the
chances are you will be
turned down on the spot od
never will be asked to give an
interview.
Have you ever tried to
rent a movie in Gettysburg?
If so, you better not tell the
clerk that you are a Gettys
burg College student. De
spite the fact that you may be
living here for several years,
you can't get it because of
your status as a student.
Have you ever tried to
walk across the town square?
If so, you better think twice.
Borough police can smell col
lege students a mile away. I
have a couple of friends who
have been harassed by more
than one officer while simply
walking across the grass on
the circle.

Have you ever tried to
get a drink at a local tavern?
If so, don't let them know
that you are a college student.
Otherwise you will have to
produce twice as much iden-

student.
So what does all this
mean? Hey! Wake up kids!
The people already don't like
us. How come, you ask. Quite
simple. Here are the explana
tions I have gotten. In the
workplace we don't show up
on weekends. At the video
store we don't return videos for
weeks at a time. At the library
they stop issuing cards to stu
dents so that they can "cut their
losses" on stolen books and
materials. On the square it is
illegal to walk, I guess (no one,
ever gave me a good explana
tion for that one). At the tav
ern, underage college kids try
to sneak in to have a beer.
They don't need an orga
nization to oppose us. The
movement is already underway.
The power to stop it lies in your
future actions from this point
forward. What will you do to
rectify the situation?

I don't think anyone in
the great town of Gettysburg
needs a lecture on discrimina
tion and prejudice. It is wrong,
or so the last 2000 years have
taught us, to stereotype people
based on their age, sex, race,
creed, or nationality—and if 1
may add, status as a student.
The fact that a college profes
sor, an educated person one
would assume, has joined this
association is absolutely abhor
rent, but people do make mis
takes from time to time.

All that aside, there is
without a doubt some grounds
to the local residents' com
plaints. The things which they
often complain about are per
tinent to a small minority of the
college population. These
same things are also true for a
percentage of the Adams
County population. As college
students and as citizens within
this community—which is
what you must view yourselves
as—we do have certain rights
and responsibilities. Quit do-

are responsible individuals,
even if you are not. Make a
game of it. Try to act like you
have some common sense and
you will get respect back from
the townspeople. Money isn't
everything, and the town can
survive without ours, so quit
spitting on them every chance
you get and things just MIGHT
get better, for all of us.
Oh yeah, I am a college
student and a resident of Get
tysburg. Which ignorant ste
reotype would you like to ap
ply to me? The lines aren't al
ways so clear. Let us stop build
ing this wall.
Respectfully submitted,
J. Christopher Meixner

The Writing Center: Huber Hall
Monday-Thursday: 8 p.m.-lO p.m.
At the center peer tutors and
faculty members will help students
clarify an assignment, plan for an
assignment, organize a paper,
suggest ways to make troublesome
parts within a piece of writing
more effective, or discuss general
writing difficulties. The staff will
not proofread, edit, or ghostwrite
papers. Students can call X7576 or
drop in.
Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is

composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of
the College Union. The Allies
bulletin board is located in the
College Union across from the post
office. For more information,
contact any of the following
persons: Students: Christian King
(Allies moderator), Ext. 8I59;T.J.
Scott (Allies secretary/treasurer),

8:00 p.m. College Union Ballroom
ZIGGY MARLEY
and the MELODY MAKERS with Special Surprise Guest
No group connects reggae's rich and spiritual heritage with
today's music scene like Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers,
Blessed both by heredity and by singular talent, the Melody
Makers have carried on their father's legacy by delivering
stirring "roots" music and a dizzying array of other styles
on the eight acclaimed albums they have released since the
mid '80s. Along the way, they have sold millions of records,
won two Grammy Awards, and played to countless
devotees world wide.
and...GUSTER
When a band works entirely on its. own outside the parameters
of current trends, and on a shoestring budget, any
accomplishment is seen as a major one. But, every once in a
while, a band comes along that surpasses every expectation,
one-ups every industry naysayer and manages to excel on
their own terms. That hand is OUSTER.

Bullets flying high, trying to catch Terror

by Bill Davidson
Staff Reporter Splitting doubleheaders
with Ursinus and arch rival
Dickinson, the Women's soft
ball team fell one game behind
Western Maryland for the Cen
tennial Conference lead. Post
ing a record of 17-6 overall and
8-2 in conference play, the
Lady Bullets have found them
selves in the thick of a playoff
race. Angie Hoptak was bril
liant in the opener against the
Red Devils, pitching a 4-hit
shutout en route to her third
straight conference win.
Marybeth Korejko contributed
two RBI, going one-for-one
with a walk, in the 4-0 victory.
In the nightcap,
Dickinson used a four run fifth
inning, sending 10 batters to
the plate, to earn the split. Jen
White and Sara Graveline each
recorded multiple hit games in
the losing effort, while Alyson

Adams and Erin Killeen pro
vided_.stellar defense at the cor
ners. On Saturday, the women
dropped a 10-inning heart
breaker, falling 3-2 to the
Ursinus Bears. A sacrifice fly
in the top of the tenth proved
to end the pitching duel.
Hoptak was credited with the
loss, despite another strong
outing.
Hoptak pitched all 10 in
nings, striking out two, while
only allowing one earned run.
Karyn Miller and Marybeth
Korejko provided an offensive
spark in the losing effort, drill
ing three hits apiece against one
of the conferences best pitch¬

ers. The Lady Bullets re
sponded to this defeat by
pounding the Bears 8-1 in the

SportsWeekly
Bullets shoot way to head of conference

by Henry Fawell
Assistant News Editor

While most of the school
spent this past week gearing up
for the holiday respite, the
Men's Lacrosse team used the
warm weather wisely by vent
ing a little on-field frustration
against Western Maryland
College and Washington Col
lege, two teams that ripped the
Bullets in 1997 by a combined
score of 28-14.
While the two confer
ence losses last year may have
been the most disappointing of
the season, this week's 15-9
victory over Western Mary
land, and a 7-3 triumph over
Washington, have catapulted
the Bullets to the brink of the
Centennial Conference crown,
a title they have not claimed
since the 1995 season.

As Western Maryland
rolled into Musselman Sta
dium on Wednesday, last year's
10-5 loss against the Green
Terror weighed heavy on the
minds of those Gettysburg
players who were there. "They

Jamie Bateman (11) makes his move past opposing defenders. ' by Emily

came in unranked at the time.
We didn't give them much

thought and we paid for it,"
said middie Andrew Edgerton,
"Everyone was thinking about
it on Wednesday."
After spotting WMC the
game's first goal, the Bullets'
silenced any effort on behalf of
the Green Terror to duplicate
last year's upset. It would be
another thirteen minutes before
they could find the net again,
and by that time Gettysburg
had a firm grip on the game's
tempo.
While ten different play
ers were able to score for the
Bullets, the most notable offen
sive performance came from
All-Conference defenseman
Brian Abbot who, one week af
ter scoring his first career goal,
racked up two more scores, in
cluding a fancy left-handed shot
coming out of transition.

Ross Garretson led the
Bullets' offense with three goals
and one assist, while Abbot, Lee
Hemming and Jamie Bateman
each scored twice. Mark Pol
lack, Rob Crowe, Doug Sage,
Christian Cronin, Pete
Milhman and Kevin Callahan

rounded out the scoring with
a goal each, Goalie Andrew
Barter spearheaded a solid de
fensive effort as he stopped 15
shots. Chestertown, Md.,
hometown to Washington Col
lege, has also been a source of
discomfort for the Bullets as
well. The Shoreman got a grip
on the Centennial title two
years ago by slamming the
door on Gettysburg, the '94
and '95 champs. Last year's
18-9 thumping of Gettysburg
solidified a second straight

title. On Saturday, though, the
Bullets fed off of an outstand
ing defensive effort and loos
ened, at least temporarily, the
Shoremens' two year strangle
hold on the crown. Goalie An
drew Barter, who was credited
with 16 saves by game's end,
teamed up with Brian Abbot,
Justin Domingos, and Mike
McCrain to hold Washington
College to a humbling three
goal output.
Not only was the defen
siye performance superb, but

it was nearly mistake-free, as
well. Gettysburg was only
called for the three penalties in
the entire contest, then stuffed
the Shoreman man-up team by
allowing only one shot in ex
tra-man situations.
Midfielder Lee Hemming
sparked the Bullets' offense as
he ripped the first of his two
goals past All-American Any
Taibl in the game's opening
minutes. From then on, Gettys
burg refused to slow down as
they piled up a 5-0 lead before
the Shoremen could slip in their
first goal.
Washington managed to
climb back to a 5-3 deficit at
the end of the third quarter, but
goals by Sage and Mark Pollack
in final period helped seal the
upset.

With the victory, Gettys
burg snapped Washington's 17
game conference win streak,
which dated back to the 1995
season. This week's conference
matchups against Dickinson
and Swarthmore are now more
important than ever, as Gettys
burg remains as the last unde
feated team in the conference.

Grossberg pleads
guilty to manslaughter

Spring Fest!

Sweetheart of former student faces imprisonment

by Dan Larkin
News Editor

The Associated Press reported
yesterday that the plea agreement
was reached after Grossberg's attor
neys reviewed a transcript of an in
terview Peterson had with prosecu
tors. Peterson reportedly said that
the baby was blue at delivery and
he thought that it was dead.
Peterson also told authorities
that Grossberg had considered get
ting an abortion in the spring of
1996, but decided against it.
Grossberg's lawyers confirmed that
she did consider the abortion.
Grossberg's attorneys main
tained that she believed she was only
four or five months pregnant at the
time of the delivery. She apparently
had a medical exam in July 1996
that did not reveal that she was preg
nant. The teens have both been liv
ing at home with their families, and
have been electronically monitored.
They were each free on $300,000
bail.

Amy Grossberg, high-school
sweetheart of former Gettysburg
College student Brian Peterson
pleaded guilty to manslaughter yes
terday in the death of their infant

son. The child of the affluent teens
from Wycoff, New Jersey was found
in a hotel trash bin in November
1996. Coroners for the state of Dela
ware claimed that the child was born
alive at full term, and died due to
multiple skull fractures caused by
shaking and blunt trauma.
Grossberg and Peterson, both
19, were charged with first-degree
murder after the child's body was
discovered.
Last month Grossberg's attor
neys asked to be tried separately from
Peterson and asked to introduce new
evidence placing blame for the
newborn's death solely upon the
former Gettysburg student.
According to Grossberg's law
yers, polygraph tests showed that she
never saw the child, and thought that
she had a miscarriage.

Peterson pleaded guilty to man
slaughter in the case in March, and
agreed to testify against Grossberg.
His attorney's claimed that he
believed the child to be stillborn, and
put the child in a trash bag per
Grossberg's orders to "Get rid of it!"
Despite the fact that
Grossberg's attorney, Robert
Tanebaum said in March that
Peterson's plea "[did not] change our
strategy at all," it currently appears
otherwise.

'$$_ekettd% _Spiring Fest activities on Stine Lake.

¦ ,'
¦ ''

Grossberg was set to go to trial
on May 4, and could have faced up
to life in prison if convicted.
She entered the courtroom in
tears and embraced family members
before entering her plea. Like
Peterson last month, she answered
in the affirmative to question if she
understood her actions.
Grossberg's sentencing was set
for July 9, as was Peterson's. A man
slaughter conviction carries a maxi
mum penalty of 10 years.
Deputy Attorney General Paul
Wallace said that the baby's death
"was caused by her chilling indiffer
ence," and felt that imprisonment
would be an "appropriate" sentence
for the teens.

Review celebrates 10th anniversary

Gettysburg
chapter of OBK
turns 75

by Laura Root
Staff Reporter From the beginning, the
founders of The Gettysburg Re
view worked for greatness.
Its first issue was published
January 15, 1988. It had every
thing that the staff wanted—
strong writing, professional pub
lication design, and impressive
artwork.
"We wanted to make what
a literary magazine should be,"
said Peter Stitt, editor of the Re
view. "We wanted to start out
with something really good that
we could base the rest of our
magazines on. No poor publica
tions, not even the first time."
This strong work ethic has
helped to produce one of the fin
est literary magazines in the na¬

tion. The goal of the magazine is
simple. "We want to publish the
best writing in America," said
Stitt. According to its readers and

critics, it has.
The Review has been
home to the works of Ritd
Dove, Donald Hall, Garrison
Keeler, Joyce Carol Oates,
John Barrymore, Elizabeth
Bishop, Robert Bly, E.L.
Doctorow, and Robert Frost.
Three Gettysburg Re
views are published each
year by a staff of four pro
fessionals and three students.
The workers sort
through many submissions
to decide which ones will fit
into the magazine's frame
work best. It usually takes
three months to put an en
tire Review together.
The staff works on sev
eral Reviews simultaneously,
however, so this is only a
rough estimate. Some works
are even ready for next
year's publication.
Poetry, fiction, and
non-fiction can be found
within the magazine. It con¬

tains the work of about 24 au
thors. The Gettysbmg Review
adds to both the literary com
munity and the Gettysburg
College community. It brings
prestige to the Gettysburg Col
lege image and provides the
students with a lively source of
intellectual and artistic mate
rial. To celebrate its tenth an
niversary, The Gettysburg Re
view invited two prominent
writers to come and read at the
College. Last week, former
Poet Laureate and Pulizer Prize
winner Rita Dove read selected
poems.
This fall, Donald Hall
will visit the Gettysburg cam
pus. He is New Hampshire's
Poet Laureate and the winner
of many awards, including the
National Book Critics Circle
Award, a Caldecott Medal, and

from staff reports
The Gettysburg College
chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, Iota
chapter of Pennsylvania, is cel
ebrating its 75th anniversary
this year. Founded in 1776 at
The College of William &
Mary, Phi Beta Kappa is the
oldest honorary society in the
United States. It exists prima
rily to give public recognition
to excellence in undergraduate
liberal arts studies, to promote
liberal learning, and to support
and encourage scholars in their
activities,
The Gettysburg College
chapter was founded on Janu
ary 11,1923.
On Thursday, 45 mem
bers of the class of 1998 will
be inducted into Phi Beta
Kappa, two others were in
ducted in the fall, the initiation
ceremony will be followed by

the Los Angeles Times Book
Prize in Poetry.
Both poets are members
of the Advisory Board of The
Gettysburg Review and are con
tributing editors.
Dove was one of the
original members of the Advi
sory Board. Last week's visit
to campus was not her first.
Ten years ago, all nine of
the Review's editors visited
Gettysburg. Hall has been here
twice. Before Dove read from
her works, she gave a few
words on The Gettysburg Re
view. "It is one of the few
magazines that I look forward
to getting in the mail," she says,
"I can always count on the
good quality."

This year, The _Gettysburg
Review is not only celebratinj
ten years of being, but ten year
of being great.

a special dinner and program
celebration. Anne Fradiman,
the new editor of The Ameri
can Scholar will be the keynote
speaker. The title of her address
is "Procrustes and the Culture
wars". Dr. James Lusardi,
Francis A. march Professor of
English at Lafayette College
and Phi Beta Kappa Senator
will bring greetings from the
phi Beta Kappa society. More
than a dozen Gettysburg Col
lege alumni who were inducted
into Iota chapter more than
fifty years ago will be recog
nized.

Seniors raise $18,300 for scholarship fund

from Staff Reports
The Class of 1998 has
currently raised over $18,300
towards the Senior Scholarship
Prize Fund. The Scholarship,
established by the class of
1996, provides two scholar
ships annually to rising seniors.
The scholarships, presented
during Commencement cer
emonies in May, are awarded
to the man and woman in the
rising senior class who best ex
emplify a Gettysburg College
education. Candidates for the
scholarship must have a mini
mum 3.3 GPA and be involved
in various activities and honor
societies.

The members of the Senior Scholarship Committee with Dr.
Haaland.

The first Senior Schol
arship Prize was awarded last
year to current seniors Dan
Crowell and Lindsey Musser.
Funds for the gift are
raised by the Senior Scholar
ship Committee, which is cur
rently made up of twenty-seven
members, and is co-chaired by
Sara Glatfelter, Rebecca Card,
Brian Rusignuolo, and Mat
thew Eisenberg.
The goal set by the Com
mittee this year was to raise
$19,980 from 50% of the Class
of 1998 by April 24.
Currently the Com
mittee has gotten 44% of the
class to participate, and earned
an unprecedented amount of

Senior Scholarship co-chairs with President Haaland
(from left, Sara Glatfelter, Becky Card, Brian Rusignuolo
and Matt Eisenberg.)

money for the fund. Assistant
Director of Annual Giving
Kristen Anderson attributes the
success of the Committee to the
co-chairs. "They've done an
incredible job and worked re
ally hard," she said.
Though the Senior
Scholarship Prize is a relatively
new program, it is part of a
longstanding tradition at the
College. It grew out of what
was previously the Senior Class
Gift to the College.
Members of the Senior

Class who make a pledge of
$100 or more by June 30,1998
will become members of the
1998 Cupola Society Associates
program.
The Cupola Associates
program allows ' younger
alumni of Gettysburg to play a
key role in the future of the
College that was previously
available only to older alumni.
Students who make a
pledge to the fund now are not
required to pay right away. No
money has to be paid until one
year following graduation.



College to host cabaret

GCPR .
Gettysburg College will
host a "Jazz Club Cabaret" fea
turing The Buzz Jones Big Band
with special guest George
Rabbai at 8 p.m., Tuesday, April
28, in the College Union Ball
room. The performance, which
will include the music of
George Gershwin and Woody
Herman, is sponsored by the
Gettysburg College Social Ini
tiative Committee and the Jazz
Appreciation Society. The con
cert is open to the public and
free of charge. Doors will open
at 7:30 p.m., and light refresh
ments will be available.
George Rabbai's first
national recognition as a trum
peter came when he joined the
Woody Herman orchestra,
touring as a jazz soloist. Dur
ing his two-year stay, Rabbai
performed festivals and concert

halls throughout the country
and abroad and recorded with
Herman on the Concord and
Toshiba EMI labels.
After touring with
Herman Orchestra, Rabbai was
selected as part of the Woody
Herman All-Star small group,
performing with artists like Sal
Nistico, Jake Hanna, Nat
Pierce, and Frank Wess. He has
performed as a soloist with the
Concord Jazz All-Stars. As a
leader, Rabbai has recorded
with jazz greats Hank Jones,
Rufus Reid, and Mel Lewis.
An active jazz per
former and educator, Rabbai is
currently on the faculties of
Philadelphia's University of the
Arts, The College of New Jer
sey in Glassboro. He makes fre
quent appearances at area
schools as a jazz clinician, fes
tival adjudicator, and feature
artist.

OBK editor to speak

GCPR

The Spring 1998 issue
of "The American Scholar,"
a journal that conducts an
ongoing public conversation
about literature, science,
culture,and life of the mind,
is the first under Fadiman's
editorship.

tion is part of the celebration
of the 75th anniversary of
the Gettysburg College
chapter of Phi Beta Kappa.

The editor of Phi Beta
Kappa's quarterly journal,
"The American Scholar," will
discuss "Procrustes and the
Culture wars" at Gettysburg
College on Thursday, April 3,
in the College Union Ball
room. Anne Fadiman's pre
sentation, which will begin at
8:45 p.m. following the
College's Phi Beta Kappa ini
tiation ceremony and ban
quet, is open to the public free
of charge.

Psi Chi inducts
14 members

from Press Release
Psi Chi, the National
Honor Society in Psychology,
is proud to announce that the
Gettysburg College chapter of
Psi Chi inducted 14 new mem
bers into the honor society on
Friday, April 17th, 1998.
Psi Chi was founded in
1929 for the purpose of en
couraging, stimulating and
maintaining excellence in
scholarship, and advancing the
science of psychology. Mem
bership is awarded to graduate
and undergraduate men and
women who are making the
study of psychology one of
their major interests and who
meet the qualification. Psi Chi
is a member of the American
Psychological Association
(APA) and the American psy
chological Society (APS). Psi

Chi has grown over the past 65
years into one of the largest
and most successful honor so
cieties in the world with over
840 chapters located at college
and university campuses
throughout the U.S. The in
ductees are:
Rachel Acuna
D. Sheffield Maclntyre
Meghan Anderton
David Michael Mahoney
Leah Kristin Bagley
Anne Eliza Main
T. Pemberton Brown
Courtney B. Marotta
Allison F. Kennedy
Andrea E. Russell
Sarah H. Lindahl
Amy J. Sedor
M. Elizabeth Lisi
Amy L. Valentine

The response to this sur
vey was impressive...and di
verse. Many people returned
the survey, and it was quickly
discovered that there are lots
of opinionated people here.
And they feel very passionately
about many things.

ample of this. Many profes
sors were named as favorite,
but because of this, no one pro

for asking.

tual chair in the library.

vorites listed above? Many
people didn't. Maybe The Best
of Gettysburg 2 (date un
known) will better reflect your

Reel Hits & Misses Object of our contention

by Dan Larkin and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Mike: The new movie
starring Friends star Jennifer
Aniston is a romantic comedy
known simply as The Object of
My Affection . Aniston plays
Nina, a youth counselor living
in Brooklyn, who meets
George, a gay school teacher,
at a party.

and George, played by Paul

bers of Friends than I ever

ably, I've been pleasantly sur

come to an end with The Ob

Both George and Nina

are people with difficult prob
lems. George has recently bro
ken up with his boyfriend of
four years and Nina is pregnant
by her overbearing boyfriend,
Vince, played in a solid perfor
mance by John Pankow (Ira
from Mad About You).
Needless to say, they be

that Nina ends up asking
George to help raise her child
when it comes into the world.
The plot moves for

though at times it is a bit /

very well and are believ
able as friends and kindred
spirits.

extremely well by a strong sup
porting cast.

To say that the plot of this
movie is "a bit slow" is quite
the understatement. It drags

and drags and drags. I guess the

Warrior Poets play for Irish children Monday

by Barb Dickson
Features Editor
The Warrior Poets, an
Irish music group made up of
sophomores Ian Isherwood and
Jay Spiese and senior Paul
"Hutch" Hutchinson, will per
form for the last time on cam
pus on Monday, April 27, in the
Junction from 8 to 10 p.m.
The group is performing as a
benefit to raise money for the
Irish Children's Fund and will
be joined on stage by friends.
Hutchinson says the
show will be a "good, rowdy,
fun show. It's late in the se
mester and people need a good
time." According to
Hutchinson, the group wanted
to do a big last show, play some
new songs, and make it worth
something. That's where the
idea for making it a benefit con
cert comes in.

The concert itself will be
free, but the group is asking for
a donation of at least one dol
lar. Anyone who donates more
than $10 may also be given a
tape of an earlier Warrior Po
ets concert, recorded in Febru
ary. The availability of the
tapes has yet to be determined.
The Irish Children's Fund
(ICF) is a group that works to
bring groups of both Catholic
and Protestant Irish children
together in the United States.

The students, all eleven to
twelve years old, live together
for six weeks during the sum
mer and get to know children
not of their faith. Hopefully
they will create friendships that
will weather the trip back to
Ireland and create understand
ing in the war-torn country.
The ICF, founded in
1982, is dedicated to salvaging
some of the joys of childhood
for the children of Northern
Ireland, and to building a foun
dation for future peace. Its

goals are to teach tolerance,
understanding, and respect for
the religious, political, and cul
tural beliefs of others, laying
the groundwork for communi
cation.
Among Isherwood's
many hare-brained ideas (after
forming the group, playing in
the Junction, and getting a job
at Buckley's) is the idea to unite
the island of Ireland with the
music of the Warrior Poets,
"like Bill and Ted," says
Hutchinson.

The group was originally
contacted to perform for
Stephanie Sellars' senior thesis
on Irish music in America.
They thought at first about get
ting a large number of campus
bands together to perform, but
decided the idea would be too
difficult to carry out at this busy
time of the semester.

Friends of the group who
will join them on stage during
the performance include Sam
Goodman, who wrote a song
for them, and Sellars, as well
as senior Joie Bucci and other
seniors. "It's sort of a last hur
rah for the seniors," according
to Hutchinson.
The concert will be vid
eotaped, and a copy will be
given to GCTV
The group was formed
last Thanksgiving, and had
their first performance early
this semester. The Warrior Po
ets have performed at the Junc
tion a couple of times, and per
form regularly at the Irish bar
in town, Buckley's. They may
perform at the bar one more
time before graduation. "My
parents still haven't seen me
perform," commented
Hutchinson.

Hutchinson, after gradu
ating in May, will be working
in Gettysburg next year.
Isherwood, however, will be
studying abroad, so the Warrior
Poets will have to disband.
Hutchinson is thinking of
forming another Irish band.
The new band need to think of
a new name though—they
wouldn't be the Warrior Poets.
Even so, "there's still a
future to the band,"
Hutchinson states, and the
band's future is one to watch.

Jones, Rabbai
perform concert

from press release
The Buzz Jones Big Band,
with special guest George
Rabbai, trumpet and scat, for
merly with Woody Herman's
"Thundering Herd" Jazz Or
chestra, will be Celebrating
Gershwin on Tuesday, April
28, at 8 p.m. in the CUB Ball
room. Doors open at 7:30 and
admission is free. Refresh
ments will be provided.
Rabbai's first national
recognition as a trumpeter
came when he joined the
Woody Herman Orchestra,
touring as a jazz soloist. Dur
ing his two year stay, Rabbai
performed at jazz festivals and
concert halls throughout the
United States and abroad, and
recorded with Herman on the
Concord and Toshiba EMI la
bels.

His unique style of scat
singing prompted Herman to
reinstate and rerecord the clas
sic arrangement of the big band
be-bop hit Lemon Drop as a
vocal feature. Lemon Drop is
also the title of Rabbai's own
CD, released in 1997, on DBK
Records.
After touring with the
Herman Orchestra, Rabbai
was selected as part of the
Woody Herman All-Star small
group, performing with artists
like Sal Nistico, J ake Hanna,
Nat Pierce, George Duvivier_,
Scott Hamilton, and Frank
Wess. He has also performed
as a soloist with the Concord
Jazz AllStars.
As a leader, Rabbai has
recorded with jazz greats Hank
Jones, Rufus Reid, and Mel
Lewis for the Naxos label.

Rabbai's lyrical trumpet
sound is featured in the
soundtrack of Baseball , a film
by Ken Burns, which first aired
nationally on PBS in 1994. He
can also be heard in Burns' epic
documentary The West.
Rabbai has been cur
rently working as a soloist be
hind vocalist Rosemary
Clooney, and is featured on her
"Demi-Centennial: A Girl
Singer's Golden Anniversary"
television special for A&E.

He has also recorded
with Margaret Whiting and
was featured with Tony Bennett
on his television special, "Tony
Bennett With Love."
Admired for his tone,
phrasing and swinging style,
Rabbai infuses his perfor
mances with humor and per
sonality. From his exuberant
scat vocals to his warm
flugelhorn and wide array of
assorted mutes, Rabbai's musi
cal colors fill the complete
spectrum of jazz.
His performing engage
ments have included Carnegie
Hall and the famed Rainbow
Room, as well as European jazz
festivals, New York City's St.
Regis Hotel and many East
Coast jazz clubs.

An active jazz performer
and educator, he is currently on
the faculties of Philadelphia's
University of the Arts, The
College of New Jersey in Tren
ton, and Rowan College of
New Jersey in Glassboro. He
makes frequent appearances at
area schools as a jazz clinician,
festival adjudicator, and fea
tured artist.
John Williams "Buzz"
Jones is the Director of Bands
and Associate Professor of
Music at Gettysburg College.
He is responsible for conduct
ing the Symphonic Band, Jazz
Ensemble, Marching Band, and
instrumental chamber en
sembles.
The Buzz Jones' Big Band
was formed in 1979. It was
started simply as a "rehearsal
band," meaning it was basically
a group of people bonded to
gether through the common
thread of music.

The band became popu
lar by word of mouth, and be
gan doing small gigs. At the
peak of their career in the
1980's, they were playing ap
proximately 100 dates a year.
With Jones' teaching career,
however, they had to cut back.
The band now performs be
tween 12 and 15 times a year.
The concert is sponsored
by the Social Initiative Com
mittee and the Jazz Apprecia
tion Society.

AIDS affects all

by Amy Hackman and Rebecca who is sexually active can con
Layton tract this disease.

Contributing Reporters
The HIV and AIDS epi
demic has been growing since
the late 1970's. Scientists and
doctors have been struggling
f n r

years in
hopes of find
ing a
cure. AS
w a _ij
identK

fied asWw _JH_^_A
t h e _^ _SU _* 1 ""^^^ b ~ l
"homo
sexual white male disease" be
cause most AIDS and HIV cases
were found among homo
sexual males. Currently this
disease is prominent among
heterosexual females. The
myth that AIDS and HIV is
only contained within the ho
mosexual community is false
and needs to be addressed.
Anyone, any race, any gender,

The only way to protect
yourself is by abstaining from
intercourse or by you and your
partner getting tested. The
more education there is about
AIDS and HIV, the lower the

number of cases there will be.
The top ten states in
number of reported cases are
(in order) New York, Califor
nia, Florida, Texas, New Jersey,
Puerto Rico, Illinois, Pennsyl
vania, Georgia, and Maryland.
The top ten cities are New York
City, Los Angeles, San Fran
cisco, Miami, Washington
D.C., Chicago, Houston, Phila¬

delphia, Newark, and Atlanta.
AIDS is so deadly due to
its ability to mutate rapidly to
counteract the effects of any
drugs used to resist it. Drugs
used in HIV therapy work by
inhibiting specific viral en
zymes essential to the virus'

normal func
tion or replica
tion. It ih es
sential li you
believe that you
are at risk for
AIDS that you
get tested.
Only about
20% of people
at risk are

tested; this is how the disease
spreads.
In the past year, the death
rate has dropped by half not
only due to the new medica
tions, but also because of the
awareness about the disease,
who it affects, and how it can
be prevented. HIV and AIDS
can affect anyone, so don't
think, "That could never hap
pen to me." It could.


Health Beat

Cancer sticks

by Wesley Thurmond and
Andrew Addonizio
Contributing Reporters
Despite the overwhelm
ing statistics, the tobacco in
dustry still claims that there
is no link between smoking
and cancer. In 1990, it was
estimated that over 419,000
people died from diseases di
rectly related to smoking ciga
rettes. This statistic accounts
for one-fifth or all deaths in
the United States.
Not only does smoking
have health problems related
to it, but the economic factor
is astronomical. Over 97 mil
lion dollars are spent each
year to treat smoking related
diseases. This does not in
clude such things as smoking
related fires, birth defects
caused by smoke, or illness
due to second-hand smoke.

It is know that tobacco
smoke contains 4000 chemi
cals, including 200 known
poisons. This fact alone
shows a great link between

cancer and cigarettes. Smoking
can also cause emphysema and
chronic bronchitis.
The best way to reduce
your risk of cancer is to fully
abstain from smoking. It has
been found that non-smokers
live 25 percent longer than those
who do smoke.
Sidestream smoke, which
is blown at bystanders, contains
higher concentrations of some
harmful compounds than the
mainstream smoke inhaled by
the smoker.
To help fight the war on
smoking, Congress has set regu
lations on the tobacco industry.
All states have banned the sale
of cigarettes to anyone under 18,
and have banned the use of
vending machine cigarette sales.
Many states now ban advertis
ing on billboards and public
transportation.

For a healthier lifestyle for
you and others around you, ab
stain from smoking cigarettes.
Quitting smoking will improve
your health and could possibly
save your life.

Greek tragedy at
Gettysburg

From staff reports
On Friday, May 1, Clas
sical Studies 264, Ancient
Tragedy, will be performing
Euripides' The Phoenician
Women as interpreted
through the eyes of directors
Jeremy Knapman, Travis
Kreider, Marty Masar, John
Meier, and Erich Peitzsch.
The play will take place
in front of Penn Hall, on the
Musselman Library side, and
will begin at 3 p.m.
The Ancient Tragedy
class puts on a play each year
on the reading day before fi
nals. Past plays include last
year's Amphitryon.
Oedipus discovers that
he has just married his own
mother and killed his father
and so blinds himself in pun
ishment. He then hands over
the rule of Thebes to his two
sons which causes conflict and
civil war. Some Phoenician

Women who are trapped in
Thebes witness the horrors of
the war.
This play, written in 410
B.C. and considered to be among
Euripides' most famous works in
Plutarch's time, about the con
flict between two brothers at
tempting to gain the heritage of
their father's land, is a great rep
resentation of a typical Greek
tragedy.
Euripides, who began writ
ing plays at the age of 18, wrote
approximately 92 plays, of
which 18 remain. He was the
third of the three great Greek
dramatists, Aeschylus and
Sophocles being the other two.
He was quite popular in his
own time and was the object of
satire by Athenian writers of
comedy, particularly
Aristophanes.

Come out on the reading
day at 3 p.m. and see how Greek
tragedies were performed way
back in ancient Greece.

Library BULLETin

by Libby Musselman
Library Columnist
Q: If it's too late to send
a request on Interlibrary loan
and hope to get it in time to
write my paper what can I get
NOW to finish my research?
You might be surprised
that you have some excellent
options right in Musselman Li
brary. Most importantly,

don't panic! Con
sult with a refer
ence librarian if
you can't find what
you need. Refer¬

ence librarians are I
at the reference I
desk Monday-Fri- I
day 9 am-5 pm and I
Sunday-Thursday
pm-lOpm. Or sign I
up _^^
desk for a Research ^^^
Paper Consultation. _^
If you're looking for
journal articles, the place to
begin is with Periodical Indexes
& Abstracts on the library's
webpage. The library has
nearly 100 indexes, so feel free
to ask a librarian to recommend
the best one(s). Periodical in
dexes contain citations to jour
nal articles. Not all citations
are for journals owned by
Musselman Library, but the
chances of getting citations to
journals that ARE in

Musselman Library are better
in some indexes than others.
Also some of the indexes have
the full text of the articles.
You can also search the
Fulltext Journals &c Texts area
of the library's website. There
are a couple ways to use this
part of the website. You
can

_^mmmmW check
to see if the library
has an electronic subscription
to a given journal that you have
a citation for, or you can search
different groups of electronic
journals. The library is your
link to thousands of electronic
articles in hundreds different
journals. Ask a librarian for
help if you don't find what you
need.

Desperate for a book? If
you can't wait for Interlibrary
Loan, consider driving to an
other college library in central
PA. Search the ACLCP WebCat
(there's a link from the,library
homepage) to see if a nearby
library has the book you need.
ACLCP is Associated College
Libraries of Central Pennsylva
nia, and it includes schools

within an easy drive like
Shippensburg, F&M,
I Dickinson, York,
I Messiah, and others.
I Your Gettysburg ID
I will get you free bor
I rowing at any ACLCP
I school.
I Libby's tip of
I the week: "Freshmen

shall at no time wear
_^ I white trousers and
shall at all times wear
J only plain black socks
t0_^ and black neckties."
These and other words of
advice are display in the Fresh
man G-books, in the exhibit
cases on the main floor of the
library. Stop in and see the
archive's collection of dinks—
and if you don't know what a
dink is, you'll have to read the
G-book!
Today's question is
timely; please send more of
your comments, questions,
and/or complaints to
lmussel@gettysburg.edu
