CONFLICT & Consensus

Everyone Should Study Abroad

enough, I chose to come back

To the Editor:
Disclaimer: Any sarcas
tic, negative comments di
rected at a particular group
on campus is merely a gener
alization that is not meant to
offend any individual.
As a graduating senior,
I spend a lot of time reflect
ing on the past four years. We
are all aware of the debates
that have spilled across the
pages of The Gettysburgian
with the two most volatile is
sues being Greek vs. Indepen
dent and diversity. Before

you stop reading, I assure you
that this is not another poorly
written, squashy stream of
complaints about the institu
tion we all chose to attend. I
assume that all the students
at Gettysburg College are
here out of their own free
will; if not, well, I can't imag
ine anyone being dragged
kicking and screaming by
their parents to a college that
costs $30,000 a year. Finan
cial issues are not my concern
in this letter, but I can con
tinue along the theme of "free
will."

At first glance at all the
Greeks running around doing
juvenile things because a fel
low brother or sister tells
them to, and at the flocks of
sheep that thunder into Servo
every evening, Gettysburg
College does not seem like
the ideal place to grow as an
individual. Yet, adversity of
ten sprouts integrity, just as
suffering allows one to feel
and appreciate happiness to
a greater degree. Take me as
an example of this sociologi¬

cal phenomenon. After one
semester at Gettysburg, I was
ready to transfer. But I'm still
here. Why? Besides the fact
that I never actually applied
to any other schools, I rea
soned that if I go abroad for
one full /ear, three years
won't be so bad. Actually, it's
been pretty darn good. I
would say that the best thing
that Gettysburg has done for
me is provide me with the
opportunity to expand my
education into the world.

Isn't that what we're all here
for, to learn about the world?
Gettysburg is far from being a
microcosm of planet Earth (it's
probably closer to Mars, since
we're so ahen-ated...ha ha);
behold the necessity of study
ing abroad, or spending some
time off-campus in a more di
verse community via a service
learning project, for example.
One does not have to
leave the country in order to
experience "diversity" (for lack
of a better word); go to New
York City, Arizona, or the Sea
Islands and you will discover
that the United States does not
lack culture; too many students
are just too sheltered in their
personal lives to realize or care
that it exists. Yet, the many
colors of America make up only
a fraction of the prism. Every
student should go abroad at

some point during his/her
higher education. I do not
mean a two week European
vacation, American style. I
mean whether it is two weeks
or two years, one must live in
another country. I have heard
students complain that spend
ing a semester away from Get
tysburg would interfere with
his/her major or that it is too
expensive. Getting away from
Gettysburg does not necessar
ily mean physically leaving
Gettysburg during the aca
demic year. There are many
abroad opportunities during
the summer; you can even le
gally work in some countries,
and get a practical as well as
cultural experience. As for the
cost, a semester at Gettysburg
is more expensive than some
study abroad programs. I do
not wish to ramble on like a

study abroad brochure, so for
more information contact
Rebecca Bergen at OffCampus
Studies. The important thing
is to open your mind beyond
Gettysburg, because, as St. Au
gustine said, "The world is a
book, and those who do not
travel, read only a page."
That brings me back to
the idea of free will. I chose to
go abroad, and surprisingly

If I could have completed a
degree in England or France
(where I spent my junior year,
respectively) I probably would
have stayed. But for conve
nience and to please my par
ents, I reluctantly came back to
Gettysburg. I came back ex
pecting everything to be the
same, and weekends to be spent
sighing in my room looking at
photos of my European travels,
reminiscing about wild nights
in pubs and clubs. But, some
thing had changed. Weekend
thoughts went from "what to
do, what to do" to "what can I
do...I can do this, this, or
this..." without even thinking

about leaving campus. I left the
Dive to return to the Junction.
(Of course, I knew about the
renovation before leaving, but
it was quite a shock anyway).
Whether it's the coffeehouse,
a concert, a speaker, a poetry
reading, weekend or weekday
the Junction is never left in
bubbling emptiness (allusion to
the bubbly pillars of the Dive).
Along the lines of improved
social programming are BYOB
events, and talk about building
a bar and maybe even a dance
club on campus. So congratu
lations to SAC and others for
their efforts in making Gettys
burg a better place to party.

In addition to the long
awaited changes that have fi
nally come forth and those that
are in the midst of creation, I
have noticed a slight decrease
in the student apathy for which
Gettysburg College is s known.
There may not be less com
plaining, but there is definitely
a lot more doing. Unfortu
nately, these changes have not
affected everyone. The echo of
"there's nothing to do here" is
still in the air. And though
there are more minority and
international students than my
first year, I still smell a cloud
of intolerance floating around.
- continued on page 13 -
see ABROAD

Consider this

When it comes to getting
students fired up, the best in
stigator isn't a anti-Greek ar
ticle but the debate over
Macintosh versus PCs.
There are too many con
sequences for Gettysburg to
become a PC-only environ
ment, just as converting to all
Macs is unreasonable.
The College supported
Macintoshes when the Classes
of '98, '99, and '00 arrived.
Ironically, at those times, one
of the College's selling points
was that it had equal numbers
of Mac and PC labs, yet the
current proposal threatens to
exclude the computers that the
College endorsed for students
prior to their enrollment.
Denying support to Mac
users is not only unfair but
unjustified. The resources to
maintain those machines on
campus are minimal. This
move will not reduce the num
ber of computers on campus
but simply shift the balance to
PC, a type of machine not
without its own faults.
The Mac phaseout would
alienate too many incoming
students that would want to
bring their Macs from home.
Such drastic measures would
also cause students who own

Macintoshes to feel obligated to
purchase a PC system-another
expense to discourage would
be students.
While Mac-bashing is
trendy, the facts are that new
Macs have faster processors
than the Pentium II, are easier
to use and network (although
PCs are quickly learning that
Apple is on target and has be
gun to follow the Mac lead),
and are better for graphic arts
and publishing applications.
While the cost of updat
ing the Mac labs with new ma
chines has been argued, a col
lege that wants to upgrade its
academic standing should not
fear expense when it comes to
purchasing cutting-edge tech
nology to bolster the education
of its students.
Macs and Mac clones are
still used in the "real world"
that college prepares us for.
The real world uses a lot of dif
ferent kinds of computers, and
learning any one of them
should be ample preparation
for working in the Information
Age. The question should not
be Mac versus PC but rather a
matter of allowing students to
use the operating system of
their choice.

The Gettysburgian Publication Code
Stories printed in The Gettysburgian are accurate to the knowledge
of our reporters. Editors should be contacted by letter if errors
occur. Signed letters to the Editor will be printed without
name(s) on a request-only basis.

"Consider This" is a weekly feature expressing views on issues of concern
to the campus community. Written by members of The Gettysburgian
staff, the feature represents the opinion of the editorial board and is not
meant to reflect the opinions of the College as a whole


The Pachyderm's Pulpit

Republican changes now can mean big gains in 2000

by John Dunlap
Political Columnist
This week Republican
congressional leaders dumped
the entire United States tax
code into Boston Harbor as a
way to show their desire to
change the burdensome and
overly large federal tax sys
tem. Once again, the GOP
hopes to stand with our revo
lutionary forbears. However,
over three years after a Re
publican Revolution was pro
nounced, Republicans seem to
have lost their revolutionary
zeal. In 1995, Republicans
entered Congress in the ma
jority for the first time in forty
years. Seventy-three fresh
man Republicans in the
House o'f Representatives
were setting the tone and had

a Contract on America to work
from. They wanted a balanced
budget, tax cuts, regulatory re
form and tort reform. Today we
have a balanced budget, we have
received some tax cuts (but not
nearly enough), and no regula
tory or tort reforms. This is not
the complete fault of Republi
cans. The first one hundred days
of the Republican majority were
remarkable. They kept all of
their promises and had pre
empted the President. Bill
Clinton was forced into arguing
that he was still relevant. Within
a year, the White House spin
took over, along with a media
onslaught against House Speaker
Newt Gingrich of Georgia. On
the issue of the budget, the presi
dent demonized Republicans,
and things only got worse in the
1996 presidential campaign.
The 1996 Republican

nominee for the presidency,
former Senate Majority Leader
Robert Dole, seemed out of
touch with the conservative
movement and ran a poor cam
paign. In congressional races,
Republicans kept with the mes
sage and held on to Capital
Hill. 1997 would bring a still
divided Washington, but now
Republicans seemed afraid of
the president. The budget was
balanced, but no major reduc
tions in the size of government
were made and taxes are still
too high. Republicans talked
up tax reform but have only
held hearings, and GOP lead
ers are still divided. Speaker
Gingrich has survived one coup
attempt, and Majority Leader
Dick Armey has come under
assault by Republican sopho
mores in the House.

Just recently the days of
the old Democratic pork-bar
rel politics came back to the
House and Senate as a pork
barrel transportation bill was
passed. Its main author was the
Republican version of the
Democratic Senator, and pork
barrel king, Robert Byrd, Bud
Shuster of Pennsylvania.
Gettysburg's own history pro
fessor Norman Forness said it
correctly in his Urbanism in
American History course when
he stated, "Republicans know
how to spend when they want
to." The GOP is great at talk
ing tax cuts and reduction, but
Washington has trapped them.
Do not get me wrong,
things are much better than
they were four years ago when
we had an off and on liberal
Democratic president and
Democratic Congress. In

1994, the talk in Washington
was of tax increases, national
ized health-care and increased
government spending. Repub
licans have given us welfare
reform, the line-item veto and
health-care reform that Presi
dent Clinton could not deliver.
Republicans can get back
on track by maintaining the
Congress this year and electing
a President in 2000 who favors
basic reforms such as tax re
form. I do believe that repub
licans should just not wait the
Clinton presidency out. They
should be pushing for com
mon-sense reforms and debat
ing the president on the key is
sues of the day, not just watch
ing for the next presidential
scandal.
We have the majority for
the first time in forty years.
Let's do something with it.



CONFLICT & Consensus
Bothered "brother" bashes 'burgian

To the Editor:
In search of some
amusement, I decided to read
The Gettysburgian. As usual,
I was provided with hours of
laughs from this poorly writ
ten, researched, and pre
sented excuse for a paper.
Specifically, I chose to make
this overreaching generaliza
tion to stoop to the level of
your authors. Many instances
in your paper have been por
trayed in highly biased and
stereotypical fashion.
Instead of focusing on
this endless list of previous
mistakes, I would like an ex
planation from the nameless
author in the "Consider
this..." section of the paper to
defend his or her statement-

that "brothers were allowed to
continue their repulsive lifestyles
off campus." This statement is a
horrendous accusation. Assum
ing that you are somewhat edu
cated here at Gettysburg, igno
rance cannot be your excuse.
All-inclusive statements are
wrong both morally and ethi
cally when referring to a group
of people. Also, being a fellow
"brother," I'm extremely in
sulted that you have described
my lifestyle as "repulsive." Please
step off you pedestal and stop
judging others.
Also, I would like to com
ment to the people of the "Ha
zel Alley Association." Your
town is a fine town, but most of
the time your "townie" mental¬

ity is part of the problem. I
would like to know the answer
to a few trivial questions: Why
do the Gettysburg police wait
in the Ice House overflow lot
to give tickets to college stu
dents? Why are all the meters
in town free during the Christ
mas season while the college
meters are still ticketed? How
is Crack Alley coming? Are
there still bar fights once a
week at Hamilton's? Why am
I harassed and annoyed by loi
tering high school children at
7-11? Also my most important
one, Why do some of the land
lords charge -astronomical
amounts of rent to college stu
dents? The town is selling their

soul to rent their properties and
they still have the audacity to
complain when college kids do
not treat them with respect.
Basically, I would like to say
that some of the landlords here
are thieves. As college students
we are very limited in the prop
erties that we can rent. Have
some integrity and break up
your monopoly of rental prop
erties and earn the respect of
the students. I can site numer
ous examples of houses that
four to six college students pay
more than $3,600 per person
to rent a house for one year that
often does not include utilities.
Also, these rentals are often
safety hazards and show land
lords' ability to count money,

but not to spend it. I just don't
understand how the rentals in
Gettysburg can be priced like
they're on Park Avenue. Actu
ally, I think I know why—Be
cause we have no choice if we
don't want to live on campus.
Wake up Gettysburg and stop
playing this elitist game. You
complain about empty kegs and
I'll complain about
Gettysburg's homeless, va
grants, crack, and thieving mo
nopolistic landlords. Don't
you people have something
more worthwhile to attend to?
I know I do.
Sincerely,
Michael J. Holm '99


CONFLICT & Consensus
Musical Tribute to Professor DeClair

TU .1 C.
To the Editor

Tragedy

To the Editor:
I bemoan the musical
tragedy that occurred in the
CUB on Saturday, April 18.
Ziggy Marley and the Melody
Makers were wonderful as
usual (I think), but our ears
were deprived of the experi
ence. Why? Because the deep
bass was cranked so loud that
it distorted and covered the rest
of the sound spectrum. This
made it virtually impossible to
hear the lyrics, or to appreci
ate the subtlety of the instru
mental mix. I felt as if I were

being buffeted by the wind, and
it rattled my entire body.
I complained to three dif
ferent people by the sound
board, none of whom seemed
neither to have any authority
nor care to pass the word to
anybody who did. When I
spoke to the man in charge as
he walked by me, he wouldn't
and/or couldn't hear me. Ev
eryone else I talked to agreed
with me that it was too loud,
including both students and old
fogies like me.
Ziggy's brand of reggae is

joyful, spiritual, and (often)
lyrically significant. It doesn't
need to be blasted and distorted
to make an impact. And it
wasn't when I heard them at
Yale 4 1/2 years ago. What a
pity that Gettysburg College
was deprived of a similar ex
perience due to the behavior of
the contracted audio firm that
handled our concert.
After an hour I gave up
and left. Outside the building

I saw people dancing to the
sound of "Raw Riddim" and
rattling windows. At home I
played my three Ziggy Marley
CDs to replace bad vibes with
good. We have heard great con
certs in the CUB before. I'll
never forget Squeeze and Flock
of Seagulls in the early 80s, and
the more recent Violent
Femmes concert. It can hap
pen again if somebody can con
trol the sound contractor.

Sincerely,
Charles F. Emmons,
Music lover

For the past five years
Professor Edward G. DeClair
has given his knowledge and
foresight in an effort to better
prepare his students for the
adversities they may face in the
real world. His unique style of
teaching, while sometimes con
troversial, offers his students an
educational experience wholly
different from the rather bor
ing and mundane styles so
prevalent on this campus. His
methodology of treating his
students like the adults they
supposedly are and should be,
along with his refusal to mol¬

lycoddle those who have no
desire to learn, often offends
people. Yet for those who wish
to receive an excellent educa
tion, above and beyond the ut
terances of a textbook, he
shines as an educator who
genuinely cares about the well
being of his students. It is our
position that the denial of ten
ure to this excellent professor
was a grave mistake, made by
those who care too much about
catering to the infantile few and
not enough about the values of
a superior education. Yet this
forum is not for rehashing is¬

sues that have long since passed
us by, but instead, formally say
ing goodbye to the man who
gave many of us the greatest
educational experience of our
lives. While many who have
taken a class taught by Profes
sor DeClair may agree with the
statements made in this article,
only those who have taken his
European Union: Policy and
Progress course can appreciate
fully, the professor, the man,
and the paramount importance
of his presence. The culmina
tion of a semester of immense

work and research is the Euro
pean Union Simulation in
Washington D.C. The three
day simulation is not only an
opportunity for students to use
the acquired knowledge in a
practical manner, but stands
alone as the only practical uti
lization of knowledge, incorpo
rating both academics and life
skills. For those who partici
pate, a commitment is made
not only to Professor DeClair,
but to their fellow students as
well. It is a commitment to
learn and work together, not
only through the course of the

semester, but representing Get
tysburg at the simulation,
which involves thirteen other
schools. Each year this simu
lation is dominated by Gettys
burg and this year was no dif
ferent. From December 4-7,
Professor Declair's students
performed at a level that far ex
ceeded their colleagues from
other schools. Their level of
preparation was noticeably bet
ter than the other participating
schools. For its participants,
obvious credit should be given

to Professor DeClair for pre
paring his students in a man
ner that allowed them to rep
resent Gettysburg in a way that
all would be proud. To profes
sor DeClair, who gives so much
of his time to insure the suc
cess of his students, we say
Thank You. You have given us
memories, which we shall
never forget; for that we are
eternally grateful. Wherever
you may go, you will be re
membered not only as a great
professor, but a wonderful man
as well.
Thank you and good
luck!


EU class. Fall 1997

To the Editor:

For almost two years I
have observed the system of
our residential staff. In this
time I have come to the con
clusion that this system is a
mockery of the same ideals that
Gettysburg College so fervently
espouses: unconditional equal
ity and unbiased action. The
first page of the Student Hand
book states that, "It is the
policy of Gettysburg College
not to discriminate improperly
against any matriculated stu
dent, employee or prospective
employee on account of race,
color, religion, ethnic or na
tional origin, age, gender,
sexual orientation, or being dif¬

ferently abled."
However, the college
gives distinct and empowering
abilities to a select few and
leaves the vast majority impo
tent and "differently abled." As
mere matriculating commoners
we are left to the disposal of
the elite R.A. class. This is not
equality. One can respect the
logically-appointed hand of a
college administrator, but he
surely cannot respect the im
pulsive fist of his fellow stu
dent. It is hardly uncommon
for R.A.s to become authoritar
ian or experience delusions of
grandeur. And all too often

there is a grievous abuse of
authority. R.A.s are best
known for their unwarranted
"power-trips" and wanton dis
regard for their fellow students.
Like the Gestapo of old,
R.A.s frequently take pleasure
in the misfortunes of their resi
dents. They notoriously boast
of their citations, trophying the
enormity of the subsequent
fines. Concepts of fraternity
and confidence are surely lost
in this deceitful power struc
ture. R.A.'s need nothing more
than the cross of a "t", to be
seen for what they really are:
RATS.
Name Witheld Upon Request

Abroad

-from
Experiencing other cultures is
the way to dissipate that
cloud...if only every student
was required to experience
other cultures (because some
irrationally choose not to),
whether by going abroad, do
ing a service learning project,
or some other way...but per
haps I am being too hopeful.
All I can do, as one who is de
parting, gladly (because I'm
ready to move on), yet sadly
(because I wish I could be
around a little longer to ap-

page 11
preciate the wonderful
changes that have been hap
pening here and help initiate
more) is encourage those who
remain: go away, but while
you're here, do something.
Gettysburg College is finally
progressing rapidly; it can
only be blinded by the cloud
when people refuse to see the
beauty outside, and reel that
beauty in with persistence and
enthusiasm.
Stephanie Sellars

Noon Math Colloquium 212 Gla
Dr. L. Car ) Leinbach, Gettysburg
College, "What Is This Matrix
Telling Me?"
Matrices, or tables of numbers, are
representations of operators on a
vector space that preserve the
essential operations of vector addition
and scalar multiplication. They have
applications in many important areas
including mechanics, fluid flow,
ecology, probability theory, engineer
ing, and communications. A key to
understanding the behavior of a
matrix is its factorization. In this
talk, we look at a particular factoriza
tion, the Singular Value Decomposi
tion • and how it can be used - via a
simple, albeit incomplete, example
from communications. ALL STU
DENTS AND FACULTY ARE
INVITED.

The Writing Center: CUB 240

Monday-Thursday: 11 a.m.-l 1 pm
Friday: 11 a.m.-3 p.m.
Sunday: 1 p.m.-11 p.m.
AND
The Writing Center: Huber Hall
Monday-Thursday: 8 p.m.-10 p.m.
At the center peer tutors and
faculty members will help students
clarify an assignment, plan for an
assignment, organize a paper,
suggest ways to make troublesome
parts within a piece of writing
more effective, or discuss general
writing difficulties. The staff will
not proofread, edit, or ghostwrite
papers. Students can call X7576 or
drop in.

Allies is a campus organization
funded by the Student Senate,
founded to raise community aware
ness on issues related to sexual
orientation. The organization is
composed of students, faculty,
administrators, and support staff of
all orientations who share a com
mitment to creating and maintain
ing a supportive and nurturing
Gettysburg environment for gay,
lesbian, and bisexual persons.
Allies meets every Monday from
12 noon to 1 p.m. in room 230 of

Dear Gettysburg College Community,
The Office of Student Activities is
proposing to no longer publish This Week
At Gettysburg (T.W.A.G.) in the
"Gettysburgian." We can no longer justify
the cost of providing T.W.A.G. since the
same information can be accessed via
CNAV at no cost.
We are requesting input from the
Gettysburg College Community
concerning this proposed action.
Please email Diann Cooper,
dkcooper@gettysburg.edu, with your
comments.
Thank you.

Forget about raising the roof... raise the rim

by Bill Davidson
Staff Reporter
Basketball is a game ot
passing, cutting, and shooting
that requires skill, balance, and
grace. This is still true at the
amateur level, but the National
Basketball Association (NBA) is
another story. Taller, stronger
athletes dominate the game. To
continue popularity, the NBA
needs to adjust its rules to ac
commodate these phenomenal
players.
The evolution of NBA
athletes is evident when com
paring teams of different eras.
The average height of the
1959-60 World Champion
Boston Celtics was 6'4", while
the 1997-98 Los Angeles Lak
ers average a height of 6'8".

During the 1960_'s a leg
endary giant dominated the
NBA. Wilt Chamberlain, a 72"
giant possessing astounding
speed, towered over the com
petition like a redwood in a
scrub forest. His supremacy
peaked in the 1961-62 season
when he averaged an unprec-

¦e de _ited hfty points per game.
To reduce Chamberlain's domi
nance, the NBA intervened,
widening the three-second lane
by four feet, forcing him to play
farther from the basket. The
rule change was needed, and it
worked to a certain extent.
Since the 1960's, the aes
thetics of the game have
changed. Today, there are sev
eral NBA centers with Cham
berlain-like attributes. Patrick
Ewing, Shaquille O'Neal, and
David Robinson all possess ex
ceptional speed and jumping
ability to accompany their tre
mendous height. Guards and
forwards have also followed
this trend. Tall, rangy athletes
_snch as Eddie Jones have cre
ated a new generation of guard
play-

Forwards close to 7' such
as Kevin Garnett possess the
agility of guards. As a result,
these oversized players have
created a claustrophobic game
above the rim. To counter this,
the NBA needs to make a
monumental rule change that
would drastically improve the

game. Raising the basket six
inches would revive passing,
cutting, and shooting, ingredi
ents which used to be essential
in the NBA. All NBA players
would need to utilize funda
mental skills. Dominating cen¬

ters and leaping forwards
would no longer be able to
dunk at will. Instead of dunk
ing, they would need to en
hance their Herculean power
with finesse. Undoubtedly
these players would respond to
this change by developing their
skills, thus restoring the purity
of the game.
The majority of dunks in
a NBA game are no longer en
tertaining. Watching giants

such as Shaquille O'Neal barely
leave the ground before thrust
ing the ball through the hoop
is simply not fun to watch.
Raising the height of the rim
would solve this problem.
Most players would still be able
to dunk, but they would do so
less frequently. Therefore,
dunk shots would once again
be appreciated. And, fans
would respond to the fresh
game above the rim.
The six-inch theory faces
three common arguments.
Most people feel that the his
tory oi the game would be jeop
ardized, making past, present,
and future records incompa
rable. Second, people who
think the height adjustment is
a good idea are still skeptical
because they feel all baskets at
every level of play would need
to change accordingly. Finally,
many critics feel the change
would hamper shooting.

The NBA, like most pro
fessional sport leagues, has
tinkered with subtle rule
changes throughout its history.
In 1979 they added the three
point arc to generate more

scoring and in the process cre
ated a more enjoyable game for
fans. A rim adjustment in high
school or college basketball
would be ludicrous. At these
levels, the game is played in its
purest form, below the rim.
Only in the NBA are seven
footers abundant. Only in the
NBA do 6'10" forwards possess
forty-eight inch vertical leaps.
Only in the NBA does the av
erage guard approach six-and
a-half feet.
Incoming players would
need time to adjust to the dif
ferent rim height, but the tran
sition would not be difficult.
After several weeks of practice,
any player would realize that
it is not a substantially higher
target at which to shoot.

For NBA fans there is
no need to panic. The game
will not be ruined. Kobe
Bryant would still deliver acro
batic dunks; Reggie Miller
would still drain three's, silenc
ing raucous crowds; and
Michael Jordan would still be
the most talented man to ever
play the game.



Bateman shoots his way into the record books

Bullet bats battling barrage
of close games

by Henry Fawell
Assistant News Editor
The Bullets used this past
week wisely by scoring two big
wins and continuing to nail
down their chances for the

pionship.
Consecutive victories
over Dickinson and Swarth
more, both conference oppo
nents, improved the Bullets'

share of the conference crown.

burg travelled north to Carlisle
where the Dickinson Red Dev
ils were looking for their first
conference win of the season.

the Devils may have had by
racking up a dominating 27-2
win, where fifteen different
players scored for the Bullets.

Lowery each tallied five goals
in the win. In the past two sea
sons the Bullets have beaten
Dickinson by a combined score
of 57-4.

Despite skid, laxsters learning

from Staff Reports
As of late the young Lady
Bullets lacrosse team has been
running into some tough com
petition. The Bullets have been
playing well, but their oppo
nents have been putting up
some tough competition.
After winning four times
in a span of five games from
March 26 through April 11, the
Bullets (5-7, 5-3 conference)
have suffered consecutive
losses to nationally ranked op
ponents Drew and William
Smith.
Through 11 games, se
nior Chrissy Nordoff is the
Bullets leading scorer with 34
goals and seven assists.
Nordoff leads the team in as
sists with sophmore Amy
Stambaugh, who has had 17
goals to go along with her seven

assists.
Freshman Michelle
Centrella has been the Bullets
starting goalie the whole sea
son and has saved close to 80
shots. Statistics prove these
women have had some tough
games. To date the Bullets have
scored 121 goals, while their
opponents have scored 122.
The Bullets have gotten off 336
shots while their oppoents have
only totalled 284 shots.
The team has registered
36 assists to their opponents'
25, and have also out- hustled
their opponents gaining 298
ground balls to their challeng
ers' 220.
In recent action, the Lady
Bullets took on the Lady Dip
lomats frnm F &" M. Once

again super-senior Kristin
Sullivan (17 goals, 3 assists) is
leading the team with her abil¬

ity and heart, as she endless
romps up and down the field.
The Bullets made a great
effort against the Diplomats
and played with all the inten
sity of a locomotive train, but
came up short in the end, los
ing 17-11.
The team has the talent
and they fight until the final
whistle blows, but the fact re
mains that this particular group
of women has only played to
gether for 12 games.
With mostly an under
classman starting contingent,
this squad, though packed with
talent, may just need one thing:
time. Though this season is
drawing to a close, along with
the carrers of Nordoff and
Sullivan, this group of Bullet
women hope to open eyes in
the future, with talent, heart
and experiences.

Women defend crown at Messiah, men compete well

by Erika Durst
Contributing Reporter
Strong performances
were recorded by the men's
and women's track and field
teams on Saturday at the Mes
siah Invitational. Although
both teams were set back due
to illness and schedule con
flicts, the women defended
their invitational title and the
men finished strong placing
sixth. The women's team bet
tered its record by sweeping the
18-team invitational. The Bul
lets finished with 117 points,
while Dickinson was second
with 111. Other strong teams
included Roberts Wesleyan,
Susquehanna, and Lebanon
Valley.

Leading the Gettysburg
women with individual efforts
was Tabitha Gary, whose per
sonal bests of 35-0 3/4 in the
triple jump and 16-2 1/2 in the
long jump earned her first place
in both events. Karen Helmick
lead the distance squad with a
personal record of 5:10.2,
good for 6th place, and a 5 th
place finish in the 3000m run.
Other personal bests in
clude Michelle Fields' 71.48
debut in the 400m hurdles, and
Kelley Lord's 43:50.98 effort
in the 10000m run.

The women's 400m relay
team of Keri Hymen, Jackie
Klug, Emily Brown, and Andi
Therit set a new school record
with a time of 51.01. Cathy
Spangler lead the women's field
events finishing seventh place
in the shot-put, a sixth in the
discus and fourth in the ham
mer throw.
The men's team, while
missing several key athletes,
posted many exemplary perfor
mances. Gene Kraus set a new
school record with his hammer
throw of 120-9, good enough
for a runner-up title. Nathan

Grim was the shot-put winner,
recording a new invitational
record at 51-5 1/4.
The men's distance team
was headed by Jon Catlett,
placing third in the steeple
chase (9:52.96) and eighth in
the 800m run (2:02.64), and
Dave Gary, completing 25 laps
in 34:15.58, for a third place
in thelOOOOm run, and record
ing a fourteenth place in the
800m Run. Will Hanema
achieved a personal best of 12
feet in the pole vault, while
running well in the 400m run
and 1600m Relay.

Members of the Bullet
team will compete in the Penn
Relays in Philadelphia, on
Thursday and Friday, and will
return to vie for titles at the

SportsWeekly
Softball team rides roller-coaster to conference title

by Bill Davidson
Staff Reporter The Gettysburg softball
team experienced a roller
coaster week, hitting several
peaks and valleys before find
ing themselves back where
they had started.
A sweep of F 8c M,
paired with a Western Mary
land loss, left the Lady Bullets
in a first place tie with the
Green Terror atop the Centen
nial Conference. Then they
rolled over Albright in a non-

conference doubleheader and
were seemingly gaining mo
mentum for the weekend se
ries against conference foe
Muhlenberg. However, the
women were tripped up by the
Mules in the opener 6-5, be
fore earning the split with a 7
5 comeback victory in the sec
ond game. When the dust
cleared, they found themselves
in a familiar position, one
game behind Western Mary
land for the Centennial Con
ference lead.

In Lancaster, Melissa
Hazzard pitched 4 and 1/3 in
nings of shutout relief, while
scattering 3 hits to earn the 5-

4 victory over F &: M.
Emily Boardman singled
in the tying and what would
prove to be the winning run in
the 6th. Jill Murphy and
Marybeth Korejko once again
provided solid defensive play, in
addition to contributing multi
hit games.
In the twinbill finale,
Suzzanne Dailey was brilliant,
outdueling the Diplomats 2-0 in
a game, which did not feature
an extra base hit. Traci Bullock's
RBI single and Sara Gravehne's
sacrifice fly supplied the only of
fensive support.
The women were cruel
hosts to Albright on Thursday
outsconng them 21-5 in the
doubleheader. Graveline led
the balanced onslaught in the
first game, going three-for-three
with one RBI and two runs
scored.

Jody Noel scored three
runs, converting two walks into
stolen bases, while Sara Stokes
picked up the 11-3 win. In the
second game, Katelynn Gorton
tossed a three-hitter, allowing 0
earned runs en route to a con
vincing 10-2 triumph. Bullock
and Murphy each went 1 for 2,

Lambda Chi Alpha to become student housing
Fraternity leaves house due to financial woes

by Laura Root
Staff Reporter The house that
has belonged to the
Lambda Chi Alpha fra
ternity for years is set
to become student
housing next year. It
will stay that way for
the next two to five
years. According to
College administra
tors, fanancial troubles
and the fraternity's
small size contributed
to the decision to lease
the house.
Two years ago,
the Lambda Chi house,
located on West Broad
way, went through
some major renova
tions. To pay for these
renovations, a loan had
to be taken out.

Because of the
loan, the brotherhood
is in debt. To pay back
the debt, the Alumni
Corporation of
Lambda Chi (who
owns the house) decided
be in the best interest of

to lease their house.
The house will be leased to the
College for a maximum of five years.
At the end of each year, the fraternity
has the option to buy out the house's
occupants and move into the house the
following year.

Photo by Emily Glatfelter ternity meetings and
The Lambda Chi Alpha house on West Broadway will become student housing in the fall. The fraternity functions but do not
plans to move back into the house within two to five years. llve in the same

that it would
the fraternity

According to Assistant Dean of
the College and Director of Greek Or
ganizations, Dennis Murphy, the
fraternity's return to their house could
take anywhere from two to five years.
The house will be open to the
brothers for receptions and meetings
during Alumni and Homecoming
Weekends.

Current chapter president, An
thony Futia insisted that the fraternity
will remain active on campus, and
hoped to move the brothers back into
the house "in the shortest possible time."
Murphy said that the house will
most likely become Honors Housing
next year. To prepare for its new resi
dents, the house will undergo some mi¬

nor renovations in
cluding a new paint
job. The use of the
Lambda Chi house
for student housing
will help to alleviate
the current housing
shortage on campus,
which has increased
the number of stu
dents living off cam
pus. The College
has current plans to
reduce the number
of students living off
campus to 200 by
the year 2000 (see
article on page 4).
Until they re
turn to the house,
Lambda Chi broth
ers will be living in
residence halls on
campus. During this
time, it will be a
"non-residential fra
ternity," where
brothers attend fra-

house.
Currently, the Lambda Chi Alpha
fraternity has 18 members. According
to Dean Murphy, that is not a large
enough membership to continue as a
brotherhood. But beyond the issue of
membership, the greater problem that
Lambda Chi faces is sustaining increas
ing costs of living while they remain in
a large amount of debt.

Gallman named first Luce Professor

GCPR J. Matthew Gallman,
professor of history at Loyola
College in Baltimore, has been
named the Henry R. Luce Pro
fessor of the Civil War Era at
Gettysburg College. The first
person to be named to this
newly established position,
Gallman will begin teaching
and administrative duties of the
position in the fall.
Gallman was selected
for the post after an extensive
national search. The College

was awarded a six year grant
of approximately $600,000 last
year from the Henry Luce
Foundation to establish a pro
fessorship in the Civil War era.
Gallman will lead an under
graduate program in Civil War
studies and will develop and
direct "The Gettysburg Semes
ter," a program through which
college students from across
the country will come to
Gettysburg College for a se
mester of intensive interdisci
plinary study of the Civil War

era. "This
is a signifi
cant faculty
appointment
to a presti
gious profes
s o r s h i p , "
said Daniel

provost of
Gettysburg
College.

Gallman's

combina
tion. Build

considerable

resources
available at

Henniger receives Goldwater scholarship Luce

by Henry Fawell
Assistant News Editor
Dr. Hans Mark, Chair
man of the Board of Trustees
of the Barry M. Goldwater
Scholarship and Excellence in
Education Foundation, re
cently announced that the
Trustees have awarded 316
scholarships for the 1998-99
school year to undergraduate
sophomores and juniors from
the fifty states.
Jay L. Henniger, a jun
ior physics and mathematics
major at Gettysburg College,
was one of the recipients.
Henniger, a native of Seattle,
Washington, has studied exten
sively in the fields of as
tronomy, with Dr. Larry
Marshall, and combinatorial
mathematics, under Dr. Bela
Bajnok.

Henniger is an active
member of the Society of Phys
ics Students and the Math
ematical Association of
America. In January, Henniger
and his partner Andy Danner
received Honorable Mention at
the student poster session at the

national MAA meeting in Bal
timore. The Goldwater Schol
ars were selected on the basis
of academic merit from a field
of 1,186 mathematics, science,
and engineering students who
were nominated by the facul
ties of colleges and universities
nationwide. One hundred and
eighty-three of the Scholars are
men, 133 are women, and vir
tually all intend to obtain a
Ph.D in their respective areas
of study. Nineteen scholars are
mathematics majors, 215 are
science majors, 20 are major
ing in engineering, and 62 have
dual majors in a variety of
mathematics, science, engineer
ing and computing disciplines
The one and two year
scholarships will cover the cost
of tuition, fees, books, and
room and board up to a maxi
mum of $7,500 per year.

The Scholarship Pro
gram honoring Senator Barry
M. Goldwater was designed to
foster and encourage outstand
ing students to pursue careers
in the fields of mathematics,

science and engineering. The
Goldwater Scholarship is the
premier undergraduate award
of its type in these fields.
The Foundation, now
in its tenth year, has, to date,
awarded 2,407 scholarships
worth approximately twenty
five million dollars. The Trust
ees plan to award about three
hundred scholarships for the
1999-2000 academic year.

College close to obtaining $48 million bond
Funds to pay for construction of new student housing

by Henry Fawell
Assistant News Editor
Gettysburg College is on
the verge of obtaining a $48
million bond issue from the
Gettysburg Municipal Author
ity, following a 6-2 borough
council vote Monday.
The bond will be used by
the College mainly to help fi
nance construction of new
buildings and the renovations
oi old ones. As a result, the
College hopes to minimize the
number of students living off
campus.
Members of the Hazel

Alley Association, an organiza
tion formed by area residents
to deal with off-campus hous
ing problems, have requested a
commitment from the College
that the number of students liv
ing offcampus be reduced to
200 by the upcoming fall se
mester.
Gordon Haaland, presi
dent of the College, has yet to
comply to this commitment,
despite college efforts to lower
the number by reducing admis
sions next fall and adding 150
on-campus beds by 2000.
The college's plans in
clude the construction of a new

science facility, which would
then open up dorm space, as
the present science building
would be converted into col
lege housing.
The College has already
made some immediate efforts
to alleviate the housing prob
lem. The purchase of a prop
erty on North Washington
Street and the lease of the
Lambda Chi fraternity house
(see front page) are some of
these efforts.
While the borough was
pleased by the efforts, their
overriding concern was the
college's plan to curb the un¬

civil behavior of some of its stu
dents. In an article run by The
Gettysburg Times President
Haaland said, "We have a di
lemma. We invite a group of
intelligent, ambitious young
people. They are teenagers, but
college is a time of change. We
need to use appropriate re
straints and still understand
that young people are differ
ent." These restraints may in
clude programs designed to fa
miliarize students with life
within the community, and an
orientation program for stu¬

dents who plan to live off-cam
pus. The borough council is
also doing its part to quell stu
dent behavior. An ordinance is
being discussed among the pub
lic safety Committee that would
require landlords to regulate
the behavior of student tenants.
Some behavioral prob
lems mentioned by residents
have been excessive porch fur
niture and students sunbathing
on roofs.
Concerning the council's
demands on the college, one
Gettysburg resident told The
Gettysburg Times, "If nothing
else, we got their attention."

Lukewarm L Baltimore

by George Spelvin
Contributing Reviewer
The Hot L Baltimore, the
Owl and Nightingale Players
spring production by Lanford
Wilson, is a play about a once
elegant hotel left to rot along
with its tenants until finally it
is set to be demolished. This
description does not describe
the production, and I think
that, with a couple of excep
tions, the presentation was an
elaborate success.
Directed by George
Muschamp, the gritty, realistic
drama t came to life. No easy
script to direct, Muschamp
handled the blocking brilliantly.
Everyone on stage had much
"business," yet nothing was dis
tracting. His direction of the
final fight scenes at the ends of
Acts I and II began minimally
and then little by little he added

tension; the pattern of crosses

increased the stress level and
finally the big explosion ar¬

rived. I do question the open
ing tableau. For me, it left
something unfinished. I ex
pected perhaps a da capo fin
ish or some reason for the ac
tors to be in those specific
places. In a show that is 100%
realistic, the freeze just didn't
make sense.
I also had a problem with
the third act. Now, this is not
the fault of the director or any
of the actors, but of Lanford
Wilson's. One word sums up
the final act—anticlimactic.
After the fight at the end of Act
II between Morse, Jackie, and
Katz, to have such a "blah" act
can only mean poor writing.
Additionally, some of the
loose ends seemed untied.
What will happen to everyone

in the hotel after the demoli
tion? Who knows?
The rest of the play, how
ever, was full of conflict, ten
sion, and interesting dialogue.
Also, the theme, as Muschamp
puts it in the program, of the
threatening demise of human
spontaneity appropriately ap
plies to today.
As far as the visual ele
ments, the set designed by Brian
Hershfeld was, in a word, fan
tastic. I felt as though I was
actually in a ' hotel lobby. The
detail work of the stairs, ' the
marbling, the-_^flats, etc., im
pressed me immensely. Kudos
to Anne Semple for her set
decoration. One thing did
bother me, for it _seamed quite
out of place —the mural on the
stage left catwalk. Although
drawn and painted well, it just
conflicted with the other set el
ements.

The lighting, also de
signed by Mr. Hershfeld,
worked efficiently. It was un
obtrusive and nondistracting.
However, the fade ins and outs
occurred a bit too slowly, al
lowing the audience's attention
to wander. Thank goodness for
the music; otherwise the audi
ence would have been far too
gone during the changes.
The costuming was ap
propriate, as was most of the
makeup. April (Mary Cordero)
could have used a bit more age
makeup, however.
The acting was Very good
as well. Not one cast member
really could qualify as miscast
or as a "bad actor." Overall,
the actors handled the difficult
timing with success at most
points. All were very believ
able in the massive fight scene
at the end of act one.
However, as with any

production, there were some
standouts. Duncan Niederer as
Mr. Morse knew exactly what
he was doing. More impres
sive than his speaking lines was
his ability to just sit around
during Act III. It takes great
concentration to act when say
ing nothing, and he certainly
deserves applause for his silent
performance in that final act.
Additionally, I loved his
checker-fight with Jaime (Paul
Lapato).
Brad Cerilli as Bill Lewis
also performed well. His fa
cial expressions were excellent.
He had the most stage business
of any of the actors and not
once could I say he was dis
tracting or unrealistic.
Colleen Hubbard as
Millie played the old southern
- continued on page 7 -
see HOT L


Reel Hits & Misses _ T r . A
Falling Angels

by Dan Larktn and Mike Petro
Movie Columnists
Do you believe in angels?
Maybe you do or maybe you
don't. Perhaps your faith
might tell stories of angels and
you take their existence on
faith, and perhaps you just
think it is all just myths and
fairy tales.
Angels are certainly all
the rage these days. They're on
all sorts of pins and bumper
stickers, and there's that annoy
ing TV show that my mom likes
so much. So, I fi gured that City
of Angels would be yet another
f oray into pop spirituality.
The new movie City of
Angels takes a look at the an
gels of our world. According
to the story, angels are all
around us and even though we
cannot see them, they are al
ways there. They hear music
in the sunrise, feel no pain or
other human emotions, can
read anyone's mind, and are

messengers of God. These di
vine beings operate around us
all the time.
One such messenger,
Seth, turns up one day during
a heart surgery that has gone
wrong. During the trauma of
the moment, the chief surgeon,
Dr. Maggie Rice, played by
Meg Ryan (Joe vs. the Volcano,
Amityville 3-D) while working
feverishly on her dying patient,
sees Seth in the room and hears
him too. The patient dies; Seth
had come for him.
Maggie, confused and
bewildered, ends up in a stair
well sobbing, thoughts of what
went wrong spinning in her
head, and as she cries, Seth is
there, longing to reveal himself
to her, yet knowing nothing of
what he feels inside.

This turns out to be the
telling moment of the film: it
is where Seth, played with
charm and charisma by Nicho
las Cage (Zandalee, Trapped in
Paradise), falls in love with

Maggie.
Cage is one of my favor
ite actors, though he's been
slumming since Leaving Las
Vegas, but even his mediocre
performances are pretty good.
He does an okay job in this
movie, but he doesn't act so
much as stare soulfully at Meg
Ryan throughout the movie.
Troubled by his thoughts
of love, and intrigued by the
interaction he wants to have
with Maggie, Seth seeks coun
sel with his partner of sorts,
Cassiel, played by Homicide's
Andr e Braugher. Seth learns
of the ability for an angel to
"fall" to earth and become hu¬

man. This part reminded me a
lot o/"Superman II, when Clark
gives up his powers in order to
have a relationship with Lois.
And Nick Cage will be playing
Superman in a new movie next
year. Ah, the irony.
The rest of the movie fo
cuses around the conflict of

emotions between the two
main characters and the
struggle each has with their
emotions. Both are assisted in
understanding by Nathaniel
Messinger, a fallen angel him
self, played extremely well by
Dennis Franz (Sipowicz!), a joy
in a often sad movie.
I'm a big fan of Dennis
Franz on NYPD Blue, but I was
worried when I saw that he was
in this, we wouldn't see his na
ked butt. I shouldn 't have wor
ried. He does a pretty good job
with the acting.
This is a well put to
gether, if not sometimes sappy
love story. I love the visual
imagery of the movie and I like
the conceptualization of what
an angel is. I think it works as
a romance and as a means to
spiritual exploration.

The actors are very good
together as well. Franz and
Braugher give solid perfor
mances that are reflective of
their excellent talents, and

Cage and Ryan are both excel
lent in their own right.
The visuals of this movie
are very impressive. I liked the
scenes with the angels on the
rooftops. It wasn't over-the-top
special effects wizardry, like
Fifth Element (about which I
might have been a little over
zealous in an earlier statement
I made about the Oscars), but
just really nice camera shots.
This is a very watchable
film and I found myself liking
it very much. For a good,
thought provoking and roman
tic movie to cleanse your pal
ate before the summer explo
sion fest, see City of Angels*
Three and a half out of five

stars. I can't say that I found
this movie thought-provoking
It made me sad. I guess you
could call it tear-provoking?
Though fairly predictable, City
of Angels is a nice romantic
tear-jerker. Two and seven
eighths stars (out of five).

80's Brat Pack flick provokes laughter and thought

In Case You Missed It

by Eileen O'Donnell
Movie Columnist
What happens when five
teenagers are locked together
in a library for a whole Satur
day? John Hughes' moving tale
about teen angst, The Breakfast
Club, asks this question.
Starring Molly Ringwald
(Pretty in Pink, Sixteen
Candles), Emiho Estevez
(Maximum Overdrive), Ally
Sheedy (Maid to Order), An
thony Michael Hall (Weird Sci
ence), and Judd Nelson (TV's

Suddenly Susan), The Breakfast
Club was released at the height
of Brat Pack fame. These five
stars were the stock actors and
actresses for adolescent films of
the early to mid 1980's.
Ringwald and Hall starred to
gether in Sixteen Candles.
Nelson, Sheedy, and Estevez
were all together again in St.
Elmo's Fire, which also starred
Rob Lower, Andi MacDowell_,
Demi Moore, and Andrew
McCarthy.
An emotionally complex

film, The Breakfast Club has
very little action. The setting
is a Saturday detention in the
library of Shermer High School

i n
Shermer, I
Illinois.
The five
students,
Andy Clark,
the Jock I
(Estevez);
Brian
Johnson,
the Brain
(Hall);
John Bender,
the Criminal (Nelson);
Claire

Standish, the Princess
(Ringwald); and Allison
Reynolds, the Basket Case
(Sheedy), are required to write
an essay saying who they think
they are.
On the surface, The
Breakfast Club is a movie about

five kids who are serving de
tention for breaking various
rules. On this level, the movie
elicits both laughter and tears

as the students antagonize the
detention monitor, Mr. Vernon
(Paul Gleason_, the nemesis of
Eddie Murphy and Dan
Aykroyd in Trading Places) and
each other.
On a much deeper level,
Hughes explores stereotypes,

generalizations, and confor
mity. He attempts to make
sense of a teenager's need to fit
in and be accepted by his or her
peers.

Not
only
does
Hughes
explore
the atti
tudes of
teenag
ers to
wards
their
peers,
but he
also ex
amines the rela
tionships of teens
The film

with their parents.
begins with each kid being
dropped off by his or her par
ents. Interestingly, Brian's
mother is played by Hall's real
mother, Mercedes Hall. And
making a cameo as Brian's fa
ther is Hughes.

Mr. Vernon, meanwhile,
sees the students under his care
in the broadest terms and in the
most convenient categories, not
for the people they are.
Hughes directed many "of
the Brat Pack films that we can
all remember. He is respon
sible for Sixteen Candles, Pretty
in Pink, Ferris Bueller's Day
Off, Some Kind of Wonderful,
and Weird Science.
Hughes has also directed
National Lampoon's Vacation,
European Vacation, and Christ
mas Vacation, as well as Uncle
Buck, Mr. Mom, The Great
Outdoors, and Home Alone 1
3. The film is full of honest
feelings, and the dialogue is
brutally frank. The Breakfast
Club is one of those rare films
that makes you think, but
makes you laugh at the same
time.

If you take anything away
from this movie, remember
this: "Screws fall out all the
time; the world's an imperfect
place." -John Bender



GECO winners

by Kyle Heulitt
GECO Columnist

The results from
G.E.C.O.'s first annual Poetry
and Essay Contest are in, and
the winners are: first place, a
$50 gift certificate to the Blue
Parrot, goes to sophomore
Ashley Binter; second place, a
$20 gift certificate to K&K
Records, goes to junior Julie
Ann Calamaras; and third
place, a G.E.C.O. mug, goes to
senior Stephanie Sellars.
Thanks to everyone who en
tered! Also, thanks to the Envi
ronmental Science Department
and Student Senate for helping
judge the contest.
Our third place winner,
Stephanie, agreed to have her
entry published in the paper, so
here it is:

thing catches my eye.
A black form, a few feet
to my right, sits in the sand. 1
approach the figure and I can
see that it moves, awkwardly
No, it hobbles, crippled. As 1
get closer, it tries to move away
but it can't; it struggles as if the
beach has suddenly become
quicksand.
I am close enough to see
what it is now, a creature of the
air, imprisoned on the earth by
a blackness, cruel and unnatu
ral. Her eyes are shut, glued
by the black goo that separates
her feathers into stiff spikes,
like a porcupine, but these
spikes are no defense mecha
nism; they are an encumbrance,
rather, heavy chains that pre
vent her from taking flight as
she was born to do.

It's still a beautiful day
Blue sky, hardly a cloud, but the
sun screams Icarus. I imagine
how that boy must have felt,
trying to defy nature with his
foolish wings. Invincible. But
he died of natural causes. This
bird, however, may never reach
the sun again. She will not
melt, but she may suffocate in
the black stains deposited by
the Icaruses of the earth.
I reach out, and pick up
the black, sticky mass of plum
age, as a tear falls from my sun
blocked face and mixes with
the sympathetic salt of the
ocean.

It's a beautiful day. Blue
sky, hardly a cloud, and a sun
that screams Helios. The UV
rays brighten every melancholy
face. A perfect day for the
beach. So I pack my 100% UV
resistant sunglasses and a bottle
of 15 SPF: skin cancer preven
tion fluid. As I walk along the
water's edge, black sand sticks
to my feet. I forgot my all
natural cork flip-flops. I wade
into the water to wash off the
gritty oil. While scraping the
sewage from my feet with a
piece of broken glass, some-
